text: Every other Tuesday,  Steven Petrow, the author of “Steven Petrow’s Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners,” (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

headline: A Start-Up Fund That Lets College Students Make the Decisions
text: Most college dormitories are a mixture of unmade beds, fireproof carpeting, beer pong, ramen noodles and that poster of John Belushi in “Animal House.” Investors want to add two more ingredients: successful start-ups and budding venture capitalists.

headline: Parking Rules
text: Because of the eighth day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: China Frees Frail Tibetan in Prison for Activism
text: BEIJING — A Tibetan activist whose long, harsh detention by Chinese authorities drew international scrutiny has been freed after serving 17 years in prison, exile groups reported on Tuesday.

headline: The Most Useless Exercise in Kenya?
text: LONDON — Although predictions are risky, here’s one I offer with absolute confidence: Traffic jams will return to Nairobi this week.

headline: Blackstone’s Curious Bid for Dell
text: The Blackstone Group’s interest in Dell seems to raise more questions than it answers, especially in light of Dell’s 274-page proxy filing about the process of selling the company. Is Blackstone “really bidding for Dell? Or is it part of a bizarre, high-stakes charade?” Andrew Ross Sorkin asks in the DealBook column.

headline: Lawmakers in New York Tied to Bribery Plot in Mayor Race
text: The two men sat in the state senator’s parked car in suburban Rockland County, but New York City was at the front of their minds and the focus of their conversation.

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
text: Spell-check can’t replace the keen eyes of an experienced editor.

headline: In Performance: ‘Hands on a Hardbody’
text: “Hands on a Hardbody,” a new Broadway musical at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, concerns a group of Texans vying to win a truck in an endurance test. The country-rock score was written by Trey Anastasio, of the jam-band Phish, and Amanda Green, who also wrote the lyrics. (Doug Wright wrote the book.) In this excerpt Mr. Anastasio, on guitar, accompanies the actors Allison Case and Jay Armstrong Johnson in “I’m Gone.”

headline: Incentives for Men, to Help Women to Work
text: As I wrote in an article appearing this week in The New York Times Magazine, if you want women to be bigger participants in the labor force, some expansion of work-life accommodations (parental leave, flex work, telecommuting, etc.) is probably desirable, particularly relative to the barren landscape of work-life policies in the United States.

headline: Q&A: Updating a BlackBerry (or Not)
text: Q.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Reducing Sodium in Your Diet
text: Reducing sodium in your diet, a better way to reunite lost items with their owners, women and marriage at Princeton and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Opinion Report: Medical Devices
text: From the editorial page

headline: Martin Scorsese Argues For Film Preservation in 2013 Jefferson Lecture
text: Drawing upon films that included Orson Welles’s “Citizen Kane,” Alfred Hitchcock’s “Vertigo” and Thomas Edison’s short of two cats engaged in a boxing match, Martin Scorsese made the case on Monday evening that Americans “need to take pride in our cinema, our great American art form” and that all films need to be preserved, regardless of their box-office performance or apparent cultural merit.

headline: $14 Million SAC Settlement Is Approved
text: On the same day prosecutors announced insider trading charges against a former portfolio manager at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, a judge signed off on a civil settlement between the fund and regulators related to the same set of facts.

headline: Cyprus Chief of Finance Quits Post
text: Michalis Sarris, the Cypriot finance minister who negotiated Cyprus’s bailout agreement with international creditors, resigned on Tuesday, citing the beginning of a government inquiry into the collapse of the country’s banking industry.

headline: Good Enough to Eat | Pieces of Porcelain
text: Just in time for all things springlike, the latest collection in the Pieces of Porcelain line from the Australian studio Mod Collective is available from Gretel Home. Mod Collective’s founder, the ceramicist Valissa Butterworth, combines digital design and hand-molding and casting to make these hard-to-resist bowls, plates and cups. She colors them with raw pigment, a process that allows her to use bold hues as well as delicate ones, and which ensures that even if a piece chips, you still see color all the way through. The exteriors are left unglazed, while a clear gloss glaze is used on the inside of the pieces to make them safe for food. Prices for the collection range from $32 to $149.

headline: Colorado Looks to Its Own People to Burnish Its Image
text: Colorado is taking a nontraditional approach to the usual efforts of creating ads that are meant to help burnish the brand image of a state. With an initiative — Making Colorado — to be announced on Tuesday, the state will ask its residents for advice that will shape the development of a campaign that is to be introduced in August.

headline: Mustard Fails Security Test at the Airport
text: Dear Diary,

headline: Could Verizon’s Best Friend Be Its Biggest Rival?
text: For years, Verizon and Vodafone have confronted a problem: what to do with Verizon Wireless, which they both own nearly equally?

headline: March Auto Sales Increased 3.4% for Highest Total Since 2007
text: DETROIT — Automakers reported on Tuesday that March sales of new cars and trucks were the highest monthly total in five years, providing more evidence of a sustained turnaround in the industry.

headline: Who Has the Most Exclusive Backstage Pass?
text: This past weekend’s article about the Yeah Yeah Yeahs features portraits by Robert Maxwell. But for a more candid look at the band, we asked the guitarist Nick Zinner to send us some of his most recent pictures of the group’s performances and travels. Zinner’s photography has been exhibited in art galleries and collected in four monographs. I asked him a few questions about his work.

headline: After Running S.E.C., Schapiro Becomes Bank Consultant
text: After more than three decades of policing Wall Street, Mary L. Schapiro is going to work for some if its biggest players.

headline: The Debate Over Welfare Reform in Britain … and Even France
text: LONDON — Iain Duncan Smith, a millionaire minister in Britain’s Conservative-led coalition government, was evidently tempting fate when he claimed this week that he could live on the equivalent of $11.50 a day.

headline: Daily Report: Pressured by China, Apple Apologizes for Warranty Policies
text: Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, took the unusual step on Monday of apologizing to Chinese customers over the company’s warranty policy and said he would improve customer service in the country, David Barboza and Nick Wingfield report in Tuesday’s New York Times.

headline: Grand St., an Online Boutique for Electronics, Raises $1.3 Million
text: Often, the new must-have gadget is not something you can pick up at Best Buy or find on Amazon. It is something you find on a site like Kickstarter, or a product produced by a small start-up company.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Atlantic: Your house is still overrun with Peeps. Here’s another use for them: Infuse them with vodka. — Maria Newman

headline: Leading Off: The Dodgers’ Hollywood Opening
text: As opening day dawned bright and full of hope almost everywhere except the Bronx, there was occasion for hope in so many places. The Nationals opened at home looking for all the world like the next superstar team. The Braves have launched a whole era by uniting the Upton brothers. Seattle’s Felix Hernandez pitched so well, people stopped minding that he needs a Brinks truck to bring home his new paycheck. And while New York slumped at the sight of the Yankees’ geriatric era, the Mets tried to inject a ray or two of sunshine by thinking almost aloud, “Hey, we might not be totally terrible!”

headline: Cinematic Head Start on Istanbul Art Biennial
text: ISTANBUL — The 13th Istanbul Biennial — whose title theme is ‘‘Mom, am I Barbarian?’’ — doesn’t officially open until Sept. 14. But you can get a leap on the curator Fulya Erdemci’s views on the public versus private spheres, civility versus violence, and utopian societies by going to the movies this week.

headline: A Building Not Just Green, but Practically Self-Sustaining
text: SEATTLE — When an office building here that bills itself as the world’s greenest officially opens later this month, it will present itself as a “living building zoo,” with docents leading tours and smartphone-wielding tourists able to scan bar codes to learn about the artfully exposed mechanical and electrical systems.

headline: Opening a Gateway for Girls to Enter the Computer Field
text: WHEN Julia Geist was asked to draw a picture of a computer scientist last year, the 16-year-old sketched a businessman wearing glasses and a tie. Looking around at her classmates’ drawings, she saw similar depictions of men.

headline: Jack Pardee, a Star at Texas A&M and an N.F.L. Coach, Dies at 76
text: Jack Pardee, a survivor of Coach Bear Bryant’s merciless “Junction Boys” training camp at Texas A&M who went on to become an All-Pro linebacker and a coach of the year in the N.F.L., died on Monday in suburban Denver. He was 76.

headline: The Complaint Against Smith, Malcolm, Et Al.
text: Read the full formal complaint against State Senator Malcolm A. Smith, City Councilman Daniel J. Halloran III, et al.

headline: The Gun Report: April 2, 2013
text: Take a look at the second shooting in today’s Gun Report. A toddler gets a hold of a loaded gun and kills himself. I keep coming back to this particular kind of shooting: children killed or maimed after finding a loaded gun. Not only because they are so heartbreaking, but because they are so preventable. I wrote a column 11 days ago about the possibility of childproofing guns. Not surprisingly, gun absolutists find this idea appalling.

headline: Why So Few Women Reach the Executive Rank
text: Here is a puzzle. If the bulk of studies show that women are a net plus to corporate America, why are they still a small minority on Wall Street and in the executive suite?

headline: Subaru Recalls 215,000 Outbacks and Legacies for Corrosion in Brake Lines
text: 12:26 p.m. | Updated Subaru is recalling at least 215,000 of its most popular models – the 2005-9 Outback wagon and Legacy sedan – because of corrosion of the brake lines, the automaker says.

headline: The Man Behind ‘Mad Men’ Is Back: Matthew Weiner Talks Season 6
text: LOS ANGELES – With every ad campaign won or lost by Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce, every whiskey swigged, every cigarette smoked and every errant lipstick stain that turns up on the wrong collar, “Mad Men” draws nearer to its end. That AMC period drama begins its second to last season on Sunday with a two-hour premiere. As audiences prepare to get reacquainted with Don Draper, the enigmatic executive played by Jon Hamm, and his colleagues and family, Matthew Weiner, the “Mad Men” creator and show runner, isn’t taking any victory laps.

headline: Block Party
text: Come spring, not everyone wants to wear flowery prints and Breton stripes. The solution? Cubism!

headline: The Mumbai/New York Photo Project: Education Heroes
text: Mumbai and New York may both be the financial capitals of their respective countries and home to vibrant economies, but the cities have struggled since their birth with persistent social inequity.

headline: North Korea Heightens Nuclear Tensions
text: The country’s leadership strives to gain leverage in its escalating standoff with the United States and its allies.

headline: Keeping an Eye on Savings Account Transfers
text: Back in January, I fulfilled a New Year’s resolution by setting up automatic online transfers for my children’s weekly allowances. So far, so good — or, so I thought.

headline: Chipping Away at the Glass Ceiling in Private Equity
text: The clubby, male-dominated world of private equity prompted a lot of name-calling in the late 1980s. Barbarians. Raiders. Vultures.

headline: Israel Says Its Tanks Responded to Shots Fired From Syrian Side
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military said Tuesday night that its tanks had fired into Syria in response to shots fired from the Syrian side at an Israeli Army jeep in the Israeli-held Golan Heights, adding that the shells hit their target. Earlier that day, the Israeli military said, a mortar shell from Syria sailed over the Israeli-Syrian cease-fire line and crashed into an open field.

headline: Palestinians Jailed in Israel Protest After Inmate Dies
text: JERUSALEM — Hundreds of Palestinian prisoners staged protests in Israeli jails on Tuesday as the Palestinian leadership accused Israel of deliberately delaying the treatment of a fellow prisoner who died that morning of cancer.

headline: Marriage, Procreation and Historical Amnesia
text: Not surprisingly, my Sunday column raising the possibility that the successes of the gay marriage movement might be having some modest influence on marriage’s overall decline left liberals (and many others) unpersuaded. Kevin Drum has a usefully representative rebuttal, whose three major points I think I’ll take up in separate posts. Here’s the first, which dismisses the idea that the push for same-sex marriage has tended to weaken the legal and cultural connection between marriage and procreation by … blaming social conservatives for injecting that supposed connection into the debate in the first place:

headline: America’s Pastime, Behind Bars
text: Civil War prisons were terrible places: captured solders suffered and died by the thousands from malnutrition, disease and exposure to the elements. But in several Northern and Southern prisons, a few fortunate inmates were able to enjoy, for a moment, a lighter side of life: baseball.

headline: Rockwood Music Hall Starts a Record Label
text: For the last eight years, Ken Rockwood has served as an impresario and a mentor for scores of New York bands, giving them shows on the two stages at his Rockwood Music Hall on the Lower East Side. Now he says he is taking the next step: he has started a record label.

headline: A Global Mission to Fight Sexual Violence Against Women
text: WASHINGTON — Just as the pressing call for an end to violence against women resounds around the world, it is also making itself heard here in Washington.

headline: One Size Fits None
text: In today’s Business Insider, Joe Weisenthal reports on Europe’s truly dismal PMIs (survey-based indexes that act as early-warning indicators for official economic data). There’s no doubt at all that the continent is falling deeper into recession, even in the core countries. And reading this news reminds me of something I’ve been meaning to write – namely, that discussions of Europe’s troubles, and the debate over austerity, often suffer from a tendency to blur two somewhat different issues.

headline: U.N. Treaty Is First Aimed at Regulating Global Arms Sales
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to approve a pioneering treaty aimed at regulating the enormous global trade in conventional weapons, for the first time linking sales to the human rights records of the buyers.

headline: A Plan to Simplify the Tax Code That May Be Too Simple
text: Did anyone else notice the elephant in the living room?

headline: That Falling Feeling
text: This has been a nasty winter for those of us afraid of falling. Recently, having left my dog alone far longer than expected, the call of nature required I take him out immediately on returning home — after yet another March snow. He is big, I am small, and in his urgency he yanked me down the unshoveled and unsalted porch steps. That was fall No. 1.

headline: Kindergarten ‘Redshirting’ Gets Tougher in N.Y.C., With Repercussions
text: We “redshirted” our son last year, and I’m so glad we did.

headline: Final: Bayern 2, Juventus 0; P.S.G. 2, Barcelona 2
text: The Goal blog provided updates and live analysis of Tuesday’s UEFA Champions League quarterfinal matches: Barcelona at Paris St.-Germain and Juventus at Bayern Munich. Read on for updates, photos and video highlights.

headline: Easter Postscript: What to Do With Ham Stock
text: Cooks who tried our braise-roast technique  on an Easter ham this year may now have quarts of tasty stock on hand. It freezes well until you figure out how best to use it.

headline: A Virtual Tour of the Observation Deck
text: A virtual tour, based on renderings, of the World Trade Center Observation Deck.

headline: Staying Independent Is Not Much of an Option for MetroPCS
text: MetroPCS owners should forget about a stand-alone option. The dissident investors John A. Paulson and Peter M. Schoenfeld persuaded two proxy services that the cellphone operator was selling out on the cheap to a rival, T-Mobile USA, and that independence was a better option. While the agitating may bring a sweeter bid, MetroPCS is unlikely to prosper or exist for long on its own.

headline: Jack-booted Insurance-bringing Thugs
text: Jonathan Chait and Aaron Carroll both have fun with Elizabeth Cheney‘s bonkers op-ed about how Obamacare will destroy our freedom.

headline: Double Dose on Opening Day Warms the Soul
text: Two opening days in the same town did not sound kosher.

headline: World Nomads Arts Festival to Focus on Tunisia
text: This year’s World Nomads Festival, presented in May by the French Institute Alliance Française, will focus on the culture of Tunisia, where artists played a crucial role in overthrowing the country’s authoritarian government in January 2011. Those street protests ignited demonstrations in other nations and helped usher in the Arab Spring. Marie-Monique Steckel, the president of Alliance Française, said that the festival, which runs from May 3 – June 1, will feature some of the “phenomenal artistic creativity that has emerged on the heels of the Arab Spring.” There will be art, film, photography and dance shows, an ideas forum, and a Tunisian craft market. Performing alongside his Tunisian-born father, Tsvi Bokaer, the dancer and choreographer Jonah Bokaer will present the United States premiere of “The Ulysses Syndrome.” Some of the country’s best-known artists, including Sonia M’Barek, Ghalia Benali, Emel Mathlouthi, will also be performing. For more information, go to www.fiaf.org.

headline: G.O.P. and Democratic Senators Back Gay Marriage
text: Two more senators, one from each party, announced their support for same-sex marriage on Tuesday. Their shifts appear to mark 50 votes to legalize such unions in the Senate.

headline: Rigging New York City’s Mayoral Race?
text: The Times’s Michael Barbaro on how the arrest of two lawmakers and a half-dozen other politicians could shake up New York’s Republican Party.

headline: The Envelope Please: Sush Krishnamoorthy
text: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student in New Delhi who is applying to universities in the United States, lists the resources that helped her navigate the college admissions process from afar.

headline: Cano Fires Agent and Signs With Jay-Z’s Agency
text: When Robinson Cano rejected the offer of a substantial contract extension from the Yankees before spring training, he was still being represented by Scott Boras, baseball’s most formidable and challenging negotiator. It is Boras, after all, who consistently takes big-name players to free agency so they can obtain every last penny possible in a new contract.

headline: Acceptance Rates, Apparently, Are Poor Predictors of Getting In
text: Early in the college application process, I classified colleges as “dream” schools and “reach” schools based on their acceptance rates. It is popular advice to do so. Also, the terms “selectivity” and “acceptance rate” are often used interchangeably, and this indicated to me that the higher the acceptance rate of a college, the easier it is to get in.

headline: A NASA Hangout on Rising Seas and Global Warming
text: 2:11 p.m. | Updated |Earlier today, I participated in a NASA Google+ Hangout on Air on these questions and more:

headline: Comparing the World’s Glass Ceilings
text: One of the more surprising things I learned in my research for an article in The New York Times Magazine is that despite all the complaints about the glass ceiling, the United States is actually doing a relatively good job of getting women into high-achieving jobs.

headline: Finding a Coder When You Don’t Know How to Code
text: When I first entered the start-up world, I found the landscape tricky to navigate — especially as a nontechnical founder of a technology company. How could the founder of a tech start-up not know anything more than HTML? How was I going to hire the right people with the right skills to build the lines of code I needed if I didn’t understand what I was looking for?

headline: Report Sees Guns as Path to Safety in Schools
text: WASHINGTON — With the Senate set to debate gun control this month, a National Rifle Association task force released a 225-page report on Tuesday that called for armed police officers, security guards or staff members in every American school, and urged states to loosen gun restrictions to allow trained teachers and administrators to carry weapons.

headline: Feeling For | Bright Lights
text: I’m just mad for these candylicious resin lamps by the London-based designer Marianna Kennedy. They come in eye-popping colors like deep sea green or chrome yellow, and at about $600 each (with shade) are relatively affordable, unlike the lacquered gueridon tables and gilded mercury mirrors in Kennedy’s gallery-quality collection. The conical shades are made from antique book cloth, most of which Kennedy sources from Paris. “Isn’t it funny,” she says, “you just have to say it comes from Paris and it sounds irresistible.”

headline: U.S. Soccer Celebrates 100 Years
text: U.S. Soccer is coming home — to New York — to celebrate the 100th anniversary of its founding on April 5, 1913.

headline: Prepare for Launch with Angry Birds
text: Angry Birds, the popular video game that involves catapulting birds at fortresses constructed by enemy pigs, now has a greater purpose than killing time at the checkout line. It’s the subject of a 4,485-square-foot exhibit at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex in Florida that is meant to teach children physics.

headline: A Beach Vacation, Lizard-Style
text: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvard’s Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

headline: ‘Cat’ Ticket Sales Fall Short of Recouping Costs
text: The Broadway revival of “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,” starring Scarlett Johansson as Maggie the Cat, fell short of recouping its $3.6 million capitalization before ending its 15-week run on Saturday, a spokeswoman for the show said on Monday.

headline: It’s an April Fool’s Day Spoof, but It’s Not a Joke
text: Monday was a really funny and sad day on the Internet.

headline: James and Wade Will Sit Out Against Knicks
text: The Miami Heat entered Tuesday 11½ games ahead of the Knicks in the Eastern Conference. The standings make it clear the Heat, the defending champions, and the Knicks are not equals at this point late in the regular season. The Knicks are still fighting for their playoff seeding, while Miami long ago locked up the No. 1 spot and has the luxury of resting players after winning 29 of the last 30 games.

headline: Motorsports: Larry Dixon Uninjured in Dragster Spinout
text: Larry Dixon escaped injury in a terrifying Top Fuel dragster mishap Friday, at an exhibition in Queensland, Australia.

headline: A Law Firm Stands Out for Its Work, Not Its Gender Makeup
text: As Harvard Law School classmates in the mid-1980s, Susan E. Brune and Hillary Richard dreamed about one day starting their own law firm.

headline: Unfamiliar Feelings in a Familiar Land
text: When I first set foot at Baghdad International Airport in March 2010 to work for The New York Times, I was no stranger to Iraq. Until 2003, Baghdad had been my home. I still had family and friends here, and they remained dear to me, and I to them.

headline: Women Lead the Way in White-Collar Law
text: It’s still a man’s world in many sectors of the legal profession, as it is in much of corporate America. It’s true for prosecutors, for white-collar defense partners at major firms and in executive suites. But when it comes to researching and being an authoritative voice of study about white-collar crime, women are taking the lead.

headline: Breaking It Down: Williams vs. Sharapova
text: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Serena Williams is from another planet.

headline: A Huge Parking Bill, but It’s Also a Huge Space
text: By the end of the week, Roman Abramovich’s latest bill for parking in New York City will reach $100,000. And by the time his ship sails, the tab could exceed $150,000.

headline: Hanjan
text: Inside a Korean restaurant that infuses traditional dishes with new ideas.

headline: China Announces 4 New Bird Flu Cases
text: SHANGHAI — China said Tuesday that four more people in the coastal part of the country had been infected with a new strain of bird flu, which is believed to have killed two Shanghai residents last month and left one person in critical condition.

headline: Women in a Man’s World
text: Irene Dorner blames herself — and her female colleagues — for the lack of women on Wall Street.

headline: Law Firm Partner Accused of Sexual Harassment Fires Back
text: A law firm partner who was sued last month, accused of sexual harassment, fired back on Tuesday at the junior lawyer who brought the case, contending that she fabricated her claims and was obsessed with him.

headline: John J. Gumperz, Linguist of Cultural Interchange, Dies at 91
text: The conflict hinged on a single word: “gravy.”

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Action on the Climate
Splitting the Difference
text: The pajeon at Hanjan did not look like any Korean pancake I’d ever seen. It appeared to be a casual pile of squid tempura interlaced with a few splinters of fried green stuff, but I took a knife to it and quartered it anyway. Amazingly, the gold loops and strands held together as they traveled from the dish of spicy dipping sauce to my mouth.

headline: Press Conference by N.R.A. Task Force
text: The National Rifle Association proposes a plan to train and arm security guards at every school in the nation.

headline: A $100 Weekend in Boston
text: Philadelphia might claim Benjamin Franklin as its own, but I can think of two ways he’s more closely tied to Boston. First, he grew up there. Second, I just spent a weekend in Boston for the value of the bill that bears his portrait.

headline: HBO Orders Fourth Season of ‘Game of Thrones’
text: George R. R. Martin, it will soon be time to put down your remote control and pick up your pen (or get behind your computer keyboard), because HBO will have need for more of your narrative content. The cable network said on Tuesday that it had officially ordered a fourth season of “Game of Thrones,” its epic fantasy series created by David Benioff and D. B. Weiss, and adapted from Mr. Martin’s best-selling “Song of Ice and Fire” novels. This announcement comes two days after the third-season premiere of “Game of Thrones,” which set ratings records for that series, drawing 4.4 million viewers first episode and exceeding the 4.2 million viewers who watched the initial broadcast of its second-season finale last June. HBO said that “Game of Thrones” had an average gross audience (including showings on the network as well as plays on DVRs and digital services like HBO Go) of 11.6 million viewers in Season 2.

headline: The Roving Runner: Elevating the Jog
text: No smoking, dog-walking, biking, skating or scooting.

headline: Coffees to Go, and Make One ‘Suspended’
text: A while back, I wrote about how I was pleasantly surprised to receive a free coffee at a bagel shop drive-through, during “Random Acts of Kindness” week. The customer in front of me paid for my order before driving away.

headline: The N.R.A.’s Useless Advice
text: Paging through the new National Rifle Association report on improving school security, I stopped short at a photograph illustrating how profoundly depressing that document really is.

headline: A Polished Past and Polite People
text: When Meghan Fedor opened her mailbox recently, she found a brown paper bag with a length of green ribbon enclosed, along with a note explaining that a local high school girl was undergoing treatment for lymphoma and that the ribbons could serve as a show of support. Within days, some 150 homes in Ms. Fedor’s Basking Ridge neighborhood had ribbons waving from mailboxes and lamp posts. It’s this kind of neighborly act, said Ms. Fedor, who commutes to a job at the Environmental Protection Agency in New York three days a week, that has had her marveling since she moved here almost two years ago.

headline: Living In Basking Ridge, N.J.
text: Open tracts, a friendly downtown and a rich history characterize the commutable town.

headline: Night, Night, Little Headset
text: The Jabra Motion is a wireless headset that knows when it’s nap time.

headline: Is It Too Classy for Pancakes?
text: DOVER PLAINS, N.Y. — In Robb Turner’s telling, it all sounds so inevitable, as if maybe the same thing could happen to you. You would buy some land, discover it dense with maple trees and decide to tap them for syrup. Your product would so intrigue the sommelier at Per Se that he would leave his job to sell it for you. One of New York’s most celebrated chefs would design the kitchen for an all-maple cafe at your new sugarhouse.

headline: N.R.A. Unveils Plan to Arm School Guards
text: The Times’s Sheryl Gay Stolberg discusses a new proposal commissioned by the National Rifle Association to place trained guards in American schools.

headline: The Inside Scoop on Your Insides
text: The Times’s Quentin Hardy talks with Mary Roach about her new book, “Gulp: Adventures on the Alimentary Canal.”

headline: Untangling Two New York Corruption Cases
text: Diagrams showing how the arrested officials are linked.

headline: Closing a Gender Gap: A Computer Science Immersion Program Aimed at Girls
text: Girls Who Code is among a recent crop of programs aiming to close the gender gap in technology by intervening early, when girls and young women are deciding what they want to study.

headline: For Albany, Yet Another Corruption Case
text: The arrest of State Senator Malcolm A. Smith on Tuesday followed a string of corruption cases involving elected officials in New York State that has helped burnish Albany’s reputation as an ethical cesspool.

headline: Divisions Form in Atlanta as Bail Is Set in Cheating Case
text: ATLANTA — Confusion, anger and charges of racism played out at the Fulton County Jail here on Tuesday as the process of booking 35 educators in the nation’s largest school-cheating scandal began.

headline: Google Faces More Inquiries in Europe Over Privacy Policy
text: Instead of facing one European investigation into its privacy policy, Google now has to contend with at least six of them.

headline: A Glimpse of the World
text: Two of the country’s most valuable sports franchises extended their reach to New York’s newest and tallest perch Tuesday morning, when they unveiled plans for the three-level “One World Observatory,” on the 100th floor of 1 World Trade Center.

headline: Image of the Day: April 2
text: World Autism Awareness Day celebrated in India.

headline: Big Profits at Fannie and Freddie Reignite Debate on Housing Supports
text: What was the most profitable insurance company last year?

headline: Generational Shift: Learning to Drive a Stick
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Dorrie Sibley’s reason for bringing her son Breslin, 16, to learn how to drive a car equipped with a manual transmission, a so-called stick shift, had nothing to do with the reason the instructional event was being held. But it was a very good reason nonetheless.

headline: Wheelies: The Secret-of-My-Success Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Formichetti Out at Mugler
text: If Lady Gaga wants to continue her career in runway modeling, she will have to look elsewhere than Mugler. Joël Palix, the president of the Clarins Fragrance Group and the director general of its Mugler fragrance and fashion label, announced on Tuesday that the company had parted ways with the creative director Nicola Formichetti.

headline: Clinton and Biden on Stage, No Spin Room Needed
text: Before the Great Showdown of the Presidential Candidates comes the Great Showdown of the Award Presenters.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Digg Resurgence, and Nanoparticles vs. Viruses
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: ‘The Century’s Bitterest Journalistic Failure’? Considering Times Coverage of the Holocaust
text: April 8 is Holocaust Remembrance Day (Yom Hashoah), which marks the anniversary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising on the Hebrew calendar.

headline: Banish Winter With the Taste of Spring
text: Though the vernal equinox has passed, here in the Northeast trees remain largely bare, with brown branches on view instead of cherry blossoms. If spring has actually arrived, it is in its slow beginning stages, with daffodils and tulips poking through the hard ground.

headline: In Act of Solidarity, Top Pentagon Officials Will Return a Share of Salaries
text: In an unusual act of solidarity with the Pentagon’s civilian workforce, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and the department’s deputy secretary, Ashton B. Carter, will return a share of their salaries to the federal Treasury for the same number of days that employees are docked because of furloughs.

headline: At Home in Tanzania, Thabeet Plays the Motivator
text: MINNEAPOLIS — There’s a popular bumper sticker on the streets of Dar Es Salaam, Tanzania, that reads, “This car is protected by the blood of Jesus.” But there’s one teacher at the International School of Tanganyika who needs one that reads, “This car is protected by Hasheem Thabeet.”

headline: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara Statement
text: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara outlined the criminal charges filed against six New York state officials, calling today a “sad and disappointing day” for those who still dream of an honest government.

headline: Look Who’s Not Taking a Pay Cut
text: This just in from the sequester front: The Journal Gazette reported that Indiana’s Head Start program could lose roughly 1,000 spots. Programs in Columbus and Franklin have already held lotteries to determine which needy children will get kicked out.

headline: Front Burner
text: To Prepare: A Complement From the Chef

headline: Off the Menu
text: Headliner: Lobster Place and Chelsea Market

headline: The Times, Too, Is Reconsidering the Term ‘Illegal Immigrant’
text: The Associated Press made a bold move on Tuesday in dropping the term “illegal immigrant” from its influential stylebook.

headline: Turning a Dark Place Into a Beacon of Discovery
text: The memoirist and poet Mary Karr, who has traded whiskey for Jesus, once described the difficulty of talking nonironically about faith to a secular audience. It is, she said, “like doing card tricks on the radio.”

headline: The Very Brief Revival of the Homemade Zip Gun
text: With a pipe for a barrel and a nail for a firing pin, the homemade firearm known as a zip gun fires only a single bullet at a time, with limited accuracy.

headline: Shades On | House of Waris and Illesteva
text: Waris Ahluwalia of House of Waris is to jewelry as Daniel Silberman and Jus Ske of Illesteva are to eyewear: they design culty, mostly unisex accessories; pal around with downtown’s creative peerage; and are prone to participating in one-off collaborations. It seems inevitable, then, that the two brands would end up joining forces with one another. A single eyewear style resulting from a single design session, House of Waris for Illesteva’s sunglasses ($250) might be the single most essential frame of the summer. Handmade in France, the 1960s-influenced unisex style comes in five colors, all of which are refreshingly subdued. “They look good on everybody,” says Silberman, who also wears a pair as his prescription eyeglasses. Adds Ahluwalia, “The idea was to help the world look as sexy as possible, even in the glaring sun.”

headline: S.E.C. Sets Rules for Disclosures Using Social Media
text: 8:34 p.m. | Updated Chief executives can now feel free to post, blog or tweet — as long as they inform investors about their social media strategy first.

headline: Wilson-Pakula, Obscure to All but Ballot-Hopping Politicians
text: The criminal complaint accusing a top state lawmaker of trying to buy his way into the race for New York City mayor made several references to a document most New Yorkers have probably never heard of.

headline: Hotel Review: Georges Hotel Galata in Istanbul
text: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Ámaz in Lima, Peru
text: With all of the attention paid to Peruvian food in recent years, the cuisine of the Amazon has been all but ignored. Pedro Miguel Schiaffino is a rare exception. At his Lima restaurant Malabar he uses ingredients from the Peruvian Amazon, the country’s largest and least populated region, and he has spent a decade developing a relationship with producers there. The result is Ámaz, opened last June in a high-profile location in trendy Miraflores and the capital’s first serious Amazonian restaurant.

headline: Lois Smith and Frances Sternhagen to Share Obie Lifetime Achievement Award
text: Lois Smith and Frances Sternhagen, stage veterans with recent major Off Broadway roles, are joint recipients of the lifetime achievement Obie, The Village Voice announced Tuesday. The Obies have been presented by The Voice since 1956, and the shared lifetime achievement award is a first.

headline: Beet and Bulgur Salad
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the West Bank, Myanmar, South Africa and Nepal.

headline: More Rizzo Than Sandra Dee
text: “IT SMELLS SO SWEET in here,” remarked a young female customer entering the new Cynthia Rowley shop (or should we call it Good Ship, as in Lollipop), at the end of a branch-festooned alleyway on the Upper East Side.

headline: Dragonfly, Hunting
text: The deadly, exacting aerialist catches a fruit fly.

headline: At Trade Center, Looking Ahead While Finding Remnants of the Past
text: Update, May 1: The medical examiner said fragments that may be human remains were recovered Tuesday in material excavated from the vehicle security center area at the new World Trade Center site. A total of 77 such fragments have been found since sifting operations began on April 1.

headline: The House Band Amid the Artwork
text: Hard to believe a full decade has passed since Edward Arron, a skillful young cellist with a flair for programming and a knack for organization, convened a group of his peers for a new chamber music initiative, the Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert. Formed in 2003 to help the museum celebrate its 50th anniversary as a concert presenter, the ensemble celebrated its own 10th anniversary with a concert in the museum’s Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium on Friday night.

headline: Lonely Spy in a Love Triangle
text: There is no such thing as a good old-fashioned spy story.

headline: Moonstruck, and Keeping Their Eyes on the Prize
text: With our ever-increasing ability to look deep into space and ponder its brain-bending mysteries, the humble old Moon seems largely forgotten. But a few people are still carrying a torch for that nearest of celestial neighbors, and their strange, poignant devotion is beautifully captured in a wry documentary called “Lunarcy!” on Wednesday night on Epix.

headline: Verizon Says It’s Not ‘Currently’ Planning to Bid for Vodafone
text: Investors hoping for a giant trans-Atlantic telecommunications deal will have to cool their heels for a bit longer.

headline: When the Artist’s Muse Loves the Artist’s Wife
text: “Three Trees” is inspired by the life of the 20th-century artist Alberto Giacometti and his unusual relationship with his muse, the Japanese philosophy professor Isaku Yanaihara. Unusual not only because the muse was male, but also because he happened to be sleeping with Giacometti’s wife, with the artist’s full knowledge and consent.

headline: Arts Hub for All May Work for None
text: The visionary architect Frank Gehry remains committed to designing the performing arts center at the site of the former World Trade Center. But what exactly has Mr. Gehry been asked to design? What is it for? Which institutions, ensembles or companies will perform in the complex? Who will be its artistic leader?

headline: A Generic Guitar Inspires a Distinctive Project
text: It started out as an inside joke and quickly became an international art project, linked to a charitable cause.

headline: Set Joyce to Music? Yes She Said Yes She Will Yes
text: Take a few words by Joyce. How about “herds innumerable” from the Cyclops episode in “Ulysses,” made up of “bellwethers and flushed ewes and shearling rams and lambs and stubble geese and medium steers and roaring mares and polled calves and longwools and storesheep and Cuffe’s prime springers and culls and sowpigs and baconhogs and the various different varieties of highly distinguished swine and Angus heifers and polly bullocks of immaculate pedigree together with prime premiated milchcows and beeves:” — oh, good, a colon, take a breath — “and there is ever heard a trampling, cackling, roaring, lowing, bleating, bellowing, rumbling, grunting, champing, chewing, of sheep and pigs and heavyhoofed kine from pasturelands of Lush and Rush and ...”? We’ll fade out there, but it goes on.

headline: A Suite of Their Own
text: Women make up more than half of the work force on Wall Street. But breaking into the highest ranks is still largely a man’s sport.

headline: Chastened, Folk Art Museum Puts Down Healthier Roots
text: The American Folk Art Museum’s attendance is projected to be 80,000 this fiscal year, up from 66,000. Important donors are giving again. And for the first time in its history, this summer the museum will send a work from its collection to the Venice Biennale.

headline: New America Foundation Naming Anne-Marie Slaughter as President
text: April 3 | Updated

headline: Fatal Landslide Draws Attention to the Toll of Mining on Tibet
text: BEIJING — One after another, the bodies have kept coming. By Wednesday, rescuers had pulled 66 dead miners from the snow-covered rubble. They expect to find more.

headline: Using ECMAScript 5 Objects and Properties
text: With ECMAScript 6 inching closer and closer to becoming an accepted standard, it’s a perfect time to look at some of the incredibly useful changes in the last big ES release. ECMAScript 5, published in 2009, gave JavaScript developers some great new options. One of its most powerful additions was Object.defineProperty. This method allows you to make better use of the browser’s internals. John Resig explains:

headline: Some Dessert, After That Meal With Wally
text: “It’s the art of being, not the act of performing,” the experimental-theater director André Gregory muses in “André Gregory: Before and After Dinner,” an indelible, gripping documentary portrait by his wife, Cindy Kleine. “Even emotion can be a mask.”

headline: Movie Time
text: To help moviegoers keep on track for a week’s worth of screening indie titles during this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, which takes place in New York later this month, IWC Schaffhausen created a limited-edition “Tribeca Film Festival 2013″ watch. Produced in stainless steel and a batch of only 100, the watch will set you back $13,600 and is available today at the watchmaker’s flagship store on Madison Avenue, just in time to map out your viewing schedule. For those truly wanting to commemorate the event, a single platinum version will be up for auction at Antiquorum on April 10.

headline: Sandbag Season Has Fargo Thinking of a Better Way
text: FARGO, N.D. — Just last fall, the reservoirs and rivers here in the Red River Valley were so low from drought that Mayor Dennis R. Walaker of Fargo was concerned that the faucets and shower heads in his city would run dry.

headline: FIFA Selects Goal-Line System
text: Under the cloak of games Tuesday in the quarterfinals of the UEFA Champions League, FIFA issued a communique about its approval of a single goal-line technology system that will be employed at this year’s Confederations Cup and next year’s World Cup, both of which will be played in Brazil.

headline: A Roving Noise Laboratory
text: In 1929, the Noise Abatement Commission drove a truck around New York City to measure the din. Fox Movietone Newsreel preserved by the University of South Carolina, Moving Image Research Collections.

headline: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With Robert Redford and Shia LaBeouf
text: 11:30 p.m. | Updated Tonight, ArtsBeat live streamed a TimesTalks event with the Oscar-winning director and actor Robert Redford and the actor Shia LaBeouf, who both star in Mr. Redford’s latest film, “The Company You Keep.” Click on the image above to watch the event, which was moderated by the Times media columnist David Carr.

headline: Upping the Ante in a Play for a Stronger Board
text: Would you pay a director tens of millions for fantastic performance? Welcome to the newest trend in activist investing: hedge funds paying their nominees to a company’s board as if they were chief executives.

headline: The Evolution of Audi’s Singleframe Grille, Explained in Detail
text: Wolfgang Egger, Audi’s design chief, took a few minutes last week at the New York auto show to explain the shape of the company’s new A3 and S3 models, and his new twist to the evolution of the Audi grille. Mr. Egger, 50, pulled out one of his burnt sienna drawing pencils to highlight his ideas.

headline: Video Captures Mugging in Subway Station
text: Update, April 3 | The police arrested Aidan Folan, 21, of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn on Wednesday and charged him with robbery and assault in connection with this attack.

headline: Helpful Workplace Hints From the World’s Most Helpful Guy
text: Yesterday, I asked you to write in with your questions about workplace dilemmas for the organizational psychologist Adam Grant, the subject of this past weekend’s cover article, who studies the ways that being altruistic can lead to success in a career. Here are Grant’s answers to your questions.

headline: Alec Baldwin Back on Broadway
text: Alec Baldwin, Ben Foster and Tom Sturridge discuss the gritty drama “Orphans,” Mr. Baldwin’s first Broadway appearance since 2004.

headline: The Many Faces of State Political Scandals
text: Over the past seven years, 29 state officeholders have been convicted of a crime, censured or otherwise accused of wrongdoing, according to the New York Public Interest Research Group.

headline: Pipeline Spills Stir New Criticism of Keystone Plan
text: Two recent oil pipeline spills have prompted new criticism from opponents of the proposed Keystone XL project, while raising more questions about whether the federal government is adequately monitoring the nation’s vast labyrinth of pipelines.

headline: After Protests, Prison Firm Pulls Donation
text: Sports stadiums have been named for fast food companies, office supply chains, and banks, but apparently there is one sector of the economy that is not welcome in the sports world: the private prison industry.

headline: Investments in Education May Be Misdirected
text: James Heckman is one of the nation’s top economists studying human development. Thirteen years ago, he shared the Nobel for economics. In February, he stood before the annual meeting of the Nebraska Chamber of Commerce and Industry, showed the assembled business executives a chart, and demolished the United States’ entire approach to education.

headline: Bucking French Tradition, City Sets Up a Kind of Holy Quarter
text: BUSSY SAINT-GEORGES, France — Set above a sweep of green farmland, the crumbling stone chapel at the center of this village met the spiritual requirements of its Roman Catholic residents for nearly four centuries. But Bussy Saint-Georges is no longer just a village.

text: After three weeks of testimony, jurors are to begin debating on Wednesday whether David Tarloff’s plan to save his mother — a plan that resulted in his killing an Upper East Side psychologist — was the product of an insane mind or simply a poorly thought-out crime that ended in a murder.

headline: House Immigration Bill Is Said to Offer 3 Paths
text: WASHINGTON — In the shadow of a bipartisan Senate group preparing to roll out broad immigration legislation next week, shortly after Congress returns from its holiday break, a bipartisan group of eight House members is readying its own bill.

headline: Notable Deaths of 2013
text: Remembering Jonathan Winters, Julie Harris, Edward I. Koch, Chinua Achebe, Margaret Thatcher, James Gandolfini and others who died this year.

headline: Diagnosis: Human
text: THE news that 11 percent of school-age children now receive a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder — some 6.4 million — gave me a chill. My son David was one of those who received that diagnosis.

headline: Egyptians Struggle as Wary Tourists Stay Away
text: AL-BAIRAT, Egypt — Many of this country’s post-uprising troubles wash up here, in a crumbling shack on a dirty canal, where 13 members of the Abdul Latif family have long relied on tourism to keep them from slipping from poverty into ruin.

headline: France: Ex-Minister Admits Lying About Secret Bank Account
text: The former budget minister, Jérôme Cahuzac, admitted Tuesday that he lied to Parliament and the president about the existence of a secret overseas bank account. Mr. Cahuzac, left, who resigned over the scandal, confessed to investigating magistrates that he had an undeclared account in Switzerland and then Singapore, as the Web site Mediapart had asserted. Mr. Cahuzac was preliminarily indicted on tax fraud charges, and in a statement on Tuesday, President François Hollande criticized him for “an unpardonable moral fault” in lying to “the country’s highest authorities.” Mr. Hollande’s critics accused him of a delay in cleaning house. The politician François Bayrou said the scandal produced “damages that are considerable and devastating” for French politics.

headline: Background Checks Are Still Stumbling Block in Gun Law Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — With Senate Democrats still struggling to line up support, the success or failure of President Obama’s four-month campaign to overhaul gun laws will most likely revolve around a single provision: a proposal to expand federal background checks for gun purchases.

headline: Mets’ Marcum Scratched Because of Neck Pain
text: The right-hander Shaun Marcum was unable to pitch a previously scheduled simulated game Tuesday in Port St. Lucie, Fla., after feeling pain in his neck, the Mets said.

headline: Brazil: Suspects in Gang Rape Linked to Assaults and Robberies
text: The Rio de Janeiro police said Tuesday that they were investigating a new accusation of rape against three men arrested in connection with the gang rape over the weekend of an American student in a transit van. In the newest case, a woman said she was raped by the men during the Carnival holiday in February, but she did not report the attack then to the authorities. Another woman had formally accused the same men of raping her in March. The police said they were also investigating at least 10 claims of robbery in which the men have been implicated.

headline: Did Putin Sink Cyprus?
text: ISTANBUL

headline: J.C. Penney Slashes Pay of Its Chief
text: In a clear sign of its dissatisfaction with the direction of the company, the board of J. C. Penney gave its chief executive, Ron Johnson, a pay cut of almost 97 percent, to $1.9 million, for 2012, according to a regulatory filing on Tuesday.

headline: Centers See New Faces Seeking Test Prep
text: Elma Moy, a teacher from southern China, opened her learning center in a storefront with low ceilings on Henry Street in 1982, catering to Chinatown’s growing student body. For years, her Web site was mostly in Cantonese, advertisements were reserved for Chinese-language daily newspapers, and staff members at the front desk greeted parents signing up for classes with “Ching choh la.” (“Have a seat.”)

headline: In Mexican Villages, Few Are Left to Dream of U.S.
text: EL CARGADERO, Mexico — The pretty houses in the hills here, with their bright paint and new additions, clearly display the material benefits of having millions of workers move to the United States over the past few decades. But these simple homes also reveal why another huge exodus would be unlikely: the bulk of them are empty.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Said to Have Extended NBC Contract
text: Jimmy Fallon has signed a contract extension with NBC that will keep him at the network, executives with knowledge of the deal said Tuesday night. It is understood the deal will include that he will succeed Jay Leno as host of the “Tonight” show at some point, they said.

headline: Empty Mexican Villages Raise Doubts on New Immigration Wave
text: American lawmakers worry that  a pathway to citizenship could encourage illegal immigration, but in Mexico, there seem to be few left to come.

headline: My Little (Global) School
text: There was a time when middle-class parents in America could be — and were — content to know that their kids’ public schools were better than those in the next neighborhood over. As the world has shrunk, though, the next neighborhood over is now Shanghai or Helsinki. So, last August, I wrote a column quoting Andreas Schleicher — who runs the global exam that compares how 15-year-olds in public schools around the world do in applied reading, math and science skills — as saying imagine, in a few years, that you could sign on to a Web site and see how your school compares with a similar school anywhere in the world. And then you could take this information to your superintendent and ask: “Why are we not doing as well as schools in China or Finland?”

headline: Barcelona Loses Messi and the Lead, Spoiling Its Evening in Paris
text: When the prize is the Champions League title, tiny errors and small tweaks become vital.

headline: Russia: New Law Allows Governors to Be Appointed, Undoing Reform
text: President Vladimir V. Putin signed a law on Tuesday that could roll back a reform pushed by his predecessor allowing the direct election of regional governors. The new law allows regional legislatures to forgo elections and appoint governors from a list of candidates approved by Mr. Putin. He abolished direct elections for governors in 2004, during his second term as president, but President Dmitri A. Medvedev pushed a law through Parliament last year to restore them in what was seen as a major concession to a growing political opposition movement. Mr. Putin, now serving his third term as president, has said that the new law is needed to protect minorities in regions where elections could be combustible. Critics said the law would allow the pro-Kremlin United Russia Party to avoid election defeats by using its control of regional legislatures to bypass popular voting. The law was the latest unwinding of Mr. Medvedev’s initiatives since Mr. Putin returned to the presidency.

headline: With New Move, Jay-Z Enters a Sports Agent State of Mind
text: His social circle includes the biggest names in sports. His celebrity cachet is unmatched. He has informally advised athletes on everything from housing choices to contract extensions.

headline: Public Housing as a ‘Penal Colony’
text: New York City’s constitutionally suspect stop-and-frisk program is rightly being hammered in federal courts. Earlier this year, the court ruled in the case of Ligon v. City of New York that the city had violated Fourth Amendment protections against unreasonable search and seizure by illegally stopping people outside of private buildings in the Bronx. In the case of Floyd v. City of New York, which is currently being heard in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the plaintiffs charge the city with illegally stopping and frisking citizens based on race.

headline: Bribery Case Unsettles a Coalition in Albany
text: Last fall, as a group of breakaway Democrats was preparing to join forces with Republicans to take control of the State Senate, they recruited Malcolm A. Smith, a Queens Democrat, to join their caucus.

headline: On the Frontiers of Brain Research
text: President Obama officially announced his new brain research initiative on Tuesday, with a pledge to put $100 million in his 2014 budget to support work at three federal agencies. It is a modest but welcome start for an effort that could transform our understanding of how the brain works and help researchers find new ways to treat and prevent brain disorders like epilepsy and Alzheimer’s.

headline: Bravo Discusses Mixing Advertising With Its Shows
text: Anderson Davis is not among the stars of Bravo series that the channel likes to call “Bravolebrities.” Nonetheless, he was treated like one on Monday night during an episode of “Watch What Happens Live”: he served as the bartender; joked with the host, Andy Cohen; and even took off his shirt to reveal a toned upper body that would not be out of place on one of Bravo’s “Real Housewives” shows.

headline: The Connecticut Gun-Control Package
text: The Connecticut Legislature is scheduled to vote Wednesday on what leaders of both parties call the most far-reaching gun-legislation package in the country. The bill is thorough and bipartisan. Swift approval would send a message to the entire country that, as John McKinney, the Republican State Senate minority leader, observed, some issues must rise above politics. Mr. McKinney represents Newtown, where, in December, a gunman armed with a Bushmaster XM-15 military-style rifle massacred 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

headline: Military Sees Broader Role for Special Operations Forces, in Peace and War
text: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — Here at the headquarters of the Army Special Operations Command, planning is well under way for a significantly increased presence in Africa, Asia and Latin America for the Special Forces soldiers with the distinctive green berets who were the first American troops into Afghanistan after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Special Operations forces, which include Green Berets, Navy SEAL teams, the Rangers and specialized aviation units, have historically been a small corner of the military and not always embraced by conventional commanders.

headline: Egypt and U.S. Argue Over Jon Stewart, ‘America’s Bassem Youssef’
text: Last Updated, Wednesday, 10:22 a.m. The American comedian Jon Stewart’s criticism of the Egyptian government briefly escalated into a diplomatic incident on Tuesday, as the United States Embassy in Cairo shared a link to a “Daily Show” segment on Twitter, causing the office of Egypt’s president to react with anger.

headline: Video Puts Rutgers Coach Under Scrutiny
text: In a video shown Tuesday on ESPN, the Rutgers men’s basketball coach, Mike Rice, is seen yelling homophobic slurs at his players, kicking them, grabbing them and shoving them. He also throws basketballs at their legs, their heads and their bodies from point-blank range — as if he were playing dodge ball.

headline: Why Do G.M.O.’s Need Protection?
text: Genetic engineering in agriculture has disappointed many people who once had hopes for it. Excluding, of course, those who’ve made money from it, appropriately represented in the public’s mind by Monsanto. That corporation, or at least its friends, recently managed to have an outrageous rider slipped into the 587-page funding bill Congress sent to President Obama.[1]

headline: Justice Ginsburg’s Misdirection
text: With two same-sex marriage cases before the Supreme Court, numerous commentators have latched on to remarks by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg critical of the court’s 1973 Roe v. Wade decision that legalized abortion nationwide. It is not the judgment that was wrong, but “it moved too far, too fast,” she said at Columbia Law School last year, a view she has expressed in various speeches and law review articles. As one of the court’s moderate liberals and a champion of women’s rights, she is now being routinely cited to argue for a timid resolution on the issue of same-sex marriage that would strike down California’s ban on such marriages, but would leave prohibitions standing in about 40 other states.

headline: Addictive Animal Webcams Get Network Attention
text: The average visitor to the Kitten Cam on Animal Planet’s Web site has a hard time leaving. The live Internet stream of felines has been watched more than 25 million times since it started last September. The average person, seemingly transfixed by the cuteness, stays on the page for 18 minutes and 50 seconds.

headline: 2 Deterrents to Robocalls Win Contest by F.T.C.
text: WASHINGTON — Caller ID, Do Not Call registries, telephone number blocking — all entered the arsenal of consumer weapons against telemarketers to great acclaim, only to fall from favor as growing numbers of cold-calling solicitors found ways around them.

headline: Jumping From Party to Party to Bribery Charge
text: You could drag Malcolm A. Smith out of bed at 6 in the morning, and he’d still look like a million dollars.

headline: U.S. Grows More Helpful to International Criminal Court, a Body It First Scorned
text: THE HAGUE — When a fugitive African warlord, Gen. Bosco Ntaganda, gave himself up in March to the United States Embassy in Rwanda and asked to be sent to the International Criminal Court here, American diplomats publicized the episode and swiftly brokered the transfer.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Apr. 3, 2013
text: “The amnesty, it’s for them, the people who are there. It doesn’t mean much for us.”

headline: Denver Oil Concern Withdraws Its Plan for Big Tank in Maine
text: A Denver oil company that had proposed building a 14-story liquid-propane storage tank on the Maine coast abruptly withdrew its application on Tuesday, bringing to a sudden halt a contentious battle that had raged for three years in the tiny town of Searsport and its environs.

headline: William F. Peel III
text: Mr. Peel, 59, is the chief executive of Datawatch Systems, a company based in Bethesda, Md., that provides remote security monitoring for commercial buildings in the United States and Canada.

headline: Interpreting North Korea
text: Rendezvous’ editor, Marcus Mabry, discusses the U.S. perspective on North Korea’s actions with Mark Landler, a White House correspondent.

headline: Emissions Rules Put Alternative-Fuel Vehicles in a Bind
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Once Hobbled, New York Developer Aims for Comeback
text: David Lichtenstein presided over one of the biggest real estate debacles of the last economic cycle. In 2009, only two years after he bought a portfolio of nearly 700 hotels for $8 billion, almost all of it borrowed, he filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline: The Damage Done by a ‘Lucky Guy’
text: I WENT last week to see “Lucky Guy,” the new play by Nora Ephron about the journalist Mike McAlary, in previews. The decision to cast Tom Hanks in the lead role was brilliant. Mr. Hanks cannot be anything but endearing, almost cuddly, even though the man he is portraying was complicated and deeply flawed.

headline: Advances in Science of Fire Free a Convict After 42 Years
text: TUCSON — Prosecutors who seek a conviction on a charge of arson must first prove that a fire was intentionally set, and then that the defendant was the one who set it.

headline: Report Links High Rates of Gun Violence to Weak State Regulations
text: Many states with the weakest gun laws have the worst rates of gun violence, ranking high on numerous indicators, like gun homicides and suicides, firearm deaths of children, and killings of law enforcement officers, according to a report to be issued Wednesday by the liberal Center for American Progress.

headline: Legislative Deal Prompts Run on Connecticut Gun Shops
text: Guns shops were jammed. Gun manufacturers were angry. Gun-control advocates were thrilled. Many legislators were torn.

headline: ‘Can He Win?’ Trumps ‘Is He a Fascist?’
text: LONDON

headline: Retailers Track Employee Thefts in Vast Databases
text: Facing a wave of employee theft, retailers across the country have helped amass vast databases of workers accused of stealing and are using that information to keep employees from working again in the industry.

headline: Corrections: April 3, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: He Sings, She Sings: Who’s Right?
text: In the more than 10 years since “The Last Five Years” was first produced, this two-character musical by Jason Robert Brown about the life and death of young love has been embraced by new generations of musical-theater lovers. Watching the revival that opened at Second Stage Theater on Tuesday night, I fancifully imagined I could hear all the fans in the audience singing along in their heads. They greeted almost every number with fervent applause, as if each were the guest of honor arriving at a birthday party.

headline: Holy Fish
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — If I didn’t know any better, I would say that it is the beginning of baseball season. In fact, it opened on April 1 for most ball clubs, and soon we should be in full MOOD SWING.

headline: Scandal in Atlanta Reignites Debate Over Tests’ Role
text: There are few more contentious issues in public education than the increased reliance on standardized testing.

headline: Diplomatic Incident Arises Over Egyptian Comedian
text: CAIRO — The legal troubles of an Egyptian television comedian briefly escalated into a diplomatic incident on Tuesday, when the United States and Egypt traded barbs on Twitter and in the news media over issues including freedom of speech, religion and sovereignty.

headline: Legacy of Mets’ Injured Aces: Big Paydays for Few Victories
text: Pedro Martinez and Johan Santana came to the Mets with high hopes, reputations as clubhouse leaders and multiple Cy Young Awards. They had sterling debut seasons that kept their teams in playoff contention, but then both spent long stints on the disabled list.

headline: Should Tweets Cost You Your Job?
text: Managers and employees have to figure out how workers should represent themselves and their employers online.

headline: Accusations of Bribery Hit a Village’s Main Street
text: The large sign by the fenced-in property next to a strip mall in Spring Valley, N.Y., seemed to offer so much promise. “Coming Soon!” it said, the words floating above a picture of a mock-up of a gaudy community center and catering hall that was to have a capacity of more than 1,000 people.

headline: Happily Never After?
text: I’m worried about the Supreme Court.

headline: 2 Canadians Who Joined Algeria Attack Are Identified
text: LONDON, Ontario — Two friends who met at a high school here have been identified as among the militants who attacked an Algerian gas plant in January, an assault that left 37 hostages and 29 kidnappers dead, government officials said Tuesday.

headline: With Legacy on His Mind, Mayor Adds More Schools
text: As the clock winds down on his administration, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is moving quickly to ensure that his educational legacy lasts until long after he is gone, or at least to make it difficult for his successor to undo it.

headline: Pakistan: Attack on Power Station Leaves 7 Dead and a City Dark
text: At least seven people were killed early Tuesday in a militant attack on a power grid station outside Peshawar, the provincial capital of insurgency-riven Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province. Dozens of militants, believed to be Taliban, attacked the 500-kilowatt grid station, killing four government employees and three police officers. The militants planted bombs inside the compound and took four employees hostage. The explosions destroyed the offices and control room of the station, resulting in a power breakdown that lasted for several hours in Peshawar and neighboring areas. As the country gears for general elections on May 11, militants have stepped up their attacks on government installations and security forces, and have threatened to attack election rallies.

headline: Rangers Obtain Big Forward; Bruins Get Jagr
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — On the eve of the N.H.L. trade deadline, the Boston Bruins loaded up for the playoffs by acquiring Jaromir Jagr, and the Rangers, desperate for scoring and grit and now ninth in the Eastern Conference, acquired forward Ryane Clowe from San Jose.

headline: Devils’ Playoff Push Feels Like a Halfhearted Tap
text: NEWARK — The Devils trailed by 2-0 when the feisty right wing Tom Kostopoulos attempted to spark his seemingly listless team by dropping his gloves and exchanging blows with the Islanders’ Matt Martin on Monday night.

headline: Crosswalks in New York Are Not Havens, Study Finds
text: Pedestrians struck by cars are most often hit while in the crosswalk, with the signal on their side.

headline: Clinton Speaks Up for Women’s Issues
text: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton made her public debut in her new role as prospective presidential candidate on Tuesday night by returning to the issue that has animated her long career on the national stage — the empowerment of women around the globe.

headline: Crucible of Change in Memphis as State Takes On Failing Schools
text: MEMPHIS — Not far off a scruffy boulevard lined with dollar stores and payday loan shops in a neighborhood of run-down brick bungalows, Corning Achievement Elementary School here is a pristine refuge, with gleaming tile floors and signs in classrooms proclaiming “Whatever it takes.”

headline: Game No. 1, if Not Others, Favors Mets
text: It is one of those quirky statistics that cannot be explained, other than to concede that baseball is baseball, and the Mets are the Mets.

headline: Turning Around Failing Schools
text: Tennessee is one of a handful of states attempting a radical experiment in which schools are removed from the oversight of traditional school boards and pooled into special districts.

headline: A G.O.P. Candidate Heard His Party’s Message: To Run, You Pay
text: Last August, George T. McDonald sat down in an East Harlem restaurant with the five bosses of New York City’s Republican Party, hoping to persuade them to support his bid for mayor.

headline: Treatment Plant for Waste in Nuclear Cleanup Has Design Flaws, Panel Says
text: WASHINGTON — A treatment plant that the Energy Department is counting on to stabilize the radioactive waste at the nation’s largest environmental cleanup project, at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington State, has design problems that could lead to chemical explosions, inadvertent nuclear reactions and mechanical breakdowns, a federal advisory panel warned on Tuesday.

headline: Chuck Fairbanks, a Fitful Football Coach, Dies at 79
text: Chuck Fairbanks, who built successful football teams in college at the University of Oklahoma and in the National Football League with the New England Patriots but left each job under a cloud of disfavor, died on Tuesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 79.

headline: More Than Just Green
text: The Bullitt Center, a  new office building in Seattle, goes beyond energy conservation and recycled materials in an effort to be fully sustainable.

headline: How the Auto Industry Fared in March
text: How the Auto Industry Fared in March

headline: Officials Say Texas Inquiry Is Not Limited to White-Supremacist Gang
text: KAUFMAN, Tex. — Law enforcement officials investigating the fatal shootings of two prosecutors here have been pursuing a variety of leads, including prison interviews with members of a violent white-supremacist gang and an examination of cases worked on by both victims. But they remain no closer to linking the shootings to any particular suspects or motive.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 2, 2013

headline: A Debate in the Open on the Fed
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Federal Reserve officials regularly air their views in public speeches, but they rarely engage in public debates. On Tuesday night, two of the officials who disagree most sharply about the Fed’s current policy did just that.

headline: Former Students Recall Teachers Accused of Abuse
text: DEERFIELD, Mass. — After he went off to college, Michael Zimmerman returned when he could to Deerfield Academy, the elite boarding school he had attended for three years. On one visit to the campus, which rises in vine-covered brick from a rural stretch of this small town, he was invited by his former dormitory master, Michael Bois, for a glass of wine.

headline: Oregon: Groups Give Notice of Suit Over Coal Dust
text: An environmental coalition on Monday charged that coal and coal dust spilled from railroad hoppers is polluting the scenic Columbia River Gorge, and pledged to sue mining companies and the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railroad if they do not halt the spills. Representatives of the Sierra Club and other conservation groups said they were invoking a clause in the Clean Water Act that permits lawsuits if those accused of polluting do not remedy environmental problems within 60 days. Each coal train leaves behind 10,000 pounds of loose coal in the gorge containing heavy metals and other harmful chemicals, the groups maintained. But there has been little research on the issue, they added, and the environmental impact is unclear. The groups declined to release their own studies of the contaminants.

headline: Massachusetts: Harvard Admits Deeper Search
text: Harvard’s search of staff e-mail accounts went further than previously disclosed, administrators said Tuesday. They announced that an outside lawyer would investigate the matter and a task force would review privacy policies. President Drew Gilpin Faust and two deans revealed the developments in a faculty meeting, and the deans apologized. In investigating leaks about a cheating scandal, administrators searched subject lines in the accounts that 16 instructors have as resident deans. On Tuesday, administrators said that with one resident dean, the search included that dean’s personal Harvard account, but no e-mails were opened.

headline: N.C.A.A. Replay: April 2
text: Images from the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament, where Louisville and Notre Dame joined UConn and California in the Final Four.

headline: Anthony, With the Stage to Himself, Scores 50
text: MIAMI — Carmelo Anthony decided to try to beat the depleted Miami Heat single-handedly Tuesday night, and he succeeded.

headline: Why Big Data Is I.B.M.’s Friend
text: For big sellers of computer technology to business that are looking to stay relevant, there’s no friend quite like Big Data.

headline: Reasons Not to Stretch
text: Most of us grew up hearing that we should warm up with a stretch. Strike and hold a pose, such as touching your toes, for 30 seconds or more, we were told, and you’ll be looser, stronger and injury-proof.

headline: Word of the Day | hallucination
