text: DETROIT — Hiroki Kuroda threw a bullpen session Friday morning at Comerica Park. Despite a sore right finger, he remains on schedule to make his next start Monday in Cleveland.

headline: Collins’s Job Goes Beyond Basketball at Northwestern
text: EVANSTON, Ill.– Northwestern rolled out everything short of a purple carpet to introduce new men’s basketball Coach Chris Collins on Tuesday.

headline: American in Panama Reflects on His Cult Classic, Now Reissued
text: R. M. Koster’s novel “The Prince” is one of those cult classics that is hard to classify, and so is its author. He is an American writing in English, but he writes from and about Latin America, his home for more than 50 years, in the fantastical style associated with Gabriel García Márquez and other Spanish-language writers.

headline: Why Sanford vs. Colbert Busch Could Be Competitive
text: Former Gov. Mark Sanford won a runoff election this week, securing the Republican nomination for South Carolina’s First Congressional District. He will face the Democratic nominee, Elizabeth Colbert Busch, in a May 7 general election.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The chef Marcus Samuelsson and his wife, Maya Haile, have started Three Goats, a nonprofit organization to help children in their native Ethiopia. They are starting their fund-raising efforts on Sunday with an event from 6 to 9 p.m. at Ginny’s Supper Club, 310 Lenox Avenue in Harlem. There will be cocktails, appetizers, entertainment and a silent auction and raffle. Tickets, available online, are $150 per person, and proceeds benefit the organization.

headline: Visions of a Perfect College
text: I’m getting ready for what could be a rough month of decision-making. Instead of waiting to be surprised with a potential conflict, I’m taking the time now to decide what factors I want to keep in mind when deciding where I want to go to college.

headline: The First 100 Dates Were Just a Warm-Up
text: By the time Twist Phelan met Jack Chapple online in October 2009, she was 100 times better at dishing out rejection than accepting it.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Amateur Pursuits
text: People do the darndest things. In this week’s episode David Carr and A. O. Scott scour The Times’s newsroom for moonlighting musicians, dancers and artists.

headline: Business or Pleasure? Try Both
text: IT WAS HAPPY HOUR in Austin, Tex. The sun was sinking, and music was rising on East Sixth Street, a strip of bars and clubs with names the kid in you wants to shout out loud: Chuggin’ Monkey, Dizzy Rooster, Jackalope. Closed to cars, the street was a thoroughfare for musicians, party promoters and people looking for beer and a good time. Little by little they found it, disappearing into bars and re-emerging on balconies, drinking from plastic cups and pulling on light jackets as a March wind blew, a reminder that spring was still just out of reach.

headline: A Few Niches in Closet History
text: A playful look at the evolution and growth of the closet in New York City real estate.

headline: Drought on the Range
text: The United States cattle herd is at its lowest level in 60 years, largely because of the drought. Many ranchers are struggling to hang on.

headline: Glimmers of Jewish Glory Days in Baltimore
text: I grew up on stories about the glory days of Jewish Baltimore, when, in my father’s telling, Jews were really Jews. He told stories about walking to shul, or synagogue, with his father and uncles, seeing men and women in their Shabbat finery promenading after services, and sitting in awe as the great Viennese-trained cantor, Abba Yosef Weisgal, cried out to the heavens under the soaring ceiling of Congregation Chizuk Amuno in Reservoir Hill, the Baltimore neighborhood that my forebears called home.

headline: A Stubborn Drought Tests Texas Ranchers
text: BLOOMING GROVE, Tex. — Gary Price is a rarity among cattle ranchers these days. He’s making money on his herd of 200 cows in this tiny town about an hour south of Dallas-Fort Worth.

headline: Jewish History in Baltimore
text: Exploring a 19th-century synagogue and a street once known as Corned Beef Row.

headline: Tourism in Java’s Land of Ghosts
text: As we neared the top, a monotone world surrounded us. The thickening fog stitched gray rocks to the sky. Piles of volcanic ash sat, untrammeled, in driveways, as innocuous as autumn leaves. The narrow road snaked ever upward, passing emergency shelters and informal checkpoints.

headline: Facing a Fear of Flying
text: When Julia Cameron, the author of many books, including the popular spiritual guide to developing your creativity, “The Artist’s Way,” moved to Santa Fe, N.M., a few years ago, she found herself flying once a month to teach writing classes and workshops in New York. The frequency of the trips made her long-standing fear of flying unbearable — and embarrassing.

headline: Obama Budget Is Dismissed by G.O.P. and Attacked by Left
text: WASHINGTON — The speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, waved aside reports on Friday that President Obama would seek a new budget compromise next week, accusing the president of again demanding tax increases in exchange for “modest entitlement savings.”

headline: The Sweet Spot | Amateur Pursuits
text: People do the darndest things. In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott scour The Times’s newsroom for moonlighting musicians, dancers and artists.

headline: Popcast: New Albums by the Strokes and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs
text: On this week’s Popcast, Jon Pareles, the chief pop critic for The Times, talks to the host, Ben Ratliff, about two new albums by New York bands: the Strokes, formed in 1998, and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, formed in 2000.

headline: Judge Approves MF Global Liquidation Plan
text: A day after MF Global’s bankruptcy trustee hinted he might sue top executives for “negligent conduct,” his separate plan to liquidate the firm secured court approval, ushering in a final phase of a case that rattled Wall Street and prompted a federal investigation.

headline: Ware Takes a Break, But Will Attend Louisville’s Game
text: ATLANTA — On Friday afternoon, dozens of reporters crowded into Breakout Room No. 1, where Louisville guard Kevin Ware, he of the gruesome leg injury in the N.C.A.A. tournament, was scheduled to speak. A placard with Ware’s name rested on the table. Scribes lined the wall. Cameras crowded together in the back.

headline: The Employment Rate
text: Spare a moment for an overlooked economic indicator: The employment rate.

headline: Two Dog Owners Arrested on Animal Cruelty Charges
text: Bentley, a fluffy shih tzu mix who lived in Flatbush, Brooklyn, was administered a beating that fractured his skull and jaw and caused brain hemorrhaging, animal welfare officials said.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Batman Team Back on Top
text: The unstoppable team of Scott Snyder and Greg Capullo is at No. 1 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week, with “Batman: The City of Owls,” in which the caped crusader combats an evil tied to the earliest days of Gotham City. The top spot is not unfamiliar to Mr. Snyder and Mr. Capullo — they were there last month with “Batman: Night of the Owls,” another chapter in the superhero’s battle against the Court of Owls.

headline: Vain Glorious | Olfactive Studio
text: “Images and perfumes have always been linked,” says Céline Verleure, a 20-year fragrance industry veteran based in Paris. “When we smell a perfume, it gives us images in our heads, like a landscape or a scene.” A few years ago, she decided to explore this relationship further by asking perfumers to collaborate with photographers on a series of eau de parfums inspired by the visual artists’ works. Thus, Olfactive Studio was born, and the French brand’s five highly concentrated unisex scents arrive in the United States on April 8. “The perfumers are able to create on a spiritual level. Olivier Cresp, who worked on the Flash Back fragrance with the photographer Laurent Segretier, says there’s a new and special freedom in starting with the visual,” Verleure notes. Her current favorite in the lineup is Lumière Blanche, a milky yet fresh and spicy concoction from the perfumer Sidonie Lancesseur, who drew her inspiration from the famed photographer Massimo Vitali’s picture of sunbathers gathered on the ivory-hued Scala dei Turchi cliff in southern Sicily. To fully experience the connection between the visual and olfactory elements, Verleure suggests first choosing a scent based on the image, which adorns the fragrance box, and then smelling the juice second. “Pick the photo that gives you the most emotion, and you will really like that perfume. It works!” she says.

headline: Stock From Every Chicken
text: In today’s video I demonstrate how to cut up a whole chicken, which is a worthwhile thing to know and not at all hard. I also show how to take the chicken back (and neck and innards, if your chicken came with them — not all of them do) and turn it into a small batch of chicken stock. I usually make the stock immediately after cutting up the chicken, but you could also save the back for later. You could freeze it if you’ve got the freezer space or, if you want to combine it with the leftover bones from the chicken you are cooking, like I did with the chicken curry that I describe in this week’s column, you can stick the back in the fridge for a day or two.

headline: The Dark Side of Verbs-as-Nouns
text: In my previous essay, I wrote about nominalization — the deployment as nouns of words we mostly expect to encounter as verbs or adjectives. Aware of many people’s tendency to vilify this kind of usage, I speculated about the psychology behind it. I was interested in thinking about why someone might prefer “Do you have a solve for this problem?” to “Can you solve this problem?”

headline: Easing Access to Contraception
text: The Times’s Pam Belluck explains how the emergency nature of the morning-after pill pushed a federal judge to increase its availability.

headline: Q & A
text: Dreaming of a Solarium

headline: Friday Night Music: Fleetwood Mac
text: It’s only Friday afternoon, but I have places to go and things to do.

headline: Outside the Studio, Ramping Up the Funk
text: On the way from the studio to the stage, Jessie Ware’s songs got a big boost of funk and soul.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Baby Who Won’t Eat Solved!
text: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 3-month-old baby who stopped eating and became weak. More than 700 readers wrote in with their take on this terrifying case. More than 100 nailed the diagnosis. And I loved all the discussion!

headline: Reclaim the Center
text: Not surprisingly, troubled economic times often beget proselytizers of wacky, extreme ideas. The stagflation of the 1970s blessed us with damaging wage and price controls and the utterly counterintuitive supply-side notion — famously drawn on a napkin — that cutting taxes would lead to higher tax revenues.

headline: Even Its Players Learned About Wichita State on the Fly
text: ATLANTA – Do you know much about Wichita State University? No? You are not alone. Even the players on this year’s Final Four surprise team admitted to having little institutional knowledge about the university of roughly 12,000 undergraduates located in the largest city in Kansas.

headline: Examining a Humor Born of Many Struggles
text: The choreographer Camille A. Brown begins “Mr. TOL E. RAncE,” a look at race, stereotypes and the way humor plays into them, with a video montage of numbers from minstrel shows. During the screening her dancers, wearing suspenders, gray suits and caps, quietly assemble onto a darkened stage as if in mourning.

headline: Off the Shelf | ‘Light Years’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Paradigm Shift | Tools for Life
text: After its sneak preview in January at the fall 2013 Prada men’s fashion shows, “Tools for Life,” the furniture collection designed for Knoll by OMA, the architecture office that was co-founded by Rem Koolhaas, will make its official debut next week during the Salone Internazionale del Mobile in Milan. The collection, which will be on view April 9 and 10 at Prada’s exhibition space at Via Fogazzaro 36, consists of pieces that address the increasingly blurred boundaries between working and living space by being kinetic rather than static. As Koolhaas said, his goal was to create furniture “that performs in very precise but also in completely unpredictable ways” and indeed, flexibility is the key here. A massive, heavily engineered piece called the 04 Counter consists of three horizontal bars that stack like a wall, but which can also pivot and cantilever, transforming the piece from room divider to “piazza,” as Benjamin Pardo, Knoll’s design director, called it, adding, “Once people discover that the object moves, they want to engage with it.”

headline: A Motivational Thread Ties the Junction Boys to Rutgers
text: The death of Jack Pardee on Monday and the firing of the Rutgers men’s basketball coach Mike Rice on Wednesday bring us to a compelling intersection of coaching norms and excessive behavior. They also remind us that the good old days weren’t all that good.

headline: Financial Lessons for American Expatriates
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about the tax rules in the United States that can trip up Americans living abroad. The rules have become tougher as the United States tries to find secret overseas accounts. And the rules are also affecting more people as more Americans find job opportunities far from home.

headline: Malala Yousafzai Announces Grant for Girls’ Education
text: Malala Yousafzai, the teenaged Pakistani girl who was shot by the Taliban in 2012 because of her activism for girls’ education, has announced the first grant in an international fund set up in her name.

headline: Rap’s Peter Pan Considers Alternatives
text: There are so many ways to be young: ignore responsibility, look wide-eyed at the world, rile up elders, don’t deliver on promises, make fun of the incomprehensible, avoid feeling, believe in yourself over all others. It’s part liability, part opportunity. Sometimes it’s a fixed condition, sometimes it’s a choice.

headline: Vibrations From Brazil, Church and Deep in Your Headphones
text: Ensemble Pearl

headline: A 2-Bedroom With a Home for the Car
text: It wasn’t that Jennifer Song Kim liked moving so often, but that moving was a small and temporary hardship far outweighed by the chance to live in a new neighborhood. So she and Richard Kim, who were married a little more than four years ago, moved within Manhattan every time their lease was up.

headline: Big Ticket | $10.2 Million for Sweeping Vistas
text: A duplex penthouse distinguished by a pair of romantic Moorish-style arched brick terraces near the top of the Barbizon/63, at 140 East 63rd Street, sold for $10,182,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Appily Ever After: A Smartphone Shrink
text: When I was a kid, my favorite toy was the Magic 8 Ball. There was something immensely comforting about asking this little gizmo a question (“Will I find true love?”), shaking it and then seeing the answer that would bubble to the top of the screen: “Outlook good.”

headline: Wheelies: The Dear Leader Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Week in Review: Lessons From Top Women on Wall Street
text: Blame abounds over a flawed foreclosure review. | A lawsuit by the ex-wife of the SAC Capital founder is revived on appeal. | DealBook’s special section: women in a man’s world. | S.E.C. sets rules for disclosures using social media. | Andrew Ross Sorkin asks a $25 million question over a bid for Dell. | Pay for boards at banks soars amid cutbacks.

headline: If It’s Aliens, at Least They Won’t Be Naked
text: Lots of outlets — Nickelodeon, ABC Family, the Disney Channel — have taken aim at that elusive, possibly nonexistent swath of Americans who just want to be able to watch television together as a family without worrying that something distasteful or inappropriate for children will pop up. But everyone seems to have a different idea of what kind of content that demographic craves.

headline: Rundown and Cluttered, a Sacred Space for Music Prepares to Move
text: Four-fifty West 41st Street, a rundown blue-tiled former warehouse by the Lincoln Tunnel, is the unimpressive sort of city architecture that you walk by without noticing. A shaky elevator ride up to the sixth floor, and the rooms behind the white door hold a trove of bland metal desks overflowing with papers and office plants growing down a shelf of books.

headline: A Bartender’s Sojourn, Garnished With Adventure
text: PARIS — It’s already 10:15 at night and Colin Field has been waiting for nearly three hours in a windowless, overheated bar at the back of a taco shop in the Marais district to create his new cocktail.

headline: Boeing’s 787 Takes Flight to Assess New Battery
text: A Boeing 787 flew for nearly two hours on Friday in a flight that wrapped up the company’s tests of modifications meant to prevent fires in its lithium-ion batteries.

headline: MF Global Bankruptcy Saga
text: Whereas bailouts and rescues often obscure the dirty details of exactly why a particular financial institution failed, bankruptcies have a way of bringing everything to light.

headline: Ex-Senator Is Tempted by Neighbor
text: If the special Senate election in Massachusetts has put the political cognoscenti to sleep, a possible race in neighboring New Hampshire may wake them up.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 5
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: A Quick Electronic Signature at the Car Rental Office, and Then Trouble
text: Sandra McKinnon knew the drill after three trips from Oakland, Calif., to Tulsa, Okla., to visit her elderly father. When she went to pick up a rental car, she would have to decide whether to buy the insurance.

headline: Bending a Club Legend to His Own Purposes
text: One thing musicians often say about playing at the Village Vanguard, New York’s oldest extant jazz club, is that you have to make your peace with the ghosts in the room. What that means has less to do with the spirit realm than with the specters of historical memory shaped by famous recordings and firsthand experiences, and made all the more immediate by the photographic portraits on the wall.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A six-bedroom colonial in New Rochelle, N.Y., that includes a stained glass dome, and a Tudor with a patio and pool in Nassau County, N.Y.

headline: Obama Apologizes for Praising Attorney General’s Looks
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama late Thursday night called Kamala Harris, the California attorney general, and apologized to her for telling a group of wealthy donors that she is the “best-looking attorney general in the country.”

headline: Everybody Loses in This Beauty Contest
text: MY GUESS IS, in the pause following President Obama’s comment “by far the best-looking attorney general in the country” — after he had praised Kamala Harris’s achievements — some guests at the private fund-raiser in California cringed and said to themselves, “Oh, no … he went there.”

headline: Running Into Problems at the Car Rental Counter
text: If you’ve ever rented a car, you know the questions that you need to be prepared to answer at the rental counter: Do you want insurance? Do you need it?

headline: One Fish, Two Fish
text: Everyone knows fish is good for you, but many of us get stuck eating the same varieties — tuna, cod, salmon and shrimp. This week Martha Rose Shulman explores the flavor and benefits of trying new types of fish.

headline: How Skeptics and Believers Can Connect
text: STANFORD, Calif.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Brooklyn Heights studio with a panoramic view, a SoHo prewar one-bedroom and an Upper West Side apartment with two bedrooms and a working fireplace.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 5
text: More photographs.

headline: Ask Well: More Repetitions vs. More Weight?
text: Question:

headline: Looking Ahead at ‘Mad Men’
text: Logan Hill and Sloane Crosley predict what season six of “Mad Men” has in store for viewers.

headline: Do We Really Hate Anne Hathaway?
text: Will they ever stop hating on Anne Hathaway?

headline: Embassy Warning Joins Drumbeat of North Korea Threats
text: MOSCOW — The North Korean government on Friday advised Russia and other countries to consider evacuating their embassies in Pyongyang amid rising tension there, Russia’s foreign minister said.

headline: Hybrid Drivers Wanted
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — Every major car company has its own DNA, a set of qualities that make it clear to drivers that they are behind the wheel of a Chevy, a Toyota or a BMW. And just like a healthy human’s genetic code, automotive DNA should be an immutable thing, regardless of the technology powering the wheels.

headline: Volkswagen’s New Frontier
text: The Jetta Hybrid represents uncharted territory for VW, whose identity is fundamentally characterized by the rumble of an efficient internal-combustion engine.

headline: The Economy’s Spring Slide
text: The Times’s Catherine Rampell and Nathaniel Popper on how slow payroll growth affects a struggling recovery.

headline: A Cocktail of Beers, Pencils and a Model
text: Sunday nights used to be slow at Macri Park, a no-nonsense neighborhood bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. But on a recent evening, patrons jammed into banquettes and sat on the floor, all eyeing Danny Casner, a 28-year-old tattooed bike messenger who wore nothing but black American Apparel underwear and checkered Vans.

headline: Diesel Efficiency With a Solar Enhancement
text: TESTED: 2013 Volkswagen Beetle TDI convertible

headline: How Do I Get My Child Into _____?
text: April 12 | Updated  Read Sarah Kramer’s interview with Robert Sanft.

headline: Ebert Was a Critic Whose Sting Was Salved by Caring
text: By midafternoon on Thursday the digital common was crowded with mourners. #Ebert and #RIPEbert crowded out all the other hashtags on Twitter. Every movie blogger, entertainment journalist, critic and film buff who had crossed paths with Roger Ebert or absorbed his influence — which is to say just about all of us — posted an elegy or a reminiscence. Along with those collegial and filial tributes came salutes from filmmakers and a statement from the White House after his death at 70, almost surely the first time a film critic has been eulogized by a president.

headline: The Catch of the Day in Amphawa
text: Vendors in the floating market of Amphawa, Thailand, display a recent catch of seafood from their small boats. Amphawa is located about an hour west of Bangkok, in the Samut Songkhram province. The picturesque village is known for canals that feed off the Mae Khlong River, where visitors can dine from the boats.

headline: F.A.A. Delays Closings of Airport Towers Forced by Cuts
text: LEESBURG, Va. — The Federal Aviation Administration said Friday that it would delay closing control towers at 149 airports until June to allow for safety analyses and “to attempt to resolve multiple legal challenges.”

headline: Wrestling’s Private Equity Champion
text: Michael Novogratz, a principal at the Fortress Investment Group and former Princeton wrestler, is trying to score an emergency takedown. Since the International Olympic Committee voted to eliminate wrestling starting in 2020, Mr. Novogratz has been working the phones from a war room inside Fortress’s 46th-floor headquarters in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: The New WRX Concept Shows Off Subaru’s New Design Language
text: Osamu Namba, the Subaru design chief, made a surprise appearance at the New York International Auto Show last week for the unveiling of the new WRX concept. In an interview at the company’s stand, he said the car presented the company’s new design language, parts of which were seen in the Viziv concept shown at the Geneva auto show in March. As the most extreme of Subaru designs, the WRX offers the company a chance to render the new vocabulary in striking form.

headline: The First Lady of Yoga
text: Vaguely indicating the lower torso, the word “core” has been rippling (as it were) through American fitness programs for about a decade. But the yogini Colleen Saidman Yee likes to be more specific.

headline: As Workload Overwhelms, Cars Are Set to Intervene
text: Heading south on Route 34 toward Jersey Shore beaches on a summer weekend, drivers confront a daunting array of highway quirks, not limited to jughandle intersections and baffling exit signs.

headline: Outside the Red Rooster, a Rare Break in the Bustle
text: In this weekend’s Food & Drink Issue, you’ll find something you might never otherwise see: nearly 130 employees of Marcus Samuelsson’s Harlem restaurant, Red Rooster, gathered in one place, and standing still. Stephen Wilkes photographed the group around 10 a.m. on a Saturday, and everyone — from the line cooks to the dishwashers to the chef himself — wore their work outfits. You can watch a time-lapse video of the shoot above, and see some behind-the-scenes photos of the day below.

headline: Managing a Driver’s Many Inputs
text: The study of driver workload management is progressing alongside the efforts of the planners who dream up new generations of infotainment features.

headline: Mad, Mad World
text: Each week the author Sloane Crosley and the journalist Logan Hill will chat here about all things “Mad Men.”

headline: A New Element for a Lawyer’s Victory, Long After Death
text: The vote on Thursday by Alabama lawmakers to issue posthumous pardons to the nine Scottsboro Boys would have pleased Samuel S. Leibowitz of Brooklyn.

headline: Guide Revisions Provoke Uproar
text: Proposed changes to the used-car Buyers Guide required by the Federal Trade Commission have been criticized by consumer groups and the attorneys general of 22 states, who say the revisions would be a setback in consumer protection.

headline: The Search for 9/11 Remains Goes On
text: Update, May 17: The office of the chief medical examiner is sifting through 590 cubic yards of material excavated from around the World Trade Center in search of fragments that may be human remains. On Thursday, two such fragments were recovered from the Vehicle Security Center area. That brought the total to 78 since work began on April 1; 44 from the C-Grid area outside the World Financial Center, 34 from the Vehicle Security Center.

headline: Yankees Lose Another Shortstop Against the Tigers
text: DETROIT — It was six months ago that the Yankees were knocked out of the postseason here in humiliating fashion, barely scoring a run in Detroit’s four-game sweep. On Friday, the Yankees returned and immediately encountered more of the same.

headline: Comparing Italian TV to ‘The Truman Show,’ Italian Blogger Calls for Sweeping Reform
text: Beppe Grillo, the Italian populist who started the insurgent Five Star Movement online after he was barred from state television channels for his political comedy, plans to press for sweeping reform of Italy’s public broadcaster RAI through new legislation.

headline: The Fries-With-That Economy
text: One of the more striking patterns in the recovery has been the fast clip of low-wage job growth. The best example of this is probably in food services and drinking places, which have been adding jobs for 37 consecutive months. (Employment over all has been growing for 30 consecutive months.) Over that time, eating and drinking places have added 856,200 jobs.

headline: Donating Their No. 26 Jerseys to Aid Newtown
text: HAMDEN, Conn. — Dave Clarke, the women’s soccer coach at Quinnipiac University, was exchanging instant messages with Lauren Carmody Grenier, a former team captain, on the morning of Dec. 14. It was the type of online tête-à-tête in which spelling and punctuation were secondary to speed.

headline: The Highest-Paid C.E.O.’s
text: 100 of the most highly paid chief executives at U.S. public companies in 2012.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photos from India, Mali, China and Gaza Strip.

headline: Anheuser-Busch Merger Deal Clears an Antitrust Hurdle
text: 8:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: Bill Cunningham | Parading
text: On Fifth Avenue, the public still enjoys dressing up for Easter and making their own looks.

headline: An Ensemble in Flux Plays Pieces From Its Past
text: In the long months that have passed since the conductor James Levine resigned from his position as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in September 2011, the ensemble has seemed caught up in questions of what it is and what it will be. Mr. Levine’s seven-season tenure brought artistic progress but also mounting frustration regarding his increasing inability to work due to injury and illness.

headline: Queer Theory May Not Have a Beat, but Academicians Can Still Dance to It
text: The gender theorist Judith Butler has been assailed by critics as the academic world’s worst writer. But on Thursday night at the downtown performance space Dixon Place, she was celebrated as the “Girl From Ipanema.”

headline: Young, Quicksilver and Never Daunted
text: For its premiere in 1984 at City Center, Murray Louis’s “Four Brubeck Pieces” was accompanied by none other than the Dave Brubeck Quartet. When Juilliard students danced the work on Wednesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, the four Brubeck songs were played by a crack quartet of Juilliard jazz musicians. Not a bad substitute, really.

headline: Fisker Automotive Lays Off Majority of Employees
text: Fisker Automotive, the maker of a $100,000-and-up plug-in hybrid luxury sedan, said on Friday that about three-quarters of its workers had been let go to “allow the company to work through its current financial challenges.”

headline: JPMorgan Works to Avert Split of Chief and Chairman Roles
text: JPMorgan Chase is working behind the scenes to avert a major potential embarrassment.

headline: Traditional Polish Fare for the Early Birds
text: The cozy dining room at Krakowiak Restaurant is nothing fancy, and the service is brisk, but the plain food is carefully prepared, thoughtfully presented and delicious in a way that recalls a past era. That could explain the steady stream of customers on my visits, maybe half of them in their 60s or older, all of them entering as if they knew every nook in the place.

headline: Photo Replay: April 5
text: A view of the day in sports, including wall-to-wall defense in Denver.

headline: Discuss Tensions on the Korean Peninsula
text: As our colleague Martin Fackler reports, “Despite the steady drum beat of war talk, life seems to go on as usual in most of South Korea,” even near the heavily fortified border that separates the American ally from the increasingly belligerent North.

headline: Beyond the Whimsy, Sushi With Ambition
text: Once upon a time there was Once Upon a Moose, a quirky little landmark of a lunch place that you took your mother to for tea and an omelet after browsing the used books in one of the eclectic cliff-top shops down the street. It had a run for decades in its prime corner spot in tiny Sea Cliff; then the site was briefly home to Olives by the Sea, a boho tapas bistro.

headline: Week in Pictures, April 4
text: A look back at the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: Investigation Report on Mike Rice
text: A report by outside counsel commissioned by Rutgers on how to handle concerns of abusive behavior by Mike Rice, who was fired this week as the men’s basketball coach.

headline: Dell Offers to Reimburse Icahn for Deal Work, With Strings Attached
text: A special committee of Dell‘s board offered on Friday to reimburse Carl C. Icahn up to $25 million worth of expenses tied to a possible bid for the computer company – provided that he plays nicely.

headline: From Scratch, Making Meals Appear
text: The drab-gray exterior of 50 West does little to attract attention, and compared with the towering pink neon and gleaming chrome facade of a neighboring diner, it appears to be a model of discretion. That sense of subtlety is reinforced by rooms simply decorated with honey oak paneling, washed-mango paint, a few mirrors and glass chandeliers.

headline: U.S. and Japan Agree on Returning Okinawa Land
text: TOKYO — The United States and Japan agreed Friday on a new timetable for the return to Japan of a Marine airfield and other military bases on Okinawa, moving to solve a long-festering issue that has bedeviled America’s ties with its largest Asian ally.

headline: Jacoby Open Swiss Teams at Spring Nationals
text: ST. LOUIS — On the final day of the Spring Nationals here last month, the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams were captured by Richard Schwartz of Aventura, Fla.; Allan Graves of St. Johnsbury, Vt.; Boye Brogeland and Espen Lindqvist from Norway; and Jon Baldursson and Thorlakur Jonsson from Iceland.

headline: Fake Twitter Followers Become Multimillion-Dollar Business
text: Far from slowing, the market for fake Twitter followers seems to be taking off.

headline: Germans See Hope in Leak for Fighting Tax Evasion
text: BERLIN — Typically, major countries issue ringing denunciations when privacy guarantees are breached and secret information is disclosed, particularly when such disclosures concern those nations’ wealthiest individuals. But the leak this week of information on tens of thousands of offshore accounts, many set up by German banks, was received with glee by German officials.

headline: A Mixture of Mexican Hustle and Charm
text: On our first visit to Guapo Cocina Mexicana, two of my guests stood outside and peered through the plate-glass window while I fed the parking meter. By the time I joined them, they wore big grins: the manager of the restaurant, sensing an opportunity, had come out into the cold and handed them coupons for free margaritas. It was this mix of hustle and charm offensive — and lively, well-priced, authentic Mexican dishes — that had us developing a little crush on Guapo.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

text: Not since 1979 has such a small share of the population been working or actively looking for a job.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Ten Years Later, McNamara Hopes He’s Still on Target
text: ATLANTA — A smile worked its way across Gerry McNamara’s face as he described the 10-year-old feeling that will never be forgotten. His eyes widened, his mouth perked up and he failed to contain the grin of a shooter talking about a time the basket never seemed bigger.

headline: Assaults in Istanbul
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Climate Justice’
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Composer Who Escapes Easy Labels
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — The path to the music room in Steven Mackey’s spacious Princeton home is lined with toys: a phalanx of toddler-size vehicles, a toy kitchen, a Thomas the Tank Engine table crisscrossed with rail tracks. Next to the brightly colored plastic objects, the black grand piano takes on the wryly amused look of a buttoned-up uncle at a birthday party, besieged on all sides by cheerful chaos.

headline: Week in Pictures for April 5
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a baby giraffe, the Yankees’ opening day and political corruption.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Street Art of the Arab World on YouTube
text: The Cairene journalist and blogger Soraya Morayef, who has written extensively about the Egyptian revolution’s graffiti, has produced a series of new video reports on street art of the Arab world, as part of a series for MOCAtv, the YouTube channel of the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Silicon Valley Poverty and Verizon Contracts
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Family Seeks Return of a Matisse Seized by the Nazis
text: The heirs of a French art dealer are demanding that a Norwegian museum return one of its featured paintings, a Matisse that was confiscated by the Nazis in 1941 in Paris.

headline: An Unorthodox Look at a President’s Home
text: OYSTER BAY, N.Y. — Early last year, shortly after Theodore Roosevelt’s stately home, Sagamore Hill, was closed to the public for a three-year, $7.2 million restoration, a photographer who uses the name Xiomáro was allowed into the 23-room mansion to take pictures. Many of the home’s 14,000 objects had already been placed in storage or moved elsewhere, and he didn’t have to stand behind the velvet ropes that prevent ordinary visitors from getting too close to the elaborate wallpaper, fancy woodwork and handsome fireplace mantels of the house where the 26th president lived from 1887 until his death in 1919 (except when he lived in the White House from 1901 to 1909).

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Drawing Evolves, Testing Its Boundaries
text: While drawing once served an auxiliary function — that is, as studies for paintings, sculpture and architecture — over the last century it became a stand-alone medium. And like other art media in this age of cultural and technological flux and innovation, its definition is often pushed to the limits. You can sense this just from the title of “Extreme Drawing” at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: Settlement Is Reached With Family in Slaying
text: MIAMI — The parents of Trayvon Martin, the unarmed teenager who was shot by George Zimmerman last year, have settled a wrongful-death lawsuit against the homeowners’ association in the gated community where he was killed.

headline: Cuomo Picks Judge in City to Fill Spot at Top Court
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo nominated Justice Sheila Abdus-Salaam on Friday to fill a vacancy on the state’s highest court, and if confirmed, she would become the first African-American woman to serve on it.

headline: Interfaith Unions: A Mixed Blessing
text: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.

headline: In Jodhpurs, Hailing Caesar With Seduction
text: The director David McVicar’s imaginative, daffy and affecting production of Handel’s “Giulio Cesare,” which opened at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night, is new to the company but not to the opera world. It was introduced at the Glyndebourne Festival in England in 2005, has played there and elsewhere since then, and is available on DVD.

headline: ‘Giulio Cesare’
text: An imaginative “Giulio Cesare” at the Metropolitan Opera, with David Daniels and Natalie Dessay.

headline: Rubio, Amid Planning, Is Yet to Commit on Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON — When Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, last appeared with a bipartisan group of senators to discuss their plans for a broad overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws, he looked optimistic, apple-cheeked — and slightly nervous.

headline: Steak for Two, Please, With a Side of Bribes
text: One day in December, a member of the New York State Assembly walked into Peter Luger, the Brooklyn steakhouse against which all others are compared.

headline: If the Church Is Serious About Welcoming Gays...
text: IN an Easter morning appearance on ABC’s “This Week,” Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, spoke words that some gay and lesbian Catholics thought they might never hear.

headline: America’s Left Bank
text: Greenwich Village was, from the beginning, home to the city’s outliers, New Yorkers who for one reason or another escaped or were exiled from the teeming, pestilent, Tory, boss-controlled and buttoned-down tip of Downtown Manhattan to the “Left Bank of America.”

headline: With All Its Titles, Bayern Munich Hungers for an Elusive One
text: BERLIN — They wear red uniforms, have an unfair concentration of top athletic talent and are crushing the rest of their league into submission. They are not the Miami Heat, but Germany’s F.C. Bayern Munich.

headline: U.S. Spurns California Move for Greater Say on Prisons
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A federal judge on Friday rejected California’s motion to regain control of mental health care in its prisons, ruling that the quality of care failed to meet standards required by the Constitution. The move dealt a blow to Gov. Jerry Brown’s broader efforts to bring the prisons back under the state’s authority.

headline: As Brazil’s Influence Expands, So Does a Campaign Strategist’s Success
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil

headline: Breach Through Fire Island Also Divides Opinions
text: FIRE ISLAND, N.Y. — If on some stretches of this barrier island the scars of Hurricane Sandy are fading, at a spot called Old Inlet, a physical reminder of the storm remains: a channel, now 856 feet wide, through which seawater pours into the Great South Bay. The breach, in a federal wilderness area at the eastern end of the island, has already helped clean the much-compromised bay.

headline: A Shaman, Coaxing Sobriety
text: One by one they squeezed into a meeting room at a Harlem needle exchange on Thursday — roughly two dozen men and women with drug problems — and Dimitri Mugianis, 50, greeted them all.

headline: Recent Polling on Nationwide Gun Control
text: Recent Polling on Nationwide Gun Control

headline: A Suburban Standoff
text: For the past year, the 32-year-old mayor of Ellisville, Mo., has been at war with its City Council, which is now trying to remove him from office.

headline: Impeachment Proceedings Break a Small Town’s Quiet
text: ELLISVILLE, Mo. — At a glance, this town of 9,000 offers the peaceful allure of suburban American life: good schools, tranquil, neatly manicured housing developments and large strip malls accommodating myriad retail needs.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. Thomas F. Byrnes, who became New York City’s chief of detectives in 1880, is often credited with establishing the first extensive illustrated police catalog of known criminals, as the F.Y.I. column of Jan. 20 reported. But hadn’t the New York Police Department opened a rogues’ gallery of photographs of villains well before his time?

headline: Jury Still Out on Killer of Psychologist
text: Jurors in the trial of David Tarloff, a schizophrenic man charged in the 2008 murder of an Upper East Side psychologist, finished their third day of deliberations on Friday without reaching a verdict.

headline: Local Stop: Bay Ridge
text: In Bay Ridge, urban meets suburban, and many cultures mingle.

headline: Detecting Shift, U.S. Makes Case to China on North Korea
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, detecting what it sees as a shift in decades of Chinese support for North Korea, is pressuring China’s new president, Xi Jinping, to crack down on the regime in Pyongyang or face a heightened American military presence in its region.

headline: Texas Police Seeking Clues to How Killer Got in Home
text: KAUFMAN, Tex. — Investigators looking for clues in the killing of the local district attorney and his wife are trying to answer a key question about the crime: did the couple know the person or people who shot them?

headline: Players Club Removes Director Amid Turmoil
text: The Players, a 124-year-old private club on Gramercy Park, removed its long-serving executive director this week amid charges of financial mismanagement, several members and employees said on Friday.

headline: Death Again Visits a Racecourse on Trial
text: AINTREE, England — The death of a second horse in two days at the Grand National meeting at Aintree Racecourse has dampened spirits on the eve of the 166th running of the Grand National steeplechase, a race that animal rights groups declared to be “on a yellow card” after a run of 18 deaths in the past 20 years, including four in the past two races.

headline: Where Urban Meets Suburban
text: Looped by parkways and bounded to the west by shoreline, Bay Ridge looks self-contained on a map: an island at the edge of Brooklyn. But the neighborhood is anything but insular. Italian specialty shops, Turkish diners, Norwegian delis and Lebanese restaurants along Third and Fourth Avenues suggest its richly diverse population. And Bay Ridge’s streets seem similarly mixed — decidedly urban on one block, suburban on the next.

headline: Hepatitis Alert for Restaurant’s Diners
text: Diners who recently ate at a West Village restaurant may be at risk of contracting hepatitis A and should be vaccinated, the New York City health department said on Friday.

headline: Storm Debris Transformed by a Treehouse Architect, or a Big Bird
text: Of all the trees toppled in the city by Hurricane Sandy, perhaps none had been more lovely than those in public gardens and arboretums. At Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the storm’s victims included Persian ironwood, persimmon, black walnut and Japanese flowering cherry trees.

headline: U.N. Says It Is Running Out of Money to Assist Wave of Refugees From Syria
text: GENEVA — The United Nations will soon have to start cutting off lifesaving aid to people fleeing the war in Syria because the exodus has far outstripped financial support from international donors, one agency at the center of the humanitarian relief effort warned on Friday.

headline: Good Sense on the Morning-After Pill
text: A federal district judge in New York has overturned the Obama administration’s ban preventing girls younger than 17 from purchasing emergency contraceptive pills over the counter. It was a well-deserved rebuke to a politically motivated decision that overrode sound science and the health needs of young girls in order to placate political opponents of emergency contraception.

headline: A Tax Scandal Adds to French Malaise
text: France is reeling from a scandal all but guaranteed to widen the chasm between its recession-battered voters and a Socialist government still peddling fiscal austerity.

headline: Hunger Strike at Guantánamo
text: The hunger strike that has spread since early February among the 166 detainees still at Guantánamo Bay is again exposing the lawlessness of the system that marooned them there. The government claims that around 40 detainees are taking part. Lawyers for detainees report that their clients say around 130 detainees in one part of the prison have taken part.

headline: Progress on Okinawa
text: Tensions in Okinawa over the American military presence on that island have festered for decades. On Friday, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan showed political leadership by agreeing with the United States on a timetable for reducing the size of the American force and returning some land used as a military base.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Apr. 6, 2013
text: "I started crawling. I’d stop for a few minutes, then start crawling again.”

headline: Crosswords, Cooking and Other Sports
text: Last week, Ron Darling, the retired starting pitcher for the New York Mets, returned to work as an announcer for his former team on TBS and SportsNet New York. Mr. Darling, 52, is doing commentary at several games a week, including Sunday’s against the Miami Marlins at Citi Field. During the season, Mr. Darling, who lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with his wife, Joanna, an interior designer, spends his Sundays at the ballpark; the rest of the year, his weekends are more family-oriented.

headline: Carmine Infantino, Reviver of Batman and Flash, Dies at 87
text: Carmine Infantino — the man who SAVED BATMAN! — died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Infantino, a celebrated comic-book artist who also drew the Flash, was 87.

headline: Video Reviews Can Be Accidental Game Changers
text: ATLANTA — The last 10 minutes of a college basketball game will never be described as crisp. Between television stoppages and a never-ending procession of coaches’ timeouts, the average fan watching an N.C.A.A. tournament game often sees an abundance of commercials, countless team huddles and the odd spurt of game action, which typically has all the rhythm of rush-hour traffic.

headline: Corrections: April 6, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Less Culpable, but With Longer Sentences
text: PHOENIX — Members of a white supremacy group descended on a home here 11 years ago to scare a man into paying back the $200 his roommate had accused him of stealing. The attack ended in the man’s death.

headline: Debating Death Penalties
text: Prosecutors in many of the states that carry the death penalty have to weigh the high cost of mounting a capital trial against the likelihood of a conviction when deciding whom to charge.

headline: Label for the Bee Gees
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the most wonderful and frustrating aspects of solving a Saturday crossword puzzle is the tease: just enough stuff you know in order to get a toehold, combined with tough-as-nails clues that stop you dead in your tracks the first time you look through them.

headline: U.S. Attorney Added Staff to Fight Corruption
text: The two federal cases that mesmerized Albany this week — a state senator accused of trying to bribe his way onto the New York City mayoral ballot and an assemblyman charged with taking payoffs to write made-to-order legislation — come as federal prosecutors in Manhattan have increased their focus on political corruption, officials said on Friday.

headline: Ties Between Congress and the Tax Lobby
text: Analysis of lobby filings show ties between Congress and the tax lobby.

headline: Back in Majors, Pitcher Maine Denies Lying to Mets in 2010
text: The last five pitches of John Maine’s time with the Mets were the most painful of his career, not because of what he felt in his shoulder, but because of what was said about him afterward.

headline: Paying Respect to Ancestors
text: Families gathered at a cemetery in Westchester County to honor their ancestors before the Chinese festival Qingming.

headline: Chinese Families Celebrate Qingming Festival in New York
text: VALHALLA, N.Y. — Three generations of the Cung family gathered at Kensico Cemetery in Westchester County last Sunday to place cans of guava juice, paper money, paper dress shoes and a paper copy of a Louis Vuitton purse before the headstone of Lien Sau Khau, the family matriarch. The offerings were later set aflame, sending them to Ms. Lien to use in the other world.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 5, 2013

headline: New Name Near Top Isn’t a Shock to Everyone
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The appearance near the top of the Kraft Nabisco Championship leader board of Jodi Ewart Shadoff, a nonwinner on the L.P.G.A. Tour, came as no surprise to the sports anchor where she lives in Sarasota, Fla. He pointed out that Ewart Shadoff ranked second on the tour in greens in regulation and was in the top 25 in driving accuracy.

headline: Asteroid Wanted in NASA Project
text: The budget being readied by the Obama administration has one item that might sound outlandish: nabbing an asteroid.

headline: Renaissance in Grand Central
text: Members of the Renaissance Street Singers perform free concerts in Grand Central Terminal over the winter months.

headline: First Traveler on Unusual Route to Masters
text: As dusk settled over Augusta National Golf Club in January, John Peterson prepared to play the famous par-3 12th hole, the most photographed golf real estate in the world. The moment was overwhelming, so he backed away from the ball.

headline:
In Connecticut,
New Firearms
Limits Faced
Uphill Fight
text: HARTFORD — Almost from the moment that Adam Lanza ended his siege, it seemed that Connecticut, dominated by Democrats and already with some of the nation’s toughest gun laws, would quickly pass sweeping new restrictions on firearms.

headline: Veterans’ Programs Are Set for Raise in Spending Plan
text: WASHINGTON — Facing growing criticism from Congress, veterans’ groups and even late-night television hosts, the Obama administration announced on Friday that it would include significant increases for veterans’ programs, including money for mental health services, in the budget it unveils next week.

headline: Why Rutgers Blinked
text: ATLANTA

headline: A New Era in Political Corruption
text: Have you ever noticed how high the bar is when it comes to getting arrested for political corruption? Really, you practically have to go around with a sign that says “Will Trade Influence for Cash.”

headline: The Young are the Restless
text: The surge of generational change continues in this country, altering the cultural landscape with a speed and intensity that has rarely — if ever — been seen before.

headline: Giants Raise Banner and Remind Cardinals How They Won It
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The last time the Giants raised a championship banner, after their 2010 World Series victory, it came on a wave of civic incredulity that such a thing could happen after a 56-year dry spell.

headline: Singing Sacred Songs in Secular Spots
text: On a recent Sunday afternoon, 17 people with sheet music gathered in a semicircle in the Graybar Passage at Grand Central Terminal. People streamed by. After a brief warm-up, the group’s conductor, John Hetland, dressed in dark jeans and a green plaid shirt, lifted his hands and the chorus began its a cappella rendition of a polyphonic hymn, “Kyrie,” by the 15th-century German composer Heinrich Finck.

headline: Burnside’s Police State
text: Near dawn on March 24, 1863, Maj. Gen. Ambrose E. Burnside stepped off a train in Cincinnati. The tall, bald, magnificently bewhiskered soldier arrived from Washington to take command of the Army’s Department of the Ohio, an enormous command that encompassed Ohio, Indiana, Michigan, Illinois and most of Kentucky. His orders from the War Department were to collect troops and prepare to lead an invasion of eastern Tennessee. In the meantime, though, he also had to deal with the roiling antiwar politics of the Ohio Valley.

headline: A Final Round of Applause
text: Elaine Stritch, now 88, is packing it in, but not quietly, of course.

headline: Robert Remini, Exhaustive Andrew Jackson Biographer, Dies at 91
text: Robert V. Remini, an admired historian best known for his study of Andrew Jackson, including an exhaustive three-volume biography that traced how the seventh president harnessed his populist appeal to wield unusual executive power, died on March 28 in Evanston, Ill. He was 91.

headline: Newcomer to Penguins Beats Lundqvist and Rangers in Shootout
text: PITTSBURGH — The game had a playoff feel to it, fast and desperate, hard-hitting and angry, with accusations flying afterward like pucks and errant elbows. The Penguins won, 2-1, in a shootout, but the Rangers were encouraged by a tenacious performance that earned them a precious point in the standings.

headline: Exiting, Stage Center
text: Elaine Stritch is leaving New York.

headline: Knicks Win 11th Straight as Anthony Hits 40 Again
text: Amid the dreamscape that has been the Knicks’ recent surge, various obstacles have threatened to derail them, though none with much success.

headline: Editor Who Wrote of Racism in Cuba Loses His Post, Colleagues Say
text: MEXICO CITY — The editor of a publishing house in Cuba who wrote a critical article in The New York Times opinion section about persistent racial inequality on the island, something revolutionaries proudly say has lessened, has been removed from his post, associates said on Friday.

headline: Arrests by the Fashion Police
text: Here is a vignette from March 2013: A 24-year-old gay man named Yhatzine Lafontain is leaving a restaurant late at night with a friend on Roosevelt Avenue and 95th Street in Queens. Both are dressed as women, Mr. Lafontain in a jacket, short dress and heels. Exchanging goodbyes outside, they are approached by a man who tells them they look good.

headline: Newly Rebuilding Marlins Beat Long-Rebuilding Mets
text: A year ago, when the Mets and the Marlins first faced each other at Citi Field, the question entering the series was how fans would receive shortstop Jose Reyes, who had left New York to sign a big free-agent contract with Miami in the off-season. Would they cheer? Would they boo?

headline: Williams Sisters Win Four Times in One Day
text: DANIEL ISLAND, S.C. — Unusual things can bloom after a heavy rainfall. Witness Friday’s unorthodox but highly entertaining schedule at the Family Circle Cup, which featured a quadruple-header for the Williams sisters.

headline: Programs Change, but Pitino’s Methods Do Not
text: ATLANTA — The laboratory back then was Case Gymnasium, a cozy cedar closet of an arena that must have felt like a casino floor to the men’s basketball team at Boston University. The windows were taped over for practice, and the clocks were, too. Rick Pitino was a first-time head coach who possessed the energy of an uncoiled spring, and to change what he considered a culture of losing at B.U., he needed his players to run and run and run — two, three, sometimes even four times a day.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) DARK SHADOWS (2012) Johnny Depp, above, summons the spirit of the romantic vampire hero Barnabas Collins in Tim Burton’s revisiting of a 1960s daytime soap opera. Eva Green plays the maid Angelique, who paws at Barnabas’s body. Bella Heathcote is Josette, who runs off with his heart. Three’s a crowd, and the witchy Angelique casts a spell that leaves Josette dead and Barnabas bereft — and leads to a timeout in a deep grave, where, after 200 years of entombment, he awakes in 1972, like a thirstier Rip Van Winkle. “Barnabas’s liberation does the same for Mr. Depp’s performance, and it’s delightful to watch how the actor handles the vampire’s readjustment to the world of the living, which, after he has thrown back some invigorating human Slurpees and faced down a ‘demon’ (a car), he does with both lofty entitlement and abject bewilderment,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “ ‘Dark Shadows’ isn’t among Mr. Burton’s most richly realized works, but it’s very enjoyable, visually sumptuous and, despite its lugubrious source material and a sporadic tremor of violence, surprisingly effervescent,” she added. “And while there may not be any deeper resonance lurking in his ‘Dark Shadows’ — the show first surfaced in the middle of the Vietnam War, when real horror was playing out daily in the news — Mr. Burton’s gift for deviant beauty and laughter has its own liberating power.”

headline: Michigan Assistant a Showman, Too
text: ATLANTA — Somehow, they all work, the varied elements of Bacari Alexander’s story. Somehow, it all ties together, from the streets of Detroit to the Harlem Globetrotters to the Michigan Wolverines, from nutcrackers to construction hard hats to sledgehammers, from custom suits to Magic Circles to basketballs that spin forever on his index fingers.

headline: Online Betting Site Intrade Faces Liquidation
text: The online betting Web site Intrade, which gained widespread notice for serving as a predictions platform for elections and events not related to sports, is facing liquidation because of a $700,000 cash shortfall, a development that comes a month after it halted trading and froze its customer accounts.

headline: ’73 Knicks, Including Jackson, Get a Garden Welcome
text: Phil Jackson does not spend much time wading in old memories or romanticizing his past. He is not the sentimental type. But when the 1973 Knicks call, Jackson answers.

headline: Final Four at a Glance
text: A look at the Final Four teams in the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Uncovering Lost Footage
text: MSG Network hired Maurice Schechter to restore damaged tapes and prepare them to be televised as part of its 40th anniversary commemoration of the Knicks’ second title.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 6
text: NEWS North Korea’s torrent of threats — and the matching show of military power and political resolve from the United States and South Korea — began showing signs of unsettling foreign investors’ confidence Friday. South Korean stocks slumped 1.64 percent Friday in a selling spree among foreign investors that analysts attributed to jitters over North Korea. The South Korean won also sank against the U.S. dollar.  Choe Sang-hun reports from Seoul.

headline: The Early Word: Calamity
text: Today’s Times

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Haryana: President Pranab Mukherjee rejected the mercy petition of Dharampal, who was convicted of raping a woman in Sonepat, Haryana, in 1991 and murdering five members of the victim’s family, The Indian Express reported. He will be hanged next week, the report said.

headline: Of Karaoke Kings and Pinball Wizards. What’s Your Pleasure?
text: As I worked on “This Is Who Rules the Bars of New York,” my roundup in this weekend’s Food & Drink Issue of people who excel in activities like trivia and Ping-Pong at bars, I thought a lot about what exactly constitutes a bar pastime. Darts and pinball seem obvious. Bocce and drawing, less so.

headline: Sunni Leader Is Named Prime Minister in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Tammam Salam, scion of a prominent political family, was officially named the new prime minister of Lebanon on Saturday after receiving a string of endorsements from the country’s warring factions over the past few days.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Nuclear Talks With Iran End Without Accord or Plans for Another Round
text: ALMATY, Kazakhstan — Negotiations over Iran’s disputed nuclear program broke off Saturday with scant signs of progress, much less an agreement on tighter controls demanded by six world powers in exchange for some easing of sanctions that have a stranglehold on the Iranian economy.

headline: We Get Results, Japan Edition
text: Let it not be said that the scribblings of academic economists have no effect. Some of us have been urging the Bank of Japan to get truly aggressive and adventurous on monetary policy — and it’s happening!

headline: Europe Doesn’t Trust Its Politicians. What’s the Alternative?
text: LONDON — Is Europe’s long-running economic drama in danger of turning into a political crisis?

headline: Five Killed in Year’s Deadliest Attack on Americans in Afghanistan
Self- Improvement in a Bull Market
text: THE stock market is up, and your home — if you own one — is probably worth more than it was at the real estate market’s nadir. So the odds are that you are feeling a bit better about your financial self these days.

headline: Mandela Released From Hospital
text: JOHANNESBURG — Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s first black president, was discharged from a hospital on Saturday after a nine-day stay to receive treatment for pneumonia, the South African government said.

headline: In Exchange-Traded Funds, a Variable Worth Watching
text: EXCHANGE-TRADED funds that track indexes may sound like straightforward investments. Because they tend to have low fees and can be used to build diversified portfolios, as well as for esoteric strategies, E.T.F.’s are wildly popular among individual and institutional investors alike. But even when E.T.F.’s appear simple, there may be more risk than meets the eye.

headline: Why Solar Power Stocks Are Still Earthbound
text: LONG-SUFFERING investors in solar energy stocks had reason to enjoy the first six weeks of 2013. After several years of poor performance while the overall market advanced, solar and other “green” energy technologies were market leaders early this year.

headline: Money Funds, Waiting for the Fog to Lift
text: THIS is the kind of market that makes cautious investors long for the comfort of cash.

headline: A Low-Growth World Can Also Mean High Profits
text: ECONOMIC growth has been subdued for so long that conditions that used to seem like busts are starting to look like booms.

headline: The Kitchen-Table Sequester
text: KNOW who’s really great? Our elected representatives in Washington, that’s who.

headline: Vows: Headhunter / Matchmaker
text: For work, Andy Hunter matches executives with jobs; for fun he matches hearts. He and his wife, Sarah Hunter, have played matchmaker for five married couples, including a niece, Sally King McBride.

headline: Variety: An Ideal Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I loved this acrostic, and not just because Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon are two of my favorite constructors. It just has so many things going for it.

headline: Latecomers, Flocking to the Party
text: AFTER long spurning the bull market for fear of being burned again, investors have finally given in this year. They have abandoned their aversion to stock funds, pouring more money into them in January than in any other month ever.

headline: 2 Weeks Before Iraqi Local Elections, Deadly Bombs Hit Campaign Event
text: BAGHDAD — Two explosions, the first from a suicide bomber and the second from a homemade bomb, ripped through a tent at a political rally on Saturday in Baquba, north of the capital, where voters and candidates had gathered for lunch.

headline: Woods, Putting Well and Seemingly at Peace, Is Masters Favorite Again
text: Like the towering oak outside Augusta National’s clubhouse, Tiger Woods will cast a considerable shadow over this year’s Masters. With his trunk once again in perfect alignment over putts, Woods, a four-time champion, arrives at the men’s first major of the year as the world’s No. 1 golfer and the prohibitive favorite.

headline: Imagining the Majors With No Nicklaus or Woods
text: Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods — you can’t have one without the other. As the Masters approaches, they embody a golf question for the ages. You can’t discuss Jack’s record 18 major titles without wondering if Tiger, who has 14, will surpass him.

headline: A Gun Guy’s Argument
text: The Op-Ed columnist Joe Nocera talks to Dan Baum, a gun owner and a self-described liberal, about the role “gun guys” can play in solving the problem of violence in America.

headline: Thinking Small, and Winning Big, at Three Funds
text: BACK in the 1970s, the British economist E. F. Schumacher declared that “Small Is Beautiful,” in a short book that was part environmental manifesto and part broadside against corporate bigness.

headline: Health Policy Is in Flux, and So Are 2 Health Funds
text: THE Affordable Care Act, a k a Obamacare, isn’t the only upheaval in the health care sector lately. Health care mutual funds have experienced tumult, too.

headline: In Shift, Police Advise Taking an Active Role to Counter Mass Attacks
text: The speed and deadliness of recent high-profile shootings have prompted police departments to recommend fleeing, hiding or fighting in the event of a mass attack, instead of remaining passive and waiting for help.

headline: Recruiting a Recruiter for Your Next Job
text: Q. Some of your friends and colleagues have used a recruiter to find jobs, and you are thinking of doing the same. How do you find good recruiters in your industry?

headline: Cover to Cover, and Beyond
text: ALTHOUGH most of the mail that comes to the public editor’s office can be described as frustrated complaints (Misleading headline! Wrongheaded columnist! Enough about Brooklyn already!), there is a second category of correspondence. Let’s call it “perfectly reasonable questions.”

headline: Turning Around a Life Adrift
text: JONESBORO, Ark.

headline: Florida Algae Bloom Leads to Record Manatee Deaths
text: Florida’s endangered manatees, already reeling from an unexplained string of deaths in the state’s east coast rivers, have died in record numbers from a toxic red algae bloom that appears each year off the state’s west coast, state officials and wildlife experts say.

headline: Ebbets, His Team and His Ballpark
text: Charles H. Ebbets grew up on Spring Street in Manhattan, but he became inextricably linked with Brooklyn by the time he was a young man.

headline: What Gun Lovers Think
text: IN most respects, Dan Baum is a political liberal. But he has always had a thing for guns and has just written a book, “Gun Guys: A Road Trip,” which is part gun country travelogue and part meditation on what it means to be a gun lover at this particular moment. Baum, who lives in Colorado, agreed to come to New York, where he grew up, to debate the issue with me.

headline: Big Thoughts, Early On
text: I WAS born in Hong Kong and immigrated to the United States with my family when I was 4. I spent most of my childhood in Chicago. My elementary school had no program in English as a second language, so I was placed in a class for students with speech impediments. It worked out well because we had to pronounce sounds over and over, and I’m told that I don’t have an accent today.

headline: Shifting Our Retirement Savings Into Automatic
text: MANY problems are so complex that even if we had the money to fix them, we wouldn’t know how to do it. Fixing inner-city schools, reducing obesity, creating peace in the Middle East are just a few examples.

headline: How Texas Became Texas and Why It Matters
text: AS a Texas-raised journalist, I can tell you two things with confidence about my native state. One, its economy has been humming nicely for years. Two, this appears to greatly offend a certain breed of Northern writer, several of whom have descended on the state in an attempt to rebut stories of a “Texas miracle.” Their reports, Erica Grieder writes, have contributed to “a widespread impression that Texas is corrupt, callous, racist, theocratic, stupid, belligerent, and most of all, dangerous.”

headline: Europe’s Markets, No Longer in Lock Step
text: ALTHOUGH the overall European economy is stuck in neutral at best, the region’s stock market may have turned a corner in the first quarter.

headline: The Infinity Pool of Executive Pay
text: RELAX. Sit back. And forget, for a moment, those pesky shareholders and bothersome boards, the regulations, the investigations and all the other headaches of being a chief executive today.

headline: If Shareholders Say ‘Enough Already,’ the Board May Listen
text: RAISES may be hard-won for most American workers these days, but for those fortunate few in the executive suite, the pay increases just keep on coming. Last year, the median chief executive at a United States company with more than $5 billion in revenue received about $14 million, 2.8 percent more than in 2011, according to an annual pay analysis conducted by Equilar. The 2012 increase, though relatively modest, still represents a raise for most of those who inhabit the corner office (and whose companies had filed the data by the end of March).

headline: Far From Reservation, Sisters Lead Louisville
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Louisville had just advanced to the women’s Final Four, and the sisters Shoni and Jude Schimmel had helped cut the nets in celebration, a rare achievement for American Indian athletes. But it was not the biggest family news of the day.

headline: At Intersection of Fading Eras in Women’s Game
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: First, Make Sure Your Idea Works on a Small Stage
text: This interview with  Francesca Zambello, general and artistic director of the Glimmerglass Festival and artistic director of the Washington National Opera, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Don’t Know Much About Gun Laws
text: IN polls, a slight majority of Americans consistently say that we need better enforcement of our gun laws. But there’s a problem with that: many don’t really know what our gun laws are.

headline: Bayern Munich Clinches Bundesliga Title
text: Bayern Munich made history in Germany on Saturday when Bastian Schweinsteiger’s backheel flick off a crossing pass from Philipp Lahm gave the club from Bavaria its 23rd title with six games left in the season.

headline: Day of the Hunter
text: PEOPLE who rhapsodize about the glory of hunting never mention what an unfair fight it is.

headline: Drivers Are Still Distracted, Study Finds
text: At any moment during daylight hours, according to a new government study, 660,000 Americans are using cellphones or other electronic devices while driving.

headline: Finally, Maybe, at Last
text: Look to Washington in the next week or so for the first legislative rumblings of the great battle over comprehensive immigration reform, 2013. The effort will end either in collapse and failure, followed by years of political recriminations, or, amazingly, a big fat bill.

headline: Ready to Cut the Cord?
text: How easy is it to live without cable TV? I have been finding out for the last several months while staying with a friend who, like several people I know, does not subscribe to cable or satellite TV. So far, thanks to Netflix and Amazon Prime’s streaming of movies and TV shows, I haven’t missed cable TV much, except maybe the HBO show “Girls.” And when the sixth season of “Mad Men” kicks off on Sunday, I’ll keep up with the dark lives of Don Draper and company by buying the whole season on iTunes for $22.99, and watching the episodes as they become available for download each week. Come May, when I move into my own place, I’ll have to make a decision: Should I join the ranks of the so-called cord cutters, who rely solely on Netflix, iTunes and the rest of the Internet for TV (or use high-definition TV antennas to get broadcast stations)?

headline: The Secrets of Princeton
text: SUSAN PATTON, the Princeton alumna who became famous for her letter urging Ivy League women to use their college years to find a mate, has been denounced as a traitor to feminism, to coeducation, to the university ideal. But really she’s something much more interesting: a traitor to her class.

headline: A Year in Trees
text: SOMEONE asked me the other day how I had gotten over the sudden death of someone I loved. What I wanted to say but found myself unable to explain (for it would have sounded too strange) was that I learned a good deal about moving through grief from some trees I once knew. They were not my trees. I didn’t plant them. I lived in an apartment surrounded by them. The only tending done was to give them my full attention over the course of four seasons.

headline: Calamity for Our Most Beneficent Insect
text: Every beekeeper, small or large, hobbyist or commercial, knows that honeybees are in trouble. Over the past decade, bee colonies have been dying in increasing numbers. Last year was especially bad. Perhaps as many as half the hives kept by commercial beekeepers died in 2012. The loss has created a crisis among fruit and vegetable growers, who depend on bees to pollinate their crops.

headline: Pity the Men on Top
text: WHEN I dream about my father, as I do even though he has been dead for more than a quarter of a century, I always wake up when I hear the crunch of tires rolling over rock salt — an unmistakable sound evoking the winters of my Michigan childhood in the 1950s and early ’60s. Dad, an accountant, would pull his car out of our icy driveway and head for his office long before first light. This was tax season, and he could keep his business and our family financially afloat only by working 80-hour weeks.

headline: How We’ve Wasted Our Timeout
text: YES, it’s true — a crisis is a terrible thing to waste. But a “timeout” is also a terrible thing to waste, and as I look at the world today I wonder if that’s exactly what we’ve just done. We’ve wasted a five-year timeout from geopolitics, and if we don’t wake up and get our act together as a country — and if the Chinese, Russians and Europeans don’t do the same — we’re all really going to regret it.

headline: Suburban Disequilibrium
text: A little pocket of Los Angeles County tucked into the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains reflects a crucial facet of suburban life. There’s tiny, wealthy Bradbury, a town that prides itself on having one of the richest ZIP codes in Los Angeles, where a house is on the market for $68.8 million. A couple of miles to the east is Azusa. This modest suburb is more than two-thirds Latino, a town of working families whose incomes and home values are a sliver of the wealth nearby.

headline: Wearing a Badge, and a Video Camera
text: HERE’S a fraught encounter: one police officer, one civilian and anger felt by one or both. Afterward, it may be hard to sort out who did what to whom.

headline: J. B. Straubel
text: J. B. Straubel is a founder and the chief technical officer of Tesla Motors in Palo Alto, Calif. The company makes electric vehicles that some compare to Apple products in terms of obsessive attention to design, intuitive user interface and expense.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Tackling Global Warming
text: Readers urge carbon taxes, lifestyle changes and a new term.

headline: The Atlanta Teacher Aptitude Test (ATAT)
text: Please use a sharp No. 2 pencil and gloves to fill in each circle completely or maybe a little less.

headline: Wars on Drugs
text: LAST year, more active-duty soldiers committed suicide than died in battle. This fact has been reported so often that it has almost lost its jolting force. Almost.

headline: Trading in the Dark
text: Stocks dropped on Friday, after the dismal employment report for March forced investors to rethink the recent rally. Stock prices have been driven up by easy money from the Federal Reserve, but the jobs picture indicates that little of the Fed’s largess has made its way to Main Street, where unemployment remains high.

headline: The Arab Spring Started in Iraq
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: Getting Serious About a Texas-Size Drought
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: Courts Without Judges
text: The number of vacancies on the nation’s federal courts has reached an astonishingly high level, creating a serious shortage of judges and undermining the ability of the nation’s court system to bestow justice.

headline: Can We Get Hillary Without the Foolery?
text: PLEASE don’t ask me this anymore.

headline: Out of the Spotlight, a Lucrative Payday
text: OUR annual list of highly compensated executives includes some astonishing salaries. But they are not necessarily the richest compensation packages out there.

headline: African North Americans and the War
text: Thomas Peter Riggs was not like most soldiers. A private in the 54th Massachusetts regiment, his race would have stood out first to contemporary observers: Riggs was black, and his unit was the first to be organized in the North, after President Lincoln and the Union Army acquiesced to expanding the power of the Emancipation Proclamation with African-Americans fighting as soldiers.

headline: How Memoirists Mold the Truth
text: In the wake of horrible family rows, short of leaving my father, my mother would do something that shook the foundations of my childhood. She would step into our living room and, spurred by rage, spite and last-ditch efforts to restore order in her life, she would single-handedly move all the furniture around. The sofa was relegated to the place held by an imposing bookcase.
