The bookcase would be shunted over to a corner that belonged to an unassuming cabinet, now demoted to another corner where it sat in the dark under the terrified gaze of two leather armchairs squatting in the maelstrom.

headline: Green Clay, in Use at Only One Tour Stop, Shows Promise
text: DANIEL ISLAND, S.C. — The dimensions of the tennis courts are standard, but the surface is unique at the Family Circle Cup in this island community outside Charleston.

headline: A Secret Deal on Drones, Sealed in Blood
text: Nek Muhammad knew he was being followed.

headline: Blue Jays Have Task of Keeping Fans Who Returned
text: TORONTO — Among the Blue Jays fans expressing caution about the extraordinary buildup of hope and hype for the 2013 season, there was Joe Carter, the smiling symbol of the franchise’s glory days, doling out restraint.

headline: High Speeds, Injuries and Competition Lead to Renewed Safety Focus
text: MARTINSVILLE, Va. — Denny Hamlin stood atop his hauler at Martinsville Speedway on Friday and watched as Mark Martin wheeled the No. 11 Toyota around the track during Sprint Cup practice. That was Hamlin’s racecar, the number he drove for 264 consecutive Cup races since late 2005. His streak will not reach 265.

headline: An Autograph Collector With Special Access
text: Don Schulze is the pitching coach for the Midland RockHounds, a minor league affiliate of the Oakland Athletics, two rungs below the majors. In 1985, after Schulze had gone 3-6 for the Cleveland Indians, Topps rewarded him with card No. 93 in its annual baseball card set.

headline: On an Aching Roster, a Knick Prefers to Forgo Ice
text: After a recent game in Utah, at the end of the Knicks’ Western trip, Kurt Thomas had his right foot in a large bucket of ice. Across the room, Jason Kidd held a bag of ice against his left wrist. J. R. Smith iced his shins and ankles, Iman Shumpert both knees.

headline: Brazil Opens Inquiry Into Claims of Wrongdoing by Ex-President
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s Public Ministry, a body of independent public prosecutors, has begun an investigation into a claim connecting former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva to a vast vote-buying scheme that involved the channeling of funds to the governing Workers’ Party.

headline: A Final Four Star, and a Mere Footnote
text: With Michigan back in the men’s Final Four for the first time in 20 years, the video of Chris Webber’s attempted timeout at the end of the 1993 national championship game between Michigan and North Carolina will surely be shown again and again.

headline: College Games on Television? That Might Work
text: CHICAGO — Eddie Einhorn is not going to the men’s Final Four this year. There will be no buzzer-beaters for him, no monster dunks, no shining moments.

headline: Before Playoffs, a Few Defeats May Actually Help
text: It may sound ridiculous to declare six better than four or five, but when it comes to playoff seedings in the Eastern Conference, you could certainly make the argument that it would be better to be worse.

headline: Damaged Nuclear Plant in Japan Leaks Toxic Water
text: TOKYO — Tens of thousands of gallons of radioactive water leaked from a large underground storage pool at Japan’s crippled nuclear plant, and thousands more gallons could seep out before the faulty pool can be emptied, the plant’s operator said Saturday.

headline: A Thinking Man’s Player Never Stops Thinking
text: Jerry Lucas found it easier than most to let go. He had a couple of years remaining on his contract with the Knicks when he retired in 1974, but he wanted to do something more important with his life. He had a plan. Lucas always had a plan.

headline: A Bloated Contract Keeps a Player Stuck in Place
text: When is a contract too rich for a player’s own good? It is an odd question, but one that comes up repeatedly in the strange case of Vancouver goalie Roberto Luongo.

headline: F.B.I. Investigating Former Rutgers Assistant
text: The F.B.I. is investigating whether the assistant at Rutgers who first voiced concerns about the abusive behavior of his boss, Mike Rice, tried to extort the university.

headline: No TV? No Subscription? No Problem
text: LAST Sunday afternoon, some friends and I were hanging out in a local bar, talking about what we’d be doing that evening. It turned out that we all had the same plan: to watch the season premiere of “Game of Thrones.” But only one person in our group had a cable television subscription to HBO, where it is shown. The rest of us had a crafty workaround.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 7
text: Dan Pfeiffer, senior adviser to President Obama, joins ABC’s “This Week” and “Fox News Sunday” to discuss topics including tension with North Korea, the president’s budget proposal and negotiations on immigration and gun control.

headline: Household Debt, vs. the Government’s
text: Household Debt, vs . the Government’s

headline: A Footnote in a Trade, Buck Now Matters to Mets
text: John Buck began the year as an afterthought, the footnote to the package of players who arrived this winter from the Toronto Blue Jays for R. A. Dickey, the Mets’ former ace. Rather, it was the pair of young prospects in the deal — catcher Travis d’Arnaud and the right-handed pitcher Noah Syndergaard — who garnered all the attention.

headline: A Delicate Dance for Los Angeles Mayoral Candidates
text: Organized labor has loomed large in a race where the two candidates have little separating them ideologically.

headline: Union Views Loom Large as Los Angeles Picks a Mayor
text: LOS ANGELES — They are both Democrats with years of experience at City Hall, who have both chided and courted labor unions over the years. Now, in a race with little separating them ideologically, the two candidates for mayor face the challenge of simultaneously fighting over this powerful force in Los Angeles politics while trying to convince weary voters that they will be independent enough to force unions to accept cutbacks needed to solve the city’s looming budget problems.

headline: J. David Kuo, Who Split From Bush Faith Effort, Dies at 44
text: WASHINGTON — J. David Kuo, an evangelical Christian who was a leader in President George W. Bush’s faith initiative but who later became a critic of it, died on Friday. He was 44.

headline: Fitting Rearrangements
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Some puzzles are fun right out of the box, and others you have to work a bit before you uncover all of the nuggets of cleverness. This one by Matt Ginsberg was a bit of both.

headline: On Matters of Transportation, Some Dare to Bring Up Taxes, Tolls and Debt
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: The First D.H. Reflects on How the Position Changed the Game
text: On April 6, 1973, at Fenway Park, Ron Blomberg became the first player in major league history to start in a game then take a position on the bench instead of on the field. Blomberg, a .293 hitter during a career spent mostly with the Yankees, was the first designated hitter. Blomberg was drafted first over all in 1967, by the Yankees, after being a standout in baseball, basketball and track in high school in Georgia.

headline: An Exoneration After Decades, and a Conviction
text: If not for the 25 years that Michael Morton spent battling to prove his innocence from behind bars, the police might never have captured the man who authorities believe killed Mr. Morton’s wife and another Austin woman, said Lisa Tanner, the prosecutor, days after securing Mark Alan Norwood’s capital conviction.

headline: Destroying Syria’s Past
text: In 2013, C.J. Chivers examined how Syria’s archaeological heritage was imperiled by war, facing threats that range from collateral damage from ordnance to pilfering for the black market.

headline: Grave Robbers and War Steal Syria’s History
text: TELL MARDIKH, Syria — Ali Shibleh crawled through a two-foot-high tunnel until reaching a slightly larger subterranean space. He swung his flashlight’s beam into the dark.

headline: Tensions Over North Korea Rattle the South’s Economy and Its Foreign Investors
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Threats by North Korea and displays of military resolve by South Korea and the United States have begun to unsettle foreign investors’ confidence in the South, creating a secondary layer of worries for Seoul and Washington.

headline: Rumors About Uzbekistan Leader’s Health Set Off Succession Debate
text: MOSCOW — The president of Uzbekistan, a white-haired man in a suit, rose from his seat at an annual spring festival and swung his hips, clapped his hands and danced a vigorous little jig.

headline: Myanmar Grapples With Ethnic Tensions
text: Analysts are divided on what deteriorating relations between the Kachin people and the country’s government mean for overall moves toward democracy and economic liberalization.

headline: Saudis to Delay a Measure Deporting Foreign Workers
text: CAIRO — Almost two weeks after Saudi Arabia started deporting thousands of foreign workers from Yemen and other countries in a crackdown that drew protests from local business owners and foreign diplomats, Saudi officials on Saturday reversed course and announced a three-month grace period for the workers, according to the official Saudi news agency.

headline: Ahead of the Market
text: How three of the top performers of the first quarter of 2013 fared against the market — and against their peer groups of funds.

headline: Scientists See Cruelty in Killing Method Used in Japan’s Dolphin Roundup
text: April 7, 10:19 p.m. | Updated below |In a new peer-reviewed study, scientists assess the killing method employed by the dolphin hunters of Taiji, Japan, by watching video recorded surreptitiously in 2011 by a German dolphin-protection group, AtlanticBlue. The still image at right is from the video, which can be seen here (but be forewarned; this is not suitable for children — or many adults, for that matter).

headline: Ralph Sanchez, Founder of Major Speedway, Dies at 64
text: Ralph Sanchez, a Cuban-born businessman who brought auto racing to the streets of Miami in the 1980s and later built a major speedway in a city devastated by Hurricane Andrew, died on Monday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 64.

headline: Lawrence Fuchs, Expert on Immigration, Dies at 86
text: Lawrence H. Fuchs, a scholar of American ethnicity who as a federal government adviser helped lay the groundwork for the last major overhaul of American immigration law, in 1986, died on March 17 at his home in Canton, Mass. He was 86.

headline: In History Departments, It’s Up With Capitalism
text: A specter is haunting university history departments: the specter of capitalism.

headline: Edith Schaeffer, Definer of Christian Family Values, Dies at 98
text: Edith Schaeffer, founder with her husband, Francis Schaeffer, of a Swiss commune considered the theological birthplace of the American religious right, and author of many popular books that helped define conservative Christian family values for a worldwide evangelical audience, mainly female, died on March 30 in Gryon, Switzerland. She was 98.

headline: The View From the Top Row
text: ATLANTA — With 74,000 seats available in the Georgia Dome, somebody had to watch from far enough away where binoculars and extra Kleenex to deal with nosebleeds would come in handy.

headline: Robert Ward, Composed Prizewinning ‘Crucible’ Opera, Dies at 95
text: Robert Ward, an American composer whose best-known work, an operatic setting of Arthur Miller’s drama “The Crucible,” won the 1962 Pulitzer Prize for music, died on Wednesday at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 95.

headline: No. 1 Player Gets a Chance to Pick Off the World Champ
text: The Candidates Tournament to select a challenger for the world champion Viswanathan Anand ended on Monday with one of the most exciting finishes in chess history. Magnus Carlsen tied for first with Vladimir Kramnik, but by virtue of having won more games than Kramnik, Carlsen was declared the winner. And both players lost in the final round.

headline: Yanks Off to Worst Start in 7 Years as Pitching Falters Again
text: DETROIT — Less than a week into the season, all the dire predictions about how bad the Yankees would be, especially in the first month, are looking quite accurate, but for the wrong reasons.

headline: Matthew Warren, Son of Influential Minister, Dies at 27
text: The 27-year-old son of the Rev. Rick Warren, one of America’s most influential religious leaders, committed suicide, Mr. Warren said in an e-mail released on Saturday to staff members and congregants at his 20,000-member Saddleback Valley Community Church.

headline: Tax Lobby Builds Ties to Chairman of Finance Panel
text: WASHINGTON — Restaurant chains like McDonald’s want to keep their lucrative tax credit for hiring veterans. Altria, the tobacco giant, wants to cut the corporate tax rate. And Sapphire Energy, a small alternative energy company, is determined to protect a tax incentive it believes could turn algae into a popular motor fuel.

headline: Behind Early, Tested Late, Almost There
text: ATLANTA — In Louisville’s first 160 minutes of basketball this N.C.A.A. tournament, its faithful could count how many times they were even moderately worried about their Cardinals on one hand. With five fingers down.

headline: As Derby Favorite, Verrazano Beats Traffic in Queens
text: Verrazano came to New York, the city that boasts the bridge for which he is named, undefeated and bearing the title of early Kentucky Derby favorite.

headline: Taping of Farm Cruelty Is Becoming the Crime
text: On one covert video, farm workers illegally burn the ankles of Tennessee walking horses with chemicals. Another captures workers in Wyoming punching and kicking pigs and flinging piglets into the air. And at one of the country’s largest egg suppliers, a video shows hens caged alongside rotting bird corpses, while workers burn and snap off the beaks of young chicks.

headline: Was This Aston Villa Goal Worth $50 Million?
text: Two years ago, Deloitte’s Alan Switzer, writing in The Telegraph, pegged the first-year cost of relegation from the Premier League at £25 million (about $38 million), a figure that has almost certainly risen — doubled even? — since he calculated it.

headline: Lundqvist Stops 48 Shots and Saves 2 Precious Points for Rangers
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — If the Rangers needed a breather after back-to-back games against Eastern Conference-leading Pittsburgh and before two critical meetings with Toronto this week, the schedule offered this kindness on Saturday night: a trip to Carolina. The fading Hurricanes had lost 10 of their last 11 games and had to play without the injured Alexander Semin, their second-leading scorer.

headline: Semifinal Between Venus and Serena Williams Ends in Rout
text: DANIEL ISLAND, S.C. — The first match between Venus and Serena Williams in nearly four years drew the largest crowd in the Family Circle Cup’s history, with 9,538 fans on hand Saturday to watch Serena defeat her older sister, 6-1, 6-2, in a semifinal that lasted just 54 minutes.

headline: Rutgers Officials Long Knew of Coach’s Actions
text: They first saw the video Nov. 26, the Monday after Thanksgiving, inside an office in Piscataway, N.J., but it was hardly the first time that senior Rutgers officials had heard of the troubling behavior of Mike Rice, the men’s basketball coach.

headline: Kerry Moves to Help Turkey and Israel to Restore Ties
text: ISTANBUL — Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Istanbul early Sunday morning to encourage Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey to move ahead with his commitment to normalize relations with Israel.

headline: For Wares, Games Have Been Tough to Watch
text: ATLANTA — Passengers on the express bus from Throgs Neck in the Bronx to East 23rd Street in Manhattan last Monday morning might have wondered why their driver was wearing sunglasses on a cloudy day. Kevin Ware Sr., the father of Louisville’s famously injured guard, said he had no choice.

headline: A Win-Win for Pitino
text: You might say Louisville coach Rick Pitino hit the daily double Saturday. Three time zones west of Atlanta, where his team tamed Wichita State in the N.C.A.A. Final Four semifinals, Pitino’s prized 3-year-old thoroughbred Goldencents captured the Santa Anita Derby in Arcadia, Calif.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 7
text: “Everywhere I go now, I think about exits and doorways and potential places to hide and things to barricade and fight back with.”

headline: Nets Are Lackluster but Squeak by Bobcats
text: The Nets had eight games left in the regular season when the last-place Charlotte Bobcats came to town Saturday, in what was assumed would be a figurative stroll in the park as Brooklyn built toward the postseason.

headline: A Question of Taste
text: Perhaps lazy summer days simply conjure understatement, but suddenly fancy kitchens and the hyper-styled meals they produce feel overcooked.

headline: Corrections: April 7, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Ashley Chow, Timothy Wong
text: Ashley Ellen Chow, a daughter of Anita Liu Chow and Dr. Michael Hung Chow of Nashua, N.H., was married Saturday to Timothy Henry Wong, the son of Barbara Ngor Wong and Steven H. Wong of Randolph, N.J. The Rev. Paul Kim, a Southern Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at Redeemer Fellowship Church in Watertown, Mass.

headline: Abigail Taylor, Rockford Sansom
text: Abigail Marie Taylor and Rockford Allen Sansom were married Saturday at the Laurie Beechman Theater in New York. Michael W. Fortune, a magistrate judge of Knox County Juvenile Court in Knoxville, Tenn., officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Hinton, Mathew Spooner
text: Elizabeth Kai Hinton and Mathew Patrick Spooner were married Saturday at the James L. Crawford Elks Lodge in Ann Arbor, Mich. Gail A. Farley, a friend of the bride’s family who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

headline: Alice Beauheim and Andrew Borene
text: Alice Diana Beauheim and Andrew Melanchthon Borene were married Friday by Judge John R. Tunheim of the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, at the Minneapolis courthouse in which he sits.

headline: Garrett Hall, Zachary Howell
text: Garrett Glenn Hall and Zachary William Howell were married Monday in their apartment in New York. Nicholas Domitrovich, a friend of the couple who is a Universal Life minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Megan Martin, Brian Long
text: Megan Leigh Martin and Brian Patrick Long were married Saturday evening at Cicada, a restaurant in Los Angeles. The Rev. Bob Schneider, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Cara Nelson, Jason Stern
text: Cara Avery Nelson and Jason Matthew Stern were married Saturday evening at Temple Sinai of Roslyn in Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Andrew Gordon officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Sidel and Christopher O’Neill
text: Acquaintances Are Reunited by Spam

headline: Jordan Fasbender, Christos Papapetrou
text: Jordan Rachel Fasbender, a daughter of Edyse Vogel and Bob E. Fasbender of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Christos Gus Papapetrou, the son of Helen Laliotis Papapetrou and Gus C. Papapetrou of Closter, N.J. Chief Judge Loretta A. Preska of Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated at the University Club in Manhattan.

headline: Christine Frogozo, Erik Stromquist
text: Christine de Jesus Frogozo and Erik Franklin Stromquist were married Saturday evening at Urban Studio, an event space in Portland, Ore. Daniel Savage, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Michele Calabrese, Anthony DiFato Jr.
text: Michele Jean Calabrese and Anthony DiFato Jr. were married Saturday at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Centerport, N.Y. The Rev. John Gilmartin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Mallory Zalkin, Brett Weinberg
text: Mallory Robin Zalkin and Brett Harris Weinberg were married Saturday evening at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Cantor Bradley Hyman officiated.

headline: Jamira Cotton and Cameron Johnson
text: Studying Together Seals a Bond

headline: Two Child-Rearing Stories on the Way to a Major
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Behind most decorated female golfers is a devoted father. They are easy to spot during their daughters’ rounds this week at Mission Hills Country Club, skulking in the shadows like burglars casing their next target. Their children are their most precious jewels, and they will go to great lengths to give them the chance to shine.

headline: Christina Keener, Andrew Allen
text: Christina Lucretia Keener and Andrew Robert Allen were married Friday at St. Michael’s Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Elizabeth G. Maxwell, the church’s interim pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Swati Murthy and Nikhil Joshi
text: Dr. Swati Vadrevu Murthy and Dr. Nikhil Prakash Joshi were married Saturday at the Woodcliff Hotel & Spa in Rochester. Pandit Venkatachari Samudrala led the ceremony, with Pandit Narasimha Samudrala also taking part.

headline: Laura Kaufman and Adam Rothschild
text: Laura Beth Kaufman, a daughter of Judith Richter Kaufman and Steven J. Kaufman of New York, was married in Philadelphia Saturday evening to Adam Gilbert Rothschild, a son of Deborah Menaker Rothschild and Dr. David Rothschild of Williamstown, Mass. Rabbi Joshua Bolton officiated at the Horticulture Center in Fairmount Park, with the assistance of Elana T. Friedman, a rabbinical student at Reconstructionist Rabbinical College in Wyncote, Pa.

headline: Dennis Lampkowski, Douglas Wagner
text: Dennis Lampkowski and Gary Douglas Wagner were married Tuesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Shannon Kelley, Robert Shaw III
text: Shannon Marie Kelley, the daughter of Kathleen Frechette Kelley and Allan R. Kelley of Miami Shores, Fla., was married there Saturday to Robert William Shaw III, the son of Michelle Bowdring Shaw and Mr. Shaw II of McLean, Va. The Rev. Pedro M. Corces, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

headline: Christopher Schelling and Augusten Burroughs
text: Christopher Robert Schelling, a literary agent, and the writer Augusten Burroughs, who is also his client, were married Monday at Staten Island Borough Hall. Edison Stewart, the deputy city clerk for Staten Island, officiated.

headline: Michigan Forces Syracuse Out of Comfort Zone, and Tournament
text: ATLANTA — Late in the second half Saturday, Coach John Beilein worked the Michigan sideline, his jacket off, his sleeves rolled up, his tie loosened. He crouched. He leaned. He clapped and shouted. It was part coaching, part pleading, part aerobics.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: What happens if you lose your memory? If you can’t remember your friends or family? Where you live or what you do or who you are? Charles Assisi, managing editor of Forbes India, writes a gripping tale of just that after a virus invaded his immune system and he was left with only short-term memory. He maintains a notebook to keep track of his life, but as it grows bigger and more unwieldy he realizes he needs something else.

headline: Coach Cluess Staying at Iona
text: Iona Coach Tim Cluess announced late Saturday that he had “recommitted to coaching the Gaels,” taking himself out of the running for the opening at Hofstra, according to a news release.

headline: Final Four Replay
text: Louisville overcame a scare by Wichita State and Michigan held off Syracuse to advance to the championship game Monday.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Bangladeshi Protesters Call for Blasphemy Law
text: Amid heightened security in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Saturday, advocates demanded that the authorities enact a blasphemy law to punish those who insult Islam.

headline: Sino- North Korean Relations
text: North Korea’s belligerence creates headaches for China.

headline: Afghan Children Reported Among Dead in U.S. Strike
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An American military airstrike in eastern Afghanistan near the Pakistan border was reported to have killed 18 people, including at least one senior Taliban commander but also women and children, raising the thorny issue of civilian casualties for the third time in roughly a week.

headline: A Voice That Burns With a Controlled Flame
text: On the cover of her latest album, “Girl on Fire” (RCA), Alicia Keys stands dressed in black, making a geometric figure with her hands on her hips. She struck a similar pose often when she performed on Friday night at the Barclays Center, in a thoroughly choreographed show with clear, repeated messages: Express yourself, take chances, don’t be held back or held down.

headline: South Korea Expects Missile Launch by North
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean government warned on Sunday that the North might launch a missile later this week, while a top military leader postponed a scheduled trip to Washington, citing escalating tensions on the peninsula.

headline: China Hints at Limits to North Korea Actions
text: BOAO, China — In an indirect but clear reference to the North Korean crisis, China’s president,Xi Jinping, said Sunday that world peace should not be put at risk because of a single country.

headline: Kerry Asks Turkey to Act on Relations With Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Before departing for Israel on Sunday, Secretary of State John Kerry found time in Istanbul to urge Turkish leaders to make good on their commitment to normalize relations with Israel.

headline: It’s O.K. to Put Yourself First
text: After I found out I had neurological Lyme disease, I spent two painful years attempting to recover. Since there was no end in sight, I thought a lot about how I’d change things if I ever got my life back. I considered how I would spend my energy if I were ever granted any. When I finally climbed out of bed, I decided that to the greatest extent possible, I would quit doing the things I didn’t like to do and do the things I did like to do.

headline: Dutch Man Confesses to Killing British Woman in Kashmir, Police Say
text: A Dutch man, Richard De Wit, confessed to stabbing to death a British woman in a houseboat on Dal Lake in Kashmir, the police said Sunday.

headline: Not Recoiling From a Leadership Role for Louisville
text: ATLANTA

headline: Off Air for Decades, Canteen Girl Resurfaces
text: Every Friday evening over NBC radio airwaves – or short-wave overseas – homesick troops during World War II were told to “drop in at the canteen” for comforting chat and songs by a pretty, young actress named Phyllis Jeanne Creore.

headline: Disruptions: The Logic (or Lack of It) in Appraising Start-Ups
text: I have a vision of how suitors decide how much to offer for a start-up they want to buy. Several executives go into a conference room. Each scribbles a number on a piece of paper and places it in a hat. Then the chief executive pulls out a number, and there it is.

headline: Healthy Eating on Just $300 a Day
text: Gwyneth Paltrow’s second cookbook, “It’s All Good,” which was released last week, is taking heat for being an elitist farm-to-table guide sprinkled with duck eggs and $25-a-jar Manuka honey. At best it makes it seem like healthy eating is strictly for the wealthy; at worst, it’s quack science for attempting to export Paltrow’s wacky elimination diet (no bell peppers, eggplant or corn? Huh?) to a populace that’s improperly nourished and financially struggling.

headline: Culprit in Heart Disease Goes Beyond Meat’s Fat
text: It was breakfast time and the people participating in a study of red meat and its consequences had hot, sizzling sirloin steaks plopped down in front of them. The researcher himself bought a George Foreman grill for the occasion, and the nurse assisting him did the cooking.

headline: ‘Evil Dead’ Sets Pace at Busy Movie Theaters
text: North American moviegoers bellied up to a smorgasbord of choices over the weekend: R-rated demons, animated cave people, meaty action heroes and 3-D dinosaurs all delivered solid ticket sales. “Evil Dead” (Sony) was No. 1, taking in a better-than-expected $26 million; it cost about $17 million to produce.

headline: White House Pressures G.O.P. on Gun Control
text: 6:30 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON — The White House is stepping up its public efforts to shame Republicans into allowing a vote on gun control legislation in the Senate, saying that a threatened filibuster is an affront to the families of the children who died in the December school massacre in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Lilly Pulitzer Dies at 81; Heiress Who Gave Elite Clothes a Tropical Splash
text: Lilly Pulitzer, the Palm Beach princess of prints who created an enduring fashion uniform for wealthy socialites and jet setters almost by accident, died on Sunday at her home in Florida. She was 81.

headline: Les Blank, Filmmaker of America’s Periphery, Dies at 77
text: Les Blank, whose sly, sensuous and lyrical documentaries about regional music and a host of other idiosyncratic subjects, including Mardi Gras, gaptoothed women, garlic and the filmmaker Werner Herzog, were widely admired by critics and other filmmakers if not widely known by moviegoers, died on Sunday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 77.

headline: Works on Paper, Drawn From Life, in Mixed Mediums
text: At the start of Gwen Welliver’s “Beasts and Plots” the dancer Stuart Singer sits on a folding chair with each of his arms wrapped in a long spiral of brown paper. Painstakingly he raises his arms and crosses them in front of his chair, resting the tips of paper on the floor. The sound composition, by Jake Meginsky and Bill Nace, generates a crisp score of snaps and crackles as Mr. Singer, a little like a praying mantis, spreads his legs and bends his knees. He’s not exactly a beast, yet he’s not quite human either.

headline: These Guys Were Good in Their 20s
text: NEWARK — Richard Strauss was 24 when he wrote “Don Juan” (1888), his first major tone poem. His next, “Tod und Verklärung” (“Death and Transfiguration”), came right on its heels, in 1889. That was also the year Claude Debussy turned 27 and began composing his Fantaisie for Piano and Orchestra, the closest he ever came to a piano concerto.

headline: 50 Small Victories in a Time of Unbearable Loss
text: True stories of people who helped likely victims escape an onrushing genocide never grow old, partly because they all have at their core soul-searching questions that will always be current. How can we respond to similar horrors today? Would we personally have risen to the occasion the way a few did as the Nazi nightmare was enveloping Europe or murderous extremism was sweeping Rwanda?

headline: With Swagger, Afghan Army Takes the Lead
text: DAMDARA, Afghanistan — Through the crackle of the hand radio, the Taliban fighter could be heard screaming at his comrades, berating them to strike from their mountain hide-outs and kill the infidel forces gathered nearby.

headline: Maple Leafs and Red Wings Will Meet in Winter Classic After All
text: The Detroit Red Wings-Toronto Maple Leafs Winter Classic at the Big House is back on.

headline: Remnant of Grief: A Cycle Inspired by a Death From AIDS
text: In his song cycle “Green Sneakers for Baritone, String Quartet, Empty Chair and Piano,” written in 2007, the composer Ricky Ian Gordon commemorates the 1996 death of his partner, Jeffrey Grossi, from complications of AIDS. Mr. Gordon’s text for this intimate, intensely elegiac work, heard Saturday evening at the Kaplan Penthouse as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, refuses to maintain a safe distance from the kind of extremely personal emotions that many would rather hold close to themselves.

headline: Ukraine President Frees a Rival’s Allies, but Leaves Her in Prison
text: MOSCOW — In a possible sign that political tensions are easing in Ukraine, President Viktor F. Yanukovich pardoned the country’s second-most-prominent political prisoner on Sunday, but his intentions concerning his biggest rival, who is also in custody, remained unclear.

headline: Contact! Without Connection
text: Most contemporary music programs have some theme that at least loosely links the works being played. What about the concert that the conductor Alan Gilbert presented with the New York Philharmonic at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night, part of Contact!, the orchestra’s adventurous new-music series?

headline: Israel Says It Repelled Most Attacks on Its Web Sites by Pro-Palestinian Hackers
text: JERUSALEM — A loose international coalition of pro-Palestinian computer hackers threatened to carry out what it called “a massive cyberassault” against Israel on Sunday, but the campaign created mostly minor disruptions, and the Israeli government said that as of midday its Web sites were still accessible to the public.

headline: Afghan Army Begins to Take the Lead
text: Each mission is a step toward answering critical questions: Can Afghan forces effectively fight after the Americans leave? Can they gain local support?

headline: Knicks Extend Streak and, Beating Thunder, Give It Some Weight
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The precise moment when the Knicks’ self-resuscitating winning streak turned from impressive to charmed came Sunday afternoon, on the court of the N.B.A.’s most dazzling young team, in a game that was within inches of slipping from their grasp.

headline: A Platform, or Several, for Middle East Politics
text: It is difficult to determine when the escalation began.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 6, 2013

headline: Lew to Press for European Policy Changes
text: WASHINGTON — Jacob J. Lew began his first trip to Europe as Treasury secretary on Sunday, a four-city tour in which he is expected to try to persuade finance ministers to pursue a little more growth and a little less austerity to improve the economic fortunes of the Continent and the world.

headline: New Trouble for Euro in Portugal
text: Just weeks after European leaders tamped down a banking crisis in Cyprus, troubles in the euro zone have again reared their head, this time in Portugal.

headline: Daredevils Take Flight and Land Safely Near Your Lap
text: You’d have to be a little dead inside not to get a visceral thrill from sitting in front of a dancer who takes a 25-foot swan dive and lands — face first — on a mat inches from your feet.

headline: The Light at the End of Suffering
text: How much more can I take?

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams at Spring Nationals
text: ST. LOUIS — Roy Welland drew my attention to the diagramed deal, which occurred in the semifinals of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams at the Spring Nationals here last month. The original write-up was by Paolo Enrico Garrisi on the Neapolitan Club Web site.

headline: A Fig Leaf Is Dropped in Islamic Societies
text: “Men in Egypt, in the gulf, they always want to have sex in the wrong place,” one Egyptian woman whispered to the writer Shereen El Feki, while she conducted her research into sexual proclivities in a rapidly changing Arab world.

headline: Assad Forces Push Back at Rebels Across Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The embattled Syrian government mounted attacks on rebel positions across the country on Sunday, according to opposition activists.

headline: In Dense Madrigals, What You Hear Is Whatever You Can See
text: The two things that come most readily to mind about Carlo Gesualdo are that he butchered his wife and her lover, and that he wrote extraordinary music. The complex harmonies and extreme chromaticism of his madrigals, written at the turn of the 17th century, are so viscerally unsettling that people tend to grasp for familiar points of reference to make sense of them. Aldous Huxley thought he heard Schoenberg in them. The composer and critic Philip Arnold Heseltine saw in them a prefiguration of Wagner. Stravinsky saw Picasso.

headline: Frequent Partners Unite for a New York Premiere
text: “Most of what I know about myself, I have learned from playing Schumann,” the pianist Jonathan Biss has said. Mr. Biss has focused extensively on that composer this season, as curator of a series of 30 concerts collectively titled Schumann: Under the Influence.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Marlins Show Flash of Future, but the Mets Shine in the Ninth
text: Inning after inning, the Mets squirmed from danger, finding some new escape route before the Miami Marlins could dispense a definitive blow.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Concerts Carry a Hint of a Tryout
text: You had the sense that serious business was being transacted on Thursday and Friday evenings in the second and third concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s Carnegie Hall series. The first, on Wednesday, was conducted by the 79-year-old Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos, seated and looking frail. But now on the podium was Daniele Gatti, 51, seemingly vigorous and undoubtedly a prime candidate for the orchestra’s music directorship, which has been vacant since James Levine’s health-related resignation in 2011.

headline: Sabathia Outduels Verlander, and Yankees Avoid Sweep
text: DETROIT — With the Yankees sputtering in the opening week of the season and showing few signs of hope, Sunday’s game was surprisingly important for this early date.

headline: When Cold Machinery Is Not the Musical Solution
text: Back in 2010 two disappointments stood out in New York’s opera scene: Robert Lepage’s new production of Wagner’s “Rheingold,” the first installment of his “Ring” cycle at the Metropolitan Opera, and the Latvian mezzo-soprano Elina Garanca.

headline: Trouble Stalking Night-Life Paradise
text: One dance club, Pacha, has dominated the Spanish party paradise of Ibiza since the 1970s. Built on former marshland, this island disco and its all-night parties have become global symbols of hedonistic glamour, and the business has expanded to Buenos Aires, New York and beyond.

headline: Film Music, With Just a Hint of Films
text: In the movie scores of Clint Mansell, Minimalism can hold booby traps. His music is suffused with melancholy foreboding and shadowy spaces, counting down to what might be an elegy or a cataclysm.

headline: Sweetest Part of a Cake
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — The last time we saw Janet Bender, she was trying to include us in some email by CCing us (Across Lite, Solution, blog), and today she is back to check on our OPERATING SYSTEMs.

headline: A Catalog Will Detail Hirst’s Spot Paintings
text: Damien Hirst’s whimsical work evokes amusement, fascination and annoyance among art lovers, seemingly in equal measure. His spot paintings, which he began in 1986, have particularly been lightning rods. These panels of bright-hued spots are usually arranged in columns on canvases of different shapes, and his fans have paid as much as $3.4 million for them. Last year the Gagosian Gallery mounted an exhibition, “The Complete Spot Paintings 1986-2011,” at 11 galleries in eight cities. But the show’s expansive title notwithstanding, it presented only 331 works — a fraction of the spot-painting output of Mr. Hirst. The full scope of Mr. Hirst’s fascination with colored dots will become clear this spring, when his publisher, Other Criteria, issues a comprehensive catalog of the paintings: a 1,000-page illustrated book listing every work. Jason Beard, the director of Other Criteria, told The Art Newspaper that there are about 1,400 of the works. Mr. Hirst painted the first 25 himself; the others have been mainly entrusted to his assistants. Other Criteria’s catalog already offers for sale a number of items derived from the paintings, including magnets, a T-shirt, cuff links and a spot garbage bin.

headline: A Bill Cosby Biography
text: Mark Whitaker, the former editor of Newsweek and the former executive vice president and managing editor of CNN Worldwide, will write a biography of Bill Cosby, to be published by Simon & Schuster in the fall of 2014. The book, which was announced in Publisher’s Marketplace on Friday, will be Mr. Whitaker’s second for the house. His “My Long Trip Home: A Family Memoir” was published in 2011 and explored the experiences of his parents, an interracial couple, and how they shaped his life. Mr. Cosby has published several books of his own, including “Fatherhood” (1986), “Childhood” (1991) and most recently, “I Didn’t Ask to Be Born (but I’m Glad I Was)” (2011).

headline: Questions Over Cuba Trip of Beyoncé and Jay-Z
text: Beyoncé and Jay-Z spent part of last week in Havana, celebrating their fifth wedding anniversary by touring historical landmarks and speaking with what Agence France-Presse described as hundreds of Cuban well-wishers. The Havana Times reported that the couple also visited a dance troupe, Danza Contemporánea de Cuba, the singer Haila Mompié and the children’s theater group La Colmenita, and met with students and teachers at the Superior Art Institute. They may soon be explaining the trip to members of Congress, or facing a prison sentence and a fine. Treasury Department regulations prohibit Americans from traveling to Cuba “unless authorized by a general or specific license.” Now two Republican members of the House of Representatives from Florida — which has a large population of Cuban refugees and where feelings about Cuba are acute — have raised questions about the visit. The representatives, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen and Mario Diaz-Balart, have written to Adam J. Szubin, the director of the Office of Foreign Assets Control at the Treasury Department, asking about the nature of the license the couple received for their visit. “Cuba’s tourism industry is wholly state-controlled,” Ms. Ros-Lehtinen and Mr. Diaz-Balart wrote, “therefore, U.S. dollars spent on Cuban tourism directly fund the machinery of oppression that brutally represses the Cuban people.” Penalties for violating the travel ban can include a 10-year prison sentence and a $250,000 fine. Although thousands of Americans find their way to Cuba every year, usually by way of another country, few are prosecuted.

headline: Seeking to Outdo Google in Searching for Events
text: Staying around town over the weekend and your dinner plans have fallen through? Turning to the printed page might not turn up many attractive alternatives, unless you live in a big city like New York, London or Paris and have access to magazines like Time Out or Pariscope. A Google search could present the opposite problem: too many events in too many places at too many times.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include wholesale trade for February (Tuesday); weekly jobless claims and import prices for March (Thursday); and retail sales for March, the Producer Price Index for March, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for April and business inventories for February (Friday).

headline: The Potential and the Risks of Data Science
text: Columbia University held a daylong symposium on Friday as a kind of brainy coming-out party for its new Institute for Data Sciences and Engineering. The institute is a collection of interdisciplinary centers including ones for cybersecurity, financial analytics, health analytics, new media and smart cities. It points to the direction universities will have to take if the bundle of technologies called Big Data — new data and artificial intelligence tools — really are to transform industries, as its champions predict.

headline: Contest Seeks to Honor Anti-Advertising Ads
text: “Shoot the first anti-advertising ad” is the pitch for a contest sponsored by Adblock Plus, the popular software that whites out Web site advertisements. The winning 30- to 90-second video submission, Adblock Plus says, will receive a prize of class time or video equipment worth $5,000 from a film institute in the Philippines.

headline: Just Say Nao
text: Update: yes, I know about the tilda, but could not persuade the software to show it. The tilda, I’ve always said, means that there’s an “n” at the end that isn’t written but which you don’t pronounce — if you’ve ever heard Portuguese, you’ll understand what I mean.

headline: A Cosmetics Freebie With a Cause
text: FOR decades, cosmetic companies have embraced gift-with-purchase promotions, where consumers who spend a given amount are rewarded with a free assortment of travel-size products and a cosmetic bag or tote bag. So popular are gift-with-purchase enticements that some consumers are loath to buy cosmetics without the freebies, and Web sites like GWP Addict track the offers.

headline: Roger Ebert as a Builder of an Empire
text: At journalism conferences and online, media strivers talk over and over about becoming their own brand, hoping that some magical combination of tweets, video spots, appearances and, yes, even actual written articles, will help their name come to mean something.

headline: A Priest in the New Pope’s Order Seeks to Move Hearts
text: In Rome, one of Jorge Mario Bergoglio’s first acts as Pope Francis was to call his newsdealer back home in Buenos Aires and cancel his daily delivery. In New York, the Rev. Matt Malone seemed reasonably confident that a similar papal ax would not fall on America, the venerable Jesuit weekly that he edits.

headline: Chief Tries to Infuse Yahoo With a Start-Up’s Spirit
text: Since taking the reins at Yahoo, Marissa Mayer has been trying to convince customers and employees that there is still life in a company that Silicon Valley long ago left for dead.

headline: Judge Reverses Suspensions of Prosecutors in Stevens Case
text: WASHINGTON — An administrative judge has overturned the suspensions of two federal prosecutors whom the Justice Department had tried to discipline for failing to turn over evidence that might have helped the defense in the botched corruption trial against Senator Ted Stevens.

headline: In France, Foreign Aid in the Form of Priests
text: SAINT-VALLIER, France — In Togo, the Rev. Rodolphe Folly used to conduct exuberant Sunday services for a hundred believers of all ages, who sang local gospel music and went up to him to offer what they had.

headline: Slaking a Region’s Thirst While Cleaning Its Beaches
text: LOS ANGELES — Surfers here have long lived by a simple rule: When it rains, no matter how good the waves may be, stay out of the water. Those who do head out to the Venice Pier on a rainy day might have their bravery (or naïveté) repaid with pinkeye, a fever or diarrhea.

headline: A Court Test for Suits About Head Trauma
text: The N.F.L. will face off in court Tuesday against thousands of retirees in a case that will help determine the league’s role in caring for players with dementia and other neurodegenerative diseases.

headline: Sponsors Now Pay for Online Articles, Not Just Ads
text: Articles in a series on Mashable.com called “What’s Inside” looked for all the world like the hundreds of other articles on the digital media site. But journalistically, they were something very different.

headline: 14-Year-Old Embodies Augusta’s Vision for Growing Golf
text: In his 2008 Masters address, the Augusta National chairman Billy Payne introduced a program that allowed children ages 8 to 16 free admission to the tournament when accompanied by a ticketed patron. Five years later, a 14-year-old will experience the Masters from inside the ropes as one of the 94 competitors, the beneficiary of another grand plan conceived by the club in 2008 to help the sport grow: the creation of the competition that became the Asia-Pacific Amateur Championship.

headline: Eye on Ratings, ABC Peers Into the Disney Toy Chest
text: LOS ANGELES — For 17 years, ever since the Walt Disney Company swallowed its corporate parent, ABC has been a type of distant planet in the Disney universe. With nothing overtly Disney-ish about ABC, it has largely operated outside the company’s synergistic approach to show business — theme parks fueling movies fueling merchandise fueling cable channels.

headline: A Fuss, and Then a Surge, by Williams
text: DANIEL ISLAND, S.C. — In a match that featured a testy on-court exchange, Serena Williams recovered from a slow start to defeat Jelena Jankovic, 3-6, 6-0, 6-2, on Sunday for her third career title in the Family Circle Cup.

headline: At a Library in Brooklyn, Rare Books and Coffee
text: Lucas Pinheiro and Magda Mortner entered the Mellow Pages Library in Brooklyn on Saturday afternoon, greeted the others there, and began to look at some of the library’s inventory of 1,300 books, many of them from obscure presses or by little-known writers.

headline: Mariam Chamberlain, Women’s Champion, Dies at 94
text: Mariam Chamberlain, who played a pivotal yet little-known role in establishing women’s studies in the American college curriculum, and financing early research about the inequities women faced in the workplace and other realms of society, died Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 94.

headline: Is Someone Recording This? It’s Harder to Find Out
text: The undercover F.B.I. agent, posing as a businessman, was recording the conversation with a device secreted someplace close enough to capture the politician’s words, but obscure enough to remain undetected.

text: The imagery conjures up “The Wizard of Oz”: as smoke fills the screen, the head of a frowning Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, materializes.

headline: Attack on Christians in Egypt Comes After a Pledge
text: CAIRO — Police officers firing tear gas joined with a rock-throwing crowd fighting a group of Christian mourners Sunday in a battle that escalated into an attack on Egypt’s main Coptic Christian Cathedral that lasted for hours.

text: TORONTO — It has been a season of redemption for the Toronto Maple Leafs’ Nazem Kadri.

headline: The Slow Death of the American Author
text: LAST month, the Supreme Court decided to allow the importation and resale of foreign editions of American works, which are often cheaper than domestic editions. Until now, courts have forbidden such activity as a violation of copyright. Not only does this ruling open the gates to a surge in cheap imports, but since they will be sold in a secondary market, authors won’t get royalties.

headline: An Illegal Cellphone Search

headline: U.S. Designs a Korea Response Proportional to the Provocation
text: WASHINGTON — As North Korea hints at new military provocations in the coming days, the United States and South Korea have drawn up plans to respond more forcefully than in the recent past, but in a limited way intended to prevent an escalation to broader war.

headline: Ban on Free Condoms Jeopardizes Group’s Work With Catholic College
text: NEWTON, Mass. — Chelsea Lennox, a junior at Boston College, the Gothic university overlooking this natty Boston suburb, picked up a bouquet of brightly colored condom packages and put them into the envelope that she views as a tiny beacon of sexual health resources at the deeply Catholic institution.

headline: For the Anxious, Avoidance Can Have an Upside
text: Shortly after 9/11, I wrote an editorial in the American Journal of Psychiatry with Jack Gorman, a psychiatrist with whom I was collaborating.  Many people seemed to be coping with the extraordinary events of the terror attacks by staying close to home and avoiding going back out in the world.  This was not unexpected since avoidance is a well-known form of coping with traumatic events. Politicians were urging people to go back to work, to re-engage in social activities, to get on with life.  Gorman and I thought this was really good advice because of something I’d discovered in my work as a neuroscientist.

headline: The Trouble With Drones
text: The Obama administration has floated a plan to shift drone operations from the Central Intelligence Agency to the military. This is supposed to make targeted killings of suspected terrorists more transparent and accountable, but so far it looks as if it would be a marginal improvement.

headline: Betting on the Buzzer Beaters
text: The parallel universe of widespread gambling has been in full swing during the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, whose championship game is Monday night. Betting furiously on every game, fans produced a legal take in Nevada that will exceed $200 million — twice what was bet there on the last Super Bowl.

headline: Reforms for Work Visas
text: The debate about immigration reform has properly focused on giving the 11 million unauthorized immigrants in America a shot at citizenship. But broad reform should also include improvements to employment-based visas and green cards that make it possible to attract and keep highly skilled workers in technology, medical and educational fields, among others.

text: April 7, 2013

headline: Insurance and Freedom
text: President Obama will soon release a new budget, and the commentary is already flowing fast and furious. Progressives are angry (with good reason) over proposed cuts to Social Security; conservatives are denouncing the call for more revenues. But it’s all Kabuki. Since House Republicans will block anything Mr. Obama proposes, his budget is best seen not as policy but as positioning, an attempt to gain praise from “centrist” pundits.

headline: Targeted Killing Comes to Define War on Terror
text: WASHINGTON — When Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, was taken into American custody at an airport stopover in Jordan last month, he joined one of the most select groups of the Obama era: high-level terrorist suspects who have been located by the American counterterrorism juggernaut, and who have not been killed.

headline: Cardinals Win and Big East Celebrates
text: NEW ORLEANS — California, the West Coast intruder at the Final Four, did its best to break a Big East stranglehold on the national championship game. But in a battle of scrappy teams that felt like the junior varsity preliminary, Louisville rallied from a 10-point halftime deficit to win its semifinal, 64-57, on Sunday night at New Orleans Arena.

headline: About the Children
text: THE defenders of traditional marriage tell us the argument is, first and foremost, about the children. You might not know that from the buzz surrounding the Supreme Court deliberations. The children of gay and lesbian parents got a few splashes of attention, including a powerful endorsement of marriage equality from the 60,000-member American Academy of Pediatrics and one sympathetic-sounding aside from Justice Anthony Kennedy during the hearings. But for the most part, the debate has focused on the rights of grown-ups and the powers of states, not so much on the well-being of children. And when that subject does come up, the discussion is often shallow or misleading.

headline: Bubble or No, This Virtual Currency Is a Lot of Coin in Any Realm
text: WHEN he was a Yale Law School student, Reuben Grinberg wrote one of the first academic papers about Bitcoin, a novel virtual currency that uses sophisticated cryptography to validate and secure transactions that exist only online.

headline: Korean’s Rise Leads to Victory in a Major
text: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — After the 2008 United States Open, the major championships were supposed to flow like Champagne out of a bottle. But Inbee Park, like Tiger Woods, saw her major ambitions corked for nearly five years. The impediments, mostly mental, gave way Sunday when Park carded a three-under-par 69, for a 72-hole total of 15-under 273, to win the Kraft Nabisco Championship at Mission Hills Country Club.

headline: Chasing a Record but Taking a Low-Key Approach

Then, as his teammates relaxed in the locker room after having completed their warm-ups, he went to the court, where Team Korver awaited for one of the most precise, structured pregame routines in the sport.

headline: Graduate School Applications From Abroad Rise Just Barely
text: The number of international students applying to graduate schools in the United States increased just 1 percent this year, after a 9 percent rise last year and an 11 percent gain in 2011, according to a report from the Council of Graduate Schools.

headline: Gap Widens for Faculty at Colleges, Report Finds
text: For the academic elite — tenured professors at private research universities — average pay this year is $167,118, while at public research universities such professors earn $123,393, according to the annual report by the American Association of University Professors.

headline: Scientists Question Impact as Vineyards Turn Up in New Places
text: For more than a decade, wine experts have discussed the impact of climate change on wine grapes, agriculture’s diva, a marquee crop nurtured and pampered around the world.

text: Top-seeded Connecticut spoiled Notre Dame’s run and Louisville topped California to set up a Big East meeting in the championship game.

text: Magnus Carlsen’s high profile, No. 1 ranking and lucrative sponsorship deals have pushed him beyond the world of chess into the world at large.

headline: Shrewd Marketing Moves for Top-Ranked Chess Player
text: LONDON — After 22-year-old Magnus Carlsen dispatched him in 36 deadly moves over three speedy hours in their first match at the 2013 Candidates’ Tournament here, the Russian grandmaster Peter Svidler spent a moment musing on why, to be blunt about it, Carlsen receives so much more attention than he does.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 3 P.M. (ABC) KATIE! Katie Couric visits the set of TV Land’s “Hot in Cleveland” for a “Mary Tyler Moore Show” reunion with Ms. Moore, Betty White, Cloris Leachman and Georgia Engel, friends for 40 years who have banded together to support their co-star Valerie Harper (above right, with Ms. Moore, center, and Ms. White) after her recent diagnosis of terminal brain cancer. Ms. Couric interviews Valerie Bertinelli, Wendie Malick and Jane Leeves of “Hot in Cleveland.”

headline: A Conversation With: Soccer Player Bhaichung Bhutia
text: Bhaichung Bhutia is India’s most famous soccer player. He spearheaded the national team’s attack between 1995 and 2011, scoring 43 goals in 105 appearances. Mr. Bhutia was also the first Indian to play professional soccer in Europe, turning out for the English club Bury in 1999. But his most memorable performances came in Indian club soccer, especially while playing for Kolkata arch rivals East Bengal and Mohun Bagan.

headline: News Quiz | April 8, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Anticipation Over China Visit by Iceland’s Leader (and Her Wife)
text: BEIJING — Will China’s state media show Jonina Leosdottir, the wife of the prime minister of Iceland, Johanna Sigurdardottir, during an official visit to China in mid-April? If so, how will she be portrayed, with China’s apparent conversion to First Ladyism on display in the recent high profile given to the wife of President Xi Jinping, the singer Peng Liyuan?

text: THE HAGUE — New science teaching standards in the United States will include extensive lessons on human-made climate change. Expected to be unveiled this week, the guidelines will bring the subject to classrooms in up to 40 states, in many cases for the first time.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Building Support
text: Supporters stood on a building under construction in Caracas, Venezuela, during a rally for presidential candidate Henrique Capriles on Sunday. Mr. Capriles is running against the governing party candidate, Nicolás Maduro, in the presidential election.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 8
text: NEWS The C.I.A.’s covert drone war in Pakistan began with the 2004 killing of a Pashtun militant, the result of a secret deal that was a turning point in the agency’s fight against terrorism. Mark Mazzetti reports.

text: Armed only with a tambourine, Jessica Khvedelidze will soon face the largest and toughest audience of her ballet career. But if experience is any guide, her performance will seem effortless. She will be fearless.

headline: Should There Be Stricter Rules About How Coaches Treat Their Players?
text: Last Wednesday, Rutgers University fired men’s head basketball coach Mike Rice for abusive treatment of his players that was caught on video. Then on Friday, Tim Pernetti, Rutgers’ athletic director, resigned.

headline: Total Dictation, Partial Dictatorship
text: MOSCOW — Sometimes something totally geeky suddenly catches on and becomes truly popular. This is what happened with an event called Totalny Diktant (Total Dictation). Back in 2004, a group of Russian-grammar enthusiasts in the city of Novosibirsk invited other proud spellers and punctuators to join them for an afternoon of taking dictation. Each participant’s text is corrected and the number of mistakes compared with the average from all texts. For the first five years the event drew an average of 200 people each spring. Then it went big. And then it went terribly wrong.

headline: Q. and A. With the Cosmos’ Erik Stover
text: The New New York Cosmos begin play in the newish North American Soccer League in August, playing their home games at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y., on Long Island. On Monday, the club announced plans to train at Mitchel Field Athletic Complex in Uniondale, N.Y. Erik Stover, a former executive with the Red Bulls of Major League Soccer, joined the Cosmos over the winter and recently spoke with a contributor to the Goal blog.

headline: ‘Battery University’ Aims to Train a Work Force for Next-Generation Energy Storage
text: This summer, San Jose State University is offering the first classes in what it calls “battery university,” a series in its professional development program intended to train a work force for the next generation of battery makers. The curriculum is being developed by more than 100 experts from the emerging battery storage sector — mostly from the San Francisco Bay Area — and will focus not only on developing the technology, but also on ways to make it cost-effective and realistically usable in electric cars, renewable energy or smartphones and laptops.

headline: The People’s Choice for the People’s Pension
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Part 1: Answers to Your Questions on Making the Final College Decision
text: The Choice has invited Marie Bigham, a former college admissions officer and veteran college counselor, and Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert, to answer your questions about comparing financial aid offers and deciding where to enroll in the blog’s virtual Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

headline: Hong Kong Broker Fined for Hyping Undisclosed Trades
text: HONG KONG – A local stockbroker and financial columnist, Sky Cheung, was fined 500,000 Hong Kong dollars ($65,000) on Monday by Hong Kong’s market regulator for profiting on stock trades linked to his column. His broker’s license was also suspended for 30 months.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Mark Bittman on the Reality of ‘Healthful’ Fast Food
text: Mark Bittman, op-ed columnist, cookbook author and the magazine’s lead food writer, wrote this week’s cover article for the Food and Drink Issue about developments in the fast-food industry. His article about California’s Central Valley was the cover story for last year’s Food and Drink Issue.

headline: For the High Seas, a Better Floating Computer
text: Liquid Robotics, a Sunnyvale, Calif., maker of oceangoing sensor networks, on Monday releases a new model of its seagoing computer. It is larger, faster and can carry more sensors. Just as important, it incorporates lessons its engineers have learned about how to make the Internet function in the real world, and not just within the confines of pristine data centers.

headline: Korean Factory Complex Is Shut Down by the North

We all have Seacrest to thank for the rise of the Kardashian clan. Though he trades on celebrity excess, he has somehow remained virtually gossip-proof — save the time TMZ called him out for almost phoning in sick for “American Idol.” (He didn’t.) headline: With Incentive, Monkeys Can Coordinate
text: Researchers have found that monkeys can cooperate to solve a problem, demonstrating that coordination among groups does not necessarily require language. The scientists, who report their findings in the journal Current Biology, had a group of vervet monkeys play a game called the forbidden circle. A single low-ranking female was trained to open a container holding a large amount of food — but only when dominant monkeys in the group stayed outside an imaginary circle. For anyone to get any treats, they all had to coordinate their activity and show restraint.

headline: Online Habits Coming Slowly to Older Adults
text: Older adults hit a digital milestone last year: For the first time since the Pew Research Center’s Internet and American Life Project began conducting surveys, a majority (53 percent) of people over age 65 used the Internet. The proportion has since inched upward, to 54 percent.

headline: Brash Christie Plays Rutgers Circumspectly
text: It does not take much for Gov. Chris Christieof New Jersey to uncork his temper. He has called a Navy combat veteran an “idiot,” suggested reporters “take the bat” to a lawmaker in her 70s, and gone taunt-to-taunt with detractors on the boardwalk and in countless town hall meetings.

headline: Protein Linked to Development Problems
text: The French geneticist Jérôme Lejeune discovered more than 50 years ago that Down syndrome is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. But to this day it has remained a mystery why that results in impaired physical and cognitive development. Now researchers at the Sanford-Burnham Medical Research Institute think they have found a clue.

headline: Which Governors Are Most Vulnerable in 2014?
text: A lot can change before Election Day next year, when 36 states will vote for governor. But at this early stage — when decisions on whether to run or retire are considered and made — 10 of the 32 governors who are eligible to run for re-election have net negative approval ratings in their states.

headline: The ECB, OMT, and Moral Hazard
text: Back in 2011 and again in the summer of 2012, a number of economists pleaded with the European Central Bank to intervene in sovereign bond markets, buying troubled nations’ debt to stop the “doom loop” of plunging bond prices and financial distress that was pushing the euro to the brink. The objection from austerians was always that this would create moral hazard: it would let countries off the hook, and lead them to slack off on their belt-tightening.

headline: There’s No Place Like a New Home, Ads Assert
text: It almost sounds like the start of a children’s riddle: “When is a new home not a new home?” But according to a campaign being backed by a consortium of big home builders, a new home is not truly new unless it is newly built.

headline: A Pantry Staple With Nutritional Punch
text: Nuts in general have a lot going for them when it comes to nutritional benefits, and of all nuts walnuts may be the king. Enough scientific studies have shown proof of their cholesterol-lowering properties that the Food and Drug Administration accepted a petition filed by the California Walnut Commission in 2004 to allow them to list this is a health claim. Walnuts are also associated with a reduced risk of heart disease and inflammation, perhaps because of their high vitamin E and omega-3 content and the presence of antioxidant-rich phenolic acids, tannins and flavonoids in their skins.

headline: Margaret Thatcher, Prime Minister
text: Margaret Thatcher, who died of a stroke on Monday at age 87, transformed Britain more thoroughly than any other prime minister of the past half-century. She was a pathbreaker from the moment she took office in 1979 as Britain’s first, and so far only, female prime minister. And she was the rare conservative leader to come not from the upper echelons of Britain’s class-obsessed society, but from a modest apartment above her father’s grocery.

headline: More Than ‘The Iron Lady': Margaret Thatcher, Cultural Icon
text: “The lady’s not for turning,” Margaret Thatcher famously said in an early speech. But almost from the moment she moved into 10 Downing Street in 1979, Mrs. Thatcher, who died on Monday at 87, was most definitely for filming, recording, and generally excoriating by British artists and writers who saw a rich target in her stiff-necked conservative politics and stiffer coiffure.

headline: Geffen Donates $25 Million to Film Museum Project

headline: When Weather Changes, Grasshopper Turns Locust
text: As recently as 1963, plagues of ravenous desert locusts could stretch across continents, blanketing lands from West Africa to India up to 14 years at a time. Today, with pesticides and early eradication efforts, such biblical swarms no longer occur. But as farmers in Sudan, Egypt, Israel and Saudi Arabia can currently attest, locust swarms remain a serious regional threat.

headline: Cablevision’s Actions Illegal, Board Says

headline: Mache and Endive Salad With Clementines and Walnuts
text: Mache, a delicate green with a mild, subtle flavor, packs quite a nutritional punch, as it is high in omega-3s (as are walnuts) and folic acid. The salad is simple to throw together, but its flavors are complex, with sweet juicy mandarin (or tangerine or clementine sections), crunchy bitter endive and walnuts, soft and almost sweet mache, and vibrant fresh herbs. The recipe will serve 4 to 6 but I admit to eating a good half of this salad when I tested it.

But it has now earned a very different distinction as the test case of the limits of the austerity plans that have been prescribed across Southern Europe.

headline: Tiny Chiplets: A New Level of Micro Manufacturing
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Under a microscope, four slivers of silicon — electronic circuits called chiplets — perform an elaborate, jerky dance as if controlled by a hidden puppet master. Then on command, they all settle with pinpoint accuracy, precisely touching a pattern of circuit wires, each at just the right point of contact.

headline: Adelman at 1,000 Wins
text: MINNEAPOLIS — On Saturday, a night after a tepid defensive effort and missed free throws down the stretch handed him his 703rd career loss instead of his 1,000 career win, Minnesota Timberwolves Coach Rick Adelman stood beside his wife, Mary Kay, on the floor of the Target Center. The game had been eerily similar to Friday’s loss to the Raptors: double-digit leads had evaporated, key free throws had found iron instead of twine.

headline: The Thatcher Legacy in Full
text: Reading the obituaries for Margaret Thatcher, dead today at eighty-seven, it strikes me that her relatively long post-political afterlife — it’s been twenty-three years since she left Downing Street, almost a generation — has probably made it easier to get some distance on her era, and to marry an appreciation for her achievements with a judicious weighing of her legacy in full. I’m particularly struck by the appropriate dose of the tragic sense that runs through a number of admiring right-of-center appreciations. Start with this passage from Andrew Sullivan’s moving eulogy, in which he explains how Thatcherism turned out to be “a much more complicated thing than many analyses contain”:

headline: Universities Get Middling Grades in Helping Poor
text: Prominent American and Canadian research universities earned mostly C’s on the first report card assessing how much their laboratories benefit the world’s poor.

headline: In Performance: Adam Kantor
text: Adam Kantor, accompanied by Gary Sieger on guitar, performs an excerpt from “If I Didn’t Believe in You” from Jason Robert Brown’s musical “The Last Five Years,” at Second Stage Theater.

headline: Justice Breyer Inducted Into French Academy

A Psychological & Mathematical Method.”  They have previously written about the B.C.S.national title game, this year’s Super Bowl and last year’s N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Protesters and Merkel Criticize Putin, Who Wears a Smile
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday publicly expressed her government’s disapproval of the way nongovernmental organizations are treated by the Kremlin, and she did so in the presence of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, making her the first Western leader known to have told him so directly.

headline: In Swallow Magazine, the Food, Sights and Scents of Mexico City
text: It’s hard to stand out in the crowded field of food publications. But Swallow Magazine may do just that with its latest issue, on Mexico City, which includes a scratch-and-sniff feature that also brings you the smells of the sprawling metropolis.

headline: THL to Buy CompuCom, a Technology Services Firm
text: The private equity firm THL Partners agreed on Monday to buy CompuCom Systems, a privately held information technology services provider, from another private equity firm.

headline: With Help From Nature, a Town Aims to Be a Solar Capital
text: LANCASTER, Calif. — There are at least two things to know about this high desert city. One, the sun just keeps on shining. Two, the city’s mayor, a class-action lawyer named R. Rex Parris, just keeps on competing.

headline: Security Delays Have You Upset? You Haven’t Been to Kinshasa
text: AS head of Jhpiego, I’m flying overseas almost all the time, mostly to meet with ministers of health or to meet the teams in the field who are working to train doctors and midwives. I figure I have about one weekend home a month. In 2012, I flew about 350,000 miles. I’m really lucky I have an understanding husband. He greets me at the airport at the end of nearly every trip with flowers and a smile.

headline: Not So Pumped Up About G.E.’s Latest Deal
text: General Electric shareholders are closing the gusher on bolt-on oil deals. Their reaction to the conglomerate’s $3 billion purchase of Lufkin Industries is more realistic than the wowed reception given to an earlier acquisition. Lufkin, whose technology helps increase production for aging oil wells, is a strong player in a growing sector. But previous deals did little for margins, and the latest one doesn’t come cheap.

headline: Journalist in Russia, Badly Beaten in 2008, Dies
text: MOSCOW — The Russian journalist Mikhail Beketov, who became a symbol of Russia’s culture of impunity after he was brutally beaten in 2008, died of heart failure on Monday, his lawyer announced.

headline: The Noisy Clatter of Traveling
text: Noise, to a business traveler, can be something as simple as a conversation on a train or a plane or as unrelenting as the sound of a jet engine on a seven-hour flight.

text: If a recent federal court ruling stands, any young woman will be able to walk into her neighborhood drugstore, find the morning-after pill near the shelves stocked with condoms and KY Jelly and buy it — no questions asked.

text: DEN HAAG, the Netherlands — The alarm always seems to go off much too early the morning after a game.

text: Want better sex? Consider getting a new hip or knee.

text: Nikolai and Simon Haas, the L.A.-based twins known for their design collaborations with Peter Marino and Mario Testino, are adding another boldfaced name to their roster: Versace. Tomorrow, their design project with Versace Home — a 12-piece homage to Donatella’s style — makes its debut at Salone del Mobile in Milan. Watch the making of “The Donatella Chair” in this video by Alexa Karolinski.

headline: Life as a Race Against a Diagnosis
text: While undressing for bed one night in 2009, Susan Spencer-Wendel noticed that the muscles in her left palm had disappeared, leaving a scrawny pile of tendons and bones. Her right hand was fine. She let out a yelp and showed the hand to her husband, who told her to go to the doctor. She was 42.

text: To the Editor:

headline: A New Competition for Young Golfers at Augusta
text: Billy Payne, the chairman of Augusta National Golf Club, announced on Monday the formation of a nationwide Drive, Chip and Putt Championship for children ages 7 to 15. Inspired by the N.F.L.’s punt, pass and kick competition, and created in concert with the U.S. Golf Association and the PGA of America, the contest will consist of local and regional qualifiers in four separate age classifications for boys and girls (7-9, 10-11, 12-13, 14-15).

headline: Battle Heats Up Over Fate of Troubled Energy Buyout
text: The biggest private equity buyout ever — the $45 billion deal for the Texas energy giant TXU in 2007 — has been steadily sliding toward becoming one of the biggest busts.

text: Off the Dribble highlights three essential games to watch each week, featuring hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and intriguing matchups in the N.B.A. (All times Eastern.)
