headline: Lots of Federal Property to Sell, but It’s Not That Easy
text: WASHINGTON — As government agencies are forced to do more with less, the General Services Administration has stepped up its efforts to dispose of surplus government buildings across the country in new and more profitable ways, instead of simply auctioning them off.

headline: Madison Square Garden Says It Will Not Be Uprooted From Penn Station
text: Madison Square Garden wants everyone to know: it isn’t going anywhere.

headline: Obama Chef Told to Plan Some Time Off
text: Although President Obama is unlikely to miss any meals, the White House kitchen will be missing its assistant chef, if only for a few days every now and then. Sam Kass, who cooks dinner for Mr. Obama several nights a week and is also his senior adviser on nutrition policy, is one of 480 White House employees who were expected to receive furlough notices stemming from the across-the-board budget cuts known as sequestration.

headline: Kovalchuk, Return Still Unclear, Practices With the Reeling Devils
text: NEWARK — Ilya Kovalchuk practiced with the Devils for the first time since he injured his right shoulder on March 23, offering a ray of hope for a skidding team working to stay optimistic.

headline: A New Buyer for Status-Symbol Horses in Spain: The Abattoir
text: CHAPINERÍA, Spain — Like his father and grandfather before him, Alberto Martín breeds horses, raising them on two farms, one of them here on the outskirts of Madrid. But even as a third-generation breeder, nothing in his experience had prepared him for times like these. Over the last two years, Mr. Martín says he has been forced to sell 50 of his 70 beloved mares for about $400 each. That is all the slaughterhouse would pay.

headline: Arrest Made in Stabbings at Texas College
text: At least 14 people were injured, four of them seriously, in stabbing attacks at a community college campus in a Houston suburb on Tuesday, the authorities said.

headline: Staal Says His Return to Ice Will Include a Helmet Visor
text: As he writhed on the Madison Square Garden ice in agony March 5 after being struck in the eye by a deflected slap shot, Rangers defenseman Marc Staal was ruing his decision not to wear a helmet visor.

headline: Marty Blake, Sharp Judge of N.B.A. Talent, Dies at 86
text: Marty Blake, a basketball executive whose capacious memory, keen eye for talent and relentless appetite for scouring gymnasiums in remote places made him perhaps the most valuable scout in the history of the National Basketball Association, died on Sunday in Alpharetta, Ga. He was 86.

headline: How a Leafy Folk Remedy Stopped Bedbugs in Their Tracks
text: Generations of Eastern European housewives doing battle against bedbugs spread bean leaves around the floor of an infested room at night. In the morning, the leaves would be covered with bedbugs that had somehow been trapped there. The leaves, and the pests, were collected and burned — by the pound, in extreme infestations.

headline: Obama Nominates 3 to Serve on Labor Relations Board
text: President Obama announced three nominations to the National Labor Relations Board on Tuesday to complete a package of five nominees — three Democrats and two Republicans — that the administration hopes Senate Republicans will approve to end the board’s unusual limbo.

headline: Jeter Takes Next Step Forward by Running Sprints
text: CLEVELAND — Despite his sorrow over his favorite college basketball team, the Michigan Wolverines, losing in the national championship game Monday night, Derek Jeter was back at work Tuesday.

headline: Hollande Finds His Gift Camel Was Consumed
text: PARIS — As if President François Hollande of France did not have enough trouble with a stagnant economy and a scandal over his former budget minister’s secret overseas bank accounts, now his camel has been eaten.

headline: Jason Griffith
text: Mr. Griffith, 36, is a founder and a chief executive of SiteCompli, a real estate technology company that provides monitoring services to owners and managers of commercial and residential buildings, helping them comply with the myriad rules and regulations within various New York City agencies.

headline: Upstart Party in Italy ‘Occupies’ a Parliament That Is Already Paralyzed
text: ROME — Just when Italians thought their politics could not get any stranger, on Tuesday they did. That was when members of the Five Star Movement of Beppe Grillo decided to “occupy” Parliament, a step that would seem unnecessary since voters had already sent them there to occupy 163 of its 945 seats.

headline: As Governor Steers Maryland to the Left, Talk Turns to 2016
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — As the Maryland Senate debated a crackdown on guns last week, one Republican after another objected that amendments were being smothered by the Democratic majority in its haste to send Gov. Martin O’Malley the bill he wanted.

headline: Broadcasters Circle Wagons Against a TV Streaming Upstart
text: When Chase Carey, Rupert Murdoch’s top deputy at News Corporation, told broadcasters on Monday about his contingency plan to turn the Fox network into something available only on cable, he knew policy makers would be listening, too. But a few of them were busy that day, meeting with Chet Kanojia, the very man who had provoked Mr. Carey’s stark warning.

headline: Peace Envoys From Taliban at Loose Ends in Qatar
text: DOHA, Qatar — When a handful of Taliban emissaries flew into Qatar on an American plane in 2010, the Obama administration hoped they would help negotiate a peace deal that could stabilize Afghanistan and allow the United States a graceful exit.

headline: Dutch Reporter Spends Night in Cairo Jail After Citizen’s Arrest
text: A Dutch reporter in Cairo spent Monday night in jail after the owner of a cafe detained her on suspicion of “spreading European culture” and endangering Egypt’s national security by looking for subjects to interview for a story about youth unemployment.

text: As myriad court battles pitting the Occupy Wall Street movement against New York City agencies proceed, protesters claimed a victory on Tuesday, based not on how they were treated, but on how their books were mistreated.

text: Maybe it was the ice sculptures. Or the order to stock slim, European-style men’s suits. Or the swagger of a protégé of the mighty Steve Jobs.

headline: Canadian Visits U.S. to Promote Oil Pipeline

headline: A FoxNews.com Reporter Is Facing Jail for Refusing to Identify Police Sources

text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — On the 50th anniversary of his first Masters victory in 1963, Jack Nicklaus on Tuesday met with reporters to reminisce, although the questions were often about the future.

headline: Three Obama Nominees Encounter No Opposition at Senate Confirmation Hearings
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s three nominees to run Medicare and Medicaid, the Energy Department and the Office of Management and Budget sailed through their separate Senate confirmation hearings on Tuesday and appeared to be on track to win approval from the committees, though none of the panels voted on the nominations.

headline: On Korean Peninsula, South Koreans and Foreigners React to Tensions
text: The North Korean government has hinted at new military provocations in the coming days, testing global leaders and consuming headlines almost everywhere. Last week, we asked readers who live on the Korean Peninsula or have family members there to weigh in on how the escalating tensions affect them and what the South Korean government and the international community should do to address those tensions. You can still join the discussion by submitting a comment in the thread below, in English or Korean, or post your thoughts on Twitter, with the hashtag #NYTWorld. We will update this post with a selection of views.

headline: A Solution for Penney May Be to Sell Itself, or Some of Its Assets

headline: Obama Pushes His Choice for Position on Appeals Court
text: WASHINGTON — With a coordination and an energy that echo a Supreme Court nomination fight, the Obama administration is pushing for the confirmation of a senior Justice Department lawyer to the country’s most prestigious appellate court. If the effort fails, it could lead to a confrontation with the Senate over the long-simmering issue of judicial nominees.

headline: Eating With Our Eyes Closed
text: The food that comes from factory farms is ultimately consumed by the public, which gives the public an interest in knowing how that food is produced. But in most of the major agricultural states, laws have been introduced or passed that would make it illegal to gather evidence, by filming or photography, about the internal operations of factory farms where animals are being raised.

headline: Worry Over Attention Deficit Cases
text: It is hard not to be concerned about the large number of children who have been given a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, a condition that impairs the ability to focus on a task or to control impulses. A new analysis of government data found that almost one in five boys of high school age in the United States and 11 percent of school-age children over all had been reported to have the disorder at some point in their lives. The troubling question is whether they had or still have A.D.H.D. that actually needs treatment with potent drugs.

headline: Not Enough Reform on Derivatives
text: On Thursday, several bills to pre-empt the regulation of derivatives will be the focus of a hearing in the House Financial Services Committee. The bills, which have already passed the Agriculture Committee, must be stopped if the world is to be made safe from reckless risk-taking by banks. As it turns out, Representative Jeb Hensarling, Republican of Texas and the new head of the Financial Services Committee, may be the man to stop them.

headline: The Public Wants Background Checks
text: On Thursday, the full Senate is scheduled to take its first procedural vote on a bill designed to keep guns out of criminal hands, more than three months after the school massacre in Newtown, Conn. In those few months, much of the urgency has seeped out of the search for solutions to gun violence. That return to complacency is reflected in the difficulty in reaching bipartisan agreement on which bill will reach the floor.

headline: The Qualities of the Squid, as Observed in the Capitol
text: In nature, the octopus and the squid are known for their quick-changing colors, allowing them to blend into any environment. Lacking spines, they can slip through the tiniest crevices. Yet they have tremendous strength in their tentacles, which are lined with suction-cup structures that have so much power they can burst an artery in a human, capsize boats, or stay fixed to a rock until they are good and ready to let go.

headline: The Arab Quarter Century
text: I guess it’s official now: The term “Arab Spring” has to be retired. There is nothing springlike going on. The broader, but still vaguely hopeful, “Arab Awakening” also no longer seems valid, given all that has been awakened. And so the strategist Anthony Cordesman is probably right when he argues: It’s best we now speak of the “Arab Decade” or the “Arab Quarter Century” — a long period of intrastate and intraregional instability, in which a struggle for both the future of Islam and the future of the individual Arab nations blend together into a “clash within a civilization.” The ending: TBD.

The peacekeepers, who were Indian, were attacked while escorting a convoy through Jonglei State. At least seven civilians were also killed. Indian news media reported that rebels attacked the peacekeepers with assault rifles and rocket-propelled grenades.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (BBC America) SPIES OF WARSAW In the conclusion of this two-part mini-series based on the novel by Alan Furst, Col. Jean-François Mercier (David Tennant, foreground above), a French military attaché in Warsaw, goes undercover in Czechoslovakia as he searches for the man who can lead him into the Nazi war machine. Anna Skarbek (Janet Montgomery), his mistress and a lawyer for the League of Nations, receives devastating news about her former lover, the Russian journalist Maxim Mostov (Piotr Baumann), and flees to Spain on a mission of mercy. The drama “has an almost comic-book adherence to stereotype, from the dashing Polish nobleman to the sallow, pockmarked Nazi border guard,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “On the other hand, there is nothing more satisfying than a prewar espionage story that shows, up close and told-you-so, how most of Europe slept through Hitler’s rise.” She added, “There are many impediments to true love in ‘Spies of Warsaw,’ but Mercier, solitary and sorrowful, learns to trust his heart — and not the Maginot Line.”

headline: Anthony Weiner and Huma Abedin’s Post-Scandal Playbook
text: One day in early February, I met Anthony Weiner and Huma Abedin for breakfast at the Gramercy Park Hotel, one of their regular joints, just a few blocks from their apartment on Park Avenue South. The first thing Weiner said when I sat down was that their 13-month-old son, Jordan, had just moments ago taken his first step. They were both giddy, kvelling with baby-pride, especially Weiner, who, with all his free time, has become his son’s primary caretaker. This is what life is like now for the man whose name is invariably followed in print by some version of “the disgraced former congressman who sent out a lewd picture of himself via Twitter.” He seems to spend much of his time within a five-block radius of his apartment: going to the park with Jordan; picking up his wife’s dry cleaning and doing the grocery shopping; eating at his brother Jason’s two restaurants in the neighborhood. This is what happens after a scandal: Ranks are closed and the world shrinks to a tiny dot. It is a life in retreat. And for a man who was known, pre-scandal, for his overweening ambition, his constant presence on cable news, his hard-charging schedule that verged on lunacy, well, it has been quite a change.

headline: The Gang Legacy of Central America’s Wars
text: Donna De Cesare had just walked into the AIDS ward at a public hospital in El Salvador one day in 1989 when a young voice greeted her.

headline: Do You Ever Seek Advice on the Internet?
text: What did we do before the Internet? How did we know how to shoot a basketball or shake hands properly? Now we can seek the specific advice we want whenever we want it.

headline: Anthony Weiner Is Weighing a Run for Mayor
text: Saying that he would like, at some point, to “ask people to give me a second chance,” Anthony D. Weiner, the former congressman who resigned in 2011 amid a scandal over his lewd online behavior, is mulling a run for mayor this year because “it’s now or maybe never for me.”

headline: Using Retirement Money to Start a Business
text: You’re thinking about starting a company. You’ve decided that the best bet is to buy a franchise. This will give you a leg up because someone else has done the heavy lifting and can give you a road map for success. You’ve discussed opening the business with your spouse, and your spouse is supportive. The only problem is that you need to raise $300,000 to get the franchise off the ground.

headline: Antique Tractor Sale Will Be Crawling With Caterpillars

headline: Obama Budget Opens Rift for Democrats on Social Benefits
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s new budget has opened a debate over what it means to be a progressive Democrat in an age of austerity and defines him as a president willing to take on the two pillars of his party — Medicare and Social Security — created by Democratic presidents.

headline: By the Teeth of Their Skin
text: CAIRO — You may have missed it, but April 4 was International Topless Jihad Day. Announced by Femen, the radical feminist group that originated in Ukraine, it was organized in solidarity with Amina Tyler, a 19-year-old Tunisian woman who last month sparked a storm in Tunisia by posting two topless photos of herself online. In one, she faces the camera with both hands held up defiantly, her middle fingers unfurled; her torso bears an inscription cursing “your morals.” In the other photo, she wrote “my body belongs to me and is not a source of anyone’s honor.”

headline: Shadow Regulator Under Scrutiny
text: Mary L. Schapiro, who ran the Securities and Exchange Commission until last year, is only the latest former political insider to join the Promontory Financial Group, which has such a star-studded roster of former bureaucrats that it has become known as Wall Street’s shadow regulator. With these connections, the firm “has emerged as a major power broker in Washington, helping Wall Street navigate an onslaught of new rules and regulatory scrutiny,” Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook.

headline: Daily Report: Aereo’s Inroads Bring Sharp Reaction From Networks
text: Aereo is a service that scoops up the free signals of local television stations and streams them to the phones and computers of paying subscribers. Because Aereo cuts off the stations from the retransmission fees that they have grown to depend on, they are determined to shut down the service — even, the station owners say, if they have to go cable-only, Brian Stelter reports in Wednesday’s New York Times.

headline: After Years of Playing Bette, Another Role
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — “It’s all about the bosom,” Bette Midler says as she slinks down in an armchair, arches her back and steadies her breasts until they are horizontal enough to balance an ashtray.

headline: Wednesday Reading: The Rewards of Going Off Itinerary
text: Going off itinerary while traveling, exercise may bolster memory, first checks to be issued in mortgage settlement and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Poor Nations Fight, Rich Nations Pay
text: When the United Nations peacekeeping forces face a violent conflict, as they did in South Sudan this week, odds are high that a South Asian soldier will be among the injured or killed.

In particular, she did hardly anything to scale down the British welfare state (although she did make a hash of retirement security — more on that in a later post). Here’s one indicator, from the Institute for Fiscal Studies (pdf):

text: If you watch HBO or use Netflix by using a friend’s password, thus managing to avoid paying for the service yourself, is that acceptable digital-native behavior or is it piracy?

headline: A Senator’s Search for an Ally Keeps a Gun Bill Alive
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III so craved a pro-gun-rights Republican as a partner for a bill to expand background checks on gun buyers that he took to buttonholing senators on the in-house subway that ferries them from their offices to the Capitol, making his pitch while his colleagues were trapped with him in the tiny car.

headline: By Accident, Fed Gives Early Data to Banks
text: The Federal Reserve alerted bank officials on Tuesday that policy makers were considering a shift on when to begin easing back on stimulus efforts, a day before the news was released publicly, but it insisted there was no evidence traders on Wall Street had benefited from what was called an error.

headline: Chelsea: Kind of Blue
text: It is only April, but already Chelsea and its equipment sponsor Adidas are looking ahead to next season, when the club will begin anew its quest to win England’s Premier League … and sell thousands of new jerseys.

headline: Advice for Couples About Their Sex Lives, Part 1
text: Readers recently submitted questions about male sexuality to Dr. Ronald F. Levant, a professor of psychology and director of the Psychology Department Counseling Clinic at the University of Akron. Dr. Levant was president of the American Psychological Association and is an author or editor of 14 books, including “Men and Sex: New Psychological Perspectives.” Dr. Levant asked the counselors that he supervises in his clinic, all Ph.D. students in psychology who see a broad range of clients, to help him compose answers to these questions. Thanks are due to Mike Aguilar, Brittany Baker, Natalie Grandy, Craig Libman and Arielle Riutort. Because of the large number of submissions, not every question was addressed. In particular, they were not able to answer questions on medical issues, as their expertise is psychological, not medical. More answers will be posted next week.

headline: Census Takes a Look at New Yorkers’ Migration Patterns
text: So much for Horace Greeley. Between 2006 and 2010, more people, on average, moved to Manhattan from Los Angeles annually (3,251) than, for example, from Suffolk County (2,301). And more moved to Manhattan from Brooklyn (11,469) than from any other county in the United States or from any other country. (Europe was second.)

headline: Europe Urged to Make a U-Turn on Austerity
text: LONDON — Austerity in Europe is under fire, and not just from protesters.

headline: The iPad as Child’s Easel
text: IPad cases for children abound these days, but if your intention is to create a child’s easel, ArtSee Studio from WowWee ($40) is the best bet. Designed to offer both protection against drops and reduce the chance a preschooler might end up in your email, the plastic case includes a home button lock, a rubber-tipped stylus and five stamps of the variety you might find at the post office. Instead of ink, each stamp has a unique dot pattern that triggers an artistic effect when placed against the iPad’s screen. Want to add a swimming dolphin? Use the sticker stamp. Want to make your dolphin move? Use the Arrow stamp, and trace a course. After you snap your iPad into the holder and download the free app, called ArtSee Studio, your child is free to sketch. One weak point — our testers found it hard to “undo” a sticker once it has been placed. But they were impressed by the powerful drawing options, which include such wonders as a rainbow crayon. Saving projects is automatic, and there is a set of games like connect the dots and concentration.  The case fits all generations of iPads.Download the app here.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Times: The fight to save a family-owned oyster bed in Northern California has thrown together some very strange bedfellows, including Alice Waters and Republicans trying to promote the Keystone XL pipeline and drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. – Patrick Farrell

headline: Gunman Attacks Police Officer Guarding Polio Workers in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A gunman shot and killed one policeman and wounded another on Wednesday as they provided security for a team of polio eradication health workers in northwestern Pakistan, according to government officials.

headline: Paolo Soleri, Architect of Counterculture, Dies at 93
text: Paolo Soleri, a visionary architect who was best known as the designer and oracle of Arcosanti, a settlement in the Arizona high desert that became a symbol of hippie-era utopianism and a prescient environmentalism, died on Tuesday at Cosanti, his home in Paradise Valley, Ariz. He was 93.

headline: Updates on the Gun Debate | April 10, 2013
text: Two senators announce a bipartisan compromise on background checks. Michelle Obama wades into the gun debate. Newtown families urge Republican senators to vote instead of filibuster.

headline: Russian Ballerina Natalia Osipova Joins London’s Royal Ballet
text: LONDON — It was only 18 months ago that the Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova shocked the dance world by leaving the Bolshoi Ballet, where she was considered a major star, to join the lesser-known Mikhailovsky Ballet in St. Petersburg. But on Monday, the Royal Opera House announced that Ms. Osipova would join the Royal Ballet as a principal dancer for the 2013-14 season. The announcement came hot on the heels of Ms. Osipova’s wholesale conquest of this city during the Mikhailovsky’s recent two-week engagement here.

headline: If American and US Airways Merge, What Should Fliers Expect?
text: American Airlines is on its way to becoming the biggest airline in the world after winning bankruptcy-court approval to merge with US Airways. Maybe you don’t fly those airlines often, but here’s why you should care: the consolidation of two major carriers might affect how seamlessly you can fly. It might affect what you pay. It might even affect your miles strategy.

headline: Hotel Review: The Saguaro in Scottsdale, Ariz.
text: Upshot

headline: Restaurant Report: Shanik in Seattle
text: Encouraged by the flowering of Seattle’s once-industrial South Lake Union neighborhood, the area’s restaurants now reflect a veritable United Nations of world cuisines. One of the latest and most celebrated is Indian, by way of the fertile mind of Meeru Dhalwala, half of the husband-wife team behind Vij’s, the outpost of nontraditional Indian cuisine in Vancouver, British Columbia.

headline: When is a Person Not a Human? When it’s a Dolphin, or Chimp, or…
text: After I wrote over the weekend about new research on the killing method employed in the dolphin roundups undertaken in Taiji, Japan, a fascinating comment on the rights of “nonhuman persons” was posted by Thomas I. White, who is the Conrad N. Hilton Professor in Business Ethics at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles.

text: Bill’s Food & Drink, the high-end Manhattan restaurant that opened last fall, has a new bartender. And he’s no stranger to Midtown, or to Midtown drinkers.

headline: Fed Says Minutes Were Inadvertently Released
text: The Federal Reserve was forced to release the latest minutes of its monthly policy-making meeting five hours early Wednesday, after they were inadvertently distributed Tuesday to more than 100 Congressional staff members and trade organization officials.

text: Q.

headline: Handicapping the Masters
text: The Masters begins Thursday, and Michael Rosenberg at Sports Illustrated thinks Tiger Woods will win, one reason being his putting: “He has done two things exceptionally well: Avoided three-putts (he is No. 4 on tour), and rammed home putts from 5 to 20 feet. Those are a function of great putting more than luck.”

headline: KPMG and the Pain That Comes of Breached Trust
text: Trust can be breached – even on the golf course.

headline: Applied Arts
text: For the last several years, the coolest design schools were those, like Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands, that turned out the most conceptual work, much of it laced with social commentary. But now the school whose name seems to be everywhere is the ÉCAL/University of Art and Design Lausanne. Like many of its peers, the 192-year-old Swiss institution offers an undergraduate degree in industrial design. But unlike many schools, it also has something called the Master of Advanced Studies in Design for Luxury and Craftsmanship, which was founded five years ago and has made a name for itself through its collaborations — with luxury goods companies like Baccarat, Christofle, Bernardaud and Audemars Piguet — that bring new ideas to old-line manufacturers.

headline: Subway on Way? Maps Tell You
text: Google Maps has added information on public transportation in several cities. The service now provides up-to-date departure times for seven New York City (above) subway lines and for buses and trams in the greater Salt Lake City area, and service alerts for Washington’s Metrorail subway. Updates are available in many other major cities, including London, Madrid and San Diego.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Legal Fight Ends in ‘Artistic Divorce’
text: After more than a year of brinkmanship at the negotiating table the producers of the musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” and their former director, Julie Taymor, announced on Wednesday that they had settled their acrimonious legal battle over profits, copyright claims and artistic credit for the $75 million show, the most expensive in Broadway history.

headline: The Gun Report: April 10, 2013
text: Reports of drive-by shootings first dominated the headlines in the 1980s, and were largely associated with the infamous Los Angeles gang wars as well as the drug trade in cities such as Chicago. But readers of our daily report will notice that such shootings are not a remnant of the Reagan-Thatcher years: they’re happening all the time, in Texas, Alabama, Tennessee—and now Tupelo, Mississippi. That’s where Carol, the 39-year-old Asian elephant used in the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, was shot in a drive-by early Tuesday morning. At around 2:00 a.m., someone fired his gun into the BancorpSouth Arena parking lot where the circus animals were being kept.

headline: The Scale of the President’s Budget
text: How spending in President Obama’s 2014 budget compares with proposals from both parties and historical averages.

headline: Moving to a Place Where Strangers on the Street Say Hello
text: My main goal for spring break was to visit Vanderbilt University. Even though I had been admitted in January as a Posse Scholar, I had yet to see the campus for myself. So, my parents and I got on a plane and arrived in Nashville on a Sunday.

headline: Man Accused of Burning Jewish Symbols Is in Police Custody
text: Updated, 12:03 p.m. | The suspect in this week’s hate-crime burning of a dozen Jewish doorway adornments in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is in custody, a law enforcement official said Wednesday.

headline: Obama’s Budget Proposal
text: The White House’s complete budget proposal for the 2014 fiscal year.

headline: If You Need More Time to File Your Tax Return
text: Tax Day is next Monday. If you haven’t filed your taxes yet, should you be considering filing for an extension?

headline: Dozens Injured in Tamil Nadu Train Accident
text: Chennai, TAMIL NADU — One person was killed and at least 27 people were injured early Wednesday morning after the derailment of nearly half of the coaches of a 24-car train traveling from the eastern state of Bihar to the southern state of Karnataka.

headline: Image of the Day: April 10
text: An artisan works on freshly dyed strands of multicolored thread used in Hindu rituals, in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: $25,000 Dance Prize Goes to Michelle Dorrance
text: Jacob’s Pillow, the dance festival and school in the Berkshires, will award its seventh annual Jacob’s Pillow Dance Award to Michelle Dorrance, the tap dancer and choreographer whose company, Dorrance Dance, is known for its blend of inventiveness, virtuosity and musicality.

headline: Brave Young Heroine
text: On the Broadway stage a heroine named Matilda is showing that magical things can happen to brainy, confident and righteous little girls. Meanwhile, in a new graphic novel, a blue-haired child named Hilda is proving much the same point. In Matilda’s case, what must be overcome is a world of foolish and powerful adults. For Hilda, the obstacle is a new town, Trolberg, where a well-meaning but insensitive group of peers prove insufficient armor against an unfamiliar and seemingly forbidding environment.

headline: G.E. Turns to the Crowd for Help in Creating Consumer Products
text: General Electric has been making a serious push in recent years into the so-called Internet of Things, where all kinds of devices connect to the Internet, creating a constant stream of data about how they’re working. Now it is hoping to crowd-source consumer uses for technologies it has developed for things like power plant turbines and medical imaging equipment.

headline: Riding the Momentum Created by a Cheeky Video
text: In March 2012, a video promoting a razor-blade business called Dollar Shave Club took YouTube by storm. It featured the company’s founder, Michael Dubin, who had spent the bulk of his career in digital media and marketing and had performed improvisational comedy as a hobby, walking briskly through a warehouse as he issued off-color wisecracks and encouraged men to buy his razor blades on a subscription basis for as little as $2 a month.

headline: Chrysler Will Recall 213,000 Vehicles in Five Actions
text: Chrysler will recall more than 213,000 vehicles in five actions for problems that include driveshaft failures, underhood fires, stalling and air-bag malfunctions, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: City Introduces Online Database for Its Potter’s Field
text: For more than a century, to be buried on Hart Island, off the coast of the Bronx, was to be essentially forgotten.

headline: A Peek Into Your Closet
text: We asked readers to submit images of their masterpieces of organization. Here are some of their responses.

headline: MTV Cancels the Reality Series ‘Buckwild’
text: MTV has decided to cancel the reality series “Buckwild,'’ nine days after the death of one of its cast members, the network said on Wednesday.

headline: Has Your Business Tried Video Marketing?
text: We’ve just published a Conversation with Michael Dubin, a founder of Dollar Shave Club, the razor-blade business that got its start with a promotional video that went viral in March 2012. It featured Mr. Dubin walking briskly through a warehouse as he issued off-color wisecracks and encouraged men to buy his razor blades on a subscription basis for as little as $2 a month.

headline: A Photograph With Legs
text: Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

headline: Robert G. Edwards Dies at 87; Changed Rules of Conception With First ‘Test Tube Baby’
text: Robert G. Edwards, who opened a new era in medicine when he joined a colleague in developing in vitro fertilization, enabling millions of infertile couples to bring children into the world and women to have babies even in menopause, died on Wednesday at his home near Cambridge, England. Dr. Edwards, who was awarded the Nobel Prize for his breakthrough, was 87.

headline: Notes on Deborah Madison’s Onion Tart and Asparagus Salad
text: This month’s book for Recipe Lab is “Vegetable Literacy” by Deborah Madison, and our live chat is coming up this Tuesday at 3:30 p.m. Eastern. This will be your chance to ask her everything and anything about vegetable cookery, or about the recipes I hope you’re planning to try out before then. (You can find the recipes here; you can see how they come together in the video below.)

headline: Study of Babies Did Not Disclose Risks, U.S. Finds
text: A federal agency has found that a number of prestigious universities failed to tell more than a thousand families in a government-financed study of oxygen levels for extremely premature babies that the risks could include increased chances of blindness or death.

headline: Rangers Face Crucial Rematch With Toronto
text: With nine games remaining in the lockout-shortened N.H.L. season, every point is crucial for the Rangers if they are to make the playoffs.

headline: The Fall of Satan’s Kingdom
text: “[T]he crowning act of this war ought to be by the navy…I pray you give us Charleston if possible…for the Fall of Charleston is the fall of Satan’s Kingdom.”— Asst. Navy Secretary Gustavus Fox to Admiral Samuel F. DuPont, June 3, 1862

headline: Spokesman Quits After French Rabbi Admits Plagiarism
text: PARIS – The spokesman for the chief rabbi of France, who has refused to quit his post despite admitting to plagiarism and lying about his qualifications, quit himself on Wednesday, French news agencies reported.

headline: G.M. Goes to Germany to Reaffirm Support for Opel
text: RÜSSELSHEIM, GERMANY — As they prepare to meet with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, top managers of General Motors sought to dispel any doubts about the company’s commitment to its unprofitable Opel unit in Europe, reiterating plans to invest billions in new models and break even by the middle of the decade.

headline: A U.S. Soccer Star’s Declaration of Independence
text: LYON, France — The latest attempt at a women’s professional soccer league in the United States begins this weekend, so the stars of the American team from the London Olympics have, for the most part, returned to preaching the gospel stateside. Abby Wambach, the powerful striker, is with a team in Rochester; Alex Morgan, the pixieish, pink-headband-wearing poster girl, is in Portland, Ore.; and Hope Solo, the mercurial goalkeeper and “Dancing With the Stars” alumna, would be in Seattle were it not for a wrist injury.

headline: Properties for $995,000
text: A Chicago penthouse one block from Lake Michigan, an Italianate revival in Memphis and a house in Colorado Springs with mountain views.

headline: What You Get for ... $995,000
text: CHICAGO

headline: Army Judge Raises Burden in Private’s Trial on Leaks
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — The military prosecutors seeking to have Pfc. Bradley Manning convicted of violating the Espionage Act over his release of secret government files to WikiLeaks will face an additional burden at his court-martial under a ruling on Wednesday by a military judge.

headline: Architectural Masterpiece in Moscow Under Grave Threat, Preservationists Say
text: MOSCOW — The Russian avant-garde architect Konstantin Melnikov’s seminal cylindrical house in Moscow, which has inspired architects around the world for nearly a century, is gravely threatened by construction of a large multipurpose complex abutting its tiny backyard, Russian and international preservationists say.

headline: Obama Likes Some Sin Taxes More Than Others
text: President Obama’s budget continues the Democratic preference for cigarette taxes over alcohol or soda taxes – even though alcohol and soda consumption may cost society more money than smoking.

headline: A Vocabulary Site Shows How to Tailor Online Education
text: The recent excitement about online learning has mostly been focused on the power of technology to distribute and democratize education. At the forefront has been the rise of massive open online courses, or MOOCs, which have been magnets for attention and investment.

headline: What Makes a Successful Stepfather?
text: How mothers and their new partners feel about becoming a stepfamily is one thing, and how the children involved feel is quite another. In 2009, more than 7 percent of children lived with at least one stepparent, yet much of the research and writing on the topic centers on how the adults navigate their new family dynamic.

headline: Highlights From Obama’s Budget Proposal
text: 11:10 p.m. | Updated  A condensed version of this post is available here.

headline: High Low | Dr. Martens Sneakers
text: Injecting a tinge of athletic spirit to its archive of iconic punk-cult classics, the British shoe brand Dr. Martens introduces a new line of sneaker-inspired footwear for the spring season. The Farrell style, the standout in the new collection, combines the classic Dr. Martens air-cushioned wedge sole with a sleek smooth leather upper available in three colors (black, navy and cherry). Resembling many of the chunky-soled shoes that have treaded the runway in recent collections of Raf Simons, Acne and Marni, the Dr. Martens Farrell is a fresh alternative that can be worn with as much regularity as a favorite sneaker. And for under $100, it’s difficult not to want all three.

headline: Martyl Langsdorf, Doomsday Clock Designer, Dies at 96
text: Martyl Langsdorf’s clock has yet to strike midnight.

headline: Checking Your Own Bags
text: Hawaiian Airlines has become the first domestic carrier to extend the concept of self-check-in to luggage. The airline recently began allowing passengers at check-in kiosks at Honolulu International Airport to weigh and tag their bags. The move is expected to cut check-in time, already down to a slim eight minutes, in half, according to Hawaiian.

headline: 10 Mistakes of the Iraq War
text: In 2003, Col. Ted Spain was deployed to Iraq as the commander of the 18th Military Police Brigade. His task was to rebuild the Iraqi police force, establish a detention system and forge a new model for law and order in the country. But on the ground, he says, this task was made impossible by a lack of manpower, limited resources and the rising animosity of the Iraqi people. When he retired in 2004, the military police were still struggling to put these systems in place, and law and order seemed a distant goal.

headline: Brains as Clear as Jell-O for Scientists to Explore
text: The visible brain has arrived — the consistency of Jell-O, as transparent and colorful as a child’s model, but vastly more useful.

headline: Parliament Debates Thatcher
text: Prime Minister David Cameron and members of Parliament pay tribute to Margaret Thatcher.

headline: From the Audience to the Stage at the Metropolitan Opera
text: The soprano Danielle de Niese came for a relaxing evening at the Metropolitan Opera – in the audience — with her husband and parents on Tuesday night. Instead, she found herself onstage.

headline: Tentative Settlement Reached in Labor Dispute at St. Paul Chamber Orchestra
text: The St. Paul Chamber Orchestra’s musicians and management have tentatively settled one of the stickiest labor disputes of the musical world this season, a conflict that has caused the cancellation of concerts since October.

headline: Champions League Quarterfinals: Matchday 4
text: When does four minus two equal four? Today.

headline: Political Introspection
text: David Brooks: Have you noticed that there have been twice as many essays on Margaret Thatcher as there are English speakers on earth?

headline: Thatcher as Theater: A Prime Minister Playwrights Couldn’t Resist
text: LONDON — Margaret Thatcher didn’t have much time for one of Britain’s defining qualities — its abundance of theater — but theater people certainly had plenty of time for her. If only antagonistically.

headline: Two National Theater Directors to Depart
text: Having just celebrated his 10th anniversary as artistic director of London’s National Theater, Nicholas Hytner announced on Wednesday that he would leave his position at the end of March 2015. Nick Starr, who became the company’s executive director in 2002, also announced that he would leave the theater in 2014. Mr. Hytner and Mr. Starr have been a powerful team, and Mr. Starr told The Guardian that the two planned to work together on future projects.

headline: Dinner Diplomacy, This Time at the White House
text: WASHINGTON — If President Obama meant his new budget proposal to be an olive branch to Republicans, he had a chance to test their reaction in person on Wednesday night as he hosted a dozen senators from the opposition party for dinner at the White House.

headline: Court Expresses Antipathy for S.E.C. in Handling of Madoff Case
text: A federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday that Bernard L. Madoff‘s investors cannot sue the Securities and Exchange Commission for not uncovering his fraud, but at the same time blasted the agency for its failings.

headline: Postal Service Halts Push to End Delivery of Mail on Saturdays
text: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service on Wednesday backed away from its plan to stop Saturday mail delivery, criticizing Congress for taking the cost-cutting proposal off the table.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: April 11
text: Cutout dresses will be big for spring; Bao Bao Wan presents little ones pendants; the black-and-white patterns come in a range of styles: platforms, heels, sandals; and other shopping news.

headline: How the Cubs Explain the Cosmos
text: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.April means the arrival of a new baseball season. More than a few intellectuals have described the game in quasi-religious terms, crediting baseball with the capacity to add meaning and texture to life. A recent book by the embattled N.Y.U. president John Sexton even makes an explicit case for “Baseball as a Road to God.”

headline: Jury Lineups Announced for Tribeca Film Festival
text: Imagine a cocktail party populated by recognizable guests who would otherwise probably never hang out together: some of them are highly knowledgeable about movies, some have made movies, others have appeared in movies and still others have at least seen some movies. Hold that image in your mind and tally off the boldface names in attendance, and you may come up with rosters not unlike the — shall we say, heterogeneous — juries that will preside over this year’s Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Hofstra Hires New Basketball Coach
text: Hofstra named Joe Mihalich its new men’s basketball coach Wednesday, ending a monthlong search to replace Mo Cassara, who was fired in March after three seasons.

headline: Strike Over Pickpockets Shuts the Louvre
text: PARIS –The Louvre museum was shut on Wednesday after 200 guards and surveillance agents went on strike to protest the growing number of often violent pickpockets who prey on them and tourists.

headline: Turning Street View Images Into Time-Lapse Films
text: Hyperlapse videos are a variation of traditional time lapse filmmaking in which the camera travels while also panning, rotating and tilting. The effect can be striking or dizzying. But under normal circumstances, coordinating all that action and turning it into a film is exceedingly complex and time consuming.

headline: Broad Outlines of Senate Immigration Agreement Emerge
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators has largely agreed on a broad immigration bill that would require tough border measures to be in place before illegal immigrants could take the first steps to become American citizens, according to several people familiar with drafts of the legislation.

headline: Timberlake’s ‘20/20 Experience’ Rolls On at No. 1
text: Justin Timberlake’s latest album is No. 1 on the Billboard chart for a third week, beating new albums by the Band Perry and the rapper Tyler, the Creator.

headline: Justice for All? Teaching About Crime and Punishment in America
text: The United States holds a larger proportion of its population in prison than any other nation in the world. How has this happened, and is it a problem? In this lesson, students will consider whether the nation’s system for addressing crime is effective and consistent with its Constitutional ideals of equality under the law.

headline: When the Present Is Past It Looks Much Prettier
text: André Aciman is a connoisseur of nostalgia, like a contemporary Proust. A French-speaking Jew expelled from Egypt with his family in the early 1960s, when he was 15, he now lives in New York and writes in precise and elegant English. But in his novels and memoirs he takes a certain melancholy pleasure in considering himself a permanent exile, which is for him less a condition of displacement than one of disappointment and vacillation. Wherever he finds himself he’s less happy than where he was just before, and you sometimes get the sense that he feels truly at home only in memory, in the places he reconstructs for himself on the page.

headline: Arab Israeli Is Accused of Joining Rebels in Syrian Revolt
text: JERUSALEM — A district court on Wednesday charged an Arab citizen of Israel with crimes including contact with a foreign agent after he traveled to Syria to fight alongside the rebels, Shin Bet, Israel’s internal security agency, said in a statement.

headline: Arrests of 2 Officials Lead to a Tense Village Meeting
text: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y. — It would have been a routine gathering of this community’s governing body except for one salient and looming fact: It was the first meeting since the mayor and the deputy mayor had been arrested in a complicated and brazen federal corruption case that also ensnared a state senator and a New York City councilman.

headline: A Hide-Out From the Ordinary
text: IT HAS BEEN SOME TIME since a new store, the brick-and-mortar kind, for those of you who can remember, has set out to do something more surprising than sell clothes. But then, entertaining the customer has become a low-priority line item on most retailers’ budgets these days.

headline: Country Music Hall of Fame Names New Members
text: Kenny Rogers, Bobby Bare and Cowboy Jack Clement will be inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum later this year, the Country Music Association announced at a news conference on Wednesday.

headline: ConocoPhillips Suspends Its Arctic Drilling Plans
text: HOUSTON — ConocoPhillips announced on Wednesday that it was suspending its plans to drill in Alaskan Arctic waters in 2014 because of uncertainties over federal regulatory and permitting standards.

headline: Hollande Creates a Prosecutor for Fraud and Vows to End Tax Havens
text: PARIS — Buffeted by a political scandal, a stagnant economy and angry public reaction to an investigative report about secret offshore bank accounts, President François Hollande on Wednesday announced the creation of a position of special prosecutor to pursue cases of corruption and tax fraud, and vowed to eradicate tax havens “in Europe and the world.”

headline: Girl Scout Cookies as a Tax Deduction
text: Last weekend, The Wall Street Journal ran an article on how some states, like Idaho, tax the sale of Girl Scout cookies. That got us thinking about another tax-related question having to do with Samoas and other Girl Scout treats.

headline: Steinem on Thatcher
text: Margaret Thatcher, who died on Monday at 87, was the first female prime minister of Britain and, for a time, among the most powerful women in the world. But her conservative politics and dismissive attitude toward “women’s libbers” (her words) made Mrs. Thatcher a complicated figure for feminists, even after she withdrew from public life.

headline: Candidates React to Weiner Speculation
text: At a candidates forum in the Bronx, The Times’s Stephen Farrell spoke with some of the mayoral candidates about the news that Anthony Weiner is considering a run.

headline: Melissa Harris-Perry’s ‘Uncontroversial Comment’ About Children
text: If you send your children to public school, are they still your children? If you trust that should they fall off their bike while riding along on the sidewalk in front of the neighbor’s house, he might run out with a Band-Aid, is that the end of the nuclear family? Does taking support for those children, in the form of the Children’s Health Insurance Program, Head Start or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, mean you have you ceded your place as mother or father to the collective?

headline: Roman Charity
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Man of Our Time
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Wilder Way
text: See the interactive slide show

headline: Measuring Inflation for Social Security
text: 4/11/13 | Updated to restore an omitted paragraph on the effect on the oldest retirees.

headline: ‘Ghana Must Go’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Banking’s Crocodile Tears
text: The story is told of a young heir whose family fell on times hard times and he could no longer afford to keep his polo ponies. He still had a big house and enough trust fund income to make a paid career optional, but it was hard to look his polo-playing friends in the face. The shame was almost unbearable.

headline: The Answer to Too Big to Fail?
text: Senators Sherrod Brown, D-Ohio, and David Vitter, R-Louisiana, have a new bill that would make banks keep much higher levels of capital. Not surprisingly, representatives for the financial industry are already claiming that such a requirement would ruin the economy.

headline: The Power of Talking to Your Baby
text: By the time a poor child is 1 year old, she has most likely already fallen behind middle-class children in her ability to talk, understand and learn. The gap between poor children and wealthier ones widens each year, and by high school it has become a chasm. American attempts to close this gap in schools have largely failed, and a consensus is starting to build that these attempts must start long before school — before preschool, perhaps even before birth.

headline: First Hudson Yards Tower Signs Three Major Tenants
text: There was a time when developers and city officials thought that the city’s financial institutions would lead the development of the rail yards on the Far West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Disney Studios Lays Off 150 Employees
text: LOS ANGELES – Walt Disney Studios, which employs 7,000 people, on Wednesday laid off 150 workers, including a few relatively senior executives in movie publicity and the DVD department.

headline: Vacation Behind Him, Stoudemire Will Revisit Israel as Coach
text: As players did layup drills in a high school gymnasium in Toronto one afternoon in August, John Dore disappeared briefly and returned with a tall guest wearing a black skullcap.

headline: T Magazine at Design Week
text: A host of boldface names celebrated Deborah Needleman’s latest design issue at Design Week in Milan.

headline: Relighting Sarfatti
text: A look at Gino Sarfatti’s lighting designs.

headline: Beyoncé to Headline Philadelphia Music Festival
text: Jay-Z did not have to look far for a singer to headline the second annual Budweiser Made in America music festival in Philadelphia — his wife Beyoncé will be at the top of the bill, Billboard reported.

headline: Hood by Air Has a Fashion Moment
text: The fashion show was running an hour late, but no one seemed to mind. The rapper Waka Flocka Flame took a seat near the artist Terence Koh. Tank and Bambi, two miniature Pomeranians with more than 3,000 followers on Instagram, sat front row with their owner, the creative director Nicola Formichetti. Then, with a smoke-filled spectacle of bluish lasers and flickering LED signs, a mash-up of post-apocalyptic, post-Internet looks was unveiled.

headline: Weiner Jolts Mayor’s Race by Saying He May Enter It
text: John C. Liu was effusive in his encouragement, but offered this pearl of wisdom: “Just stop tweeting.”

headline: A Baseball Golden Age?
text: That’s the bold claim advanced last week by Michael Brendan Dougherty, who just took a step away from political writing to found a baseball newsletter (news-email?) called “The Slurve”, and who gives a great interview about the decision here. His case that baseball is peaking acknowledges the sport’s various difficulties (the Hall of Fame’s steroid problems, the pace of games, the Florida Marlins), but then follows with this:

headline: Leaked Report to Egypt’s President Implicates Army in Torture and Killing of Civilians
text: A leaked report published on Wednesday by The Guardian implicates Egypt’s armed forces of participating in the disappearance, torture and killing of civilians across the country during the 2011 Egyptian revolution, an uprising in which the military initially professed neutrality before President Hosni Mubarak was removed from power.

headline: Sleep Less, Weigh More
text: A new study suggests that adolescent obesity could be decreased if teenagers got more sleep, and the heaviest would benefit most.

headline: Beyoncé and Jay-Z’s Cuba Trip Was Approved, Treasury Dept. Says
text: As it turns out, Beyoncé and Jay-Z were never in much danger of serving the 10-year jail sentence, or paying the $250,000 fine, that their visit to Cuba last week supposedly might have cost them. Treasury Department regulations prohibit Americans from traveling to Cuba “unless authorized by a general or specific license,” and several Florida lawmakers have raised strong objections.

headline: Lilly Pulitzer’s Uniforms for an Entire Class
text: In the days after the passing of Lilly Pulitzer, who died on Sunday and whose memorial service will take place Thursday at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea in Palm Beach, Fla., the memories of her loyal customers and friends (the two were often interchangeable) flooded back.

headline: Jolts From Life: Christian Wiman Talks About ‘My Bright Abyss’
text: In “My Bright Abyss: Meditation of a Modern Believer,” the poet and essayist Christian Wiman writes about his religious faith, which intensified after he met his future wife and then intensified again when he was afflicted with a rare type of cancer at the age of 39. In his review, Dwight Garner called it a “slim and simmering book” that “works both sides of the tracks — the intellectual and the mystical — in its considerations of faith.” In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Wiman discussed why he’s a Christian, the writers who mean the most to him, the state of his health and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Scouting Report
text: Even if you’re not Coachella bound, the Los Angeles-based designer Cynthia Vincent has stocked her Elizabeth Street store with festival-ready wares that include silk ikat shorts ($198) and embroidered ankle boots ($374). They will look equally cool in the suddenly hot city as they will in Indio, Calif. At 253 Elizabeth Street, (646) 707-3830.

headline: T Salone Party
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Ex-SAC Trader Gets Court Permission for African Honeymoon
text: Donald Longueuil, a former employee of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors, has big for plans when he gets out of prison.

headline: Budget Embodies Obama’s Vision for Remaking Economy
text: President Obama used the first budget of his second term to sketch out his vision for an economy with more lasting economic growth and less income inequality than the country has experienced in more than a decade.

headline: Looking Into the Decline in African-American Players
text: Every player in the major leagues will wear No. 42 on Monday as baseball pays its annual tribute to Jackie Robinson, who integrated the game in 1947 and whose life story will play out in movie theaters nationwide this weekend. Yet few of the players wearing Robinson’s number will be African-American, a trend that has grown increasingly troubling to major league officials.

headline: Scene City: A Party Warhol Would Have Loved
text: Shopping as art, for the New York Academy of Art’s Tribeca Ball.

headline: 12-Year-Old Building at MoMA Is Doomed
text: When a new home for the American Folk Art Museum opened on West 53d Street in Manhattan in 2001 it was hailed as a harbinger of hope for the city after the Sept. 11 attacks and praised for its bold architecture.

headline: Questions on a Study of the Cost of Federal Regulation
text: In late March, Representative Tammy Duckworth, a Democrat from Illinois, announced a new bill promising regulatory relief to small businesses. But what caught The Agenda’s eye was Ms. Duckworth’s justification for the legislation. “For businesses with less than 20 employees,” she said in the press release, “the annual cost of federal regulation can be over $10,000 per worker.”

headline: China’s Actions in Flu Cases Draw Critics
text: HONG KONG — Of all the mysteries surrounding the emergence of a new and deadly strain of avian influenza around Shanghai, one of the biggest is why China’s hundreds of medical and veterinary labs did not spot the problem sooner — or if they did, why it was not disclosed.

headline: A Budget Focus on Inequality
text: The great economic focus of the White House, the financial crisis and recession aside, has been inequality.

headline: Cooking Onion Tart and Asparagus
text: Julia Moskin makes two recipes from Deborah Madison’s new cookbook, “Vegetable Literacy”: fragrant onion tart and asparagus with salsa verde and scarlet onions.

headline: Evidence a Reporter Was More Than a One-Story Wonder
text: McCandlish Phillips, the masterly former New York Times reporter who died on Tuesday, was about a lot more than exposing a Jewish-born Ku Klux Klansman, although that is what he is often remembered for. His deceptively simple-sounding declarative voice could make just about any subject seem irresistibly droll.

headline: How to Lighten the Crush of E-Mail
text: E-mail is  the worst. Between alerts from Facebook, newsletters from Groupon, reply-all e-mail chains, work brainstorming sessions and social coordinating, the in-box becomes a daunting pit of quicksand. At a certain point, even the most dogged among us give up.

headline: Calculating the Cost of Revenge: The Price Is Always High
text: How can an art form be updated while maintaining its integrity? That’s the challenge when staging traditional dance for modern audiences. Sophiline Cheam Shapiro, the choreographer and director of Khmer Arts Ensemble, succeeds at this more than most. “A Bend in the River,” performed by an all-female cast at the Joyce Theater, isn’t flawless. Yet in it Ms. Shapiro peels back a layer of Cambodian classical dance — liberating the movement from heavy costuming — and shows the potential of its undulating flow.

headline: Independent Spirit
text: With her eye for the unusual, the ancient and the brightly colored, Irene Silvagni orchestrates her Provencal retreat into a wonderfully imperfect harmony.

headline: A Venture Capital Partnership for Google Glass Apps
text: Three prominent venture capital funds want software developers to know they are on the hunt for apps and software for Google Glass, the company’s Internet-connected glasses.

headline: 2 Investors Give $35 Million to Brown
text: Brown University has some well-placed friends in Silicon Valley.

headline: Spinning Her Brand of Mysticism and Moves
text: What is Sufi Kathak? As the Indian dancer Manjari Chaturvedi made abundantly clear during her New York debut at Symphony Space on Tuesday, Sufi Kathak is a dance style invented by Manjari Chaturvedi. It borrows from Kathak, an Indian classical dance with both Hindu and Muslim roots, to express the mysticism of Sufi poetry and music.

headline: Goldman Reaches Deal to Let C.E.O. Be Chairman
text: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive and chairman of Goldman Sachs, is keeping both of those roles.

headline: Bluegrass and Jazz, Meeting in More Than the Middle
text: Chris Thile and Brad Mehldau come from different worlds but the same species, and whatever feels unlikely about their pairing is eclipsed by what feels perfectly natural. Mr. Thile, the mandolinist and singer with Punch Brothers, is a progressive-bluegrass pacesetter; Mr. Mehldau is the most influential jazz pianist of the last 20 years. Both are team players who can still give the impression of aesthetic self-containment. Both love Bach and the Beatles, and both have developed fan bases bigger and broader (and younger) than their genre silos can accommodate.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Sweetens T-Mobile Bid for MetroPCS
text: 6:07 p.m. | Updated

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iran and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Iran, Pakistan, Gaza City and Kashmir.

headline: Making the American Dream a Two-Week Endeavor
text: “The Moment,” a new reality series on USA in which people are given the chance to try out for the dream job they thought had passed them by, wants us to root for the weekly hopeful, of course. But here’s the thing: Success for those people would mean that the Western educational and economic systems are giant houses of cards and that everything we have come to believe about how the socio-economic structure ought to work is a lie.

headline: Man With Ties to Karzai Dies in a Military Raid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A special operations raid meant to disrupt a Taliban arms operation in southern Afghanistan ended in the death of a man with family ties to the Afghan president’s inner circle, leading to tensions between regional officials and the military, officials say.

headline: Tour Bus Rolls On, Newbies Included
text: Despite one of music’s most positive names the veteran quintet Yes has seen more than its share of turbulence and rivalries over a life span that has now reached its 45th year. A hard-touring institution, the current Yes came to the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night for a show comprising three of its most durable albums: all from the 1970s, each played from start to finish.

headline: Building Numerical Literacy in the Very Young
text: My children adore tablets and they’re now so accustomed to touch screens that their fingerprints can be seen on my TV set when they forget it doesn’t work that way. But my wife and I are careful about the apps they can use. Although we’ve installed a few that are purely games, there are many inspiring educational apps that are just as much fun. Their numeracy skills have definitely been helped by the counting and math apps.

headline: Heeding Between the Lines
text: The jazz drummer Jeff Ballard’s new band, Fairgrounds, makes the sound of between and among. It’s somewhere between a trio and a quintet; among free play and funk and mainstream jazz models of the ’50s and ’60s; between acoustic and electric; among flowing and limpid and fractured phrasing.

headline: The 2014 Maserati Ghibli Aims to Be a 5 Series Fighter
text: Automotive conglomerates can produce the strangest things, like, say, a diesel-powered Maserati. The company released the first official photos Monday of the four-door 2014 Ghibli sedan, which will be introduced at the Shanghai Motor Show next week.

headline: The Mezzo-Soprano’s Guide to Bilingual Education
text: The two halves of the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard’s recital on Tuesday evening at Zankel Hall reflected the two sides of her ancestry. Her mother is Argentine and her father is from the United States, so before intermission she sang Spanish songs and after it American ones, including new pieces by Jennifer Higdon, Glen Roven and Ben Moore.

headline: This Week’s Links: HTML5 Dev Conf Edition
text: 12:18 p.m. | Updated  A few of the videos are now available.Last week, I attended the HTML5 Dev Conf in San Francisco. Overall the event was quite illuminating; I got a strong sense of where the web development community sees itself, and where it would like to go. This week’s links are to slides of talks I heard, as well as some I couldn’t attend but heard good things about. This is by no means an exhaustive list. (A few of the videos are now available; look for more on the HTML5 Dev Conf video page.)

headline: I Went to a Movie and an Art Exhibition Broke Out
text: Cultural events are reaching ever-wider audiences through various conduits these days, including HD simulcasts and screenings of operas and plays in movie theaters. Last year an art exhibition received this treatment for the first time. The result was “Leonardo Live,” an HD film tour of the acclaimed (and thronged) exhibition “Leonardo da Vinci: Painter in the Court of Milan,” a blockbuster at the National Gallery in London. It was directed by the documentary maker Phil Grabsky.

headline: At Howard University, Rand Paul Argues Republican Case to Black Voters
text: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky stepped inside an auditorium at Howard University’s School of Business on Wednesday to deliver a message to young black voters: the Republican Party wants you back.

headline: Unsealed Indictment of Nelson L. Castro
text: Read the unsealed indictment of Nelson L. Castro.

headline: Facebook Refines Ad Targeting
text: Bought granola at the supermarket lately? Expect to see an ad soon on your Facebook page for something that fits your granola-buying profile.

headline: U.S. Efforts to Regulate Consultants Face Big Obstacles
text: Federal regulators are facing pressure from Capitol Hill to rein in a multibillion-dollar consulting industry after the companies stumbled during their recent review of mortgage foreclosure abuses. But the efforts could be stymied, given regulators’ close ties to consultants and limited legal authority to penalize them.

headline: Tightrope Artist Reveals Tricks (No Craning of Necks Required)
text: This time, Philippe Petit was only a couple of feet off the ground.

headline: An Easy Chair (Accent on Easy)
text: The latest collaboration between the Denmark-based manufacturer Fritz Hansen and the Spanish designer Jaime Hayon is an easy chair with serene lines and a name (Ro) that means tranquillity in Danish. Mr. Hayon was asked to create a piece for relaxation and reflection; he started by thinking about the shape of the human body.

headline: Sales at Future Perfect, Canvas and Others
text: Furniture, rugs and home accessories are up to 70 percent off at the Future Perfect, through April 21 (the Oscar armchair by Matthew Hilton for SCP, usually $4,288, is $3,064; the Nos Da Arthur pouffe by Donna Wilson, usually $783, is $392); 115 North Sixth Street (Berry Street), Brooklyn, (718) 599-6278, thefutureperfect.com.

headline: What’s Wrong With the Chapter 14 Proposal
text: On Thursday, I am speaking at New York University’s Stern School of Business on a panel on Dodd-Frank’s orderly liquidation authority. It seemed like an appropriate time to discuss why, although I’m no huge fan of the authority, I also have my doubts about its leading alternative.

headline: A New Spirit in the Material World
text: Trained in Japan, England and Guatemala, Hiroko Takeda, the Brooklyn-based textile artist, is not easily characterized as modern, classic or futurist. Her collection, which intermingles silk and metal, mohair and linen, is all that and more. Whether weaving a throw on a traditional loom or knitting a huge architectural commission in black metallic thread, Ms. Takeda experiments with color, texture and technique. After working for storied textile firms in Tokyo, Kyoto and New York, she struck out on her own in 2010. Since then, Calvin Klein Home, Urban Zen and Christian Dior have commissioned one-of-a-kind pieces as artwork for their stores. Custom fabrics can cost $200 to $600 a yard, not including setup fees, and a 75-by-25-inch panel of her intricate Giant Waffle Cartography series can be priced upward of $1,500. Information: (917) 676-8329 or hirokotakeda.com.

headline: Now Your Backsplash Can Move With You
text: Thin magnetic plywood tiles dyed to look like classic quilt patterns: that’s the innovation of Moonish, a company founded by Giovanna and Matt Taylor. The married couple, who silk-screen the 6-by-6-inch tiles in their wood shop in Greenpoint, in Brooklyn, had never done design work before. He is the lead singer in the indie rock group Mamal of Paradise; she used to work in the film and music industry.

headline: Post-Breakup Bungalow
text: A house and a marriage in shambles. At least one was fixed.

headline: Magazine Ready, Except the Marriage
text: In October 2011, our real estate agent sent us a listing for a short sale a block away from where we were renting. Considering the area — Echo Park, a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood in Los Angeles — I knew it was a good deal, on paper at least.

headline: For Baccarat, a Language Other Than Glass
text: The Brazilian brothers Fernando and Humberto Campana have designed luxurious furniture and accessories made with humble materials like cardboard, rope and even stuffed animals (though not all at the same time). And this week, during the furniture fair in Milan, they are presenting lamps for Baccarat that introduce bamboo and wicker to the materials palette of the French glassware company.

headline: A Creative Mind in Motion
text: It would be only a slight exaggeration to say that you can’t toss a meatball in Milan this week without hitting a project by Ferruccio Laviani. The Italian designer is highly visible at the international furniture fair, which opened Tuesday. Not only is he introducing lights and furniture for a passel of companies, including Kartell, Foscarini and Emmemobili, but he also designed their booths.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. I plan to reduce the clutter in my home by putting everything in the closet. Do I need to worry about what buyers will think of my overstuffed closets?

headline: Shopping for Brass Accessories
text: Anna Karlin, a British-born designer, says that brass is “blingy without being tacky.”

headline: Star Hurls Musical Barbs Before Venezuela’s Vote
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Political campaigns in Venezuela often can seem like a battle of the bands. Songs written for the campaigns blast from huge speakers at rallies and from the backs of trucks that drive around cities where candidates appear. Campaigns vie to come up with the catchiest tunes to energize their supporters at rallies that are often beer-fueled street parties.

headline: Brass Accessories
text: AFTER YEARS OF TAKING A BACK SEAT to other metals, brass is enjoying a newfound popularity. Why? “It’s beautiful, tactile and earthy,” said Anna Karlin, a British-born designer based in New York. “It’s blingy without being tacky.”
