headline: How to Make a Basic Studio Look Monumental
text: Just keep it simple.

headline: The Refined Studio
text: By his own admission, Paul Palandjian is a guy who has always been rigorously focused: Harvard-educated, a former professional tennis player and the scion of a family of real estate developers who joined the family business. His tastes were conservative, particularly in architecture. After all, he grew up outside Boston.

headline: A Thief’s Trick: Turn a Filing Cabinet Into Electronics
text: How many computer hard drives can you fit in one filing cabinet box?

headline: The HTC One Deserves Its Place in the Spotlight
text: Remember HTC? For a long time, this Taiwanese phone maker seemed to be on a roll. Its Android phones kept making gadget headlines.

headline: Time-Traveling
text: Visiting Sylvester Manor on Shelter Island can feel like returning to the 17th century.

headline: Life on the Plantation
text: SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y. — Imagine going to your great-aunt’s funeral and unexpectedly being offered an estate that harked back to the 17th century, complete with a plantation house where slaves once slept in the attic.

headline: Television, D.C.’s Dark Mirror
text: Modern series set in Washington, D.C., tend to present the city as a place full of reprobates.

headline: PC Sales Still in a Slump, Despite New Offerings
text: It should be one of the most exciting periods in years for people looking to buy new PCs, with a new version of Windows on sale and shelves full of slick touch-screen devices to run it.

headline: Tim Hetherington, in Film and Indelible
text: A new documentary by Sebastian Junger explores the life and work of his friend and colleague Tim Hetherington.

headline: Inspired by Brights of Spring
text: Metallic, frosty or pearly, colors come out to play on nails or lips, for a refreshing change of seasons.

headline: Spring Fashion: Take Me to September
text: A highly selective, woman-friendly, not too-too pricey mix of spring clothes you’ll want to wear.

headline: Spring Fashion: Picky, Picky
text: A critic’s practical, and ornery, guide to spring shopping (but don’t hold her to it).

headline: Suspect Dead After Taking Firefighters Hostage in Georgia
text: Updated| 8:18 P.M.  A heavily armed man is dead after the police stormed his suburban Atlanta home to rescue four firefighters taken hostage when they responded to a 911 call for medical attention to the house on Wednesday, officials said at the scene in Suwanee, Ga.

headline: Picky, Picky: A Critic’s Spring Fashion Guide
text: The other day I wandered into Céline on Madison Avenue. I was looking for spring clothes. Actually, I girded myself for the trip. Ever since I found a pair of black Céline trousers at Barneys with a hangtag that said I could always get that same style year in and year out, I’ve thrown my hat to Barneys, at least for Céline.

headline: NBC Renews ‘Last Call’ With Carson Daly
text: NBC announced on Wednesday that it had renewed its late-night show “Last Call” with Carson Daly as the host, confirming his spot in the network’s prime-time lineup for a 13th year.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,179 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Seeking Relief, Banks Shift Risk to Murkier Corners
text: Banks have been shedding risky assets to show regulators that they are not as vulnerable as they were during the financial crisis. In some cases, however, the assets don’t actually move — the bank just shifts the risk to another institution.

headline: Mets Still Haven’t Settled on a Leadoff Hitter
text: PHILADELPHIA — The No. 1 spot in the Mets’ lineup remained a revolving door Wednesday as Manager Terry Collins employed his third leadoff hitter of the week during the team’s series finale against the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Stan Isaacs, Cheeky Columnist, Dies at 83
text: Stan Isaacs, a longtime sports reporter and commentator for Newsday who wrote the quirky column Out of Left Field, died on April 2 at an assisted living facility in Haverford, Pa. He was 83.

headline: Cuba Returns Couple Who Fled With Sons in Custody Fight
text: MIAMI — A Florida couple who are accused of kidnapping their two young boys after losing custody last week and then fleeing to Cuba were brought back to the United States on Wednesday and arrested in Tampa, a rare moment of cooperation between two hostile countries and one that sidestepped a possible international custody battle.

headline: Photo Replay: April 10
text: Family and old friends gather at Augusta National on the day before the Masters.

headline: Tumblr to End Storyboard and Dismiss 3 Employees
text: Tumblr, the popular social blogging site, said Tuesday night that it would shut Storyboard, the multimedia news blog that it had created to report on its own community and that it had started only last May.

headline: ‘Swatting’ Hoax Tests the Police and Stars Alike
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — The 911 call came in late Monday afternoon. Two men with guns, one wearing a bulletproof vest, were storming the home of the actor Russell Brand, tucked away on a crest in the Hollywood Hills.

headline: White House Budget Curbs Some Deductions for the Wealthy
text: President Obama is no longer pressing to raise income tax rates on the rich. But that doesn’t mean he thinks the wealthy are paying enough in taxes.

headline: An Exhibition for Students Who Lost Art in a Studio Fire
text: A painter’s art is irreplaceable, so it was no surprise that 44 seniors at Pratt Institute were heartsick, many of them left sobbing, when their studios and the paintings they kept there went up in flames in February in a middle-of-the-night fire at the art and design school’s historic Main Building in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

headline: Foundation Releasing Aid to Families in Newtown
text: Facing complaints that money raised in the wake of the killings at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., was not being distributed promptly to the families it was intended for, the foundation charged with distributing the largest pool of aid said this week that it would distribute $4 million to 40 families directly affected by the massacre.

headline: Nearly 70 Years Later, a New Round of Auschwitz Prosecutions
text: BERLIN — They worked as guards at the Holocaust’s most notorious death camp, and nearly seven decades later they may finally be brought to account before a court of law.

headline: Tips Traded on Golf Course Led to KPMG Executive’s Downfall
text: 10:01 p.m. | Updated

headline: Miles Apart in Connecticut, Now Even Closer at Frozen Four
text: HAMDEN, Conn. — Yale and Quinnipiac are roughly 15 minutes apart, linked by Whitney Avenue. The universities may be close geographically, but that connecting thoroughfare remains their only real bond.

headline: Helena Carroll, 84, Actress of Stage and Screen, Dies
text: Helena Carroll, an Irish actress known for her stage, film and television appearances in the United States, died on March 31 in Marina del Rey, Calif. She was 84.

headline: Happiness, Beyond the Data
text: Happiness studies are booming in the social sciences, and governments are moving toward quantitative measures of a nation’s overall happiness, meant to supplement traditional measures of wealth and productivity. The resulting studies have a high noise-to-signal ratio, but we can expect that work with an aura of scientific rigor on something as important as happiness is going to be taken seriously. Still, our first-person experience and reflection can catch crucial truths about happiness that escape the quantitative net.

headline: After KPMG, Audit Firms Reconsider Procedures
text: Accounting firms are being forced to take a fresh look at their practices in the wake of an insider-trading scandal involving one of KPMG’s top auditors, as new rules requiring more transparency by the firms are already being considered.

headline: Loopholes in Gun Laws Allow Buyers to Skirt Checks
text: When Zina Haughton, 42, got a restraining order against her husband, Radcliffe, last October — she told a court that his threats “terrorize my every waking moment” — he became ineligible to buy a gun under federal law. But he found a way around that: he bought a gun from a private seller he found on the Internet who, unlike federally licensed dealers, was not legally required to check his background.

headline: Child Migrants, Alone in Court
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: In China, Feudal Answers for Modern Problems
text: BEIJING

headline: Yipes, It’s Congress on the Move
text: Wow, there’s a lot going on in Washington! Budgets are flying all over the place. The Senate might actually start voting on a gun bill Thursday. And immigration reform has now gotten so far that the House of Representatives has a bipartisan Gang of Eight working on it.

headline: At Augusta, Attention Is Back on the Golf
text: AUGUSTA, Ga.

headline: Hope Leaves the Shadows at the Capitol
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Mental Illness in California Prisons
text: There are about 33,000 mentally ill prisoners in state prisons in California, close to 30 percent of the prison population. The number of suicides in state prisons has soared in recent years, to about 24 suicides per 100,000 inmates a year, a rate about 48 percent higher than the national average.

headline: From Poverty to a Top-Tier College
text: Because educational opportunity has much to do with upward mobility, it is distressing that low-income students who qualify for top-tier colleges rarely end up there. Flummoxed by the admissions process and scared off by what they think will be unmanageable costs, many of these students settle for lesser colleges with lower graduation rates, less financial aid (which means more debt) and less marketable degrees.

headline: The President’s Budget
text: President Obama knew full well that many Democrats and liberals would be sharply critical of his decision to propose reducing the Social Security cost-of-living adjustment, one of the centerpieces of his 2014 budget, which was released on Wednesday. In fact, he was counting on it. He wanted to show that he was willing to antagonize his supporters to get a budget compromise, putting Republicans on the spot to do the same.

headline: Questions for a Young Immigration-Rights Activist
text: The video for “"El Hielo,” or “The Ice,” by the Los Angeles-based band La Santa Cecilia, was shot with a cast of undocumented immigrants, some of them leaders in the immigrant-rights movement. One is Erika Andiola, 25, of Mesa, Ariz., a 2009 graduate of Arizona State University and one of the founders of DRM Action Coalition, a group pushing for the Dream Act, a bill to grant legal status to unauthorized immigrants who were brought to the United States as children, as she was. Ms. Andiola made national headlines in January when her mother and brother were detained by Immigration and Customs Enforcement and then released after a fierce outcry by immigrant groups. Ms. Andiola, like thousands of others, has had her deportation temporarily stayed under President Obama’s “deferred action” program. She now works as an aide to Representative Kyrsten Sinema, a Democrat of Arizona. In Washington on Wednesday, before the rally for immigrant citizenship on the law of the Capitol, Ms. Andiola spoke with The Times. The interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Denouncing Serbian Tilt, U.S. Boycotts U.N. Meeting
text: The United States boycotted a United Nations General Assembly meeting on Wednesday, organized by the former Serbian foreign minister who is the body’s current president, that in theory was about the role of international criminal justice but appeared to be a thinly disguised Serb complaint forum about the war-crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.

headline: A Hobbled Messi Helps Barcelona Advance
text: For nearly an hour, the Barcelona fans at Camp Nou divided their gazes between the action on the field and the movement — or lack of it, really — on the team’s bench.

headline: In Political Campaigns, Do You Get What You Pay For?
text: Mark Hanna, the Republican Party political boss, famously declared at the outset of the McKinley-Bryan campaign of 1896: “There are two things that are important in politics. The first is money, and I can’t remember the second.”

headline: Move to Widen Help for Syrian Rebels Gains Speed in West
text: LONDON — A long-debated move by Western nations to expand support for Syria’s opposition gained momentum on Wednesday, with the United States poised to increase its nonlethal aid to rebel groups and pressure building to lift a European Union embargo on sending arms to Syria.

headline: Man Takes Firefighters Hostage and Dies in Raid, Police Say
text: ATLANTA — A man who the police said was in deep financial trouble called firefighters to his house in a suburb north of Atlanta and then held them hostage for almost four hours until he died by gunfire as the police stormed the house Wednesday evening.

headline: California Examines Puzzling Trend of Horses’ Sudden Deaths
text: Seemingly healthy racehorses have been dropping dead at an alarming rate in California, perplexing researchers and attracting the attention of regulators. The three-time Kentucky Derby-winning trainer Bob Baffert has had seven horses die suddenly in the last 16 months, necropsies revealed.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 10, 2013

headline: Excerpts From the Taxi Compliments File
text: Taxi drivers in New York City are known to generate hostility, disgust or, if particularly fortunate, indifference among New Yorkers. Rare is the case when passengers have something nice to say about cabbies. Rarer still are the people, so taken with their drivers, who call 311 to register their compliments. Yet a total of roughly 700 compliments were received by the service in 2012. The following is a sampling of some of the more unusual entries, which include a story about a lost engagement ring and the offer of a gift made by a late relative:

headline: Taboo on Speaking Ill of the Dead Widely Ignored Online After Thatcher’s Death
text: Even in ancient Sparta, apparently, people had to be advised to resist the urge to speak ill of the dead. According to Diogenes Laertius, among the precepts held dear by Chilon of Sparta was that “of the dead, nothing but good” should be spoken.

headline: Killings Stir Questions on Indonesia Military Overhaul
text: JAKARTA — Soon after midnight on March 23, a group of heavily armed, masked men forced their way inside a prison near the Indonesian city of Yogyakarta and summarily executed four recently arrived detainees with gunshots to the head.

headline: 'Accidental Racist' and Lyrical Provocation
text: "Accidental Racist," the new country-rap duet, has reinvigorated the debate on racism and pop culture. But should commercial music have this much influence?

headline: Food Politics Creates Rift in Panel on Labeling
text: The politics of genetically modified food has created a rift in a policy-setting committee of the influential Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics that demonstrates the difficulty in finding anyone — anywhere — who doesn’t already have an opinion on the issue.

headline: City Report Looks at Subway Link to New Jersey
text: The plan to build a new rail terminal beneath Grand Central Terminal had its skeptics. A Second Avenue subway has seemed an impossible dream for decades. So perhaps it is plausible that on some faraway date, a traveler will walk out of a Mets game in Flushing, Queens, board the No. 7 train, ride beneath two rivers, and get off in Secaucus, N.J.

headline: Gold, Long a Secure Investment, Loses Its Luster
text: Below the streets of Lower Manhattan, in the vault of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the world’s largest trove of gold — half a million bars — has lost about $75 billion of its value. In Fort Knox, Ky., at the United States Bullion Depository, the damage totals $50 billion.

headline: Obama Moves to Block Horse Slaughter
text: The Obama administration has included a proposal in its 2014 budget that would effectively ban the slaughter of horses for human consumption.

headline: Informer in Assembly, Accused of Perjury, Apologizes
text: Nelson L. Castro, a Democrat who resigned from the State Assembly to avoid prosecution on perjury charges, apologized on Wednesday for his misconduct, but insisted that throughout his time in office he had worked hard for his West Bronx district even as he also secretly cooperated with state and federal investigations of public corruption.

Corrections: April 11, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Something You Might Make
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — It has been unseasonably warm here in the Northeast (not that I’m complaining), so I’m very grateful for the fruity ADES Jim Hilger provides for us at 1 Across as we start out today.

headline: Judge Questions Legality of Fee for Bike Tour
text: An effort by New York City to charge a nonprofit bicycling group nearly $1 million for the cost of policing its annual citywide bike tour appeared to be in jeopardy on Wednesday, when a judge seemed unpersuaded by the city’s arguments.

headline: Bieber Backs a Debit Card for Teenagers, From Parents
text: JUSTIN BIEBER earned $55 million in 2012, according to Forbes, but in new videos for the SpendSmart Payments Company, which offers a prepaid debit card for teenagers, the singer talks about his modest upbringing.

headline: Nemesis for Knicks, Bulls Loom as Streak Busters
text: For 24 days and 13 games, across seven cities, two countries and three time zones, the Knicks have crushed every challenger, obliterated every obstacle, eradicated all doubts and left little to prove in the fleeting days of this revitalizing season.

headline: New Solar Process Gets More Out of Natural Gas
text: WASHINGTON — The Energy Department is preparing to test a new way for solar power to make electricity: using the sun’s heat to increase the energy content of natural gas.

headline: Carter Gets Peace Award at Law School, Despite Criticism
text: Despite complaints from some students and alumni before the event, an award ceremony honoring former President Jimmy Carter took place without incident on Wednesday at the Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School in Greenwich Village.

headline: Rand Paul Goes to Howard
text: The Republican Party is struggling with its future. Will it be a regional, Congressional party fighting a last-gasp battle for a shrinking base in a David and Goliath war against ominously expanding federal government? Or will it become a national, presidential party capable of adapting to a new American reality of diversity and expression in which the government serves an essential function in regulating public safety, providing a safety net and serving as a safeguard against discrimination?

headline: Mishaps Underscore Weaknesses of Japanese Nuclear Plant
text: TOKYO — More than two years after multiple meltdowns at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, a series of recent mishaps — including a blackout set off by a dead rat and the discovery of leaks of thousands of gallons of radioactive water — have underscored just how vulnerable the plant remains.

headline: Next on the List for Coney Island: A New Theater
text: A deal has been reached to give the revived Coney Island amusement area a new 5,000-seat music hall and theater, partly on the vacant site of a well-known terra cotta landmark, Brooklyn officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Shootout Specialist Comes Through for Rangers
text: A shootout goal from the player called the Norwegian Hobbit and a lucky bounce off an apologetic linesman helped the Rangers to an important 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: In Season of Goodbyes, Rivera Is Saying Thanks
text: CLEVELAND — In a room beneath the stands at Progressive Field on Wednesday, Mariano Rivera sheepishly walloped a bass drum with a stick, producing the sound that has echoed in his ears here for 19 years.

headline: Israel: Rabbi Says He Won’t Fight Plan on Western Wall
text: JERUSALEM – Shmuel Rabinowitz, the Orthodox rabbi of the Western Wall, said Wednesday that he would not oppose a proposal  to create a new area of prayer for Jews wishing to worship in a less traditional, more egalitarian style at a southern section of the wall known as Robinson’s Arch.

headline: Sometimes, Riders Find a Cabby Worth Praising
text: There is perhaps no more judgmental perch than the back seat of a New York City taxicab.

headline: Yemen: President Set to Purge Military Leadership
text: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi announced a purge of Yemen’s military leadership on Wednesday that could sideline relatives of his autocratic predecessor, Ali Abdullah Saleh, who agreed to step down in November 2011 but whose continued influence has troubled Yemen’s brittle transition. Mr. Hadi restructured the military in December, but the moves announced Wednesday were more far-reaching, removing Mr. Saleh’s son and two nephews from powerful security posts as well as from the country. Officials said that Mr. Saleh’s son, who was the head of the Republican Guard, had been appointed ambassador to the United Arab Emirates, and that the nephews had been made military attaches in Ethiopia and Germany.

headline: Obama’s Mix of Taxes and Spending
text: The president’s 2014 budget includes $1.4 trillion in spending cuts and tax hikes over 10 years compared with current policies.

headline: Egypt: Qatar Offers Support With Bond Purchase
text: Qatar’s government announced Wednesday that it would buy billions of dollars of Egyptian government bonds, giving critical support to President Mohamed Morsi as his government struggles to mend the country’s ailing economy. Sheik Hamad bin Jassem al-Thani, Qatar’s foreign minister, said his government would buy Egyptian bonds worth $3 billion and was exploring the possibility of supplying Egypt’s natural gas exports, to ease domestic shortages. Egypt relies heavily on natural gas to produce most of its electricity and neighborhoods in Cairo are suffering from occasional blackouts.

headline: China: Official Dies During Inquiry
text: BEIJING — An official from a Chinese state-owned enterprise died after an accident while being investigated for possible violations of Communist Party discipline, according to a report by China Daily, an official English-language newspaper.

headline: Mexico: Government Says Murders Tied to Organized Crime Have Fallen
text: MEXICO CITY — The new government here, which has complained that Mexico’s image has been sullied by persistent reports of violent crime, presented data on Wednesday that it said showed that murders related to organized crime had dropped sharply.

headline: Rift at Dietetics Academy
text: The politics of genetically modified food has created a rift in a policy-setting committee of the influential Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics.

headline: Health Care and Military Spending Bear the Brunt of Proposed Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s effort to control federal spending would require the largest cuts from the government’s biggest programs — health care and the military — while preserving or increasing spending on favored initiatives like early education, manufacturing and research.

headline: Once Again, Phillies Pound Hefner in First Inning
text: PHILADELPHIA — Jeremy Hefner stood on the mound here early Wednesday night, a succession of Philadelphia Phillies players orbiting him along the basepaths.

headline: Easy Hearing for Obama’s Choice for Court
text: WASHINGTON — Sri Srinivasan, President Obama’s nominee to one of the country’s most politically significant appeals courts, breezed his way through an uneventful Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday that ended with at least one Republican saying he would support the nomination.

headline: Texas Considers Backtracking on Testing
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — In this state that spawned test-based accountability in public schools and spearheaded one of the nation’s toughest high school curriculums, lawmakers are now considering a reversal that would cut back both graduation requirements and standardized testing.

headline: Muses in Motion, Captured on Camera
text: To watch a Terrence Malick movie is to be on the move. Forty years after his debut with a road movie (“Badlands”), he now makes truly moving pictures of a more restless sort. His characters and camera constantly chase and encircle one another, searching for some kind of connection — be it physical, emotional or spiritual.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Apr. 11, 2013
text: “I’m an atheist, but I thought that was kind of touching.”

headline: Nets, Beating Celtics, Move Closer to 4th Seed
text: BOSTON — The teams had not met since Christmas Day, when Avery Johnson still coached the Nets, and Rajon Rondo still led the Celtics. Boston embarrassed the Nets on national television then, and Johnson was fired a few days later.

headline: Rhapsody in Blue (and White)
text: Designer Juan Pablo Molyneux’s dedication to historical mastery and creative rapture resulted in a spectacular design folly.

headline: Bradley Finds His Footing at Roma
text: Michael Bradley has conversed in Italian with ease when handed the opportunity in the aftermath of matches in the Stadio Olimpico news media zone this season.

text: gambol •\ˈgam-bəl\• verb and noun

headline: Texas: Judge to Replace Slain Prosecutor
text: Eleven days after the Kaufman County district attorney and his wife were found shot to death at their home, Gov. Rick Perry named the prosecutor’s replacement on Wednesday, a local judge who has become the first black woman to be a top prosecutor in Texas. The new district attorney, Erleigh Norville Wiley, was appointed for a term to expire at the next general election, in November 2014. Ms. Wiley had been the judge of the county’s Court at Law since 2003, and had served 14 years in the Dallas County district attorney’s office. She will lead Kaufman County prosecutors at a time of widespread fear and anxiety after the killing of an assistant district attorney, Mark E. Hasse, on Jan. 31 and the deaths of the district attorney, Mike McLelland, and his wife, Cynthia, last month.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 8:30 P.M. (13) LA CLEMENZA DI TITO Elina Garanca performs the trouser role of Sesto, the devoted lover of the vengeful princess Vitellia (Barbara Frittoli), whom she persuades to assassinate the Roman emperor Tito (Giuseppe Filianoti) in this Metropolitan Opera performance of Mozart’s opera featuring Jean-Pierre Ponnelle’s 1984 staging. Kate Lindsey and Lucy Crowe (from right above) round out the cast as the young lovers Annio and Servilia. “In an alert, engaged performance with a well-balanced ensemble, what’s best in ‘Clemenza’ cuts to the quick with the elegance and efficacy found in all of Mozart’s finest works,” Steve Smith wrote in The New York Times when the production was revived in November. “Happily, it was just that kind of account that Harry Bicket, an English conductor closely associated with early-music groups and period-instrument players, elicited from the Met cast, chorus and orchestra.”

headline: Around the Country, Cries for Immigration Reform
text: Several tens of thousands of immigrants and advocates held rallies in Washington and other cities, as lawmakers continued to iron out legislation measures.

headline: Religious Remark Confirmed in Irish Abortion Case
text: DUBLIN — A woman who died after being refused a potentially lifesaving abortion even while she was having a miscarriage was told that her repeated pleas could not be granted because Ireland is a Catholic country, an inquest has confirmed.

headline: A Shot at Redemption Is Washed Away
text: CLEVELAND — Ivan Nova was looking forward to getting back on the mound Wednesday to help erase the memory of a poor outing in his last game, on Friday, but rain washed away the chance.

headline: Kaziranga Remains a Success Story, Despite Rising Poaching
text: Kaziranga, ASSAM — One challenge facing any visitor to one of India’s tiger parks is actually seeing a tiger. Often, people leave without ever catching a glimpse.

headline: News Quiz | April 11, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Carson, a Hope of Conservatives, Declines Speech After Furor
text: Dr. Benjamin Carson, a Johns Hopkins University neurosurgeon who has emerged as a rising star in conservative political circles, has canceled plans to appear as the graduation speaker at the university’s medical school after a furor over his provocative remarks about same-sex marriage.

headline: Story of Women’s Labor Camp Abuse Unnerves Even China
text: 8:50 a.m. | Updated BEIJING — In September 2011, 62-year-old Wang Guilan walked out of the Masanjia re-education through labor camp in China’s northeastern Liaoning province with a rolled-up diary, written on waterproof material, hidden in her vagina. Guards had searched her before she left but had missed the document, by a fellow inmate called Liu Hua, recounting the torture taking place in the camp on a daily basis.

headline: Philadelphia Orchestra to Tour China
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra is holding firm to plans for regular, lengthy visits to China. The orchestra said on Thursday it would tour the country from May 29 to June 10 and offer master classes, coaching sessions and workshops with young music students and local professional orchestra musicians. The orchestra made a similar visit last May, saying it would become a regular affair.

headline: In Assam, Searching for New Crops and Farming Methods for Depleted Soil
text: Boralapar, ASSAM — For generations, the annual monsoon cycle blessed the upper Assam village of Boralapar with ideal conditions for paddy farming. Moderate annual flooding of the Dorpang River, a small tributary of the Brahmaputra River, enhanced the rich, loamy soil with a yearly booster dose of river-borne nutrients.

headline: Captains Charged in Hong Kong Boat Collision That Killed 39
text: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police on Thursday filed manslaughter charges against the captains of two boats that collided off Lamma Island in October, an accident that took the lives of 39 people in the city’s deadliest maritime disaster in more than four decades.

headline: Military in Syria Is Accused of Massacre
text: Syrian military forces have moved aggressively to retake territory lost to the insurgency in the country’s south over the past few days, antigovernment activists reported Thursday, and in one contested town at least 60 civilians, including women and children, were killed in what the opposition called a government-ordered atrocity motivated by revenge.

headline: Filmmakers Capture Chaos After Airstrikes in Syria
text: Human Rights Watch accused the Syrian authorities Thursday of ordering “indiscriminate and in some cases deliberate airstrikes against civilians,” in a report released on Thursday along with a video summary that included dramatic footage of the chaos and bloodshed on the ground in the immediate aftermath of such attacks. According to the rights group, its report, “is based on visits to 50 sites of government air strikes in opposition-controlled areas in Aleppo, Idlib, and Latakia governorates, and more than 140 interviews with witnesses and victims.”

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 11
text: NEWS Of all the mysteries surrounding the emergence of a new and deadly strain of avian influenza around Shanghai, one of the biggest is why China’s hundreds of medical and veterinary labs did not spot the problem sooner — or if they did, why it was not disclosed. Keith Bradsher reports from Hong Kong.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 11, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Schools Put College Dreams Into Practice.”

headline: A Trove of Cubist Art Will Go to the Met
text: In “A Billion-Dollar Gift Gives the Met a New Perspective (Cubist),” Carol Vogel writes about one of the most significant gifts in the history of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: The Flaw in Obama’s Budget Approach
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Tim Hetherington, Indelible on Film
text: Sebastian Junger and Tim Hetherington basked in the celebratory spotlight the night of the 2011 Academy Awards, where their groundbreaking film “Restrepo” was in the running for Best Documentary. While “Restrepo” did not take top honors, it made a powerful mark as one of the few films to delve deeply into the lives of men at war.

headline: A Tale of Two Courts
text: ALEPPO, Syria — “In this court, we just fight Bashar al-Assad,” said Marwan Qaid, the gray-haired, clean-shaven chief justice of the Mohokum al Qada al Motahed, or Integrated Judicial Council. He drew on a cigarette and smiled behind a desk piled high with legal papers. “But in the Shariah Authority, they also fight the infidels. And in their eyes, we are infidels.”

headline: What Would Your Ideal Summer Camp Be Like?
text: Have you ever been to summer camp? What was your experience like? Will you be going to a camp this summer?

headline: At 11th Hour, China’s Censors Bar ‘Django Unchained’
text: HONG KONG — The American film “Django Unchained” was abruptly pulled from theaters in China on Thursday, its opening day, a surprising move that underscored the fragility of Hollywood’s evolving relationship with the Chinese movie industry.

headline: Geek Appeal: New York vs. Seattle
text: THE East Coast/West Coast rivalry is not just over hip-hop, food and fashion anymore. Now it has made its way to universities preparing the next generation of technologists: data scientists who can make sense (and use) of the explosion of information that is now produced by nearly every industry. New York and Seattle are already sparring over which will be the next hotbed, beyond Silicon Valley, for educating these analysts of the future.

headline: Part 4: Answers to Your Questions on Making the Final College Decision
text: The Choice has invited Marie Bigham, a former college admissions officer and veteran college counselor, and Mark Kantrowitz, a financial aid expert, to answer your questions about comparing financial aid offers and deciding where to enroll in the blog’s virtual Guidance Office, a forum for college applicants and their families seeking expert advice.

headline: Data Science: The Numbers of Our Lives
text: HARVARD BUSINESS REVIEW calls data science “the sexiest job in the 21st century,” and by most accounts this hot new field promises to revolutionize industries from business to government, health care to academia.

headline: Poll Finds Mixture of Support and Opposition for Bloomberg’s Plans
text: Despite forceful opposition from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, two-thirds of New York City voters support a plan to establish an inspector general’s office that would independently monitor the Police Department, according to a poll released Thursday.

headline: South Korea Moves to Defuse Tensions With the North
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea appeared to ease its stance on North Korea on Thursday by calling for dialogue to help defuse tensions, as its president moved to calm foreign investors whose confidence the North has tried to shake with increasingly belligerent maneuvers.

headline: What One Company Is Doing to Generate Sales Leads
text: Last week, I wrote a post about the analysis that we did of our sales funnel and the conclusion that we reached to open a lead-generation center in Pittsburgh. On Twitter, the post elicited a particularly important question: “How are you managing CPA with the addtl overhead?”

headline: Those Who Can’t Teach Block
text: MEXICO CITY — When the federal policeman approached the strikers, they started to sing the national anthem. “I am Mexican,” the policeman told them. “You are Mexican. But there are thousands of Mexicans behind me who just want to get on their way. So I am asking you to free at least one lane — just one lane.”

headline: Monetary Policy In A Liquidity Trap
text: I’ve made it clear that I very much approve of Japan’s new monetary aggressiveness. But I gather that some readers are confused – haven’t I been arguing that monetary policy is ineffective in a liquidity trap? The brief answer is that current policy is ineffective, but that you can still get traction if you can change investors’ beliefs about expected future monetary policy – which was the moral of my original Japan paper, lo these 15 years ago. But I thought it might be worthwhile to go over this again.

headline: Citigroup Sells Turkish Consumer Unit as It Pares Global Operations
text: LONDON – Citigroup agreed on Thursday to sell its consumer banking business in Turkey to the local lender DenizBank in its latest move to offload international assets.

headline: Zao Wou-ki, Abstract Painter, Dies at 92
text: Zao Wou-ki, a Chinese émigré who merged Eastern and Western aesthetic traditions in his abstract paintings — helping to shape avant-garde art in postwar Europe and attracting a newly wealthy Asian following that made him one of the most commercially successful living artists in either hemisphere — died on April 9 in Nyon, Switzerland. He was 92.

headline: A Scale That Measures Your Heart
text: The Quantified Self movement, which advocates measuring and tracking physiological data, has a new tool. A Withings scale not only measures your weight when you stand on it, but also your heart rate, and it sends the findings to a personal Web page and your phone.

headline: Global Fight Against Tax Havens
text: Governments are cracking down on offshore tax havens.

headline: Updates on the Gun Debate | April 11, 2013
text: With the help of 16 Republicans, the Senate voted on Thursday to clear the way for a debate on gun measures, including a bipartisan agreement on background checks proposed by Senators Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, and Patrick J. Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania. The senators said they were working hard to get the votes needed to expand background checks to online and gun show sales.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Bjarke Ingels and Colleen Atwood
text: A dashing Danish architect and Oscar-winning costume designer discuss Willie Nelson, luggage, champagne and bracelets.

text: Mr. Smith never goes to Washington anymore.

headline: Future Looks Bleaker Than Anticipated in Cyprus, Its Creditors Claim
text: ATHENS — After a chaotic month in which Cyprus was pushed to the brink of default and a possible exit from the euro zone, Cypriots knew things would get bad. But not this bad.

headline: Now You See the Risk, Now You Don’t
text: Banks are reducing risky assets to show regulators how strong they are. But sometimes the assets don’t actually move – the bank just shifts the risk, DealBook’s Susanne Craig reports. “As regulators press for banks to be safer, demand for these maneuvers — known as capital relief trades or regulatory capital trades — has been growing, especially in Europe.”

headline: Thursday Reading: Making That Final College Decision
text: More on making the final college decision, how to lighten the crush of e-mail, advice for couples about their sex lives and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Japanese Automakers Recall 3.3 Million Vehicles
text: Honda, Toyota, Nissan and Mazda are recalling about 3.3 million vehicles worldwide because the passenger-side air bag could deploy with too much force, sending shards of metal into the passenger area, the automakers said Thursday.

headline: Senior R.B.S. Executive in Japan Expected to Resign in Libor Scandal
text: LONDON – A senior executive at the Royal Bank of Scotland’s Japanese investment banking unit is expected to resign in the wake of a rate-rigging scandal, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

text: Marc Leishman and Sergio Garcia are tied for the lead after the first round of the Masters at six under par, each trying to end a long drought.

headline: For Swing-State Democrats, Political Liability on Gun Control Issue
text: WASHINGTON — The families of the Newtown, Conn., shooting victims who have converged on Capitol Hill this week made a point of visiting Senator Heidi Heitkamp, a freshman Democrat known for the “North Dakota nice” of her home state, but on the main issue that brought them here — limiting the capacity of gun magazines and universal background checks — she curtly rejected their pleas for support.

headline: Daily Report: Tumblr Shutters a News Blog, Not Yet a Year Old

headline: Twirling in Oklahoma, a Dervish for Love
text: In Terrence Malick’s films — he has made six so far, three in this century — it is usually possible to discern, beneath the blossoms of metaphor and the philosophical foliage, the trellis of a more or less conventional plot. “The Thin Red Line” is a combat picture. “The Tree of Life” is a nostalgic coming-of-age story. And “To the Wonder,” Mr. Malick’s latest, is a romantic melodrama whose major characters fall tragically and beautifully in and out of love.

headline: What We’re Reading

headline: ‘Good’ Patients, ‘Bad’ Patients
text: He was the kind of patient I went to medical school for.

headline: The Gun Report: April 11, 2013
text: We all know the terrible toll a mass shooting can take on human life: 26 people can be gunned down in a matter of seconds. But how does that compare to a mass stabbing?

headline: Options if You Can’t Pay Your Income Taxes
text: Monday is the deadline for filing your federal income tax return. What if you owe taxes, but don’t have enough money to pay them?

text: Q.

headline: Clive James: By the Book
text: The novelist, critic, poet and author, most recently, of a new translation of Dante’s “Divine Comedy” relishes his defense of Philip Larkin: “Spraying cold water on a witch hunt is one of the duties that a critic should be ready to perform.”

headline: Vonn Makes Her Masters Debut
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. – The Olympic ski racing champion Lindsey Vonn waited at a table on the Augusta National Golf Club veranda next to the putting practice green Thursday morning as Tiger Woods completed his final warm-up swings before his 10:45 a.m. tee time.

headline: Why Bayern and Dortmund Success Might Be Bad for Joachim Löw
text: Last weekend Bayern Munich won the Bundesliga title. That in itself wasn’t particularly surprising: the newly crowned Deutscher Meisters have claimed the so-called salad dish trophy 22 times, pushing their collection of national championships to a dominating 23.

headline: A Fine Feather
text: In “From Europe With Love ,” opening May 2 at the Cristina Grajales gallery in SoHo, the Paris-based designer Sam Baron reinterprets traditional European design with what he calls “a kind of French sense of humor.” He applies a champagne-colored lacquer to Louis XVI-style cabinets, and deconstructs the traditional process of painting these bisque porcelain birds made by the venerable Portuguese house Vista Alegre.Through July 12; 10 Greene Street.

headline: Where Do You Find Quiet in New York?
text: Where do you go to find peace in this boisterous city? With eight million New Yorkers and 50 million tourists a year all packed into 301 square miles, is there a special park bench, riverside fishing spot or underused historic site where you go to cherish the sound of silence?

headline: The Tiger Anole
text: An Anolis tigrinus moved across a tree branch in Venezuela.

headline: Obama’s Progressive Budget
text: The first thing to be said about the budget President Obama delivered this week is that, at last, he has one. Until now his answer to the brutal specifics of the Republicans’ law-of-the-jungle budget has been a slogan – “a balanced approach.” Now he has provided (mostly) hard, credible numbers to show what he means by that slogan. I wish he’d produced such a document a year ago and campaigned on it, which would strengthen his claim to a popular mandate. But give the guy credit. It was time to put up or shut up, and he put up.

headline: An Embarrassment of Anoles
text: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvard’s Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

headline: Image of the day: April 11
text: Gudi Padwa festival celebrations in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
text: WASHINGTON — Pressed by shooting victims and relatives of Americans slain in gun violence, the Senate on Thursday voted to begin an emotionally and politically charged debate on gun safety proposals as advocates of new laws overcame a Republican filibuster threat.

headline: PC Sales Data May Bolster Case for Taking Dell Private
text: It is becoming harder to believe that a turnaround of Dell  will be anything but messy – and shareholders may not want to stick around for that part.

headline: Immigration Bill Expected to Focus on Work Skills
text: WASHINGTON — The sweeping immigration bill that a bipartisan group of senators is preparing will include a major new merit-based program for foreigners to become permanent legal residents based on their work skills, including both high-skilled and blue-collar workers, according to people familiar with a draft of the legislation.

headline: Which Came First, the Chicken or the Wing?
text: Being vegetarian doesn’t mean you lose that desire to pair your sports viewing and beer drinking with some spicy Buffalo wings. Inspired by Mark Bittman’s cover article this past Sunday on healthful, veggie-friendly fast food, I spent my weekend hunting for the best vegan Buffalo wings in New York City.

text: See the interactive slide show

headline: Wireless Stereo That Really Is Stereo
text: The problem with most speaker docks is that the left and right speakers are inches apart in a single box, even fancy ones like the Bowers & Wilkins Zeppelin. They might as well be monaural. Not so the Soundfreaq Sound Platform 2. When you buy two of the wireless docks ($150 each) they recognize each other and become left and right speakers that can be separated by whatever distance Bluetooth and your room allow.

headline: A Seasonal Pattern to Mental Health
text: A new study using the patterns of Google search queries suggests that mental illnesses flourish in winter and decline in summer.

headline: Major Sports Leagues Prepare for the ‘I’m Gay’ Disclosure
text: With growing expectations in recent weeks that a gay male athlete in one of the four major professional sports leagues in the United States will soon come out publicly for the first time, the leagues have begun exploring ways to accommodate and respond to such a landmark announcement.

headline: Foodie Fare
text: Inside Cherry Bombe magazine’s first issue.

text: How can there be a Fleet Week without the fleet?

headline: The Language of Meat in a Vegetarian Butcher Shop
text: http://vimeo.com/63599404

headline: Speak Up, the Internet Can’t Hear You
text: The Internet might have looked very different than it does today. When Marc Andreessen and Eric Bina were building Mosaic, the browser that practically created the Web in 1993, they included the ability to annotate any page. Discussions immediately sprang up. But they quickly realized that the server to host the annotations would have had to scale to enormous size, which was not practical. So they took the feature out.

headline: 36 Hours in Taipei, Taiwan
text: Nestled in a river valley and edged by low, tranquil mountains covered in tea shrubs, Taipei is home to 2.6 million people. The cultural and political center of Taiwan, it flaunts its modernity in high-tech company headquarters, an ultraefficient public transportation system and bustling retail centers. Yet it also encompasses teeming street markets, polytheistic temples, recreational green space and other vestiges of ancient traditions reflecting generations of cultural influx from nearby and far-off lands. A haven for insomniacs of all types, Taipei is truly a city that never sleeps, welcoming residents and visitors to brush up on their history, explore their spirituality and, most of all, satisfy their taste buds.

headline: Touring Taipei
text: Scenes from the cultural and political center of Taiwan.

headline: Creating ‘The Glorious 54th’
text: “Does it not behoove every colored man,” James Henry Gooding, a 26-year-old free black man from New Bedford, Mass., asked the readers of his hometown newspaper in March 1863, “to consider … whether he cannot be one of the glorious 54th?” New Bedford was a wealthy whaling town with a large abolitionist community, but one where many black citizens toiled in poverty. With such conditions likely in mind, Gooding believed that military service provided the key to African-American advancement. “There is more dignity in carrying a musket in defense of liberty and right,” he maintained, “than there is in shaving a man’s face, or waiting on somebody’s table.”

headline: Climbing ‘100 Famous Japanese Mountains’
text: When Akira Chiba reached the top of Mount Yarigatake a dozen years ago and stared out into the volcanic gas clouds that wreathed its peak, it was the realization of what for some is a long-held dream. He had just summited the last of the 100 mountains listed in a popular book by Kyuya Fukada — a goal held by many Japanese mountaineers, including Crown Prince Naruhito. Reaching the marker, though, he was not overcome with elation. He experienced the normal exhilaration of summiting a mountain and a longing for distant peaks, one that he has continued to indulge.

headline: Gentle Treatment Yields Fuel Economy Rewards With Hyundai Sonata Hybrid
text: 3:38 p.m. | Updated

headline: Window Shopping With a Pop Patriarch
text: Pop Art is basically about two things: ordinariness and eating. It’s about daily consumption; the democratic appetite, ravenous for meat, sweets, life on the street, and getting more of everything, cheap. No artist cooked up a tastier version of the primal Pop recipe than Claes Oldenburg did in New York in the late 1950s and early ’60s.

headline: In Deal, 2 Men Will Be Jailed 30 Days for Beating Cat to Death
text: A father and son who beat a cat to death before leaving his carcass on a Brooklyn street pleaded guilty on Thursday to animal cruelty charges, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: Oldenburg at MoMA
text: Claes Oldenburg is the focus of two exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: The Library at the Public
text: Inside the discreet bar and restaurant in the old Astor Library in NoHo.

headline: Franco Biondi Santi, Brunello Winemaker, Dies at 91
text: More than 100 years ago, Franco Biondi Santi’s grandfather virtually invented Brunello di Montalcino, a Tuscan red wine that was little known until late in the 20th century. Since 1888, his family alone has produced it continuously.

headline: Does a Streak Portend Playoff Success?
text: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on The Times’s sports blogs.

headline: Tracking Hastert Rule Violations in the House
text: In a largely unnoticed vote on Tuesday, the House passed legislation without the support of a majority of Republicans, the fourth time in 2013 that the so-called “Hastert Rule” was broken by the majority party.

headline: Paramount Enters Resorts
text: The hospitality brand of the Paramount Pictures film studio has announced that it is opening its first resort, Damac Towers by Paramount, in Dubai, in 2015. The studio behind classics like “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” (above) announced last year that it would license its name to a Dubai-based investment group for its hotels, which will include private screening rooms and a library of Paramount films. Hotels are also planned for Brazil, Indonesia and other countries.

headline: Jay-Z Responds in Song to Critics of Cuba Trip
text: Jay-Z lashed out on Thursday at members of Congress who have raised questions about the legality of his recent trip to Cuba with Beyoncé, his wife. He released a scathing rap aimed at those critics and suggested he had been falsely accused of breaking the law because of his friendship with President Obama.

headline: Shh! It’s Time to Eat
text: It is forever after-hours at the Library at the Public, a crepuscular attic of a restaurant chiseled last fall from the upper recesses of the lobby at the newly renovated Public Theater, reachable by a discreetly bland stairwell. (Look to your left.) The lamps are tepid, verging on gaslight, barely adequate for reading the menu, let alone one of the books lodged at calculated intervals along the walls.

headline: The Problem With Investment Banks, as Seen By a Bank
text: LONDON – As Jamie Dimon puts the final touches on JPMorgan Chase’s latest earnings report, scheduled to be published on Friday, the bank’s own analysts are raining on his parade.

headline: Why Am I Paying All These Taxes?
text: Baby boomers, stand tall! This is our moment.

headline: Education Life: Teaching the Techies
text: Data science is the hot new pursuit in higher education, a field spawned by the enormous amounts of data that modern technologies create — be it about the online behavior of Facebook users, tissue samples of cancer patients or crime in cities. Data scientists crunch the data, use mathematical models to analyze it, create narratives or visualizations to explain it, then suggest how to use the information to make decisions.

headline: How to Value Bausch & Lomb
text: The mooted value for Bausch & Lomb needs to be re-examined through fresh lenses. The private equity firm Warburg Pincus bought the eye care company for $3.7 billion at the peak of the buyout boom and has been reportedly seeking a valuation of up to $10 billion. Even after cleaning up problems with recalls and accounting, Bausch & Lomb isn’t worth a big premium to other similar companies. A figure like $8 billion makes more sense.

text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Investigation of 1984 Sikh Massacre Continues in India
text: Laying blame for the 1984 massacre of thousands of Sikhs in India has taken center stage in Delhi again after a court reopened an investigation against the Indian National Congress Party politician Jagdish Tytler.

headline: A Start-Up Spirit, Without the 18-Hour Days
text: This interview with  Sabrina Parsons, chief executive of Palo Alto Software, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Jersey Shore, Damaged by Sandy, Is Ready to Run
text: When Joe Gigas, the executive director of the New Jersey Marathon, returned to his home in Long Branch after evacuating for Hurricane Sandy, he found that the ocean had ripped off one side of his house and sucked out the contents of four rooms.

headline: Fitting In at the Fitness Center
text: AT 5 feet 3 inches and 203 pounds, Julia Dalton-Brush can attest to the challenge of finding the right exercise environment. A New York makeup artist, Ms. Dalton-Brush recently started a Web site, fit-journey.com, geared to those who are considerably overweight or new to gym workouts.

headline: Humble Paella
text: I was once accused by Catalans near Valencia — which is the home of paella — of knowing nothing whatsoever about paella, and of making at best what they called “arroz con cosas”: rice with things.

headline: Hedge Funds Drop Campaign Against T-Mobile’s Bid for MetroPCS
text: The most outspoken opponents of T-Mobile USA’s bid for MetroPCS are backing off following an improvement in the takeover offer’s terms.

headline: Nearly 400 People Detained in Immigration Raid in Russia
text: MOSCOW — Russian security services and immigration police raided a market in the center of St. Petersburg on Thursday and detained 378 people, many of them migrants from Central Asia and the mainly Muslim North Caucasus.

headline: Court Rules for Women in Western Wall Dispute
text: JERUSALEM — In the latest twist in the struggle for the character of the Western Wall, a magistrates’ court here ruled on Thursday that five women who had been detained at the Jewish holy site that morning for wearing prayer shawls and singing aloud were not disturbing public order, as the police had asserted.

headline: Celebrating for Longer Than 15 Minutes
text: Andy Warhol said that an artist is somebody who produces things that people don’t need to have. He also said that good business is the best art. Both ideas were in play Monday night at the New York Academy of Art, the graduate school he helped found in 1982. For its annual Tribeca Ball, about 800 guests stormed the school’s five floors, throwing down Champagne and opinions about the work of 110 students on display.

headline: Labor Board Complaining Over Cablevision’s Tactics
text: The battle between Cablevision and organized labor has dragged on for months, punctuated by protests and lawsuits, in a feud that has been particularly nasty even by most labor-management standards. Now the National Labor Relations Board has accused the company of acting illegally to avoid reaching an agreement with several hundred unionized cable installers in Brooklyn.

headline: Julia Sweeney Sees the Absurd in Motherhood (and Shares)
text: Within pages of opening “If It’s Not One Thing, It’s Your Mother” by Julia Sweeney (familiar to me, and many, as a former star of “Saturday Night Live” and the creator of the one-woman show and memoir “God Said Ha!”), I felt like I’d made a new friend — a funny, wry, so-cool-she-doesn’t-care-about-being-cool fellow parent with a voice I loved. I asked Julia for permission to share some of the book (it’s below) and I also asked her (among other things) what it’s like to see the world through her eyes.

headline: Scheduled to Play the Twins, the Mets Face Snow Instead
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Don’t get the Minnesota Twins’ president, Dave St. Peter, started on the decision to build an open-air stadium in a city known for its brutal winters and fickle springs. The Twins benefited from favorable April weather in their first three seasons at Target Field, but St. Peter figured they were due for a problem.

headline: Russia Skips Hybrids in Push for Cars Using Natural Gas
text: MOSCOW — Igor A. Samarsky of the southern Russian city of Krasnodar gets fuel economy on his 1998 Lada sedan that would make a Prius owner green with environmental envy.

headline: New Yorkers Brace for Cuts in Unemployment Benefits
text: Federal benefits for New Yorkers who have been unemployed for more than six months have been gradually disappearing. Now, the ones that remain are shrinking.

headline: Handling Nerves, Lynn Enjoys Strong First Round
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Minutes after his four-under par 68 made him the clubhouse leader, David Lynn said his runner-up finish at last year’s P.G.A. Championship helped him avoid any nervousness in his first Masters on Thursday.

headline: Lincoln Scribbled Here: Strokes That Fascinate
text: NOT everybody gets it. For some people old documents, however historical, are little more than humdrum records, created to be filed for reference and cited when necessary, the documentary backdrop of grander happenings, with signatures that do no more than guarantee their authenticity. And for those with that point of view, autographed items other than formal documents — say, the back of an envelope — are merely fetishistic totems, and perhaps a little silly.

headline: Getting Personal: Writing College Essays for the Common Application
text: In this lesson, students will explore the open-ended prompts for the 2013-14 Common Application essays through writing and discussion. Then, they will identify and examine Times pieces that might serve as “mentor texts” for their own application essays. Finally, they craft essays.

headline: Environmental Readings at Poets House
text: The Miser has never known quite what to make of W. H. Auden’s assertion in his poem “In Memory of W. B. Yeats” that “poetry makes nothing happen.” Did he really hold so radically modest a view of art’s potential? Or was he being slyly ironic, daring us to doubt such seemingly hopeless pronouncements?

headline: Officially, There’s Now No Chance of Hurricane Sandy Returning
text: There will never again be a Hurricane Sandy.

headline: When Independence Means You’re on Your Own
text: In late February, Lorraine Bayless, 87, died at a California independent living facility after an employee declined to provide CPR — for more than seven minutes, even as a 911 dispatcher pleaded with her to intervene. The incident was the subject of enormous public outcry and generated widespread criticism of the facility. But it also raises important legal questions relevant to older adults and families living in similar settings.

headline: Alcohol and Breast Cancer Survival
text: Alcohol consumption is known to increase the risk for breast cancer. But a new study suggests that moderate drinking has little effect on survival after diagnosis, and may reduce deaths from cardiovascular disease.

headline: Director Named for New Dance School at University of Southern California
text: Jodie Gates, a dancer, choreographer and educator who is a former principal dancer with the Joffrey Ballet, has been named vice dean and director of the new Glorya Kaufman School of Dance at the University of Southern California. Ms. Gates is currently a professor of dance at the University of California, Irvine,  and is the founder and artistic director of the Laguna Dance Festival in Laguna Beach, Calif. In addition to the Joffrey, she has been a principal ballerina with the Frankfurt Ballet, the Pennsylvania Ballet and other major companies. Ms. Gates will begin her position in August at the school of dance. The school was established in November 2012 by a gift from Glorya Kaufman, a philanthropist and dance patron.

headline: Clip: ‘Kon-Tiki’ (Norwegian Language)
text: A scene from the Norwegian language version of “Kon-Tiki,” with English subtitles.

headline: Knicks to Waive Injured Thomas
text: CHICAGO — The history of the Knicks’ transformative winning streak cannot be written without Kurt Thomas, although the conclusion to this breakthrough season most certainly will be.

headline: New Concerns From Germany Over European Banking Supervisor
text: DUBLIN — Germany has raised new concerns about a proposal to create a single banking supervisor for the European Union that could delay plans to help troubled lenders that finance ministers were to discuss here on Friday.

headline: Never Mind Facebook; Winklevoss Twins Rule in Digital Money
text: The Winklevoss twins, Cameron and Tyler — Olympic rowers, nemeses of Mark Zuckerberg — are laying claim to a new title: bitcoin moguls.

headline: Wine’s Leading Man Sets Down His Glass
text: To watch Jacques Lardière scoot about the cellar at the headquarters of Louis Jadot in Beaune, France, the crossroads of Burgundy, is to see a man in his element. With white hair cascading from his head like a puffy cumulus cloud, red pants the likes of which only a Frenchman could even think of carrying off, twinkling eyes magnified by spectacles and an ever-present smile, Mr. Lardière is a cross between a wizard and an elf, climbing over barrels and digging deeper into Jadot’s rich Burgundian holdings in a determined effort to explain the wondrous mysteries that keep Burgundy lovers so everlastingly entranced.

headline: How to Write a College Application Essay
text: Our friends at The Learning Network blog have just published a lesson plan devoted to helping students prepare their essays for the Common Application, which recently released new essay prompts for the 2013-14 admission season.

headline: Canadian Teenager’s Suicide Ignites Calls for Review of Rape Case
text: The recent suicide of a Canadian teenager has revived outrage that the authorities did not do enough to investigate allegations that she was gang-raped in 2011 and bullied after photographs of the assault were shared and posted online.

headline: Having Mom Do Your Laundry, to Save Money
text: When I was in high school, I visited France on an exchange program and stayed with a well-to-do family. When I returned home, I marveled that the household employed a maid who washed my clothes. My mother rolled her eyes. “You have a maid here who does your laundry,” she said. “Me!”

headline: Hong Kong Operator Makes Bid for Telecom Italia
text: BERLIN — Telecom Italia on Thursday said it would formally consider an offer to merge with a smaller rival in a deal that would make the Hong Kong industrial group Hutchison Whampoa its largest shareholder.

headline: Clip: 'Kon Tiki' (English Language)

headline: Here’s Hoping Understudies Aren’t Needed
text: Bang! Bang! The sound of artificial gunfire is not unheard-of at the theater. But the shots fired in “Bullet Catch,” a magic show written, directed and performed by Rob Drummond, are more unsettling than most. They come from what is presented as a real handgun, and while one shot is fired at a porcelain plate, the second is aimed straight at Mr. Drummond’s head, as a volunteer from the audience, wearing ear protectors and goggles, faces him from several feet away — as if participating in a one-sided duel.

headline: Keeping Score: Changing Coaches Changed Nets Late in Games
text: On Dec. 26 the Brooklyn Nets lost to the Milwaukee Bucks, their 10th loss in 13 games after a franchise-best 11-4 start.

headline: Cracking the Mystery of Here to There
text: WASHINGTON — If you successfully navigate to the coordinates posted at the entrance — 38 degrees 53 minutes 18 seconds north latitude and 77 degrees 1 minute 8 seconds west longitude — you will find yourself at the new permanent exhibition at the National Air and Space Museum, “Time and Navigation: The Untold Story of Getting From Here to There.” And if you then make your way through the 5,000 square feet devoted to this show, most of which is superbly executed, you will realize just how astounding that initial feat was: to journey to a particular spot on the globe, consulting, perhaps, no more than a pocket-size smartphone, without risk of loss of life.

headline: New York’s Longest-Serving Pastor Dies at 93
text: Msgr. Gerald Ryan, who began working as a priest in the Bronx in 1945 and went on to become the longest-serving pastor in New York and probably the country, died on Thursday at Our Lady of Consolation, a residence for ill priests, in Riverdale. He was 93.

headline: ‘Tuck Everlasting’ Can’t Find a Parking Spot on Broadway
text: With luck, audiences won’t have to live forever to see a musical adaptation of “Tuck Everlasting” hit Broadway, but they are going to have to wait a little longer for it. The producers of a new musical based on that Natalie Babbitt children’s novel, about a girl who meets a boy from a family of immortals, said that its planned world premiere in Boston would be delayed because there were no theaters in New York where the musical could transfer.

headline: Paris Judge to Rule Friday on Hopi Artifact Sale
text: A French civil court judge heard arguments for two hours Thursday and said she will rule Friday on whether a major auction of sacred Hopi Indian artifacts can go forward in Paris despite claims by the tribe that they were stolen and that selling them is sacrilegious.

headline: Citigroup’s Washington Push
text: Citigroup‘s chief executive, Michael L. Corbat, understands Washington’s importance.

headline: The Price of Gold (and Ron Paul)
text: The price of gold, The New York Times reported today, has fallen 17 percent since late 2011. Just on Wednesday, the price of bullion dropped $28, to $1,558 an ounce. Gold-focused mutual funds, which reached a peak value of $26.3 billion in April of 2011, have lost half of their value since then.

headline: The Roger Vivier Legacy
text: Last night Dr. Valerie Steele, the director of the Museum at F.I.T., moderated a discussion with the Roger Vivier creative director Bruno Frisoni and the Vivier brand ambassador Inès de la Fressange to talk about the release of a vibrant new coffee table book on the history of the storied French shoe label. Images from the new tome informed the talk, which took place in the Katie Murphy Amphitheatre.

headline: Google Introduces a Tool for Planning for Your Digital Afterlife
text: One of the most haunting questions facing Web companies and their users is, what happens to the stuff of our digital lives after we die?

headline: Bangladesh Police Arrest Acting Editor of Pro-Opposition Paper
text: CHITTAGONG, Bangladesh — The police in Bangladesh arrested the acting editor of a pro-opposition newspaper on Thursday amid strikes by opposition forces that have frozen travel in much of the country and that are crippling its economy.

headline: U.S. Embassy in Turkey Said to Be Targeted
text: ISTANBUL — Turkish police said Thursday that they had found evidence of a plot linked to Al Qaeda to bomb the United States Embassy in Ankara, a synagogue in Istanbul and other targets, from a raid on two houses in February, according to news reports.

text: ROLLDOWN STEEL MURALS

headline: Republican Effort to Unpack the Court
text: Liberals are tearing into a Republican plan to reduce the number of judges on the country’s most important appeals court, calling it a political ploy to keep President Obama from making the court less conservative.
