headline: Who Made That Lipstick?
text: In the 1940s, lipstick tended to fade and smear. Women were constantly checking their teeth for red marks and repainting their mouths. Hazel Bishop — a biochemist with a background in petroleum science — set out to solve this problem. Using the tiny kitchen of her Central Park West apartment as a lab, she cooked potions in a double boiler and compounded dyes on a countertop. Sometimes so much dust escaped from her experiments that the butter in her refrigerator turned red. Lipstick had existed for centuries, of course, but Bishop hoped to create a long-lasting version for the modern woman, one that would stand up to the friction of coffee cups, cigarettes and kisses. She hit on a formula made with lanolin and dyes that penetrated deep into the skin. To demonstrate its sticking power, she persuaded her neighborhood druggist to decorate his hand with streaks of her lipstick. As he rang up purchases, the red stripes stayed bright.

headline: Prairie Jazz Companion
text: A few years ago the jazz composer Maria Schneider traveled back to her hometown, Windom, Minn. She climbed a ladder with a childhood friend named Tony Thompson and found herself at the top of a silo. She looked out over the fields: acres of Thompson’s bean plants moving over and past one another in the breeze. Windom, population 4,646, is the seat of Cottonwood County, near the state’s southwest corner. The Des Moines River flows leisurely through it. The land is smooth prairie, in all directions. “The mistake people make,” Schneider told me about this flat place she came from, “is thinking that it’s flat.”

headline: Temple Grandin on Autism, Death, Celibacy and Cows
text: In your new book, “The Autistic Brain,” you seriously entertain possible links between vaccines and autism in children, links that scientists have vehemently dismissed.  Well, there’s only one vaccine that could possibly be a problem, and that’s the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine. Now that they’ve changed the vaccine, it has fewer antigens, and that would make it a lot safer. But with the old version of the vaccine, I have not yet come across a study that looked at regressives — when a child had some speech but lost it.

headline: Tobacco That’s So Brooklyn but Made in Belgium
text: We were somewhere around Barolo on the edge of the Italian wine country when my wife’s 68-year-old uncle, Dario, lurched forward in the driver’s seat, fished a small leather pouch from the floorboard and threw it in my lap. “Semwaz!” he cried, as if this were the answer to everything.

headline: Coping With a Neighbor’s Renovation
text: Dan Kramer found out his new neighbor was planning extensive renovations last summer when he overheard an architect talking in the backyard next door. Within a few weeks, the reality of how this project was going to affect him literally hit home.

headline: This Week’s Movies: ‘To the Wonder,’ ’42’ and ‘It’s a Disaster’
text: This week’s video includes reviews of “To the Wonder,” “42” and “It’s a Disaster.” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: Movie Review | 'To the Wonder'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "To the Wonder."

headline: Will Synthetic Biology Benefit or Threaten Wild Things?
text: Please look below for a “Your Dot” missive on an emerging force that will, in ways both direct and indirect, shape the face of what we used to call “nature” or “wildlife.” The post was sent by Cristián T. Samper, the president of the Wildlife Conservation Society, from a meeting held this week at Cambridge University to examine this question: “How will Synthetic Biology and Conservation Shape the Future of Nature?”

headline: French Senate Approves Same-Sex Marriage Bill
text: PARIS — The French Senate on Friday approved a bill to allow same-sex couples to wed and adopt children, leaving France poised to join the small group of nations that have fully legalized gay marriage, despite an unexpectedly vocal campaign by conservative opponents.

headline: In Search of Slow Lorises
text: Mary E. Blair is a postdoctoral researcher in the American Museum of Natural History’s Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, where she coordinates the Enhancing Diversity in Conservation Science Initiative.

headline: Movie Review | '42'
text: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "42."

headline: Focus on Dairy Farmers in Immigration Debate
text: PERRY, N.Y. — When the letter arrived at Jeff True’s dairy farm here in western New York, it was, he recalled, “like getting sucker punched right in the gut.”

headline: Movie Review | 'It's a Disaster'
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "It's a Disaster."

headline: Fewer Are Losing Their Jobs
text: The rate of layoffs and discharges has fallen to the lowest level since the government began calculating the figure at the end of 2000, dropping below the level seen in the fall of 2006, before the Great Recession began.  More people are leaving their jobs voluntarily and more are also being hired than during the recession, but those rates remain well below the previous peaks.  Rates of firings and layoffs are highest in the construction industry, and lowest in government jobs.

headline: HD Supply, Backed by Carlyle and Bain, Files for I.P.O.
text: HD Supply Holdings, an industrial distribution company owned by a group of private equity firms, filed on Friday to go public.

headline: Brad Paisley’s Accidental Uproar
text: New York Times op-ed columnist Charles M. Blow talks to Ben Ratliff about Brad Paisley’s controversial new song “Accidental Racist.”

headline: In a Rare Show at Radio City, Two Prizefighters Will Take the Stage
text: Frank Sinatra performed there; so did Rodney Dangerfield and Kermit the Frog.

headline: Chaos Assembled, Beauty Emerges
text: At the end of the second movement of Charles Ives’s Symphony No. 4 a tender melody suddenly erupts into bawdy cacophony, like a marching band lurching through a carnival fun house.

headline: Leading Off: A Baseball Brawl That Hurts
text: Zack Greinke, the right-hander who signed a six-year, $147 million deal with the Los Angeles Dodgers in the off-season, broke his left collarbone Thursday night when Carlos Quentin of the San Diego Padres charged the mound after Greinke hit him in the left shoulder with a pitch.

headline: Back Home in Texas, for the First Time
text: WHARTON, Tex. — This is the kind of town (population 8,832) where line-hung laundry flaps in the breeze, crows caw from 100-year-old oaks, and neighbors have you over for a Sunday supper of fried chicken and collard greens. Everyone knows everyone, so a stranger gets noticed, particularly a famous actress putting her hands in the dirt of a plowed-up cornfield.

headline: The Man Who Took His Life as a Dance
text: “Are we still shaking?” the choreographer Bill T. Jones asked, extending a hand to Dr. Oliver Sacks, the writer and neurologist. Then he chuckled and instead went in for a hug, parting ways with him after tea at Dr. Sacks’s Greenwich Village apartment.

headline: New Chamber Music From Lee Hyla
text: Lee Hyla: ‘My Life on the Plains’ (Chamber Works)

headline: Technology’s Impact on the Value of Financial Advice
text: WE use technological shortcuts for things from simple tasks like booking vacations and buying books to more consequential matters like searching for a new home or trying to diagnose our ailments.

headline: Gym, Tan, Laundry, Family, Talk Show
text: It could have been any house on this suburban stretch of Staten Island, with a well-worn basketball hoop outside and a sign out front warning, “Beware of Dog.” But here one wintry February afternoon Vinny Guadagnino, the former “Jersey Shore” star, was pacing from room to room of the home where he grew up, now the site of his new MTV talk show, as he awaited a visit from the pop star Kesha.

headline: When Shareholder Democracy Is Sham Democracy
text: Two weeks ago, I argued that it was hard to imagine a more compelling case for ousting directors than the one posed by Hewlett-Packard.

headline: The Gun Report: April 12, 2013
text: Since Roger Ebert’s passing last week, most obituaries have focused—naturally enough—on his witty, wide-eyed movie criticism. But in his later years he wrote on a number of topics, including gun legislation. After the massacre in an Aurora, Colo., movie theater, he wrote an Op-Ed in this newspaper arguing that there is no “easy link between movies and gun violence. I think the link is between the violence and the publicity.” He continued:

headline: The Coda of Shuggie Otis
text: This week the first new music in almost 40 years will arrive from Shuggie Otis, one of the more enigmatic figures in pop music history. The album, “Wings of Love” (Epic/Legacy), with 14 previously unreleased tracks, is being packaged alongside a reissue of his previous and most celebrated recording, “Inspiration Information,” from 1974.

headline: Common Core Practice | Pseudo-Academia, ‘Accidental Racist’ and Broadcasts in Latin
text: This week, our collaborators in New Jersey got playful with both their Times choices and the writing activities they suggest for them.

headline: Popcast: ‘Accidental Racist’ and the Possible Value of a Flawed Song
text: This week, the New York Times Op-Ed columnist Charles M. Blow talks to the host Ben Ratliff about Brad Paisley’s controversial new song, “Accidental Racist,” in which the central character — a white southerner — walks into a Starbucks and experiences a moment of clarity, or something like that, regarding the Confederate flag T-shirt he’s wearing. (LL Cool J plays the barista and de facto spirit guide.)

headline: Wheelies: The Fantasy Electric Truck Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Growing Up on a Musical Diet of Presley and Blondie
text: The Tennessee pop-punk band Paramore, fronted by Hayley Williams, is attempting a reintroduction. It has to. Its self-titled fourth album, just released on Fueled by Ramen, follows two years of turmoil in which the brothers Josh and Zac Farro, the nine-year-old band’s founding guitarist and drummer, quit. On his blog Josh Farro called Paramore “a manufactured product of a major label” and accused Ms. Williams of hogging the spotlight. She stood up for her band and its authenticity on MTV. (Zac Farro later said his brother had regrets about the post.)

headline: America’s Quartermaster
text: In July 1862, George B. McClellan’s Peninsula Campaign ended and Union forces slowly began their trek back from Virginia’s backwaters, stunned by their losses. But if it was a failure on the battlefield, as a logistical operation, it was a stunning success, one of the great organizational feats of human history, all thanks to one man: Quartermaster General Montgomery C. Meigs.

headline: In the Hytner Era, the National Theater Hit Its Mark
text: LONDON—At last, a date has been named. I’m referring not to the next general election but to a handover to come that may loom larger in the minds of culturally minded Britons. Nicholas Hytner has announced that he will step down at the end of March 2015 as artistic director of the National Theater, a position he has filled with considerable glory since 2003, over time repositioning the primacy of the three-auditorium complex as arguably the defining theatrical address in the English-speaking world.

headline: A Coffee Deal for the Long Haul
text: Bart Becht’s $10 billion coffee run has a dash of Warren E. Buffett about it.

headline: U.S. Penalizes Russians for Human Rights Violations
text: WASHINGTON — The United States imposed new sanctions Friday on about two dozen Russians accused of human rights violations, and Moscow vowed to retaliate as a fractious dispute between the two countries escalated further into a cold war-style, tit-for-tat clash.

headline: Rare Bay Psalm Book Goes on View at Sotheby’s
text: One of eleven surviving copies of the Bay Psalm Book — the first book printed in what is now the United States, and one of the world’s most valuable books — will be on public view from Friday until Sunday at Sotheby’s in New York, in advance of a November auction where the book is expected to fetch more than $15 million.

headline: Interim M.T.A. Leader Picked to Be Its Chief
text: More than three months ago, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority lost its chairman, Joseph J. Lhota, to a mayoral run buoyed by the subway system’s rapid recovery after Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The documentary “American Meat,” about the meat production industry, will open Friday at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street in Greenwich Village. There will be a panel discussion after the film. Tickets are $11 per person, and Chipotle Mexican Grill, one of the sponsors of the premiere, will hand out a free gift after the screening and at other showings over the weekend.

headline: As You Watch, Invasion of the Platforms
text: Visitors to “A Journal of Insomnia,” part of the Storyscapes section of the forthcoming Tribeca Film Festival, will set up an appointment and, at the agreed-upon hour, receive a phone call. They will then presumably stumble sleepless to their computers, click on the “Insomnia” Web site and interact with one of four characters featured in the festival’s foray into transmedia: the crazy-quilt crossroads of new technology, uncertain expectations and audience participation.

headline: Food’s Newest, Chicest Magazine: Cherry Bombe
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Florida; North Adams, Mass.
text: Solid Sound Festival, North Adams, Mass. After a one-year hiatus, this music festival, curated by and featuring the band Wilco (above), returns to the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art (MASS MoCA) from June 21 to 23. Throughout the museum’s 19th-century factory buildings and across its expansive lawns, about two dozen acts, including bands like Yo La Tengo and Neko Case and comedians like Jen Kirkman, will perform. A part of North Adams’s downtown will be open for camping, and $80 round-trip bus transportation is available from New York and Boston.

headline: Full Circle, Almost, for Real Sociedad
text: Fans at Anoeta saw six goals last Saturday. Two were scored by Malaga, a quarterfinalist in this season’s Champions League, but it was the four that were scored by Real Sociedad that will add to the growing sense of belief that echoes around San Sebastián these days.

headline: Mets Find Out They Won’t Have a Snow Day
text: 3:08 p.m. | Updated A Twins spokesman said Friday night’s game is on. The club is offering free coffee and hot chocolate at the Target Field gates to anyone hardy enough to show up.

headline: Jonathan Winters, Unpredictable Comic and Master of Improvisation, Dies at 87
text: Jonathan Winters, the rubber-faced comedian whose unscripted flights of fancy inspired a generation of improvisational comics, and who kept television audiences in stitches with Main Street characters like Maude Frickert, a sweet-seeming grandmother with a barbed tongue and a roving eye, died on Thursday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Guilt by Slippery Slope
text: One thing you have to love about the debate over gun control is the lack of inhibition. The anti-gun-control side seems especially willing to say ridiculous things, but their opponents aren’t shy, either.

headline: April 14 — 20
text: Baroque Ensemble, Back in Brooklyn

headline: Fifth Avenue Co-op at $25 Million
text: The eighth floor apartment includes a grand salon with design details reminiscent of a Faberge egg.

headline: A Grand Paean to Royalty
text: A fancifully renovated floor-through apartment dominated by a Versailles-style salon with a coffered 18-foot-high ceiling decorated with Fabergé-egg intricacy and a 40-foot-long wall of windows opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art is entering the market for the first time in nearly 40 years. The all-cash asking price for the five-bedroom four-bath co-op, which also has two powder rooms, four marble fireplaces, and a staff suite, is $25 million; the monthly maintenance is $9,750.

headline: Chocolate-Crusted Banana Blondies
text: Tired of banana bread and banana muffins? Melissa Clark presents another sweet option for ripe bananas.

headline: Cracking the Walnut
text: Nuts can add lots of flavor and crunch to your favorite dishes, and they just happen to be good for you. In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman celebrates the versatility of the walnut. As she writes:

headline: The Week in Food
text: Lots of meat news: More evidence linking red meat consumption to heart disease: Researchers have found that bacteria in the human gut converts a nutrient common in beef into a compound that might quicken the build up of plaques in the arteries. (Just in time, Bill Gates has a new site promoting plant-based food companies like Hampton Creek Foods and Beyond Meat.)

headline: One Man, Saved From Invisibility
text: “What do you do for a living, Jason?”

headline: A Muslim College Mixes Subjects to Achieve an American Feel
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — I was a bit late for my meeting last week with 19-year-old Mussab Abouabdalla, who I hoped would explain to me why anyone would attend Zaytuna College, an unaccredited three-year-old Muslim institution with about 30 students and not even 10 professors. I found Mr. Abouabdalla at Caffe Strada. He had arranged his books on the table as if to answer my question.

headline: Without the Fudge, Blondies Have More Fun
text: When I imagined a pan full of chocolate banana blondie bars, I could see exactly what I wanted. A bittersweet bottom crowned with a brown-butter, rum-scented, banana-imbued butterscotch blondie. Two distinct layers and a complex set of flavors harmonizing in every gooey bite.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Thank You, Roger Ebert
text: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott reflect on the life of Roger Ebert, the brand he created, and the effect he had on Mr. Scott’s beginnings as a film critic.

headline: Start-Up Looks to Make Law Firm Billing More Transparent
text: The world of big law has been buzzing with talk about billing, especially after a client of DLA Piper accused the giant law firm of inflating bills through overstaffing and  performing unnecessary work.

headline: Chávez’s Lasting Impact
text: Even in death, the former leader Hugo Chávez plays an omnipresent role in Venezuela’s presidential campaigns as voters prepare to elect their new leader on Sunday.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Two Thumbs Up
text: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott reflect on the life of Roger Ebert, the brand he created and the effect he had on Mr. Scott’s beginnings as a film critic.

headline: Caring for a Special Member of the Family
text: Basement, attic or back of closet: those three storage options, though commonly chosen, are not the best for brides hoping to save their wedding gown for the next generation.

headline: J.C. Penney Wins Ruling in Dispute With Macy’s
text: With Ron Johnson out, Martha Stewart is in at J. C. Penney, at least for the moment.

headline: A Dad’s Hidden Truth of Parenting: We’re All Clichés
text: Over the past few years, a new wave seems to be washing over the world: a wave of bellyaching fathers complaining about how hard it is to be a parent. There is nothing particularly original about these complaints. In fact, as in most things, women were here first. But when it comes to whining, we men are better at it, or at least much, much louder.

headline: Maria Tallchief, a Dazzling Ballerina and Muse for Balanchine, Dies at 88
text: Maria Tallchief, a daughter of an Oklahoma oil family who grew up on an Indian reservation, found her way to New York and became one of the most brilliant American ballerinas of the 20th century, died on Thursday in Chicago. She was 88.

headline: Fewer Americans Lose Jobs, but Hiring Is Also Down
text: AMERICAN workers are being fired or laid off less often than at any time in the last decade, the government reported this week. But companies are also less willing to hire than they used to be.

headline: To Celebrate a Landmarks Law, Planting Flags in a Tiny New York
text: David Grainger is walking on the water again. One foot is upstream from the Manhattan Bridge and the other foot is downstream from the Williamsburg Bridge, and he is reaching over the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway to plant a yellow flag at the intersection of Pierrepont Street and Hicks Street in Brooklyn Heights.

headline: DNA Project Aims to Make Public a Company’s Data on Cancer Genes
text: Anyone in the United States who wants to know if she has mutations in two breast cancer genes has little choice of where to be tested. One company alone has patents on the genes, and that company pretty much controls the market.

headline: Looking for Love and Lobster Salad
text: About the last place on earth a single person with no children would expect to meet someone is at a children’s birthday party 2 states and 178 miles from home. Then again, if by chance two single people should be at such an event, they would certainly stand out in the crowd.

headline: Jettisoning a Few Extra Square Feet
text: Nearly five years ago, Alyse Booth and Steve Lefkowitz bought a second home in the Berkshires, a house near a pond on four wooded acres.

headline: Immigration Compromise Leaves Out Many
text: The Times’s Ashley Parker on why a plan that offers a path to citizenship is a win for Senator Marco Rubio but a loss for illegal immigrants who’ve only recently arrived.

headline: Now Listening | Ra Ra Riot, ‘All I Fear’
text: The indie rock outfit Ra Ra Riot is no stranger to old-fashioned means of music discovery. After all, the group, which first cut its chops playing house parties at Syracuse University, gained notoriety only after putting in stints at CMJ and South by Southwest and garnering positive reviews for its tireless live shows. It’s fitting, then, that the band — made up of Wes Miles on vocals, Rebecca Zeller on violin, Mathieu Santos on bass and Milo Bonacci on guitar — should be fans of Record Store Day.

headline: In France, Where Brunch Is Au Courant
text: My wife and I darted over to Paris for a long weekend to visit our 21-year-old son, Peter, who is spending the semester studying abroad and absorbing the numerous cultural pleasures that Europe has to offer. Unexpectedly among those pleasures, he said, Parisians are currently obsessed with brunch, a bane of the New York food-obsessed, who writhe in agony over the popular banality of bad eggs Benedict and dreadful Bloody Marys.

headline: Looking Back at a Dancer With Fire
text: Images of Maria Tallchief, one of the most brilliant American ballerinas of the 20th century.

headline: New York City Unveils Parking App Pilot Program
text: New York City passed a major milestone this week, introducing a new app that helps motorists find and pay for parking using a smartphone. The pilot program for the app will be near Fordham University in the Bronx and will include 264 parking spaces along nine blocks.

headline: The Treasure Trove on the Ground Floor
text: New York is rife with urban legends, like the one about the nine-foot crocodile that lives in the sewers, or the one about the treasure buried on Liberty Island.

headline: What Happens if You Don’t Pay Your Taxes
text: People who commit tax fraud can face big fines and even imprisonment. Just ask the recently released Wesley Snipes, who had served most of a three-year sentence for not filing his taxes. The timing of his release, just ahead of the tax filing deadline, may not have been an accident; the Internal Revenue Service appears to ramp up publicity of its tax fraud cases right before April 15, a 2010 study found.

headline: Big Ticket | A Reconfigured Aerie, Sold for $16.25 Million
text: An indulgent and elegant apartment on the 42nd floor of the Trump International Hotel and Tower, which was reconfigured to a two-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath aerie from the original four bedrooms and six baths by the designer Jeffrey Bilhuber, sold for $16.25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Q & A
text: A Disappearing Community Room

headline: ‘Last Goodbye,’ With Jeff Buckley Music, to Open Old Globe Season
text: The Old Globe Theater in San Diego will open its 2013-14 season with “The Last Goodbye,” a long-in-development adaptation of “Romeo and Juliet” set to the music of Jeff Buckley.

headline: Video: Remembering Jonathan Winters
text: Jonathan Winters, the frenetic comedian who created many indelible characters and also had a nearly unmatched gift for wild comic improvisation, died on Thursday. He was 87.

headline: Remembering Maria Tallchief in Motion
text: Maria Tallchief, one of the 20th century’s most important ballerinas, died on Thursday at 88. Ms. Tallchief, a former wife and muse of the choreographer George Balanchine, was known for dazzling audiences with her speed, energy and fire. Here are a selection of video clips of Ms. Tallchief dancing.

headline: Jonathan Winters, 1925-2013
text: Jonathan Winters was a rubber-faced comedian whose unscripted flights of fancy inspired a generation of improvisational comics.

headline: New Flavors in a Newark Neighborhood
text: The Ironbound district of Newark is not the sort of place that outsiders flock to.

headline: Wasn’t It Summer Just the Other Day?
text: What is it with this weather? A warm January, a chilly start to spring, an early-April hot spell complete with brush-fire outbreaks, and now, freezing winds driving the rain into the sockets of your skull.

headline: Where the Rumble Meets the Road
text: Three Harley-Davidsons sat rumbling near the guardrail at a Yosemite National Park overlook, barely tethered stallions. One rider, wearing leather chaps and a stars and stripes helmet, laughed in the direction of our overloaded BMW R1100R, piled high with bungee-corded duffel bags and camping gear.

headline: ‘Get Back on That Steel Stallion and Ride’
text: Tales from motorcycle America.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Sam Tanenhaus signs off as host, handing over the reins to Pamela Paul, the new editor of the Book Review, and hearing from past contributors.

headline: Transcending ‘Idol,’ Two Roles at a Time
text: LOS ANGELES — Constantine Maroulis does not want to be thought of as just — his words — “that guy with the hair from ‘American Idol.’ ”

headline: Are You Ready for Some Futebol?
text: The banner-waving, anthem-singing fans of Rio de Janeiro’s Flamengo club formed a billowing mass of ruby-and — black-clad humanity. They moved not only in reaction to the ebbs and flows on the field far below, but also to the samba beat pounded out by musicians in the midst of the grandstand mayhem around me and my friend Doug. The bands had not stopped playing, and fans had not stopped chanting, in the 18 minutes since the game began.

headline: A Taste of Soccer in Brazil
text: As the country prepares to host the World Cup, see scenes from a sport that animates the country.

headline: Old Warehouses Go Beyond Storage in Raleigh, N.C.
text: A long-dormant area has started to hum with galleries and shops.

headline: New Interior Secretary Is Sworn In
text: Sally Jewell officially became the 51st interior secretary on Friday, taking the oath at noon from retired Justice Sandra Day O’Connor in the Supreme Court’s West Conference Room, one of two formal ceremonial conference rooms at the court.

headline: Two for Life, Following Their Own Destiny
text: Pat and Anne Chang will celebrate their 30th wedding anniversary on July 2, 2013. The couple live and work at Ramapo College in New Jersey, where Pat is associate vice president for student affairs and Anne is an adjunct professor from time to time. They met as graduate students at Columbia University and became engaged in a New York City subway station, which they wrote about in a letter to The New York Times in 1982. Our conversations have been edited and condensed.

headline: Barack and Michelle Obama’s 2012 Tax Returns
text: President and Michelle Obama released their 2012 tax returns.

headline: Cicely Tyson’s Trip to Wharton
text: Images of Ms. Tyson’s tour of Wharton, Tex,, the birthplace of the playwright Horton Foote.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Sam Tanenhaus Signs Off
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Dan Savage reviews “Does Jesus Really Love Me? A Gay Christian’s Pilgrimage in Search of God in America” by Jeff Chu. Mr. Savage writes:

headline: On the Market in San Francisco
text: A mansion in Presidio Heights, a co-op on Russian Hill, a three-bedroom in Lower Haight, a Nob Hill home and a SOMA condo with a balcony.

headline: In Mexico, Where the Waves Still Win
text: Planning a return trip to my favorite beach in the world, I was almost as apprehensive as I was excited. The last time I visited Troncones — a town of some 600 people pushed up against the Sierra Madre del Sur mountains on the Pacific coast of Mexico — was five years earlier. At the time, we’d been living in San Miguel de Allende, and we occasionally drove down with our two sons and two dogs. My husband — an avowed “non-beach guy” — and I had come to love this village of farmers and fishermen for its rawness, its drowsy authenticity.

headline: Sun and Surf in a Small Mexican Beach Town
text: Troncones offers gentle vibes and a dog-friendly atmosphere.

headline: Joseph and Jill Biden’s 2012 Tax Returns
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Jill Biden released their 2012 tax returns on Friday.

headline: A Fur Man, Known to Insiders, Adds Some Fun
text: A FEW TIMES A YEAR, Nick Pologeorgis leaves his family’s business on West 29th Street to attend the fur auctions in Toronto, Seattle and St. Petersburg, the home of the Russian sable market. His father, Stanley, started Pologeorgis Furs in 1960; after Nick graduated from Boston University in 1984 with a degree in finance, he joined the firm. His sister, Joan, works on the production side. Lately, if there’s one thing Mr. Pologeorgis has noticed at the auctions, aside from rising prices (they have doubled in the last three years), it’s the number of Chinese bidders. No doubt the two are connected.

headline: Looking for Isherwood’s Berlin
text: When Christopher Isherwood moved to Berlin in 1929, the 25-year-old British novelist could not quite bring himself to settle down in one place.

headline: Austria, Under Pressure, Defends Bank Secrecy Rules
text: DUBLIN — Austria will not yield to pressure to follow Luxembourg in dropping its banking secrecy rules, Finance Minister Maria Fekter said Friday, as she sought to portray Britain as one of the European Union’s biggest tax havens.

headline: Rights Groups, in Letter to Obama, Question Legality and Secrecy of Drone Killings
text: In a letter sent to President Obama this week, the nation’s leading human rights organizations questioned the legal basis for targeted killing and called for an end to the secrecy surrounding the use of drones.

headline: Twitter Will Introduce a Music Application
text: Twitter is an online service where millions of people go to chat. Now the company behind it is hoping that it will also be where they go to find new music.

headline: Near Cut Line, Guan Is Penalized for Slow Play
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The talk during the first day of the Masters was how the Chinese teenager Guan Tianlang seemed so far ahead of his time. At 14, he was playing with the game and the poise of a player twice his age. But on Friday, Guan was punished for dawdling, with a one-stroke penalty for slow play after the 17th hole of his second round at Augusta National Golf Club.

headline: Lessons on Bacon, Sex and Nixon, Not Available in a Sitcom
text: When Louis C. K. walks onto a stage in Phoenix at the beginning of “Louis C. K.: Oh My God,” his new HBO stand-up special, and responds to the crowd’s applause with what feels like a practiced bit of false modesty — “I don’t necessarily agree with you but I appreciate it very much” — it’s the only moment that feels inauthentic in the hourlong show. If he didn’t agree with the audience, would he have been doing this for more than a quarter-century?

headline: Welcome the Library’s Sleeping Lions: River and Dale
text: After a worldwide naming contest, the stone lions snoozing outside the Riverdale branch of the New York Public Library in the Bronx have been officially christened: River and Dale.

headline: Indentured Servitude in the Persian Gulf
text: DOHA, Qatar

headline: Green Light From Ivy League, but Mixed Signals From Stanford
text: The day I received a rejection letter from Washington University in St. Louis, I talked to my mentor, who currently goes to Harvard. He told me that it gets better after the first rejection.

headline: Rick Ross Apologizes for Offensive Lyrics
text: A day after Reebok fired him as a spokesman, the Miami rapper Rick Ross issued a statement apologizing for his lyrics on a song that seemed to condone rape, saying they are offensive, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Proving Its Depth
text: The Range Rover, subject of a complete redesign for 2013, still has the capability to carry occupants to places where most owners would never dream of driving.

headline: Yes, We Have Ripe Bananas
text: This week’s column comes from my being in a constant state of having too many ripe bananas in the house. It’s either that or having no ripe bananas at all. I can’t seem to get into a rhythm of acquiring just the right amount, which I suppose is because what might have worked last week is either too much or not enough this week. And so it goes.

headline: What the Brain Can Tell Us About Art
text: THIS month, President Obama unveiled a breathtakingly ambitious initiative to map the human brain, the ultimate goal of which is to understand the workings of the human mind in biological terms.

headline: Charting Vampire Weekend’s New Album
text: The New York indie rock band  Vampire Weekend will release its third album, “Modern Vampires of the City,” on XL on May 14. The artist Andrew Kuo breaks down two new songs, “Step” and “Diane Young,” whose video features Saabs burning against a Manhattan cityscape.

headline: Week in Review: From Banes of Zuckerberg to Bitcoin Moguls
text: Never mind Facebook; the Winklevoss twins rule in digital money. | An ex-KPMG partner is charged in insider case. | Seeking relief, banks are shift risk to murkier corners. | Ex-regulators are finding a home with a powerful firm. | A solution for Penney may be to sell itself, or some of its assets. | A battle is heating up over the fate of a troubled energy buyout.

headline: Goldman Raises Directors’ Pay by 500 Shares
text: Goldman Sachs directors are getting a pay raise.

headline: Raj Chetty Wins the John Bates Clark Medal
text: Raj Chetty, an economist at Harvard University, has won the 2013 John Bates Clark Medal, a laurel considered by many economists to be second only to the Nobel Prize.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Predictions: What Do You Think Will Happen Sunday?
text: On the season premiere of “Mad Men,” Don Draper showed up drunk at a funeral and his ex-wife, Betty, showed up brunet after a foray to the East Village. Though it’s a sure bet Don will be drinking again on Sunday’s episode (when does he not?), any guesses on what else will happen? In a new feature, here’s your chance to make your predictions. Check back next week to see how you did.

headline: Consultant Recants in Chevron Pollution Case in Ecuador
text: HOUSTON — An environmental case that has pitted Chevron against Ecuadorean Amazon villagers for two decades has taken another bizarre twist, with an American consulting firm now recanting research favorable to the villagers’ claims of pollution in remote tracts of jungle.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers:  Scott Snyder’s  ‘American Vampire’
text: The writer Scott Snyder seems to be making a home out of our hardcover list. This week, Volume 5 of “American Vampire,” about a new breed of bloodsucker, enters the list at No. 2. (He is also the writer behind the Batman stories at No. 1 and No. 8.) In this latest installment of “American Vampire,” Mr. Snyder has been blessed with two gifted collaborators: Rafael Albuquerque, the original series artist, and Dustin Nguyen, who illustrates a spin-off story included in this collection. Though vampires have seemingly given up their number one status in pop culture to zombies, Mr. Snyder proves there are still plenty of tales to tell about these creatures of the night. Mr. Nguyen lends his wonderfully expressive and moody art to an adventure involving the hunt for the granddaddy of all vampires, Dracula, while Mr. Albuquerque illustrates the exploration of all things related to Skinner Sweet, the first American vampire, who is more vicious and less bothered by sunlight. The only drawback to reading this book in collected form is that the reader does not get to long savor the cliffhangers with which Mr. Snyder ends most issues. (Click here for a profile on Mr. Snyder from Sept. 2011.)

headline: The Business of Being | India Hicks
text: India Hicks adds another facet to her ever-growing brand with the debut of her home line for HSN this week. The author, model, designer, hotelier and mother has curated a brand that encompasses both her English upbringing and current Island lifestyle. The daughter of David Nightingale Hicks, the famed interior designer, and Lady Pamela Mountbatten, India has been surrounded by style from an early age. From fine jewelry to home goods to tropical properties, T Magazine breaks down the world of India Hicks.

headline: A Rich Nod to Old Elegance
text: Few of the old-school Italian restaurants remain in San Francisco’s North Beach neighborhood — the kind of places where the waiters wear red jackets, the wine list is bound in leather and the menu’s size makes it hard to see one’s tablemates.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Serbia and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Serbia, Egypt, India and Syria.

headline: Adam Smith Hates Bitcoin
text: There have been many good pieces written on the dubious economics of Bitcoin; I especially liked this one by Neil Irwin. One thing I haven’t seen emphasized, however, is the extent to which the whole concept of having to “mine” Bitcoins by expending real resources amounts to a drastic retrogression — a retrogression that Adam Smith would have scorned.

headline: Someone’s Ruffled Her Feathers, and She’s in Perpetual Motion
text: At the start of “Kinetic Makeover,” the choreographer Milka Djordjevich stands with her back to the audience. She stands there a long time, in silence, dressed in a pink and blue top and tight sherbet-orange pants (designed by Reid Bartelme). Almost imperceptibly, she begins to sway side to side. Gradually, the swaying swells, her knees bending, her torso pitching, until she has rocked herself onto the floor in a seated position and turned her face front. . Her eyes continue to ticktock, left, right, left.

headline: Lessons in Domestic Diplomacy
text: I CALLED IT THE 7:42 P.M. FIGHT. It happened every night when my wife and I gathered to discuss the detritus of our lives. Who’s waking up early with the kids? Who’s going to take Grandma to the eye doctor? What do you mean you forgot to pick up the milk?

headline: F.D.A. Issues Warning on Workout Supplement
text: Certain workout-booster and fat-burning products, sold in recent years by retailers like GNC and Vitamin Shoppe, are illegal and may present serious health hazards to consumers, federal health regulators have determined.

headline: A Premiere, Shimmering and Spectral
text: The American conductor David Robertson and the French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard share a gift for devising programs that juxtapose old and new works in fascinating ways. So it was on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall, when Mr. Robertson conducted the New York Philharmonic with Mr. Aimard as soloist.

headline: Can You Say ‘Do It Again’ in Norwegian?
text: In January “Kon-Tiki,” a biopic about the Norwegian explorer Thor Heyerdahl and his perilous 1947 journey across the Pacific on a balsa-wood raft, was nominated for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film. (It lost to Michael Haneke’s “Amour.”) On April 26 the film will be released commercially in the United States — but in a version that is entirely in English, rather than in the original Norwegian.

headline: Same Scene, Different Languages
text: A comparison of a scene from both the English-language and Norwegian-language versions of “Kon-Tiki.”

headline: Lost Plenty of Pounds, but Not a Lightweight
text: BIG WATER, Utah — On the specification sheet for the 2013 Range Rover is an entry you don’t often see applied to a luxury vehicle: wading depth, 35.4 inches.

text: TESTED 2013 Hyundai Elantra GT

headline: With Land Rover Heritage, but Destined for Asphalt Jungles
text: The new-for-2014 Range Rover Sport made its world premiere in Manhattan on March 26, on the eve of press previews for the New York auto show. Though the city might not seem to be a Range Rover’s preferred habitat, the setting was entirely appropriate: the United States is the biggest market for the Sport model and New York accounts for the most sales of any city.

headline: Newtown Parent to Give White House Address
text: 6:42 a.m. | Updated  Coverage of the address is available here.

headline: Obamas’ Income Has Dropped, Their Tax Returns Show
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s personal income has plummeted in the four years since he was first inaugurated, thanks mostly to declining sales of his two best-selling books, according to his 2012 tax returns released on Friday.

headline: Australia’s Brand Name for Ferocity, Softened by Time
text: MELBOURNE, Australia

headline: Yankees’ Rodriguez Tied to Clinic Records Purchase
text: Former employees of a now-shuttered South Florida anti-aging clinic and others who had ties to it have told Major League Baseball that the Yankees’Alex Rodriguez arranged to purchase documents from the clinic to keep them out of the hands of baseball officials, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Colleges Struggling to Stay Afloat
text: STUDENTS piling on debt to go to college might attract all the attention, but colleges have been on a borrowing spree as well, nearly doubling the amount of debt they’ve taken on in the last decade to fix aging campuses, keep up with competitors and lure students with lavish amenities.

headline: The Faces That Would Be Mayor
text: Portraits of candidates for mayor of New York, photographed by The Times’s Damon Winter.

headline: First Tastes of the 2012 Bordeaux
text: PAUILLAC, France—I joined hundreds of wine buyers and critics for the annual tastings of the new vintage in Bordeaux this week. But amid all the talk of business, the wines themselves sometimes seemed to be overshadowed. So how does 2012 Bordeaux look?

headline: T’s Spring Design Issue
text: The actress Julianne Moore, photographed by Inez and Vinoodh, is the cover subject of the Spring Design issue of T, where we learn how the natural beauty likes to play against type. Inside: discover the glories of Lowcountry cooking in Charleston, read Nicky Haslam’s take on how good and bad taste evolve over time, and admire the rich tones and gems inside jewelry designer Marie-Helene de Taillac’s apartment in Paris. Other spots on this issue’s house tours: the Milan town house of the C.E.O. of Kartell, Irene Silvagni’s wonderfully imperfect Provençal retreat and the landscape designer Piet Oudolf’s lush home in Nantucket. Finally, take a look at a collection of “Great Gatsby” editions that offer an illuminating cross section of 83 years of book design. See all from the issue >>

headline: Injecting a Little Levity: Heaven With Rodgers and Hart
text: For some lucky musicians, like John Pizzarelli, work and play are pretty much the same thing. At any of Mr. Pizzarelli’s concerts, with or without his singing and life partner, Jessica Molaskey, Mr. Pizzarelli conveys a contagious enjoyment that transports you to a place where worries recede, and you can coast along with him to a jazz-pop heaven.

headline: Ah, Brains: To Eat or Not to Eat?
text: You won’t find Yorick’s skull in “Living Dead in Denmark,” the Just Kidding Theater Company’s antic production at the Gene Frankel Theater. But you will find bound human heads suspended on a wall en route to your seat. You’ll also find Shakespearean characters, men in drag, a villain called Lady Gaga and more zombies than you can shake a broadsword at.

headline: Bach Suites, Without a Break or Pedal
text: When Andras Schiff performed Bach’s six English Suites on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall, he played the first four — almost 90 minutes of music — with barely a pause. In an onstage interview after the concert, the WNYC radio host John Schaefer commented that it had almost seemed like an athletic feat, one both mental and physical.

headline: BBC Won’t Ban ‘Ding Dong! The Witch Is Dead,’ Adopted as Anti-Thatcher Anthem
text: Last Updated, 6:13 p.m. The BBC on Friday rejected loud calls to ban the song “Ding Dong! The Witch Is Dead” from its airwaves after the apparent success of a Facebook campaign to celebrate the death of Margaret Thatcher, the divisive former prime minister, by driving sales of the tune from “The Wizard of Oz” up the British singles chart.

headline: Think Positive, and Try Not to Burn Your Bottom: Desert Island Dos and Don’ts
text: Some shows come with a strong-sexual-content warning. Some come with a graphic-violence warning. Not too many come with a buttocks warning.

text: A selection of comedic moments from Jonathan Winters's career.

text: They’re still incredibly young — but awesomely talented, and they’ve gotten deeper since I first posted one of their performances:

headline: Play at the Charlottesville, Va., Regional
text: The most successful players at the Charlottesville, Va., regional from Feb. 25 to March 3 were Judith Bianco and Win Allegaert of New York City; Kevin Bathurst of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.; and Justin Lall of Las Vegas. They played in two knockout teams and one Swiss team and won all three.

headline: Former Credit Suisse Executive Pleads Guilty to Inflating the Value of Mortgage Bonds
text: A former senior trader at Credit Suisse Group pleaded guilty on Friday to charges that he fraudulently inflated the value of mortgage bonds as the housing market collapsed, becoming one of the highest-ranking Wall Street executives to admit to crimes related to the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Bequest to the Boy Next Door
text: Ray Knox still owns and occasionally rides the custom-made French bicycle that he pedaled from Paris to Athens in 1984, solo, when he was 25.

headline: High-Class Hand-Me-Down
text: Ray Knox was a high school senior when he inherited a 1966 Cadillac Fleetwood from a neighbor. Decades later, it remains a treasure.

headline: Looking for Green on the Big Screen
text: Now that spring has (finally) brought bloom-inducing weather to the city, many of us are turning our focus to what can be done with gardens and balconies, decks and window boxes and stoops. For landscape designers, however, the lens is always and everywhere open — even in darkened movie theaters.

headline: Editors’ Lab at the NYT
text: Next weekend, April 20–21, The New York Times will host an Editors’ Lab event. Organized by the Global Editors Network (GEN), the Editors’ Lab will bring together teams from top media companies for two days of working sessions and talks. Each team will consist of a journalist, a designer and a developer. The hack event at the Times building will be the fifth in a tournament series that began in Buenos Aires and culminates at the GEN News Summit in Paris in June. We’ll post details next week; meanwhile, you can learn more at the GEN site.

headline: Eluding Ennui and Bad Relatives
text: Repo Man

headline: Vying for a Spot on the World’s A List
text: SO NOW we know. After months of hype and speculation, the winners were announced last month. These were not the Oscars, but the World Reputation Rankings, “the world’s definitive index of academic prestige,” according to its publisher, Times Higher Education, a weekly magazine based in London.

headline: Answers: Astronomy
text: WHAT’S OUT THERE? JUST DO THE MATH

headline: Answers: Human Ecology
text: 1. c. Life’s boundaries are not always clear. One fungus occupies about 2,384 acres of the forest floor in eastern Oregon, the filaments extending along the root systems of trees. The Pando aspen grove, once thought to be the largest organism, consists of about 47,000 genetically identical trees on 107 acres.

headline: Trimming the Ivy
text: TOM HARKIN, chairman of the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, who has represented Iowa in Congress since 1974, has announced that he will not seek re-election in 2014. Senator Harkin, a 73-year-old Democrat, is an old-fashioned, plainspoken populist — the driving force behind the 1990 Americans With Disabilities Act and a strong proponent of reforming health care.

headline: Two, Three Essays? More Can Mean Less
text: DURING a staff retreat last winter, Boston College’s admissions officers decided something had to change. Although the college was receiving more applications each year, increasingly larger shares of admitted students were choosing to go elsewhere. Between 2004 and 2011, the college’s yield — the proportion of accepted students who enroll — had declined from 32 percent to 23 percent. Some applicants, says John L. Mahoney, director of undergraduate admissions, “probably weren’t very serious about us all along.”

headline: Technion
text: Technion

headline: The Technion: Israel’s Hard Drive
text: WHEN the Technion class of 1957 graduated, its members got together and wrote a letter of complaint to their prime minister, David Ben-Gurion, who was otherwise busy building a nation. “There were no jobs for us in our fields,” recalls Gideon F. Inbar, an electrical engineer who is now 79. “My wife kept saying, ‘Oy, things are grim, grim, grim.’ ”

headline: Signs of Easier Money for Mortgages
text: What was so unusual about Phillip Ratliff’s experience in getting approval for his first mortgage was that it wasn’t difficult at all — even though he could afford a down payment of only 5 percent.

headline: Embracing Technology, for Better or Worse
text: Paul Sullivan writes this week in his Wealth Matters column about financial advisers’ increasing interest in technology. He raises two questions about expanded use of technology: Will it help advisers do their job better? And will it be better for clients or confuse and frustrate them?

text: Here are six other YouTube

headline: E.P.A. Will Delay Rule Limiting Carbon Emissions at New Power Plants
text: WASHINGTON – The Environmental Protection Agency said Friday that it would delay issuance of a new rule limiting emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases from new power plants after the electric power industry objected on legal and technical grounds.

headline: A Savory Taste of the Pampas
text: The first empanada I ever had was made by an Argentine friend in college. That country’s version of the small South American meat patty features a substantial beef filling tucked into a flaky shell, and it was love at first bite. I’ve had dozens and dozens of empanadas since, made in almost as many styles, but it was the one from Gaucho Grill, an Argentine restaurant that opened in White Plains last year, that gave me the biggest thrill since my first.

headline: Seven Pinots to Pair With Duck
text: Many red wine lovers consider pinot noir and duck an ideal combination. And many fans of duck think the white Pekin breed farmed on Long Island is America’s best. That’s where East End pinot noir producers come in.

headline: Kosher Food Maker’s Inventory Seized Over Rodent Infestation
text: Fans of KoJel kosher foods like instant pudding, hot chocolate mix and instant noodle soup, brace yourselves: V.I.P. Foods, the Queens food supplier that manufactures the products, had about $1 million in inventory seized by the federal Food and Drug Administration because of “widespread rodent infestation,” federal prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: First-Timers, Out to Charm
text: Some towns on Long Island have so many restaurants (Huntington and Rockville Centre come to mind) that competition can be fierce. Babylon is another one. That is the only explanation I can find for the scarcity of patrons on recent visits to the 11-month-old Nocturne Dining and Spirits there.

headline: Advisers Urge Political Changes in Italy to Break Stalemate
text: BY GAIA PIANIGIANI

headline: When Small Appliances Misbehave
text: It’s not even Halloween, and Dimension Films (the Weinstein Company’s horror, action and sophomoric-comedy arm) is releasing “Scary Movie V,” the latest installment of the slick, highly profitable parody franchise. Hollywood has certainly kept the screenwriters (the “Scary Movie” veterans Pat Profft and David Zucker) supplied with material: the biggest targets here are the “Paranormal Activity” series, “Black Swan” and “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” with nods to “Mama,” “The Ring,” “Saw” and others.

headline: The Woman With 1 Billion Clicks: Jenna Marbles
text: A young woman with magenta-streaked hair stands in her bathroom, speaking to a webcam. In a hushed tone, she chews over a thorny problem of young adulthood: how to apply full evening makeup when you’re already inebriated from drinking all day?

headline: A Mortgage Holiday for Some Borrowers Hurt by Hurricane
text: Thousands of homeowners whose properties were damaged by Hurricane Sandy  and cannot make their mortgage payments have gotten another reprieve —  the federal government announced Friday that borrowers  with home loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration could suspend mortgage payments for up to one year while they repair their homes.

headline: Bonhomie, Even if They Don’t Know Your Name
text: When he was a boy, back in the 1970s, Michael Pryer often accompanied his father to a bar called Flynn’s, in Chatham. Over the years, he mused about turning the scruffy bar into a place where customers could order more than just a liverwurst or Taylor ham, egg and cheese sandwich — the only items the kitchen served back then, Mr. Pryer, 47, recalled over the telephone after my visits.

headline: The Taste Divide
text: How does an actress design her image? In our celebrity-obsessed culture, she usually dresses in the very latest fashion and has her photographs airbrushed into superhuman oblivion. Julianne Moore, while she indeed looks ravishing in films and on the red carpet, and even in her sweatpants at morning drop off (where I see her from time to time as our children attend the same school), is not such an actress. She is someone who rather pushes the boundaries in her acting in order to inhabit the characters she plays. For this issue she collaborated with the photographers Inez and Vinoodh and the makeup wizard Peter Philips, all artists in their own right, who seek to extend our way of seeing. Here they show us a more real, and even exaggerated side of Moore’s natural beauty. Freckled from birth (and not in a cute way, she explains in the piece), Moore’s face was sprinkled by Philips with even more spots. The resulting image, unlike most cover shots, isn’t retouched to perfection. The power comes from Moore’s striking and honest intensity, and from her scarcely made-up face, remarkable and beautiful at age 52.

headline: A Chat With Raj Chetty, Clark Medalist
text: This afternoon, we caught up with Raj Chetty, the 33-year-old Harvard economist who is the latest winner of the John Bates Clark Medal, a prestigious award for economists under the age of 40. Mr. Chetty is a public economist whose work has addressed topics including the returns from education, tax policies and savings behavior, often by parsing huge troves of data. This interview was lightly edited for clarity.

headline: Qualifying for a Mortgage
text: You probably know someone who has a good story to tell about how difficult it was to get a mortgage in the wake of the housing crisis.

headline: Test Run: What Mobile Payments Companies Can Learn From Chipotle
text: The lingering problem with mobile payments is that it’s usually no more convenient to pay with a phone instead of cash or credit card. Square’s wallet, for example, a feature that promises to let you pay simply by saying your name at the register of participating businesses, is clunky and has rarely worked when we have tried.

headline: ‘Lone Wolf’ Theory Gains Ground in Texas Deaths
text: KAUFMAN, Tex. — Soon after one of his prosecutors was shot and killed here in January, the district attorney in this rural county outside Dallas, Mike McLelland, told colleagues that he believed the victim was the target of a specific disgruntled defendant whom his office had successfully prosecuted.

text: Later this month, the Surflight Theater in Beach Haven will roll out its 64th season with shows that lend themselves to escapism. “We want people to come to the theater and relax a little bit,” said Ken Myers, the executive director.

headline: Morsi Shows Support for Egypt’s Military
text: CAIRO — President Mohamed Morsi appeared with Egypt’s top general on Friday as the military leader denied recent news reports that soldiers may have detained, tortured and killed civilian protesters during the 18-day uprising that ousted former President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Experiment in Oregon Gives Medicaid Very Local Roots
text: SALEM, Ore. — Some say America has been homogenized, a chain-store nation bereft of regional distinction in dialect or dinner. But now this state, at the pioneer’s end of the road, is testing the idea that local community difference is alive and well, and that grass-roots leadership holds the key to fixing health care in America.

headline: Obama Sees Insurers; Health Law Is Subject
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama met with insurance industry executives at the White House on Friday to coordinate the introduction this fall of the insurance marketplaces at the heart of the national health care law, and to discuss so-called rate shock if the industry sharply raises premiums.

headline: Jealousy and Its Shakespearean Outcome
text: Oh, please, King Leontes. So your breathtakingly gorgeous wife flirted a little too much with your best friend after dinner. Give the woman a break. She’s got to be eight months pregnant. And you’re the one who keeps inviting the man to stay longer at your house, palace, whatever.

headline: The Well-Trained Eye of an Art Historian

Born in Fairfield, Conn., and raised in Bucks County, Pa., and Knoxville, Tenn., Ms. Fine Collins, who says she is in her early 50s, lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Bradley Collins Jr., who teaches art history at Parsons the New School for Design.

headline: Students Told to Take Viewpoint of the Nazis
text: ALBANY — High school is full of hypotheticals, like “How does one solve for x?” and “What happens if I skip class?” But this week, students at Albany High School were given an alarming thought puzzle: How do I convince my teacher that I think Jews are evil?

headline: Inflation Is Miserable. Unemployment Is Worse.
text: Unemployment makes people unhappy, according to economic research. So does inflation. But here’s the part the economists are paid for: evidence that unemployment makes people more miserable than inflation.

headline: Syrian Rebels Break With Group Over Qaeda Wing Alliance

headline: A Revered French Winery Breaks With a Bordeaux Tradition
text: PAUILLAC, France — As they have every April for decades, wine merchants from around the world donned their tweed jackets, tucked in their pocket squares and descended on Bordeaux this week to assess the latest vintage. In visits to revered chateaus in localities like Pomerol, Margaux and Saint-Estèphe, they swirled, sniffed, spat and scored the 2012 Bordeaux.

headline: Chinatown, Not the Film, but the Trial
text: A Chinatown gangster and seven or eight of his flunkies supposedly entered a gambling parlor in 2001, walked straight over to a man who owed them money and beat him. The gambler would, 12 years later, be referred to in court documents simply as Victim 1.

headline: In Washington, Clamming for Food and Tradition
text: OCEAN CITY, Wash. — Some razor clammers take a methodical line, a slow, eyes-down stroll through the outgoing tide, watching for the telltale quarter-size divot that marks a clam’s hiding spot, two feet or so below the surface.

headline: Congress Is Socially Insecure
text: When it comes to congressmen behaving badly — and such a list it is, my friends — the prize this week goes to Representative Greg Walden of Oregon. Although I am sorry to say that his bad behavior does not involve any interesting new illicit sex issues.

headline: Vows: Wedding Dress Preservation
text: The textile conservation expert Jonathan Scheer shows us what not to do when putting away a wedding gown for storage.

headline: My Other Car Is… a 1962 Oldsmobile Starfire
text: The Aug. 22, 2005, obituary for Edna Potvin in The Glens Falls Post-Star included a note about her car: “Mrs. Potvin was well known in the Glens Falls area for the immaculate turquoise and black 1962 Oldsmobile Starfire, which she drove until the age of 90.”

headline: Contrasting Views on North Korea Underscore Sensitivities and Lack of Evidence
text: WASHINGTON — On the hawkish end is the Pentagon’s intelligence arm, the Defense Intelligence Agency, which fears that North Korea could threaten American troops with a nuclear weapon on a crude missile. On the skeptical end is the State Department, which has more doubts about Pyongyang’s capabilities. And somewhere in the middle is the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Mindful of Drugs, Race Officials Will Keep Closer Eye on Kentucky Derby
text: The 72 hours before the Kentucky Derby traditionally have been filled with steam, as it is known in racetrack parlance — rumors about which horse is due for a big race and which veterinarians are working overtime to get their horses to the gate. But for the first time in the 139 years of the race, the authorities this year will know precisely who is going into which barn in the hours leading up to the race and for what reason.

headline: Teachers: Will We Ever Learn?
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: Jenna Marbles on YouTube (and Her Dogs)
text: After The New York Times sat down with Jenna Marbles, she made a video answering some questions from the newspaper about her work, her puppies, and her “magical YouTube videos.”

headline: Pettitte to Skip Scheduled Start Sunday Because of Back Spasms
text: Andy Pettitte was at home Thursday night when he and, in turn, the Yankees were reminded once again of their collective fragility. The 40-year-old Pettitte was getting off his couch when his lower back locked up.

headline: BlackBerry Disputes Report on Z10 Phone
text: OTTAWA — BlackBerry contends that a securities analyst’s report about its latest phone is not only wrong, it’s so wrong that it should be investigated by securities regulators.

headline: Longtime CUNY Chancellor to Step Down After Pushing Higher Standards
text: Matthew Goldstein, who oversaw an expansion of the city’s public college system and set out to raise its prestige with a new honors college and other measures, announced on Friday that he would step down after 14 years as chancellor of the City University of New York.

headline: Bomb North Korea, Before It’s Too Late
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: Day Edges Into Lead After Woods Hits Flagstick and Falls Back
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods was cruising. Tied for the lead in the second round of the Masters and the only player in the field who had not bogeyed a hole, he stood in perfect position in the 15th fairway.

headline: Steely Leader of South Korea Is Battle-Ready
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Her mother was shot by an assassin. Her father, a staunchly anti-Communist dictator, was similarly killed. And she survived a vicious razor attack to the face.

headline: Building Better Halfway Houses
text: With corrections costs exceeding $50 billion a year, federal and state officials are understandably eager to make sure that the hundreds of thousands of people released annually from prison get the drug treatment, job placement and support services they need to have a chance at crime-free lives.

headline: A Phantom Ad Comes to New York
text: New York City voters have enjoyed the best and fairest campaign finance system in the country for almost 25 years. Now, a shadowy group organized as New York City Is Not for Sale is attempting to influence this year’s mayoral race with a secretive, independent committee much like those that have so tainted federal elections in recent years. This is the last thing the city needs.

headline: The North Korea Problem
text: Secretary of State John Kerry sent several important messages to North Korea after talks on Friday in Seoul with South Korean leaders. Speaking at a news conference, he said that the United States would defend its South Korean and Japanese allies if there was conflict, that the international community would never accept the North as a nuclear weapons state, and that Washington was willing to resume long-stalled negotiations but only if the North Koreans agreed to move seriously on denuclearization.

headline: A Box of Sheep
text: This week, a sheep arrived in a box. Not the whole sheep, which is still, I hope, grazing happily in a pasture somewhere in northeast Washington State. Only its fleece. I’ve raised many animals but never sheep. My dad, who raised them as a farm boy, left me with a vicious prejudice against them, and the only sheep I saw as a boy did nothing to counter it. They stood — a dim, ghostly flock — in a grove they had denuded entirely of grass and undergrowth. It occurs to me now that this was the fault of the farmer, not of the sheep, who have no more interest in eating bare dirt than I do.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Second Round: Masters Replay
text: Big putts, slow play and changes on the leader board in the second round.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: J.C. Penney’s chief executive, Ron Johnson, is ousted; Aereo, a television streaming service, wins an appellate decision; and gold prices are plummeting.

headline: Joe, Jack and Frank: An Alternative History
text: In a two-page timeline for “Ride the Tiger,” the Long Wharf Theater program tracks the two decades from Joe Kennedy’s ill-judged, career-killing statement in 1940 that “democracy is finished in England” to the 1963 assassination of his son John in Dallas. But wise theatergoers will pay no attention at all to these hard facts. They will instead just follow along with the fancies of the playwright, William Mastrosimone, as he constructs a clever, vastly entertaining counter-history of Camelot.

headline: Tasting Good Life, Opposition in Zimbabwe Slips Off Pedestal
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The guests arrived in Bentleys, Benzes and BMWs. At a plush, riverside wedding in an upscale suburb, the wine and spirits flowed and tables groaned with the ample buffet. Politicians, celebrities, diplomats and business leaders mingled to the strains of Oliver Mtukudzi, a Zimbabwean music star, serenading the happy couple with his famous love song “Svovi Yangu.”

headline: Corrections: April 13, 2013
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Play Both Sides
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s not easy to stack 15-letter entries, even one atop the other, and still integrate them meaningfully into a crossword puzzle. Very often, what the constructor winds up with is either junk fill, or he or she rips the section out and starts again. Don’t even get me started on quad stacks.

headline: The Île à Vache: From Hope to Disaster
text: Virginia’s massive Fortress Monroe, operating under Union control from the beginning of the war, played witness to an unusual sight on the morning of April 14, 1863. For some six days prior the Ocean Ranger lay at anchor in sight of the fort’s guns as a steady stream of food and supplies were carried aboard. The brig’s main cargo, however, consisted of passengers — specifically 453 recently freed African-Americans — about to set sail for a new life in Haiti.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Using Nature to Depict Itself
text: Ellie Irons keeps her eyes to the ground in her Bushwick, Brooklyn, neighborhood. She is looking for plant life, invasive species that pop up beside tree roots and between cracks in the sidewalk. She plucks what she finds and, back in her studio, researches their identities and their origins. Then she crushes them to produce colors she uses to paint maps tracing their journeys to New York.

headline: After Conviction in ’75 Murder Is Thrown Out, Victim’s Family Relives Pain
text: The last time Walter J. Smith saw his little sister Karen alive, on a warm spring day, March 28, 1975, she was on her way to the corner store to buy a 100 Grand candy bar. Hours later, at 1:50 a.m., her body was found in a darkened 16th-floor stairwell of the South Bronx housing project where she lived. The 8-year-old girl had been raped, stabbed and left to die — the candy bar wrapper by her side.

headline: Padres’ Quentin Suspended After Brawl Injures Dodgers Pitcher
text: Beyond the suspensions that Major League Baseball handed down Friday for a fight between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Diego Padres on Thursday night, one real cost to the Dodgers was already known: $531,250.

headline: Once the Story, Now She’s Telling It
text: WAXHAW, N.C. — After weeks of hopscotching across the country on assignments for NBC’s “Today,” Jenna Bush Hager settled her pregnant frame into an oversize leather couch here to conduct an interview. Her subject was Jackson TerKeurst, a 24-year-old Liberian college student who was adopted as a teenager by a local family.

headline: From Expert Cooks, a Baroque Banquet
text: SAN FRANCISCO — New York City’s early-music scene has fostered a number of fine period-instrument ensembles in the recent past. But for a full-size orchestra of period-instrument specialists who have played together for decades under the direction of a committed and charismatic conductor, New Yorkers need to look west — and may well do so with envy. On Thursday evening the Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra, led by Nicholas McGegan, gave a performance of Handel’s “Teseo” at the Herbst Theater here that confirmed its leading position in the field.

headline: Rights Groups Share Concerns Over Target Killings
text: Several human rights and civil rights groups wrote a letter asking the Obama administration to take essential steps to reform the nation’s policy regarding drone killings.

headline: Dancing Across the Decades
text: As a teenager growing up in Brooklyn, Esther Rabinowitz jitterbugged her way through the Great Depression, and even now, at age 90, she has never really stopped.

headline: Social Media, Pushing Reebok To Drop a Rapper
text: The groundswell of protests that has apparently forced Reebok to end its relationship with the rapper Rick Ross has focused attention on the feminist group UltraViolet, which harnessed social media and even placed ads on Facebook in a campaign against Mr. Ross after he rapped about drugging a woman and having sex with her without her knowledge.

headline: If You Don’t Like the View, Just Wait a Few Measures
text: This week the Joyce Theater Foundation continued its efforts to expand its brand — and audience — with a gala presentation on Wednesday featuring a variety of companies and artists at the David H. Koch Theater. They included the Nederland Dans Theater, which also performed the next two nights. But what of expanding the art form? If you judged by these performances, this seemed to be of little concern.

headline: Early in Mayoral Battle, Carriage Horses Are Drawn Into Race
text: As a political issue, it has legs. Four legs.

headline: Conserving Their Energy, Knicks Shift Into Cruise Control
text: CLEVELAND — The last time the Knicks faced the Cavaliers here was a low point for Carmelo Anthony. He fell on his swollen right knee and had to leave the game. Afterward, he revealed for the first time how much the injury had been bothering him.

headline: Questioning Zimbabwe’s Underdogs
text: As elections near, some voters who once had faith in Morgan Tsvangirai’s opposition party ask if it has been tainted by governing with Robert Mugabe.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. The Woolworth Building celebrates its 100th birthday this month. Can you tell me a few things about it?

headline: Mets-Twins Take Field Thanks to Grounds Crew
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Shortly before the Minnesota Twins took the field for batting practice Friday, the exhausted head groundskeeper, Larry DiVito, looked around at an empty and snow-free Target Field with stoic appreciation. A little more than 24 hours after a spring storm had dumped 5.1 inches of snow downtown, DiVito described how dozens of workers had readied the field for the Mets and the Twins to play.

headline: North Korea’s Nuclear Threats, in Focus
text: A detailed overview of the military tension on the Korean Peninsula, with photographs, graphics and reactions from residents of the region.

headline: Pizza Cravings Satisfied, Finally
text: The pizza at Totonno’s in Coney Island has received enough glowing words in its nine-decade history that it doesn’t need more here, except perhaps two: it’s back. Five months after the restaurant on Neptune Avenue was flooded during Hurricane Sandy, the three sibling owners — Antoinette Balzano, Frank Balzano and Louise Ciminieri — reopened for business on March 24.

headline: Horses Enter the Race
text: Proposals to ban horse carriages and other animal rights issues surfaced at a forum for Democratic candidates during the New York City mayoral election campaign.

headline: Hearing Set on Cheating Claim in Capital
text: The City Council in Washington will hold a hearing next week after a memo warning officials of cheating on standardized tests during the chancellorship of Michelle A. Rhee surfaced Thursday night.

headline: An Error and a Triple Play Brighten the Yanks’ Night
text: It was not exactly raining Friday at Yankee Stadium. The night was cold and windy and somewhat misty, and after being exposed to that weather for a while, the skin became cold and damp.

headline: A Pastime Thrives in the Northwest
text: In a tradition that goes back thousands of years, enthusiasts dig Pacific razor clams, which are sweet, meaty and at home in high-end restaurants.

headline: A Day Away From the Stage
text: The soprano Deborah Voigt carries a shield and runs up and down a complicated stage set in her role as Brünnhilde in the Metropolitan Opera production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle. But on Sundays, even Valkyries like to kick back. “Generally it’s the one day off that I don’t have to work, so I try not to schedule too many things,” Ms. Voigt, 52, said. Though she has a condominium in Florida, Ms. Voigt spends most of her time these days in an apartment in Hell’s Kitchen, with an 11-year-old Yorkshire terrier named Steinway. The “Ring” cycle — Ms. Voigt sings in"Die Walküre,""Siegfried” and “Götterdämmerung” — runs through May 11.

headline: Washington Eyes Raising State Tuition of Foreigners
text: Some Washington State legislators are proposing a 20 percent tuition surcharge for international students at the state’s public universities and community colleges as a way to raise revenues.

headline: Nets Start Impressively and Hold On
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The Nets have had a playoff spot secured for several weeks now, and their seeding — third, fourth or fifth — has been the only thing at stake since. They might have begun resting players, or relaxed a bit, or even conceded a game or two, and few would have questioned it.

headline: Matching Students With Schools
text: As chief executive of the Office of Student Enrollment in New York City’s Education Department, Robert Sanft, 41, places tens of thousands of students each year in public schools. He and his team of nearly 200 handle prekindergarten admissions, gifted and talented slots and the high school matching process. A graduate of New York public schools, Mr. Sanft lives in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, with his wife, his son, a fourth grader, and his daughter, who is in prekindergarten. They attend public school.

headline: Detroit’s Leaders Carry on, but Know Who’s Really in Charge
text: DETROIT — Mayor Dave Bing made new budget recommendations to the City Council on Friday, a gloomy ritual that laid out another austere spending plan for this financially distraught city.

headline: Virginia Abortion Clinic Rules Get Final Approval
text: The Virginia Board of Health on Friday gave final approval to new regulations for abortion clinics that will force them to spend large sums on renovations that abortion rights advocates say are medically unnecessary.

headline: Dirt Flies at the Garden Club (Even Before Spring Planting)
text: It started with the accusations of sex behind the back pond. Of late-night parties that begot stitches and adultery. Favoritism. Misspending. Bullying.

headline: When ‘Affordable’ Is Just a Word
text: The spring has the real-estate press enthusiastically reporting on the construction of 432 Park Avenue, an apartment tower that its developers claim will be the tallest residential building in the Western Hemisphere. Apartments in the tower, designed by Rafael Viñoly and to be completed in 2015, are offered in the $20 million to $80 million range, which in the context of Ludicrously Priced Housing for Oligarchs Who Spend Most of the Year in Tax Exile on Mediterranean Yachts isn’t as numbing as it might otherwise be. Such is the historical moment that a few blocks west, in another glass tower, called One 57, apartments have sold in the past year for more than $90 million.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Apr. 13, 2013
text: "I wish they would have made an example of somebody else other than a 14-year-old kid, you know?”

headline: Germany: Former President Wulff Charged
text: German prosecutors charged former President Christian Wulff with corruption on Friday, more than a year after he quit amid accusations that he had accepted favors from business executives before becoming president. Mr. Wulff, 53, was picked by Chancellor Angela Merkel in 2010 for the largely ceremonial post. He quit 20 months later after the revelations about vacations with rich friends and favors and gifts that he had accepted earlier in his political career. On Friday, prosecutors in Hanover accused Mr. Wulff of allowing a movie producer to pay for a family vacation in 2008, while Mr. Wulff was governor of Lower Saxony. In exchange, prosecutors said, Mr. Wulff lobbied the engineering giant Siemens to help promote one of the producer’s films. Mr. Wulff, who denies the allegations, rejected an offer to settle the case by paying a fine.
