headline: N.R.A. 500 Thrusts Nascar Into Hot Seat
text: A picture of 6-year-old Charlotte Helen Bacon was tucked into the pocket of the firesuit Michael Waltrip wore when he raced in the Daytona 500 in February.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 12, 2013

headline: More Test-Taking Scrutiny at L.I. District After Coaching Accusations
text: The State Education Department said on Friday that it was requiring a Long Island school district to keep closer watch on classrooms during standardized tests because of accusations that some of its teachers may have improperly helped students during last year’s exams.

headline: A South Korean Leader Toughened by Adversity
text: President Park Geun-hye’s mettle is being tested in the Korean crisis.

headline: Playing a Wizard’s Game on Ordinary Broomsticks
text: Not many people have heard of Macaulay Honors College, a school in New York City with 1,770 students and just one athletic team: the Marauders.

headline: Three International Stars Give Islanders Ballast and Banter
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders have a reason to be grateful for the four-month N.H.L. lockout: the bond between their captain, Mark Streit, and their budding star John Tavares.

headline: Autistic, and on the Airwaves
text: The participants at Lifestyles for the Disabled do not exactly seem like naturals as radio personalities.

headline: A Rarity for Rangers and Islanders, With Playoff Berths at Stake
text: Fans at Nassau Coliseum will witness something rare Saturday night: a late-season game between the Islanders and the Rangers in which both teams’ playoff chances are on the line. It has happened only four previous times in the 40-season history of the rivalry. The Islanders hold the upper hand, having won three games and tied the other.

headline: Coachella: A Heavy Lean Toward the British
text: Coachella has become one of the primary American summer music institutions, not from a loyalty to domestic acts, but because it is warm to an idea that arose around the indie-mainstream collapse of the 1990s: subcultures can be mainstreamed too. The festival, one of the primary American summer music institutions with its 90,000 or so attendees this weekend and next, relies on that.

headline: The Mets Keep Pounding the Ball to Stay Warm
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Someone with a sardonic sense of humor at Target Field chose the break between the fourth and fifth innings to play the Andy Williams Christmas classic “It’s the Most Wonderful Time of the Year.”

headline: Spain vs. Germany in Champions League Semifinals
text: Each Champions League semifinal will pit a German club against a Spanish one: Bayern Munich and Barcelona will fight for the right to play the winner of Dortmund versus Real Madrid. The final is in London on May 25. In the second-tier Europa League, Chelsea will play Basel of Switzerland, and Fenerbahce of Turkey will play Benfica of Portugal.

headline: Avian Flu Virus Confirmed in Beijing for First Time
text: HONG KONG — The bird flu virus that has been centered in the city of Shanghai and surrounding provinces has now been reported elsewhere in China, as a 7-year-old girl was being treated on Saturday in a Beijing hospital for avian influenza.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 13
text: The United States imposed new sanctions Friday on about two dozen Russians accused of human rights violations, and Moscow vowed to retaliate as a fractious dispute between the two countries escalated further into a cold war-style, tit-for-tat clash. The Obama administration barred 18 Russians from traveling to the United States and froze any assets they may have here under a new law intended to punish human rights violations. A handful of other more highly placed officials, including the head of the Russian region of Chechnya, were put on a list not publicly revealed. Russian officials promised to ban a like number of Americans. Peter Baker reports from Washington and Ellen Barry from Moscow.

headline: 5 Dead and Scores Missing After Boat Sinks Off Indonesia
text: SYDNEY, Australia — At least five people have died and as many as 60 were missing on Saturday after a boat carrying people believed to be seeking asylum in Australia broke apart in the Sunda Strait, a patch of water between Sumatra and the main Indonesian island of Java.

headline: Kerry in China to Seek Help in Korea Crisis
text: A more recent article about Secretary of State John Kerry’s trip to Asia can be found here.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: ­Jammu and Kashmir: A soldier was killed and five others were injured when a grenade accidentally exploded inside an army camp in the Kupwara district in northern Kashmir, according to a Press Trust of India report on the NDTV Web site. The accident occurred when the soldiers were preparing to embark on an anti-militant operation, the report noted.

headline: All Aboard Rescued After Plane Skids Into Water at Bali Airport
text: HONG KONG — A plane with more than 100 people onboard skidded off the runway and cracked in two while trying to land on the resort island of Bali on Saturday, and officials said rescuers pulled all passengers and crew members to safety from the jet after it came to rest in shallow waters.

headline: Mother of a 6-Year-Old Boy Killed at Newtown Delivers the White House’s Weekly Address
text: WASHINGTON — The mother of a child killed in the school shooting in Newtown, Conn., delivered a raw plea on Saturday for the Senate to pass gun control legislation, using an avenue normally reserved for the president.

headline: The Weekend Word: Mental Health
text: Today’s Times

headline: Beating Dead Horses
text: Slightly strange piece in BusinessWeek, sold on slightly false pretenses — I had a quick conversation with Peter Coy (while walking along Broadway, no less), which I thought was input into a larger story; instead, it’s just me, verbatim. Still, people may be interested in how I think about my role in this macroeconomic debate.

headline: After Two-Stroke Penalty, Woods Plays On
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — As the cheers for Tiger Woods on the first tee gave way to the relative hush of patrons hoofing it to the green, a man behind the tee box turned to his wife and said, “I didn’t hear anybody call Tiger a cheater.”

headline: A Cheesy Audience
text: Patrick Watson, owner of Stinky Bklyn, practices for his performance of the national anthem at Barclays Center by singing to the cheeses in his store.

headline: Mubarak Appears at Trial, Which Ends Abruptly in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Former President Hosni Mubarak sat up, waved and even smirked as he appeared at a hearing on Saturday to open his retrial on charges related to the killing of protesters at the end of his rule.

headline: Coachella: When the Band Is a Second Gig
text: INDIO, Calif., — It’s nice to have a hobby — a job can be stressful, especially when you are good at doing it and it keeps the lights on.

headline: North Korean Leader, Young and Defiant, Strains Ties With Chinese
text: BEIJING — The last known face-to-face contact between Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, and senior Chinese officials did not end well.

headline: Assad Foes Hire Former British Diplomat to Plead Their Cause
text: LONDON — A former British diplomat with a reputation for championing underdogs has been hired by Syria’s opposition coalition to help in its potentially uphill mission to persuade reluctant governments to do more to end the country’s civil war.

headline: Immersing Himself to Play a Pioneer
text: There is a moment in “42,” the Jackie Robinson movie released this weekend, in which Chadwick Boseman, the actor playing Robinson, gives a perfect depiction of the mentality of an athlete. Someone tells Robinson he is a hero, and while Robinson surely understood his heroic undertaking in breaking baseball’s color barrier, he deflected the praise.

headline: Bryant Has Surgery for Torn Tendon, Ending His Season
text: LOS ANGELES — In retrospect, it was as if the last six games, in which Kobe Bryant played all but 14 minutes, had been leading to something as inevitable as it was wrenching.

headline: China’s Theaters May Soon Show Tarantino Film
text: LOS ANGELES — Details remain sparse, but Quentin Tarantino’s “Django Unchained” is expected to be back in China’s theaters soon, after some further editing.

headline: Men of Words, Men of Deeds
text: Midway through the second half of a close and pivotal game against Texas Southern during the 1967 football season, Coach Eddie Robinson’s Grambling team mounted a drive. It ended abruptly when Grambling’s center threw a forearm at the nose tackle who had been dominating him. A referee penalized Grambling and ejected the center from the game.

headline: Unlikely Source Has Produced an N.F.L. Draft Prospect
text: MINEOLA, N.Y. — It was the morning of Notre Dame’s pro day, and the cameras, commentators and representatives from nearly every N.F.L. team gathered in South Bend, Ind., for another meticulously planned, flawlessly controlled workout at one of the most traditional spots to scour for college talent before April’s draft.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Pacers Preach Balance in Star-Driven League
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Before the playoffs began last season, Indiana Pacers Coach Frank Vogel was asked who he thought could be the team’s go-to player in crunch time, with a postseason game on the line. “Our depth,” Vogel responded.

headline: Preaching Citizenship
text: A changing attitude in evangelical congregations like the First Baptist Church of Orlando, Fla., could help sway lawmakers as they consider immigration reform.

headline: For Evangelicals, a Shift in Views on Immigration
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — In the pews of the First Baptist Church of Orlando, where thousands of evangelical Christians gather on Sundays to worship and sing, a change of heart is happening on the once toxic issue of immigration.

headline: Russia Bars 18 Americans After Sanctions by U.S.
text: MOSCOW — A day after the United States imposed sanctions on Russians accused of rights violations, Moscow said Saturday that it could not “leave this open blackmail without response” and published a list of 18 current and former American officials who will now be barred from entry to Russia.

headline: Variety: Getting To The Point
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — This was a lot of fun for me, and I can tell you why.

headline: Letter From London | Spring Drinks
text: Rita Konig, T’s European editor, unveils persons, places and things on her radar in her online letters from London.

headline: Helping Teachers Learn
text: The school cheating scandal in Atlanta that led to criminal indictments against dozens of teachers, principals and administrators last month contains at least three lessons for states that are developing teacher evaluation systems.

headline: Gifting and Politicking
text: George Washington Plunkitt’s timeless defense of “honest graft” in government has been a measure of political dodginess for the last century. “I seen my opportunities and I took ’em,” Plunkitt bragged after becoming a millionaire by exploiting the legal edge of patronage and machine politics in the Tammany Hall era.

headline: Courage in Kansas
text: Nearly four years after an anti-abortion extremist opened fire and killed a Wichita abortion provider, Dr. George Tiller, as he stood in the foyer of his church, a new medical clinic offering comprehensive reproductive health services — including abortions through the first trimester of pregnancy — opened on April 3. It is in the building that once housed Dr. Tiller’s clinic.

headline: Public Pensions in Bankruptcy Court
text: Devastated by the recession, the city of Stockton, Calif., is trying to renegotiate its debts in a bankruptcy case that could set an important precedent on whether courts can forcibly reduce the pensions of government employees.

headline: When Election Regulators Are Mocked
text: It is an open scandal in Washington that the Federal Election Commission is completely ossified as the referee and penalizer of abuses in national politics.

headline: Pope Francis Names Advisory Panel at Vatican
text: VATICAN CITY — In his first significant decision since becoming pontiff — and a radical step toward more democracy in the Roman Catholic Church — Pope Francis on Saturday named a group of eight cardinals from around the world to advise him in governing the church and overhauling the troubled Vatican hierarchy, which has been rocked by scandals.

headline: Another Attempt at Women’s Circuit, but With a Twist
text: All they have ever wanted was a league of their own. Just not three.

headline: Faltering Courts, Mired in Delays
text: Outside the courtroom, the children of the murdered man waited with their mother. It had taken five years for the Bronx courts to get around to them and to the man with teardrop tattoos charged with killing their father.

headline: On the Golf Course, It’s All About Building Relationships
text: AUGUSTA, Ga.

headline: You Loved My Film? Thanks, Man. Spare a Dime?
text: From all available evidence, this is a new golden age for Texas independent filmmaking. Eight narrative features, either made by Texas-based directors or shot in the state, had their world premieres at this year’s Sundance Film Festival; more than a dozen more Texas efforts had their premieres at the South by Southwest Film Festival last month.

headline: W.N.B.A. Hopes Griner Can Change Perceptions, as Well as Game Itself
text: Forget for a moment whether Brittney Griner has the skill to play in the N.B.A. There are more urgent and relevant questions. One is whether she will thrive as a primary face of the W.N.B.A.’s campaign to rebrand itself in its 17th season, beginning with its first prime-time draft Monday.

headline: Missing Deflation
text: Keynesians have, over all, had a very good track record in this economic crisis; one indication of just how good is the remarkable extent to which people on the other side have had attack people like me for supposed wrong predictions we never, in fact, made (you endorsed Obama’s economic projections! No, I didn’t).

headline: At a College, Dropping Sports in Favor of Fitness
text: ATLANTA — The softball bats and golf clubs have been stored away. All is quiet, too, at the basketball gymnasium, the volleyball courts and the soccer field.

headline: At Augusta, if You Have to Ask, The Answer Is No. So Don’t Ask.
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Golf is a game of order with a 140-page rule book that is a vast compendium of what the golfer is not permitted to do.

headline: Private Jets and Country Clubs Help Soften Blow of Meager Pay
text: Many Texas lawmakers are quick to name the sacrifices they make to serve: the meager state pay, the grueling hours, the time spent away from their families and their day jobs.

headline: From Staten Island, a Unique Broadcast
text: Meet Totally ’80s Chris, Michael the date whiz and Mystery Man, D.J.’s on Lifestyles Radio, a program run by Lifestyles for the Disabled on Staten Island.

headline: A Slim Chance for Lawmakers to Self-Regulate
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: Heavier Trucks From Mexico Could Prove a Boon for Texas
text: Each year, just before they approach the United States border, thousands of truck drivers hauling produce from western Mexico to southern Texas stop in the city of Reynosa to lighten their loads.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8:30 P.M. (HBO) THE CAMPAIGN (2012) In this comedy about rival candidates in a North Carolina Congressional election, directed by Jay Roach, Will Ferrell, above, plays Cam Brady, a blow-dried Democrat espousing a platform of guns, God and family while violating his marriage vows at every turn. Zach Galifianakis is Marty Huggins, the sweet, wimpy son of a local politico (Brian Cox), plucked from obscurity by Republicans. Dylan McDermott plays the hatchet man dispatched to make Marty into a political machine. “You can chuckle at the buffoonery, raise your eyebrows at the baroque scatological and sexual humor — Mom, they said ‘penis’ again! — and conclude that ‘The Campaign’ goes too far,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But then a glance at some of the clowns we do elect, perhaps especially to our national legislature, might lead you in the opposite direction. Really, the movie could not possibly go far enough unless the screenwriters (Chris Henchy and Shawn Harwell) had abandoned all invention and transcribed the script directly from C-Span.”

headline: When God Is Your Therapist
text: IT had never occurred to me to think of God as a therapist when I began to spend time, 10 years ago, at an evangelical church in Chicago. Like many secular observers, I was interested in the fact that people like me seemed to experience reality in a fundamentally different manner. I soon came to realize that one of the most important features of these churches is that they offer a powerful way to deal with anxiety and distress, not because of what people believe but because of what they do when they pray.

headline: Think Those Chemicals Have Been Tested?
text: MANY Americans assume that the chemicals in their shampoos, detergents and other consumer products have been thoroughly tested and proved to be safe.

headline: A Troubled Court System in the Bronx
text: The New York Times reporter William Glaberson explains his nearly yearlong investigation into the dysfunctional courts in the Bronx.

headline: Anthony Closes in on Scoring Title
text: In 1994, David Robinson of the San Antonio Spurs entered his team’s final game locked in a battle with Shaquille O’Neal of the Orlando Magic for the league’s scoring title. Robinson, a veteran center, needed to score 4 more points than O’Neal to overtake him. Just to be safe, Robinson went on a tear, scoring a career-high 71 points — making him the fourth player to surpass 70 points in a game — and finishing with an average of 29.8 points a game. O’Neal could not match him, scoring 32 in his team’s finale and finishing with an average of 29.3.

headline: Note to New S.E.C. Chief: The Clock Is Ticking
text: AFTER receiving unanimous support from the United States Senate, Mary Jo White was confirmed last week as the new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission. At her swearing-in, she praised S.E.C. officials for “vigorously enforcing the securities laws.”

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Lifestyle and Taxes
text: Writers discuss incentives to marry, procreate and buy a home.

headline: Quietly, Indians Reshape Cities and Reservations
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Nothing in her upbringing on a remote Indian reservation in northern Minnesota prepared Jean Howard for her introduction to city life during a visit here eight years ago: an outbreak of gunfire, followed by the sight of people scattering.

headline: A.B.A., or Something Unlike It
text: LIMA, Ohio — The bleachers at the high school gym were mostly empty. The visiting team, the Michiana Monarchs, was running late. Players from the home team, the Lima Explosion, were still recovering from long shifts at their day jobs: working construction, stocking shelves, teaching high school.

headline: Thomas R. Frieden
text: Thomas R. Frieden is the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta and previously served as New York City’s health commissioner.

headline: As Indians Move to Cities, Old and New Challenges Follow
text: The migration of American Indians to cities has taken place amid hope and some concern.

headline: Red Wings-Blackhawks Rivalry Will Be Readjusted by Realignment
text: CHICAGO — On a visit to Olympia Stadium in Detroit in the 1960s, the Hall of Famer Bobby Hull recalled, he was skating through warm-ups with the Blackhawks when three Red Wings fans in the front row began yelling obscenities at him. Their shouts grew louder and more disparaging, and soon the fans had climbed the glass and dangled their arms over it. Hull skated toward the glass, hooked the three fans with his stick and with a flick of his wrist sent them sprawling.

headline: Balance and Bias
text: THE traditional American mass media — the crumbling, Internet-besieged edifice of newspapers and news shows, magazines and roundtables and journalism schools — evolved to believe with equal vigor in two not entirely compatible ideals.

headline: Love, Love Them. Do.
text: HE was a darling of the cable news shows, which indulged his appetite for attention so frequently that he carried his own makeup kit, to be ready and pretty at a moment’s notice. But the lights and the cameras weren’t enough.

headline: The Ghosts of Afghanistan’s Past
text: ON March 10, Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai, shocked Western leaders by declaring that recent attacks proved that the Taliban “are at the service of America.” The implication was clear: terrorists were colluding with the United States to sow chaos before America’s planned withdrawal in 2014. American and European leaders, mindful of the blood and treasure they’ve expended to defend Mr. Karzai’s government, were baffled and offended.

headline: Chris Murphy’s Crucible
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Hacktivists as Gadflies
text: Around 400 B.C., Socrates was brought to trial on charges of corrupting the youth of Athens and “impiety.” Presumably, however, people believed then as we do now, that Socrates’ real crime was being too clever and, not insignificantly, a royal pain to those in power or, as Plato put it, a gadfly. Just as a gadfly is an insect that could sting a horse and prod it into action, so too could Socrates sting the state. He challenged the moral values of his contemporaries and refused to go along with unjust demands of tyrants, often obstructing their plans when he could. Socrates thought his service to Athens should have earned him free dinners for life. He was given a cup of hemlock instead.

headline: Patricia McCormick, Bullfighter Who Defied Convention, Is Dead at 83
text: During the 1950s, when young women from West Texas were typically expected to take care of the home, Patricia McCormick bucked social convention, and a long male tradition, by entering the bullfighting ring.

headline: One Man’s Passing
text: The photographer Joshua Bright spent more than a year visiting and taking photos of a dying man named John R. Hawkins.

headline: A Good Death
text: FOR more than a year, I visited and photographed a dying man named John R. Hawkins. I had found him through the New York Zen Center for Contemplative Care when I went in search of both a photo project and a profound experience.

headline: How Should We Rank Margaret Thatcher?
text: ON Wednesday, Margaret Thatcher’s funeral, at St Paul’s Cathedral in London, will put her in the company of only three other Britons in more than 200 years: Lord Nelson, the Duke of Wellington and Sir Winston Churchill.

headline: The Trauma of the Pink Shirt
text: LET me tell you an odd little story, in anticipation of summer. Last June, just as New York City was turning back into a summer sweatbox, our friend Shirley called my wife and said she knew someone with a pool in New Jersey who was away for the weekend, and wouldn’t mind our using it. An irresistible invitation.

headline: A Big Bet on Downtown Detroit
text: Against tall odds, Dan Gilbert, the Quicken Loans chairman, wants to revive a two-square-mile stretch that was once Detroit’s core.

headline: Finding Purpose in Tunneling Through Granite
text: This interview with  Marcus Ryu, the C.E.O. of Guidewire Software, a maker of software for the insurance industry,  was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: A Missionary’s Quest to Remake Motor City
text: THE best way to experience all that is strange and a little otherworldly about downtown Detroit is to walk the streets around 5 p.m. on a weekday. At that hour, you’ll notice not just the peculiarity of what is around you — notably, the gorgeous, Art Deco skyscrapers alongside empty, decrepit buildings — but also what is missing. There is no traffic here. As the workday ends, cars trickle out of underground parking lots and speed off to nearby highways, but in a volume that doesn’t cause delays.

headline: Mounting Tensions Escalate Into Violence During Raid at Guantánamo Prison
text: WASHINGTON — Weeks of mounting tensions between the military and detainees at the wartime prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, escalated into violence on Saturday during a raid in which guards forced prisoners living in communal housing to move to individual cells.

headline: John Tavares Quietly Making Case for Hart Trophy
text: Short schedule or long, the criterion for deciding who deserves the Hart Memorial Trophy does not change: it goes to “the player judged most valuable to his team.” So should John Tavares win the Hart Trophy this season?

headline: Why Home Prices Change (or Don’t)
text: WHAT prices will today’s home buyers get if they sell a decade from now?

headline: Hackers Post Witness List in Trial on Ex-Premier’s Death
text: PARIS — Hackers broke into a major Lebanese news Web site and plastered the front page with the names of the so-called secret witnesses for the trial in the killing of the former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri in an apparent bold, new move to intimidate witnesses and derail the trial.

headline: Texas Official Questioned in Killings Is Held Over Alleged Threat
text: KAUFMAN, Tex. — A former justice of the peace who has been questioned in the murders of two prosecutors here was arrested early Saturday on charges that included making a threat, the authorities said.

headline: The Economic Data Filters, Clogged Again
text: ROBERT HEILBRONER, the author and economist, was often asked where interest rates, the stock market and the economy were heading.

headline: Mirth and Taxes
text: A study of 54 nations — ranked below — found that those with more progressive tax rates had happier citizens, on average.

headline: Sometimes, We Want Prices to Fool Us
text: WHEN the board of J. C. Penney ousted its chief executive, Ron Johnson — news that broke last Monday — you might say it was, in some small way, because he didn’t understand Tracie Fobes.

headline: Mentors Are Good. Sponsors Are Better.
text: AS Sheryl Sandberg of Facebook tells it, what accounts for her spectacular leap to leadership is her unfettered embrace of career opportunity. By “leaning in,” she maintains in her new book, she has been able to join the male-dominated ranks of corporate executives.

headline: My Copyright Career
text: I GREW up in a working-class family in Beverly, Mass., where my father had several jobs, including packing chemicals and working in shipping and receiving at Logan Airport. He and my mother, a preschool teacher, met at a bowling alley in 1962 and married soon after.

headline: Heavens, Not Havens
text: THE words happy and taxes do not often appear together. In fact, death is the word that people associate most often with taxes, according to wordassociation.org.

headline: The Furtive Tax
text: APRIL 15 is dreaded as the deadline for filing income tax returns, but in fact every day is tax day for most working people. That’s because more than half of all Americans pay more in payroll tax than in income tax. That includes nearly everyone in the bottom half of the income distribution.

headline: Go Simple
text: HOW many millions of hours do you think Americans spend on government paperwork every year?

headline: Palestinian Prime Minister Resigns, Adding Uncertainty to Government
text: JERUSALEM — The internationally respected prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Salam Fayyad, resigned on Saturday, raising concerns about political stability in the West Bank days after Secretary of State John Kerry proposed a broad initiative to aid the Palestinian economy there to shore up peace efforts.

headline: Coachella: Day 1
text: The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival kicked off with performances by IO Echo, Of Monsters and Men and Band of Horses.

headline: On Alert for Meningitis in Los Angeles
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — A potentially deadly strain of meningitis, which has left one resident brain dead, has sent a shiver through the large gay community here, as public health officials have urged residents to be on the lookout for any symptoms of the disease.

headline: Coachella: Photos From Day 1
text: The photographer Chad Batka captured highlights from the first day of the music festival in California. See larger versions of the photos here.

headline: Mickey Rose, TV Writer and Woody Allen Collaborator, Dies at 77
text: As Brooklyn high school buddies, Woody Allen and Mickey Rose had a dream: one day, with luck, they would open a pharmacy together.

headline: Playing Catch-Up With Robocallers
text: IF this column were a TV show, what kind of TV show would it be? The Haggler is thinking dark comedy, laugh track optional. But sometimes the material here feels more like the stuff of farce. Laugh till you cry farce. As it does with the continuing Whirlpool ordeal experienced by Shira London, who e-mailed an update last week.

headline: Medical Care, Aided by the Crowd
text: TWO years ago, Chase Adam, a Peace Corps volunteer in Costa Rica, was riding a bus through a town called Watsi, when a woman got on board asking for money. Her son, she said, needed medical attention and she couldn’t pay for it. As the woman walked through the bus, she showed people a copy of her son’s medical record. Mr. Adam, who is now 26, noticed that nearly everyone donated money.

headline: North Korea Threatens Colorado City, Inaccurately
text: North Korea, which seemed to be running out of tubs to thump, found a new target for its ire in a propaganda video released Saturday on Uriminzokkiri, a government Web site.

headline: Conduct at Issue as Military Officers Face a New Review
text: WASHINGTON — After a series of scandals involving high-ranking officers, the American military for the first time will require generals and admirals to be evaluated by their peers and the people they command on qualities including personal character.

headline: A Viewer’s Guide to the Mayoral Candidates
text: Seeking the New York City mayor’s office are seven Democrats, three Republicans and one candidate on the Independence Party’s ballot.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 14
text: Senator Marco Rubio visits seven programs this Sunday, talking about immigration as he and the rest of a bipartisan group of eight senators prepare to release a proposal to overhaul the system. The Florida Republican will appear on the five major Sunday shows, as well as the programs on Telemundo and Univision.

headline: Basketball’s Renegade Spirit
text: Today’s A.B.A., a basketball league that is not particularly professional, shares little with the original other than the name, the ball and a renegade spirit.

headline: DNWR in the EA
text: That’s downward nominal wage rigidity in the euro area (and actually in neighboring countries too). I’ve been talking about DNWR in the US context, but it’s a much bigger issue in Europe, where the whole adjustment strategy relies on “internal devaluation”: countries that experienced large capital inflows during the period 2000-2007 are supposed to regain competitiveness by cutting costs, and that’s really hard if nominal wages have to come down.

headline: ‘My Treat’
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh my, I loved this puzzle. Your mileage may vary. But as far as I’m concerned, the only thing that would have made this puzzle better is if we had some sort of technology here at The New York Times that would make the puzzle lickable. Maybe scratch ‘n’ sniff, as a second choice. But definitely lickable.

headline: Robert Byrne, Chess Grandmaster, Dies at 84
text: Robert Byrne, an international grandmaster and United States chess champion who, as the chess columnist for The New York Times, analyzed top-flight matches from 1972 through 2006, the eras of Bobby Fischer and Garry Kasparov, died on Friday at his home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 84.

headline: Coachella: A Few Sparks of Creative Rock
text: INDIO, Calif. — American rock music might get a bad rap, but its cancer begins from within. Major labels have all but tabled creative ambition, meaning that even bona fide indie stars may have to content themselves with being miniscene champions for life. Early on Saturday at Coachella, there was a suite of young American bands trying to find a path out of the darkness.

headline: Obama’s Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
text: WASHINGTON — Whether or not Republicans ever agree to a budget deal with President Obama, one thing seems certain: now that he has officially put Social Security and Medicare benefits on the negotiating table, opponents on his party’s left will make that an issue for Democrats in the midterm elections next year — and perhaps in the 2016 presidential contest.

headline: Shy No More, N.R.A.’s Top Gun Sticks to Cause
text: WASHINGTON — Victims of the massacre in Newtown, Conn., had just been laid to rest when Wayne LaPierre, the chief executive of the National Rifle Association, met with his board of directors in early January. A national tide of grief had prompted new attacks on his group and a White House push for more gun control measures, while Mr. LaPierre — who had called for armed guards in every school — was pilloried as a “gun nut” on the cover of The New York Post.

headline: Mystery Shrouds Rise and Aims of Rebel at Helm of Central African Republic
text: A portly sexagenarian, Michel Djotodia had dressed for his coup d’état, donning desert camouflage, a turban and sandals like those of the rebels in his region of the Central African Republic.

headline: Sierra Leone’s Health Care System Becomes a Cautionary Tale for Donors
text: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — The health statistics in this battered land, still scarred from a decade of civil war, are so alarming that for a decade, donors have opened their wallets to help improve some of the world’s worst rates of maternal and infant mortality. This is the third-most dangerous place on earth to have a baby, and one of the most perilous to be a baby.

headline: No Stranger to Scandal, Spitzer Says Weiner ‘Can Come Back’
text: As he considers a potential mayoral run in the wake of an online sex scandal, former Representative Anthony D. Weiner has won a vote of confidence from a politician who can identify with his predicament: Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Brooklyn School Takes Title at the ‘Supernationals’
text: Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn won its division at the “Supernationals” scholastic championships in Nashville last weekend.

headline: Morneau’s Homer Ruins No-Hit Bid, but Mets’ Harvey Stays Dominant
text: MINNEAPOLIS — It wasn’t a bad pitch, but it wasn’t the right pitch. Matt Harvey realized that not long after Minnesota’s Justin Morneau swung at an inside slider with two out in the seventh, pulling a home run high off the right-field pole and halting Harvey’s bid for a second Mets no-hitter in two years and his first professional shutout.

headline: Wigan Defeats Millwall in Violence-Marred F.A. Cup Semifinal
text: LONDON — There were two sparkling goals, a typically gray and rainy English day and plenty of pomp, but the lingering image from Saturday’s F.A. Cup semifinal between Millwall and Wigan will be that of a young girl crying.

headline: Early Signs of Parity in A.L. East, Where 90 Wins May Be Enough
text: The Baltimore Orioles unloaded on Phil Hughes on Saturday, hitting him so hard for three innings that Hughes said he could not remember the last time he had pitched so badly. Maybe there were better times to ask Hughes about the strength of the division, times when he could have been more objective. But his perspective seemed to sum up the new reality of the American League East.

headline: On Leader Board Full of Challengers, Top Two Say They Have a Plan
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Controversy over Tiger Woods’s two-stroke penalty for hitting from the wrong spot Friday enveloped the Augusta National Golf Club grounds for hours before play began in Saturday’s third round. In the galleries, among the players and in the deliberations of tournament officials, the attention of all conversation was focused on the past, on what Woods did and did not do in the second round.

headline: Hughes Returns to Mound, but Briefly
text: The grumbling began with a lone fan who had given up on Phil Hughes in the third inning. “Take him out! Take him ouuuuuut!” He was louder with each hard hit. Soon, a few others started to boo. By the fourth, as Hughes walked off the mound with his head bowed after being removed from the game, the crowd was more decided.

headline: Attention, Second-Guessers: Golf Takes Calls (and Texts)
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — In golf, and almost no other sport, interactive, real-time communication between armchair television viewers and referees supervising the competition routinely changes rulings and alters the outcomes of tournaments. This collaboration of living room second-guessers and rules officials is an almost weekly occurrence. On Saturday, it embroiled the Masters, golf’s biggest event, in a controversy that involved the game’s most celebrated player, Tiger Woods.

headline: China Makes Inroads in Nepal, and Stanches Tibetan Influx
text: CHOSAR, Nepal — The wind-scoured desert valley here, just south of Tibet, was once a famed transit point for the Tibetan yak caravans laden with salt that lumbered over the icy ramparts of the Himalayas. In the 1960s, it became a base for Tibetan guerrillas trained by the C.I.A. to attack Chinese troops occupying their homeland.

headline: Playoff Race Reanimates Rivalry, and Rangers’ Overtime Goal Electrifies It
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Nassau Coliseum was rocking the way it used to, decades ago, when J. P. Parise, Denis Potvin and Chico Resch were leading the upstart Islanders against the established Rangers of John Davidson, Phil Esposito and Ron Duguay. Those clashes generally ended with the Islanders on top, but that was not the way Saturday night’s game ended.

headline: Third Round: Masters Replay
text: Scenes from Saturday’s third round at Augusta National.

headline: National Title Is State Title as Yale Beats Quinnipiac
text: PITTSBURGH — Three weeks before the Connecticut neighbors Yale and Quinnipiac met on college hockey’s biggest stage, they played on a much smaller one in the ECAC Hockey tournament’s consolation game. Quinnipiac won that day, just as it had in the teams’ two meetings during the regular season.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 14
text: “It should never take five years. All the good parts of New York, the high-class parts of New York, they easily get justice.”

headline: Java’s War Wins Blue Grass Stakes; Overanalyze Takes Arkansas Derby
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Fourteen horses, the maximum number allowed, entered the starting gate for the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland Race Course. They lined up 10 across for the Arkansas Derby at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark.

headline: Karina Garcia, David Magruder
text: Karina Marie Garcia and David Michael Magruder were married Saturday at St. Ann Roman Catholic Church in West Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Nestor Rodriguez, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Hanna Lundqvist, Reece Dameron
text: Hanna Rebecca Lundqvist and Reece Campbell Dameron were married Saturday at the Four Seasons Resort Rancho Encantado in Santa Fe, N.M. Judge Sarah M. Singleton of New Mexico’s First Judicial District Court in Santa Fe officiated.

headline: Abigail Curran, Chad Horrell
text: Abigail Flicker Curran and Chad Daniel Horrell were married Saturday at the University of Virginia Chapel in Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Andrew I. Walton, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Christine MacGregor, Theodore Iobst
text: Christine Elder MacGregor and Theodore David Iobst were married Saturday at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. R. Charles Grant, an associate pastor at the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Rachel Bordenstein, Eric Saar
text: Rachel Michelle Bordenstein and Eric Thomas Saar were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Brenner J. Glickman at the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota, Fla.

headline: Jennifer Bjorklund, Jonathan Lloyd
text: Jennifer Lynne Bjorklund and Jonathan Alden Casey Lloyd were married Saturday in Griffith Park in Los Angeles. Thomas J. LaBonge, a Los Angeles city councilman who was appointed a temporary deputy marriage commissioner by Los Angeles County for the event, officiated.

headline: Jennifer Young, Jay Mehr
text: Jennifer Lee Young and Jay Steven Mehr were married Saturday evening at the Manor, an event space in West Orange, N.J. David J. Issenman, a retired Superior Court judge whose chambers were in Elizabeth, N.J., officiated.

headline: Brian Healy and Daniel Hantman
text: Donall Brian Healy Jr. and Daniel Harris Hantman were married Saturday at Judson Memorial Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Donna E. Schaper, the church’s senior minister who is affiliated with the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

headline: Rachel Mindlin, Matthew Rednor
text: Rachel Anne Mindlin and Matthew Benjamin Rednor were married Saturday evening by Cantor Marcos Askenazi at Studio 450, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: Laurie Perez and Jeffrey Collette
text: Laurie Sue Perez and Jeffrey James Collette were married Saturday at Merriman’s Kapalua, a restaurant in Lahaina, Hawaii, on the island of Maui. Ernest K. Puaa, a Pentecostal minister with the Harvest Chapel Church of God in Lahaina, Hawaii, officiated.

headline: Abigail Collier and Christopher Buhrman
text: Abigail Ipolani Collier and Christopher David Buhrman were married Saturday in Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. David C. L. Prior, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel.

headline: Alexandra Cohen, Jordan Scheiman
text: Alexandra Lauren Cohen and Jordan Leone Scheiman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Arthur Nemitoff at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y.

headline: Whitney Robinson, Louie Rivers III
text: A Two-Part First Date

headline: Astrid Hill and Ryan Dattilo
text: Astrid Tomilson Hill, a daughter of Janine W. Hill and J. Tomilson Hill of New York, was married Saturday to Ryan Joseph Dattilo, the son of Lori A. Dattilo and Joseph A. Dattilo of Cincinnati. The Rev. Jonathan Morris, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

headline: Dana Scardigli, Christopher Chiapparelli
text: Dana Michel Scardigli and Christopher Charles Chiapparelli were married Saturday evening at the Ocean Reef Club, a resort in Key Largo, Fla. The Rev. Lee G. Ganim, a minister of the International Council of Community Churches, officiated, with Charles A. Chiapparelli, the groom’s father, an associate judge of the District Court of Maryland in Baltimore, taking part.

headline: Jessica Leight and Amir Satvat
text: Jessica Ellen Leight, the daughter of Margaret Bruzelius and Peter W. Leight of Amherst, Mass., was married Saturday to Amir Satvat, the son of Ashraf Owlia Satvat and Dr. Behzad Satvat of Avon, Conn. The bride’s father officiated at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., having received a temporary authorization certificate from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

headline: Mariama Jerrell and Lesslie Boamah
text: Bonding Over a Poignant Story

headline: Amy Purnell, Daniel Silberman
text: Amy Clements Purnell and Daniel Craig Silberman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky at Guastavino’s, a restaurant in New York.

headline: Julie Moon, Reid Gustin
text: Julie Won Moon and Reid Byron Gustin were married Saturday at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York. The Rev. Annie Lawrence, an interfaith minister, officiated.

headline: Caitlin Smith, Carlo Frevert
text: Caitlin Ashley Smith and Carlo Friedrich Frevert were married Saturday by Sandra Sander, a registrar of civil marriages, who officiated at the Rathaus Schmargendorf, a town hall in Berlin.

headline: Nicole Eason, Gregory Collins Jr.
text: Nicole Michele Eason, the daughter of Marie E. Eason and Wayne S. Eason Sr. of Fort Worth, was married Saturday to Gregory Lee Collins Jr., a son of Carolyn S. Collins and Mr. Collins Sr. of Bear, Del. The Rev. S. Mark Haywood II, a cousin of the groom and a Baptist minister, officiated at the Adolphus hotel in Dallas.

headline: Corrections: April 14, 2013
text: NEW YORK

headline: Judge Rules Against Football Helmet Manufacturer
text: A jury in Colorado has found that Riddell, the country’s largest helmet manufacturer, was at fault for failure to adequately warn players wearing their football helmets about the dangers of potential concussions.

headline: A ‘Gangnam Style’ Escape From Korean Tensions
text: BEIJING — “Psy. I read about this guy named Psy in Korea,” the U.S. secretary of state, John Kerry, said Saturday, addressing Chinese and overseas reporters at a news briefing in Beijing, where he was visiting to discuss the high tensions on the Korean Peninsula, among other things.

headline: Coachella: Rap’s Web-Fueled Misfits
text: INDIO, Calif. — At Coachella, everything happens more or less on time, but 2 Chainz was late. His set on Saturday afternoon was meant to start at 4 p.m., but 4:05, 4:10 and 4:15 all passed without sight of him, his band reduced to playing a minute or so of “I’m Different,” which petered out, soon followed by boos.

headline: Wayne LaPierre: Behind the Rhetoric
text: The Times’s Jodi Kantor looks at how the National Rifle Association’s Wayne LaPierre has drawn strength from criticism directed at him since the school shooting in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Rebel Flag Flies Over a Province, and Indonesia Wants It Torn Down
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The Indonesian government has given the leaders of strife-torn Aceh Province until Tuesday to annul a bylaw passed last month that declares the banner of a former armed separatist movement to be the province’s official flag and seal.

headline: Should You Be Paying Taxes on Your Baby Sitter?
text: If you want to hear a pin drop, ask a room of parents whether they report employment taxes for their baby sitter or nanny. My (admittedly unscientific) conclusion, drawn from four years of Manhattan motherhood, is that many families do not. In a 2011 discussion of nanny compensation on Park Slope Parents, most families reported paying their caregivers completely off the books, while very few said they paid the tax. Susan Fox, founder of Park Slope Parents, suspects the off-the-books number among her readers is well over half.

headline: Milton Friedman, Currency Debaser
text: Brad DeLong links to a Forbes piece by Tim Lee from last year that I missed, which in turn quotes Milton Friedman on the macroeconomic views that prevailed in the early 1930s:

headline: Venezuela Goes to the Polls
text: The Times’s William Neuman reports from Caracas, Venezuela, on the morning of an election for the successor to Hugo Chávez, who died in March.

headline: A Purveyor of Brie, Prosciutto and Anthems
text: Thirty minutes before Stinky Bklyn opens for business, its proprietor strolls the floor singing in a powerhouse tenor to Parmigiano-Reggiano and hickory-smoked Benton’s bacon. He is not being a ham. Patrick Watson is getting his pipes in shape to sing the national anthem at the Barclays Center, where he is better known as the supplier of Stinky Brown Butter Rice Krispy Treats and the crumbled blue cheese topping on the Nathan’s Famous hot dogs sold at the concession stand.

headline: Highlights and Analysis From Masters
text: Adam Scott, 32, became the first Australian to win the Masters, defeating Angel Cabrera of Argentina in the second hole of the sudden-death playoff Sunday.

headline: Top Brass, Low Key
text: She is only 34, but there is already a statue of the glamorous trumpeter Alison Balsom standing in her hometown, Royston, England, where she grew up playing in a brass band.

headline: Rubio Offers Full-Throated Support for Immigration Bill
text: Senator Marco Rubio offered an extraordinary endorsement of legislation to overhaul the nation’s badly strained immigration system on Sunday when, after holding back for weeks, he appeared on no fewer than seven television talk shows to explain and defend a plan that he said would be “a net positive for the country, now and in the future.”

headline: Jackie Robinson Movie Has Strong Opening
text: Hollywood was predictably shocked over the weekend to find that a well-reviewed drama succeeded at the box office even though it was aimed at geriatric moviegoers (industry definition: anyone over the age of 25). The Jackie Robinson biopic “42” was a strong No. 1 at North American movie theaters, taking in about $27.3 million, according to its distributor, Warner Brothers. Legendary Entertainment spent a relatively modest $38 million to make the film, which performed best among older men, the hardest demographic for studios to reach.

headline: Rat Kidneys Made in Lab Point to Aid for Humans
text: Researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston have made functioning rat kidneys in the laboratory, a bioengineering achievement that may one day lead to the ability to create replacement organs for people with kidney disease.

headline: For Manchester City, F.A. Cup Final Offers a Consolation Prize
text: LONDON — On Saturday, there was ugliness at Wembley, as the bloodied faces of a group of Millwall fans — who pummeled one another, and the police, in the stands in a grim episode of in-game violence — overshadowed Wigan’s victory in an F.A. Cup semifinal. On Sunday, the lasting image of the second semifinal at England’s national stadium was more idyllic: a sea of light blue Manchester City fans, moving in unison as they danced, cheered and whipped their scarves around in giddy celebration of a thrilling 2-1 win over Chelsea.

headline: Students Face Tougher Tests That Outpace Lesson Plans
text: At Public School 10 on the edge of Park Slope, Brooklyn, parents begged the principal to postpone the lower school science fair, insisting it was going to add too much pressure while they were preparing their children for the coming state tests.

headline: Kerry Says North Korea Talks Are Possible, but Hints at Conditions
text: TOKYO — Secretary of State John Kerry said Sunday that the United States was prepared to reach out to Kim Jong-un of North Korea if he made the first move to abandon his nuclear weapons program.

headline: Centerpiece of Gun Bill Remains in Doubt
text: The Senate could vote as early as Tuesday on expanded background checks for gun buyers — a centerpiece of broad gun legislation — but leading lawmakers said Sunday that approval of the measure remained uncertain.

headline: For One Royal, History Has Added Insult to Injury
text: In February, when the British novelist Hilary Mantel delivered a lecture describing the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton, as a “plastic” princess “designed by a committee and built by craftsmen,” the response was swift and in some quarters furious. Prime Minister David Cameron dismissed the remarks as “completely misguided and completely wrong.” The Daily Mail denounced them as a “venomous attack.”

headline: Excerpt: 'The Call'
text: A scene from Tanya Barfield's play, a co-production between Playwrights Horizons and Primary Stages.

headline: End of Palestinian Power Play Muddles the Peace Process
text: JERUSALEM — Salam Fayyad, the internationally respected Palestinian politician and economist, is widely credited with ending the chaos in the West Bank and putting things in order in his six years as prime minister. But his resignation over the weekend, the result of internal power struggles, has left the Palestinian Authority suspended in political ambiguity and confusion.

headline: Mets and Twins Postpone Series Finale as Snow and Temperature Fall
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Most of the Mets never made it to Target Field from their hotel on Sunday morning.

headline: South Street Seaport Museum Has More Time
text: Although the South Street Seaport Museum has yet to recover from Hurricane Sandy, the Museum of the City of New York has agreed to continue running the museum for another three months.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Orian Almog and Joanne Yun joined Media6Degrees, New York, in new posts. Ms. Almog becomes an account executive; she had been a director at Cognitive Match, New York. Ms. Yun becomes director for sales strategy and operations; she had held various posts at the New York office of Google.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Flaws Seen in Protection of Animals on the Set
text: LOS ANGELES — On a film set, even the bugs bite by the book.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Quirks and All, a Group Welcomes a Playmate
text: The Bad Plus is an odd bird. The three members of this trio individually lean on specific languages of jazz improvisation, but collectively the band hesitates to get close to any single tradition. It likes to build a crescendo past the point of comfort, or move extremely slowly, or structure a kind of pop song with irresolutions and gravitational tempo shifts and wild staggers, or pump stiff grandiosity into something simple and scratchy. It plays, a little perversely, with putting on a hard shell. It exaggerates with a straight face and builds self-contained events within themselves rather than partial re-enactments of an open-ended story, which is what most jazz is.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Wallace Appears Close to Returning and Reminding Fans He Still Plays for Knicks
text: Rasheed Wallace, the Knicks veteran with the scruffy beard, has been on the court before games for the last month practicing his jumper, mostly from behind the 3-point line. He may get the chance to do it in a situation that counts when the Knicks visit the Charlotte Bobcats on Monday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include the Consumer Price Index, housing starts and industrial production for March (Tuesday); the Federal Reserve’s beige book (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims and leading economic indicators for March (Thursday).

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in St. Louis
text: ST. LOUIS — The most surprising result during the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams here last month was when Sabine Auken; Morten Bilde and Dennis Bilde (Morten’s son) from Denmark; and Roy Welland of New York City defeated Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness). With 16 boards to play, Monaco led by 56 international match points and was fielding two of the world’s top-ranked pairs. With their rankings in parentheses, these were Fantoni (1) and Nunes (2); and Helgemo (9) and Helness (10).

headline: Psy’s New Video Is a Quick Web Hit
text: The Korean pop singer known as Psy, who gained global notoriety last year when his song “Gangnam Style” became an Internet sensation, released a new single over the weekend, and many were quick to notice. In a little over a day, the video for the song, “Gentleman,” attracted more than 32 million views on YouTube after it had its premiere on Saturday during a concert in Seoul.

headline: In Little Italy, Saving the Past by Rebuilding It
text: The 19th-century brick building that houses the Italian American Museum in the Little Italy neighborhood of Manhattan radiates an Old World intimacy, with its tin ceiling and its proximity to shops that still sell slices of pink prosciutto and balls of snow-white mozzarella.

headline: Booksellers Hoping for Pulitzer in Fiction
text: At the Community Bookstore in Park Slope in Brooklyn last Wednesday, booksellers were happily engaged in an annual parlor game of the publishing industry: guessing which title might win the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for fiction on Monday.

headline: Flaunting the Spirit of Support for the Arts
text: LINZ, Austria — This industrial city of almost 200,000 midway between Vienna and Salzburg, and the capital of the state of Upper Austria, has long had a bit of an inferiority complex when it comes to culture. So it seemed, at least, in a series of slightly defensive speeches by government and arts figures on Thursday evening at the opening of the new Linz Opera House, formally known as the Musiktheater am Volksgarten, referring to the public park it adjoins.

headline: Losing a Step, Nike Seeks to Regain Its Edge
text: Lost in the middle of a debate last month over a Nike ad that congratulated Tiger Woods for regaining his ranking as the world’s No. 1 golfer was that people were talking about a Nike ad.

headline: This Caesar Wears an African Cloak
text: The blood runs warm in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s vibrant production of “Julius Caesar,” now at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Experience has taught the inhabitants of the African country in which this Shakespeare tragedy has ingeniously been reset that life is tenuous and easily taken. Their fears lie close to the surface, quick to tumble into anger, despair and, on occasion, a joy that remains edged in apprehension.

headline: A Child’s Video Tour of Her Family’s Garden
text: An enduring question these days is how to engage children with nature given how much time they spend looking at screens of one size or another.  I’ve written off and on about the merits of hybrid experience, …

headline: What Makes a Crowd
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Gayle Dean was a prolific crossword puzzle constructor in the pre-Shortzian era (prior to 1993) and she’s had a few puzzles since then, but we haven’t seen here since 2001. Ms. Dean is back today with a lesson in Yiddish.

headline: Racing Against Time to Save a Young Star
text: When was the last time you were impressed by a makeover? In the hands of New York’s finest blond-highlighters, blow-dry artists and cheekbone illusionists, almost any woman can dazzle for 24 hours. But Tara Taylor’s transformation in “Futurology the Musical” is something else.

headline: Scenes from Coachella
text: More photographs from the music festival in Indio, Calif.

headline: Aliens Invaded, and the Future Looks Like the Old West
text: The new television show “Defiance” has received so much attention for being joined at the hip to a video game that the wrong questions are being asked about it. How the TV series and the online game — which share characters and stories but take place in different parts of a post-alien-invasion earth, circa 2046 — will inform each other is more than a little beside the point, especially since the show’s first season is already shot and won’t be affected by the game.

headline: More Cracks Undermine the Citadel of TV Profits
text: For the longest time in the media business, the concept of the bundle has been foundational. Ads go with editorial content in print, commercials go with programming on television and the channels you desire are paired with ones you did not in your cable package.

headline: Crossroads Guitar Festival
text: Scenes from Eric Clapton’s festival at Madison Square Garden.

headline: The Blues Mix and Mingle With Soul, Country and Rock
text: The blues was the center of the guitar universe at Eric Clapton’s Crossroads Guitar Festival, two all-star concerts with more than 30 guitarists on Friday and Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Classical and Modern, Partners in the Spirit
text: After nearly 10 years on hiatus, Dance Theater of Harlem is back. Its return performance on Wednesday at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center, though flawed, gave reasons enough to celebrate. But its second program, on Friday, opened with something more heartening: “Gloria,” a beautiful New York premiere by the company’s resident choreographer, Robert Garland.

headline: Intel Tries to Secure Its Footing Beyond PCs
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — For the last several months, Andy Bryant, the chairman of Intel, has been trying to put steel in the backs of the company’s employees. At meetings, he tells them that Intel must fundamentally change even though the computer chip maker still has what it takes to succeed in engineering and manufacturing.

headline: Upon a Rotating Set, a Shift of Siegmunds in Wagner Performance
text: “Die Walküre” returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday, and the machine worked without noticeable hitches. Yes, that machine, the 45-ton set consisting of 24 rotating planks that dominates this production from the director Robert Lepage. These days an element of tension hovers over each performance from Wagner’s epic cycle, back for the first run this season at the Met, because you never know when the machine might malfunction, as happened on April 6 during “Das Rheingold.”

headline: More Snow Could Be in Mets’ Future
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Light early-morning snow showers and an ominous forecast prompted the Minnesota Twins to postpone Sunday’s game with the Mets before some people had their breakfast. The Twins e-mailed the announcement at 8:53 a.m. Central time.

headline: Support Grows for European Effort to Fight Tax Havens
text: DUBLIN — Europe’s effort to crack down on tax havens gained momentum during the weekend as the number of countries agreeing to share more bank information doubled.

headline: Sabathia’s Star Comedic Turn
text: The Yankees’ C.C. Sabathia is expanding his horizons as a commercial actor. In a new spot for ESPN’s “SportsCenter” that comes out Monday, Sabathia gives a marvelous deadpan comedic performance along with the ESPN hosts Steve Levy and Scott Van Pelt in an ad that plays off Sabathia’s heft.

headline: BBC Tactics in Covering North Korea Are Faulted
text: As tensions escalated between North Korea and the world late last month, a small group of students from the prestigious London School of Economics crossed the border into the reclusive country for what was described by organizers as a government-sanctioned “week of sight seeing, meeting with ministers, government officials” and academics.

headline: Knicks Win and Get What They Want: Matchup vs. Celtics
text: The scene was set Sunday afternoon at Madison Square Garden — for payback, for message-sending, for a modest celebration and for a timely, well-earned rest. All the Knicks needed on this first day of the final week of the season was a sound victory over the Indiana Pacers. That, and four quarters without anyone being bruised, battered or broken.

headline: NPR Series on Race Aims to Build a Wider Audience
text: NPR’s race, ethnicity and culture reporting initiative will make its broadcast debut this week with a four-part series called “Changing Races” for the morning and evening news programs.

headline: A Trudeau Again Leads Canada Party
text: OTTAWA — Justin Trudeau was elected leader of the embattled Liberal Party of Canada on Sunday, 45 years after his charismatic and contentious father, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, assumed the same political position.

headline: Random House Adds a Big Name in Fitness
text: David Zinczenko, the former Rodale Inc. executive with a talent for self-promotion and sculpturing physiques, has signed on with Random House to provide some juice to its health and fitness offerings.

headline: German Elites Drawn to Anti-Euro Party, Spelling Trouble for Merkel
text: BERLIN — With less than six months to go before parliamentary elections in Germany, a new political party that is calling for an end to the European currency union is gaining strength.

headline: U.S. Rethinks How to Respond to Nuclear Disaster
text: WASHINGTON — Two years after the Fukushima nuclear accident in northern Japan, the United States government is using lessons from that disaster to rewrite its plans for responding to radiation contamination, focusing on long-term cleanup instead of emergency response. But the proposals have set off vehement opposition from critics of nuclear power.

headline: Coordinated Blasts Kill at Least 20 in Somalia’s Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Militants carried out a suicide attack on the court complex here, and a bomb was detonated later on the airport road, in a coordinated wave of violence Sunday in the Somali capital that left at least 20 people dead, officials said.

headline: Once-Maligned Coin Nears Its Big Payday
text: On the rainy night of March 9, 1962, a head-on car crash scattered a quarter-million dollars’ worth of coins across a North Carolina highway, and the life story of a solitary collector named George O. Walton came to an end. But another story began — one of expert blunders, abiding family loyalty and long-awaited redemption.

headline: Venezuela Gives Chávez Protégé Narrow Victory
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — In an unexpectedly close race, Venezuelans narrowly voted to continue Hugo Chávez’s revolution, electing his handpicked political heir, Nicolás Maduro, to serve the remainder of his six-year term as president, officials said late Sunday.

headline: A Capricious River, an Indian Island’s Lifeline, Now Eats Away at It
text: MAJULI, India — Not too long ago, Ganesh Hazarika grew rice, vegetables and peas near the edge of the Brahmaputra River on a small plot that provided him a livelihood and a safety net. Then one day the river took it away. Steadily and mercilessly, it had chewed at the banks until his tiny farm fell into the water.

headline: Europeans Reach Deal With Google on Searches
text: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators into whether it abuses its dominance of online search.

headline: Afghan Interpreters for the U.S. Are Left Stranded and at Risk
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The first time the Taliban tried to kill him, Sulaiman was driving to his base when his truck was hit by a rocket, knocking him down a cliff.

headline: For Guan, a Week to Savor
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At the last hole, Guan Tianlang retrieved his ball from the cup after ending his first Masters with his 48th par. The fans ringing the 18th green gave him a standing ovation. They no doubt were thinking that they had not seen the last of Guan, a 14-year-old from China who finished as the low amateur.

headline: A Top Producer Leaves ‘Katie’ for CNN
text: Jeff Zucker, who left Katie Couric’s syndicated talk show, “Katie,” at the end of last year to take over CNN Worldwide, is bringing in one of the show’s top producers to join him.

headline: In Testimony, Guatemalans Give Account of Suffering
text: MEXICO CITY — They were just children when Guatemalan soldiers rampaged through their villages, often killing their parents and siblings. Many fled to mountain forests, where they foraged for food and watched some of their numbers starve to death.  Some were abducted and sent to other families to be raised, in cities and towns far from the life they had known.

headline: A Mill’s Fate Weighs Heavy on a Washington Timber Town
text: HOQUIAM, Wash. — On mornings with good weather, Jack Durney has coffee in the backyard of his house overlooking the town where he grew up and now presides over as mayor, and one of the first things he focuses on these days is the boiler stack at Harbor Paper. Is there steam coming from the mill?

headline: Bryant Goes Away, but Not Quietly
text: LOS ANGELES — Kobe Bryant is no stranger to social media. In recent months, he has treated his millions of followers on Twitter and Facebook to pictures of his breakfast. He has espoused the virtues of sleep aids. He has shared inspirational quotations. And, in a nod to the all-consuming commerce of his chosen profession, he has cited his various sponsors, which include watchmakers, apparel companies and an airline based in Turkey.

headline: The Antisocial Network
text: Bitcoin’s wild ride may not have been the biggest business story of the past few weeks, but it was surely the most entertaining. Over the course of less than two weeks the price of the “digital currency” more than tripled. Then it fell more than 50 percent in a few hours. Suddenly, it felt as if we were back in the dot-com era.

headline: If Companies Are People...
text: HERE’S an idea: why not tax corporations as if they were natural persons, in accordance with their newly discovered rights of free speech? That move would solve any impending fiscal crisis.

headline: Branko: Return to Auschwitz
text: Branko Lustig, a Holocaust survivor and Oscar-winning producer of “Schindler’s List,” returns to Auschwitz for the bar mitzvah he couldn’t have in his youth.

headline: As Wall St. Soars in Tough Era, Company Size Is a Big Factor
text: It’s tough to make sense of the economy these days.

headline: ‘Branko: Return to Auschwitz’
text: April 15 marks the 68th anniversary of Branko Lustig’s liberation from the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp when he was not quite 13 years old. In this Op-Doc video, we follow Mr. Lustig back to Poland to visit the Auschwitz and Birkenau camps (where he was also interned) and to celebrate the bar mitzvah he could never have as a young man.

headline: Daniel Reich, 39, Resourceful Art Dealer, Dies
text: Daniel Reich, a scrappy and innovative New York art dealer who held exhibitions for two years in his tiny studio apartment and, even after renting a traditional gallery, continued to show art nomadically in places like the Chelsea Hotel and a former delicatessen in Midtown, died on Dec. 25 at his parents’ home in Larchmont, N.Y., his sister confirmed this week. He was 39.

headline: On Guns, a Mixed Report From the States
text: The good, the bad and the ugly are emerging from statehouses across the nation as lawmakers address wildly different gun proposals prompted by the Newtown, Conn., massacre in December.

headline: Parties’ Rifts Hinder Background Check Measure in Gun Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Deep divisions within both parties over a bipartisan measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are threatening its chances as the Senate this week begins debating the first broad gun control legislation in nearly 20 years.

headline: Justices Consider Whether Patents on Genes Are Valid
text: The Supreme Court is poised to take up the highly charged question of whether human genes can be patented. But another question could trump it: Has the field of genetics moved so far so fast that whatever the court decides, it has come too late to the issue?

headline: Past Failures Vanish as Australian Wins Masters
text: AUGUSTA, Ga. — With two strokes using his long putter, once considered the dullest tool in his bag, Adam Scott expunged one bitter memory that was 266 days old and another that had lingered in a country’s consciousness for 17 years. Scott became the first Australian to win the Masters when he drained a 12-foot birdie putt on the second playoff hole Sunday and defeated Ángel Cabrera of Argentina, whose birdie bid moments earlier had died on the edge of the cup.

headline: Are Human Genes Patentable?
text: BRCA1 and BRCA2, abbreviations for breast cancer 1 and 2, are the names of human genes linked to a significant increase in the risk of breast and ovarian cancer for women. In 1997 and 1998, Myriad Genetics, based in Utah, obtained broad patents on the isolated DNA it managed to extract from these genes and on diagnostic tests to find the genes.

headline: Carmen Weinstein, Who Led the Jews of Cairo, Dies at 82
text: CAIRO — Carmen Weinstein, the leader of Cairo’s small Jewish community and the driving force behind the restoration of Maimonides’s yeshiva and other monuments of Egyptian Jewish history, died on Saturday at her home here on the island of Zamalek. She was 82.

headline: Europe’s Bitter Medicine
text: For more than two years, European leaders have pushed a cocktail of fiscal austerity and structural reforms on troubled countries like Portugal, Spain and Italy, promising that it will be the tonic to cure their economic and financial ailments. All the evidence shows that this bitter medicine is killing the patient.

headline: Cowboys and Eggheads
text: My Times colleague Mark Mazzetti has a new book out that is getting a lot of attention, including some cinematic excerpts published in The Times, here and here. “The Way of the Knife” recounts the recent transformation of the Central Intelligence Agency from a traditional spying shop into more of a man-hunting paramilitary — custodian of lethal drones, sponsor of dark ops, employer of secret armies and shady contractors.

headline: A Tax System Stacked Against the 99 Percent
text: LEONA HELMSLEY, the hotel chain executive who was convicted of federal tax evasion in 1989, was notorious for, among other things, reportedly having said that “only the little people pay taxes.”

headline: A Missouri School Trains Its Teachers to Carry Guns, and Most Parents Approve
text: WEST PLAINS, Mo. — At 8:30 on a cloudy, frigid morning late last month in this folksy Ozark town, the superintendent of an area school strolled through the glass doors of the local newspaper office to deliver a news release.

headline: Highest-Paid Hedge Fund Managers
text: A number of hedge-fund leaders had mega paydays last year by posting big returns on their investments.

headline: Should Tax Rates Penalize Marriage?
text: Federal tax rates discourage dual-income couples from marrying, and encourage single-earner couples to marry. Does this mixed message make sense?

headline: Capitalism in History Class
text: To the Editor:

headline: Latin, Here to Stay
text: To the Editor:

headline: Condoms on Campus
text: To the Editor:

headline: Silencing Witnesses to Animal Abuse
A Lesson at Rutgers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Support for Bronx Activist
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gitmo Is Killing Me
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba

headline: Woods’s Odd Journey Through Golf’s Majors
text: AUGUSTA, Ga.

headline: David Burge, Pianist, Is Dead at 83
text: David Burge, an American pianist and composer known as an indefatigable champion of 20th-century music, died on April 1 in Warwick, R.I. He was 83.

headline: Adoption Anxiety, Long Before the Child Arrives
text: Annie (Kerry Butler), the troubled heroine of “The Call,” a thoughtful and engrossing new play by Tanya Barfield, finds herself staring down a problem that has become more widespread as women marry later, postponing parenting choices as they become caught up in the anxious business of pursuing careers — or should I say just earning their livelihoods.

headline: Hey, Diana, Smokey, Stevie: You’re on Broadway!
text: The hit parade reels on seemingly forever in “Motown: The Musical,” a dramatically slapdash but musically vibrant trip back to the glory days of Detroit, where the vinyl pouring out of an unassuming two-story house took the world by storm, all but paving the city’s streets with gold records.

headline: Stubbornness Behind Pitcher’s Career Path
text: CHICAGO — The questions that Chicago Cubs starter Jeff Samardzija faces today are different from the ones he used to get. Two years ago, people wanted to know if Samardzija, a former all-American wide receiver at Notre Dame, was on his way out of baseball, if he had picked the wrong sport, whether, at 26, he was a has-been football player and a never-was baseball player.

headline: Weiner, Exploring Possible Mayoral Bid, Issues Policy Booklet With Familiar Ring
text: As he seeks to extend the discussion about a possible candidacy for mayor — and shift attention away from the online sex-messaging scandal that cost him his Congressional seat — Anthony D. Weiner released a 21-page policy booklet on Sunday that he described as a blueprint for keeping New York City “the capital of the middle class.”

headline: Sir Colin Davis, British Conductor, Dies at 85
text: April 16 | Correction appended. A full obituary for Mr. Davis is published here.

headline: Small Leak Is Discovered at Plant in Fukushima
text: TOKYO — Efforts to remove highly contaminated water from a leaking underground storage pool at the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant were delayed on Sunday when the plant’s operator said it had found yet another leak, this time in the pipes that would be used to move the water to above-ground storage containers.

headline: MetroCards for the Poor? No Asking in Stations
text: The sums are a pittance — spare quarters and dimes, perhaps less in some cases — left behind on the unwanted MetroCards tossed to the station floor.

headline: The Doctor Is In, but Hundreds of Miles Away
text: High in a Manhattan skyscraper near Grand Central Terminal on a recent Tuesday, 80 critically ill patients in intensive care units scattered from Georgia to New Jersey were being monitored, remotely, by a doctor scanning a dozen computer screens.

headline: Restroom on Boardwalk Threatens Luxury Views
text: The residents of the Oceana, a luxury apartment complex that sits next to the boardwalk at Coney Island Avenue in Brighton Beach, take pride in their million-dollar ocean views — or, more precisely, their up to $2 million condominium ocean views.

headline: Besedka Johnson, Late-Blooming Actress, Dies at 87
text: Besedka Johnson, who was plucked from obscurity and made a star by a movie producer who had spotted her swimming one summer in Southern California — when she was 85 — died on April 4 in Glendale, Calif. She was 87.

headline: Eldest Statesman Plays for Pure Enjoyment With Championship Hopes
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Teemu Selanne was in a deep recess of Honda Center, talking about life as a 42-year-old N.H.L. star and as the chiseled, aging face of a franchise filled with hope and Stanley Cup aspirations.

headline: The Derby Dartboard
text: A points system is now being used to determine the field for the Kentucky Derby, replacing the use of graded-stakes earnings. Points are earned by the top four finishers in prep races and records are starts-win-place-show. An article on the Blue Grass Stakes and the Arkansas Derby on Saturday can be found here.

headline: J.F.K. Runway Run
text: Runners compete in the annual 5K race at Kennedy International Airport in Queens.

headline: A Different Way of Taking Off at J.F.K.
text: As a pilot, Alexander Richards spends a fair amount of his time on runways. But as he arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport in Queens early Sunday morning, he had a different flight plan in mind: he was going to run on the runway.

headline: In Surprise, Recovery in China Loses Steam
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese economic recovery lost some of its momentum during the first quarter of this year, official data released on Monday showed, surprising analysts who had expected growth to accelerate on the back of ample credit, strong infrastructure spending and firm exports.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 14, 2013

headline: Acclaim Comes Late for Baseball Pioneer
text: When the mayor of Cooperstown, N.Y., Jeff Katz, searched for an appropriate street to dedicate in Bud Fowler’s memory, he decided on one that led to Doubleday Field, the quaint brick stadium a baseball’s throw from the Hall of Fame. An old survey of the village indicated that the street had not been named, Katz said.

headline: The Sight of Granderson Serves as a Welcome, if Distant, Sign
