text: Perhaps the injury news for the Yankees is finally beginning to improve. The arrival of the injured outfielder Curtis Granderson in the clubhouse Sunday was a welcomed sign that some help is on the way.

headline: Courts in Slow Motion, Aided by the Defense
text: The grand exhibition hall of dawdlers that is the Bronx courthouse features procrastinating prosecutors, sluggish jailers and unhurried judges. But the true masters of delay are the defense lawyers. For them, muddled memories and lost witnesses — the passage of time itself — are the ingredients for getting clients off.

headline: Yankees’ Kuroda and Cast of Understudies Subdue Orioles
text: It has been six months since the Yankees edged the Baltimore Orioles in the American League division series, although in many respects, for the winners, it has felt like six awfully long years.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 15
text: “Smaller companies face greater headwinds. Is it G.E. or Caterpillar who will be hurt? Of course not. It’s Joe’s Deli.”

headline: Minnesota N.A.S.L. Club Takes a Stand for Tolerance
text: Nick Rogers, a Liverpool fan, had a cringe-worthy experience when his North American Soccer League team was relaunched, rebranded and renamed Minnesota United.

headline: A Chat With the Boston Fed’s Chief
text: Eric S. Rosengren, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, said in an interview that he wanted to see the economy adding at least 200,000 jobs a month in addition to a declining unemployment rate before he would be ready to consider scaling back the Fed’s efforts to stimulate the economy.

headline: Avoiding Emergency Rooms
text: On a recent Sunday afternoon, a 75-year-old Philadelphia man with a fever of over 102 degrees was unable to reach his doctor. So his daughter took him to an emergency room, where the two sat for hours until he was examined by a physician who found no reason for the fever and decided to admit him overnight.

headline: Combating Tech’s Conflict Minerals With Disclosure
text: 2:49 p.m. | Updated with announcement.Some of our most advanced technology products have helped finance the deadliest conflicts of our time. Perhaps, if tech companies change some of their habits, that can change.

headline: AMC Shifts a Series to Saturdays, but Not to Kill It
text: For almost a decade, Saturday night has been television’s version of Boot Hill — where series go to die.

headline: Live Music’s Charms, Soothing Premature Hearts
text: Even the Beatles would have had trouble recognizing their peppy song in the lullaby that Andrea Zalkin sang to the tiny, fragile baby clutched to her chest in the neonatal unit. But there was something unintentionally poignant in the title she chose for her son: “Eight Days a Week” is more time than can fit on the calendar. Ms. Zalkin’s baby, Hudson, born 13 weeks early, has had too little time.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (13) WONDER WOMEN! THE UNTOLD STORY OF AMERICAN SUPERHEROINES In this “Independent Lens” presentation, the director Kristy Guevara-Flanagan and the producer Kelcey Edwards chronicle the evolution of Wonder Woman, from her genesis in 1941 as a DC Comics character — the creation of William Moulton Marston, a Harvard-trained pop psychologist — to present-day incarnations and what she says about society’s feelings toward powerful women. Among those interviewed are the ’70s television stars Lynda Carter (the “New Original Wonder Woman” TV film and the series “The New Adventures of Wonder Woman”), above, and Lindsay Wagner (“The Bionic Woman”) and the feminist writer and activist Gloria Steinem.

headline: Hedge Fund Titans’ Pay Stretching to 10 Figures
text: In recent years, the criticism about giant Wall Street hedge funds — those that command billions of investor dollars from pension funds, endowments and the wealthy — is that they’re simply too big to beat the market.

headline: Rivals in the Showroom, Ford and G.M. Will Develop Transmissions Jointly
text: Ford Motor and General Motors announced on Monday that they would jointly develop new transmissions with 9 speeds for front-wheel-drive vehicles and 10 speeds for rear-drive cars and trucks. The new transmissions, with more forward gear ratios than either company now offers, are expected to reach the market beginning in 2016.

headline: In Surprise, Recovery in China Loses Steam
text: HONG KONG — China’s newly installed leadership is facing a major challenge on the economic front, after data released Monday showed that the country’s growth had unexpectedly lost momentum in the first quarter, complicating Beijing’s efforts to promote higher-quality output that relies less on credit-fueled investment.

Can Bengali ‘Mishti’ Go Global?
text: KOLKATA— In West Bengal, it’s easy to find confectioners that have been making Bengali sweets, known as mishti, for more than a century. There, you will find sandesh (a soft, fudge-like confection made with cottage cheese and sugar), and roshogolla (balls of cottage cheese poured into hot sugary syrup) as they have been made for decades.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 15
text: NEWS In an unexpectedly close race, Venezuelans narrowly voted to continue Hugo Chávez’s revolution, electing his handpicked political heir, Nicolás Maduro, to serve the remainder of his six-year term as president, officials said late Sunday. William Neuman reports from Caracas.

headline: San Jose’s Gordon Faces Discipline Over Antigay Slur
text: Tuesday, 5:07 p.m. | Updated San Jose Earthquakes forward Alan Gordon was suspended for three games by Major League Soccer on Tuesday afternoon for directing an antigay slur at an opponent during a game against Portland on Sunday night. Gordon also was fined an undisclosed amount by Commissioner Don Garber and ordered to take part in diversity and sensitivity training.

headline: Japan’s Rootless and Restless Workers
text: A dark suit jacket hangs by a shaded window, beneath a portrait of a smiling, well-dressed executive.

headline: Should Colleges Fund Wellness Programs Instead of Sports?
text: Six sports teams at Spelman College, a historically black women’s college in Atlanta, have been disbanded. A seventh, the tennis team, will wrap up its operations by the end of the month. The money that would have been spent on collegiate sports will now fund wellness programming for the whole campus.

headline: Production of Opium by Afghans Is Up Again
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the third year in a row, opium cultivation has increased across Afghanistan, erasing earlier drops stemming from a decade-long international and Afghan government effort to combat the drug trade, according to a United Nations report released on Monday.

headline: Greece Reaches a Deal for More Bailout Money
text: ATHENS — After nearly two weeks of tense negotiations, Greece and its troika of foreign creditors said Monday that they had clinched an agreement on economic measures that Athens must enforce to secure the release of further crucial rescue money. Those measures include thousands of layoffs in the civil service.

headline: Attackers Strike Across Iraq as Elections Approach
text: BAGHDAD — Attackers struck targets across Iraq on Monday morning, setting a bloody backdrop to the last week of campaigning as Iraqis prepare to vote in local elections on Saturday.

headline: Mesut Özil: Real Madrid’s Engine Room
text: The International Film Festival in Berlin earlier this year debuted a short documentary about a 17-year-old soccer player playing at Schalke in 2006. What initially began as a look at youth soccer in Germany in general turned into a focus on a certain Mesut Özil. Although shy, timid and soft-spoken in conversation, his commanding abilities on the field demanded the full attention of the camera lenses and the filmmakers.

text: LONDON – Creditors of the European division of the defunct American bank Lehman Brothers may recover all their money, according to a report from the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers.

headline: Federal Regulators Warn of 15-Passenger Van Rollover Danger
text: Spring has sprung, so more people will be out on America’s roadways soon on their way to and from warm-weather activities. Many will be riding in 15-passenger vans, and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says watch out: the risk of rollover in an overloaded van is high, and rollover crashes can be fatal.

headline: Gold Does Not Glitter
text: So, the slide in gold has turned into a rout. As Joe Weisenthal says, this should be seen as really good news, because it offers strong evidence that the goldbug/inflationista view of the world — which says that we need to stop all efforts at monetary and fiscal stimulus lest we turn into Weimar — is, in fact, all wrong.

headline: Dish’s $25.5 Billion Offer for Sprint
text: Dish Network offered on Monday to buy Sprint Nextel for $25.5 billion in cash and stock, challenging the planned takeover of Sprint by the Japanese telecommunications company SoftBank. The offer of $7 a share is worth about 13 percent more than the SoftBank proposal, Dish said in a statement. “The Dish proposal clearly presents Sprint shareholders with a superior alternative to the pending SoftBank proposal,” Charles W. Ergen, chairman of Dish, said in a statement. The Dish offer, he added, would yield “substantial synergies that are not attainable through the pending SoftBank proposal.” SoftBank has proposed a $20.1 billion deal to acquire a 70 percent stake in Sprint.

text: 9:36 a.m. | Updated

headline: A Better Baby Lullaby
text: New research finds that live music played for premature babies can be beneficial, calming their heart rate and breathing, and helping their sleep and sucking ability.

headline: Europe in Brief
text: Tim Duy asks, when can we all admit that the euro is a failure? The answer, of course, is never. Too much history, too many declarations, too much ego is invested in the single currency for those involved ever to admit that maybe they made a mistake. Even if the project ends in total disaster, they will insist that the euro didn’t fail Europe, Europe failed the euro.

headline: ‘Lean In’ Software Goes Corporate

headline: Anne Frank House Says Bieber’s Visit Was ‘Positive’

text: The prices of stocks and gold appeared to chase each other sharply lower on Monday after a report said growth unexpectedly slowed in China.

headline: Climate Change Didn’t Cause the Big Drought
text: THE HAGUE — During his most recent State of the Union Address, President Barack Obama cited the Great Plains drought last year as an example of extreme weather caused by climate change.

headline: Supermodel and Draft-Dodger
text: TEL AVIV — The Foreign Ministry, always on the lookout for ways to make Israel’s image trendier, recently asked the supermodel Bar Refaeli, one of the country’s most famous celebrities, to lead an ad campaign promoting Israeli technology and innovation abroad. She agreed, free of charge. Apparently it was a success: “My Instagram feed has more readers than Israel’s most popular newspaper,” Refaeli bragged in a tweet.

headline: A Conversation With: Singer Chandrika Krishnamurthy Tandon
text: NEW YORK CITY — On her newest album, the singer Chandrika Krishnamurthy Tandon has reimagined “Raghupati Raghav Raja Ram,” a devotional bhajan, or hymn, in different musical traditions including Brazilian bossa nova and Chinese rhythms. Some of the tunes are fast-paced, others more meditative, but the lead voice is always unmistakably Ms. Tandon’s.

headline: Justices Refuse Case on Gun Law in New York
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said Monday that it would not weigh in on a major Second Amendment question that has divided the lower courts: May states bar or strictly limit the carrying of guns in public for self-defense?

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Smithsonian: Don’t fret the invasion of the cicadas. Fry them up! Here are some tips for how to collect and prepare them for eating. Our favorite is No. 2: gather twice as many as you and your family think you can eat. — Maria Newman

headline: Swoon Over Augusta
text: Ever since Adam Scott dropped to his knees after his putt plunked into the cup on the second playoff hole at the Masters Sunday evening, golf has been in full swoon. The golfing gods couldn’t have come up with a champion they’d love more if had they drawn him up in an animation studio. He is young and fun and personable and as the young female portion of his fan base would say, adorbs! Australians, of course, are over the moon. They can now forget that whole Greg Norman thing ever happened. And the stuffy old men in the green eyeshades who run golf? They’d be forming a conga line if they did that sort of thing. Scott gives their moldering sport a shot of curb appeal lacking since the legend of Tiger Woods lost a battle with a fire hydrant.

headline: Triple Play: Week 2 Results
text: The perhaps overachieving Mets have a better record than their crosstown rivals, but they are the correct answer to Question No. 1 thanks to the hot start by the Atlanta Braves.

headline: Brown Rice and the Arsenic Conundrum
text: I’ve always been a big promoter of brown rice, and I was happily testing recipes last week for short-, medium- and long-grain varieties when I remembered that there had been reports in the past year about dangerous arsenic levels in rice, particularly in brown rice. I thought about shelving the recipe tests and choosing another subject for this week’s Recipes for Health, but then I decided to take a closer look at the reports to see if there was a way to make rice viable for health-conscious rice lovers.

headline: Why E.T.F.’s Won’t Solve Our Behavioral Problems
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: Tip of the Week: Magnifying Smartly on the Mac
text: The Preview app included with Mac OS X does more than just open images and PDF files. While the program can zoom in and out of open PDF files (and even display the document in a full-screen view), the Smart Magnify feature in Preview for OS X 10.7 (and later) enlarges a specific area of the document quickly.

headline: Kerry Meets With Parents of Diplomat Killed in Afghanistan
text: CHICAGO — Secretary of State John Kerry met here privately on Monday with the parents of Anne Smedinghoff, the young State Department officer who was killed this month in Afghanistan. She was the first State Department officer to die in the line of duty since the September attack on the United States diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: Dealing With a Laid-Back Software Vendor
text: In a post published last month, Susan Parker, a member of the She Owns It business group, shared some of her frustrations about working with a software vendor that didn’t seem to share her sense of urgency. Her company, Bari Jay, has been in the process of switching to new software for more than a year. During a recent conversation, Ms. Parker reviewed the status of the project, which was supposed to take three months, and she responded to reader comments on the earlier post.

headline: Safer Hospital Rooms
text: C. difficile contamination of hospital rooms is a leading cause of deadly infections, and human behavior may be at least as important as technological innovation in controlling it. A new study has found that imposing a three-step cleaning procedure — and supervising it carefully — can nearly eliminate the microbe.

headline: Walkabout – 4/15: Vandalism in Joshua Tree; More Troubles for Boeing
text: Defacing an American Gem Graffiti has become so pervasive at Joshua Tree National Park’s most popular hiking spots that officials have had to close them to the public. Some say social media is to blame for the bump in vandalism. (USA Today)

headline: The Boat Captain Puzzle
text: We’ve got something a bit different this week — several cryptic word-logic puzzles of the sort that will be featured at the upcoming Stanford Puzzle Hunt, a one-day team competition taking place Saturday at Stanford University. Before we give the puzzles a try, let’s warm up with this classic boating challenge from the math educator and problem-solving expert George Polya’s 1974 classic Stanford Mathematics Problem Book.

headline: Hill Country’s Draft Lines Finally Flow With Shiner
text: Since it opened in Manhattan in the summer of 2007, Hill Country Barbecue Market has had draft lines. But they remained dry. Only one beer would do, and it wasn’t available.

headline: Off-Duty Officer Killed Boyfriend, Their Year-Old Son and Then Herself, Police Say
text: To those on the outside, the couple seemed content, spending time together on a quiet block in Brooklyn, working at solid city-paid jobs and delighting in their infant son.

headline: Challenges Mount for China’s President
text: Whatever honeymoon President Xi Jinping of China may have been having appears to be over. If you think you are having a difficult Monday, consider his challenges.

headline: What Your Tax Dollars Are Buying
text: Today – and I hope this does not come as a surprise to any of you – is tax day, when we are required to settle our bills with the federal government for the year 2012. Given how much we pay to Washington every year, it seems only fair that we ask for a receipt.

headline: Stir-Fried Brown Rice With Kale or Frizzy Mustard Greens and Tofu
text: I used a beautiful green I’d never seen before called frizzy mustard greens for this quick and easy stir-fry. They look like a cross between frisée and curly kale and have a sharp, mustardy kick. Curly kale makes a fine substitute. Also, you can substitute white rice for the brown.

headline: A Long Pursuit of Self
text: Lizzy Hawker had just finished running a nine-stage race through some of Nepal’s wildest trails when she learned that her flight back to Katmandu, about 200 miles away, was canceled because of bad weather.

headline: Isabel Leonard Wins Richard Tucker Award
text: The Richard Tucker Foundation said on Monday that the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard had won its award named after the American tenor. The award, which comes with a $30,000 prize, is conferred on singers who the foundation deems are about to plunge into major international careers, and it often makes good calls. Past winners include Angela Meade, Joyce DiDonato, John Relyea, Matthew Polenzani, Deborah Voigt and Renée Fleming.

headline: Beet Greens and Rice Gratin
text: Like so many of my Mediterranean gratins, this is bound with a combination of rice and egg. It’s good hot or cold.

headline: Dish Network Courts Sprint
text: Dish Network is bidding to buy Sprint Nextel to be able to offer consumers a competitive package combining broadband and cellphone service.

headline: Going Up a Few Feet, and Hoping to Avoid a Storm’s Path
text: Jim and Leah Hogan are doing some work on their house. The ground floor is stripped down to the bones, the lawn is all dug up, and sunlight is streaming inside from unusual places, like up through gaps in the floorboard and right in through the fireplace.

headline: The Season’s Top Seller? Jackie Robinson
text: More than 30 years after Jackie Robinson played his last game, the baseball pioneer made a cameo of sorts in Spike Lee’s 1989 movie, “Do the Right Thing.” Lee, who also directed the film, played a pizza deliveryman named Mookie who wore Robinson’s Dodgers jersey as he navigated racial tensions brewing in Brooklyn.

headline: Politics Aside, the Gosnell Trial Deserves — and Is Getting — More Coverage
text: 10:34 a.m. | Updated On Friday, after hearing some complaints about The Times’s coverage of the horrifying Philadelphia murder trial of Dr. Kermit Gosnell, I reviewed what had been written so far.

headline: Labyrinth Theater Company Names Mimi O’Donnell Artistic Director
text: The Labyrinth Theater Company, a downtown ensemble devoted to producing new plays with multiracial casts, said on Monday that the costume designer Mimi O’Donnell will become its new artistic director – an appointment aimed at stabilizing the company after three years of uneven output.

headline: Library Association Lists Frequently Challenged Books
text: Sadomasochism, gay penguins and Captain Underpants. This is what passed for controversial in American literature in 2012, according to the American Library Association’s annual list of “frequently challenged books,” released on Monday.

headline: Survey on Gun-Carrying Youth Adds Fodder to Stop-and-Frisk Debate
text: Here’s more grist for the debate over whether the New York Police Department stops and frisks too many young members of minority groups: Among high school students in the city, more black and Hispanic young men than white young men said in a federal survey that they had carried a gun at least once in the previous month.

headline: Penney Has Some Persuading to Do
text: Here’s the good news: J. C. Penney appears to at least understand that it has entered the endgame.

headline: Justices Seem Wary of Bold Action in Gene Patent Case

headline: A Merger Monday for Barclays

headline: Two More Are Accused of Plotting to Kidnap, Torture and Kill Women
text: Two men, including a former librarian at Stuyvesant High School, were arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents on charges that they plotted to kidnap and torture women, according to a criminal complaint released on Monday.

headline: To Reinvigorate Production, Alaska Grants a Tax Break to Oil Companies
text: Hoping to reverse two decades of declining oil production in Alaska, the State Legislature in Juneau has granted oil companies an estimated $750 million in annual tax relief to increase investment in the giant North Slope oil field.

headline: The Top 10 Private Equity Loopholes
text: Happy Tax Day. April 15 is a good day to reflect on how much you pay in taxes and what you receive in return. It’s also good to think about how your tax rate compares with what your friends, neighbors and colleagues pay.

headline: Senator’s Absence Worries Democrats as Gun Votes Near
text: WASHINGTON — As a crucial series of gun-control votes approaches in the Senate, lawmakers on Capitol Hill are suddenly preoccupied with one question in particular: when is Frank Lautenberg coming back?

headline: 20 Lifeboats, Each a Poetic Story
text: To mark the 101st anniversary of the sinking of the Titanic, the City Room comment stalwart known as Lifeboat No. 6 has bestowed upon us a mini-epic: a long, traditional-form haiku of 20 stanzas, each representing one of the lost liner’s 20 lifeboats. We salute him.

headline: Human Genome, Then and Now
text: Eight years of work, thousands of researchers around the world, $1 billion spent — and finally it was done. On April 14, 2003, a decade ago this week, scientists announced that they had completed the Human Genome Project, compiling a list of the three billion letters of genetic code that make up what they considered to be a sort of everyperson’s DNA.

headline: In Montana, New Controversy Over Physician-Assisted Suicide
text: 8:34 a.m. | Updated  On Monday, the Montana Senate defeated H.B. 505, which would have mandated prison sentences and fines for physicians who provide aid in dying to terminally ill patients. The vote was 27 to 23 in opposition, after which the Senate also voted to indefinitely table the bill, eliminating the need for a final vote on Tuesday.

headline: Street Style: Iridescence
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of April 8.

headline: In These Ads, ‘Someday’ Is More Than a Wish
text: A campaign for an organization that fights leukemia and lymphoma is taking a bold, assertive tack in a bid to stand out from fund-raising efforts for other causes.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Shooting at the N.R.A. 500
text: Kyle Busch won both major Nascar events at Texas Motor Speedway over the weekend. But Saturday night’s N.R.A. 500, named for its controversial National Rifle Association sponsorship, was marred by a shooting in a spectator area in the track’s infield that has been ruled a suicide.

headline: When to Talk About Adoption, and When to Let It Go
text: When our former babysitter had her baby last week, I was among the first ones to show up to greet her son. My 4-year-old daughter came along. She handed over the presents, disputed whether she was ready to part with the board book I’d tossed in, and chattered during the entire visit. She is old enough now, though, to let me sit with a featherweight bundle of day-old baby without complaint.

headline: Prepaid Debit Cards More Popular, Despite Fees
text: An analysis of prepaid debit cards finds that even as more consumers use the cards as an alternative to checking accounts, fees on the cards still vary widely.

text: 4/16/13 | Updated to reflect new figures on housing starts and building permits.

headline: Kermit Gosnell and Reproductive Care
text: What does the trial of a Philadelphia doctor who is accused of performing illegal late-term abortions by inducing labor and then killing viable fetuses have to do with the debate over legal abortion?

headline: Lakers Lack Bryant but Not Confidence
text: LOS ANGELES — Last summer seems so long ago for the Los Angeles Lakers. While Kobe Bryant was in London winning his second gold medal as a member of the United States Olympic men’s basketball team, the stateside hype over the coming N.B.A. season was just beginning. Bryant was about to be joined by Steve Nash and Dwight Howard to form a superfriend collective to rival the Miami Heat’s.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Nance'
text: Jonny Orsini and Nathan Lane in a scene from Douglas Carter Beane's new Broadway play at the Lyceum Theater.

headline: British Writers, World Citizens: Granta’s List of Young Literary Stars
text: Every 10 years since 1983, the London-based literary magazine Granta names the 20 writers it considers the Best of Young British Novelists. The list has come to be regarded as a bellwether in the literary world, since so many of the writers singled out at that early stage of their careers — starting with Martin Amis, Pat Barker and Salman Rushdie — have gone on to great critical and commercial success.

headline: Antisectarian Campaign in Egypt Urges Citizens to Remove Religion From ID Cards
text: Egyptian activists have begun an online campaign against sectarianism in the wake of a deadly attack on mourners at Egypt’s main Coptic Christian cathedral this month.

headline: ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’ Will Close on Sunday
text: The new Broadway play “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” will close on Sunday after 17 preview performances and 38 regular performances, the producers said on Monday. The play, adapted by the Tony Award winner Richard Greenberg (“Take Me Out”) from the Truman Capote novella, opened on March 20 to largely negative reviews.

headline: As U.S. Seeks Security Pact, Obama Is Set to Meet Putin
text: MOSCOW — President Obama has accepted an invitation to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin ahead of a Group of 20 conference in Russia this fall, officials here said Monday — signaling a new opportunity to ease tensions even as the Kremlin continues to bristle over an American effort to punish Russian citizens accused of violating human rights.

headline: Micro Go Round
text: Q. Why does my microwave’s turntable switch directions when I stop it and start it again? Does it affect how the food heats?

headline: Rabbi Expands Tributes to Robinson Beyond the Major Leagues
text: It was April 15, 2009, when David Zaslow, a rabbi in Ashland, Ore., plopped on his living room sofa to catch some of the day’s baseball highlights. Born in Coney Island and raised as a devout fan of the Brooklyn Dodgers (for his call to prayer, instead of instructing the congregation to look east toward Jerusalem, he prefers to say east toward Ebbets Field), he began to tear up at the unexpected sight of a wondrous celebration. Zaslow saw that every player had worn jerseys without names that day, donning only the No. 42.

headline: Granta’s Best of Young British Novelists
text: On Monday, the London-based literary magazine released its latest list of the most promising young British writers.

headline: The Old A.B.A. Lives (Online)

headline: Times Wins Four Pulitzers; Brooklyn Nonprofit Is Awarded a Reporting Prize
text: The New York Times won four Pulitzer Prizes on Monday, including two awards for its reporting on the actions of companies like Apple and Wal-Mart overseas, and another for an examination of the hidden wealth of the Chinese premier’s family.

headline: Blasts at Boston Marathon Kill 3 and Injure 100
text: BOSTON — Two powerful bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon on Monday afternoon, killing three people, including an 8-year-old child, and injuring more than 100, as one of this city’s most cherished rites of spring was transformed from a scene of cheers and sweaty triumph to one of screams and carnage.

headline: April 15 Updates on Explosions at the Boston Marathon
text: On Monday afternoon, there were explosions near Boston’s Copley Square at the finish line of the Boston Marathon. Both The Boston Globe and the NBC News affiliate WHDH-TV captured dramatic video of one explosion.

text: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday. The list of winners in the journalism categories follows.

headline: Bush Welcomes Grandchild and Prepares to Dedicate Presidential Library
text: DALLAS – For a former president, it does not get much better than this. Over the weekend, George W. Bush welcomed his first grandchild into the world. And next week he will welcome the arrival of his other baby, a 226,565-square-foot presidential center.

Edie Ugot, the sous-chef at the restaurant, will take over April Bloomfield’s kitchen on Monday and offer dishes like lumpia (crispy egg rolls) and oxtail stew with Asian vegetables.

text: Mr. Duck would also like to remind you that paying your taxes not only fulfills your civic duty, it also helps defeat the Nazis.

headline: Study on Wealth Fuels Euro Crisis Debate in Germany
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank normally does its best to hold the euro together, but a study it recently issued has created a furor that could do the opposite: drive a wedge in European unity.

headline: Dinner, Drinks and Despair
text: Through a scheduling coincidence, television offered a weird dating-show hat trick last week. What unites three series is that the optimal audience for each is probably not the one that the creators aimed for.

headline: Language on Twitter, Saturn’s ‘Ring Rain’ and More
text: Hey, dude, can you tell, like, how old I am? Not if I’m over 30 and tweeting, it turns out.

headline: Crucial Studies, Fragile Subjects
text: WASHINGTON — How much oxygen should a premature baby be given in the first days and weeks of life? Neonatologists have been trying to answer that question since the 1940s, sometimes with disastrous results.

headline: To Be a Great Flier, Be a Great Sleeper
text: I DON’T mind business travel. I’m an excellent flier because I’m an excellent sleeper. I have absolutely no problem falling asleep really anywhere.

headline: Reviving the Colorado, Preemies and Sound, Mental Illness and Weight
text: Henry Fountain looks for new signs of life in a previously depleted river delta; Pam Belluck on recreating the body soundtrack for premature babies; Catherine Saint Louis on how obesity has become an impediment to treatment for people with serious mental illness.

text: THE Customs and Border Protection officer and I were definitely having a problem, but he was determined to fix it.

headline: Bringing Back the Delta
text: A new agreement between Mexico and the United States called Minute 319 will ensure more water flows into the Colorado River delta in Mexico, helping to restore parts of the once fertile region.

headline: Breast Cancer Drugs Urged for Healthy High-Risk Women
text: Should healthy women take drugs to lower their risk of breast cancer?

headline: Esquire Network Debut Is Postponed
text: The new Esquire Network has pushed back the first day of its newly branded cable channel until sometime in the summer, the top executive at the channel said on Monday. The channel was to have had its debut next week.

headline: Defensive Gun Use
text: The National Rifle Association maintains a blog called The Armed Citizen, which highlights defensive gun use. The latest entry, from April 9, describes three incidents: Two from 2013 and one archival example from 1969. It’s not hard to see what the NRA’s getting at, but just in case, a sidebar on the site states: “Studies indicate that firearms are used over 2 million times a year for personal protection, and that the presence of a firearm, without a shot being fired, prevents crime in many instances.” In other words, as Wayne LaPierre put it after Newtown, “the only thing that stops a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun.”

headline: This Is Your Brain on Opera
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — I attended two performances of Jonathan Berger’s “Visitations” at the Bing Concert Hall at Stanford last week here. On Friday evening I sat in the primary motor cortex. The following night, my seat was located off to the side, in Broca’s area.

headline: Flights May Get Rougher as CO2 Builds Up
text: As the earth gets warmer, that flight to Europe may get bumpier.

headline: Relief for a Parched Delta
text: CUCAPÁ EL MAYOR, Mexico — Germán Muñoz looked out at the river before him and talked about the days when dolphins swam here, 60 miles from the sea.

headline: A Battle Plan to Lose Weight
text: Laura Ward, 41, had always attributed her excess pounds to the drugs she takes for major depression. So Ms. Ward, who is 5-foot-6 and once weighed 220 pounds, didn’t try to slim down or avoid dietary pitfalls like fried chicken.

headline: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With Alec Baldwin, Ben Foster and Tom Sturridge
text: 8:49 p.m. | Updated  Tonight ArtsBeat live streamed a conversation with Alec Baldwin, Ben Foster and Tom Sturridge, who star in the darkly comic play “Orphans,” opening on Broadway on Thursday. Click on the image above to watch the event, which was moderated by Patrick Healy.

headline: On Clarinet, the Composer
text: Two years ago, in the intimate Rose Studio high above West 65th Street, the German composer and clarinetist Jörg Widmann opened a Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concert with a performance of his Fantasie for Solo Clarinet, inspired by commedia dell’arte.

headline: Trying Passenger Patience
text: One traveler criticized the body scanners at airport checkpoints as “an overpriced technology that provides a false sense of security and a real sense of intrusion into our personal lives.” A second called the machines a “disgrace,” requiring travelers to stand “with arms in the air and hands overhead, for screening our entire bodies each time we fly.” A third said simply, “You have NOT made me feel safer!”

headline: Now Reopening | Amsterdam’s Rijksmuseum
text: While the decade-long renovation of Amsterdam’s Rijksmuseum left some grumbling about delays and costs, the weekend’s grand reopening, counted down on a huge digital clock on the neo-Gothic building’s facade, couldn’t have come at a more fitting moment. In just a few weeks, the Netherlands’ Queen Beatrix will turn the throne over to her son Willem-Alexander, having declared that the future of the nation lies with “the next generation.”

headline: Uncertainty After Venezuela’s Election
text: The Times’s William Neuman looks at Venezuela’s tight presidential race and what Nicolás Maduro’s slim victory could mean for his presidency.

headline: European Lawmakers to Vote on Tougher Carbon Measure
text: LONDON — Efforts to put some bite into Europe’s toothless market for carbon-emission permits face a crucial vote Tuesday in the European Parliament.

headline: Explosions Rock Boston Marathon
text: The Times’s John Eligon reports from Boston, where two people have been confirmed dead after explosions near the race finish line.

headline: Iceland and China Enter a Free Trade Agreement
text: PARIS — In its first such agreement with a European country, China signed a free-trade deal with Iceland on Monday as Beijing reached out for allies at a time when many of its trading partners are wary of its increasing economic might.

headline: Science Bookshelf: Methodology
text: The titles ranked here are selected by the science editors from all adult nonfiction books reported to The New York Times for the month. These titles are fundamentally based on the sciences; those for which science is more tangential or peripheral are generally excluded. Rankings reflect combined print and e-book sales for May 2013.

headline: Moses Leaves Egypt, and City Opera Comes Home
text: The good news from New York City Opera is its terrific production of Rossini’s “Moses in Egypt” (“Mosè in Egitto”), which opened on Sunday afternoon. Here is an exciting performance of an overlooked masterpiece with a winning young cast in an imaginative staging by the director Michael Counts that boldly incorporates video elements.

headline: Albums from the Flaming Lips and Bobby Avey
text: THE FLAMING LIPS

headline: Finally, Maybe, We Are What We Cook
text: Michael Pollan’s seventh book will not substantially surprise readers of the first six. Mr. Pollan has often said that we lose touch with the basic facts of food production at our own peril, and that shared meals hold families and communities together. He has advocated fresh ingredients and sounded warning bells about why processed foods are barely worth digesting. And he is a major ingredient in his books’ blend of gastronomy, science and investigation, linking his own experiences to the lessons he imparts.

headline: Ice Cream’s Identity Crisis
text: Back then, we knew something was up if our mother returned from ShopRite with a half-gallon of Breyers ice cream. It meant that another 8-year-old first communicant had feigned an understanding of transubstantiation. It meant that someone was celebrating her first birthday, or that someone had seen his last.

headline: Witnesses to Chaos at Boston Marathon
text: A runner and bystanders near the explosions at the Boston Marathon describe the blasts and the chaotic scene.

headline: Side Sleeping May Reduce Risk of Stillbirth
text: If pregnant women in poor countries were advised to sleep on their sides, many stillbirths might be prevented, a new study suggests.

headline: Right to Win: Q. and A. With Tom Coughlin

text: Most residents in assisted-living centers suffer from multiple ailments.

headline: A Madman, but Angelic
text: My father’s laughter introduced me to the comedy of Jonathan Winters. My dad was a sweet man, but not an easy laugh. We were watching Jack Paar on “The Tonight Show” on our black-and-white television, and on came Jonathan in a pith helmet.

headline: Scenes From Coachella

headline: At Coachella, Nostalgia Trumps Newness
text: INDIO, Calif. — At the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, which descends upon the Empire Polo Field here each April, there are two large outdoor stages, three almost as big stages under gargantuan tents and one enclosed nightclub-esque structure. All together, they played host to about 190 acts from Friday to Sunday, ranging from global superstars to promising indie bands that may never rise beyond that level.

headline: Contention in Making Generic Drugs
text: Generic drug makers need samples of branded drugs in order to test their products and get them approved. Increasingly, brand-name manufacturers are refusing to sell them these samples.

text: President Obama spoke Monday evening about the explosions in Boston.

headline: Drug Makers Use Safety Rule to Block Generics

headline: Photographs of Syria Sweep Pulitzer Prizes
text: Rodrigo Abd, Manu Brabo, Narciso Contreras, Khalil Hamra and Muhammed Muheisen of The Associated Press have won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize in breaking news photography for their coverage of Syria’s civil war. Javier Manzano, a freelance photographer working with Agence France-Presse, has won the Pulitzer in feature photography for his picture of two Syrian rebel fighters taking aim through a pockmarked wall in Aleppo.

headline: Colin Davis, a British Conductor Known for His Exuberant Approach, Dies at 85
text: Colin Davis, one of the most acclaimed British conductors of the 20th century, who brought immense authority and an almost palpable zest to his music-making on both sides of the Atlantic, died on Sunday. He was 85.

headline: Cuomo Hits the Magazine Stands, Head First
text: ALBANY – It was probably to be expected for a man whose name is invariably mentioned on a short list of 2016 presidential contenders, but Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has become a full-fledged cover boy, albeit one whose defining physical and personal characteristic seems to be his head.

headline: War Zone at Mile 26: ‘So Many People Without Legs’
text: BOSTON — About 100 feet from the end of the 26.2-mile Boston Marathon, explosions shook the street and sent runners frantically racing for cover. The marathon finish line, normally a festive area of celebration and exhaustion, was suddenly like a war zone.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  Wireless Pain and Apple Paychecks
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, Egypt, Syria and France.

headline: Assassinations Grow as Iraqi Elections Near
text: BAGHDAD — In the first Iraqi elections since the American troop withdrawal, Sunni candidates are being attacked and killed in greater numbers than in recent campaigns, raising concerns in Washington over Iraq’s political stability and the viability of a democratic system the United States has heavily invested in over years of war and diplomacy.

headline: Pope Upholds Reprimand of American Nuns’ Group
text: Pope Francis has reaffirmed the reprimand of American nuns issued by his predecessor, Pope Benedict XVI, and endorsed the plan to have three bishops supervise an overhaul of the nation’s largest umbrella group of American nuns.

headline: Kuwait Gives 5-Year Term to Dissenter
text: CAIRO — A court in Kuwait on Monday sentenced a prominent opposition politician to five years in prison for insulting the country’s ruler, a crime that leaders around the Persian Gulf are prosecuting with increasing frequency in an effort to stanch emboldened protest movements, or stop protests before they start.

headline: Boston Marathon Bombing Caught on Tape
text: Video shot by The Boston Globe’s Steve Silva captures the scene after two bombs exploded at the Boston Marathon. Warning: Footage contains some graphic language.

headline: India, Long the Home of Outsourcing, Now Wants to Make Its Own Chips
text: NEW DELHI — The government of India, home to many of the world’s leading software outsourcing companies, wants to replicate that success by creating a homegrown industry for computer hardware. But unlike software, which requires little infrastructure, building electronics is a far more demanding business. Chip makers need vast quantities of clean water and reliable electricity. Computer and tablet assemblers depend on economies of scale and easy access to cheap parts, which China has spent many years building up.

headline: Remembering the First Battle
text: Participants and spectators gathered on Monday for a dawn re-enactment of the Battle of Lexington, the first skirmish of what would become the American Revolution.

headline: Again, Tarloff Jury Reports Deadlock
text: For the second time during nine days of deliberations, jurors in the murder trial of a schizophrenic man accused of killing a psychologist in her Upper East Side office in 2008 sent a note to the judge insisting that they were deadlocked.

headline: Europe Split Over Austerity as a Path to Growth
text: WASHINGTON — In the last year, the International Monetary Fund has performed a major reassessment of how it thinks austerity harms a weak, financially troubled economy. But while warning of the perils of slow growth, it still often insists on austerity for just such economies.

headline: Stupid Writer Tricks
text: One day a couple of years ago, when I found my desk drawer so full of microphone headsets that it would no longer close, I realized it was time for an intervention. I could no longer deny it: I needed to stop reading interviews with authors.

headline: Nathan Azrin Dies at 82; Changed the Field of Behavioral Psychology
text: When Nathan Azrin was appointed director of treatment development at Anna State Hospital in Illinois in 1958, a majority of the patients he was expected to treat were schizophrenic, emotionally withdrawn and in many cases mute after years in institutions. Few bothered getting dressed; most spent their days in hospital gowns.

headline: U.S. Sting That Snared African Ex-Admiral Shines Light on Drug Trade
text: DAKAR, Senegal — For months, they met in hotel rooms and at an army base in Guinea-Bissau, plotting the exchange of thousands of pounds of cocaine and an arsenal of weapons between South America and West Africa.

headline: With Grandchild and Library, a New Chapter for Bush
text: DALLAS — For a former president, it does not get much better than this. Over the weekend, George W. Bush welcomed his first grandchild into the world. Next week he will welcome the arrival of his other baby, a 226,565-square-foot presidential center.

headline: Price of Gold Takes a Flashy Fall; Other Markets Follow

headline: Senators, Seeking Support, Weigh Revisions to Background Check Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Short of votes for their compromise gun legislation, Senators Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, and Patrick J. Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania, on Monday considered changes to their plan to expand background checks for gun buyers as they scrambled to win needed converts.

headline: An Argentine Tradition Threatens to Crumble With City Architecture
text: BUENOS AIRES — As Concepción Martínez, her husband and two daughters pulled into the last subway station here, cheers and clapping erupted from the throngs of people, some wearing turn-of-the-20th-century dress, waiting on the platform.

headline: Long Island Inquiry Includes Claim of Altered High School Exam Score
text: An investigation into whether teachers in a Long Island school district improperly coached students on standardized tests has expanded to include an allegation that administrators changed a Regents exam grade for at least one high school student, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Under Orders, French Officials Reveal Financial Worth
text: PARIS — In most any other European democracy, the disclosures might have passed quietly, yet another dull moment in the administrative tedium of the vetting of public servants.

headline: Bob Perry, Big Backer of ‘Swift Boat’ Ads, Dies at 80
text: Bob Perry, a homebuilder who became one of the largest Republican campaign donors in Texas and eventually the nation, gaining notoriety in 2004 as the top contributor to the “Swift Boat” ad campaign attacking John Kerry, the Democratic presidential nominee, died on Saturday at his home in Nassau Bay, Tex., near Houston. He was 80.

headline: Once a Vocal Champion of a Cleaner Albany, Cuomo Appears Plaintive
text: When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo pushed through his ethics legislation two years ago, few clapped as loudly as the governor himself.

headline: In Break With Tradition, It’s Open Season on the Royal Family
text: MADRID — For decades, the members of Spain’s royal family were treated with profound deference by the public, politicians and the media. Their private lives generally went uninvestigated, their whereabouts unreported, and the sources of King Juan Carlos’s vast personal wealth were not discussed, even though he came to the throne with almost no money in 1975, after the death of Gen. Francisco Franco.

headline: Yankees’ Veteran Newcomers Filling Leadership Gap
text: Lyle Overbay laughed when he was compared with Derek Jeter. The notion that he — a 36-year-old first baseman long removed from his best years — could fill the void left by Jeter made him giggle.

headline: Collecting Data on the Habits of Passengers Underground
text: The decisions arrive with each approaching train, testing the hard-won instincts of the New York City subway rider — world-weary, antisocial and at all times strategic.

headline: Stepping on Jesus
text: I’m trying to think my way through the controversy provoked by a student at Florida Atlantic University who complained when his instructor asked members of the class to write the name “Jesus” on a piece of paper and then step on it.

headline: Assad’s Forces Break Through Rebel Blockade of Military Bases
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Loyalist forces in Syria have breached the insurgency’s extended blockade of two important northern bases, possibly opening the way for the military to strengthen supply lines and undertake a new campaign to recapture territory lost to the rebels in the north, antigovernment activist groups said Monday.

headline: Dr. King’s Righteous Fury
text: CHRIS ROCK caused a stir last Fourth of July when he tweeted, “Happy white peoples independence day the slaves weren’t free but I’m sure they enjoyed fireworks.” Mr. Rock’s tweet may not have topped the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.’s “God damn America” sermon, but both sentiments are of a piece, and both seem a far cry from the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s appeal to the American dream and his embrace of “the magnificent words of the Constitution and the Declaration of Independence.”

headline: Syria’s Forgotten Front
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Strategists Assess How a Weiner Candidacy Would Shake Up the Race for Mayor
text: Anthony D. Weiner has not declared his candidacy, hired a staff or even held a news conference. But already, New York City’s mayoral contenders are strategizing about what they have to do to prevent the former Queens congressman from making it to City Hall.

headline: Tena Tries Fresh Terms for a Delicate Topic
text: BECAUSE it’s not the cheeriest of topics, advertising for products that treat women’s urinary incontinence tends to steer clear of medical terminology. Poise, a Kimberly-Clark brand, uses the term “light bladder leakage,” while Tena, an SCA Personal Care brand, uses one that could just as easily describe the kitchen sink, “unexpected leaks.”

headline: The Locker and the Closet
text: I’ve been hearing the name Jackie Robinson a lot lately, and not just because a movie about him, “42,” hit multiplexes on Friday and had a bigger opening-weekend gross than any baseball movie ever.

headline: What You’ll Do Next
text: Over the past few centuries, there have been many efforts to come up with methods to help predict human behavior — what Leon Wieseltier of The New Republic calls mathematizing the subjective. The current one is the effort to understand the world by using big data.

headline: A Wrenching Adoption Case
text: The Indian Child Welfare Act was passed in 1978 to prevent state and local welfare offices from separating Indian children from their parents, many without good reason, and placing them in non-Indian homes.

headline: Westchester Loses Again on Fair Housing
text: More than three years have passed since Westchester County signed a landmark consent decree to settle a fair-housing lawsuit — years the county and County Executive Rob Astorino have spent shirking their obligations, challenging the deal in court, and losing. It lost again on April 5, when the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld a district judge’s ruling that the county was in violation of terms of the court order.

headline: An Ethical Breakdown
text: Despite reforms to protect patients from being harmed by medical research in recent decades, 23 academic institutions authorized a research project that failed to meet the most basic standard: providing an informed consent document to parents that accurately described the risks and benefits of the research to be conducted on extremely premature babies.

headline: Online Furor Draws Press to Abortion Doctor’s Trial
text: PHILADELPHIA — Through four weeks, prosecutors have laid out evidence against Dr. Kermit Gosnell, a Philadelphia abortion provider on trial on charges of killing seven viable fetuses by “snipping” their necks with scissors and of causing the death of a pregnant 41-year-old woman during a procedure.

headline: Surveillance Video of the Suspect
text: A video of the suspect and the person of interest engaging in conversation was obtained from a commercial location next to the B12 bus stop at the intersection of Albany Avenue and Rutland Road.

headline: Man Sought in 3 Brooklyn Rapes in 2 Weeks
text: The New York Police Department released a video on Monday, hoping to identify a man who they say lured three women to separate spots in Brooklyn in the last two weeks and raped them. After the third attack, on Thursday night, a clear pattern had emerged, and investigators were certain that the same person was behind all of the attacks.

headline: Bombs at the Marathon
text: A marathon is the most unifying of sporting events. The city that shows up to cheer on thousands of runners doesn’t really know or care much about who wins; there are no sides to root for or against. Those who stand on the sidelines — as they have done in Boston since 1897 — come to celebrate runners from around the world. The country or neighborhood of origin of the competitors matters far less than their stamina.

headline: Energy Future Holdings Offers Bankruptcy Plan

headline: Indonesia: Flag Dispute Put Off
text: The Indonesian government has extended by 60 days a deadline for the government in Aceh Province to annul a new bylaw that declares the banner of a former armed separatist movement to be the province’s official flag and seal, a Ministry of Home Affairs official said Monday. Zaini Abdullah, the governor of Aceh, had faced a Tuesday deadline to strike down the bylaw, which was passed by the provincial legislature last month. The dispute centers on the outlawed flag of the Free Aceh Movement, now defunct, which signed a peace agreement with the Indonesian government in 2005 that ended a 29-year civil war. The national government and armed forces oppose the use of the banner, citing multiple national laws against separatism. Officials in Aceh say the peace agreement and the province’s special autonomy status allow it to have its own flag and seal.

headline: Keep Calm and Carry On
text: Just over a week ago, my wife and I took our daughters down to the Washington Mall to see the cherry blossoms, only to find our way blocked by the Cherry Blossom Ten Mile Run, whose closing stretch lay between us and the Tidal Basin. After some deliberation, we gritted our teeth and shoved our tank of a stroller through the throngs milling just beyond the finish line, elbowing the runners out of our grim parental path, until we were through the press and headed down toward what turned out to be the not-yet-blooming sakura.

headline: Iran: On Africa Trip, President Will Visit a Uranium Producer
text: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran has started a three-nation Africa trip that includes a visit to Niger, a leading producer of uranium. Mr. Ahmadinejad, left, is also visiting Benin and Ghana. Iran’s state-run media did not specify the purpose of the trip beyond a desire to advance relations with all three countries. But the stop in Niger aroused speculation that Iran, which is under international sanctions over its disputed nuclear program, might be looking for outside sources of uranium, despite its claims of self-sufficiency. Last week Iran said it had opened two new uranium mines, suggesting that its supply is running low. According to the World Nuclear Association, a London-based trade group representing the nuclear profession, Niger is the world’s fourth-biggest uranium producer. Most of it goes by contract to Areva, a mining company based in France, the former colonial power in Niger.

headline: Cautious Call for Political Reform in China

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE CENTRAL PARK FIVE (2012) The directors Ken Burns, David McMahon and Sarah Burns revisit the case of the Central Park jogger, a 28-year-old white woman who was found in the park very early on April 20, 1989, bound, gagged, nearly naked and nearly dead, and the five black and Latino teenagers who were arrested (above, Yusef Salaam, one of the accused). They argue that the convictions, and the years the defendants served for the attack, of which they were eventually absolved last year, constituted a second, racially motivated crime. “Equal measures criminal investigation, cultural exhumation and a consideration of race in a presumptively postracial America, it seeks to set the record straight,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Measured in tone and outraged in its argument, it is an emotionally stirring, at times crushingly depressing cinematic call to witness. It’s also frustrating because while it re-examines the assault on the jogger and painstakingly walks you through what happened to the teenagers — from their arrest through their absolution — it fails to add anything substantively new. If you followed the news, the story will be familiar; if you lived in New York in 1989, it may also feel incomplete.”

This seemed pretty impressive to us at the time.

headline: Microsoft Takes Aim at Amazon With a New Cloud Service

headline: Why Do I Think My Salary Pays for Child Care?
text: A few years ago, I wrote an eBook about how couples manage their money. As part of my research, I read “The Creation of Domestic Currencies” by the Princeton professor Viviana Zelizer, who studies the way economics and emotion intertwine. Dr. Zelizer writes about how in the 1920s and ’30s, when wives earned money — no matter how much money it was or how important it was to the family’s bottom line — it was treated as “pin money” and was earmarked for the more frivolous expenses. Maybe it would be used to buy a special dress for the baby. It probably would not be used to buy a house.

headline: Goldman’s Earnings Show Strength
text: Goldman Sachs on Tuesday reported profit of $2.2 billion in the first quarter, driven by strength in investment banking and lending. The earnings of $4.29 a share represented a 9 percent increase from the quarter a year earlier. The results beat analysts’ expectations of $3.89 a share, according to Thomson Reuters. “Our strong client franchise across our businesses drove generally solid results. Still, the potential for macroeconomic instability was felt in the quarter and constrained overall corporate and investor activity,” Lloyd C. Blankfein, Goldman’s chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. Goldman’s stock rose slightly in premarket trading on Tuesday. A conference call to discuss the results is being held at 9:30 a.m.

headline: Fighting for Girls’ Education

At a time when revolutions rock false republics and new powers struggle to balance political rights with economic prosperity, women and girls are demanding a guarantee of an equal stake in the futures of their respective countries.

headline: In Boston, Tragedy and Triumph
text: Acts of terror typically rip apart ordinary days, turn routine trips to work or school into pits of pain and heartache. That is what made the shock of Monday’s blasts at the Boston Marathon finish line so different. Patriots’ Day in Boston is no ordinary day. It’s a day to celebrate America’s essential character. The marathon itself is a stream of celebration, a parade of people defying limits, championing their determination and resolve. And then two bombs went off and rocked it all. The shock waves did not stop before reaching every last bit of our country, and beyond.

headline: Catch of the Day
text: It’s hard to believe that these soft, buttery clutches were once swimming in Lake Victoria and are now eliciting oohs and aahs on a breakfast table at Balthazar in New York. Passers-by stop to ask how to snare one of them. Nile perch leather clutches in natural beige and smoky blue gray are exquisite and surprisingly sturdy. Susan Easton, a former graphic designer who traverses the globe seeking such treasures, found the leather in Kisumu, Kenya, where she met the wives of fishmongers who skin and prepare the fish for sale. Each piece, hand-sewn by an artisan born to a family of tailors, is made from a single fish hide and is sewn along the bottom of the envelope-style clutch, which leaves a flap with an interesting, natural edge. The metal clasp is made of reclaimed brass, hammered and shaped like a fish scale. Get hooked.

text: WASHINGTON — The bombing of the Boston Marathon on Monday was the end of more than a decade in which the United States experienced strikingly few terrorist attacks, in part because of the far more aggressive law enforcement tactics that arose after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

headline: Preppy Gets a Tweak
text: SOMETIMES A REPP TIE is just a repp tie, a madras bow tie merely a madras bow tie, a ribbon belt nothing more than a ribbon belt.

headline: What Would a Fighter Jet Buy 60 Years After Eisenhower’s Speech?
text: Shortly after the death of Joseph Stalin, President Dwight D. Eisenhower believed a rare opportunity existed to reset United States-Soviet relations, and he announced it to the world 60 years ago Tuesday in his 1953 Chance for Peace speech.

headline: Edible Schoolyard NYC Spring Benefit
text: Early last night, a crisp spring evening, New Yorkers picked up their forks in celebration of the Edible Schoolyard NYC’s recent expansion into Harlem. The industrial setting — the Essex Market — contrasted with the fresh produce and drinks on offer. Guests sipped summerlike libations (Parkside Fizz, Paris 75) and nibbled a selection of local cheeses and passed hors d’oeuvres before dinner. During cocktails, Diana Taylor and Elizabeth Leeds were resplendent in coordinating green dresses from Oscar de la Renta and Rag & Bone, respectively.

headline: If You Like Judy Collins, Try Amy Speace
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Author Who Annoyed McCartney Will Write His Biography
text: Philip Norman, a prolific biographer whose  “Shout! The Beatles in Their Generation” is considered by many to be among the most absorbing and comprehensive biographies of the group, and whose “John Lennon: The Life” was widely admired, has been signed by Little, Brown and Company to write a biography of Paul McCartney.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Big Knife'
text: Reg Rogers and Bobby Cannavale in the Roundabout Theater’s revival of Clifford Odets’s 1949 play.

headline: Security Experts Ponder Whether Any Long Race Can Be Completely Safe
text: Investigators in Boston are still sifting through evidence to determine who set the bombs that killed three people and injured scores on Monday.

headline: A New Sign of a Swoon
text: Don’t be fooled by the headline number – there was more evidence of a spring swoon in new government data released Tuesday.

headline: Thermo Fisher’s Deal Shows Life in Strategic Bids
text: Corporate bidders have life in them yet. Thermo Fisher Scientific is paying $13.6 billion for the genetic test equipment maker Life Technologies, edging out a group of private equity suitors.

headline: Suit Seeks to Block Arkansas Abortion Law
text: Supporters of abortion rights on Tuesday filed a challenge to the new Arkansas law banning most abortions at the 12th week of pregnancy, calling it a “violation of over 40 years of settled United States Supreme Court precedent” and a threat to “the rights, liberty and well-being of Arkansas women and their families.”

headline: Holy Coding Error, Batman
text: The intellectual edifice of austerity economics rests largely on two academic papers that were seized on by policy makers, without ever having been properly vetted, because they said what the Very Serious People wanted to hear. One was Alesina/Ardagna on the macroeconomic effects of austerity, which immediately became exhibit A for those who wanted to believe in expansionary austerity. Unfortunately, even aside from the paper’s failure to distinguish between episodes in which monetary policy was available and those in which it wasn’t, it turned out that their approach to measuring austerity was all wrong; when the IMF used a measure that tracked actual policy, it turned out that contractionary policy was contractionary.

headline: Chianti and More for Traditional Italian Dishes
text: David Tanis shares his recipe for saltimbocca chicken in his column, City Kitchen. Here are some thoughts on what to drink with that dish; share your suggestions in the comments section below.

headline: Manzanilla
text: Inside the chef Dani García’s first restaurant outside Spain.

headline: New York City Ballet Announces 2013-14 Season
text: The 2013-14 season of New York City Ballet will include the world premieres of ballets by Peter Martins, Justin Peck, Angelin Preljocaj and Liam Scarlett, as well as original scores by Marc-André Dalbavie (Mr. Martins) and Sufjan Stevens (Mr. Peck), the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Budget Would Eliminate Taxes on Forgiven Student Debt
text: President Obama’s proposed budget for the 2014 fiscal year would prevent the taxation of student debt that is forgiven under federal income-based repayment plans, according to the Institute for College Access and Success.

headline: Obama Doubts That North Korea Can Make a Nuclear Warhead
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said in an interview broadcast Tuesday that he did not believe that North Korea yet had the ability to miniaturize a nuclear weapon to fit atop a missile, and he said nothing would shake him from a strategy of refusing to “reward” the kind of provocative behavior exhibited by Kim Jong-un, the North’s leader.

headline: An Import With a Foot in Spain
text: Wylie Dufresne was sitting at the end of the bar. In about three weeks he would open another restaurant of his own, but he had given himself a night off to check out somebody else’s, Manzanilla. Its chef and owner is Dani García, a big deal in Andalusia and, as the first guy to bring liquid nitrogen into the kitchen, a member in good standing of the modernist sorcerers’ club. At his flagship restaurant, Calima in Marbella, Mr. García makes trompe l’oeil tomatoes and fashions chocolate butterflies with mango wings. Simply by opening Manzanilla, his first restaurant outside Spain, on East 26th Street, he has drastically increased the number of chefs in town with whom Mr. Dufresne might conceivably swap recipes.

headline: The T Words
text: Terror. Torture. Name it and claim it.

headline: Public Theater Season to Include ‘Fun Home’ and New Apple Family Series Play
text: The Public Theater’s 2013-14 season, announced on Tuesday, will include the new musical “Fun Home,” based on the graphic novel by Alison Bechdel, and the new play “Regular Singing,” the fourth and final part of the critically acclaimed Apple family series by Richard Nelson. In addition, all four plays in the Apple series – which are each set on important days or anniversaries in American civic life – will be performed at the Public in repertory, with “Regular Singing” opening on Nov. 22 – the 50th anniversary of the Kennedy assassination.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Creates Prize to Honor Nora Ephron
text: A quintessential New York filmmaker is getting an award named for her by a quintessential New York film festival. The organizers of the Tribeca Film Festival said on Tuesday that they will introduce a new honor, the Nora Ephron Prize, named for that screenwriter and director of “Sleepless in Seattle” and “This Is My Life,” among other films, who died in June.

headline: How Not to React to Boston
text: With downtown Boston still an active crime scene, one of the leading anti-immigrant voices in Congress latched on to the marathon bombings as a reason to halt immigration reform.

headline: Officials Describe Chaos at Guantánamo in Weeks Before Raid on Prison
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY NAVAL BASE, Cuba — Military officials on Tuesday described prison conditions here in the weeks leading up to a raid Saturday as chaotic, with detainees breaking rules with impunity, blocking cameras and windows, shouting at guards, splashing them with urine and poking sticks at them through the fencing. They said prisoners refused to go into their cells and shut their doors for a daily two-hour lockdown, and it was deemed too dangerous for guards to enter the common area to remove a troublemaker when many prisoners were freely roaming.

headline: Digital Notes: Spotify’s Global Ambitions
text: The worldwide competition among digital music services continues to grow as Spotify expands in Asia, Europe and Latin America.

headline: A Study That Set the Tone for Austerity Is Challenged
text: 8:10 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON — In recent years, policy makers in Europe and the United States have fastened on the notion that reaching a certain heavy burden of debt would threaten future economic health — often to justify austerity budgets that increased unemployment and sapped economic strength in the here and now.

headline: Bedford-Stuyvesant Historic District Triples in Size
text: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted on Tuesday to triple the size of the Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, historic district, expanding its borders to include 800 more buildings.

headline: Oklahoma State of Mind
text: It was F. Scott Fitzgerald — or was it Thomas Wolfe? — who established the four essential ingredients of the first novel of the smart young man from the American provinces: girl, town, youth and book. These are not independent elements. The longing for the girl is a longing to write. The elegy for the town is the elegy for youth, the girl and the book. A sentence about one is a sentence about all.

headline: A Culinary Union in Barcelona
text: Three head chefs from different backgrounds have fused their culinary worlds together at Pakta.

headline: After the Foam and Fame, a New Direction
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Don’t expect molecular gastronomy at the Adrià brothers’ latest Barcelona restaurant. In fact, don’t even mention it.

headline: Neighborhood Mourns Loss of 8-Year-Old Following Boston Blasts
text: BOSTON — Bill Richard, the father of the 8-year-old boy who was killed in Monday’s deadly explosions at the Boston Marathon, released a statement on Tuesday thanking everyone for their thoughts and prayers and asking for “patience and for privacy as we work to simultaneously grieve and recover.”

headline: Speed Demons and the Velocity of Words
text: Rachel Kushner’s second novel, “The Flamethrowers,” unfolds on a bigger, brighter screen than nearly any recent American novel I can remember. It plays out as if on Imax, or simply higher-grade film stock.

headline: American Airlines Resumes Flights After a Computer Problem
text: American Airlines was forced to ground all of its flights for several hours on Tuesday after a nationwide problem with its computer systems. By late afternoon, its computers were back up and its operation were slowly coming back to life.

headline: Reviving the Colorado
text: The Times's Henry Fountain discusses a new agreement between the United States and Mexico that seeks to revitalize the long-parched Colorado River delta.

headline: Tokhtakhounov, Alimzhan et. al. Indictment
text: Read the full indictment of the investigation into a gambling operation that focused on a Russian organized crime group that ran high-stakes poker games.

headline: After Bombings, Rivers Commends ‘Spirit of Boston’
text: BOSTON — If the N.B.A. schedule allows, Celtics Coach Doc Rivers always has a set plan to watch the Boston Marathon. He leaves the team’s practice site in Waltham, Mass., for the drive back to his hotel in Boston, which is a few blocks from the finish line.

headline: Basketball Giant Keeps Pressing China on Rhinos and Ivory
text: It’s encouraging to see China’s basketball legend Yao Ming continuing his effort to educate China’s middle class on the ecological cost of its appetite for ivory and rhinoceros horn. He put on a new push at a Beijing news conference today.

headline: An Acting Debut for John Guare
text: The Atlantic Theater Company announced on Tuesday that the Tony Award-winning playwright John Guare, whose plays include “Six Degrees of Separation” and “The House of Blue Leaves,” will make his Off Broadway acting debut in its production of his new play, “3 Kinds of Exile.”

headline: As Shareholder Fights Heat Up, Activists Aim at Bigger Targets
text: The annual proxy season battle between shareholders and corporations appears to have reached a tipping point in favor of shareholders this year. And while some may hope that this will change public companies for the better, we may instead end up with something resembling trench warfare.

headline: Preemies and Sound
text: The Times's Pam Belluck reports on a new study about the use of music therapy for premature infants.

headline: Cyberwar: How Digital Threats Are Redefining National Security
text: In this lesson, students learn about the scope of recent cyberattacks and what is being done to counter such threats. Then they consider the broader practical and ethical consequences of preparing for cyberwar.

headline: Now Showing | Saturdays Surf NYC
text: “Twenty years ago, if you told somebody on the West Coast that you were from New York or New Jersey and that you surf, they would look at you like you had two heads,” says Danny DiMauro, a surfer and New Jersey native. The same reaction may result at the suggestion of starting a lifestyle periodical in print that is entirely free of advertising. But this week, the fellows behind Saturdays Surf NYC, a hybrid brand that acts as a surf shop, bookshop, coffee bar and men’s-wear boutique, release the second issue of their biannual publication called Saturdays Magazine.

headline: F.D.A. Rejects New Drug for Migraines
text: Only weeks after Allergan spent nearly $1 billion to acquire the rights to a new drug for migraine headaches, the Food and Drug Administration has rejected the product.

headline: Supreme Court Rules in Favor Of 1 Worker, but Not Another
text: WASHINGTON — In a pair of 5-to-4 decisions issued on Tuesday, the Supreme Court ruled in favor of an injured airline mechanic and against a registered nurse who said her pay had been unfairly docked.

headline: Sorting Through the Debris in Boston
text: Authorities are searching the cordoned streets near two explosions that struck Monday in an attempt to find any clues about what happened.

headline: Europe Says Tests Show Horse Meat Scandal Is ‘Food Fraud’
text: LONDON — Two months after a horse meat scandal first gripped Europe, tests conducted by European Union countries showed on Tuesday that France had found the most beef products containing horse DNA, while Britain had detected the most traces of a painkiller banned from the human food chain.

headline: Returning Home: Benjamin Lytal Talks About ‘A Map of Tulsa’
text: Benjamin Lytal’s novel “A Map of Tulsa” is the story of Jim Praley, a young man back in his hometown for a summer during college who falls in love with an artist named Adrienne. Five years later, living in New York, Jim returns to Tulsa when he learns that Adrienne has been injured in an accident. In The New York Times Book Review, Gary Sernovitz writes, “Lytal asks the essential questions: how to be good; how to be an adult; how to live outside one’s head; how to love unselfishly; how to understand if this girl, this town — any of it, anything at all — are indispensable, and if they’re meaningful enough to turn into art.” In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Lytal discussed the elements of autobiography in his book, what he’s learned from being a book critic and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: In Denver, No Business Like Snow Business
text: DENVER — The day here, at least by baseball standards, began with a fairly extraordinary sight.

headline: Hospitals Profit From Surgical Errors, Study Finds
text: Hospitals make money from their own mistakes because insurers pay them for the longer stays and extra care that patients need to treat surgical complications that could have been prevented, a new study finds.

headline: Rangers With Boston Connections Have Heavy Hearts
text: PHILADELPHIA — Rangers Coach John Tortorella did not want to talk about it. That is not an unusual stance for Tortorella, who has a chilly relationship with the news media, but this time he was referring to the bombings at the Boston Marathon on Monday.

headline: Putin Nemesis Stays Defiant Ahead of Trial
text: MOSCOW — When middle-class Muscovites massed for the first time on Dec. 5, 2011, chanting “Putin is a thief,” many were there because of the anticorruption blogger Aleksei A. Navalny.

text: Shortly before his trial on embezzlement charges was to begin, the blogger and opposition activist Aleksei A. Navalny, 36, sat down for an interview in the Moscow office of his anti-corruption fund.

headline: Kimchi Omelet With Sriracha Syrup

headline: Why the Background Check Bill Is in Trouble
text: Senator Jeff Flake, the freshman Republican from Arizona, announced today that he would not support the bill to expand background checks for gun buyers. His opposition isn’t surprising — only three or four Republicans have come out in full support. But his reasoning, if you can call it that, illuminates why the bill is in such trouble.

headline: Boy, 8, Among Victims in Boston Blasts
text: The Times’s John Eligon describes the scene in Boston’s Dorchester neighborhood, where Martin Richard, an 8-year-old victim in the Boston Marathon bombing, lived.

I think this paragraph, though, deserves to be unpacked a little more:

headline: Museum of the Moving Image Naming Theater for Sumner M. Redstone
text: In 2013, your moviegoing dollar may not get you the same number of feature-length entertainments and concession-stand goodies that it used to. But for the right amount of those dollars, you can still get a movie theater named in your honor.

headline: For a Cheeseman’s Barclays Debut, Hit Play
text: So how did Patrick Watson, the opera-singing Brooklyn cheesemonger we wrote about on Sunday, do at his Barclays Center debut singing “The Star-Spangled Banner” in front of approximately 16,774 sports fans on Monday night? Watch the video above and judge for yourself.

headline: Splashing Her Grief All Over the Walls
text: Does grief make narcissists of us all? It certainly does Joanna, the chief mourner in “Sleeping Rough,” Kara Manning’s unsatisfying play at the Wild Project.

headline: New York State Legislature API Deprecated
text: As of April 15, 2013, the New York State Legislature API has been deprecated. You can read more about this change in Derek’s post from March.

headline: Writes Well With Others
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — A Google search spurred Jackie Sibblies Drury’s first produced play, and she peppers her stage directions with smiley or frowny emoticons to suggest a line’s emotional color. But these aren’t the reasons this 31-year-old is a playwright of the moment.
