text: Cold-pressed juice has morphed from a corner-shop curiosity to a major industry.

headline: Adam Scott (Actor) Is No Fan of Adam Scott (Golfer)
text: It didn’t take long after Adam Scott’s victory in the Masters for the impact to reach his namesake, the actor Adam Scott of “Parks and Recreation.” The jokes came fast and furious, and they did not meet Scott’s definition of humorous.

headline: A Shy Rat Pack, Longer on Volume Than on Vim
text: “Oh, father,” the pathetic Gilda cries in horror in the second act of Verdi’s “Rigoletto,” “what fierce joy flashes in your eyes!”

headline: Alighting on Staten Island, Democratic Mayoral Hopefuls Make Their Appeals
text: Staten Island does not get a lot of love in Democratic primary elections — only around one-sixteenth of New York City’s residents live there, and its population is relatively conservative.

headline: F.D.A. Chief Concedes Need for Policing of Compounders
text: Dr. Margaret A. Hamburg, the Food and Drug Administration commissioner, told Congress on Tuesday that her agency should have acted more aggressively against compounding pharmacies like the one that was responsible for a deadly meningitis outbreak last fall.

headline: A Recorded Legacy of Sports
text: During a 74-year career as a sportscaster, Bob Wolff collected his interviews with some of the best-known athletes in the United States. Now he is donating the collection to the Library of Congress.

headline: In Asuncion, Paraguay, Small-Scale Charms and a Complex History
text: Cooking a chipa caburé in a tatakua is surprisingly like roasting a marshmallow in a campfire. After wrapping dough around a stick, you place it just barely inside the edge of the domed brick oven and rotate it slowly. Get too close to the wood fire and the exterior burns; rotate it just enough and it browns beautifully as the inside cooks through, ready to be slid off the stick and eaten hot.

headline: Photo Replay: April 16
text: A view of the day in sports, from the red clay of Monaco to a ballpark’s blanket of white in Denver.

headline: The Juice-Bar Brawl
text: For a symbol of how quickly the juice business has changed in the United States, just look in the bottling room at the BluePrint factory in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Sister Act | Chapin Sisters
text: Abigail and Lily Chapin have been singing together their entire lives, and performing as a band, the Chapin Sisters, for almost a decade. For their latest project, the pair decided to compose an album entirely of Everly Brothers songs — not so much as a tribute but, according to Abigail, 33, as “a master class.” Because the folk-pop duo began their career as a trio — their half-sister, Jessica Craven, left the group to start a family in 2009 — they’d been studying the Everlys for clues as to how to move from what Abigail describes as “an almost doo-wop style, in which one of us is singing and the other two were kind of backing her up,” to a sound that features the kind of two-part harmonies that the Brothers are famous for, in which both singers deliver almost every line “as a single storyteller.”

headline: Dr. Leo Galland Is Answering Your Fresh Juice Questions
text: Can 16 ounces of vegetable juice really help “cleanse” your body of toxins? And which toxins are we talking about? What are “live enzymes,” anyway, and should you be ingesting more of them? If you’ve got gobs of fruit (and the sugar that comes from it) squeezed into your cold-pressed juice, is that ultimately a good thing or a bad thing? What’s up with wheatgrass and liquid chlorophyll? Should fresh juice be pasteurized? Can a juice cleanse really make your skin as glowingly radiant as Gwyneth Paltrow’s?

headline: Broadcaster’s Trove Is Calling All Ears
text: WASHINGTON — In their final years before moving to Minnesota, the Washington Senators struggled to keep fans interested. They were never contenders. Their statistics, generally, were so meager that their broadcaster rarely cited them.

headline: Amid Gun Debate, Giffords Returns to Capitol to Honor Staff Member
text: As the Senate prepares to start voting on gun safety measures this week, one of Congress’s most visible symbols of gun violence appeared in the Capitol on Tuesday to help rally support for her cause.

headline: Yahoo Profit Rises 36%, Exceeding Expectations
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo is still doing better as an investment house than as an Internet company. Its first-quarter earnings beat analysts’ expectations, but much of the gain was from its investments abroad.

headline: Response From Reinhart and Rogoff
text: Following is a statement on Tuesday from Professors Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff in response to a new paper that cited flaws in their 2010 study, “Growth in a Time of Debt.”

headline: A Fantastical Tale to Set the Ears and Eyes Popping
text: LONDON — The German notion of Gesamtkunstwerk — a synthesis of disparate art forms brought together in harmonious collusion to express a unified vision — is central to “Sunken Garden,” a new musical-theater work that had its premiere on Friday evening at the Barbican Center. Staged by the English National Opera, and described as “an occult-mystery film opera” by its Dutch composer, stage director and filmmaker Michel van der Aa, it is a provocative combination of live performance and cinema, fused in subtle and arresting ways.

headline: Theater Owners Call for Fewer R-Rated Movies
text: LAS VEGAS — Clashing messages took center stage on Tuesday morning at CinemaCon, the annual gathering of movie theater owners.

headline: Judge Approves SAC Settlement in Insider Trading Case, With Reservation
text: 8:30 p.m. | Updated A judge has approved a settlement between the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors and securities regulators that allows the firm to pay a $602 million fine to resolve a civil insider trading case without admitting any guilt, but he conditioned his ruling on a pending ruling from the Federal Appeals Court.

headline: Intel’s Profit Falls 25% With Decline in Chip Sales
text: Intel, the world’s largest computer chip maker, reported a sharp decline in its quarterly profits on Tuesday as its financial performance follows the fading fortunes of the personal computer industry.

headline: A Finale, Firsts Included
text: Celebrating its 20th season this year, the New Juilliard Ensemble has taken audiences on a world tour.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Boston and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Boston, Bahrain, Syria and North Korea.

headline: Justices Hear Case of Indian Child Caught in Custody Fight
text: WASHINGTON — A Supreme Court argument on Tuesday over the fate of a 3-year-old girl operated on three levels: as a wrenching adoption dispute, as a technical parsing of a complex federal law meant to protect American Indian tribes, and as a broad discussion of how to assess a multiracial child’s best interests.

headline: Verizon Is the New BlackBerry’s Best Friend
text: A new analysis of mobile online traffic indicates that Verizon’s launch of the BlackBerry Z10 gave the product a significant sales boost. The Z10 is the first of a series of smartphones based on a new operating system that BlackBerry hopes will revive its substantially diminished fortunes.

headline: Rabbit Head: A Spicy Specialty
text: In Beijing, restaurants serve food from all over China, including colorful oddities like spicy rabbit head.

headline: This Ranch in Detroit Is Not for Sale. It’s Art.
text: DETROIT — The sight of an empty house on a barren lot is far too familiar in parts of this struggling city, which was recently placed under the control of an emergency manager to try to head off bankruptcy.

headline: Face to Face With Dinner
text: Eating animal heads, preferably heavily spiced, is enjoying a growth in popularity in China’s biggest cities.

headline: When Dinner Has a Gleam in Its Eye
text: BEIJING — Bundled up on a wind-whipped day, about 30 people lined up outside a restaurant takeout window here, waiting for rabbit heads.

headline: Inspired by ‘Glee’ (Emphasis on Inspired)
text: They can’t be serious. Er, can they?

headline: The New Exploratorium in San Francisco
text: The science museum has moved into a new $220 million home along the city’s Embarcadero.

headline: Taking Swings in the Ring, Without a Fight’s Stakes
text: Since Gleason’s Gym opened in 1937, hundreds of the world’s greatest boxers have trained there. As it has moved around the city, from its first home in the Bronx to its current address in Dumbo, Brooklyn, it has also served as the location for countless photo shoots, commercials and movies, including “Raging Bull” and “Million Dollar Baby.” On Saturday it was home to a dance performance.

headline: An Emphasis on Newton’s Laws (and a Little Lawlessness)
text: SAN FRANCISCO — During the years after the Exploratorium opened in 1969 in the ramshackle Palace of Fine Arts here, did it ever think that the world had passed it by? At first, it was a countercultural revelation to start a science museum in which every visitor was treated like a chalk-smeared genius carrying out experiments. There were no objects in display cases, no signs saying, “Don’t touch.” Every exhibit was handmade on site and was meant to look it.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  Twitter TV and New Google Stores
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: With Nagging Questions, Looking Back on a Decade
text: Certain choreographers grumble at the prospect of reviving dances. Others actually relish the experience of looking back. In the case of Bebe Miller, who formed her company in 1985 and has been a regular figure on the New York dance scene in the ensuing years, such yearning has resulted in “A History.”

headline: Investigation Under Way in Boston
text: Authorities were trying to identify suspects and a motive behind an attack that killed three people and injured 176 at the Boston Marathon on Monday.

headline: TV Viewers Flock to News Programs After Boston Blasts
text: Millions of viewers turned to cable news starting Monday afternoon as word spread of the bomb attacks at the Boston Marathon.

headline: Pat Summerall, Star Kicker With Giants and a Calm Voice on TV, Dies at 82
text: Pat Summerall, the Giants’ outstanding place-kicker who went on to team with John Madden for 21 seasons in network television’s most prominent N.F.L. broadcast twosome, died on Tuesday in Dallas. He was 82.

headline: Keeping His Secrets Well Up His Sleeve
text: “Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay” is a mouthful of a title, if not nearly as charmingly loquacious as those for some of Mr. Jay’s books, including “Learned Pigs & Fireproof Women: Unique, Eccentric and Amazing Entertainers: Stone Eaters, Mind Readers, Poison Resisters, Daredevils, Singing Mice, etc., etc., etc., etc.” Those four punctuating “etc.’s” — what more could there be? — are an especially nice touch because they suggest that Mr. Jay has so much up his pushed-up sleeves that he couldn’t possibly squeeze everything into a single title.

headline: How We Got More Than Even With New York Magazine
text: Duke and Carolina never play each other until the final month of the college basketball season. And the Army-Navy game traditionally is the last contest of the college football regular season. So, yes, it seemed a wee unnatural that The New York Times Magazine and New York magazine would meet in the season opener of their media softball league on Monday night. It was pegged as our big rivalry game of the year for reasons I’m not entirely clear about. I guess some of our people used to work there and vice versa. (Oh, and they also beat us last year.)

headline: Where to Find Fish, Rabbit and Duck Heads in New York
text: Thanks to a renewed appreciation of China’s rustic culinary roots, eating animal heads has become fashionable in Beijing, as Craig Smith writes in this week’s Dining section. There are restaurants solely devoted to the preparation of fish, rabbit and duck heads. In New York you may search long and hard without finding such a restaurant. Look carefully, though — not only in the warrens of a mall in Flushing, Queens, but also on Restaurant Row in Manhattan — and you may be surprised to see what’s looking back. Though the cooking process may render an entire head a nearly uniform brown, there’s no mistaking a rabbit’s incisors or a duck’s bill.

headline: Decades of Decline in Attacks

headline: Bring On the Next Marathon
text: Looking at scenes of the Boston sidewalk a few hours after Monday’s bombing — torn clothing, bloodstains, shards of glass — I found my mind going back to a similar sidewalk in Tel Aviv in September 2003. A Hamas suicide bomber had blown himself up at a bus stop outside the Tsrifin army base, and by coincidence I was nearby and got there to witness the immediate aftermath. As I wrote then, parts of the bomber were still on the street, including his hairy leg. His shoe had been blown off, but his brown sock was still daintily on his foot. Israeli rescue workers calmly carried away the dead on stretchers, with an odd mix of horror and routine. But what I remember most was something the police spokesman said to me: “We will have this whole area cleaned up in two hours. By morning, the bus stop will be repaired. You will never know this happened.”

headline: Florida: Teachers Sue Over Evaluation System
text: Seven Florida teachers have brought a federal lawsuit to protest job evaluation policies that tether individual performance ratings to the test scores of students who are not even in their classes. The suit, which was filed Tuesday in conjunction with three local affiliates of the National Education Association in Federal District Court for the Northern District of Florida in Gainesville, says Florida’s two-year-old evaluation system violates teachers’ rights of due process and equal protection. Under a 2011 law, schools and districts must evaluate teachers in part based on how much their students learn, as measured by standardized tests. But since Florida, like most states, administers only math and reading tests and only in selected grades, many teachers do not teach tested subjects. One of the plaintiffs, a first-grade teacher, was rated on the basis of test scores of students in a different school in her district, and another, who teaches vocational classes to aspiring health care workers, was rated based on test scores of students in grades and subjects she had never taught. “This lawsuit highlights the absurdity of the current evaluation system,” said Andy Ford, president of the Florida Education Association.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 8 P.M. (13, 49) THE MYSTERY OF EELS Snakelike and slimy, with a row of jagged teeth and, in some cases, a life span of more than 100 years, the eel is one of the natural world’s few enigmas, with little known about where it goes, what it does and how it dies. In this “Nature” episode the naturalist James Prosek tries to shed light on this creature, above, christened “the North Sea siren” and “love’s arrow on earth” by the Italian poet Eugenio Montale. In “Australia’s First 4 Billion Years: Life Explodes,” on “Nova” at 9, Richard Smith investigates fossils for clues as to how arthropods invaded that barren continent from the ocean and spawned life on land. And “Guts With Michael Mosley,” at 10, explores the human digestive tract.

headline: Advice From Expert on Male Sexuality, Part 2
text: Readers recently submitted questions about male sexuality to Dr. Ronald F. Levant, a professor of psychology and director of the Psychology Department Counseling Clinic at the University of Akron. Part 1 of his answers can be found here. Dr. Levant was president of the American Psychological Association and is an author or editor of 14 books, including “Men and Sex: New Psychological Perspectives.” Dr. Levant asked the counselors whom he supervises in his clinic, all Ph.D. students in psychology who see a broad range of clients, to help him compose answers to these questions. Thanks are given to Mike Aguilar, Brittany Baker, Natalie Grandy, Craig Libman and Arielle Riutort. Because of the large number of submissions, not every question was addressed. In particular, we were not able to answer questions on medical issues, as our expertise is psychological, not medical. This feature is closed to further questions.

headline: Letdown for Bank of America
text: Bank of America said on Wednesday that it earned 20 cents a share in the first quarter, falling short of analysts’ expectations of 23 cents a share. Still, the first-quarter results compared with earnings of 3 cents a share in the period a year earlier. The bank also posted revenue of $23.5 billion. In a statement, Brian T. Moynihan, Bank of America’s chief executive, said, “Our strategy of connecting our customers to all we can do for them is working.” The question now is whether the earnings will add to the recent optimism surrounding the bank, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. The bank’s shares were down in premarket trading. Bank of America is holding a conference call at 8:30 a.m. to discuss the results.

headline: George Beverly Shea Dies at 104; Stirring Singer at Billy Graham Revivals
text: George Beverly Shea, who escaped a life of toil in an insurance office to become a Grammy-winning gospel singer and a longtime associate of the Rev. Billy Graham, appearing before an estimated 200 million people at Graham revival meetings worldwide, died on Tuesday in Asheville, N.C. He was 104.

headline: Site to Be Seen | Christie’s Vintage Couture Accessories
text: The venerable auction house Christie’s opens the bidding for its online-only auction of vintage accessories – including costume jewelry, handbags and trunks – at 10 a.m. on Thursday. Carefully curated by Clare Borthwick, Christie’s specialist in vintage couture and accessories, the goods include jewelry from Chanel, Kenneth Jay Lane, Miriam Haskell and Yves Saint Laurent; handbags from Hermès in almost every color, including a white Birkin with gold hardware ideal for the summer; and trunks from Louis Vuitton that date back to the first quarter of the 20th century. The sale will continue online through May 2. And if your dream bag isn’t on the site yet, don’t fret: Christie’s specialists already have their next online-only sale planned to start on May 9 featuring exotic handbags from Hermès.

headline: Suspicions in Boston Attack Turn to Man Seen in Videos
text: BOSTON — In the first major break in the hunt for the Boston Marathon bomber, F.B.I. personnel on Wednesday found security video clips that showed a man they believe may have played a role in planting the explosives that killed three people and injured more than 170 on Monday.

headline: A Worthy Tablet for Children
text: The Polaroid Kids Tablet ($150) is yet another seven-inch Android 4.0 portable option for children. But it’s worth a second look, because unlike the now dozens of others, both the power and volume controls are well marked, easy to find and right there on the front panel. You can’t miss them.

headline: Shoes the Pros Use

Among the amendments rejected by the Senate were a measure that would expand background checks for gun purchases another that would reinstate ban on assault weapons.

headline: Arctic Nations Seek Common Management of Fishing as Open Water Spreads
text: Humanity has long had a two-pronged reaction to environmental change — girding against risks but also probing for opportunities. The spread of ice-free Arctic Ocean waters in summer is eroding shorelines and may be affecting Northern Hemisphere winter weather (the jury is out). But of course this change has also prompted enterprising shippers to test new trade shortcuts and led to projections of bountiful new fisheries.

headline: Disgraced Official’s Wife Accuses Him in Texas Killings

headline: Militants in Egyptian Sinai Fire Rockets Into Israel but Do No Damage

headline: Afghan Islamic Courts: A Pre-Taliban System With Post-2014 Potential?
text: The American military has built much of its transition strategy in Afghanistan around establishing local police forces to help keep the peace. In recent months, much has been made about the rise of indigenous anti-insurgent forces, separate from the American-sponsored local police, in the historical Taliban strongholds of Ghazni and Kandahar Provinces. Implicit in the praise for these forces is that indigenous militias of this type represent a vital local vision for the future and a sustainable means of keeping the Taliban at bay after 2014.

headline: Moonless on the Mississippi
text: For most Americans, their historical memory about the Civil War centers on the battles in the East, from the First Bull Run to Petersburg. But taken at its most fundamental level, the Civil War was actually a war of geographic attrition, beginning in the West. The West constituted the strategic military arena, for there, rivers ran parallel to Union lines of invasion; in the East, they ran perpendicular to them.

headline: Queen for a Day: Sandra Bernhard Looks Back on ‘The King of Comedy’
text: It’s been 30 years since Rupert Pupkin made his notorious debut on “The Jerry Langford Show,” a moment that exists only within the reality of “The King of Comedy,” Martin Scorsese’s dark satire about a struggling standup (played by Robert De Niro) who kidnaps his favorite talk-show host (Jerry Lewis). But it’s also a more tangible milestone for the film’s co-star Sandra Bernhard, who played Masha, an equally unhinged fan who helps Pupkin carry out his twisted show-biz schemes: for Ms. Bernhard, “The King of Comedy” was a breakthrough (for which she was cast from the comedy-club scene in Los Angeles) that garnered critical praise and led her to a wider stage and screen career.

headline: Can a Woman Win the Kentucky Derby?
text: Here is the perception: female jockeys can’t ride. They’re too weak. They don’t have the fight in them. They can’t close — not like men, anyway. Down the stretch, you need a jockey to carry the horse to the end, rally the winded animal and squeeze speed out of weary legs. Female jockeys can’t do that. Or so goes the explanation for why, almost 50 years after women first fought legal battles to become jockeys, there are so few top jockeys who are women.

headline: I Heart Artichokes

headline: Hiking Through History, With Your Daughters
text: The best miracle happened outside the town of Portomarín. There’d been a number of them on this family trip — with my wife and two daughters — walking the ancient pilgrimage route to Santiago de Compostela, Spain. That July morning my youngest daughter, Yancey, and I stepped out of a forest and onto a field — and, it seemed, into a previous century. Hundreds of pilgrims milled about, locals sold trinkets, jugglers wandered by, musicians played, people handed out refreshments and offered showers at a community center.

headline: Vain Glorious | Aqua Spin Classes
text: Aqua spinning, the fitness fad that’s swept over France, has just landed stateside with the newly opened Aqua Studio in TriBeCa. As the name implies, there are elements taken from traditional spinning — fat-blasting and calorie-burning moves, upbeat soundtracks, and friendly (but firm) instructors — but there are also benefits that only exercising in water can boast. For starters, there’s the draw of a low-impact, high-resistance workout. The water supports your body weight and reduces stress on joints while generating resistance, which encourages your legs to move in a safe and controlled manner. Devotees also claim that aqua spinning can help smooth dimpled thighs. Aqua Studio’s founder Esther Gauthier, a French expat, says, “Moving in water generates a natural massage that drains the lymphatic system and improves the appearance of cellulite.” But most important, being in the water is simply fun. There’s something about throwing on a bathing suit and splashing in water that takes the typical emotional edge off of exercising: your muscles are getting a serious workout, while your mind feels buoyant and light. After my first session, I felt rejuvenated and energized, not wiped out (like I do after an intense run), and left the studio with a spring in my step. Sorry, guys: for the moment, Aqua Studio is for the ladies only.

headline: Writers and the Women They Worship
text: These three delightfully deranging books offer alternatives to your staid biographies. They’re a bit dangerous, a bit rude — free from the tyranny of good taste. The authors, first-rate obsessives, riff on the women who’ve consumed them — bearing out Frank Bidart’s line, “What you love is your fate,” with mischief, feeling and a rare frankness. That’s the thing about obsession. It can’t be faked.

headline: Blame The Pundits, Too
text: Still Reinhart-Rogoffing; I think it’s important to be clear that R-R aren’t the only ones at fault here. In particular, the people who cited their work don’t have the right to claim innocence, because how could they know that they were being given bad data?

headline: Terry de Havilland
text: “A lot of my stuff terrifies buyers,” Terry de Havilland says, chuckling. A desire to show the shoe-buying public what they’re missing spurred the designer, who made some of the most memorable footwear of the 1970s, to open a three-month-long pop-up boutique in London’s Carnaby Street area beginning on April 20. It’s his first stand-alone retail venture since his Kings Road shop, Cobblers to the World — where Led Zeppelin, Anita Pallenberg and Bianca Jagger bought their platforms — closed in 1979. Though he makes other styles, including a fetching Cuban-heeled boot for men, de Havilland will forever be associated with the platform, which he learned to make at his father’s knee; his parents had a shoe business that catered to showgirls in postwar London, and it was those original designs that prompted him to resuscitate the platform for the glam rock generation and again more recently for customers like Kate Moss. “I think they empower women,” he says. “They give you your own little stage to stand on.”

headline: Why So Little Terrorism?
text: With ricin-laced letters suddenly showing up in Washington D.C., I worry a little that I’m tempting fate by writing about the rarity of organized terrorism in early 21st century America. But hopefully one more post won’t hurt. So, picking up where my last one left off, here are three theories about why our culture seems to be producing relatively few people with the combination of ideological commitment, organizational competence and zeal that has sparked and sustained terrorist campaigns in other times and places:

headline: House Hunting in ... Costa Rica
text: A FIVE-BEDROOM CONTEMPORARY ON A GOLF COURSE IN COSTA RICA

headline: Properties for $795,000
text: Homes in Hillsborough, N.C., Lewes, Del. and Oakland, Calif.

headline: Tibetan Woman Kills Herself by Self-Immolation
text: BEIJING — A young Tibetan mother has killed herself by self-immolation to protest Chinese rule, according to reports by Radio Free Asia and Voice of America, two news organizations financed by the United States government.

headline: Introducing The Daily Dog-Ear
text: Starting today, The Daily Dog-Ear will appear weekdays on The 6th Floor, directing you to things we find notable, interesting, surprising, provocative or otherwise dog-ear-able.

headline: What You Get for ... $795,000
text: HILLSBOROUGH, N.C.

headline: Complaints About Money Transfers
text: Millions of people use money-transfer services, like Western Union or MoneyGram or smaller competitors, to send cash in the United States or outside.

headline: Berlin’s New Entry on the Summer Festival Calendar
text: There’s a new summer festival in town, and that town is Berlin. From June 27 to July 14, the city will host Foreign Affairs, an ambitious multi-arts festival whose program was announced this week in Berlin by the artistic director, Matthias von Hartz.

headline: Calling Superfans of ‘The Last Five Years’
text: Say “cult musical” and what comes to mind is a notorious Broadway turkey like “Carrie.” But a two-character show about the failed relationship between a Jewish guy and a Gentile girl whose stories are told backward (hers) and forward (his), with a number called “Shiksa Goddess”?

headline: Why Weiner’s Mayoral Bid Is a Long Shot
text: A poll released on Tuesday by Marist College shows former Representative Anthony Weiner running in second place in the Democratic primary for mayor of New York. Mr. Weiner has 15 percent of the vote, behind Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, at 26 percent.

headline: With Debt Study’s Errors Confirmed, Debate on Conclusion Goes On
text: The Harvard economists Carmen M. Reinhart and Kenneth S. Rogoff have acknowledged that their groundbreaking 2010 study “Growth in a Time of Debt” includes statistical errors that significantly alter its results.

headline: Scene City: Pillars of New York Society
text: Vanity Fair’s party kicks off the 12th Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Complete Immigration Overhaul Bill
text: A bipartisan group of senators working on an immigration compromise released an 844-page bill.

headline: Paramore Unseats Timberlake at No. 1
text: The rock band Paramore scored the No. 1 spot on the Billboard album chart this week with its first new release in four years, ending Justin Timberlake’s three-week run and beating out a new album by Brad Paisley.

headline: Cristin Milioti in 'Once'
text: The actress performs “Raglan Road” from this Broadway musical about two musicians who fall in love.

headline: Make a Note of It: Speech Recognition Apps Are Getting Better
text: Science fiction writers have long imagined a future where we simply voice-command our devices, cars or spaceships. The technology isn’t quite there yet, despite Apple’s best efforts with Siri, its digital personal assistant. But our smartphones and tablets are getting quite good at turning the spoken word into text. This app technology has the power to turn your mobile device into a powerful writing tool, without your having to lift a stylus or type on a touch screen.

headline: Euro Zone Crisis Has Increased I.M.F.’s Power
text: FRANKFURT — When Wolfgang Schäuble, the German finance minister and war horse of European politics, celebrated his 70th birthday at a theater in Berlin last September, two of the most powerful women in the world offered warm words in his honor.

headline: Eric Ripert and Richard Gere Will Be Your Chefs
text: A dinner for $220,000?

headline: Image of the Day: April 17
text: A procession organized by eunuchs in Ajmer, Rajasthan.

headline: Ask Well: Long Runs vs. Sprints
text: Question:

headline: Does High Debt Cause Slow Growth?
text: The debate over whether government spending hurts or helps growth has again taken center stage this week because of a new research paper by two professors and a graduate student at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Their study critiques the methods and conclusions of a 2010 paper by Kenneth Rogoff and Carmen Reinhart, both professors at Harvard, showing that countries with high debts also have lower growth rates.

headline: Blogger Who Traced Flow of Arms to Syria Through YouTube Seeks Crowdfunding
text: The British blogger Eliot Higgins, who has played an important role in tracing the flow of arms to Syrian rebels through close analysis of video clips posted on YouTube from his living room in England, began an appeal for financial support from readers this week.

headline: In New Home, Exploratorium Widens Its Interactive Appeal
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The Exploratorium science museum, which reopened Wednesday on a new nine-acre campus by the San Francisco Bay, is striking for how closely it has hewed to its quirky, interactive and “work in progress” roots.

headline: Exclusive Clip: ‘Mr. Jones’
text: A scene from the horror film “Mr. Jones,” playing in the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Bus Finder App, and Tabletop PC
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Life Stinks, but It’s Still Precious
text: “Art should comfort the disturbed and disturb the comfortable,” an epigram popularized by the street artist Banksy, aptly describes Jean Thompson’s new novel, “The Humanity Project,” in which the question of how to comfort the miserable — and whether it’s even possible — becomes nearly as troubling as unhappiness itself.

headline: At the Tribeca Film Festival Party, Every Name Is Bold
text: It wasn’t clear which stood taller: the Corinthian columns of the New York State Supreme Court or the towering figures of New York society who mingled beneath them at the kickoff to the 12th annual Tribeca Film Festival on Tuesday night.

headline: For Bank of America, C.E.O. Greed Would Be a Good Thing
text: Bank of America investors had better hope the bank’s chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, is long-term greedy. About half his pay is now tied to hitting specific targets for average return on assets and tangible book value by 2015. The bank’s first-quarter showing of $2.3 billion applicable to shareholders is better than last year. But without significant further improvement, Mr. Moynihan’s going to fall way short.

headline: Real Madrid No. 1 in the Money League
text: The rich keep getting richer, and for now, Real Madrid is the richest of all.

headline: Strolling in Paris, With Menus in Mind
text: Paris is, of course, a walker’s city. But which direction to take? And to what destinations? With previously unknown (to me, at least) restaurants as my end points, I started at Notre Dame (essentially the center of town; all time allotments below are from there) and headed in different directions for different lengths of time.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Boston and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Boston, England, Pakistan and India.

headline: Hearing the Benefits of Confronting Mozart
text: When I spoke recently with the clarinetist and composer Jörg Widmann before his three-concert Contrasts series this week at the 92nd Street Y with the eminent violinist Christian Tetzlaff, he said that the series’ juxtapositions of his music and Mozart’s could bring out the knots in the great master that are often hidden in plain sight.

headline: Oilers President Decides Insulting Fans Was a Bad Idea
text: The Edmonton Oilers’ president of hockey operations, Kevin Lowe, apparently needed to learn a lesson this week taught in Sports Marketing 101: Never take potshots at your fans. There might be a special chapter in the marketing handbook about doing so in a news conference designed to inspire optimism among your fans, as when you hire a new general manager because the last one drove the franchise into a ditch.

headline: Clip: 'G.B.F.'
text: A scene from the high school comedy "G.B.F.," directed by Darren Stein.

headline: Harry Reid’s Conscience
text: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid generally isn’t thought of as a conviction politician. He’s a vote-counter; a highly cautious pragmatist who not long ago ducked an opportunity to reform the filibuster, and with it the increasingly slow-to-non-existent legislative process.

headline: A Label Finds 99 Ways to Make Classical Profitable
text: Among iTunes’s top classical albums are plenty by Yo-Yo Ma and Glenn Gould. But the list is also filled with budget compilations, like “The 50 Most Essential Pieces of Classical Music” and “Beethoven: 100 Supreme Classical Masterpieces,” that pack in dozens of “1812” Overtures and “Für Elises” for as little as $6.

headline: New Gun Measures Considered by the Senate
text: The Senate voted on a series of amendments on Wednesday afternoon that may determine the shape of new gun legislation.

headline: The F.B.I. Criticizes the News Media After Several Mistaken Reports of an Arrest
text: The F.B.I. scolded several news outlets on Wednesday for mistakenly reporting that an arrest had been made in the Boston Marathon bombings, and warned that such unverified reporting could have “unintended consequences” for its investigation.

headline: This Script, They Think, Could Be the One
text: Writing a script is tough. But writing a script about writing a script — well, that’s a whole other story.

headline: Now Opening | Altai
text: Amaryllis Knight, a globe-trotting, British-born designer, has left her aesthetic fingerprints all over her adopted home of Los Angeles: in the homes, gardens and offices of private design clients; in her own house; and soon, in the smartly appointed restaurant that chef Josef Centeno is opening this summer (Orsa & Winston). Now, with the opening of Altai — the retail store (which opens April 18) and online platform for her consultancy and furniture studio — Knight’s eclectic vision is, at last, shoppable. “It’s a lot more than a store,” she says. “It’s a way to further explore my work and interests while contributing to a conversation in Los Angeles about varied worlds of design and how they intersect.” Situated on a stretch of 3rd Street that’s a retail desert — but a quick skip to LACMA and Regen Projects — the light-drenched, vaulted-ceilinged space sells everything from $14 Santa Maria Novella lozenges to a $600,000 1948 Vincent 1000cc Rapide Series B motorcycle with a legendary racing pedigree. (“It’s a wild machine,” Knight says.)

headline: Cerberus Owner Might Buy Its Gun-Making Group
text: Four months after the investment firm Cerberus put the country’s largest gun company up for sale in the wake of the school shootings in Connecticut, it has found a possible buyer in Cerberus’s owner, Stephen A. Feinberg.

headline: With Pulitzer, She Became a Composer
text: Caroline Shaw, the winner of the 2013 Pulitzer Prize in Music, isn’t quite ready to own up to what she does.

headline: With Falsetto and Flash, a Band for Which Bigger Is Always Better
text: The English band Muse loves science concepts. It opened its Madison Square Garden concert on Tuesday night with “The 2nd Law: Unsustainable”: a warning, based on the second law of thermodynamics, that entropy makes an economy based on endless growth unsustainable. (The song, from Muse’s 2012 album, “The 2nd Law,” is also a trendy blast of dubstep, disrupting one of the band’s many somber keyboard introductions with a bass upheaval and a swooping synthesizer.)

headline: A Shower of Sparkles Amid a Haze of Smoke
text: “Sortijas,” a premiere for Ballet Hispanico by the Spanish choreographer Cayetano Soto, opens on a darkened stage as Jamal Rashann Callender, a sinewy, shirtless wonder in black pants, lifts Lauren Alzamora from behind. Her legs splay awkwardly, while her top — a riot of sparkles by the German-American design team Talbot Runhof — glitters relentlessly. A haze of theatrical smoke clings to the stage, rendering it difficult to make out choreographic nuances. Perhaps that’s for the best.

headline: ‘Bravest Woman in Mexico’ Sees Her Story on a New York Stage
text: Until last week, Marisol Valles García, a petite, soft-spoken 23-year-old with rather severe rectangular glasses, had never visited New York, never ridden in an elevator, never dined in an Italian restaurant. And she had never seen a play.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: April 18
text: Giada Forte jewelry; offsetting bursts of spring color with a neutral bag; and Pas de Calais, a Japanese label with a Gallic inflection, opens its first United States store in SoHo.

headline: In ‘Spuren,’ Glass Finds His Inner Bruckner
text: LINZ, Austria — How did Anton Bruckner, thought by some to have been the stodgiest of composers, suddenly become cool? Well, not cool himself, exactly, but he seems to be hanging out more with cool guys: namely, a couple of Minimalist pioneers.

headline: Editors’ Lab at The New York Times
text: This weekend, April 20–21, we’re hosting an Editors’ Lab hack event at the Times building. The worldwide Editors’ Labs series, organized by the Global Editors Network (GEN), invites teams to build apps and projects around a media-related theme. This weekend’s theme is “newsgaming”: projects at the intersection of games and journalism.

headline: Company Founder Makes Court Appearance in Breast-Implant Case
text: PARIS — The founder of a French company accused of selling hundreds of thousands of defective breast implants to more than 65 countries appeared on Wednesday in a courthouse in Marseille, with more than 300 victims in attendance.

headline: The ‘Weird Realism’ of H.P. Lovecraft
text: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

headline: Scouting Report
text: The Brooklyn-based jewelry line Holst + Lee, created by Natalie Holst and Rochelle Lee, is the latest addition to the roster at Plum Alley, a new luxury e-commerce platform that curates products exclusively from companies founded by women. In honor of the occasion, Ms. Holst and Ms. Lee have designed three pieces exclusively for the site: glass crystal and nylon rope earrings ($175), a Swarovski crystal-studded necklace ($275) and a multistrand necklace made from nylon rope wrapped with pearl cotton thread ($225). This week, 10 percent of the proceeds on these items will go to Somaly Mam Foundation, an organization that works to end human trafficking.

headline: For Quinn, Weiner Is the Possible Candidate Who Must Not Be Named
text: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, is rarely reticent on the campaign trail, doling out rhetorical jabs and gibes and regularly earning laughter from crowds.

headline: EBay’s Profit Rises 19%, but Results Miss Estimates
text: EBay continues its turnaround, from troubled online auction site to a forward-looking, mobile-oriented e-commerce company.

headline: Times Talks: Ken Burns on Justice and ‘The Central Park Five’
text: Watch the discussion about the issues raised by “The Central Park Five,” the award-winning documentary about a 1989 rape in Central Park, the rush to judgment and the lives of those wrongly convicted.

headline: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
text: Ah, those online relationships.

headline: At Age 14, No Stranger to a Steal
text: On the Internet, no one cares that you’re 13. That’s what Henry Kilpatrick discovered when he started his vintage-furniture retail site, Magic City Finds, in September 2011, at the dawn of his teen years. Mr. Kilpatrick, who is now 14 and lives in Birmingham, Ala., had no idea who Herman Miller was when he plucked a fiberglass armchair from his grandmother’s storage space, but one online search later, he knew he had a find. He plowed the $75 he made on that initial sale, along with some birthday money, back into furniture bought at estate sales and off Craigslist, including 20 more Eames chairs, which cycled through his parents’ garage. He mostly works on the weekends, as it is “tough to do schoolwork and business, and schoolwork comes first,” he said.

headline: Recalling a Chronicler of Combat as It Is
text: The British-born photojournalist Tim Hetherington starts and stops, groans and grimaces, as he tries to explain why he’s made a career of taking his cameras as close as possible to the places where men are killing each other. He manages to get out, “The important thing for me is to make work that is connected to people,” before shaking his head in disgust: “Blah blah blah blah blah.”

headline: Inspiration From a PB&J
text: When Deborah Ehrlich, a glass designer in Accord, N.Y., needed a new porch light almost four years ago, she designed one. “The idea was a jelly jar,” she said. But it is a refined version, made by artisans in Sweden with whom Ms. Ehrlich has worked for 13 years. The material is Swedish crystal. “You can blow it very thin, and it doesn’t break,” Ms. Ehrlich said. The light, which has a white glazed porcelain base and a rubbed brass shade holder, is now in production. Fully assembled, it measures 4 inches wide and 8 inches high, and sells for $225 at Artware Editions, 270 Bowery, second floor (Houston Street), (212) 463-7490; artwareeditions.com.

headline: He Wouldn’t Change a Thing
text: On April 23 and 24, Christie’s will stage an auction of the contents of a Palladian-style villa in Malibu, Calif., that was designed by Michael S. Smith, the Obamas’ White House decorator. The auction includes many museum-quality pieces, including a Sean Scully painting and a Persian rug that once belonged to the Agnelli family of Italy. A Chinese brown lacquer altar table, shown, has an estimated sale price of $4,000 to $6,000. There’s also a trove of Asian art and antiques, Old Master paintings and historic European furniture (more than 450 lots) with an estimated sale value of $3.5 million to $5 million. It took Mr. Smith five years to accumulate all the treasures, and he may bid at the auction himself. “I’m not done with anything,” he said. “I’d buy it all again.” So attached is he to the project that he wrote a book about it, “Building Beauty: The Alchemy of Design” (Rizzoli, $55). Information: (212) 636-2000 or Christies.com.

headline: Designs That Help Redefine ‘Craft’
text: By weekday, John Liston is a glass artisan working for other artists and architects in Oakland, Calif. But the rest of the time, he experiments with his own furniture and lighting in a cooperative studio in San Francisco. Out of these efforts have come burnt-recycled-wood cabinets ($11,000), lights with industrial-glass orbs perched on scrap-metal tripods ($25,000) and other mixed-media pieces, which he displays at craft shows. One of his cheeriest works is his bright orange Ribbon chair, shown, made of crisscrossed steel slats ($6,000).

headline: Need a Good Zinnia Recipe?
text: Don’t be misled by the title: “The Flower Recipe Book,” by Alethea Harampolis and Jill Rizzo (Artisan, $24.95), is not a guide for making hibiscus enchiladas or scented-geranium sorbet. Rather, it’s a beautifully illustrated and practical guide to the ephemeral art of fresh-flower arranging.

headline: Sales at BoConcept, Niche Modern and Others
text: Furniture, lamps and decorative accessories are up to 70 percent off at BoConcept’s warehouse sale, on Saturday (the Cavona dining chair, regularly $199, will be $69); 20 Pulaski Street, Bayonne, N.J., (201) 433-4461, boconcept.us.

headline: Scare Me, Sure, but Also Make a Statement
text: Propellers where faces ought to be. Woman-on-woman death matches. Celebrity chefs with a taste for human flesh. All you cinephiles who like to find grand statements and social criticism in horror movies, prepare to bloviate. It’s midnight at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Would converting my basement into a man cave increase the resale value of my home?

headline: ‘A Pretty Shameful Day’ in Washington
text: That’s how President Obama characterized the shockingly cowardly act by which the United States Senate betrayed the victims of the Newtown massacre and every American who has been killed by gun violence since then. Ninety-percent of Americans support expanded background checks, but 45 percent of the Senate killed a bill that would have provided that expansion – without infringing in the slightest way on the Second Amendment.

headline: Partner Without the Prize
text: Twenty-two years after being passed by, the architect Denise Scott Brown, 81, said at an awards ceremony for women in architecture last month that it was time she share in the 1991 Pritzker Prize that was given to her design partner and husband, Robert Venturi, with whom she had worked side by side.

headline: Obama Says Gun Lobby ‘Willfully Lied’
text: Following a Senate vote that defeated several gun-related measures, President Obama spoke in the Rose Garden of the White House.

headline: A Single Vision
text: In their new space, like every other home Teman Evans and his identical twin, Teran, have shared, nothing is costly or permanent.

headline: I’ll Be Your Mirror
text: As newborns, Teman Evans and his identical twin, Teran, looked so much alike that the doctor who delivered them had to put bracelets on them so their mother could tell them apart. (When they were 10, she confessed that soon after, she had taken the bracelets off to bathe the twins, and wasn’t entirely sure she had put them back on correctly.) At 33, those bracelets are long gone, but the twins remain almost indistinguishable.

headline: Obama Decries Senate’s Rejection of Gun Safety Measures
text: Flanked by family members of the Newtown, Conn., shooting victims and former Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona, President Obama decried a Senate vote defeating gun control legislation, saying a minority of senators “blocked common-sense gun reforms even while these families looked on from the Senate gallery.”

headline: Impatiens, and Some Alternatives
text: Consider the collapse of your favorite annual as an invitation to experiment.

headline: A Pox on Your Flowers
text: A mysterious strain of downy mildew has been killing one of the home gardener’s favorite annual flowers, Impatiens walleriana, up and down the East and West Coasts, in the Midwest, Texas and Ontario.

headline: Settling Fee Dispute, Law Firm Denounces ‘E-Mail Humor’
text: The law firm DLA Piper has settled a fee dispute with one of its clients, resolving a case that highlighted lawyers’ e-mails that discussed overbilling the client, in one instance using the phrase “churn that bill, baby!” to describe their work.

headline: Misconceptions Could Lead to Health Law ‘Train Wreck,’ Baucus Warns
text: A routine Senate budget hearing turned into a public scolding as a prominent backer of the health care overhaul warned that a lack of public information could cause a “train wreck” as the law’s implementation moves forward.

headline: Were You or Someone You Know at the Marathon Finish Line?
text: Over the past several days, Times reporters and editors have been working on identifying and telling the stories of the people in the image above, a frame from video recorded at the moment of the first explosion at the Boston Marathon. We have found many of the people seen here, but would like your help in identifying more. Are you visible in any part of this image recorded on Monday afternoon or do you know someone who was there? Please fill out the form below and include your location. A reporter or editor will follow up on all relevant leads.

headline: Making the Best of It
text: MILAN — The dog had spots.

headline: Highlights From the Milan Furniture Fair
text: From dalmatians to miniature fireplaces.

headline: A Treat for Art Students: Leggy Models With Multicolor Coats and Fine Manes
text: Jordan Judd did something on Wednesday that art students do not usually do: He walked away with one of the models.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: Groucho Marxwouldn’t join any club that would have him as a member, but he probably wasn’t as concerned about his complexion as the target customer for these deals.

headline: Rising Bank Profits Tempt a Push for Tougher Rules
text: Banks have been reporting steady growth in earnings since soon after the financial crisis. With the latest reports rolling in, analysts think the banks’ first-quarter profits will be their best ever.

headline: Photo Replay: April 17
text: A view of the day in sports, full of leaps and strong finishes.

headline: An Afghan City’s Economic Success Extends to Its Sex Trade
text: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — This verdant town is home to some of Afghanistan’s greatest treasures: It is the birthplace of the celebrated poet Rumi, and the site of one of the country’s most storied mosques. It is the first Afghan city to have been connected with another country by rail.

headline: Ricin: Poison of Choice Over the Years
text: This toxic chemical comes from the bright red castor plant and can be deadly if inhaled.

headline: The Polo Rebuttoned
text: UNIQLO IS MAKING A BIG BET on polo shirts. Walk into the stores and you will find stacks of them, striped, solid, piqué and otherwise. Hold out until next week and you will find even more.

headline: Hedi Slimane’s First Year at Saint Laurent
text: Since he replaced the designer Stefano Pilati in a creative takeover that bordered on a coup, Mr. Slimane, 44, has introduced a vision for Saint Laurent.

headline: Mr. Provocative
text: Hedi Slimane could write a book on how to lose friends and still influence people.

headline: London to Harlem via Chelsea
text: On a recent afternoon, the longtime society caterer Serena Bass was having lunch at Lido, the Italian restaurant in Harlem where she has been the executive chef since last fall, and reading a text message. “There is a book just out called ‘Best Chefs America,’ and I’m in it,” she said. “I’m quite surprised. So that’s good.”

headline: Stop Involving Red ‘Pelle Pelle’ Jacket
text: A wanted poster distributed to police officers the day of the stop and photographs of the witness who was stopped on the way home from his mother’s wearing a similar red jacket.

headline: Obama’s Remarks After Senate Gun Votes
text: The following is a transcript of remarks by President Obama and Mark Barden, the father of a 7-year-old killed during the Sandy Hook shooting, after the Senate rejected gun measures, as provided by the White House.

headline: The Senate Fails Americans
text: For 45 senators, the carnage at Sandy Hook Elementary School is a forgotten tragedy. The toll of 270 Americans who are shot every day is not a problem requiring action. The easy access to guns on the Internet, and the inevitability of the next massacre, is not worth preventing.

headline: Henry A. Prunier, 91, U.S. Soldier Who Trained Vietnamese Troops, Dies
text: Henry A. Prunier taught Vo Nguyen Giap, the Vietnamese general who withstood the armies of France and the United States, how to throw a grenade.

headline: Italian Coachwork in American Proportions: the Dual-Ghia Convertible
text: After seeing what sorts of concept-car tricks automakers were up to at the last few auto shows, it’s fun to dust off the pages of history and examine the concepts that designers dreamed up in the 1950s. Today, form usually follows function — with the possible exception of the huge, masculine grilles currently in vogue — but during the early years of the jet age, the Big Three fielded many flamboyant, sleek concepts with lines that brought to mind images of rockets blasting off into outer space.

headline: Kerry Encourages Venezuela Recount
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Secretary of State John Kerry said Wednesday that Venezuela should hold a recount of votes cast in its presidential election, which the country’s electoral authorities say was narrowly won by a protégé of former President Hugo Chávez.

headline: As Italy Picks a President, Some Say It’s Time to Choose a Woman
text: ROME — Italian lawmakers begin voting on Thursday for a successor to President Giorgio Napolitano amid growing debate about electing a woman for the first time in this male-dominated society, and even seemingly strong popular support for the idea.

headline: Just in Time, a Veteran Joins the Knicks
text: Quentin Richardson has seen and experience just about everything in the N.B.A. during his 12-year career, and when the 33-year-old veteran joined the Knicks on Wednesday morning for the team shootaround and an introductory news conference, he said all the things one would expect of a veteran who signed with a team just before the season finale.

headline: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON — Hours after a bipartisan group of eight senators introduced a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s immigration system, conservative radio talk show hosts took over two floors of a Capitol Hill hotel on Wednesday and denounced the proposal on the country’s drive-time airwaves as nothing more than a reward for lawbreakers.

headline: A History of Oopsies in Economic Studies
text: As my colleague Annie Lowrey has been covering, a frenzy has erupted over errors in an influential paper by Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff. Probably the most embarrassing mistake dealt with errors in a simple formula in an Excel spreadsheet.

headline: More Children in Greece Are Going Hungry
text: ATHENS — As an elementary school principal, Leonidas Nikas is used to seeing children play, laugh and dream about the future. But recently he has seen something altogether different, something he thought was impossible in Greece: children picking through school trash cans for food; needy youngsters asking playmates for leftovers; and an 11-year-old boy, Pantelis Petrakis, bent over with hunger pains.

headline: Report Urges White House to Rethink Iran Penalties
text: WASHINGTON — A panel of former senior American officials and outside experts, including several who recently left the Obama administration, issued a surprisingly critical assessment of American diplomacy toward Iran on Wednesday, urging President Obama to become far more engaged and to reconsider the likelihood that harsh sanctions will drive Tehran to concessions.

headline: English Club’s Change at Top Brings It Low
text: BLACKBURN, England — Neil Thornton, enjoying a drink at a restaurant inside Blackburn Rovers’ Ewood Park, smiled when he recalled his wedding reception. It was held at a suite inside the stadium in 1995, and he could glimpse the seat he occupied as a season-ticket holder.

headline: News Media Weigh Use of Photos of Carnage
text: Even for a society comfortable with blood and gore in its movies and video games, the bombings at the Boston Marathon have sparked a new debate among news organizations about when images are too gruesome to display.

headline: Making the Most of His Gifts and Flaws
text: Pat Summerall’s hotel room in Minneapolis was a mess. Clothes were strewn on the bed. There were empty bottles of booze.

headline: U.S. Accuses Company of Adding Mobile Fees
text: WASHINGTON — Those surreptitious charges for flirting tips, yoga lessons and psychic services, long a problem on landlines, have become a costly nuisance for mobile phone users — and a new focus for regulators.

headline: Court Declines to Rule in Wikileaks Complaint
text: A military appeals court on Wednesday declined to rule on a lawsuit seeking greater access for journalists to court filings and proceedings in the criminal case against Pfc. Bradley Manning, who has admitted to leaking 700,000 confidential government documents to WikiLeaks. The Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces decided 3 to 2 that it did not have jurisdiction to hear the appeal, filed by a coalition of journalists and organizations, including the Center for Constitutional Rights, which said in a statement that the ruling meant that Private Manning’s trial, set for June 3, will be “fundamentally unfair.” Military officials initially withheld from the public all documents in the case, including some the judge read aloud in court. More recently, officials have released a selection of documents, but with names and other information blacked out.

headline: A Senate in the Gun Lobby’s Grip
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Lessons From Military Surgeries Informed Treatment of Boston Victims
text: BOSTON — For years, Dr. Michael J. Weaver, an orthopedic trauma surgeon, went to meetings of his professional society and heard surgeons from the military describe what they had learned treating blast injuries. Then he would return to his practice at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston, where he mostly treated people injured in auto accidents or falls.

headline: No Deal Yet in Talks to Reduce Strife Between Serbia and Kosovo
text: PARIS — Talks aimed at overcoming ethnic enmities between Serbia and its former province, Kosovo, ended Wednesday without an agreement, senior Kosovo officials said, as the two countries struggled to negotiate a deal that would enhance regional stability and help clear the way for their eventual membership in the European Union.

headline: A Story of Pain, but Also Perseverance
text: Beginning Thursday, Amar’e Stoudemire will watch his life flash before his eyes on the big screen.

headline: Before Adding Players, Jets Face a Tough Call
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The N.F.L. draft looms large for the rebuilding Jets, who are in their current position — upending their roster, overhauling their coaching staff, hiring a new general manager — in part because of their missteps at this time of year. Their needs are so plentiful that it is feasible they could use their first-round pick, No. 9 over all, on a guard, an offensive tackle, a defensive tackle, an outside linebacker, a wide receiver or even a cornerback.

headline: Europeans Step Toward Easing Syrian Oil Exports
text: BRUSSELS — European Union members reached a preliminary agreement on Wednesday that would ease an embargo on oil exports from Syria, diplomats said, part of an effort to enable opposition-held areas with petroleum resources to develop an economic base and some self-sufficiency.

headline: War and Sports Shape Better Artificial Limbs
text: John Kremer, a Navy explosives expert, lost both his legs below the knee after stepping on a mine in Afghanistan in 2010. In his San Diego hospital bed, he assumed he would be chained to a wheelchair for a year or more. Walking seemed a distant goal. Running? He could barely comprehend the concept anymore.

headline: Of Judges and Judging
text: If you read only one judicial opinion this year, you might consider skipping the Supreme Court entirely and going right to a decision issued early this month by Judge Edward R. Korman of Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

headline: Lighting a Spark on the High Plains
text: LINCOLN, Neb.

headline: Isles’ Road to Playoffs Is Barnstorming Tour
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — As the lockout-shortened 48-game N.H.L. regular season nears a close, the resurgent Islanders face the challenge of playing their final five games on the road.

headline: Only One Title Matters (and It’s Not Scoring)
text: Before Knicks fans get too excited about Carmelo Anthony’s first scoring title, note that the N.B.A.’s leading scorer has rarely played for the league champion. That feat has been accomplished 11 times by five players, and six of those times were by one player: Michael Jordan. No one has done it since Shaquille O’Neal led the Lakers to a title in 1999-2000.

headline: The Kids Are (Not) All Right
text: The United States has done it again — and not in a good way.

headline: Pollan Cooks!
text: The seven most famous words in the movement for good food are: “Eat food. Not too much. Mostly plants.” They were written, of course, by Michael Pollan, in “In Defense of Food: An Eater’s Manifesto,” the follow-up to “The Omnivore’s Dilemma.”

headline: Fire Island’s Lucky Break
text: Fire Island, the long ribbon of sand, grass and dwarf-pine forest that lies off the South Shore of Long Island, has two main jobs. One is to be a lovely setting for vacation cottages and deer. The other is to be the barrier that encloses the placid Great South Bay and protects large swaths of the suburban mainland from the open Atlantic.

headline: A Giant Setback for Human Rights
text: The Supreme Court’s conservatives dealt a major blow Wednesday to the ability of American federal courts to hold violators of international human rights accountable. The court declared that a 1789 law called the Alien Tort Statute does not allow foreigners to sue in American courts to seek redress “for violations of the law of nations occurring outside the United States.”

headline: Surprise! Ticos Want to Play U.S. at Saprissa
text: It never snows in Costa Rica, but other unmentionable items have been know to rain down on opposing players at Estadio Ricardo Saprissa.

headline: Latin America’s Go-To Hero
text: Can you name an American founder whose name is shouted in the streets, whose legacy inspires fanatical worship, whose image is used to bolster ideals not his own, whose mantle is claimed by both left and right? There is no Washington party, no Jeffersonian republic. No one runs for president in Madison’s name. But in Latin America, as the Venezuelan election on Sunday reminded us, the question is easy, and the answer is Simón Bolívar.

headline: Honduras: Attorney General Is Suspended
text: Saying it was frustrated with some of the worst criminal violence in the world, the Honduran congress suspended the attorney general and his assistant and replaced them with a temporary oversight committee. The three-person commission will have 60 days to analyze why the prosecutor’s office has been unable to solve so many criminal cases, and will generate a plan to improve the trustworthiness of the institution. Honduras, which has become a major drug route to the United States, has one of the highest homicide rates in the world.

headline: Egypt: Mubarak to Be Moved to Prison
text: Egypt’s chief prosecutor on Wednesday ordered the transfer of former President Hosni Mubarak from a Cairo military hospital back to prison. Mr. Mubarak is expected to be held there pending a retrial on charges including complicity in the killing of protesters during the 2011 revolt that toppled him. He had been in the hospital since December after injuring himself during a fall in the prison shower, his lawyers said. The prosecutor ordered the transfer after Mr. Mubarak appeared Saturday in a Cairo courtroom, where, despite being on a gurney, the former president appeared in good health and high spirits, waving to supporters. A medical board subsequently ruled that Mr. Mubarak was well enough to be sent back to prison. A judge scheduled May 11 as the date for the new trial.

headline: Gun Control Effort Had No Real Chance, Despite Pleas
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, his face set with rage, stood in the Rose Garden surrounded by the families of Newtown and former Representative Gabrielle Giffords and asked how a measure to expand background checks for gun buyers — one supported by an overwhelming majority of Americans and a bipartisan majority of the Senate — had slipped away.

text: WASHINGTON — Federal agents arrested a man on Wednesday who is suspected of sending letters believed contaminated by the poison ricin to President Obama and a Republican senator. The F.B.I. identified the suspect as Paul Kevin Curtis of Corinth, Miss.

headline: Some Testimony on Police Tactic Undercuts Bias Claim
text: One man was stopped and frisked because of his expensive red leather jacket — similar to one that a murder suspect was wearing in a wanted poster. Another man was stopped after a woman complained to the police that he was following her. Still another was stopped by officers who had watched him jostle the door of a home, trying to get in.

headline: Mets Hoping Frigid Trip Doesn’t Send Them Into a Cold Spell
text: DENVER — Ballplayers who are asked about bad-weather games tend to offer some variation of the same stock response: Both teams played in it.

text: Just before his son was born, Dason Peters finally revealed to his mother what he could no longer hide: he would be a father.

headline: Figures in Statistics
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Every once in a while, someone comes up with a puzzle theme that is creative and, more to the point, hard to see. I thought I saw it, but I didn’t really see it until I had stared at it for a good 10 minutes after I completed the puzzle. Even though, to paraphrase Groucho Marx, the Lord ALPs those who ALP themselves, there will inevitably be people who would like the mountains to come to them, so here comes the explanation.

headline: In Boston, Waiting for a Suspect
text: In a chaotic scene Wednesday afternoon, residents and journalists gathered outside the federal courthouse after conflicting reports about whether a suspect in Monday’s bombing had been arrested.

headline: Throwback to the Days of Tasteful Opulence
text: There are tales, still told by the old ones of Broadway, of a time when Charm — with a capital C — was a cardinal virtue in the theater. It was an attribute that made plain actresses beautiful, and turned short, stocky men into matinee idols. Entire plays, it is said, were written in celebration of those who possessed this enviable trait, works filled with airy, tickling dialogue and the accouterments of tasteful wealth.

headline: Nearing End of Contract, Elias Faces Murky Future
text: NEWARK — Goalie Martin Brodeur was asked recently whether he thought the Devils should make every effort to keep left wing Patrik Elias from leaving as a free agent after the season. He threw back his head and laughed ruefully before responding.

headline: The Economy Continues to Grow Modestly
text: A roundup of regional economic conditions in the Federal Reserve’s 12 districts, according to survey results released by the Fed on Wednesday. The survey is based on information collected on or before April 5.

headline: Assad Frames Syrian Struggle as Him Against Western Colonizers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Wednesday night described what he said was an insidious Western attempt to recolonize his country, and he appeared to reject any thought of compromise or negotiation with the insurgency seeking to topple him.

headline: His Velocity Down, Sabathia Faces Reality but Doesn’t Give In to It
text: Age is unkind to all athletes, but especially to starting pitchers. A pitcher who can adjust as his arm deteriorates is one who will have a long, successful career.

headline: The Bowery: A Bounty of History
text: The Bowery in Lower Manhattan is one of New York City’s oldest addresses. That history is now being preserved, as the Bowery has just been listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

headline: Dispute in Hamptons Set Off by Effort to Hold Back Ocean
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — Soon after Hurricane Sandy hit last fall, Joshua Harris, a billionaire hedge fund founder and an owner of the Philadelphia 76ers, began to fear that his $25 million home on the water here might fall victim to the next major storm. So he installed a costly defense against incoming waves: a shield of large metal plates on the beach, camouflaged by sand.

headline: U.S. Infant Mortality Rate Fell Steadily From ’05 to ’11
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s infant mortality rate fell by 12 percent from 2005 through 2011, a promising pattern that researchers say may be due in part to a decline in premature births.

headline: Lakers Will Lean on Frontcourt in Playoffs
text: LOS ANGELES — When Mike D’Antoni took over as the Lakers’ coach in November, he felt that he had a big problem. Two of them, actually. He did not think there was any way he could keep Dwight Howard and Pau Gasol on the court at the same time.

text: Two days after deadly blasts during the Boston Marathon injured more than 170, investigators continued to search for evidence.

headline: Done With Routine of Regular Season, the Nets Can Focus on the Bulls
text: The Nets have been in playoff mode for almost a week now, making the last two games of the regular season largely irrelevant and, to put it bluntly, a bit of a drag. They spent Monday tending to the tired needs of their starters; they spent Wednesday praying those same starters would stay upright.

text: One spring morning during the second year of my surgical residency, I learned that two of my classmates, junior residents like me, had suddenly been fired.

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: Loss Leads to a Few More Questions
text: The Red Bulls lost to Sporting Kansas City, 1-0, on Wednesday night in a testy game in which they put only 3 of their 14 shots on target. The loss dropped the Red Bulls into fifth place, at 2-4-2, but raised a few more questions six weeks into the season.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 2:30 P.M. (FX) SALT (2010) Who is Salt? In this action extravaganza from Phillip Noyce, Evelyn Salt (Angelina Jolie, above) is a Russian mole or a C.I.A. assassin, or maybe both. Shedding her shoes and her underwear, she goes on the run from suspicious colleagues (Liev Schreiber and Chiwetel Ejiofor) after she is accused of being a double agent by a Russian defector. What follows is a symphony of ingenious fights and escapes as she tries to prove her innocence. “Perhaps the most ridiculous scene in ‘Salt’ has Ms. Jolie walking away unnoticed from the aftermath of a multivehicle smash-up,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “I suspect this was meant as a joke, since her magnetism is the film’s foundation and reason for being (even though her role was originally conceived as a vehicle for Tom Cruise). She is the prime special effect, and a reminder that even in an era of technological overkill, movie stars matter.”

headline: News Quiz | April 18, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Plant Explosion Tears at the Heart of a Texas Town
text: WEST, Tex. — The blast was so powerful that the United States Geological Survey registered it as a 2.1-magnitude earthquake. It reduced an apartment complex to a charred skeleton, leveled homes in a five-block radius and burned with such intensity that railroad tracks were fused. It killed up to 15 people and injured up to 180. Volunteer firefighters were missing. Residents of a nursing home were pulled from debris and rushed to hospitals.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 18
text: NEWS Sharply different perspectives within the Obama administration concerning the Syrian opposition emerged publicly on Wednesday when Secretary of State John Kerry and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel made separate appearances before Congress. Michael R. Gordon reports from Washington.

text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “In Little Italy, Saving the Past by Rebuilding It.”

headline: President Xi Takes a Taxi? Yes, Too Good to Be True
text: HONG KONG — For much of Thursday, a tale told by a Beijing taxi driver appeared to offer ideal political theater for the Chinese government: a humble cabby took the nation’s top leader, Xi Jinping, for an incognito ride and revealed Mr. Xi’s yearning to share the pain, and the congested streets, of a frustrated public.

headline: Musharraf, Fleeing Once, Is Brought Back to Court to Face Charges
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — When the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf ended his years of exile last month, it was with a vision of himself as a political savior, returning in the nick of time to save Pakistan from chaos.

headline: John le Carré Starter Kit
text: In this weekend’s magazine, Dwight Garner profiles John le Carré, “the pre-eminent spy writer of the 20th century.” Here, he picks the le Carré books that no true fan — or novice — should miss.

headline: Public Enemy’s Private Photographer
text: Ernie Paniccioli leaned in close. “Yo, take a minute,” he insisted. “You’ve got to listen to this from Public Enemy!”

headline: Waking Up on the Wrong Side of a Ratings War
text: One Wednesday last month, Ann Curry, camouflaged in a hat and trench coat, trudged into the art-deco lobby of 30 Rockefeller Plaza. It had been nine months since she was pushed out as co-host of the “Today” show. Curry was now NBC’s “national and international correspondent” and the anchor at large for “Today,” but these titles seemed honorary. Curry had appeared on “Today” only a handful of times since her ouster. She had no role in NBC’s coverage of election night or Inauguration Day. She taped a few stories for “Rock Center,” the prime-time newsmagazine show, but as she explained on Twitter, her bosses kept rescheduling them. Curry had moved to an office on the 27th floor of 30 Rock, far from her NBC News bosses on the third floor. On this morning, she was at work on a short “NBC Nightly News” segment about the anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.’s death. It would be only her sixth appearance on the network all year.

headline: John le Carré Has Not Mellowed With Age
text: On a recent Saturday morning in February, two dozen or so scent hounds streamed through the streets of St. Buryan, a small village in Cornwall, England. Behind them drifted a loose formation of men and women perched atop well-groomed horses and wearing boots, breeches and hunting coats. As the fox hunt clopped through town, John le Carré, the pre-eminent spy writer of the 20th century, sipped from a paper cup of warm whiskey punch, doled out by a local pub to riders and spectators.

headline: College Is a Journey, Not a Destination
text: Martha O’Connell is the executive director of Colleges That Change Lives, a nonprofit organization that focuses on a student-centered college search process.

headline: Experts Look Beyond Birds in Investigation of Flu Strain in China
text: BEIJING — China is investigating four possible cases of human-to-human transmission of a deadly bird flu that has killed 17 people, but so far there has been “no sustained” evidence of transmission between people, the World Health Organization said Thursday.

headline: The Early Word: Embers
text: In Today’s Times:The embers are all that remain of a push to expand gun control laws after the Senate defeated several amendments on Wednesday, leaving Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, to postpone debate on the bill on Thursday, Jonathan Weisman reports.

headline: North Korea Tones Down Language, Giving Hope for Dialogue
text: SEOUL, South Korea — By North Korean standards, the invective issued over the past week has bordered on civil. Instead of near daily threats of nuclear annihilation for the “nest of evil” in the United States and promises to “press the button,” the North in recent days has grumbled over a “crafty ploy” and “cunning trick” by America and its allies to strip the North of its nuclear arsenal.

headline: Don’t Talk the Talk
text: MEXICO CITY — There will be no more drug executions in Mexico, no more levantones (kidnappings with intent to murder) or encajuelados (dead bodies in car trunks, or cajuelas). There will be no more mob bosses, no more mob soldiers, no more hit men.

headline: The S.B.A. Wants to Encourage More Small Loans
text: For the last several years, the Small Business Administration has attempted to expand its loan-guarantee programs by making them available to bigger businesses. But with the 2014 budget that the White House sent to Congress last week, the Obama administration is trying to solve a problem at the other end of the spectrum: how to induce banks to make smaller loans, to smaller businesses.

headline: Daily Report: As Unauthorized Fees Hit Cellphone Bills, U.S. Acts
text: In the last two years, regulators have found that hundreds of thousands of mobile phone users have been charged for “premium text” services that they did not authorize, a practice known as bill cramming. Now the crackdown has begun, Edward Wyatt reports in The New York Times.

headline: Japanese Exports Rise, but Demand for Goods Is Lackluster
text: TOKYO — A dispute over islands with China that led to boycotts of Japanese goods, coupled with rising energy purchases to compensate for idled nuclear plants, gave Japan a record annual trade deficit last year, the government said on Thursday, in another sign of a steadily worsening trade situation for this onetime export juggernaut.
