headline: Our Feelings About Inequality: It’s Complicated
text: How much do Americans care about rising income inequality? Surveys send mixed signals.

headline: Straight Talk From a Professor of Flimflam (but Don’t Ask His Age)
text: Breakfast with the grand illusionist Ricky Jay happened to come on a morning when the newspapers carried articles on some well-known figures who have given others reason to wonder if they are con artists.

headline: The Jobless Trap
text: F.D.R. told us that the only thing we had to fear was fear itself. But when future historians look back at our monstrously failed response to economic depression, they probably won’t blame fear, per se. Instead, they’ll castigate our leaders for fearing the wrong things.

headline: A Cash Register Without Buttons or Bells
text: Designers are providing an increasing array of choices as retailers use iPads in place of  traditional cash registers.

headline: With Tablets, Businesses Ring Up at More Fanciful Cash Registers
text: SEATTLE — The humble cash register, a device that seems sprung from the imagination of an accountant, has become the darling of designers, adding a dash of style to the most ordinary daily transactions.

headline: Cancer Centers Racing to Map Patients’ Genes
text: Electric fans growl like airplanes taking off and banks of green lights wink in a basement at Mount Sinai’s medical school, where a new $3 million supercomputer makes quick work of huge amounts of genetic and other biological information.

headline: Activist’s Death in Egypt Spurs Charges of Police Abuse
text: CAIRO — Mohamed el-Gindy spent three days in violent protests around Tahrir Square. In a television interview, he promised a backlash if the new Islamist government tried to recreate the Egyptian police state.

headline: From Phenom to Everyday N.B.A. Player
text: HOUSTON — At the peak of Linsanity last season, a certain 6-foot-10-inch fan walked into a sports bar to marvel at Jeremy Lin’s abrupt and dizzying performance with the Knicks.

headline: Web Helps Musicians Sell Shares of Royalties
text: As a songwriter and producer for stars like Natalie Cole, Aretha Franklin and Whitney Houston, Preston Glass receives a comfortable stream of music royalties. But when he needed to make a substantial investment to embark on the next phase of his career — as a performing artist in his own right — he had few options to raise the money, he said.

headline: Investigators Dig for Roots of Bomb Suspects’ Radicalization
text: WASHINGTON — The two men suspected in the Boston Marathon bombings were armed with a small arsenal of guns, ammunition and explosives when they first confronted the police early Friday, and were most likely planning more attacks, the authorities said Sunday.

headline: Conservative Tobacco Magnate Wins Presidential Race in Paraguay
text: ASUNCIÓN, Paraguay — Horacio Cartes, a Paraguayan tobacco magnate, faced various challenges during his presidential bid. He was pressed to explain why antinarcotics police officers apprehended a plane carrying cocaine and marijuana on his ranch in 2000; why he went to prison in 1989 on currency fraud charges; and why he had never even voted in past general elections.

headline: A Blogger on Trial
text: IF you set out to design a political nemesis who would give Vladimir Putin the shivers, you might well come up with Aleksei Navalny. That is why the trial of the popular Russian activist on Wednesday is the most important political trial in Russia in decades.

headline: Two Sunday Running Events in Manhattan Are Minor, but Security Isn’t
text: A swarm of police officers was deployed. Radiation sweeps were conducted. Trash cans and parked cars were unceremoniously removed. There were bomb-sniffing dogs, capable of picking up the scent of chemical vapors drifting in the wind.

headline: Search for Home Led Suspect to Land Marred by Strife
text: MAKHACHKALA, Russia — Tamerlan Tsarnaev had already found religion by the time he landed in Dagestan, a combustible region in the North Caucasus that has become the epicenter of a violent Islamic insurgency in Russia and a hub of jihadist recruitment. What he seemed to be yearning for was a home.

headline: A Modern City in East Midtown?
text: WE are told that New York needs to be lofted back into global competitiveness. That the city isn’t modern enough. Take the area around Grand Central Terminal. With 80 percent of the building stock in the neighborhood now over 50 years old, we hear, our city is falling behind, and current zoning restrictions inhibit redevelopment.

headline: Along the Route, Main Streets, Hills and a New Kind of Heartbreak
text: HOPKINTON, Mass.

headline: Opposition Leader Rallies Italians in Protest After President Is Re-elected
text: ROME — He is not a member of Parliament or one of the 1,007 grand electors who selected a president on Saturday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 21, 2013

headline: Chinese Auto Buyers Grow Hungry for Larger Cars
text: SHANGHAI — The models wore traditional cheongsam dresses and medieval Chinese armor as well as the usual rainbow of shiny miniskirts at the Shanghai auto show this weekend, but the many midsize cars and sport utility vehicles on display made it look almost like an American auto show.

headline: Monte Carlo Streak Ends for Nadal
text: Perhaps the tightest grip on an event in professional sports ended Sunday when Novak Djokovic defeated Rafael Nadal, 6-2, 7-6 (1), in the final of the Monte Carlo Masters, ending Nadal’s streak of eight straight titles and 46 consecutive victories at the event.

headline: U.S. Box Office Heroes Proving Mortal in China
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s global business strategy, which counts on huge ticket sales in China for high-budget fantasies in 3-D and large-screen Imax formats, is coming unhinged.

headline: Trouble at the Chinese Box Office
text: Hollywood blockbusters, which fared well in Chinese movie theaters last year, fell on hard times in the first quarter. “Iron Man 3,” filmed partly in China, is the next test case.

headline: When Offense Is Not Enough, the Knicks’ Defense Comes Through
text: The Knicks knew the key to their Game 1 victory Saturday against the Boston Celtics.

headline: One Mad Power Grab, Many Dramatic Roles
text: The Scottish play, or “Macbeth” as it is known to laymen and superstition-free theater folk, sounds more Scottish than usual in the Broadway production that opened on Sunday night at the Barrymore Theater. The murderous general of the title is portrayed by the Scotland-born Alan Cumming, whose rich, rolling accent brings a whiff of the green highlands with it.

headline: After Arrest in Rapes, Another Man Is Sought in 2nd Brooklyn Case
text: Two days after the arrest of a convicted sex offender in a series of rapes in Brooklyn, detectives on Sunday were searching for a man in connection with another sexual assault pattern in the borough.

headline: Restyled as Real Estate Trusts, Varied Businesses Avoid Taxes
text: A small but growing number of American corporations, operating in businesses as diverse as private prisons, billboards and casinos, are making an aggressive move to reduce — or even eliminate — their federal tax bills.

headline: How to Handle a Terrorism Case
text: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina apparently has a thermal-imaging device for detecting the motivation of the man arrested on suspicion of bombing the Boston Marathon. He and three other Republican lawmakers declared — without the benefit of evidence — that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev should be considered an enemy combatant, not a criminal, and should be held by the military without access to a lawyer or the fundamental rights that distinguish this country from authoritarian regimes.

headline: Broken Justice in the Bronx
text: Quietly over time, the gleaming glass building near Yankee Stadium that houses the Bronx criminal courts has become a place where delay and dysfunction are the norm and central ideals of the American justice system — especially the promise of a speedy trial — have been disgracefully subverted.

headline: Visa Reforms for Skilled Workers
text: The immigration reform bill introduced by a bipartisan group of senators last week would make it easier for skilled workers to come to this country while toughening rules to prevent abuse in temporary work visas.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released includes existing home sales for March (Monday); new home sales for March (Tuesday); durable goods orders for March (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and first-quarter gross domestic product and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for April (Friday).

headline: New Leader Named for Enforcement Unit at S.E.C.

headline: The Bystanders Who Could Be Heroes
text: Do bystanders have a responsibility to intervene in crimes? Why do some individuals rush to help rather than to escape harm?

headline: A Franchise in Ruins and a Coach’s Future in Doubt
text: Until Sunday, the last time anybody had heard from Rex Ryan about something more significant than his distaste for the Baltimore Orioles was a month ago in a lavish ballroom at the league’s annual meeting. With the recovery from one season almost over and the stress of the next one months away, coaches are usually at their most relaxed and expansive at those gatherings.

headline: Nets’ Williams Is Soaring Again
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Deron Williams had dunked in practice, reverse-dunked even, in certain bursts of energy, but his momentous throw-down late in the third quarter of Saturday’s Game 1 playoff victory against the Chicago Bulls still caught teammates by surprise.

headline: Once Mr. Irrelevant, a Giant Remains an Inspiring Force
text: Thirty years ago, the fabled 1983 N.F.L. draft gave the league John Elway, Dan Marino and Eric Dickerson. But the last player picked in that draft, with the 335th overall pick in the 12th round, left a mark as well.

headline: Race and Ethnicity Hovered Over Jury Selection in Trial of Ex-Aides to Liu
text: During jury selection last week in the fraud trial of two former associates of John C. Liu, the city comptroller, federal prosecutors asked the judge to excuse a doctor who said she might have trouble being impartial because she knew a spectator who was related to one of the defendants.

headline: Scenes Along the Route of the Never Completed Marathon
text: The familiar surroundings on the path of the Boston Marathon, changed by catastrophic events at the end of the race.

headline: Report Says Myanmar Was Complicit in Anti-Muslim Violence
text: HONG KONG — The government of Myanmar, which has been trying to get in the good graces of the United States and other nations, is coming under new scrutiny for its treatment of a Muslim minority group.

headline: Photo Replay: April 21
text: A view of the day in sports, from the London Marathon to the Monte Carlo Masters in Monaco.

text: “They don’t want the same old thing, over and over again, the action blockbusters with lots of explosions.”

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (13) THE ISLAND PRESIDENT (2012) The director Jon Shenk visits the Maldives, an archipelago of about 1,200 low-lying islands in the Indian Ocean, and follows the efforts of Mohamed Nasheed, above, the country’s president from 2009 to 2012, as he tries to save the nation, a haven for wealthy tourists, from being swallowed by rising seas thought to be caused by global warming. “It is in the nature of political leaders, especially in democracies, to be optimistic, to insist that solutions can be found to even the most intractable problems,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Topical, politically engaged documentaries, particularly those made by American filmmakers, share in this tendency, offering implicit reassurance even as they deliver bad news about the state of the world.” Mr. Shenk’s film, presented here by “Independent Lens,” “is buoyant and spirited enough to keep those demons temporarily at bay,” Mr. Scott added. “It is impossible, while watching it, to root against Mr. Nasheed or to believe that he will fail. But the hope that infuses this movie makes it all the more upsetting to walk out of the theater and contemplate a looming disaster that the world’s leaders seem unable to prevent.”

headline: Claudio Pizarro: Soccer’s Best Third-Choice Striker

headline: Schwarzman’s Scholarship in China

Schwarzman, head of the Blackstone Group, is creating a $300 million scholarship for study at a Chinese university “that he hopes will rival the Rhodes scholarship in prestige and influence,” The New York Times reports. headline: Going Through the Motions

headline: Rooting for Routine
text: It was a sign of the week behind us that the highest hopes for Sunday’s London Marathon were for nothing to happen. Nothing truly awful, anyway. The sports world needed a day of nothing, of just an ordinary routine event, run under a cloud of sadness and anxiety and the now all-too-familiar flotilla of security cameras. There were winners and thousands and thousands of relieved finishers and sunny skies. There was a crash between a wheelchair athlete and one of the elite female runners, and that was the worst of it. For a while, the jet stream was fueled by the massive exhale.

But look at what follows: dozens upon dozens of killings, some accidental, some the result of a momentary rage, some clearly premeditated. Few of these other killings made the front page or the nightly news, but they add up to a country with a serious gun crisis that needs to be faced squarely—and dealt with by our society.

headline: ‘The Ghost of Gun Control’
text: For years now I have been fascinated by the story of Sarah Winchester, heiress to the Winchester rifle fortune. In the late 19th century, after early death claimed her family members one by one, she became convinced that her family was cursed, haunted by the ghosts of those killed by the Winchester repeating rifle. Sarah decided that she had to move out West and begin building a house, which would confuse and trap the ghosts that were haunting her and her family name. She settled in San Jose, Calif., and once construction on her home began, it continued until her death in 1922.

headline: What Business Owners Get Wrong When Looking for Capital

Believe it or not, I still haven’t changed the phone system in our office that I posted about months ago. I have given up on it for now, moved on to higher priorities. As owners, we concentrate on pleasing our customers and whatever urgent issues arise during the day, and we let other issues — even important ones, sometimes — take a back seat.

headline: Video Premiere | Superhumanoids, ‘So Strange’
text: Those searching for early “song of the summer” candidates need look no further than “So Strange,” the new single from Superhumanoids’ forthcoming debut, “Exhibitionists” (out on June 11 from Innovative Leisure). Products of the Silver Lake scene in Los Angeles that gave rise to the likes of Silversun Pickups and the band’s current tour-mates Local Natives, the dream pop trio of Cameron Parkins, Sarah Chernoff and Max St. John wrote the song nearly two years ago in the early stages of creating their record. “It wasn’t something that was necessarily intentional,” Parkins says, “but it was the beginning of summer for us in Los Angeles, and we really wanted to capture the excitement that people have around that time.”

headline: Video: On the Street, East of West Egg
text: Even F. Scott Fitzgerald could not have imagined the extravagance of Tiffany & Company’s Blue Book Ball Thursday night to introduce its collection of jewelry inspired by the jazz age and the new movie version of “The Great Gatsby.” Tiffany built a blue box over the skating rink at Rockefeller Center, with suspended aerialists and the Tiffany Diamond Dancers. The buffets were almost unimaginable. And, a rarity at New York high-profile events, most of the women wore their own dresses and jewels. Many guests were Asian, some in native dress. Tiffany’s focus on the era coincides with a forceful trend in men’s wear, a 21st-century take on the Gatsby style, bottom row, seen on men passing the store’s facade, marked with “fountains” of tape. On April 17, the store held a reception, bottom left and right, for the new designs, and young people dressed in the spirit. Not to be missed are the windows, each one a glittering gem, by Christopher Young.

headline: Now Showing | ‘Artist/Rebel/Dandy: Men of Fashion’
text: Peacocking, the preening of fastidiously dressed males of the fashion flock, has been exhaustively documented of late by international street fashion photographers who track willing prey in their natural habitats: outside fashion shows, fabulous parties and glitzy store openings where the rare birds tend to gather. The origin of this dandy species, Beau Brummel (1778-1840), and his fanciful progeny are the subject of the exhibition “Artist/Rebel/Dandy: Men of Fashion” at the Museum of Art Rhode Island School of Design, opening April 28. The curators, Kate Irvin and Laurie Brewer, from the school’s department of costume and textiles, have capitalized on this recent surge of interest in the artistry and craftsmanship of men’s wear with their study of clothing and ephemera honoring the aesthetic provocateur. Aided by an archive that includes the personal wardrobe of Richard Merkin, a legendary RISD professor, painter and dandy-in-residence, the curators constructed a thematic, rather than chronological, exploration into what they term the “always provocative dandy stance.” Delving deeper than the decorative surface, they contrast the social subversion of dandy “revolutionaries,” who express political views through their personal wardrobes, with a dandy “historian’s” appreciation of tailoring tradition, while a “connoisseur” prides self-expression over societal conformity. Thom Browne says in the accompanying catalog’s preface that “Rebellion comes from being perfectly comfortable doing my own thing and having the drive to make challenging statements in men’s wear.” According to the curators, by “kicking at the boundaries of taste,” the dandy is indeed much more than the commonly criticized “superficial person devoted only to the outer shell.”
