headline: Linking Stress to Diabetes and Heart Disease
text: High levels of cortisol — the so-called stress hormone — have been associated with cardiovascular disease in some studies, but not in others. This may be because measuring cortisol in blood or saliva at one point in time may pick up acute stress, but it fails to account for long-term stress.

headline: Another Scourge in His Sights
text: CHICAGO — In his home office, Dr. Donald R. Hopkins has statues of the Hindu smallpox goddess and the Yoruba smallpox god. And, floating coiled up in a glass jar, something that looks like a yardlong strand of capellini but is actually one of the last Guinea worms on earth.

headline: Met Opera Announces Outdoor Performances
text: The Metropolitan Opera released the performers, dates and places on Monday for the free park recitals it sponsors every summer in lieu of full-scale opera performances, which were suspended after 2007 because of the cost. The soprano Erin Morley, the mezzo-soprano Isabel Leonard and the tenor Stephen Costello, accompanied by the pianist Bradley Moore, will sing at Central Park’s SummerStage on July 16 and at Brooklyn Bridge Park on July 19.

headline: North Carolina Man Tied to Gun Left in Hotel Lobby
text: The man who inadvertently set off a sweeping police investigation when he hid his pistol under a cushion in a World Trade Center hotel lobby — minutes before the Boston Marathon bombing — was a tourist simply in a hurry to stow it and get back to his tour group, a relative said on Monday.

headline: In Performance: Michael Urie
text: In “Buyer & Cellar,” Michael Urie plays Alex, an actor who works in Barbra Streisand’s basement, and Barry, his boyfriend who’s worked up about the star’s relationship to her hometown, Brooklyn.

headline: Kik, a Messaging App, Raises Additional $19.5 Million
text: Kik, a popular mobile messaging app that also lets people share videos, drawings and voice messages, just got a little more gas in the tank for its race against rivals like WhatsApp, GroupMe, MessageMe and Facebook Messenger.

headline: The Ease of Stir-Fry
text: In What’s for Dinner?, a column appearing every other week on Diner’s Journal, Melissa Clark answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: MOCA Gala
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Earthquake Response and Political Tensions Return to the Spotlight
text: The challenges continue for China’s new leadership.

headline: Strike Grounds Most Lufthansa Flights
text: PARIS — A widespread strike all but grounded the German flag carrier Lufthansa on Monday, affecting around 150,000 passengers around the world amid a battle over wages as the airline pushes ahead with a $2 billion restructuring program.

headline: Therapy for the Golden Years, Crowdsourced Canines, Mind Games
text: Abby Ellin on the increasing numbers of older people turning up in therapy, Carl Zimmer on an effort to see why Spot runs or fetches or ignores you, and David Dobbs on how play contributes to human success.

headline: Creating ‘Youphoria’ the Nordstrom Way
text: Nordstrom, the conservative, upscale Seattle-based retailer, is going after a younger, hipper customer with a new, quirky regional online brand campaign.

headline: A New Look
text: You may notice that we have something of a new look: A man holding semaphore flags at the top of the page to replace the caricature of me that was created by the artist Christoph Neimann when we started the blog in November, 2011. That icon — my kids called it Lego Andy — served well when the only writers for the blog were Juliet Lapidos and myself, but now more members of the editorial board are contributing regularly.

headline: Fill-In | The Enduring Romance of Super Mario
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first nine paragraphs of the article “The Enduring Romance of Super Mario” by Alex Vadukul.

headline: How Therapy Can Help in the Golden Years
text: Marvin Tolkin was 83 when he decided that the unexamined life wasn’t worth living. Until then, it had never occurred to him that there might be emotional “issues” he wanted to explore with a counselor.

headline: S.&P. Seeks Dismissal of U.S. Suit Over Rating of Mortgage Debt
text: 7:35 p.m. | Updated

headline: Nollywood: Censored at Home, Available on the Internet
text: Nigeria’s movie industry — often dubbed Nollywood — has been a source of pride and escape for years for many of Nigeria’s 160 million residents.But the recent banning of a Nigerian documentary on corruption and the country’s oil wealth, “Fuelling Poverty,” has left many crying foul.

headline: Trucking Industry Is Set to Expand Its Use of Natural Gas
text: The natural gas boom has already upended the American power industry, displacing coal and bringing consumers cheaper electricity.

headline: Obama to Attend Memorial Service for Victims of Texas Blast
text: President Obama will attend a memorial service this week for the victims of the fertilizer plant explosion in West, Tex., in what will be his latest foray as the country’s comforter in chief.

headline: Deficits Fall in Europe, but Debt Rises
text: PARIS — An austerity push in Europe helped to reduce government budget deficits in 2012 for a fourth consecutive year, official data showed on Monday, but in relation to gross domestic product, national debt burdens grew.

headline: Avian Affairs
text: Q. Does bird mating ever cross the species line?

headline: Monday Motorsports: Sato Scores Historic IndyCar Victory
text: Takuma Sato scored his first IndyCar Series victory on Sunday with a strong performance at the Toyota Grand Prix in Long Beach, Calif. Sato, whose previous best finish was as the runner-up at Edmonton last year, is the first Japanese driver to win in the Indy car racing series. The victory was also the first for A.J. Foyt’s racing team since 2002.

headline: When Is a Chimp Not a Chimp?
text: Up there on my totally mundane list of repeat New Year’s resolutions each year, right after “drink more water,” is “listen to more podcasts.” I know there’s great stuff happening out there in podcastland — I just haven’t succeeded in carving out a regular place in my schedule for exploring it. The subway is too loud and my headphones are too weak for podcasts to join me on my commute, and if I took podcasts on my runs, they’d prevent me from enjoying shouted snippets of conversations from passing cyclists in fancy spandex.

headline: The Small Picture: Delivering the Goods
text: We recently asked small-business owners to send us photographs that capture the soul of their businesses in a single shot.

headline: Ginger’s Youthful Adventures
text: Most of us know fresh ginger as that thick-skinned, aggressively spicy little fist in the winter greenmarket, or that shrunken knob in the crisper drawer of the refrigerator. But in April and May, if you look hard enough, you’ll discover a whole new root: spring ginger.

headline: Fukushima Plant Operator Should Prepare Better, U.N. Watchdog Says
text: TOKYO — The operator of Japan’s stricken Fukushima nuclear plant should stop relying on stopgap measures and better prepare for the unexpected, the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency said Monday, even as a cooling system at the plant was once again shut down because of a dead rat.

headline: Cassava and Mental Deficits
text: Konzo, a disease that comes from eating bitter cassava that has not been prepared properly — that is, soaked for days to break down its natural cyanide — has long been known to cripple children.

headline: Rushdie on the ‘Midnight’s Children’ Script: ‘If I Want to Hack Stuff Out, I’ll Hack Stuff Out’
text: Salman Rushdie’s sprawling novel “Midnight’s Children,” published in 1981, tells the story of Saleem Sinai, a boy born at the stroke of midnight on Aug. 15, 1947, the very moment when India gained independence from British rule. The book’s many characters, elements of magical realism (Saleem can telepathically communicate with other children born at the same time), and vast spatial and temporal canvas have made it notoriously difficult to film. The BBC had planned an adaptation in the 1990s, and before that producers involved with Richard Attenborough’s Academy Award-winning biopic “Gandhi” had approached Mr. Rushdie about a possible movie version. The movie will finally make it to the screen on Friday, written by none other than Mr. Rushdie. During a recent interview, he talked about the experience of turning his own novel into a screenplay. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Two Are Accused in Canada of Plotting Train Derailment
text: OTTAWA — The Royal Canadian Mounted Police on Monday announced the arrest of two men who are accused of planning to derail a passenger train in an Al Qaeda-linked plot.

headline: Redefining a Little Library
text: He browsed the books like a giant looking for something to read. Some were small enough to fit into a fold of his hand. Many of the books were illegibly small, and he didn’t know what they were all about. But reading them was never the point.

headline: City Says It Will Represent Officer in Occupy Protester’s Lawsuit
text: Following a decision by the Manhattan district attorney not to prosecute a police commander for his actions at Occupy Wall Street protests in 2011, the city said on Monday that it was now in a position to represent him in a federal civil lawsuit.

headline: The Lies We Tell in the Exam Room
text: Soon, medical practice will be practically perfect.

headline: Playing for All Kinds of Possibilities
text: When it comes to play, humans don’t play around.

headline: Father and Son and Asperger’s
text: When John Elder Robison was teaching his young son, Cubby, the finer points of etiquette almost two decades ago, he noted that in addition to “please” and “thank you,” it’s nice to include a salutation while making a request.

headline: Ratings War Zone Is a Rough Place to Start the Day
text: Brian Stelter’s book on the nefarious network morning show wars ends up being like a breakfast made not quite to order.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Amazon Pilots, and Facebook in Iowa
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Ralph Lauren Corp. Agrees to Pay Fine in Bribery Case
text: The clothing retailer Ralph Lauren has agreed to pay about $1.6 million to resolve charges that it made illegal payments and gifts to foreign officials, including perfume, dresses and handbags, in the latest case highlighting the government’s aggressive crackdown on overseas bribery by American companies.

headline: Nest Labs Reaches for a New Market
text: Even before Nest Labs unveiled its first product in October 2011, the start-up had a strong trailing wind of Silicon Valley buzz.

headline: No E-Mail Response? ‘Life Goes On’
text: This past Saturday, I wrote my Shortcuts column on why people don’t respond to e-mails. And boy, did I get a lot of responses. Clearly many readers out there are fuming over their in-boxes.

headline: A&E Networks Chooses Programmer as New Chief
text: The A&E Networks on Monday promoted Nancy Dubuc, one of the most successful programmers in cable television, to become its next chief executive, overseeing channels like A&E, History and Lifetime.

headline: ‘Matilda’ Opens Big at Broadway Box Office
text: The new Broadway musical “Matilda,” which arrived from London this spring with exceedingly high expectations – and opened April 11 to some of the best reviews of the season – joined the million-dollar club of top-selling shows last week with a gross of $1,129,419, according to box office data provided by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. The show, based on the Roald Dahl children’s novel about a young girl persevering against cruel parents and a sadistic headmistress, sold nearly $2 million in tickets the day after opening and now has advance sales totaling nearly $20 million.

headline: Rage After Child Rape in India
text: Protesters besieged police headquarters in New Delhi, outraged by reports of the rape and torture of a 5-year-old girl.

headline: More Than 180 Dead After Nigerian Military and Insurgents Clash in Village
text: DAKAR, Senegal — One of the deadliest clashes between Islamist insurgents and security forces in northern Nigeria has destroyed much of a fishing town on the shore of Lake Chad, killed more than 180 people and highlighted the brutal tactics of Nigerian soldiers in combating the nearly four-year uprising.

headline: Transcript of the Boston Bombing Suspect’s Bedside Hearing
text: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19, was charged in a criminal complaint and appeared before a federal magistrate who came to his bedside at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center

headline: The Boston Case, From Many Angles
Concept Cars From the Shanghai Auto Show
text: International motor shows offer some of the best opportunities for auto manufacturers to strut their stuff, both in terms of what is and what could be. In the latter vein, the world’s car designers showed off an impressive array of bold-looking concepts at the Shanghai auto show over the weekend, bringing revered nameplates back to life in modern skin and introducing wild new ideas that could someday become automotive norms.

headline: At the Coachella Music and Arts Festival
text: Looks from the second weekend of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.

headline: This Tablet’s Top Attraction? Its $80 Price.
text: If you’re not sure that you need a tablet, $200 is a lot to spend just to find out. But Ematic has reduced the risk with the Genesis Prime, a 7-inch Android tablet computer that lists for $80.

headline: Thoughts on the Boston Lockdown
text: For about thirty minutes late on Friday, during a slightly shamefaced press conference announcing that the authorities had shut down all of Boston to catch a teenage fugitive and then failed to catch him, it looked like there might be a modest media backlash against the decision to put an entire American metropolis on lockdown to hunt a single bomber. But then Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was spotted in a backyard boat, the police and Feds accepted the applause of a grateful city, and the conversation turned swiftly to Miranda rights, radical Islam, and how the press covered the whole grisly affair.

headline: Q&A: Replacing a Dead Drive
text: Q.

headline: Shrinking Europe Military Spending Stirs Concern
text: BRUSSELS — Alarmed by years of cuts to military spending, the NATO secretary general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, issued a dire public warning to European nations, noting that together they had slashed $45 billion, or the equivalent of Germany’s entire military budget, endangering the alliance’s viability, its mission and its relationship with the United States.

headline: In Parents’ Embrace, Infants’ Heart Rates Drop
text: New mothers quickly learn that babies quiet down when carried and rocked. Now researchers say that this calming response is actually a coordinated set of reactions, involving the nervous, motor and cardiac systems.

headline: Q. and A.: The Senate Immigration Bill
text: On Friday, the Senate Judiciary Committee began hearings on a sweeping bill to overhaul the immigration system. The 844-page bill includes a pathway to citizenship for immigrants here illegally, new border security measures, a mandatory nationwide system to verify the legal status of newly hired workers, two new guest worker programs and a host of changes to the legal immigration system.

headline: Carrying a Torch for Pure Academic Ballet
text: LONDON — Alexei Ratmansky’s production of the three-act Prokofiev ballet “Romeo and Juliet” is engaging for both its individual and ensemble choreography, lively in its storytelling and visually attractive, with discreetly traditional Renaissance settings. It had its premiere in Toronto in 2011 with the National Ballet of Canada, which last week danced it at Sadler’s Wells Theater here with four casts of lovers. Of the six versions I have seen by choreographers alive today, this is much the best.

headline: Section 15: The Happy Arena
text: Wonder why everyone is so friendly at the Barclays Center? Ushers went through hospitality training from Disney professionals.

headline: Amazon Broadens Its Terrain
text: David Blum does not have a regular table at the Four Seasons or host celebrity parties at the top of the Standard Hotel.

headline: Original Pilots, Judged by the Masses
text: Amazon delivered its first bundle of original content on Friday, pilots for eight comedies (and six children’s shows) that could become series on Amazon Instant Video. The digital twist is that not only can the public see these pilots, but it can also rate and review them, information Amazon says it will weigh in deciding which series are made.

headline: Subtly Married Flavors
text: The Staatskapelle Dresden, which played at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday and Friday evenings, is an orchestra with a great history and reputation, but it has never appeared in the United States often enough to become really familiar here.

headline: A Star, Vital and Vulnerable
text: Of today’s pop stars, Kesha is the most irregular, the most collaged — it can seem as if she were made from factory-overrun parts. And her talent is purposefully slack. She can sing and rap and do plenty of other things well, but she’d rather hide behind a lecherous sneer and a snotty attitude, projecting a sense that things might fall apart at any moment, just as they should.

headline: Serving Up a Spectrum of Chopin: Preludes, Ballades, Mazurkas, Études
text: Some artists are almost universally admired, while others evoke wildly different reactions in listeners. The Italian pianist Maurizio Pollini has long conjured a disparate response: Some hear profundity in his work, others dispassion.

headline: Building A Mystery
text: Jared Bernstein shakes his head at what he calls “weirdness” at the Washington Post, citing an editorial and a commentary by Robert Samuelson. I second his views, but I’d like to point out something else about Samuelson’s piece.

headline: Study Charts 2,000 Years of Continental Climate Changes
text: A comprehensive new analysis of temperature changes over the continents through 2,000 years has found that a long slide in temperatures in most regions preceded the unusual global warming of recent decades, but with a lot of regional variability and other fascinating details. A National Science Foundation news release has ample background.

headline: Wanted: Mistresses, Must Be Married
text: Among Offenbach’s many operettas “La Périchole” is generally considered his most charming. Well, charming is not the word to describe the director Christopher Alden’s new production for the New York City Opera, which opened on Sunday afternoon at City Center. It’s zany, demented, surreal, strangely dark — anything but charming.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Mark Sanford’s Ad
text: Mark Sanford, the former governor of South Carolina best known for disappearing in 2009 to “hike the Appalachian trail” (actually to go on vacation with his mistress), was never going to have an easy time getting elected to Congress. But his job prospects dimmed considerably last week when allegations came to light that he’d trespassed on his ex-wife’s property.

headline: Game Theory: Jane Austen Had It First
text: It’s not every day that someone stumbles upon a major new strategic thinker during family movie night. But that’s what happened to Michael Chwe, an associate professor of political science at the University of California, Los Angeles, when he sat down with his children some eight years ago to watch “Clueless,” the 1995 romantic comedy based on Jane Austen’s “Emma.”

headline: New Albums from Phoenix and Boney James
text: PHOENIX

headline: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
text: Photos from China, India, Boston and Bhutan.

headline: Internet Sales Tax Bill Gains Ground in Senate
text: WASHINGTON — It has been labeled a tax grab and a bureaucratic nightmare by conservative antitax activists, an infringement on states’ rights and a federal encroachment on the almost-sacred ground of Internet commerce.

headline: In China, Breathing Becomes a Childhood Risk
text: BEIJING — The boy’s chronic cough and stuffy nose began last year at the age of 3. His symptoms worsened this winter, when smog across northern China surged to record levels. Now he needs his sinuses cleared every night with saltwater piped through a machine’s tubes.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Budget Deficit
text: For four years, during and in the wake of the recession, the federal budget deficit ballooned to more than $1 trillion. But because of belt-tightening in Washington and a strengthening economy, it has started shrinking — and fast.

headline: In San Antonio, Viva la Fiesta!
text: Texans love to boast about the republic they enjoyed after divorcing Mexico, but no place celebrates the six flags over the state quite the way San Antonio does. The city has started its celebration of its history called Fiesta, whose signature event is the Battle of the Flowers parade on Friday.

headline: The Best of Newsgaming at the Editors’ Lab
text: This past weekend’s Editors’ Lab at the Times building was a lot of good fun — and it produced a lot of great work.

headline: Flights Delayed Across Country Amid Budget-Cut Furloughs of Air Controllers
text: WASHINGTON — Flights were delayed by up to two hours across the country on Monday, the first weekday that the nation’s air traffic control system operated with 10 percent fewer controllers. Pilots, gate agents and others were quick to blame furloughs caused by mandatory across-the-board budget cuts, but the Federal Aviation Administration said it was too soon to tell.

headline: Architects Announce Opposition to MoMA Plan for Former Museum Site
text: Richard Meier, Thom Mayne, Steven Holl, Hugh Hardy and Robert A.M. Stern are among the prominent architects who on Monday called for the Museum of Modern Art to reconsider its decision to demolish the former home of the American Folk Art Museum.

headline: A Bear’s Brain Surgery, Babies’ Consciousness and More
text: You’re up in space — weightless — with a wet washcloth. What will happen when you wring it out?

headline: Boston Attack Shows Need for Immigration Overhaul, Ryan Says
text: CHICAGO — Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, said on Monday that he did not believe the Boston Marathon bombings should prevent immigration overhaul talks from moving forward in Washington.

headline: Building Beauty at Auction
text: Next month Rizzoli will publish the interior designer Michael S. Smith’s fourth book, “Building Beauty: The Alchemy of Design,” a vividly illustrated tour through his process of decorating a Malibu, Calif., beachfront property.

headline: Protests Against Same-Sex Marriage Bill Intensify in France
text: PARIS — On Tuesday afternoon, France is expected to become the 14th country to legalize marriage for all couples, regardless of gender or sexual orientation.

headline: Italian President, Starting Second Term, Deplores Impasse
text: ROME — As President Giorgio Napolitano of Italy was sworn in for a second term on Monday, he used his inaugural address to scold Italy’s bickering political parties for creating the impasse that led to his re-election.

headline: Turkey Criticizes Kerry Over Request to Postpone Visit to Gaza
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey chastised Secretary of State John Kerry on Monday, describing his request that its prime minister postpone a visit to the Palestinian territory of Gaza as a display of arrogance. The Turkish criticism signaled resilient tensions in the friendly relationship with the United States and suggested that the Gaza visit would proceed.

headline: Mets Add to Pitching Corps
text: The Mets signed the right-hander D.J. Mitchell to a minor league contract, the team announced Monday.

headline: Greek Basketball’s Adopted Son Ponders Major Goodbye
text: ATHENS — Vlado Jankovic feels more at home on the Panionios basketball court than other players. On walls of the tiny arena are images of his father, Slobodan Jankovic, who was known as Boban and who was paralyzed in a fluke accident in a game 20 years ago. Fans still sing songs about Boban at each game.

headline: U.S. and China Put Focus on Cybersecurity
text: BEIJING — The United States and China held their highest-level military talks in nearly two years on Monday, with a senior Chinese general pledging to work with the United States on cybersecurity because the consequences of a major cyberattack “may be as serious as a nuclear bomb.”

headline: More Fliers May Qualify for Security Shortcuts
text: THE other day I blurted out during a radio interview that I hate to travel, which is admittedly a fairly odd statement given that I have been writing about travel here for more than 14 years.

headline: That Coconut Scent, No Bikini Required
text: SINCE being introduced in 1969, the sun care brand Hawaiian Tropic has struck a chord with more than its share of adolescent boys. Miss Hawaiian Tropic bikini pageants, for example, began in 1983, while the 1995 DVD “Playboy: The Girls of Hawaiian Tropic, Naked in Paradise,” dispensed with swimwear altogether. And from 2006 to 2010, the Hawaiian Tropic Zone near Times Square, featuring waitresses in bikinis, called itself “the hottest place on earth.”

headline: Alfredo Guevara Valdés, 87, Steward of Cuban Cinema and Castro Ally, Dies
text: HAVANA — Alfredo Guevara Valdés, a Marxist intellectual and ally of Fidel Castro who presided over Cuba’s powerful state-financed film industry and its many acclaimed movies for much of the Castro era, died here on Friday. He was 87.

headline: Boeing Team Begins Repairs of 787 Dreamliner Batteries
text: Teams of Boeing engineers and technicians began fanning out across the globe on Monday to modify the battery systems of the company’s 50 grounded 787 Dreamliner jets to expedite getting the planes back in the air.

headline: A Presidential Pat for Young Scientists
text: Praising the work of young scientists and inventors at the third White House Science Fair, President Obama on Monday announced a broad plan to create and expand federal and private-sector initiatives designed to encourage children to study science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

headline: Twitter Signs Lucrative Deal With Advertising Agency
text: Twitter continued its march into the advertising world with the news on Monday that the social media company had signed a deal with one of the largest advertising agencies in the world, the Starcom MediaVest Group, part of Publicis Groupe.

headline: German Soccer Hero Faces Prison Amid Record Run and Scandal
text: BERLIN — To say Uli Hoeness led a charmed life does not do him justice.

headline: Robert Earl Holding, Wide-Ranging Entrepreneur, Dies at 86
text: Robert Earl Holding, a Western entrepreneur who made his first fortune in the 1950s running a 24-hour service station in an otherwise desolate stretch of Wyoming and became a billionaire whose assets included oil refineries and ski slopes, among them Sun Valley Resort in Idaho, died last Friday in Salt Lake City. He was 86.

headline: How Writers Interact With the World
text: The image has been handed down throughout the long iconography of the West, most effectively transmitted in the image of Saint Jerome: the writer as a recluse, weaving spirited collocations of words in hushed seclusion. Jerome may have a lion at his feet, but he lacks other company — and, of course, he has no Wi-Fi. His condition is distinctly different from that of the modern writer; her room is not only well-lighted and likely lion-free, but also furnishes an Internet connection, through which the world’s tumult pours.

headline: Subscribers Help Propel Netflix Gain
text: When Ted Sarandos, the chief content officer for Netflix, told GQ in an interview published three months ago that “the goal is to become HBO faster than HBO can become us,” maybe he was on to something.

headline: Rutgers Hires Eddie Jordan as Coach
text: Rutgers is set to introduce Eddie Jordan as the university’s new basketball coach on Tuesday, less than a month after the former coach Mike Rice was fired after video of him abusing his players — including shouting homophobic slurs at them and throwing balls at them — was broadcast on television and on the Internet.

headline: Fed Still Owes Congress a Blueprint on Its Emergency Lending
text: After the Federal Reserve lent more than $1 trillion to big banks during the 2008 financial crisis, Congress required the central bank to devise specific ways of protecting taxpayers when doling out emergency loans to financial institutions.

headline: Co-Directors for S.E.C. Signal Shift
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission ushered in a new era of leadership on Monday, appointing a former federal prosecutor turned defense lawyer to help run the unit that polices the front lines of financial fraud.

headline: Only an Accident
text: JUST after lunch break one infernal Houston afternoon in 1995, I slammed the door of the company truck, cranked the engine, and punched the gas so hard that the truck fishtailed onto Jensen Drive. Beside me sat my co-worker Charlie. In his lap, he clenched a blood-drenched wad of paper towels over what had been, minutes before, his left thumb. The severed thumb, packed hurriedly on ice in a cup, rode in the center console.

headline: Breaking Laws and Fighting Fire Ants in a Rush to the Texas Bluebonnet Fields
text: CHAPPELL HILL, Tex. — It is bluebonnet season in Texas, when hayfields and grazing pastures are transformed into seas of indigo bloom. And while Vermonters take pride in their fall foliage and Washingtonians love their cherry blossoms, Texans can be near fanatical about bluebonnets, sometimes ignoring property laws and personal safety to wade into their fragrant midst.

headline: Revis Calls Trade to Bucs a Blessing
text: Cornerback Darrelle Revis met John Idzik, the Jets’ new general manager, for the first time April 15, and a few days later, they had a more substantial conversation. It was then, Revis said, that, contrary to months of informed speculation otherwise, Idzik said that the Jets wanted to keep him.

headline: Coverage of Boston Manhunt Delivers High Ratings to CNN
text: Despite some critical reviews of its performance during coverage of the manhunt to find the perpetrators of the bombing at the Boston Marathon, CNN attracted one of its biggest audiences in a decade to its all-day reporting on Friday.

headline: New Mexico Horse Meat Facility Moves a Step Closer to Operation
text: Amid the unfolding horse-meat scandal, a New Mexico slaughterhouse has moved closer to becoming the first in the United States since 2007 to be allowed to process horses for human consumption.

headline: Granderson Rejoins Yanks for Day; His Return to Action Will Take Longer
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Curtis Granderson was back with his teammates Monday in the Yankees’ clubhouse at Tropicana Field. It was the first time he had been with them since he said goodbye March 28 when the team broke camp. But Granderson still has several hurdles to clear before he can rejoin his teammates permanently.

headline: Immigrant Kids, Adrift
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: The Confidence Questions
text: By now, many of you have seen the main Web video in the Dove “Real Beauty” campaign. It shows a police sketch artist sitting behind a curtain. He interviews women he can’t see about their own faces and he draws them, based on their descriptions. Then he asks other people to describe the faces of those same women and makes another sketch.

headline: Malicious but Delicious
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: Children Facing Deportation
text: To the Editor:

headline: Do the Police Belong in Our Public Schools?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Confirmation Too Long Delayed
text: The Senate Finance Committee is scheduled to hold a long-overdue vote on Tuesday on President Obama’s nominee to lead the embattled agency responsible for overseeing Medicare, Medicaid and the implementation of health care reforms. The committee ought to set aside its deep partisan divisions and unanimously endorse Marilyn Tavenner to be the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. The full Senate should then confirm her.

headline: When Your Name Is Prominent, but You Are Not
text: I’VE been flying most of my career. As a musician in the early days, I was flying all the time between New York and Los Angeles, and then I started working with Jim Henson and I was adding London into the mix.

headline: The Year in Hacking, by the Numbers
text: Security experts like to say that there are now only two types of companies left in the United States: those that have been hacked and those that don’t know they’ve been hacked.

headline: Justices Weigh Conditions in Awarding U.S. Grants
text: WASHINGTON — The question for the Supreme Court on Monday was whether groups receiving federal money to combat AIDS abroad may be required to adopt policies opposing prostitution. The answer, judging from the justices’ comments in the first half of the argument, seemed to be that the First Amendment bars attaching that kind of condition to federal grants.

headline: Free Speech and an Anti-Prostitution Pledge
text: A 2003 federal statute, called the United States Leadership Against HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria Act, finances a wide range of public health initiatives to treat and prevent disease around the world.

headline: The ‘Smart’ Trend in Hotels
text: At the InterContinental Miami hotel, guests in the lobby can call up the drink menu and flag down a server to order using a touch screen on the coffee tables. The Park Hyatt Tokyo and Park Hyatt Seoul give guests free access to over 2,300 international newspapers on their smartphones or tablets using the hotel’s Wi-Fi network and an app called PressReader.

headline: More Help for Syrian Rebels
text: There was more horror in Syria over the weekend, where scores of bodies, most of them civilians, were discovered in a Damascus suburb. The victims are believed to have died in a weeklong offensive by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad, who seems to have no misgivings whatever about a slaughter, including the use of airstrikes and missiles, that has claimed more than 70,000 lives so far during two-and-a-half years of war.

headline: State Department Criticized by E.P.A. on Pipeline Report
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency sharply criticized the State Department’s impact statement for the proposed Keystone XL oil pipeline, saying the report failed to adequately consider the climate change impacts of building the pipeline or to realistically assess alternative pipeline routes or modes of transport.

headline: Dropping the Ball
text: Should more undergraduate schools follow in the footsteps of Spelman College and consider dropping intercollegiate sports programs?

headline: Credit History Discrimination
text: People fall behind on their bills for many reasons — a recession that costs them jobs, a divorce, an illness. Now comes a further obstacle to getting their lives in order: employers who screen job applicants based on credit histories.

headline: In Gun Bill Defeat, a President’s Distaste for Twisting Arms
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Mark Begich, Democrat of Alaska, asked President Obama’s administration for a little favor last month. Send your new interior secretary this spring to discuss a long-simmering dispute over construction of a road through a wildlife refuge, Mr. Begich asked in a letter. The administration said yes.

headline: Stern Words, and a Pea-Size Punishment, for Google
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Regulators in Germany, one of the most privacy-sensitive countries in the world, unleashed their wrath on Google on Monday for scooping up sensitive personal information in the Street View mapping project, and imposed the largest fine ever assessed by European regulators over a privacy violation.

headline: Day Centers Sprout Up, Luring Fit Elders and Costing Medicaid
text: Scores of elderly Russian immigrants played bingo under the chandeliers of a former funeral parlor in Brooklyn on a recent Monday, with a free dinner and door-to-door transportation from anywhere in the city.

headline: Celtics’ List of Things to Improve Has a Bit of Everything
text: From Paul Pierce’s perspective, the Celtics need to do a lot of things better. Pierce did not say the Celtics should panic after losing Game 1 of their best-of-seven series with the Knicks, 85-78, on Saturday. But he said that in order to win Game 2 on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, the Celtics needed to learn from their mistakes.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Apr. 23, 2013
text: “I just woke up to the fact that I have a mind of my own. Talk about a late bloomer.”

headline: China: Prison for Preachers
text: The Chinese authorities have sentenced to prison seven underground church leaders who were arrested last April and charged with belonging to an illegal cult, according to a Christian rights group. The preachers, who officiated illegal Pentecostal congregations in Henan Province, were given terms from three to seven-and-a-half years, according to court documents released by ChinaAid, a Texas-based group. The verdicts were issued by the Ye County People’s Court on April 1, but lawyers for the four women and three men said they were not notified until last week.

headline: Officials Say They Had No Authority to Watch Older Suspect
text: WASHINGTON — Amid questions about whether the F.B.I. missed an opportunity to discover that one of the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings may have become an extremist, law enforcement officials defended their actions on Monday, saying they had no legal basis to monitor him in the months leading up to the attack.

headline: Shrovetide: Beauty in Eye of Beholder
text: The beautiful game was, and is not always, beautiful.

headline: A Watchdog That Isn’t Watched
text: At the Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s Business Integrity Commission holds a czar’s sway over a sometimes unruly 113-acre operation.

headline: Their Home Is a Castle, Like It or Not
text: AMSTERDAM, N.Y. — Susan Phemister assumed it would be easy to flip a castle.

headline: For Sale: Castle, Mint, Moatless
text: A couple renovates a castle in upstate New York but has had to slash the price below $1 million.

headline: In Tax Fight, Amazon Hands Baton to eBay
text: Let’s rename it the eBay loophole.

headline: For Wounded, Daunting Cost; for Aid Fund, Tough Decisions
text: WASHINGTON — For victims of the Boston Marathon bombings, the terrible physical cost may come with a daunting financial cost as well.

headline: A Changed Smith Gets Sixth Man Honor
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

headline: Corrections: April 23, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Sat on a Wall, Had a Great Fall, Then Took a Bow
text: Suspense is not a selling point for “Mayday Mayday,” a solo show written and performed by the English actor Tristan Sturrock that opened on Monday night at St. Ann’s Warehouse. Although uncertainty as to how the narrative will turn out is generally considered a good thing at the theater, that’s definitely not the case here.

headline: With a Vulture but No Angels
text: Just let the woman speak, for pity’s sake.

headline: After Long Playoff Wait, Warrior’s Experience Is Brief
text: To his credit, David Lee is not using the word “cursed.” Lee, the All-Star power forward for the Golden State Warriors, tore his right hip flexor in Saturday’s Game 1 loss to the Denver Nuggets, a quick ending to the first playoff appearance of his career. But he is trying to maintain a positive attitude about his misfortune.

headline: Some Call It ‘Pop’
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I grew up in one of the most cosmopolitan towns in the world, New York City, and thought I had heard everything until I went off to college in upstate New York. They speak an entirely different language up there, and it soon became apparent to me that I was going to get myself in trouble if I ventured out without someone who was willing to translate for me. SODA became “pop,” sprinkles on ice cream became “jimmies” (I misheard that one, and assumed that the young man asking me if I wanted jimmies just had an odd, third-person way of coming on to women), and I’m sure there were more that I’m forgetting. My point is, never send your kids off to school in another region without a dictionary.

headline: Hundreds Gather at Services Held for Marathon Victims
text: MEDFORD, Mass. — With the horror of the Boston Marathon bombings a week in the past, two communities carved out space for quiet remembrance on Monday, bidding farewell to Krystle Campbell and Lu Lingzi, the two young women claimed by the blasts at the race’s finish line.

headline: Richie Havens, Folk Singer Who Riveted Woodstock, Dies at 72
text: Richie Havens, who marshaled a craggy voice, a percussive guitar and a soulful sensibility to play his way into musical immortality at Woodstock in 1969, improvising the song “Freedom” on the fly, died on Monday at his home in Jersey City. He was 72.

headline: Victims Call on Horace Mann for Inquiry
text: Jon Seiger said he was abused by eight teachers at Horace Mann, the elite Riverdale preparatory school, while he was a student there in the 1970s. Ron Klepper said he was abused so often that he was too frightened to go to school. Edward Bowen said he drank and took drugs for years, trying to escape the memories of his abuse at the hands of a music teacher. Daniel Shapiro said he had spent 35 years believing he was alone in being abused.

headline: Kings Seek Repeat of Late-Season Magic
text: LOS ANGELES — Hours before the Los Angeles Kings clinched a playoff berth Saturday, General Manager Dean Lombardi leaned back against a locker room stall and put his hands behind his head and his feet up to shoot the breeze about baseball.

headline: His Own Man Now
text: Vlado Jankovic was 3 when his father, Boban, was paralyzed while playing for Panionios. After his father’s death, Jankovic became the star of Panionios, and the neighborhood embraced him.

headline: Tenants Seek to Void Deal With Owner Over Rents
text: A major settlement between rent-regulated tenants and a large New York City landlord may be at risk after some of the tenants complained that they were not eligible for millions of dollars in compensation.

headline: Agent Regrets Abrupt End to Liu Inquiry
text: The federal agent who posed as a businessman in order to investigate the campaign financing of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, said on Monday that his superiors had prematurely ended the undercover operation, even though he felt there were indications that campaign officials were involved in irregularities.

headline: Woodson Mentor-Turned-Consultant Has Celtic Roots as Player and Coach
text: BOSTON — In the Knicks’ current media guide, his name is at the bottom of the basketball staff list, below all the assistants, the advance scouts, a coaching adviser and even the equipment manager.

headline: E. L. Konigsburg, Author, Is Dead at 83
text: E. L. Konigsburg, a children’s author and illustrator who twice received the nation’s highest award in children’s literature — she won it in 1968 for her second book, edging out the runner-up, which was her own first book — died on Friday in Falls Church, Va. She was 83.

headline: In Questions at First, No Miranda for Suspect
text: A senior United States official said Monday that federal authorities invoked a public safety exemption to standard criminal procedures and questioned Dzhokhar Tsarnaev on Sunday without telling him that he had the right to remain silent, in order to learn whether he knew of remaining active threats.

headline: At Mayoral Forum, a Focus on the Environment
text: As a sharp-tongued Republican in a liberal stronghold, John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire owner of the Gristedes grocery chain, prides himself on being called a rebel. But he was unusually defiant, even by his standards, at a mayoral forum on environmental sustainability on Monday.

headline: In Stop-and-Frisk Trial, Reliance on Memory Hinders Efforts to Get to Truth
text: The two men appeared in quick succession, a police lineup turned on its head. The men were police officers, ordered to a courtroom on Monday so a witness could identify them as the officers who had stopped and frisked him.

headline: Gift to Help Cornell Tech School Offer an Innovative Program
text: Cornell Tech, the applied sciences graduate school that Cornell University has planned for Roosevelt Island, has received a gift of $133 million that will help it offer an unusual two-year, two-degree master’s program.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 22, 2013

headline: Rays’ Light Hitters Show Pop Against Sabathia While Yankees’ Bats Fizzle
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — C. C. Sabathia has not pitched very well against the Tampa Bay Rays since he joined the Yankees in 2009. He has won just 3 of his 19 starts against them in that period, and he has been even less successful here at Tropicana Field.

headline: Intersection: Bold on Burnside
text: Tiffany Trinidad, a resident of the Bronx and student at the High School of Fashion Industries, draws fashion inspiration from Kanye West and Tumblr.

headline: In a Corner of China, Boxing’s New Frontier
text: Inside the Friars Club, at a table near the back, Bob Arum leaned forward. His eyes widened. His voice rose. Here came another vision, another sell — the next future of boxing, which followed the last next future of boxing, which followed the future of boxing before that — and Arum had seen it, experienced it and planned to capitalize on it.

headline: Victims Remembered as Boston Suspect Is Charged
text: Services were held on Monday for two of the marathon bombing victims as the surviving suspect, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, was formally charged.

headline: Fighting Out of Corner, the Bulls Prevail in Round 2
text: The festive sounds of fireworks and drums in Saturday’s playoff-opening celebration at Barclays Center were replaced on Monday with the slap of a hand across the wrist, the thwack of a body landing firmly on the parquet floor. Forget a sea of blackouts by Nets fans. This was black-and-blue, Chicago Bulls basketball at its gritty best.

headline: Boston Symphony Announces New Season
text: The Boston Symphony Orchestra on Tuesday disclosed plans next season to tour China and Japan, perform Britten’s large-scale “War Requiem,” present Beethoven’s five piano concertos with Yefim Bronfman as soloist and put on a concert performance of “Salome” by Strauss – all without a music director. The orchestra released its programs for 2013-14, which will be the third season since James Levine stepped down as its music director for health reasons after already missing a number of concerts in previous years.

headline: Manufacturing Growth Slows in China
text: HONG KONG — Growth in China’s important factory sector slowed in April, a closely watched monthly index released Tuesday showed, adding to concerns that the pace of overall economic growth in China may be faltering.

headline: Word of the Day | linguistic
text: linguistic •\liN-ˈgwis-tik\• adjective

headline: Game 2: Nets vs. Bulls
text: The Bulls pulled away in the third quarter and held on to beat the Nets to even their best-of-seven playoff series at one game apiece.

headline: Prigioni Is Likely to Return; Chandler Says He Feels Fine
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Pablo Prigioni will probably be back in the Knicks’ starting lineup Tuesday night for Game 2 against the Boston Celtics.

headline: Old Sore Spots Flare Up in China-Japan Disputes
text: TOKYO — Japanese lawmakers paid their respects at a shrine to those killed in war, including those executed as war criminals, in what the local news media described as the biggest group visit by Parliament members in recent memory.

headline: When ‘Love Marriage’ Needs a Little Help
text: After decades of fixing arranged marriages for their children, Indian parents are taking on a new challenge: trying to orchestrate their kids’ love marriages.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) THE RETIREMENT GAMBLE For many Americans, retirement is more dream than reality, with 6 in 10 people believing they’ll have to delay retirement; only 14 percent very confident that they will be able to live comfortably once they’ve stopped working; and 17 percent believing that they will never retire at all, according to this “Frontline” episode. In this investigation of the financial services industry, Martin Smith uses his own retirement fund as a case study to look at the rise of the 401(k), the hidden fees and the shady financial advisers that can add years to an employee’s working life.

headline: Campaign Aide Says Bachmann Knew of Payments to State Senator
text: The former chief of staff for the presidential campaign of Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, released an affidavit on Monday describing how Ms. Bachmann’s campaign allegedly made payments to an Iowa state senator to work on the campaign.

headline: News Quiz | April 23, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Thai Billionaire Offers $6.6 Billion for Discount Retailer
text: HONG KONG – CP All, the Thai operator of 7-Eleven convenience stores owned by the billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont, said on Tuesday that it would pay more than $6 billion to acquire the discount retailer Siam Makro in the biggest takeover announced in Asia this year.

headline: China’s Criticism of U.S. on Human Rights Draws Support (and Mockery)
text: BEIJING — “Gun shootings in America are unceasing, how is it qualified to talk about human rights?”

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 23
text: NEWS Levels of deadly pollutants up to 40 times the recommended exposure limit in Beijing and other cities have struck fear into parents and led them to take steps that are radically altering the nature of urban life for their children. Edward Wong reports from Beijing.

headline: Jonas Kaufmann, Nina Stemme Named Best Singers at Opera Awards
text: Nina Stemme and Jonas Kaufmann won the awards for best male singer and best female singer, and the Frankfurt Opera House took the prize for best opera company at the first annual Opera Awards  Monday night. The ceremony was held at the Hilton Park Lane in London.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 23, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the exhibition review “Finding Painterly Drama in Life’s Delicate Perch.”

headline: ‘Cinnamon Challenge’ Can Damage Lungs
text: In “Consequences of the ‘Cinnamon Challenge,’” Anahad O’Connor writes about the very real dangers of the “wildly popular” dare.

headline: Car Explodes Outside French Embassy in Libya
text: CAIRO — A car bomb destroyed about half of the French Embassy in Libya early Tuesday, officials said, in the most significant attack against a Western interest in the country since the killing last September of the American ambassador, J. Christopher Stevens.

headline: Israel Says It Has Proof That Syria Has Used Chemical Weapons
text: TEL AVIV — Israel declared Tuesday that it had found evidence that the Syrian government repeatedly used chemical weapons last month, arguing that President Bashar al-Assad was testing how the United States and others would react and that it was time for Washington to overcome its deep reluctance to intervene in the Syrian civil war.

headline: Who Says New York Is Not Affordable?
text: One of the first things you learn when living in New York is that what qualifies as wealthy somewhere else seems barely middle-class here. On the Upper West Side, where I live, it’s hard not to feel as if Manhattan is impossibly expensive for young professionals. The average nondoorman, one-bedroom apartment in the neighborhood rents for about $2,500 a month. Oatmeal-raisin cookies at Levain Bakery cost $4 each. A pair of sensible, unstylish walking flats from Harry’s Shoes can set you back $480. I suppose, by comparison, that the $198 chef’s menu at Jean-Georges doesn’t sound so ridiculous.

headline: Protecting the Right to Photograph, or Not to Be Photographed
text: Nick Turpin has run dozens of street photography workshops in Europe, but nothing compares to Paris, where his students are often confronted by furious pedestrians who don’t want to be in anyone’s picture.

headline: Do Bystanders Have a Responsibility to Intervene When There is Trouble?
text: Have you ever witnessed someone doing something wrong–whether a bully picking on someone weaker or someone committing a crime? If so, what did you do? Why?

headline: Leaving India for the Ivy League
text: After receiving a dream acceptance, I have chosen to enroll at Cornell University. It offered me an excellent financial aid package and has a highly reputed computer science department.

headline: A Frank Lloyd Wright House Meets an Old Cadillac
text: Classic cars have a way of getting the rusty pieces of long-dormant memories moving again. The 1966 Cadillac that was the subject of the Auto Ego feature on April 14 did just that for Michael Moran of Evanston, Ill.

headline: The Early Word: Lost in Translation
text: Today’s Times

headline: Why Tim Cook Is Like Steve Ballmer
text: On Monday, Matthew Panzarino of the Next Web, a tech news site, tweeted an ironic message that read “Fire Tim Cook!,” along with a link to a couple of charts showing the steady upward march of Apple’s revenue and profit over the last few years.

headline: Gold’s Declining Price Is a Reversion to the Mean
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Remembering Pat Summerall, the Football Player
text: In the spring of 1958, Pat Summerall was at a post office in Lake City, Fla., when he read in the local newspaper that he’d been traded to New York. There, he was on a Giants team that played a major role in establishing the popularity of pro football. While he was still playing, he began what turned out to be a 40-year career in broadcasting. Summerall died on April 16 in Dallas from cardiac arrest. He was 82. A few thoughts:

headline: Dozens Killed in Battles Across Iraq as Sunnis Escalate Protests Against Government
text: BAGHDAD — Gun battles erupted in cities with Sunni majorities across Iraq on Tuesday after security forces from the Shiite-led government stormed a Sunni protest encampment in a village near the northern city of Kirkuk. The clashes left dozens dead and wounded, and raised fears that the sectarian civil war that is roiling Syria might spill into Iraq.

headline: Iran Rejects Canadian Terrorism Charge
text: LONDON — Iran on Tuesday strongly rejected Canadian police assertions that a planned terrorist attack to derail a passenger train was linked to elements of Al Qaeda on its soil, saying there was “no shred of evidence” to substantiate the claim, reports by Iranian state media said.

headline: What They Said: Former Chief Justice Jagdish Sharan Verma’s Death
text: Jagdish Sharan Verma, former chief justice of India, passed away on Monday after suffering multiple organ failure. Mr. Verma, 80, served as the 27th chief justice of India from March 25, 1997, until his retirement on Jan. 18, 1998. Having begun his legal career in 1955, he has also served as the chairperson of the National Human Rights Comission and the first chairperson of the News Broadcasting Standards Authority.

headline: Why I Pay What I Pay
text: Sometimes, when I sit down to write, I focus on documenting a recent experience. Other times, I think about things that I would like to know about other businesses but have never seen publicly discussed. This post is the latter. It’s about how business owners decide what to pay their employees.

headline: Credit Suisse Sells Private Equity Business to Blackstone
text: LONDON – The Blackstone Group has agreed to buy a private equity business owned by Credit Suisse.

headline: Daily Report: Europe’s Biggest Privacy Fine Is Pocket Change to Google
text: Regulators in Germany, one of the most privacy-sensitive countries in the world, unleashed their wrath on Google on Monday for scooping up sensitive personal information in the Street View mapping project and imposed the largest fine ever assessed by European regulators over a privacy violation, Claire Cain Miller reports in The New York Times.

headline: Should Sunday Become Sun Day?
text: On Earth Day, NASA released a stunning video view of three years of activity on the Sun recorded by the Solar Dynamics Observatory satellite. This imagery, speaking both of the stability and turbulence of the star that makes life here possible (and could greatly disrupt it) prompted me to think we should consider a slight shift in the spelling of Sunday — to Sun Day. My Twitter note has the video and my proposal:

headline: Q&A: Linking a Samsung Tablet to a TV
text: Q.

headline: Cameron Gets Warning From Both Sides
text: LONDON — It may not be every day, or in every land, that the practitioners of the state religion and the national security agencies issue parallel warnings to the prime minister about his handling of the economy, but that is what is happening to David Cameron.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Q. and A.: Whoopi Goldberg
text: Looks  at the lives of Richard Pryor and Gore Vidal, a peek inside the creative process of the Broadway actress Elaine Stritch — several documentaries at this year’s Tribeca Film Festival focus on notable figures in  arts and entertainment. These include a name that may not be as well known but whose cultural impact was significant: Moms Mabley.

headline: Salesforce Wants to Remake Marketing — and Itself
text: The head of Salesforce.com has what he hopes will be a major new product. What he really thinks it is about, though, is remaking his company for the age of social media.

headline: Bright Passages
text: Sparkling prose, from the Bronx to Paris to the obit page, over just a few days last week.

headline: Markets Jump on Hopes for European Action
text: The beleaguered euro zone remains stuck in recession, according to data published Tuesday, increasing pressure on the European Central Bank to find a way to stimulate growth soon.

headline: Trap Denial
text: OK, probably going on too much about this, but I want to return briefly to the issue of puzzled economists, specifically Allan Meltzer.

headline: EBay Joins Sales Tax Fight
text: It was once Amazon that led a lobbying campaign in Washington to prevent online merchants from having to collect state and municipal sales taxes from customers. Now, eBay has taken up the cause as the issue is moving through Washington in earnest for the first time, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. A bill introducing such a tax cleared a procedural hurdle in the Senate, setting it up for a vote this week.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Consequences of the ‘Cinnamon Challenge’
text: Consequences of the “cinnamon challenge,” seeking therapy late in life, replacing a computer’s hard drive and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Separate but Equal
text: JERUSALEM — The rain didn’t deter many observant Jews from visiting the Western Wall on a recent Sunday. And I wasn’t surprised to see more men than women, and more Orthodox men than other Jews. After all, the men have the luxury of access to a spacious covered area, where only they can pray, as long as they don’t stray from Orthodox customs. Women have a much smaller covered area and on rainy days many are forced to weather the elements.

headline: Strangers From Boston
text: Dear Diary:

headline: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Folly
text: As I have been writing a lot lately, the clean little secret of the global economic crisis is that standard economic theory actually performed pretty well.

headline: Shapeways Raises $30 Million to Bring 3-D Printing Mainstream
text: Three-dimensional printing still largely feels like a novelty or hobbyist technology, best for creating quirky trinkets, fancy desk adornments and pieces of jewelry. The dream that the average person will be able to print out a steak knife, a replacement screw or a new chair at home, as easily as microwaving popcorn — still feels a bit far-fetched.

headline: MF Global’s Trustee Sues Firm’s 3 Top Executives
text: 7:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: On Repeated Book Reviews and ‘the Hat Trick’
text: It’s beginning to feel like Nathaniel Rich Month at The Times. The author’s new novel was reviewed in the Arts section on April 10, then again in the Sunday Book Review on April 14. Mr. Rich also wrote an essay for the Sunday Book Review, with many references to that novel, “Odds Against Tomorrow.” In addition, the Editors’ Choice section of the Sunday Book Review listed Mr. Rich’s novel second on its list.

headline: Horse Doping Scandal Rocks Dubai’s Rulers
text: LONDON — The horseracing world has been shaken to its fetlocks by revelations of a doping scandal at the top prize-winning Godolphin stable, owned by Dubai’s ruling Maktoum family.

headline: Therapy Can Still Help
text: Older adults appear increasingly willing to seek psychological help, even at advanced ages, Abby Ellin reports in today’s Science Times. Therapy no longer carries the same stigma it once did, even among the so-called Greatest Generation, and therapists now discount the idea that people in their 70s and 80s can’t change their thinking.

headline: Background Checks for Pressure Cookers
text: Republicans get fired up about a terror weapon that’s not a gun.

headline: Demographics of Homicide and Suicide Victims Reveal Differences
text: More people killed themselves last year in New York City than were murdered, the authorities have said, a consequence of the city’s plunging murder rate. A peek behind the numbers reveals some interesting differences.

headline: The Gun Vote and 2014: Will There Be an Electoral Price?
text: Did the senators who voted against a proposal last week to expand background checks on gun buyers take an electoral risk?

headline: How China’s ‘Leftover Women’ Are to Blame
text: BEIJING — Feminists are concerned that some Chinese women in their late 20s who are doing well in their careers but are labeled “leftover women” for not having married yet, may be their own worst enemies.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Food Republic: A hotter oven, a shorter cooking time, a pizza that doesn’t dry out: Domenico DeMarco of the legendary DiFara shop in Brooklyn shares a few tips with “America’s Test Kitchen.” — Patrick Farrell

headline: The Dynasty Business
text: Maybe Manchester United winning the Premier League on Monday was a sign. Perhaps big-money off-season acquisition Robin Van Persie scoring a hat trick in the pivotal drubbing of Aston Villa signals that this is the year of the dynasty. This plays on the heartstrings of any hopeful superpower. Maybe the Miami Heat will repeat as N.B.A. champions and not lose a playoff game. Could Duke basketball go undefeated? Green Bay win the next three Super Bowls? Perhaps the Yankees can hold themselves together with Ace bandages and Advil and limp their way to a World Series!

headline: Baucus, Powerful Montana Democrat, Will Leave Senate
text: WASHINGTON — Under friendly fire in the Capitol and squeezed politically at home, Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the powerful chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and a man often at odds with fellow Democrats, announced Tuesday that he would retire in 2014 after four decades in Congress.

headline: Allan Arbus, Psychiatrist With Zingers on ‘M*A*S*H,’ Dies at 95
text: Allan Arbus, who left the successful fashion photography business he and his wife, Diane, built to become an actor, most memorably playing the caustic psychiatrist Maj. Sidney Freedman on the hit television series “M*A*S*H,” died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 95.

headline: The Gun Report: April 23, 2013
text: The arsenal found with the surviving Boston Marathon bombing suspect upon his arrest Friday included at least four firearms, one of which was an M-4 carbine rifle, a weapon similar to ones used by American forces in Afghanistan, the Times reported Sunday. Together, the Tsarnaev brothers fired about 80 rounds in a shootout with police officers, yet it appears neither brother was licensed to carry firearms.

headline: Midsummer Night Swing Announces Lineup
text: This year, the organizers of the Midsummer Night Swing concert series at Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center are taking few chances with the program: they have announced a lineup heavy with New York’s established big bands, including the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra, Vince Giordano & the Nighthawks and Arturo O’Farrill and the Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra.

headline: In Performance: Michael Urie of ‘Buyer & Cellar’
text: In Jonathan Tolins’s one-man play “Buyer & Cellar,” Michael Urie plays Alex More, a struggling gay actor who is hired to work in Barbra Streisand’s Malibu basement. In this scene, Alex’s boyfriend, Barry, also played by Mr. Urie, gets worked up about Ms. Streisand’s relationship with her hometown, Brooklyn. The show continues through May 12 at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.

headline: Jelly That Outgrew Peanut Butter
text: Rainy days, cool weather and the jet stream are playing havoc with spring. My plans for pickling asparagus and making rhubarb jam have been delayed. But eager to begin canning, I made this jelly from leftover wine.

headline: Boeing Acknowledges Tests Underestimated 787 Battery Risks
text: WASHINGTON — Boeing acknowledged on Tuesday that its original tests of the lithium-ion batteries on its 787 planes underestimated the risks of fire, though it defended its previous assessment that such a hazard was extremely unlikely.

headline: Decoding Dog Behavior
text: Brian Hare, an associate professor at Duke University, has created a new method to research dog behavior, using the Internet and citizen science.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage and the French Family
text: While activists demonstrate over President François Hollande’s politics, French parents debate the legalization of adoption for gay married couples.

headline: In New York City, Cheaper (and Later) Pedicures
text: I have written a column for The New York Times Magazine about the cost of living in New York, which is actually relatively cheap if you’re wealthy and have standard wealthy-person tastes. It was based largely on research by Jessie Handbury, an economics professor at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, which looked at the groceries that rich versus poor people buy, and how much those different bundles of groceries cost in rich versus poor cities.

headline: A.T.M. Surcharge Fees on the Rise
text: Anyone who uses A.T.M.’s to get cash knows that you usually pay a penalty for using a machine outside your own bank’s network. A recent government report documents just how much those fees have increased in recent years.

headline: Therapy and the Elderly
text: Abby Ellin sits down with The Times’s Michael Mason to discuss the increasing number of seniors seeking mental health counseling.

headline: Buckets of Blickets: Children and Logic
text: A game developed by researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, hopes to show how imaginative play in children may influence development of abstract thought.

headline: Reed Krakoff to Go Solo, Leaving Coach Next Year
text: Reed Krakoff will spend another year shepherding both Coach and his own brand and then go solo, he said today.

headline: Now Showing | Urs Fischer
text: The artist Urs Fischer may humbly refer to his ambitious exhibition occupying 65,000 square feet of Los Angeles MOCA’s two venues as “pretty much a sculpture show,” but it’s more than that. Fischer and Jessica Morgan, the Tate Modern’s curator, have designed a stunning visual presentation collecting more than 10 years of Fischer’s artworks into a formal exercise in high contrasts — order built from disarray, precision from destruction — presented through radical scale shifts, disharmonious color schemes and surprisingly cohesive textural oppositions.

headline: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web
text: The portrait investigators have begun to piece together of the two brothers suspected of the Boston Marathon bombings suggests that they were motivated by extremist Islamic beliefs but were not acting with known terrorist groups — and that they may have learned to build bombs simply by logging onto the online English-language magazine of the affiliate of Al Qaeda in Yemen, law enforcement officials said Tuesday.

headline: Republicans Object to Reid’s Call for Budget Negotiating Committee

headline: Sentencing Postponed in Lauryn Hill’s Tax Case
text: A federal judge scolded Lauryn Hill on Monday for failing to pay back taxes but put off for two weeks her sentencing for tax evasion, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Bayern Munich Opens Wallet, Shakes Bundesliga Again

headline: Thai Magnate Loads Up on Debt for Big Deals

Fresh from leveraging up to buy a stake in the Ping An Insurance Group of China, Dhanin Chearavanont is borrowing $6 billion to finance a takeover of Siam Makro, a cash-and-carry company. Combining that group with his 7-Eleven convenience store chain makes sense – as long as Southeast Asia’s financial boom keeps the cash flowing.

headline: Putting a Dollar Value on a Facebook Fan
text: As noted in Monday’s Dashboard summary of the week’s small-business news, a social media marketing firm, Syncapse, has published a report that says the average value of a Facebook fan is $174.17. Seeking further details about the calculation and its potential impact on a small-business owner’s social media investment, we reached out to the company’s chief executive, Michael Scissons, and had the following conversation, which has been edited and condensed.

headline: Parks, Museums and Budget Cuts
text: The across-the-board spending cuts known as the sequester may have vanished from public consciousness a couple of news cycles ago, but travelers visiting national parks and monuments and museums in Washington this summer will find sporadic reminders of them, testimony at a recent Congressional hearing suggests.

headline: Crisscrossing a Region of Strip Malls and Ghosts

headline: Rangel Sues to Overturn Censure

Rangel is suing his colleagues in the House, claiming that his constitutional rights were violated in 2010 when lawmakers voted to censure him for a series of ethics violations, including failing to pay his taxes properly and accepting rent-stabilized apartments in Manhattan at below-market rent.

headline: Talking Talent | Judith Light
text: The Emmy- and Tony Award-winning actress Judith Light, best remembered as the glamorous divorcée Angela Bower in the 1980s sitcom “Who’s the Boss?” stars as Faye, the matriarch of a wealthy Upper West Side family in turmoil  in “The Assembled Parties,” running through June 2 at Manhattan Theater Club’s Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Like her Tony-winning character Silda in “Other Desert Cities,” Light has clearly mastered the role of a Jewish woman facing personal and familial crisis with equal doses of wit and wisdom. Penned by Richard Greenberg and directed by Lynne Meadow, “The Assembled Parties” provides Light with a role that proves she is a Broadway force to be reckoned with.

headline: ‘Dangerous Liaisons’ Meets AC/DC
text: In the Lives essay I wrote for last Sunday’s magazine, a brilliant live band from Boston called the Upper Crust makes an important cameo. I knew about them because my friend Ted Widmer used to be one of their three guitarists (he also wrote for me at George magazine), and they had this shtick that sounded ridiculous until you witnessed it — they dressed up as 18th-century aristocrats and played heavy metal. Actually, it was ridiculous after you witnessed it too, but that was the point. The reason it worked, among other things, was that their songs were surprisingly great, and the band could fill a room with an energy that inspired villainy. The altercation I wrote about at a 1996 show at Brownie’s in the East Village was apparently not uncommon. “We had a lot of extremes, people who loved the humor, and then a lot of people who got out of control,” Widmer says. “It seemed to make people go crazy. There were a lot of fights breaking out at gigs in the early days.”

headline: Key Step in Checking Chemical-Arms Use Is Also Hardest
text: The most important step in conclusively determining whether chemical weapons have been used is for independent experts to get prompt, unfettered access to the site of the suspected attack, according to Physicians for Human Rights, the American organization that was one of the first to document Iraq’s use of poison gas against its Kurdish population in 1988.

headline: Guest Post | Primary Sources Meet Free Web 2.0 Tools for Common Core Learning
text: We invited staffers at Primary Source to do a guest-blog version of a presentation we saw them make at the International Society for Technology in Education conference last summer.Because the organization specializes in helping educators use primary sources, like newspapers, to teach about world histories and cultures, its writers chose three well-known tech tools — Google Docs, QR codes and LiveBinders — and showed how they might be matched creatively with Times articles and other resources to teach three topics that draw on both current and historical Times reporting.What tech tools do you use to teach with primary resources? We’d love to hear more ideas, especially if, like these tools, they’re free.— Katherine Schulten

headline: Learning (and Rapping) About 401(k)s

headline: The Exploding Floral Inevitable
text: It seemed like a never-ending winter this year in the Northeast. Every time warm weather emerged in the past few weeks, another blast of cold quickly followed, leaving us skeptical as to whether spring would ever really come. Perhaps that’s one of the reasons why Fong Qi Wei’s series “Exploded Flowers” seemed so apt when I came upon it on one one of my favorite art and design blogs, Colossal. Wei disassembled and photographed 20 varieties of flowers, arranging each blossom’s pieces to emphasize its radial symmetry. It’s a graphic and colorful way of looking at one of nature’s most recognizable symbols of spring. Wei started the series in 2011 and finished last November; the images have been making the rounds on various design blogs recently because five of the pictures won second place as a series in the 2012 International Photography Awards. For more of Wei’s images, check out the entire series.

headline: Maybe ‘Mad Men’ Lawyers Knew More Than Lindsay’s

text: Public opinion surveys conducted since the bombings last week at the Boston Marathon indicate that most Americans — while convinced future attacks are quite likely — don’t feel personally threatened by terrorism, and an increasing share of the public is skeptical about sacrificing personal freedoms for security.

headline: Barbra Streisand, at a Gala and in Memory
text: “What am I doing here?” a smiling former President Bill Clinton asked the plush, volubly appreciative crowd packed into Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening. He may have been the effective warm-up act for his friend Barbra Streisand, to whom he was about to present the 40th annual Chaplin Award. Yet when Mr. Clinton sauntered in, taking over host duties with the silky ease of a man accustomed to working the biggest stage in the world, there was no doubt who the biggest star in the room was. For almost anyone else, he would have been a tough act to follow.

headline: Women of the Senate Are Obama’s Latest Dinner Guests
text: The informal caucus of women in the Senate — now a record 20 strong — will take its monthly bipartisan dinner tradition on Tuesday night to the White House, where they will meet with President Obama to discuss budget issues and other legislative matters.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: ‘Dark Touch’
text: From “Carrie to “Firestarter,” the horror genre is filled with girls who have special powers — to move objects, or ignite flames — that can be used for good or evil. In the film “Dark Touch,” an 11-year-old  named Neve, the only survivor of a massacre that killed her parents and brother, finds she has similar powers. What she does with them, and who she turns them against, makes the film more of a grisly revenge story than a tale of supernatural chicanery.

headline: National Park Sites Are Free This Week, but Two Remain Closed

headline: Healthy, Meet Delicious
text: There was a time when few of us thought about what we ate, but that’s been turned upside down since the reigning wisdom first decried salt, then cholesterol, then saturated fat, then almost all fat, then red meat, then carbohydrates and so on. Recent culprits include so many foods and foodlike substances that at least twice a week someone asks me: “What’s left to eat? I feel like nothing is safe.”
