headline: Racing to Spread Word About New Health Plans
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — President Obama and the Democrats passed the 2010 health care law to make medical insurance available to more than 30 million people who do not have it. But with recent studies showing that as many as three-fourths of those people are unaware of their new options, health care providers are joining community organizers and insurance companies in an ambitious effort to spread the word in the six months remaining before the health plans become available.

headline: 30 Years Later, Forged Hitler Diaries Enter German Archives
text: BERLIN — When the German newsweekly Stern announced in April 1983 that it had acquired Hitler’s previously undiscovered diaries, the magazine’s exclusive prompted a worldwide sensation. The editors promised to later hand over 60 handwritten volumes to West Germany’s Federal Archives for posterity.

headline: Students Protest at Culinary Institute
text: HYDE PARK, N.Y. — About 90 students at the Culinary Institute of America walked out of classes Tuesday to protest what they called a weakening enforcement of educational standards, including a requirement that applicants have experience in a professional kitchen.

headline: For a Clam Dish, Wines With a Snap
text: Pasta with clams, one of the recipes in Mark Bittman’s new Flexitarian column, is one of my favorite dishes and is easy as can be when it comes to wine. The combination of olive oil, garlic and clam broth boiled in a rich, briny sauce practically demands a lively, lean, high-acid, somewhat austere white. Italy is full of good examples; just distinguish between mundane industrial bottles and those made with care. Good pinot grigio, Soave or Orvieto, to name three frequently abused wines, are fine choices, as are fianos and falanghinas from Campania. Avoid oakiness and lush textures; the wines want to have snap. Alternatives from farther afield? Chablis comes immediately to mind: a fresh, young modest Chablis. You have beauty in all these combinations.

headline: Theater Program For Youth Who Stutter Will Expand
text: Our Time, an arts organization in Manhattan for children and teenagers who stutter, announced on Monday night that it will expand to offer more after-school theater programs and speech therapy this fall and open new locations in Westchester County, Long Island, and northern New Jersey.

headline: In Iceland, a Festival of Present and Future
text: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — Visitors to Thingvellir National Park, just over 30 miles outside of Reykjavik, can stand on the North American continental plate one minute, and Eurasia the next, by simply crossing a rocky gorge: it’s a divergent boundary where the world’s face is ripping apart slowly. In Reykjavik a different kind of upheaval was evident last weekend, as the Iceland Symphony Orchestra presented its second annual Tectonics Festival at the Harpa Concert Hall and Conference Center here on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. The festival also engaged in shifting borders, but convergence, rather than separation, was the chief process in play.

headline: Immigration Bill Would Aid Security, Napolitano Says
text: WASHINGTON — Legislation to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws would further strengthen the country’s security system to guard against cases like the Boston Marathon bombings, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano told the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday in the last of three hearings on a bipartisan immigration proposal.

headline: Pop Relief From the Generationals
text: Innocence was regained for an hour or so last night during a late set by the New Orleans duo the Generationals at the Bowery Ballroom onthe Lower East Side. They’ve been roaming the indie circuit for a few years, and a couple of their songs — “When They Fight, They Fight” and “Ten-Twenty-Ten” — have been heard in movies or in TV shows or commercials. Even if they did leave out one of my favorite tracks, “Carrying the Torch,” the reaction to last night’s show proved that salvation can still be found in well-written three-minute pop songs with freshly showered hooks, delivered at full nozzle.

headline: Volume Rises in Las Vegas Arms Race
text: Over the last few years the center of the electronic dance world in the United States has shifted to Las Vegas, where top D.J.’s now earn some of their biggest paychecks from casino megaclubs.

headline: The Young Salinger, Mordant Yet Hopeful
text: On Nov. 18, 1941, a struggling Manhattan author wrote to a young woman in Toronto to tell her to look for a new piece of his in a coming issue of The New Yorker. This short story, he said, about “a prep school kid on his Christmas vacation,” had inspired his editor to ask for an entire series on the character, but the author himself was having misgivings. “I’ll try a couple more, anyway,” he wrote, “and if I begin to miss my mark I’ll quit.”

headline: Taking Inspiration From a Visionary Scientist
text: Last week New York Live Arts devoted its first Live Ideas festival of panel discussions, screenings and performances to the neurologist and writer Oliver Sacks. The choreographer Donna Uchizono had the daunting task of creating a dance based on “Awakenings,” Dr. Sacks’s classic 1973 book about sleeping-sickness patients who had been frozen for decades in a trancelike state before being awakened by a new drug.

headline: Temptations and Trouble
text: “Apple” does a spot-on, if unknowing, impression of a Lifetime movie as it burbles with bathos, tragic illness, cheap coincidences, gratuitous alcoholism and tearful confessions of star-crossed love. It even has cheesy transition music. About the only thing missing is your ability to change the channel.

headline: Seeking Proof on Syrian Chemical Weapons
text: The Times’s David E. Sanger on what the Obama administration is looking for before it moves on intelligence suggesting that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria used chemical weapons.

headline: A Pas de Deux for Sisters, Even Offstage
text: MIAMI BEACH — On a recent afternoon here in the spacious rehearsal halls of Miami City Ballet, where palm trees frame oversize windows, the sisters Patricia and Jeanette Delgado rehearsed Jerome Robbins’s “Dances at a Gathering” and swapped pointers. As Jeanette struggled in a high lift over her partner’s head, Patricia, sprawled on the floor below, stretching, suggested that her sister soften with the music. Later Jeanette returned the favor — as Patricia came out of a fast turn, Jeanette advised her to “roll down through your foot” to stop the momentum.

headline: Video: Two Scoops of New York Basketball
text: New York basketball has been down for a while, and it certainly has never had two N.B.A. title contenders. A hoops version of a subway series would be a great remedy.

headline: Threatening Protectionism
text: It’s not just banks who dislike higher capital standards. Now, European Union officials are complaining about them, too.

headline: Lasry Out of the Running for Ambassador to France
text: The billionaire hedge fund manager Marc Lasry will not be moving to the ambassador’s mansion in Paris.

headline: Einhorn Supports Apple’s Big Payouts
text: Apple’s huge gift to investors has at least one big fan: David Einhorn, the prominent hedge fund manager who took on the company over its payouts to shareholders.

headline: Jason Segel to Write Children’s Book Series
text: The actor Jason Segel is venturing into children’s books with a middle-grade series to be published by Random House, the publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: Bayern Munich Subdues a Stunned Barcelona
text: Bayern Munich made a brutally efficient case that it is the team to beat in the Champions League this season, humbling visiting Barcelona, 4-0, on Tuesday in the first leg of their semifinal at Allianz Arena. Thomas Müller scored two goals and set up two others for Bayern, which did not so much change places with Barcelona atop the pedestal as shove the visitors off it.

headline: Flawed Bidding Process Leaves Dell at a Loss
text: The private equity firm Blackstone Group has exited the stage for Dell, abruptly bringing down the curtain on a budding takeover contest. It has the elements of a farce, and Dell’s board has no one to blame but itself.

headline: In Hard Times, Open Dissent and Repression Rise in Vietnam
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — His bookshelves are filled with the collected works of Marx, Engels and Ho Chi Minh, the hallmarks of a loyal career in the Communist Party, but Nguyen Phuoc Tuong, 77, says he is no longer a believer. A former adviser to two prime ministers, Mr. Tuong, like so many people in Vietnam today, is speaking out forcefully against the government.

headline: The Legacy of an Author Lingers at the Met
text: Walking up the granite stairs of the Metropolitan Museum of Art from the Great Hall on Tuesday, Alison Watts immediately thought about how she had taken the same steps as the luckiest brother and sister duo in literature.

headline: Restoring Sea and Romance to a French Treasure
text: MONT-ST.-MICHEL, France — A dispatch in The New York Times in August 1944 described the view of Mont-St.-Michel that American soldiers saw, “racing their tanks across the Norman hills into Avranches.” Built “for war as well as worship,” the writer noted, the Mont “seems to float on the sea as gracefully as a ship under full sail, catching all the changing colors of the clouds.”

headline: Court Backs E.P.A. Veto of Mining Permit
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has the authority to revoke a mining permit to protect streams and wildlife, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday. The decision was a victory for the agency, which in 2011 retroactively vetoed a permit granted by the Bush administration in 2007 to allow a subsidiary of Arch Coal of St. Louis to dump tons of mining waste into several West Virginia rivers and streams. The veto was declared illegal in a 2012 decision by Judge Amy Berman Jackson of Federal District Court, who called it an illegal power grab. But on Tuesday, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled unanimously that the Clean Water Act and Congressional intent gave E.P.A. the authority to retroactively revoke a mining permit. The ruling affects a proposed mine known as Spruce No. 1, which would have involved dynamiting the tops off mountains to get at coal. Kim Link, a spokeswoman for Arch Coal, said in an e-mail: “We’re disappointed in the decision, which was related to the procedural aspects of the proceeding. The case will now go back to the district court for a decision on the merits.”

headline: Judge Allows Phone Apps for Hailing Yellow Taxis
text: A State Supreme Court justice on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit aimed at stifling New York City’s plans to allow taxi riders to hail yellow cabs using smartphone apps, ruling that a pilot program to test the apps could proceed.

headline: Financing Energy-Efficient Vehicles
text: The Advanced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing (A.T.V.M.) loan program provides loans to automotive companies for the development of energy-efficient vehicles, like hybrid or electric cars and trucks, and the systems and infrastructure to support them.

headline: Fearing Price Increases, Iranians Hoard Goods
text: TEHRAN — Iranians rushed to supermarkets to buy cooking oil, red meat and other staples on Tuesday, stockpiling the goods over new fears of price spikes from a change in the official exchange rate that could severely reduce the already weakened purchasing power of the rial, the national currency.

headline: Breaking Down on the Road to Electric Cars
text: DETROIT — No one answers the phones these days at Fisker Automotive. Its visionary founder has quit; its employees have been laid off or put on furlough without pay. Production of its sleek plug-in hybrid car, the Karma, ended months ago.

headline: Gay Marriage Measure Advances in Rhode Island
text: Rhode Island took a step on Tuesday toward becoming the 10th state to approve same-sex marriage when a major legislative committee forwarded a marriage bill to the State Senate.

headline: New Threat in Nigeria as Militants Split Off
text: ABUJA, Nigeria — Nearly four years into Nigeria’s bloody struggle with Islamists in its impoverished north, a new threat has emerged with deadly implications, this time for Westerners as well as Nigerians: local militants who openly claim to be inspired and trained by Al Qaeda and its affiliate in the region.

headline: A Met Approaches Rarefied Air
text: To be overly excited by a few games at the start of a long baseball season can be tricky. Jumping the gun and engaging in hyperbole will often end in backlash and embarrassment. So after four immensely impressive starts by Matt Harvey, is it wise to toss aside all restraint about the Mets’ young and currently unhittable pitcher? Is it time to just start piling on the praise and look for historical comparisons?

headline: Coke Looks Beyond Spotify for Music Promotion in India
text: A year ago, Coca-Cola teamed up with Spotify for what it described as a global marketing partnership, and last fall Coke participated in a $100 million financing round for Spotify.

headline: 21 Years After a Murder, an Alibi Witness Is Willing to Testify
text: At the sound of the name “Everton,” Joann Butler could be heard over the phone drawing a deep breath.

headline: Drone Strikes Turn Allies Into Enemies, Yemeni Says
text: WASHINGTON — A Yemeni man who studied at an American high school told Congress on Tuesday that a drone strike on his village in Yemen last week terrified his neighbors, turning them against the United States in a way that terrorist propaganda had failed to do.

headline: Bringing Back a Behemoth
text: Last year, the Lahontan cutthroat trout became the first confirmed catch of a fish that for decades was believed to have gone extinct.

headline: Canada: Suspects Appear in Court Over Charges in Derailment Plot
text: The two men charged with plotting to derail a Canadian passenger train with the assistance of Al Qaeda denied the charges in court appearances on Tuesday. A lawyer for one suspect said his client, Raed Jaser, was in a state of “shock and disbelief” and described him as a legal resident for about 20 years. The other suspect, Chiheb Esseghaier, tried to deny the terrorism charges he faces before being cut off by a judge. The police say the men were aided by a group in Iran affiliated with Al Qaeda. In London, an Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman said that there was “no shred of evidence.”

headline: Showdown for Westchester and U.S. Over Desegregation Agreement
text: Four years after Westchester County entered into a landmark desegregation agreement with the federal government, relations between the two sides are hanging by a thread amid federal threats of contempt suits and revocation of money. The showdown is raising unsettling echoes of the disastrous 27-year-long court fight over housing that virtually bankrupted Yonkers, the county’s largest city.

headline: Economists Agree: Solutions Are Elusive
text: Last week the International Monetary Fund hosted a conference of some of the world’s top macroeconomists to assess how the most intense crisis to have shaken the industrialized economies since the Great Depression has changed the profession’s collective understanding of how the world economy works.

headline: 20 Pounds? Not Too Bad, for an Extinct Fish
text: PYRAMID LAKE, Nev. — For most fishermen a 20-pound trout is a trophy, but for Paiute tribe members and fish biologists here the one Matt Ceccarelli caught was a victory.

headline: Britain: Man Convicted of Fraud Over Fake Bomb Detectors
text: A British businessman who sold the Iraqi security forces more than 6,000 fake bomb detectors based on $20 golf ball finders bought from the United States was convicted of fraud on Tuesday in Britain’s central criminal court. The businessman, James McCormick, 56, was described in court as having made more than $75 million from sales of the fake device in Iraq and Georgia, among other places, claiming they could detect bombs, drugs, currency and ivory, and track objects up to 3,280 feet below ground. The devices, sold for up to $40,000 each, had no working electronics and were completely useless. They were widely used at checkpoints in Iraq, giving a false sense of security. An Iraqi general, Jihad al-Jabiri, former head of the Baghdad bomb squad, has been jailed in the scam, along with other police officials.

headline: With Juice and Vegan Trends, a Company Aims for National Exposure
text: Organic Avenue, the tiny purveyor of high-end juices, fresh salads and specialty foods like cashew scallion cream cheese and Thai collard wraps, has hired a new chief executive with the goal of turning its new owner’s dreams of a national chain into reality.

headline: Camelot in Canada?
text: CANADA has never had much truck with serial ruling clans. The closest we’ve come to a dynasty was Guy Lombardo and His Royal Canadians, a dance band (not actually by appointment of Her Majesty the Queen; that self-conferred honorific was meant to charm impressionable Americans) made up of four brothers, and sometimes a sister, who ruled generation after generation wherever it is that dance bands rule. But packing an orchestra with that monogenerational cluster seemed less dynastic than incestuous.

headline: Dithering While Damascus Burns
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Hazy Future for Thriving S.E.C. Whistle-Blower Effort
text: For years, Wall Street’s top enforcers lacked the firepower to thwart financial misdeeds like Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme. But now that the Securities and Exchange Commission has turned to sophisticated statistical tools and financial experts, one of the most effective weapons in its new enforcement arsenal may be a more traditional one: whistle-blowers.

headline: A Chinese Threat to Afghan Buddhas
text: In Afghanistan, a Chinese mining company threatens to destroy the remains of an ancient Buddhist city, which archaeologists are now racing to excavate.

headline: Lawmakers Plead Not Guilty to Charges in Bribery Scheme
text: WHITE PLAINS — A state senator and a New York City councilman pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to charges that they plotted to bribe Republican Party bosses to place the senator on the ballot in the city’s mayoral race.

headline: ‘A Chinese Threat to Afghan Buddhas’
text: When I first traveled to Afghanistan in 2004, I immediately fell in love with the country and its people, and I was optimistic that the young people in Kabul would soon have better lives. Yet my hopes dimmed as I learned about a revolving door of exploitation at the hands of the Russians, Americans and now the Chinese — who have begun mining Afghanistan’s plentiful natural resources and threatening priceless national heritage sites.

headline: Goodbye to All That
text: On April 13, Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority resigned. It was an easy development to miss, but not one to be ignored. It was very bad news, because Salam Fayyad was the “Arab Spring” before there was an Arab Spring. That is, he was what the Arab Spring was supposed to lead to: a new generation of decent Arab leaders whose primary focus would be the human development of their own people, not the enrichment of their family, tribe, sect or party. That Fayyad’s brand of noncorrupt, institution-focused leadership was not sufficiently supported by other Palestinian leaders, the Arab states, Israel and America is really depressing. It does not bode well for the revolutions in Egypt, Syria or Tunisia — none of which have a Fayyad-quality leader at the helm.

headline: Smoking? Combat? Wait Till 21, Young Recruits Say
text: Nicole Michell Phipps, a soft-spoken 21-year-old woman in a furry hood who showed up at the Navy recruitment center in Harlem on Tuesday, said she was drawn to the military in search of more “structure” in her life.

headline: A Round of Hugs for Goodell and Draftees
text: Gerald McCoy could finish his N.F.L. career with hundreds of tackles and game-changing plays as a defensive tackle for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, and it would make little difference. In one incredibly vital way, McCoy’s legacy is already secure, his influence evident every April.

headline: Senators Say Case Indicates That Problems Persist in Agencies’ Data Sharing
text: WASHINGTON — As investigators sought answers to what or who may have radicalized the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings, leading lawmakers said Tuesday that potentially important clues about at least one of the men might not have been widely shared within investigative circles months before the attack.

headline: Free the Attica Report
text: The violence in 1971 at Attica resulted in 43 deaths and left many unanswered questions about what happened at the maximum security prison in western New York. The state attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, now wants a judge to allow the release of a 1975 review of the riot and the retaking of the prison by force.

headline: Japan’s Unnecessary Nationalism
text: Since taking over as Japan’s prime minister in December, Shinzo Abe and his conservative Liberal Democratic Party have been juggling a packed agenda of complicated issues, including reviving the country’s economy, coping with the aftermath of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami and managing prickly relations with neighbors like North Korea. Stirring up extraneous controversy is counterproductive, but that’s exactly what he and his nationalist allies in Parliament have done.

headline: A Common Sense Immigration Ruling
text: Federal immigration law prohibits the attorney general from letting a noncitizen stay in the United States for any reason if he is convicted of an aggravated felony. The immigration system has held that every conviction for marijuana distribution is such a felony.

headline: Minus Youkilis, Yankees Are Without Another Much-Needed Right-Handed Bat
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Kevin Youkilis was not in the starting lineup for the third straight game Tuesday because of a back problem, and the timing could not have been worse for the slumping Yankees.

headline: Outlet Mall With Fashion Ambition Rises Near Chicago
text: ROSEMONT, Ill. — A new outlet mall under construction here — the first enclosed mall to be built in the Chicago area in over a decade — is both a departure for the outlet industry and a major new attraction for this close-in Chicago suburb long known as a convention and business hub.

headline: Fate of Clerics Held in Syria Is Disputed
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Christian advocacy group and the television network Al Jazeera reported the release on Tuesday of two Syrian archbishops who had been seized on a road trip outside their home city of Aleppo 24 hours earlier. But others said the archbishops were still held by unidentified kidnappers, in a day of conflicting accounts about the fate of the pair, the most prominent clergymen drawn into Syria’s civil war.

headline: New Hosts Fill Companies’ Need for Meeting Space
text: Commercial tenants have found themselves in a quandary in the last few years thanks to the make-do-with-less downturn. Some companies have shed underused office space in an effort to cut costs, but many of those same companies still require comfortable, high-tech rooms for large events like employee orientations, brainstorming sessions and shareholder meetings.

headline: Budget Cuts, Minus the Inconvenience
text: On Monday, after the sequester cuts forced the Federal Aviation Administration to begin furloughs for air traffic controllers, delays began to build up at airports around the country. Travelers had to wait, but nothing delayed Republicans from scurrying away from all responsibility. Speaker John Boehner started using the Twitter hashtag #ObamaFlightDelays, the latest effort in his party’s campaign to blame all the pain of the sequester on the Obama administration while claiming all the credit for its effect on reducing the deficit.

headline: Lost in Space
text: When James Gleick was my editor on the City Desk of The Times, he would often stare into space.

headline: For Dodgers, Expensive Plans Go Astray
text: There was no attendant at the door of the visiting Los Angeles Dodgers’ clubhouse at Citi Field at 3:30 on Tuesday afternoon, so the greatest pitcher in their history strolled right in. At 77, Sandy Koufax looks as fit as he was in his prime. He does not need a plastic badge to identify himself.

headline: Would-Be Liu Donor Testifies That Defendant Said She Would Repay
text: They had once dated, had attended high school and Rutgers together, and had remained friends. He had even bought her a $1,500 Louis Vuitton handbag and hoped to rekindle their relationship.

headline: Safety Agency Backs Limits to Car Devices
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration released guidelines on Tuesday aimed at lessening the risks of “distracted driving,” recommending that automakers voluntarily limit the functions of electronic devices built into vehicles.

headline: Accounting Board Picks Next Chairman
text: Russell G. Golden was named the chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board on Tuesday, taking up the debate over the convergence of global rules.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Apr. 24, 2013
text: “If the system is not fixed, it will collapse on its own.”

headline: Unraveling Boston Suspects’ Online Lives, Link by Link
text: It is America’s first fully interactive national tragedy of the social media age.

headline: U.S. Accuses Novartis of Providing Kickbacks
text: Federal prosecutors in New York filed a lawsuit on Tuesday accusing Novartis of providing illegal kickbacks to pharmacies, in the form of discounts and rebates, to promote use of one of the company’s drugs.

headline: Selling Ad Time on the Big Screen With a Small-Screen Approach
text: AMONG the more interesting trends so far this year on Madison Avenue has been the expansion of upfronts, as media companies that never made sales presentations before the coming television season begin doing so. In some instances, that emulation of television’s peddling of commercial time extends beyond parties and red-carpet events with celebrities.

headline: Has NATO Outlived Its Usefulness?
text: With the Soviet Union gone and austerity challenging security, should we disband NATO?

headline: Resentenced to Life in Prison, Terrorist Plans to Appeal
text: Nearly 20 years after he served as Osama bin Laden’s personal secretary in Sudan, and a dozen years after he was convicted of conspiring to commit terrorism, Wadih El-Hage emerged from a dark cell in a federal prison to be resentenced for his crime on Tuesday.

headline: ‘The Trip to Bountiful’
text: Scenes from the Broadway revival of Horton Foote’s play.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 23, 2013

headline: Plan for Ice Center in Bronx Armory Moves Forward
text: The Kingsbridge Armory towers over the northwest Bronx, a massive empty shell that has long defied redevelopment efforts and haunted generations of city leaders.

headline: Corrections: April 24, 2013
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Home Is Where the Years Disappear
text: The title destination in Horton Foote’s “Trip to Bountiful,” which has been revived at the Stephen Sondheim Theater, is said to be a small, obscure town in Texas. But on the evidence of the performance of Cicely Tyson, who stars in the production that opened on Tuesday night under Michael Wilson’s slow-handed direction, Bountiful is a code name for the Fountain of Youth.

headline: A Rise to Power, Disco Round Included
text: Discothèques make strange bedfellows. To confirm this dangerous fact of life, just boogie on down — and you must — to the glittery new dance palace at the Public Theater. There you’ll find yourself dancing hip by pelvis with one of the most notorious power couples of the 20th century.

headline: S.E.C. Is Asked to Require Disclosure of Donations
text: A loose coalition of Democratic elected officials, shareholder activists and pension funds has flooded the Securities and Exchange Commission with calls to require publicly traded corporations to disclose to shareholders all of their political donations, a move that could transform the growing world of secret campaign spending.

headline: At Full Speed
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Tennis is a very popular game, and maybe that explains why I feel like I’ve done this puzzle before. Not the whole thing; just the theme. Still, the fill and the theme entries were enough to keep me entertained through the solve, and that’s, as Martha Stewart would say, a Good Thing.

headline: Mets Summon an Outfielder From the Minor Leagues, and Even He Is Surprised
text: Juan Lagares stood in front of his new locker at Citi Field on Tuesday with a huge smile on his face. He had arrived in New York only a few hours earlier after catching a red-eye flight from Colorado.

headline: A Health Provider Strives to Keep Hospital Beds Empty
text: CHICAGO — On a stormy evening this spring, nurses at Dr. Gary Stuck’s family practice were on the phone with patients with heart ailments, asking them not to shovel snow. The idea was to keep them out of the hospital, and that effort — combined with dozens more like it — is starting to make a difference: across the city, doctors are providing less, but not worse, health care.

headline: Petraeus to Join CUNY as Visiting Professor
text: David H. Petraeus, who resigned as director of the Central Intelligence Agency last November after having an extramarital affair with his biographer, will serve as a visiting professor at the City University of New York next academic year, the university announced on Tuesday.

headline: Edward de Grazia, Lawyer Who Fought Censorship of Books, Is Dead at 86
text: Edward de Grazia, a lawyer and teacher who in the 1950s and ’60s broadened the scope of what Americans would be allowed to read by helping to defeat government bans on sexually explicit books, died on April 11 in Potomac, Md. He was 86.

headline: Mayoral Candidates Begin to Release Their Income Figures
text: Joseph J. Lhota, a former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, reported almost $2 million in income last year, far more than any other leading candidate for mayor, according to returns released on Tuesday.

headline: Two Groups in Grief Refuse to Stand Still
text: BOSTON — In the days after the marathon bombings, the slogan “We are one Boston” became a rallying cry for this bleeding city. It flashes on L.E.D. signs that display route numbers on the front of city buses. It is echoed in the name of the One Fund Boston, a charity set up to aid victims of the attack, which killed three people and injured, at last count, 264.

headline: Shakuntala Devi, ‘Human Computer’ Who Bested the Machines, Dies at 83
text: Shakuntala Devi, an Indian mathematical wizard known as “the human computer” for her ability to make incredibly swift calculations, died on Sunday in Bangalore, India. She was 83.

headline: Senator Max Baucus Will Not Run in 2014
text: Max Baucus was elected to the House from Montana in 1974 and to the Senate four years later. He said Tuesday that he would not seek a seventh term.

headline: The World Is Watching: A Russian Blogger’s Trial
text: To the Editor:

headline: Howard J. Phillips, Stalwart Conservative, Dies at 72
text: Howard J. Phillips, a pillar of conservative activism who ran for president three times on the ticket of a political party he helped found, died on Saturday at his home in Vienna, Va. He was 72.

headline: Yankees, Showing Other Sides of Their Game, Pull Out Win
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Within an instant of unleashing a fat pitch to Jose Molina in the seventh inning Tuesday night, Phil Hughes thought he had blown the game. Molina hit the pitch for a single that tilted a taut, compelling game in favor of the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: At Republican Forum, McDonald Promises to Make the Economy His Focus
text: George T. McDonald, a Republican candidate for mayor, can be an uneven performer in public. He likes to explain his economic plan by arguing that the Bronx should produce more applesauce, and he sometimes jokes about commuting by skateboard.

headline: Transactions
text: Recent Sale

headline: Mets Lose Lead, and the Game, but Hope Niese Heals Quickly
text: Right after his 54th pitch on Tuesday night, Jon Niese stumbled off the mound and performed an awkward 720-degree spin. He could not get out of the way of a comebacker, and as the game whirred on around him, he limped toward home plate, took a few wobbly steps up the first-base line and then bent over, hands on his knees.

headline: New York City Storm Victims May Get Federal Reimbursement for Repairs
text: New York City residents who used their own money to repair damage caused by Hurricane Sandy may be reimbursed with federal money, after the city reversed its position.

headline: Rangers Miss Chance to Clinch but Have Two More
text: SUNRISE, Fla. — The Rangers simply had to beat the last-place Floria Panthers Tuesday to earn a trip to the playoffs. Instead, they lost, 3-2, in hard-to-believe fashion.

headline: Galaxy S4 Puts More Features Into the Same Package
text: “We’re No. 2,” went the old Avis slogan. “We try harder.”

headline: Do We Have to Cool Down After Exercise?
text: Do you often, if guiltily, skip cooling down after exercise? A small but soothing body of new research suggests that you aren’t missing out on much.

headline: A Warm Welcome
text: N.F.L. draft picks get a lesson on public displays of affection from Commissioner Roger Goodell.

headline: Word of the Day | repugnance
text: repugnance •\ri-ˈpəg-nən(t)s\• noun

headline: Warner Bros. Enlists Walmart Stores to Promote ‘Man of Steel’
text: LOS ANGELES — Which is more powerful: Superman or Walmart?

headline: In Game 2, Knicks Reiterate Message
text: In another time, another spring, the duel would have been tantalizing, electric and potentially epic: Carmelo Anthony versus Paul Pierce, for control of the Eastern Conference. The names alone inspire visions of a classic playoff scoring battle.

headline: Celtics Fade Once Again as Knicks Press Hard
text: The Boston Celtics had to listen for three days about how their offense scored only 8 points in the fourth quarter of Game 1. For the first half of Game 2 on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, they looked as if they had overcome that humiliation.

headline: Make Wall Street Choose: Go Small or Go Home
text: WASHINGTON

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 5:35 P.M. (Starz) THE IDES OF MARCH (2011) George Clooney, Grant Heslov and Beau Willimon received an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay for this political drama, which Mr. Clooney, above, also directed and stars in as Mike Morris, a Pennsylvania governor turned dream candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination. Ryan Gosling plays Stephen Meyers, a strategist who becomes involved with an intern (Evan Rachel Wood) with a powerful father and a secret that could derail Stephen’s career and the Morris campaign. Philip Seymour Hoffman and Paul Giamatti are senior advisers battling for Stephen’s loyalty. And Marisa Tomei is a reporter trying to get at the truth. “Mr. Clooney handles the plot complications with elegant dexterity,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of Mr. Willimon’s play “Farragut North,” loosely based on Howard Dean’s 2004 Democratic presidential primary campaign. “As an actor he works best in long, understated scenes that allow him to play with nuances of charm and menace, so it is not surprising that, as a director, he gives the rest of the cast room to work,” Mr. Scott added. “But the parts of ‘The Ides of March’ — quiet scenes between Mr. Gosling and Ms. Wood; swirling, Sorkinesque exchanges of banter; any time Ms. Tomei or Max Minghella (as a campaign worker grooming himself to be the next Stephen Meyers) are in the room — are greater than the whole.”

headline: Game 2: Knicks vs. Celtics
text: The Knicks defeated the Celtics, 87-71, and took a 2-0 lead in their first-round playoff series.

headline: News Quiz | April 24, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Coat With Pockets for Every Gadget
text: There have been multi-pocket gadget jackets before, but have any had the carrying capacity of a clown car? The Scottevest Tropiformer looks like a normal jacket, but you can just keep pulling stuff out of it.

headline: Credit Suisse, Citing Large Profit, Says ‘Transformation’ All but Complete
text: LONDON – Credit Suisse reported on Wednesday that profit rose sharply in the first quarter from the period a year earlier, when the bank booked large charges on its own debt.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 24
text: NEWS Multinational companies are racing to invest in factories and other operations to cash in on rising consumer demand in Indonesia, Southeast Asia’s biggest economy and most populous nation, with an estimated 251 million people. Joe Cochrane reports from Jakarta.

headline: Knicks Slow Garnett by Forcing Him Into Foul Trouble
text: Kevin Garnett was a solid defender when he was on the court Tuesday. The problem for Garnett and the Celtics was that he only played in half of Boston’s 87-71 loss in Game 2.

headline: Australia Arrests the Professed Head of LulzSec, Which Claims a C.I.A. Hacking
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The federal police in Australia have arrested the professed leader of a prominent international hacking collective known as LulzSec, which is perhaps best known for its assertions of being behind a cyberattack that shut down the Central Intelligence Agency’s public Web site in 2011.

headline: Glimpses From the Life of China’s Jailed Nobel Laureate
text: BEIJING — Liu Xiaobo, the jailed Nobel Peace laureate serving an 11-year term for subversion after calling for an end to one-party rule and greater democracy in China, has recently been reading a popular nonfiction book about the history of Soviet Communism and Russian intellectuals in the 19th and 20th centuries, as well as Christian philosophical texts. He has also gained weight, said Mo Shaoping, a Beijing lawyer.

headline: Barclays Earnings Decline Sharply on Restructuring Costs
text: LONDON – The British bank Barclays said on Wednesday that first-quarter pretax profit dropped 25 percent as it set aside money to pay for a major overhaul of its operations.

headline: A Conversation With: Godrej Group Chairman Adi Godrej
text: MUMBAI— Adi Godrej is the chairman of The Godrej Group, a privately held, 116-year old Indian consumer goods conglomerate.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, April 24, 2013
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “At a College, Dropping Sports in Favor of Fitness.”

headline: Texans Flock to Bluebonnet Fields
text: In “Breaking Laws and Fighting Fire Ants in a Rush to the Texas Bluebonnet Fields,” Kate Murphy writes about the seasonal rush to the blooming bluebonnet fields in Texas.

headline: Building Collapse in Bangladesh Leaves Scores Dead
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A building housing several factories making clothing for European and American consumers collapsed into a deadly heap on Wednesday, only five months after a horrific fire at a similar facility prompted leading multinational brands to pledge to work to improve safety in the country’s booming but poorly regulated garment industry.

headline: Lloyds Bank Plans I.P.O. After Branch Sale Collapses
text: LONDON – The Lloyds Banking Group said on Wednesday that it was planning an initial public offering of part of its branch network after a deal fell through to sell the division to a rival British lender, Co-operative Bank.

headline: What Would You Teach the World in an Online Video?
text: Have you ever watched an Internet video that teaches how to do something, or explains an idea or problem? Have you ever considered making a video like that?

headline: A Life Sold on Photography
text: Paul Kwilecki’s day job was running a hardware store, but his passion was documenting his hometown, Decatur County, Ga. In the 1960s, the self-taught photographer wrote to such luminaries as Ansel Adams and David Vestal, hoping to get an honest assessment of his work.

headline: President of Italy Nominates Center-Left Official as Premier
text: ROME — After months of political paralysis capped by a week of turmoil, President Giorgio Napolitano on Wednesday named Enrico Letta, a high-ranking official in the center-left Democratic Party, to form a broad coalition government to try to steer Italy out of political chaos and its worst recession since World War II.

headline: South Korea and U.S. Fail to Reach Deal on Nuclear Energy
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea and the Obama administration delayed the deadline for a deal that Seoul had hoped would allow it to begin making its own fuel for its civil nuclear energy program, but that the United States feared would undermine its attempts to curb nuclear proliferation.

headline: 21 Dead in Clash with ‘Gangsters’ in Western China
text: BEIJING — At least 21 people were killed Tuesday in fighting in far western China between security officers and “gangsters,” according to a propaganda bureau spokeswoman for the regional government of Xinjiang, where the conflict took place.

headline: South Korea Offers Aid to Business in Shuttered North Korean Complex
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea on Wednesday announced financial aid for 123 South Korean factories left stranded in an industrial zone in North Korea as the North showed no signs of allowing the complex to reopen.

headline: Heavyweight Champignon
text: The waitress placed a steak knife on the table, and everyone’s eyebrows went up. No one had ordered steak. There was an appetizer course coming. We didn’t need a steak knife.

headline: Up for Discussion: Can Employees Be Rehabilitated?
text: At a recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about the odds of rehabilitating an employee who isn’t working out. Susan Parker, who owns Bari Jay, started the discussion by explaining why she was focused on becoming better at ensuring she has the best possible employees.

headline: Monsters of the River at One Moment in Time
text: Lesley de Souza, a research biologist at John G. Shedd Aquarium, writes from Guyana, where she studies the region’s rich aquatic wildlife, including the arapaima, one of the largest freshwater fishes in the world.

headline: Obama’s Style and the Vote on Guns
text: To the Editor:

headline: Domo Arigato, Mr. Roboto — I Mean, Mr. Smith

headline: Pivotal’s Audacious Plan
text: Pivotal, an ambitious creation of the data storage giant EMC and its hefty affiliate VMware, on Wednesday said it would make cloud-based industrial software applications faster than anyone has before, and announced it had the means to do so — a $105 million investment from General Electric.

headline: Britain Offers Hand to Smaller Businesses
text: LONDON — With Britain’s moribund economy struggling to avert a return to recession, a government-backed lending program was extended and reworked Wednesday in the hope of freeing up borrowing to credit-starved small and medium-size companies.

headline: NBCUniversal Plans an ‘Upfront’ for Its Digital Properties
text: Remember how the Florida citrus growers ran commercials asserting that orange juice was not just for breakfast anymore? The NBCUniversal division of Comcast, in its seemingly continuous efforts to convince Madison Avenue that it is not just about the problematic NBC television network anymore, plans to share an ambitious slate of digital initiatives with advertisers and agencies on Wednesday evening.

headline: Vietnam’s Bilingual Experiment
text: HO CHI MINH CITY — At a handful of schools across Vietnam, children from ethnic minorities are finding something rare when they enter a classroom: They understand what the teacher is saying.

headline: Daily Report: Fisker Automotive Captured Imaginations but Failed to Deliver
text: With technical problems, management turmoil and mounting losses, Fisker Automotive offers a cautionary tale of alternative-fuel vehicles and government subsidies for start-up businesses, Bill Vlasic reports in The New York Times.

headline: Mean Cuisine
Blacklisted, From a Child’s View
text: Among the few things I share with Eugene O’Neill — although I am not nearly as brilliant or as important — is that we are both playwrights, we both chose to write about our parents, and our parents were actors. One thing we don’t share is that my parents were blacklisted in the 1950s and were unable to work in television and film for almost a decade.

headline: Martian Watch Brings Wristphone Technology to Earthlings
text: An outfit called Martian Watches has created one of the most advanced options yet to put smartphone technology on your wrist.

headline: Tip of the Week: Customize the Microsoft Office Ribbon
text: The Ribbon — Microsoft’s tabbed, consolidated command bar for its Office programs — can be overwhelming to new users, but a little customization can make it feel more comfortable. In Office 2010 and Office 2013 for Windows, you can create a personal tab on the Ribbon and add all your favorite most-used commands to it for quicker access.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Exploring a ‘Flexitarian’ Diet
text: Exploring a “flexitarian” diet, regulators aim to restrict payday lending by big banks, doubling the workout doesn’t double the benefits and other consumer focused news from The New York Times

headline: North American Sales Lift Ford’s Results
text: DETROIT — The Ford Motor Company said on Wednesday that its net income improved 15 percent in the first quarter to $1.6 billion, as record results in North America compensated for losses in Europe and South America.

headline: Uncertainty on Whistle-Blower Program
text: The use of whistle-blowers at the Securities and Exchange Commission has proved effective. A tipster bolstered an investigation into a trading blowup that almost took down Knight Capital; another aided the discovery that Oppenheimer & Company had overstated the performance of a private equity fund; and a whistle-blower helped the government pursue a Ponzi scheme in Texas, Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper report in DealBook.

headline: Could Syria’s Civil War Create Jihadis in Europe and the U.S.?
text: LONDON — Two Belgian mothers, worried for the fate of sons who left home to join Islamist rebels in Syria, reportedly traveled to Turkey this week to urge the authorities there to stem the transit of foreign volunteers heading for the conflict.

headline: Despite 787 Setbacks, Boeing Reaffirms Outlook as Earnings Beat Estimates
text: Boeing reported a first-quarter profit on Wednesday that topped analysts’ estimates, and it said the recent problems with the lithium-ion batteries on its 787 Dreamliner jets would not keep it from hitting its profit and revenue goals for the year.

headline: On a Field at M.I.T., 10,000 Remember an Officer Who Was Killed
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — More than 10,000 people, many of them uniformed police or military officers, gathered Wednesday on a tightly secured athletic field at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to remember Sean A. Collier, the campus police officer who the authorities say was gunned down by the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings.

headline: Readers Find an Online Ad Jarring Next to Boston Coverage
text: I heard from a number of readers on Monday who were disturbed by a juxtaposition of images on The Times’s home page — an interactive feature related to the bombings in Boston last week, and an advertisement for a Sundance Channel show, “Rectify.”

headline: Transit Worker in Queens Is Fatally Struck by a Train
text: A transit worker was struck and killed by a train while on the job early Wednesday, falling from a catwalk area above the tracks and into the path of an E train in Queens, officials said.

headline: The Return of Jon Winkelried, Sort of
text: With a number of high-profile investments under its belt, Thrive Capital is turning to a former top Goldman Sachs executive to help provide advice on its growth plans.

headline: When Food Isn’t the Answer to Hunger
text: When the Indian Ocean tsunami hit in December 2004, killing more than a quarter-million people, the great global humanitarian machine sprung to life. First on the list of donations, of course, was food — bags of food began arriving by airlift and sea, especially into Aceh, the hardest-hit region.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Modern Farmer: If you love chickens but hate the year-round commitment, there is an answer: rent, already. Try Rent-a-Chicken in Traverse City, Mich. Really. — Glenn Collins

headline: New Medical Exam Policy for Sexual Assault Cases
text: Techniques for collecting and analyzing evidence in rape cases have evolved over the last decade, as has the understanding of the psychological effects of sexual assault. But how health practitioners, law enforcement officers, prosecutors and others respond after a rape still varies widely across the country.

headline: ‘Nowhere to Go’
text: A new ad criticizes Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, for her role in the closing of St. Vincent's hospital.

headline: Bouncing Back
text: Certain phrases cycle in and out of child-rearing vogue, with “executive function” and “emotional intelligence” and “kinetic learning” zooming before parental headlights and then passing into oblivion until the next generation comes along. At our current moment, “resilience” is front and center, in large part courtesy of Paul Tough’s excellent book on education, “How Children Succeed.” And to this parent, at least, it seems as good a concept as any to cling to and to encourage.

headline: Glinda Would Be at Ease
text: IF THE FLICKERING CANDLE of my memory serves, it was in a feminist-studies class (very de rigueur in the early 1990s) that I first read “Warning,” the famous poem by the English writer Jenny Joseph that begins: “When I am an old woman I shall wear purple/With a red hat which doesn’t go, and doesn’t suit me.”

headline: The Gun Report: April 24, 2013
text: Dear Senator Max Baucus,

headline: States Push to Get the Most Out of Marijuana Taxes
text: DENVER — If marijuana is legalized and properly regulated, its proponents have long said, it could generate millions of dollars in state tax revenue. But how the drug should be taxed has proved to be a thorny question.

headline: More Car Sharing From Hertz
text: The car-sharing unit of the rental car company Hertz is expanding in the coming months, the company said. The service, Hertz 24/7, will extend a car-sharing model that had been available in urban areas and college campuses in the United States, and in five other countries, to suburban and rural areas. It also will improve ease of use, with self-service features including keyless entry and a flexible rental term. Hertz said that the rollout, which will eventually provide service to “the vast majority of Americans,” will begin in late summer in the United States, followed soon after in Europe, and later in China.

headline: Made in America. Craved Everywhere Else.
text: It is one of our largest exports, a product made in America from start to finish and craved by businesses and consumers around the world. And the latest edition will be released in October. We speak, of course, about the $100 bill.

headline: How Accurate Is The Prime Minister’s Economic Advisory Council?
text: On Tuesday, the Economic Advisory Council to the Prime Minister released its annual economic review for the financial year 2012-13. According to the report, the Indian economy is projected to grow by 6.4 percent in the coming year. “I believe we have reached the bottom. The economy will now continue to grow at a faster rate,” the council chairman, C. Rangarajan, said in releasing the report.

headline: For Sale at the Botanical Garden, an ‘Important Pair of Chairs’
text: If you’ve been looking to score some important patio furniture, this weekend’s Garden Sculptures and Antiques Fair at the New York Botanical Garden might be the place to do it. The fair, which the garden calls “the country’s original, largest and most important venue for authentic garden antiques,” will feature garden-related artworks and furnishings from 1750 to the present.

headline: Film Singer Shamshad Begum Dies at 94
text: Shamshad Begum, a legendary Bollywood and Hindi film singer, has died in Mumbai after a prolonged illness, her family said Wednesday. She was 94.

headline: The Samsung Galaxy S4 Review Roundup
text: Samsung’s new flagship smartphone, the Galaxy S4, will arrive in stores over the next week in the United States. Analysts expect this phone to be a potent challenger to the iPhone, but several technology writers who got the device early agree that the Galaxy S4 is good, but not great. Many felt the new software features were gimmicky and cumbersome.

headline: Strategic Posturing Behind the Suit Against Corzine
text: Louis J. Freeh, the bankruptcy trustee for the failed futures firm MF Global, filed a lawsuit aimed at pinning its collapse squarely on Jon S. Corzine, the former chief executive, and two of his top lieutenants. And unlike in many other suits, Mr. Freeh has not named other groups like a company’s directors.

headline: A Wholesaler Finds Himself in Competition With Retail Clients
text: Based in Miami, Source Outdoor is a five-year-old importer and wholesaler of patio and deck furniture owned by Gerald Shvartsman. From humble beginnings, in which he tried to sell his first containers of goods himself, Mr. Shvartsman, 35, has expanded his one-man start-up to encompass more than 50 employees and sales in 2012 of $7 million.

headline: Guggenheim Hires Lehman Veteran in Continued Hiring Spree

headline: Given Clean Slate by Knicks, Martin Writes a New Ending

A reporter was well positioned there to shoot Martin a follow-up question. Like an express train scheduled to run through local stations, Martin was not supposed to stop.

headline: Kerry Meets Top Afghan and Pakistani Officials

headline: Giving Fast Food a Good Name in Washington, D.C.
text: Washington’s culinary scene has traditionally been known for its power restaurants: clubby spots, often run by celebrity chefs, where political movers-and-shakers cut deals and charred steaks. But recently, the city has embraced the flip side of fine dining. Several casual spots have opened, offering fresh, inexpensive, vibrant fare that gives fast food a good name.

headline: In Gas-Drilling Fight, Opposites Attract, and Distract
text: There are passionate and well-meaning people arrayed all around the issues surrounding America’s enormous shale-gas resource and the communities on the surface above it. I’ve met landowners and residents and scientists in Pennsylvania and upstate New York with powerfully articulated positions against and for drilling using hydraulic fracturing, or fracking.

headline: A Lacrosse Star Who Is a Math Teacher First
text: BUFFALO — Ask the Islanders star John Tavares about his most influential role models, and he will tell you he has always looked up to his uncle John.

headline: The Lieber Codes
text: In October 1861, a legal scholar and historian named Francis Lieber presented the first in a series of lectures entitled “The Laws and Usages of War” at the Columbia College’s new law school in New York City. Though the talks, which ran through the following March, were long and often rambling, they drew up to 100 people each and afterward appeared in The New York Times and other newspapers around the country. The public, eager for insight into how the worsening war would and should be fought, devoured his every word.

headline: For Silicon Valley High Fliers
text: Mineta San Jose International Airport, Silicon Valley’s launchpad in San Jose, Calif., received the city’s approval this month to negotiate a lease with Signature Flight Support to build an elite corporate jet center. Five of the seven hangars in the 29-acre, $82 million facility will be reserved for planes owned by Google executives, including Eric Schmidt (above).

headline: Gadgets to Help Tend a Garden
text: Picture a tiny drone that arises from your vegetable garden to shoo away hungry deer. Or maybe a houseplant that, when you’re away, meanders through your rooms like a cat following a sunbeam. Or one that posts a request for water on Twitter.

headline: Feeling For | Gilbert Albert Interchangeable Rings
text: In honor of this week’s celebration of Earth Day, T is feeling for the Swiss jeweler Gilbert Albert’s rings with interchangeable stones. The bands, available in silver or gold, hold pearl-shaped gemstones that can be swapped out on a whim. There are more than 80 different precious stones to choose from, ranging from the standard amethyst, tiger’s-eye and lapis lazuli to the more grand leopard jasper, chrysoprase and mother-of-pearl. This collection gives “recycle, reuse, reduce” a whole new meaning.

text: Question:

headline: Gary Shteyngart to Publish Memoir
text: Gary Shteyngart will follow up his three best-selling novels with a memoir, his publisher, Random House, announced on Wednesday. Mr. Shteyngart’s editor, David Ebershoff, described the book as the “candid and deeply poignant story of a Soviet family that comes to America in 1979 to find its future.”

headline: Chinese Officials Order Questioning of Exiled Activist’s Relatives
text: HONG KONG — Chinese prosecutors on Wednesday ordered two relatives of a prominent human rights advocate who lives in exile in the United States to face questioning over allegations that they harbored a criminal, in what one family member considered to be retaliation against the activist’s stepped-up criticism of the government.

headline: George Improves His Game, and Has an Award to Show for It
text: With his 27-point, 10-rebound, 8-assist performance in a 110-87 win over the Milwaukee Bucks Sunday night, LeBron James served quick notice that his imminent Most Valuable Player Award will be mere window dressing on what is looking like yet another march to the N.B.A. finals for the Heat.

headline: U.N. Expert Says Bahrain Canceled Visit in Torture Inquiry
text: GENEVA — A United Nations expert who was due to visit Bahrain next month to look into reports that the authorities there have abused and tortured protesters in detention said on Wednesday that the Bahraini government had effectively canceled the trip.

headline: Johnson Sits Out Nets Practice With Foot Ailment
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As the Nets prepare for Game 3 of their first-round N.B.A. playoff series with the Chicago Bulls, there is a chance they will be without Joe Johnson, one of their All-Star playmakers.

headline: Mayor and Mets Pitch Start of All-Star Voting
text: Major League Baseball, the Mets and the New York mayor’s office held a joint news conference Wednesday morning to mark the start of balloting for the All-Star Game, which will take place July 16 at Citi Field.

headline: After Rape of Child, Indian Media and Protestors Make Common Cause
text: NEW DELHI—Over the past few days, following the rape of a five-year-old girl, the Indian government has been rocked once again by the alliance of the news media and Delhi’s street protesters. In my latest Letter From India I argue that Delhi’s new breed of demonstrators are getting better at street protests and sustaining the interest of journalists, while the government has yet to learn how to create a smart and dignified self-defense.

headline: New Xbox Console Will Be Revealed on May 21
text: It’s official: Microsoft, as expected, will unveil its new Xbox video game console on May 21.

headline: Suárez Barred 10 Games for Biting Opponent
text: Liverpool striker Luis Suárez was suspended for 10 games by England’s Football Association on Wednesday for biting an opponent during a Premier League game, but the reaction of Suárez and his club to the decision threatened to further stain the reputations of both.

headline: Hunting Down Ramps in Early Spring
text: Outtakes is a behind-the-scenes glimpse of images in the Dining section. Andrew Scrivani (@AndrewScrivani on Twitter and Instagram) is a freelance photographer and a regular contributor to The New York Times. He writes the blog making SundaySauce.

text: The director Paul Verhoeven discusses his latest project "Tricked," a film with a crowd-sourced script.

headline: Down Payment Rules Are at Heart of Mortgage Debate
text: It seemed an easy fix to prevent the excesses of the housing market: make home buyers put more money down.

headline: Test Your Economic Literacy
text: The Department of Education on Wednesday released its latest report on the economic proficiency of 12th graders, based on the test scores of nearly 11,000 students tested in 2012. It found little change in average economic literacy compared to test scores from 2006, although students in the lower part of the score distribution (at the 10th and 25th percentiles) made gains.

headline: A Lost Language
text: “Haughty” for “heavy.”

headline: A Week to Celebrate Henry Miller’s Brooklyn Connections
text: The Henry Miller Memorial Library, a nonprofit bookstore and arts center in Big Sur, Calif., where the novelist lived between 1940 and 1962, is sending envoys east to assert Miller’s presence – in spirit, anyway (he died in 1980) – in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, where he spent nearly a decade. The library’s Big Sur Brooklyn Bridge Festival, which opens on May 12 and runs for a week, will include an exhibition, readings, panel discussions, comedy and musical performances.

headline: Willkommen, Again? Roundabout Planning Another ‘Cabaret’ Revival
text: Roundabout Theater Company is planning a revival of the famed musical “Cabaret” at Studio 54 in early 2014 with Alan Cumming starring as the M.C. – the role for which he won a Tony Award in 1998 for a “Cabaret” revival by Roundabout that ended up running at Studio 54 as well.

headline: Caesars Blinds Market With Science
text: The private equity owners behind Caesars Entertainment have been working overtime in their financial laboratory. Apollo Global Management and TPG are following last year’s microscopic initial public offering with a spinoff and rights issue concoction. Aiming to raise $1.2 billion, the complex transaction mostly seems designed to buy still more time for the ailing $31 billion leveraged buyout.

headline: Short-Term Payday Loans Can Become Long-Term Traps
text: Payday loans and deposit-advance loans are intended to be short-term options for emergency cash, but they can turn into long-term debt traps for borrowers, a new federal report says.

headline: If You Like Bob Dylan, Try Jake Bugg
text: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: In Defense of Regulatory Capital Trades
text: Glenn Blasius is the chief executive of Ovid Capital Advisors LLC. He has worked with many large international banks on regulatory capital transactions involving real risk transfer over the last decade.

headline: In Israel, O’Malley Talks Jobs, Foreign Policy and, of Course, 2016
text: JERUSALEM – Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland said Wednesday that he would spend the second half of this year mulling whether to run for president in 2016. He seems already to have a campaign theme: jobs and innovation.

headline: Tribeca Video: Paul Verhoeven Discusses ‘Tricked’
text: With his latest film project “Tricked,” Paul Verhoeven worked with a list of screenwriters that rivaled the length of the script itself. In this video interview at the Tribeca Film Festival, the Dutch director, best known in America for Hollywood hits like “Robocop” and “Basic Instinct,” discusses how he and his team assembled the crowd-sourced work of multiple writers to create the screenplay for “Tricked.”

headline: Follow-Up to ‘Gangnam Style’ Hits No. 5
text: Two months ago, Billboard began incorporating YouTube views in the formula for computing its all-important Hot 100 singles chart, allowing viral-video smashes to reach No. 1 even if they trailed other songs in sales and airplay, two of the chart’s other criteria. Sure enough, Baauer’s “Harlem Shake,” a huge hit online, sailed to No. 1 in the first week of the new chart.

headline: Jones Tops Final Scouting Rankings for Draft
text: Defenseman Seth Jones, the most highly regarded African-American prospect in N.H.L. history, was ranked the top North American skater available in the draft, which will be held June 30 in Newark.

headline: The Mike Brown Redux in Cleveland
text: You can excuse pretty much anyone not living inside Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert’s head for being more than puzzled over the news that the Cavs had re-hired Mike Brown as their head coach. Because yes, it’s the same Mike Brown who was jettisoned after two 60-win seasons, as a sacrificial lamb in the desperate attempt to keep LeBron James from doing the superteam thing elsewhere, which didn’t work. And it’s the same Mike Brown who lasted five games into his second season as the clearly wrong choice to coach the Lakers.

headline: Richie Havens, 1941 – 2013
text: In 1971, around when I first heard the voice that was Richie Havens, I was 7 years old. Radio was the way you formed your musical brain and mine was hungry. It was a good time for that. The pop airwaves were almost completely integrated. The Stones, the Beatles, and CCR mingled with Stevie Wonder, Marvin Gaye, the Temptations, the Isleys, the Jacksons and even the Osmonds into one dizzying sonic mix. I learned to love practically everything. But some things leapt out.

headline: Intersection Video: Bold on Burnside
text: In the latest installment of the Intersection street style video series, we headed up to Burnside and Grand Avenues in the Bronx and met residents who draw style inspiration anywhere from Rihanna to the No. 4 train. We interviewed Tiffany Trinidad, a student at the High School of Fashion Industries, who sews her own clothes and praises Kanye West for “bringing leather back.”

headline: Darren Johnson
text: Darren Johnson on how the hoarding taskforce works.

headline: Cuts’ Impact Is Severe, F.A.A. Chief Tells Lawmakers
text: WASHINGTON — Amid an increasingly partisan atmosphere, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration told skeptical Republicans on Wednesday that automatic budget cuts had forced the F.A.A. to run somewhat like a starving airline: it has reduced its inventory of spare parts, stopped hiring and training new employees, and cut back on modernization.

headline: Minaret on a Storied Syrian Mosque Falls
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Fighting between Syrian insurgents and government forces in Aleppo left one of the Middle East’s most storied mosques severely damaged on Wednesday, its soaring minaret toppled by explosives. Each side accused the other of responsibility for the destruction at the Umayyad Mosque in Aleppo’s walled ancient city, a Unesco World Heritage site.

headline: Rising Violence in Iraq Spurs Fears of New Sectarian War
text: BAGHDAD — In what appeared to be a new phase in an intensifying conflict that has raised fears of greater bloodshed and a wider sectarian war, Iraqi soldiers opened fire from helicopters on Sunni gunmen hiding in a northern village on Wednesday, officials said.

headline: A New Approach to Cutting Health Costs
text: A strategy offers financial incentives for health care providers to cut costs by keeping patients out of the hospital.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: April 25
text: Culottes are just the thing for the in-between season; F-Troupe has colorful canvas espadrilles; Saturdays Surf NYC has rain gear for men; and Basta Surf’s neoprene swimwear.

headline: F.A.A. Chief Testifies
text: Michael Huerta, administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, testified before a House Appropriations subcommittee about the effect of automatic budget cuts on air travel. (C-SPAN)

headline: Russian Opposition Leader Asserts Innocence at Trial
text: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, the opposition leader and one of the most prominent politicians to go on trial in modern Russia, used his first full day in court on Wednesday to say the trial would prove his innocence, even if the judge convicted him.

headline: Soybean Harvest
text: In Chacabuco, Argentina, soybeans are loaded onto a truck on Thursday. Argentina is one of the world’s leading exporters of soybeans.

headline: John Drews
text: John Drews on how the hoarding taskforce works.

headline: How Do You Find the Best Green Cars?
text: Spring is in the air, and Earth Day is just behind us. Apparently, that means it’s green car choosing season, at least for the people who take the time to determine such things. But with the list of more environmentally friendly cars and trucks at an all-time high, choosing the best one can be tough.

headline: Capital One Settles Accusations It Understated Loan Losses
text: Federal regulators on Wednesday accused Capital One and two of its executives of understating millions of dollars in auto loan losses suffered during the financial crisis.

headline: Documenting a Growing Force in Fashion
text: THROUGHOUT THE RECENT and meteoric rise of Asian-Americans in fashion, there have been numerous milestones, as when Alexander Wang was named the creative director of Balenciaga last year, or when Jason Wu designed Michelle Obama’s first inaugural gown in 2009 (and her second one this year). Before them, beginning in the 1980s, came a handful of pioneers, like Vera Wang and Anna Sui.

headline: New York Bridal Fashion Week | Spring 2014
text: Wedding dress designers debuted their spring 2014 collections last weekend. Here, a selection of our photos.

headline: Samsung Delays Release of Security Software for Galaxy Phones
text: In February, Samsung Electronics introduced Knox, a version of Android with security features to make the company’s phones more suitable for businesses, expected for release this spring. But the company has delayed the release of the software until summer, according to two people briefed on the company’s plans.

headline: Ireland’s New International Food Festival
text: Between them, the collected works of the presenters at the inaugural Ballymaloe Literary Festival of Food and Wine, taking place from May 3 to May 6, would constitute the beginnings of a library, or at least a very impressive cookbook collection. Darina Allen, arguably Ireland’s most famous cook and visible advocate of its food culture, has lured many of the world’s most revered and prolific food writers to attend the three-day event outside the Irish city of Cork. This is an international food festival with a difference. Far from being staged in the usual hotel ballroom or university lecture hall, it will take place among the bucolic surrounds of Ballymaloe, the family estate made famous first by Myrtle Allen’s seminal country house restaurant, and then by her daughter-in-law Darina’s cooking school and picturesque organic farm.

headline: The Bad Economy Behind the Health Care Slowdown
text: In today’s paper, I took a look at a major innovation in health care delivery, one that Obama administration officials think might play a big role in holding down health costs in the future. It is called accountable care, and the general idea is to enlist doctors and nurses in the fight to control spending.

headline: Scouting Report
text: Collaborations

headline: Stepping In for Mayoral Candidates, Surrogates Are Left Out of a Debate
text: As latecomers slipped into their seats on Wednesday for an early morning mayoral debate on housing development, they could have been forgiven for feeling a bit confused.

headline: ‘Nice Work’ to Close on Broadway
text: The Broadway musical “Nice Work if You Can Get It,” a venture involving the heirs of George and Ira Gershwin and several veteran theater producers to showcase famous songs by the brothers, will close on June 15 after 27 preview performances and 478 regular performances, the producers announced on Wednesday. The Jazz Age-style show, which originally paired Tony Award winner Matthew Broderick as a playboy with Tony nominee Kelli O’Hara as a bootlegger, opened last April to mixed reviews and never caught real fire at the box office. (Ms. O’Hara’s role is now played by Tony nominee Jessie Mueller.)

headline: Eggs, Too, May Provoke Bacteria to Raise Heart Risk
text: For the second time in a matter of weeks, a group of researchers reported a link between the food people eat and bacteria in the intestines that can increase the risk of heart attacks.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bangladesh, Boston, Egypt and Greece.

headline: Best Actor in a Spritzing Role
text: The Australian actor Eric Bana is known for rugged, physically impressive characters with a sensitive side. But for being a cologne spokesman?

headline: U.S. General Sees Hope for Chinese Help on Korea
text: BEIJING — After three days of talks here, America’s top military officer said Wednesday that he believed China wanted to limit the nuclear ambitions of North Korea but that it remained unclear how China would work toward that goal.

headline: Third Staal Brother Joins Hurricanes
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — The Staals of Thunder Bay, Ontario, are on the verge of becoming only the third family to send as many as four brothers to the N.H.L.

headline: Tap a Word in a Sentence Three Times and It’s Yours
text: Philtrum. Salubriousness. Thaumaturge. These are three of my favorite words, but they’re not common ones. So you may be reaching for a dictionary right now.

headline: Cost of Storm-Debris Removal in City Is at Least Twice the U.S. Average
text: WASHINGTON — The cleanup of New York after Hurricane Sandy has cost taxpayers at least twice as much as the national post-disaster average, according to the Army Corps of Engineers, which city officials selected to help handle the huge job.

headline: The High Spark of Low-Heeled Shoes
text: If the men’s department is ruled by revenge of the nerds (horn rims, bow ties), women’s fashion can look surprisingly like (dare we say?) the triumph of frump. Dowager classics like frame handbags, cardies and costume jewelry are the height of chic — and now comes the low block heel.

headline: City Expands Recycling Program to Include Hard Plastics
text: Updated, 6:08 p.m. | New Yorkers, your days of expending precious brain cells trying to determine whether that yogurt cup or plastic takeout container goes in the trash or the recycling bin have come to an end.

headline: Taking the Paraguayan Route to Iguazú Falls
text: Visitors to Iguazú Falls, the 1.7-mile-long snaking series of waterfalls that is South America’s chaotic response to buttoned-down Niagara, have three choices: one, the Brazilian side (where it’s spelled Iguaçu), known for its panoramic views of the falls; or two, the Argentine side, with its pathways winding above, below and all but straight through the tumbling cascades.

headline: Time Magazine Honors 100 Influential People
text: The annual Time 100 gala, held this year on Tuesday night, is the kind of place where politicians (Joe Biden) fraternize with celebrities (a cleavage-baring Christina Aguilera.)

headline: Successful Shoulders, Rubbing Together
text: The Time 100 gala is the kind of event at which politicians (Joe Biden) fraternize with celebrities (a cleavage-baring Christina Aguilera); hedge fund managers (David Einhorn) share the red carpet with reality TV stars (Padma Lakshmi) and senators (Rand Paul); singers (Raphael Saadiq) try to catch the eye of moguls (Harvey Weinstein), explaining, “I hear Harvey is a live guy,” and celebrities confess their crushes on other celebrities.

headline: Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan
text: The Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan, started on Monday and will finish on Friday.

headline: Mark Odom
text: Mark Odom on how the hoarding taskforce works.

headline: On One Phone App, Looks Are Everything
text: The quickest hookups in New York these days aren’t happening behind the velvet ropes of No. 8, on the bar stools of Dorrian’s or in the coed bathroom of the Electric Room.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Families are in distress this month: a high school student may or may not have jumped from the roof of her private school; a suburban marriage frays at the seams; an adventurous teenager learns about the mother she never knew; and a woman flees a polygamous cult with her two daughters in tow.

headline: Zuckerberg Unbound
text: The Stone’s weekly briefing of notable philosophy-related issues and ideas from around the Web.

headline: Goodell Meets With Browns Owner
text: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell met Tuesday with Cleveland Browns owner Jimmy Haslam, whose truck stop company, Pilot Flying J, has been raided by the F.B.I. and I.R.S. and is under investigation for allegedly failing to pay rebates owed to trucking customers.

headline: Lauren Bush Lauren Is Making a Name for Herself
text: For Lauren Bush Lauren, the strikingly attractive niece of one president and the granddaughter of another, as well as the daughter-in-law of a legendary figure in the world of American fashion, it’s not easy to go unnoticed.

headline: Unmanned Killers, and the Men Behind Them
text: Over the last couple of years, numerous authors have reported on specific aspects of America’s counterterrorism effort, including the Navy SEAL team operations, the bin Laden raid, other targeted killings and the drone strikes.

headline: Cora Viega
text: Cora Viega on her role within the Orange County Taskforce on Hoarding.

headline: N.F.L. Will Advise Teams on Discrimination Policy
text: The N.F.L. will distribute to its teams in the next few weeks an information sheet that will reinforce its antidiscrimination policy and will lay out in detail what constitutes discrimination based on sexual orientation and what team members can do about it. The distribution of the information sheet comes after players said they were asked during the Scouting Combine if they liked girls.

headline: Eric Hull
text: Eric Hull on how the hoarding taskforce works.

headline: Dina Bagues
text: Dina Bagues on how the hoarding taskforce works.

headline: Making a Name by Uncovering a Lost Case
text: The news, when it came, was short and sweet. Standing on a Florida golf course last week, Gilbert King looked at his phone and saw a two-word text message from an old friend: “Dude. Pulitzer.”

headline: Dark Songs Pierced With Rays of Cheer
text: Would the baritone Nathan Gunn have done things differently had he known that the concert he presented on Monday night at Zankel Hall would take place during the early blush of spring rather than the waning weeks of winter? The program, planned for February and delayed by illness, found him joined by the pianist Julie Gunn, his wife, and the Pacifica Quartet for a darkish mix of songs with English texts.

headline: Obama’s Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
text: DALLAS — President Obama has left little mystery about how he views his predecessor. “The failed policies of George W. Bush” wiped away a budget surplus and “squandered the legacy” of bipartisan foreign policy. Mr. Bush put two wars “on a credit card,” led the country away “from our values” and “crashed the economy.”

headline: Memories of a Bedtime Book Club
