text: The wine boxes and masking tape are out, because I’ve begun to pack up the last, best books in my children’s picture book library.

headline: For Northwestern, a Second Home at Wrigley
text: CHICAGO – It has been something of a challenge for Northwestern’s athletic teams to leave a footprint in Chicago, the nation’s third-biggest media market, when they play their home games in suburban Evanston, where the university is located.

headline: Domingo Zapata’s Best-Known Work May Be Himself
text: Some artists shun the spotlight, letting galleries promote their work while they keep to their studios. Others are savvier, stoking just enough buzz to get the art cognoscenti’s attention.

headline: Luminous Time Capsule, Bobbing Alongside the Present
text: Jonas Mekas calls his blissed-out new movie “Out-Takes From the Life of a Happy Man.” It’s an honest, direct title for a transcendently lovely and delicate work created from images that didn’t make it into the filmed diaries he made from 1960 to 2000. During those years, he produced some of his most enduring films, like “Walden” and “Lost Lost Lost.” He also published “I Had Nowhere to Go,” his often haunting memoir that traces his early life as a Lithuanian refugee during World War II, and his later struggles both as a displaced person in Europe after the war and then as an immigrant living, working, yearning and shooting his first films in New York City.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Corrections and YouTube Money
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Welcoming the Gods Back to Their Majestic Gloaming
text: Perhaps it is time to stop talking about the machine. Sure, Robert Lepage’s 45-ton set for the Metropolitan Opera‘s current production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle is loud, gimmicky and exorbitantly expensive. But so are many top restaurants in this city and that has never stopped New Yorkers from clambering over one another to get a table.

headline: All Systems Are Go, and Tested
text: The alto saxophonist and composer Steve Coleman puts his trust in systems, though he’s too rigorous to let any premise go untested. During his first set at the Stone in the East Village on Tuesday night, he kept setting up patterns and disrupting them, in variable cycles. Working as usual with Five Elements, his flagship band, he created the feeling of a meticulously honed aesthetic subjected to unrelenting pressure.

headline: Scaling Up a Classic Style
text: People looking for vintage hooked rugs can’t always find what they want in the size they need. “Our customers were always asking for something larger,” said Ramin Hakimi, a partner with Kevin Rahmanan in Rahmanan Antique & Decorative Rugs, a dealer in antique and vintage carpets. To meet the demand, the men started an offshoot company, the New England Collection, reproducing, in modern sizes, designs taken from their inventory of classic American hooked rugs. The range now also includes rag rugs, needlepoints and flat-woven styles, including dhurries, Aubussons, and Persian-style kilims. The monochromatic design shown here was adapted from a 19th-century New England model, with tweaks to the palette and pattern. It was woven in cotton on different-size hooks to create a variation in depth. The 6-by-9-foot carpet is $3,942. Information: (212) 683-0167 or necrugs.com.

headline: Sales at Eskayel, Serena and Lily and Others
text: Eskayel is taking 35 percent off all pillows, through Sunday (the 24-inch square Dynasty Pillow in slate, regularly $225, is about $146); (347) 703-8084, eskayel.com.

headline: A Table That Is Pure but Not Simple
text: If the Frazier side table, by the architecture and furniture design firm Khouri Guzman Bunce Ltd., looks old, that may be because its materials are borrowed from other industries. The top is borosilicate glass intended for telescope lenses and lab equipment. (The glass is available with a mirrored finish, which makes the subtle, character-building imperfections stand out even more.) The base is silicon bronze, with a 95 percent copper content, the most durable of all bronzes, and one that is used primarily for sculpture casting. (The base is also available in brass, blackened steel and nickel.) Rather than welded, these two pieces are screwed together, which produces a visually light effect and reveals that the frame is solid metal, rather than plated. “You can go anywhere and find a plated table,” said David Khouri, a partner in the firm. “I want people to think about how this one’s made.” A standard-size table is 22.5 inches high and 19.5 inches wide. Prices start at $7,250: (212) 420-7866 or kgb-limited.com.

headline: Brightening Up a Cancer Center’s Thrift Shop
text: In February, the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center asked the textile and carpet designer Madeline Weinrib to transform its charity thrift shop on the Upper East Side into an occasional pop-up boutique for designer sample sales. “With all the consignment shops around, and people selling their furniture on eBay, it has taken a lot of business away from the charity thrift shops,” said Ms. Weinrib, who is based in Manhattan. From May 3 to 5, she will fill the 2,500-square-foot space at 1440 Third Avenue with pillows, rugs, rolls of fabric to be sold by the yard, clothing, handbags, totes, napkins and furniture. Products will be sold at 40 to 70 percent off retail. Eighteen-inch-square pillows, shown above and below, originally $350 to $575, will be $179 to $299. Home delivery is not available, but even rugs and furniture pieces will be small enough to carry. The sale will take place from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (212) 535-1250.

headline: Check In Under ‘Jay’
text: Fans of “The Great Gatsby” may recall that the novel’s title character frequented the Plaza in Manhattan. So did F. Scott Fitzgerald, and in homage to the author and to the new Baz Luhrmann movie remake of his masterpiece, the hotel has created the Fitzgerald Suite.

headline: How a Dogg Became a Lion
text: The rechristening of Snoop Dogg (né Snoop Doggy Dogg) into Snoop Lion, the extremely chill reggae superhero, at first didn’t seem much like an evolution. He’d long been low-key, long had an air of knowing semi-spirituality, long been preoccupied with smoking weed. Did he really need to don Rastafarian drag too?

headline: Quinn to Allow Vote on a Profiling Bill
text: Christine C. Quinn, the New York City Council speaker and a Democratic candidate for mayor, said on Wednesday that she would not support a proposed bill to open state courts to claims of racial profiling by the Police Department, but would allow the bill’s sponsors to submit it for a vote.

headline: ‘Yard Shows’ Are Becoming Harder to Find
text: The Tin Man sent his regrets.

headline: Scrap-Iron Elegy
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — For a long time, Joe Minter managed to share a yard with his wife, Hilda, their two sons and 100,000 of their neighbors. His scruffy three-bedroom house filled up most of a small city lot, just up the hill from Martin Luther King Jr. Drive. But somehow he made it work.

headline: One of the Last Great ‘Yard Shows’ in Alabama
text: Joe Minter’s African Village is an ever-expanding sculptural display that surrounds his Birmingham, Ala., home.

headline: Umbrella Stands
text: What New Yorker hasn’t amassed a random collection of umbrellas, from the $5 one bought on the street during a rainstorm to the full-size model that never seems to work on narrow sidewalks?

headline: Shopping for Umbrella Stands
text: Shopping for umbrella stands with Emanuel Frattini Magusson.

headline: From Ingenious to the Fantastical
text: The lofts of 135 Plymouth Street in Dumbo, Brooklyn.

headline: The Art of Digging In
text: The ceiling of Mark Winkel’s apartment sprouts foam flowers as big as a man’s torso, several trapeze swings and a half-dozen chandeliers and pendant lights entwined with 1,000 roses. These last flourishes are the remnants of a Valentine’s Day brunch that Mr. Winkel, a puckish 37-year-old events producer who favors suits and ties (even at home), held for a few friends.

headline: How Does a Chair Look Presidential?
text: In the Bush family, Texas jockeys with Maine as the favored homeland, a theme that seems to have continued with the George W. Bush Presidential Center, on the campus of Southern Methodist University, in Dallas. It opens May 1 and is furnished throughout by Thos. Moser, the Auburn, Me., producer of handmade furniture.

headline: Your Chance to Snoop
text: Spring, when nature puts itself on open display, is also the season for peeking into private havens. Scores of house and garden tours are being organized, from Brooklyn to San Francisco, and will continue through the fine months. Here’s your chance to see hidden gardens in Boston or midcentury modern houses in Philadelphia. Or you can take in kitchen-focused residences in Larchmont, N.Y. (with tastings from local chefs). Many of the events are fund-raisers, so while you’re contemplating a reflecting pool or admiring a connoisseur’s art collection, your entry fees will be at work. Unless otherwise noted, all tours are self-guided.

headline: Gawking Encouraged
text: A guide to house tours around the country.

headline: Now Listening | Luke Winslow-King
text: At the age of 19, the New Orleans-based musician Luke Winslow-King, originally from Cadillac, Michigan, set out for a domestic tour with his blues band singing Woody Guthrie songs. But when they finally made it to the Big Easy, their car was stolen, with all their instruments inside. Most everything was later recovered, and so the city — coupled with the fact that they were able to borrow instruments from supportive locals to continue their tour — left a big impression on the young artist. “It’s almost like these things happened in my life that changed my course, but put me back to where I needed to be,” says Winslow-King, who then quickly moved to the Crescent City, where he started busking on Frenchmen Street while studying music at the University of New Orleans.

headline: Scientist Says Pollution From China Is Killing a Japanese Island’s Trees
text: YAKUSHIMA, Japan — A mysterious pestilence has befallen this island’s primeval forests, leaving behind the bleached, skeletal remains of dead trees that now dot the dark green mountainsides. Osamu Nagafuchi, an environmental engineer with a passion for the island and its rugged terrain, believes he knows the culprit: airborne pollutants from smog-belching China, hundreds of miles upwind.

headline: Niese Likely to Start on Sunday
text: One day after he was knocked out of a game when he took a comebacker to his right ankle, Jon Niese said he expected to make his next scheduled start, Sunday against the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Europe Struggles in Shale Gas Race
text: IN eastern Poland, politicians are still hoping to join the shale gas energy revolution, but lately they have had to curb their enthusiasm.

headline: When Algae on the Exterior Is a Good Thing
text: AS an energy source, algae may be growing up.

headline: Mobile Chargers Prepare for Their Day in the Sun
text: WHETHER you’re comparing restaurant menus while sitting in the park or turning on the air-conditioner before getting home, life is becoming increasingly mobile thanks to smartphones and tablets. And with new apps appearing constantly, the possibilities for this kind of connected living could be endless — if only the batteries lasted long enough.

headline: How to Charge Millions of Electric Cars? Not All at Once
text: PROPONENTS of electric vehicles like to talk about a not-too-distant future when plug-in cars become ubiquitous, with millions being driven by their owners on the daily commute.

headline: By 2023, a Changed World in Energy
text: HOUSTON

headline: Slow Start on Environment in Second Obama Term
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Next Nuclear Reactor May Arrive Hauled by a Truck
text: WASHINGTON

headline: From Power Plant to Civic Renewal Centerpiece
text: THE work starts next month and, once it is complete in about two years, a revitalized 7.8-acre site at the edge of downtown Austin, Tex., will offer new office spaces, shops and a high-rise apartment complex along Lady Bird Lake.

headline: Power Grids Iffy, Populous Areas Go for Generators
text: AFTER Tropical Storm Irene pummeled the Northeast in 2011, Keith and Barbara Wolff realized it was time to act. Though they were spared during Irene, several other storms had cut the power to their home in Brookfield, Conn., forcing them to throw out food, wear sweaters to keep warm and find coffee shops to recharge their cellphones and laptops.

headline: Harvard Medical School Plans to Close Primate Research Lab
text: About 2,000 monkeys at a Harvard Medical School research center will be moved to other laboratories around the country as the school shuts down the troubled center, an official with the National Institutes of Health said Wednesday.

headline: Playing With Light in the Darkness
text: Every other year, the Festival des Arts Visuels, which is devoted to photography and held in Vevey, Switzerland, selects an artist to receive $42,000 to fund a new project. As a member of the festival’s jury last week, I helped review the work of 750 photographers from 63 countries. The winner was Augustin Rebetez, a young Swiss whose photos, videos and drawings can be frightening yet weirdly playful and touching. Awkward home scenes, with walls that come to life and beds that breathe, are filled with demented twists and creepy characters. The fairytale world of his videos is as unsettling as the early work of David Lynch and the claymation art of Nathalie Djurberg — but also tender in the way that Tim Burton’s work can be.

headline: Some Love for 3 Achy Workhorses Linking Staten Island and New Jersey
text: As a child, Angela Goethals had a fantasy about the 7,100-foot-long structure between Staten Island and Elizabeth, N.J., that she still calls “my bridge,” even though it no more belonged to her than the George Washington Bridge belonged to Washington’s heirs or the Lincoln Tunnel belonged to Lincoln’s.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Quinn, Development Interests and the Closing of a Hospital
text: Critics of Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, on Wednesday released an attack ad asserting that Ms. Quinn allowed St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village to close three years ago. The critics’ political committee, called NYC Is Not For Sale 2013, says that its mission is to defeat Ms. Quinn’s mayoral bid and that it does not represent any particular candidate. Its leaders are from Local 1180, which represents communications workers; an animal rights group which opposes horse-drawn carriages; and Wendy Kelman Neu, chief executive of Hugo Neu Corporation, a recycling company. The ad is to air on television.

headline: New Technology Inspires a Rethinking of Light
text: AFTER the joy of the birth itself, parenthood sometimes brings the unwelcome news that a newborn has jaundice and must wear goggles and be placed under special lights. Imagine how different this experience might be if there were no goggles, just a warm blanket covering the tiny body, a healing frequency of blue light emanating from its folds.

headline: Paid Games on Smartphones Expected to Outpace Hand-Held Consoles
text: When I was a kid I carried around a little backpack that held my Nintendo Gameboy, a Sega Game Gear and several dozen game cartridges for each portable system. Today’s children simply carry around a smartphone and can play hundreds of thousands of games on a single device. No backpack or external game cartridges are required.

headline: 2 U.S. Agencies Added Boston Bomb Suspect to Watch Lists
text: WASHINGTON — Despite being told in 2011 that an F.B.I. review had found that a man who went on to become one of the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings had no ties to extremists, the Russian government asked the Central Intelligence Agency six months later for whatever information it had on him, American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Ranking Top 5 Running Backs in N.F.L. Draft
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

headline: The Digital Ad Industry Gets Dressed Down in Washington
text: Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, a West Virginia Democrat, lambasted the digital advertising industry on Wednesday for failing to voluntarily honor privacy requests from online consumers called “Do Not Track” signals.

headline: Wikipedia’s Sexism Toward Female Novelists
text: I JUST noticed something strange on Wikipedia. It appears that gradually, over time, editors have begun the process of moving women, one by one, alphabetically, from the “American Novelists” category to the “American Women Novelists” subcategory. So far, female authors whose last names begin with A or B have been most affected, although many others have, too.

headline: Westchester Leader Acts on a Fair-Housing Bill
text: Facing a threat of a contempt lawsuit by the Justice Department, the Westchester County executive, Robert P. Astorino, sent county legislators a letter on Wednesday asking them to pass a law forbidding landlords to discriminate against renters based on their source of income, as required under the county’s 2009 fair-housing settlement.

headline: Evidence and Economic Policy
text: Henry Blodget says that the economic debate is over; the austerians have lost and whatshisname has won. And it’s definitely true that in sheer intellectual terms, this is looking like an epic rout. The main economic studies that supposedly justified the austerian position have imploded; inflation has stayed low; the bond vigilantes have failed to make an appearance; the actual economic effects of austerity have tracked almost exactly what Keynesians predicted.

headline: Barclays and Credit Suisse Post Strong Earnings in Investment Banks
text: LONDON — As European policy makers push financial institutions to cut back on their risky trading activity, some of the region’s largest banks are becoming more reliant on their investment banking operations to bolster performance.

headline: Ex-Carnival Operator Admits Bribing Lawmaker for Permits
text: A former carnival operator pleaded guilty on Wednesday to lying to federal agents about paying more than $10,000 to a lawmaker to secure permits for his carnival business.

headline: Feared Fiend to Gentle Friend
text: Anyone familiar with cable television knows that plenty of adults believe in monsters. But the parents of Wanda, the heroine of the new family musical “Wanda’s Monster,” must not be fans of series like “Finding Bigfoot.” Wanda can’t convince them or her brother that a creature lives in her closet.

headline: Hallucinogens Lead to Arias
text: In 2007, if Joseph Keckler’s largely autobiographical new work, “I Am an Opera,” is to be believed, Mr. Keckler had a bad trip on hallucinogenic mushrooms.

headline: Trying to Burnish Its Image, J.&J. Turns to Emotions
text: FOR the corporate overseers at Johnson & Johnson, the last few years have been a challenge.

headline: The N.P.P.A.’s Best of Photojournalism
text: The National Press Photographers Association announced the winners of its 2013 Best of Photojournalism contest on Tuesday.

headline: Rent’s Still Too High, So a Former Candidate Is Back
text: It’s finally a mayoral race. Jimmy McMillan, bewhiskered avatar of the Rent Is Too Damn High party, entered the scrum on Wednesday with the “Rent Is Too Damn High” anthem, a song and video produced for him by the folks at the blog AnimalNewYork.

headline: Building Collapse Near Dhaka, Bangladesh
text: The collapse of an eight-story building in Bangladesh that housed several garment factories injured hundreds of people.

headline: Texas Fertilizer Plant Fell Through Regulatory Cracks
text: WEST, Tex. — In the moments after a fire broke out at a fertilizer plant here last week, some of the volunteer firefighters and other first responders who rushed to the scene appeared to have known that there were tons of dangerously combustible ammonium nitrate inside, but others did not.

headline: Investigations Expand in Hacking of A.P. Twitter Feed
text: Three federal agencies are now investigating an incident Tuesday in which hackers hijacked the Twitter account for The Associated Press and momentarily erased $136 billion from the stock market after they posted a fake Tweet reporting that there had been explosions at the White House that injured President Obama.

headline: Boom Times in Paraguay Leave Many Behind
text: ASUNCIÓN, Paraguay — Walk into the headquarters of the central bank of Paraguay, a sprawling seven-story structure surrounded by flowering silk floss trees, and the message is clear: officials proudly display charts showing a dizzying economic boom, with growth reaching 13 percent this year, making Paraguay the fastest-growing country in the Americas.

headline: House Majority Leader’s Quest to Soften G.O.P.’s Image Hits a Wall Within
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the House majority leader, has been trying for months to remake the image of the Republican Party, from one of uncompromising conservatism to something kinder and gentler.

headline: Amazon Plans an Internet Video Device
text: SEATTLE — Amazon created the Kindle to breathe life into electronic books. Now it is preparing a device to bring Internet video to television sets.

headline: Revenue in Decline, Zynga Promotes a Game Sequel
text: Zynga just cannot win.

headline: Free College Options Still Exist, for Those Willing to Build Ships, Milk Cows or Salute
text: When the trustees of Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art voted this week to start charging for an undergraduate degree, it ended the institution’s lengthy reign as the most famous tuition-free private college in America.

headline: Marcum Joins the Mets
text: Shaun Marcum on Wednesday settled into his Citi Field locker inside the Mets’ clubhouse for the first time since signing with the team this winter.

headline: Are Myanmar’s Hopes Fading?
text: CHIANG MAI, Thailand

headline: No Room for Radicals
text: JUST hours after the two suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing were identified as Muslims, Representative Peter T. King of New York, the Republican chairman of the House Subcommittee on Counterterrorism and Intelligence, called for an “increased surveillance” of Islamic communities in the United States. “I think we need more police and more surveillance in the communities where the threat is coming from,” he told National Review. “The new threat is definitely from within.”

headline: Learning From China, but What?
text: BEIJING

headline: A Draft Short on Passers but Long on Talent
text: They headed to Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan last year bearing posters labeled “Hope,” with the face of the president of the United States replaced by that of a quarterback — a cluster of fans who would start chanting Robert Griffin III’s name well before the Washington Redskins were even on the clock.

headline:
U.S. Says It
Suspects Assad
Used Chemical
Weapons
text: WASHINGTON – The White House said on Thursday that American intelligence agencies now assess, with “varying degrees of confidence,” that the Syrian government has used chemical weapons, but it said it needed conclusive proof before President Obama would take action.

headline: Politics of Paranoia
text: Out-of-control federal government. An immediate and immense Muslim threat. Gun grabbing, national registries and eventual mass confiscations. Tyranny.

headline: Joint Effort Seeks Drugs for Autism
text: With the diagnosis of autism on the rise and drug companies facing major setbacks in developing successful treatments, the University of California, Los Angeles will lead a $9 million effort financed by the National Institute of Mental Health to find effective drugs, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Canada’s Oil Minister, Unmuzzled
text: The last time your friendly scribe sought an interview with Joe Oliver, Canada’s minister of natural resources, he was turned down flat. It was February last year. Oliver had made a series of impolitic remarks about the efforts to block the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which, if it’s ever built, would import oil from the tar sands of Alberta to refineries along the Gulf Coast — and which Canadians believe that the United States would be nuts to reject.

headline: Corporate Donations and the S.E.C.
text: The Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision that triggered an avalanche of corporate political spending also contained a proposal for greater public disclosure from corporations that would prefer to write their checks in the shadows. Transparency, the court advised, would let voters decide for themselves “whether elected officials are ‘in the pocket’ of so-called moneyed interests.”

headline: Updating an E-Mail Law From the Last Century
text: Steven Warshak, a Cincinnati businessman who built an empire selling male sexual enhancement drugs, was convicted of wire fraud several years ago, based in large part on his e-mail correspondence, which authorities had extracted via a subpoena under a 1986 law governing electronic privacy.

headline: Were Chemical Weapons Used in Syria?
text: It’s not hard to imagine that President Bashar al-Assad, desperately clinging to power, might use chemical weapons against the Syrian people. He has already pummeled them with warplanes and missiles and shows no signs of ending a bloody onslaught that has lasted more than two years. But while he may be capable of using weapons of mass destruction, there is no proof that he has done so.

headline: Moving Past the Last Balkan War
text: At a time of disillusionment about the state of the European Union, a diplomatic deal between Serbia and Kosovo highlights some of the more positive features of the institution that won last year’s Nobel Peace Prize but fumbled the euro crisis. The tentative agreement signed last Friday not only shows that the European Union can perform well but also that it remains an attractive destination for countries that aspire to membership.

headline: Jets’ Remodeler Refined His Style Over the Years
text: John Idzik worked in the Tampa Bay front office in 1997 when the Buccaneers set out in the draft to improve the N.F.L.’s lowest-scoring offense. They focused on a certain running back, and after ascertaining that another team was also in pursuit, they maneuvered to select him with the 12th pick.

headline: On Beyond Fear
text: The homeland security secretary, Janet Napolitano, testified on Tuesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee about the Senate’s bipartisan immigration bill. For hours, in a calm and methodical manner, she flipped each confrontational line of questioning on its head. No, the bill would not loosen security at borders and ports. It would tighten it. The bill would not weaken immigration enforcement, but strengthen it — adding resources and improving the government’s ability to keep unwanted people out and to catch fugitives, identify thieves and terrorists.

headline: Unit Aims to Improve City’s Elections Board
text: A New York City agency said on Wednesday that it was creating a unit to investigate fraud, waste and corruption problems at the Board of Elections, long a bête noire of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: 2 Tangled Lives Collide, Again, in Ricin Case
text: TUPELO, Miss. — Paul Kevin Curtis and James Everett Dutschke have a lot in common, though they would probably not like to think of it that way.

headline: Is the Hijab Worth Fighting Over?
text: One side says the Muslim headscarf is oppressive. The other side calls it liberating. But are they both overplaying its significance?

headline: Defending the Indigent
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ending Sex Trafficking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Q. and A. at Bush Museum
text: To the Editor:

headline: Despite Flaws, Bronx Courts Aim for Swift Justice
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Joy (and Despair) of Cooking
As Bird Flu Spreads to Taiwan, Governments Act to Prepare
text: BEIJING — The new strain of avian influenza that has infected more than 100 people in China in the last two months has, for the first time, been reported outside mainland China.

headline: Despair Drives Guantánamo Detainees to Revolt
text: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — In the early afternoon quiet, guards in camouflage fatigues walked the two-tiered cellblocks of Camp Six, where the most cooperative of the 166 terrorism suspects held in the military prison here are housed. From a darkened control room, other guards watched banks of surveillance monitors showing prisoners in white clothing — pacing, sleeping or reading — in their cells.

headline: Streaming on Yahoo, It’s ‘S.N.L.’
text: When they were performing on “Saturday Night Live” three decades ago, Al Franken, Bill Murray and Eddie Murphy surely didn’t expect they would ever be streamed on computers and phones. In fact, they probably would have made fun of the idea.

headline: GE Capital Cuts Gun Shop Purchase Loans
text: GE Capital, General Electric’s lending arm, recently stopped offering consumer financing programs to retailers whose main business is selling guns, in response to the “industry changes, new legislation and tragic events.”

headline: A Three-Way Battle for Two Playoff Spots
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — Thursday’s games could decide the postseason fates of the Rangers, the Winnipeg Jets and the Ottawa Senators, who are fighting for the last two playoff spots in the Eastern Conference. Or, the suspense could drag out a little longer.

headline: Officer’s Killing Spurred Pursuit in Boston Attack
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Officer Sean A. Collier was 27, not much older than the Massachusetts Institute of Technology students he watched over as a campus police officer, and he sometimes joined them in a game of darts or Xbox. So when an ambulance staffed by students rolled past his parked patrol car last Thursday night, he flashed his blue lights to say hello. The students answered with their red lights.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 24, 2013

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Apr. 25, 2013
text: “The situation is not sustainable. We need an exit strategy.”

headline: If Not Yellen at the Fed, Perhaps One of These
text: Handicapping the candidates to succeed Ben S. Bernankeas Federal Reserve chairman has much in common with predicting the outcome of a golf tournament: There’s a good chance that the winner will not be one of the early favorites.

headline: Possible Fed Successor Has Admirers and Foes
text: WASHINGTON — In July 1996, the Federal Reserve broke the metronomic routine of its closed-door policy-making meetings to hold an unusual debate. The Fed’s powerful chairman, Alan Greenspan, saw a chance for the first time in decades to drive annual inflation all the way down to zero, achieving the price stability he had long regarded as the central bank’s primary mission.

headline: In a First, Judge Orders Legal Aid for Mentally Disabled Immigrants Facing Deportation
text: A federal judge in California has ordered immigration courts in three states to provide legal representation for immigrants with mental disabilities who are in detention and facing deportation, if they cannot represent themselves. The decision is the first time a court has required the government to provide legal assistance for any group of people before the nation’s immigration courts.

headline: Boston Attack Spotlights Struggle Half a World Away
text: KIZILYURT, Russia — With an automatic weapon at his side and a black flag behind him, the Islamic rebel explained in a video why he had gone to war with his government. As is often the case in the broiling Muslim insurgency here in the North Caucasus, his complaints were intensely local: a police commander had announced a policy of harassing and threatening family members of suspected militants.

headline: Crazy Talk
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This is the type of puzzle where the reveal hits you in two parts: first, you might have filled in enough of the four theme answers — a diverse list of items, to say the least — and noticed the payoff at 50 Across to note that certain letters in the theme answer make up a “magician’s phrase.”

headline: Corrections: April 25, 2013
text: INTERATIONAL

headline: A Schmoozy Cobra, About to Be Bitten
text: Chances are you are not a movie star. Chances are equally good that this state of affairs is not likely to change soon. But if you’ve ever wondered what it might be like to explore that golden realm where the gods and goddesses of the screen dwell, race over to the Booth Theater, where you can enjoy an audience with a woman who consorted almost exclusively with box office luminaries, or “twinklies” as she affectionately calls them.

headline: Subtler Harm From Bombs: Some Victims Lose Hearing
text: Initially preoccupied by the severe injuries sustained by victims of the Boston bombings, hospitals are now grappling with a more subtle medical consequence: widespread hearing loss among those closest to the blasts.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,182 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Ascendant German Clubs Signal Shift in Continental Power
text: Changes in the balance of power in Europe can take centuries, but when it comes to soccer, a revolution happened swiftly, in 180 minutes on the field. For the second consecutive day, a German club not only defeated but also thoroughly outplayed a Spanish one.

headline: Trinity Church Split on How to Manage $2 Billion Legacy of a Queen
text: There has never been any doubt that Trinity Church is wealthy. But the extent of its wealth has long been a mystery; guessed at by many, known by few.

headline: At Trial, Liu Aide Tells of Offering to Reimburse Campaign Donors
text: A longtime aide to John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller and current Democratic candidate for mayor, testified on Wednesday that she had offered to reimburse donors for their contributions to Mr. Liu’s campaign, a tactic that prosecutors have said was part of an illegal fund-raising strategy used by some Liu aides.

headline: Gases to Be Dispersed Across City (Exhale: It’s a Test)
text: On three separate days this July, invisible and odorless gases will be released in subway stations and at street level in all five boroughs of New York City. But officials in the New York Police Department will not be alarmed — it was their idea.

headline: Syria’s Shifting Strategy
text: As the war continues, Syrian officials are trying to convince Western countries that they should not support rebel forces, saying many are extremists allied with Al Qaeda.

headline: From Terrorizing Streets to Making Them Safer
text: In its blunt retelling of Central Harlem, the documentary opens with Dedric Hammond standing in front of a Chinese takeout restaurant near the spot where he was shot the first time. Bullets had a circular presence in his life, beginning when he was known on the streets simply as Bad News, a name he got for being a shooter.

headline: Knicks Have Boston’s Numbers: Up 2, 2 to Go
text: The emotions will be powerful Friday night at Boston’s TD Garden, a mix of cathartic release and desperation. This much, the Knicks and Celtics both know and expect.

headline: Syrian Prisoners Talk, as Jailers Look On
text: Syrian officials picked prisoners to meet with New York Times journalists. Interviewed in front of their jailers, they described a range of goals.

headline: Texas: Skepticism on Immigration Law
text: In a preliminary ruling, a federal judge found that the Obama administration violated immigration law with a program last year that offered reprieves from deportation to hundreds of thousands of young illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children. The ruling on Tuesday came in a lawsuit brought by immigration enforcement agents against Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano. Judge Reed O’Connor rejected most of the administration’s arguments and found that the agents were “likely to succeed” in the case. He delayed a final ruling, asking both sides to submit more information by May 6.

headline: Obama Tells Democratic Donors He’ll Keep Reaching Out to G.O.P.
text: DALLAS — President Obama vowed Wednesday night to continue trying to work with Republican lawmakers even if doing so irritates some of his Democratic supporters who think he is “a sap.”

headline: Carlesimo and Nets Searching for Right Combinations
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Tom Thibodeau, the coach of the Chicago Bulls, is known as a taskmaster who can run his key players into the ground. In his team’s Game 2 victory over the Nets, Thibodeau used nine players who each had at least 10 minutes of action and made important contributions.

headline: Syria Plays on Fears to Blunt American Support of Rebels
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — As Islamists increasingly fill the ranks of Syrian rebels, President Bashar al-Assad is waging an energized campaign to persuade the United States that it is on the wrong side of the civil war. Some government supporters and officials believe they are already coaxing — or at least frightening — the West into holding back stronger support for the opposition.

headline: Harvey Stumbles, but Mets Prevail With a Slam
text: The Mets scratched their way back late Wednesday, to the point where a simple fly ball would have been enough to give them an unlikely come-from-behind win. They got one, and then some, as Jordany Valdespin crushed a game-ending grand slam that attached a stirring exclamation point onto the their 10-inning, 7-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers at Citi Field.

headline: Wrong Pitch Results in First Loss for Pettitte
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Andy Pettitte clearly did not want to go into a detailed discussion about the curveball that he felt decided the game. He said the location was not the problem. It was the pitch itself.

headline: Bob Edgar, Lawmaker and Liberal Leader, Dies at 69
text: Bob Edgar, a Methodist minister who pushed for liberal reforms as a six-term Pennsylvania congressman, a leader of American churches and president of the lobbying group Common Cause, died Tuesday at his home in Burke, Va. He was 69.

headline: Suzuki Collects Two Hits and Gets a Promotion
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — After collecting two hits, including the game-winning single in the ninth inning on Tuesday, Ichiro Suzuki was promoted to the No. 2 spot in the batting order Wednesday.

headline: Word of the Day | pivotal
text: pivotal •\ˈpi-və-təl\• adjective

headline: Study Ties Autism Risk to Creases in Placenta
text: After most pregnancies, the placenta is thrown out, having done its job of nourishing and supporting the developing baby.

headline: The Shadow Lobbyist
text: There has been a quiet upheaval in the lobbying industry.

headline: A Messenger for the Internet of Things
text: The vision of the Internet of Things is inspiring, if much-hyped. Billions of digital devices, from smartphones to sensors in homes, cars and machines of all kinds, will communicate with each other to automate tasks and make life better.

headline: South Korea: Ultimatum on Talks
text: South Korea gave North Korea until Friday to respond to its proposal for dialogue on a joint industrial park or face a “grave measure” on the future of the factory complex, which has been the only remaining symbol of economic cooperation between the two Koreas. A statement from the South’s Unification Ministry stopped short of clarifying whether the decision it was contemplating involved pulling out 176 South Korean managers remaining in the Kaesong factory park in North Korea or even terminating the joint economic project.

headline: North Korea Issues Threat at Ceremony for Military
text: SEOUL, South Korea — On an anniversary known for military showmanship, North Korean generals on Thursday declared that their forces were ready to launch intercontinental ballistic missiles and kamikazelike nuclear attacks at the United States if threatened.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) BLACK SWAN (2010) Natalie Portman, above, in the role that earned her an Academy Award, stars as Nina, a ballet dancer teetering on the verge of insanity as she tries to break out of the corps and into the dual lead of “Swan Lake”: the Swan Queen and her villainous black swan twin. Mila Kunis is Lily, the sultry newcomer who is everything the increasingly tormented Nina is not, as their company’s artistic director, Thomas (Vincent Cassel), points out. The result is “a witchy brew of madness and cunning,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this film, directed by Darren Aronofsky, which also received Oscar nominations for best director, best picture and others.

headline: Chinese Opera Performers See Fewer Faces in the Audience
text: BANGKOK — Sleep like dogs, eat like pigs, dress like angels.

headline: The Dodgers See Harvey, and Come Away Impressed
text: At heart, baseball players are fans too. Though they are highly paid, and often engrossed in their own world of slumps and streaks, players aren’t immune to the biggest story lines in the sport.

headline: News Quiz | April 25, 2013
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Satirizing China With the ‘China Daily Show’
text: BEIJING — As China watches the spread of a new type of deadly bird flu with unease, there’s a chicken farmer in Henan Province who’s feeling lonely.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 25
text: NEWS With any decision about closing down the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, put on the back burner, inmates there have lost hope that they will ever be released. A hunger strike is now in its third month, with 93 prisoners considered to be participating — more than half the inmates. Charlie Savage reports from Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: The Trans-Atlantic College Search
text: LONDON — At least I didn’t have to whack anybody.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Windhover’
text: On April 29th and 30th, Poetry Out Loud will hold its  National Finals of Poetry Out Loud: National Recitation Contest. In honor of this celebration of bringing poetry to an audience of not just readers, but listeners as well, this week’s Poetry Pairing matches “The Windhover” by Gerard Manley Hopkins, a popular choice for Poetry Out Loud participants, with the article, “Open Mike, Insert Verse” by David Orr.

headline: Western Firms Feel Pressure as Toll Rises in Bangladesh
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — As rescuers struggled on Thursday to reach survivors in one of the worst manufacturing disasters in history, pointed questions were being raised about why a Bangladesh factory building was not padlocked after terrified workers notified the police, government officials and a powerful garment industry group about cracks in the walls.

headline: In ‘Powerless,’ India’s Electricity Crisis Pits Maverick Against the State
text: NEW YORK CITY —The first character we meet in Fahad Mustafa and Deepti Kakkar’s film, “Powerless,” is not a person at all – it’s a menacing tangle of wires, looming over the gritty northern Indian city of Kanpur.

headline: Explosions on River in Alabama Injure 3
text: Fires ignited by a series of at least seven explosions aboard two fuel barges on the Mobile River in Alabama burned themselves out Thursday morning, the authorities said.

headline: Santander Earnings Slump on Weak Economy
text: LONDON – Banco Santander said on Thursday that first-quarter net profit fell 26 percent, hurt by continuing troubles in Spain and a slowdown in developing economies.

headline: Test Yourself | English, April 25, 2013
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “20 Pounds? Not Too Bad, for an Extinct Fish.”

headline: Listening to Poets in Unexpected Places
text: In “On the Train, or at the Laundromat, Your Poem Begins … Now,” Dusica Sue Malesevic writes about Poets in Unexpected Places.

headline: The Treasury’s Mistaken View on Too Big to Fail
text: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management.John E. Parsons is a senior lecturer in the finance group at the Sloan School and co-author of the blog bettingthebusiness.com.

headline: Caught Cold When Sochi Freezes Over
text: A few hours before President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke at a ceremony in the Bolshoy Ice Dome in Sochi in February, marking a year to the start of the 2014 Winter Olympics, I was watching pensioners strip to the waist and bask in the midday sunshine on a beach a few miles from the Olympic Park.

headline: When Should You Be Able to Buy Cigarettes, Drink Alcohol, Vote, Drive and Fight in Wars?
text: Do you think people under the age of 18 are mature enough to make life-or-death decisions on their own? Which of these things do you think constitute life-or-death decisions? Why?

headline: A Conversation With: Director Mira Nair
text: NEW YORK CITY— On Friday, April 26, the Mira Nair-directed thriller “The Reluctant Fundamentalist” opens in theaters across the United States. The film, based on the novel by the Pakistani author Mohsin Hamid, stars the British actor Riz Ahmed as a possible terrorist.

headline: Ranking Top 5 Wide Receivers in N.F.L. Draft
text: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

headline: Why We Should Miss Pillarless Rooflines
text: Once upon a time, automotive roof pillars were elegantly skinny. They’ve since bulked up in the interest of safety, but what have we lost in the process?

headline: The Early Word: Awkward
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Our Feel-Good War on Breast Cancer
text: I used to believe that a mammogram saved my life. I even wrote that in the pages of this magazine. It was 1996, and I had just turned 35 when my doctor sent me for an initial screening — a relatively common practice at the time — that would serve as a base line when I began annual mammograms at 40. I had no family history of breast cancer, no particular risk factors for the disease.

headline: Yes, You Treat Customers Well. But How Do You Treat Employees?
text: I’ve been involved in owning and coaching businesses for about 35 years. I have gone from being one of the worst employers I have ever seen to being one that is at least pretty good. The biggest lesson I learned was that if I ever wanted my employees to treat my customers well, I had better treat my employees well. It took me 10 years to learn this lesson, but once I did, our customer service went from O.K. with lots of effort to great with minimal effort.

headline: Daily Report: Yahoo Buys Rights to ‘Saturday Night Live’ Archive
text: Yahoo announced Wednesday that it acquired the exclusive rights to classic clips of “Saturday Night Live” from 1975 through 2012, effective in September. The clips will be removed from Hulu and NBC.com, where they currently reside, and be shown instead on Yahoo, which wants to share in the buzz the show creates, Brian Stelter reports Thursday in The New York Times.

headline: Europe Nears Antitrust Deal With Google Over Web Searches
text: BRUSSELS — European Union regulators took another step on Thursday toward reaching an antitrust settlement with Google, asking the company’s competitors to review changes proposed by Google to resolve concerns with its Internet search and advertising business.

headline: Much Ado About a Fake Tweet
text: A tweet from a hacked Associated Press Twitter account sent United States stocks tumbling.

headline: Q&A: Changing How iTunes Automatically Downloads Files
text: Q.

headline: ‘Punk: Chaos to Couture’
text: A look at the new exhibition at the Met’s Costume Institute.

headline: Haute Punk
text: Deep in the bowels of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a gray-smocked assistant in the Costume Institute was carefully transporting a long box from a storage area. All around her were mannequins wearing head-to-toe perfected haute couture: a laced-up Versace, a deconstructed Margiela. In a corner stood a male mannequin wearing a black bondage suit and artfully scuffed Doc Marten boots.

headline: Anarchy in the Met
text: Everyone loves a uniform. In both the mainstream and the counterculture, they connote order and authority. They shape the story. They make things easy. For the wearer, they stand in for having to speak. For the observer, they serve as shorthand.

headline: Of Nature and Rivers of Pins
text: A look at Maya Lin’s new show “Here and There” at Pace Gallery.

headline: Academic Non-Obscurity
text: Robert Samuelson tries to minimize the significance of the Reinhart-Rogoff affair; and that, I realized, offers an interesting window into why, in fact, the affair matters so much.

headline: Maya Lin’s New Memorial Is a City
text: Try to get Maya Lin to talk about her new show at Pace Gallery in New York, and she’s more likely to deliver a passionate lecture on the environment.

headline: Verizon Is Said to Hire Advisers on Bid for Wireless Stake
text: Verizon Communications has been vocal about its desire to buy Vodafone’s portion of the Verizon Wireless venture. Now, Verizon has hired banking and legal advisers to prepare a possible $100 billion cash-and-stock bid for the 45 percent of the wireless carrier it does not own, according to Reuters, which cites two unidentified people familiar with the matter.

headline: Lil Bub Hits the Tribeca Film Festival
text: If you are the type of person who is inclined to watch YouTube videos of cute animals doing even cuter things, you’ve probably encountered Lil Bub: the adorable walleyed kitten with a perpetually protruding strawberry pink tongue.

headline: K.K.R. Earnings Beat Expectations as Fee Profits Rise
text: The still-improving landscape for deal-making has been kind to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which posted first-quarter earnings of $647.7 million on Thursday, surpassing analysts’ expectations.

headline: Sony Doubles Annual Profit Estimate
text: TOKYO — Sony, Japan’s long-troubled electronics and entertainment giant, doubled its annual net profit estimate Thursday, citing a weaker yen, sales of noncore assets and a recent stock rally that has bolstered its insurance business.

headline: Half a Fare, Half a Seat
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Times Co. Profit Falls; New Subscription Model Is Set
text: The New York Times Company reported a decline in first-quarter income on Thursday as its executives continued to reposition the company into a global news outlet for a digital age.

headline: The Tea Party Caucus: It’s Baaack!
text: For the better part of a year, the country has survived, somehow, without a House Tea Party Caucus. A group that once boiled with anti-government furor went dormant last summer as the Tea Party’s popularity plummeted and its leader, Michele Bachmann, struggled to get re-elected. Ten caucus members lost their jobs in November. The sniping about the House Republican leadership — not to mention President Obama — quieted down, and so did the tweets championing Barry Goldwater’s still-radioactive support of extremism.

headline: Domestic Bliss? You Won’t Find It Here
text: “Collapse” is quite a bold title for a play that proves so trite. Built on unbelievable situations and uninspired jokes, the script holds enough humor to sustain a sitcom. But as this comedy stretches toward an hour and a half, the only thing that the title invites is an easy attempt to sum up the show.

headline: Thursday Reading: A Paraguayan Route to a Scenic Waterfall
text: A Paraguayan route to a scenic waterfall, healing plantar fasciitis, down payment rules at the heart of the mortgage debate and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: With Fellow Cigar Enthusiasts, Lhota Raises Money in Smoky Haze
text: Some politicians avoid a smoke-filled room. This week, Joseph J. Lhota held a fund-raiser in one.

headline: The ‘Poisoned’ Girls of Afghanistan
text: It’s happening again.

headline: On Being Brown in America
text: The recent bombings in Boston threw up many questions. One of the most pressing, in my somewhat narrow view, is the meaning of being brown in America.

headline: Leaving the Picture Books on the Shelves
text: Dwight Garner, longtime book critic for The New York Times, has packed up his picture book shelves — his children’s picture book shelves, that is.

headline: The Thick Have Their Needs, Too
text: To describe “Pain & Gain” as a Michael Bay movie on steroids would be accurate but also redundant and a little misleading. Pumped-up, aggressive, muscle-headed entertainment is Mr. Bay’s specialty, after all, and while this grisly true-crime drama is partly about performance-enhancing drugs and the bulky men who love them, it is also, compared with “Armageddon” or the “Transformers” series, a stripped-down, modest enterprise in which no major American city is reduced to rubble.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival: A Unique Perspective on the Madoff Meltdown
text: In early 2009, a journalist introduced the filmmakers Derek Anderson and Victor Kubicek to Eleanor Squillari. The Bernard L. Madoff financial scandal was dominating the news — Mr. Madoff had been arrested in December 2008 — and as the disgraced financier’s former secretary, Ms. Squillari was a hot property among reporters and others hoping to untangle the crime.

headline: Doctors Denounce Cancer Drug Prices of $100,000 a Year
text: With the cost of some lifesaving cancer drugs exceeding $100,000 a year, more than 100 influential cancer specialists from around the world have taken the unusual step of banding together in hopes of persuading some leading pharmaceutical companies to bring prices down.

headline: And the Oliviers Will Go to . . .
text: LONDON—This Sunday the London theater’s annual Laurence Olivier Awards will be bestowed, and those who want to guess at the eventual victors should know one thing: Anyone could win.

headline: A Night of Saurian Spotlighting
text: Jonathan Losos, professor and curator of herpetology at Harvard’s Museum of Comparative Zoology, writes from Colombia, where he is studying the biodiversity of anole lizards, an evolutionarily successful group that has produced 400 species throughout Central and South America and the Caribbean islands. For more on anoles, see anoleannals.org.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Details: Cauliflower is having a moment. Can lima beans be far behind? — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Schumer and McCain Express Optimism on Chances for Immigration Overhaul
text: Senators John McCain and Charles E. Schumer, who are leading a push for bipartisan immigration legislation, said Thursday that they were aiming to win 70 votes in the Senate and hoped to gain the backing of a majority of senators in both parties — a prospect Mr. McCain said was “very doable.”

headline: Sustaining Cities on a Crowding Planet
text: A useful discussion of urban futures with a focus on energy and resilience to environmental hazards took place today at The New York Times, including panels of mayors, a chat between me and the actor Jeremy Irons over his involvement in the documentary “Trashed” and much more.

headline: Parents Deny Sons’ Guilt and Accuse U.S. of Plot
text: MAKHACHKALA, Russia — The parents of the two brothers accused in the bomb attack that killed three people and wounded more than 260 others near the finish line of the Boston Marathon insisted on Thursday that their sons were innocent and had no connections to radical Islamists.

headline: Jonathan Franzen: By the Book
text: During a dark moment in his early 30s, the author of “The Corrections” and, most recently, “Farther Away: Essays” took solace from the self-help book “The Dance of Anger.”

headline: The Gun Report: April 25, 2013
text: I hear, reliably, that universal background checks may be back on the table. Senator Joe Manchin, the West Virginia Democrat—and former National Rifle Association golden boy—who stuck his neck out to try to push through some sensible gun legislation is said to be regrouping, and preparing for another charge up the hill in the coming week.

headline: This Week’s Links: _why Edition
text: DevTools Can Do That?

headline: The Drafts Before the Draft
text: We have finally reached the big day in N.F.L. mania circles. It is mock draft day, when you have either created one of your own ahead of Thursday night’s festivities, or you are mocking the people who have. It certainly does form the line in football fandom between the folks who have gone a bit around the bend and those who just want to know who will be on their team come September. Of course, we long ago identified the around-the-bend types because they have been poring over this stuff for weeks, watched over by their Mel Kiper Jr. bobblehair dolls.

headline: Hawks and Doves at the Fed
text: The economist Dean Baker recalls a story about Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve vice chairwoman, that seems at odds with the story that opens my profile of Ms. Yellen in Thursday’s paper.

headline: For Bush, a Day to Bask in Texas Sun
text: UNIVERSITY PARK, Tex. — Standing in front of the magisterial brick-and-limestone George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum on Thursday, Bill Clinton summed up the day with a knowing smile. “I told President Obama,” he said, “that this was the latest, grandest example of the eternal struggle of former presidents to rewrite history.”

headline: Swiss Quotas Highlight Europe’s Immigration Debate
text: LONDON — A decision by Switzerland to limit migration from other European countries has provoked a sharp response from officials of the European Union.

headline: Syria Claims Disruption of a Rebel Supply Line
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s state news media said Thursday that government forces had “restored complete control” in a strategic, bitterly contested town east of Damascus, offering new claims — disputed by rebel fighters on the ground — that loyalist troops are reversing the flow of battle in some areas, severing a crucial insurgent supply line on the approaches to the capital.

headline: What Families Are Spending on Prom Night
text: Here is my deep, dark secret from high school: I didn’t go to the prom.

headline: New Literary Prize Goes to DeLillo
text: The first Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction has been awarded to Don DeLillo, the author of “Underworld,” “White Noise,” “Libra” among numerous other works.

headline: Neil Diamond to Donate ‘Sweet Caroline’ Royalties to Boston Bombing Charity
text: Neil Diamond says he will donate the royalties from this week’s surge in sales of his song “Sweet Caroline” to a fund for victims of the Boston Marathon bombing. He made the announcement on Twitter on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: A $2 App That Refocuses Photos Like a $400 Lytro
text: Photographers have been wowed by the Lytro, a camera that can refocus a shot after you take it. But the Lytro costs $400 to $500, and that’s a lot to spend for a feature that is a bit of a novelty.

headline: For Congress, a Question of Cellphone Tracking
text: While the Senate considered an overhaul of a sweeping quarter-century-old law governing e-mail privacy, a House Judiciary Committee panel received dueling arguments on Thursday over when and how police can track the location of Americans carrying a cellphone.

headline: Israel Shoots Down Drone Possibly Sent by Hezbollah
text: TEL AVIV — The Israeli military said it shot down a drone on Thursday, five nautical miles off the coast of its northern port of Haifa, after tracking it for an hour as it flew south along the Lebanese coast.

headline: Did Boston Suspect Slip Under the Radar?
text: The Times’s Michael S. Schmidt discusses the investigation of the suspected bomber Tamerlan Tsarnaev, including what his parents said on Thursday in Russia.

headline: Ask Well: Exercises to Prevent Dementia?
text: Question:

headline: Amy Winehouse Documentary Coming From Director of ‘Senna’
text: Asif Kapadia, the director of an acclaimed documentary about the race-car driver Ayrton Senna, will next turn his attention to another life lived in a very different fast lane with a film about Amy Winehouse.

headline: Vibe Magazine Is Sold and Likely to Become Online Only
text: SpinMedia, a group of music and pop culture Web sites that includes Spin magazine, has bought Vibe, the 21-year-old R&B and hip-hop magazine.

headline: Revisiting the Buckleys
text: The director Dan Algrant discusses his film “Greetings From Tim Buckley,” featuring Penn Badgley as the musician Jeff Buckley.

headline: Four Artists Named as Finalists for Britain’s Turner Prize
text: Lynette Yiadom-Boakye, a British artist who paints portraits of imaginary people, leaving it to the viewer to supply the biographical back stories – and whose first solo museum exhibition, “Any Number of Preoccupations,” was a hit when it was mounted at the Studio Museum in Harlem in 2010 – is one of four finalists for the 2013 Turner Prize.

headline: New Details Released on Death of Israeli Spy
text: JERUSALEM — On the day he hanged himself in the shower of his solitary cell, the Australian-born Israeli spy known as Prisoner X had a visit from his wife in which he received difficult news; he emerged crying. He was taking anti-anxiety medication at the time, and told social workers that he had twice before attempted suicide and once cut his own hand.

headline: Plouffe, Ex-Obama Adviser, Joins Bloomberg Television
text: Bloomberg Television, an arm of the media giant owned by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, on Thursday hired David Plouffe to be both a contributor to its business newscasts and a strategic adviser to the network.

headline: Nora Ephron Prize Is Given to Director of  ‘Farah Goes Bang’
text: The Tribeca Film Festival on Thursday inaugurated its Nora Ephron Prize, for a “woman writer or director with a distinctive voice,” by awarding it to a very surprised Meera Menon, the director of the road-trip comedy “Farah Goes Bang.”

headline: From Horses to Horsepower: BMWs Come to Saratoga Springs
text: The high society summer season in Saratoga Springs, in upstate New York, was built around the horse racing scene. But horsepower is the theme at the Saratoga Automobile Museum, where a herd of historic BMW cars and motorcycles go on display in an exhibition opening May 6 and running through Nov. 3.

headline: Jerusalem Court Upholds Ruling in Women of the Wall Case
text: JERUSALEM — A Jerusalem court on Thursday upheld a ruling that five women who had been detained at the Western Wall for wearing prayer shawls traditionally used by men and singing were not disturbing the public order, rejecting an appeal by the police. The decision, by the Jerusalem District Court, upheld a ruling last Thursday by a magistrates’ court. The women, activists with Women of the Wall, a feminist and pluralist religious group, have been challenging the enforcement of strict Orthodox codes at the holy site. Lawyers for the group said Thursday’s ruling undermined the basis for future detentions and arrests. There was no immediate response from the police. Israeli officials are examining a proposal to create a new prayer area for more egalitarian worship after tensions over rituals at the site caused discord between the Israeli authorities and Jewish leaders abroad.

headline: The Rise of German Soccer
text: It was a memorable and historic week for German soccer to say the least. An all-German final now beckons after Bayern Munich and Borussia Dortmund’s emphatic victories against Barcelona and Real Madrid. Their success in Europe this season marks a significant turning point and is indicative of a larger trend, namely the rise of the Bundesliga and German soccer in general. Slowly but surely, the narrative is shaping up for Spain to hand over the torch to Germany as the game’s next great superpower.

headline: 2 Tibetans Die in Self-Immolations
text: BEIJING — Two Tibetans died on Wednesday after setting fire to themselves in a Tibetan region of western China to protest Chinese rule, according to reports on Thursday by Tibet advocacy groups and Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the American government. The two Tibetans, monks named Kunchok Woser and Lobsang Dawa, carried out their protest near their monastery in Dzoge County in Sichuan Province, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London. Radio Free Asia reported earlier that a third person, a 23-year-old woman, had set herself on fire in Dzamthang County of Sichuan, but then issued a new report saying that it could not confirm that episode. The news service said the two acts on Wednesday raised to 118 the number of Tibetans who have set themselves on fire since February 2009, when a young monk named Tapey did so in the town of Ngaba. Chinese security forces have flooded towns across the Tibetan plateau in an effort to stamp out the protests.

headline: Tip Sheet: Making the Final College Decision
text: Brennan Barnard is the director of college counseling at the Derryfield School in Manchester, N.H.

headline: ‘Hockey Night in Canada,’ in Punjabi
text: Bhola Chauhan and Harnarayan Singh, co-hosts of “Hockey Night in Canada,” discuss the significance of the Montreal Canadiens’ making it to the playoffs.

headline: Punjabi Broadcast: Toronto vs Montreal
text: A clip from an ice hockey game between the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Montreal Canadiens.

headline: Venture Threatens to Backfire in Virginia Governor’s Race
text: CLIFTON FORGE, Va. — When Terry McAuliffe appeared with his good friend Bill Clinton at the ribbon-cutting for Mr. McAuliffe’s electric car company in July 2012, the campaign-style event, complete with “Born in the U.S.A.” blaring, was meant to supply the top line of his résumé as he positioned himself to run for governor of Virginia.

headline: Decoded: Yahoo’s Push Into Digital Video
text: The Times’s Brian Stelter assesses Yahoo’s effort to capture more digital video advertising revenue.

headline: Chief of Unit Overseeing Britain’s Bailout Investments Resigns
text: LONDON – Jim O’Neil, who has been in charge of the British government’s stakes in Royal Bank of Scotland and the Lloyds Banking Group, resigned on Thursday to return to Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: White House Says It Believes Syria Has Used Chemical Arms
text: WASHINGTON — The White House said Thursday that it believes the Syrian government has used chemical weapons in its civil war, an assessment that could test President Obama’s repeated warnings that such an attack could precipitate American intervention in Syria.

headline: Presidents Are Viewed More Fondly in the Rear-View Mirror
text: The rise in approval ratings of former President George W. Bush has received some attention this week, in advance of the opening of his presidential library in Dallas. But that rise is exactly what one would expect, based on the history of other ex-presidents’ approval ratings.

headline: Award Nomination Lauds Marc Staal’s Season of Perseverance
text: Marc Staal, the Rangers defenseman who has battled several injuries, has been voted the team’s nominee for the Bill Masterton Memorial Trophy, awarded to the player who best exemplifies the qualities of perseverance, sportsmanship and dedication to hockey.

headline: George W. Bush in Hindsight
text: Today’s dedication of the George W. Bush Presidential Library coincides with a recent uptick in the public’s view of the 43rd president’s performance, which in turn has inspired a lot of discussion about whether Bush’s reputation could enjoy, or deserves to enjoy, a Harry Truman-style rehabilitation with historians and the public.

headline: Lionfish on the Menu
text: Frank Bruni, our colleague and former food critic, wrote the other day about making meals out of animals that are considered “the bullies of the ecosystem.” He was talking about eating feral hogs, tiger prawns, European green crabs, lionfish and other wildlife considered invasive species. “They aren’t evil in and of themselves,” he wrote. “They just don’t play so well with others.” One way to control their numbers is to eat them more often.

headline: Why Alibaba Could Be China’s Next $100 Billion I.P.O.
text: Could Alibaba be China’s next $100 billion stock market listing?

headline: God and Doctor
text: When he came to the hospital, he did not look well.

headline: Barbara Bush on Son Jeb in 2016: ‘We’ve Had Enough Bushes’
text: After having a husband and a son in the White House, Barbara Bush said she did not miss “one darn thing” about life there. And she does not want another reason to go back, even if it means depriving the country of the “best-qualified man.”

headline: The Gorilla and the Maginot Line
text: Janet Yellen likes metaphors. This is a common trait among central bankers, at least the ones who see value in trying to explain their work.

headline: Chuck Hagel’s Statement on Syria
text: As delivered by Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, on Thursday, April 25, 2013.

headline: Court Rules in Artist’s Favor
text: IN a closely watched copyright case with broad implications for the contemporary-art world, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on Thursday decided largely in favor of the artist Richard Prince, who was found by a federal court in 2011 to have illegally used photographs from a book about Rastafarians to create a series of collages and paintings.

headline: U.S. Sees No Conclusive Evidence of Chemical Arms Use by Syria
text: Editor’s Note: This article, which appeared in Thursday’s print editions of The Times, has been republished for archiving purposes. The latest article on Syria and chemical weapons can be found here.

headline: Is the Design a Little Blocky?
text: A smoke-breathing dragon made of about 400,000 Lego bricks is just one of the amenities at the Legoland Hotel (above) that opened this month in Carlsbad, Calif. The 250-room hotel, the first in the United States, is just steps from the Legoland theme park. It is designed with a shorter clientele in mind: its rooms, decorated according to themes like adventure, pirate and kingdom, feature bunk beds and a trundle bed with night lights, and its restaurant’s buffet is low enough for children to serve themselves.

headline: The Strange Pull of a Simple Love Story
text: “The Last Five Years” is a modest musical with a huge following. Jason Robert Brown’s two-person show follows the doomed marriage of Jamie, an arrogant Jewish novelist, and Cathy, an insecure gentile actress. The story of their troubled courtship is told chronologically — backward (hers) and forward (his). Their scenes intersect in the middle, when Jamie proposes to Cathy during a boat ride in Central Park. It’s an intimate, melancholy show that has confused and alienated some audience members and enchanted others since its 2001 premiere at the Northlight Theater in Skokie, Ill.

headline: White House Letter on Syria Sent to Congress
text: This letter, sent to Congressional leaders, takes the administration a step closer to acknowledging that President Bashar al-Assad has crossed a red line established by Mr. Obama last summer.

headline: Market Sweep | If the Shoe Fits
text: David Byrne’s musical marvel “Here Lies Love,” now extended through June 2 at New York’s Public Theater, celebrates the splendor of Imelda Marcos, the controversial former first lady of the Philippines who was famous for her lavish collection of extravagant footwear. The once-exiled lady of leisure’s theatrical triumph inspires a regal roundup of today’s ornate heels.

headline: Restaurants Vow to Stop Tossing Out So Much Food
text: The next time you bite into that pork bun at Momofuku or burrito at Chipotle, you can tell yourself that you are doing something for the environment.

headline: Iraqi Premier Urges Talks but Vows to Battle Insurgents
text: BAGHDAD — In the face of an armed rebellion by disgruntled Sunni Muslims against his Shiite-led government, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Thursday urged dialogue to calm tensions but vowed to continue military operations in a growing sectarian conflict that he warned could lead to a civil war like the one raging in Syria.

headline: Sorting Out a Reverse Trip on the Bases
text: Quirks of the Game is a regular feature on The Times’s sports blogs.

headline: Granta Editor Stepping Down
text: John Freeman, the American-born editor of the London-based literary quarterly Granta, has announced that he is departing the magazine, effective July 15. Mr. Freeman, 38, became Granta’s American editor in 2008 and assumed the top post in 2009. He most recently oversaw the publication of the decennial “Best of Young British Novelists” issue, with 20 writers 40 years of age or younger, which has become the magazine’s global calling card.

headline: What Millennials Need to Ask Their Parents
text: There’s no good time to find out you have a brain tumor, but I think my father has a solid claim on the worst luck ever in this regard.

headline: Even Monkeys Learn to Eat Local
text: A new study on groups of vervet monkeys suggests that social learning may have a greater influence on behavior development than previously thought.

headline: Video: Bloomberg and Kelly Speak on Boston Bombers
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly held a news conference, where they are discussed possible plans that the Boston Marathon bombing suspects may have had concerning New York City. Read the full article here.

headline: House Panel Set to Offer Several Immigration Bills
text: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee announced Thursday that it would introduce a series of bills beginning this week to overhaul the nation’s immigration system. The move was designed to keep the committee in the middle of the debate over the issue, which is now percolating on Capitol Hill, and to press a bipartisan group in the House that has been working in private on its own broad legislation.

headline: Monkeys Are Adept at Picking Up Social Cues, Research Shows
text: If you are eating lunch in Pittsburgh or Dallas, you might grab a sandwich and a Snapple to go. But should you get transferred to Paris, you will probably eat like the French: multicourse sit-down lunches plus a glass of wine.

headline: Image of the Day: April 25
text: The lawns surrounding the Taj Mahal in Agra, Uttar Pradesh, undergo beautification.
