text: HONG KONG — Deflation remains firmly entrenched in Japan, figures showed on Friday, despite optimistic forecasts from the country’s central bank, highlighting that there are no quick fixes for one of the world’s largest economies.

headline: Millionaires in a Legal Skirmish Over Child Support
text: MILLIONAIRES DUKE IT OUT OVER CHILD SUPPORT  |  The financier Warren G. Lichtenstein, head of the hedge fund Steel Partners, is accustomed to courtroom battles. But this one has a different flavor. Mr. Lichtenstein, who has a 5-year-old child with his former lover Annabelle Bond, a British socialite, is accusing Ms. Bond’s current boyfriend, Andrew Cader, a former Goldman Sachs executive and part-owner of the Tampa Bay Rays baseball team, of conspiring with her to hide her financial condition in order to secure more than $50,000 a month in child support payments, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports.

headline: Woody Guthrie Center Opening in Tulsa
text: This archive is your archive. The new Woody Guthrie Center in Tulsa, Okla., is having its grand opening on Saturday, in a homecoming for Guthrie, who was born in Oklahoma. The 12,000-square-foot research library and exhibition space houses Guthrie’s archives, which were bought from Guthrie’s family by the Tulsa-based George Kaiser Family Foundation. On display will be the handwritten version of “This Land Is Your Land,” as well as photographs, notebooks, letters and musical instruments.

headline: The Weight Those Heels Carry
text: LOS ANGELES — Kerry Washington starts with the shoes. To portray Olivia Pope, the tough crisis manager at the center of the hit ABC series “Scandal,” Ms. Washington is always in gravity-defying heels. How else to make that sexed-up power stalk down the White House corridors?

headline: Commerzbank Loses Appeal on Paying $68 Million in Banker Bonuses
text: LONDON – Commerzbank must pay a group of bankers a combined 52 million euros ($68 million) in bonuses after the German bank failed on Friday in its appeal to overturn a previous court ruling in London.

headline: Friday Reading: An Exercise Plan for Middle Age
text: An exercise plan for middle age, a new hotel for Lego lovers, a photo refocusing app for just $2 and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Return to South Ferry
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Lazard’s Profit Falls 17% in First Quarter
text: The fickleness of the mergers market can take its toll on deal makers, as Lazard reported on Friday.

headline: Federal Cuts Are Concern in Modest U.S. Growth
text: It’s not great, but it’s still probably the best growth the American economy is going to see for a while.

headline: When Movie Money Talks
text: BEIJING — On April 12, the famous commercial filmmaker Feng Xiaogang was honored as “director of the year’’ by the China Film Directors Guild. He has long been regarded as a safe bet by the authorities for his movies, many of which toe the party line.

headline: Grasping at Straw Men
text: OK, Reinhart and Rogoff have said their piece. I’d say that they’re still trying to have it both ways, on two fronts. They deny asserting that the debt-growth relationship is causal, but keep making statements that insinuate that it is. And they deny having been strong austerity advocates – but they were happy to bask in the celebrity that came with their adoption as austerian mascots, and never to my knowledge spoke out to condemn all the “eek! 90 percent!” rhetoric that was used to justify sharp austerity right now. Sorry, guys, but with so much at stake you have a responsibility not just to put stuff out but to make crystal clear what you think it implies for policy.

headline: Japan Approves Return to Air of Boeing 787
text: TOKYO — The Japanese and American authorities have lifted the final hurdles to the Boeing 787’s return to commercial flights, more than three months after the plane’s battery problems grounded the fleet.

headline: When a Reporter Is an Uninvited Guest
text: Journalism has a long and much debated history of articles reported either undercover or without complete representation — one came to light this month involving some BBC reporters and a trip to North Korea.

headline: Adolescence and Menopause: When Hormones Collide
text: Until recently, an unexpected time bomb sat in my house, waiting to explode. A modern Molotov cocktail, this volatile mix involved my grumpy, grunting adolescent son and me — his irritable, short-fused, menopausal mom.

headline: App Smart Extra: Dictionaries on the Go, Both Fancy and Simple
text: This week, my App Smart column was all about the delights of using dictionary apps on your smartphone or tablet. These apps can help you quickly look up a word’s meaning and usage or learn new words. Compared with a printed paper edition, dictionary apps on your mobile device can also let you share words you’ve found over social media or even quickly swap between looking up text in a dictionary or a thesaurus.

headline: A Cool But Splendid Spring in the Northeast
text: I had a rare moment to walk in the woods and breath the unusually cool spring air this morning and noted, thanks to my naturalist spouse, Lisa Mechaley, that the Canada mayflower (a.k.a. false lily of the valley) was bursting forth.

headline: Obesity Tied to Prostate Cancer Risk
text: A new study adds to evidence that obese men may have an increased risk for future prostate cancer.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Ledger-Enquirer: Twinkies: they’re not dead yet! — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Diabetes Advice for the Elderly: Relax
text: My mother has Type 2 diabetes, but she won’t eat. My father gets up and snacks in the middle of the night. My mom’s A1c is almost 8 percent. Why won’t she use her glucometer?

headline: Why the Rent Is So High in New York
text: In a magazine piece this week (and accompanying blog post), I talked about why many of the goods and services that high-income people consume are cheaper in New York — because it has such a large concentration of high-income people. I also mentioned that the big, glaring exception to this is housing, which is expensive for rich people as well as poor people.

headline: A Punjabi Broadcast Draws In New Hockey Fans
text: CALGARY, Alberta — Harnarayan Singh and Bhola Chauhan sat at a desk in the CBC’s studio here last month, watching the first period of a game between the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Winnipeg Jets on two televisions.

headline: Ask Well: Do We Need to Stretch?
text: Question:

headline: ‘Here Lies Love’ Adds Month to Public Theater Run
text: “Here Lies Love,” the new David Byrne-Fatboy Slim musical about Imelda Marcos, which opened on Tuesday at the Public Theater to some of the best reviews of the season, has added four weeks of performances through June 30, the theater announced on Friday. The run of the musical, directed by the Tony nominee Alex Timbers (“Peter and the Starcatcher”), had already been extended twice. The 90-minute production at the Public’s LuEsther Hall has quickly become a tight ticket, in part because the space – in which most audience members stand, move and occasionally dance during the show – holds only 160 people.

headline: Street-Level Change, a Name at a Time
text: BERLIN — When city authorities asked the Jewish Museum here to propose a name for the cobblestone square outside its new education center, museum officials promptly suggested Moses Mendelssohn.

headline: Boston Bombing Suspect Is Moved to Medical Detention Center
text: BOSTON — Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man charged with setting off explosives that killed three people and wounded more than 260 others at the Boston Marathon, has been moved from a hospital to a federal medical detention center as he continues to recover from injuries suffered during his effort to escape arrest in the days after the bombing, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: U.S. Suspects Chemical Weapons in Syria
text: A look at mounting pressure on the Obama administration after the White House said on Thursday that it believed the Syrian government had used chemical weapons.

headline: And Then There Were Ten
text: Rhode Island’s Senate — including all five Republican members — voted 26-12 on Wednesday in favor of legislation to allow same-sex couples to marry. Once Gov. Lincoln Chafee signs the bill, which is expected to happen next week, marriage equality will be the law in every New England state (Rhode Island plus Massachusetts, Connecticut, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Maine) — a meaningful victory for civil rights and a proud distinction for the region.

headline: Widening Inequality In Wages
text: Since 2000, real weekly wages of relatively low-paid workers have declined, while for those nearer the top of the ladder, they have risen.

headline: Common Core Practice | Reading The Times and Responding in Code
text: Our first prompt this week invites you to imagine you’re a movie executive looking for a hit film idea.

headline: Median Pay in U.S. Is Stagnant, but Low-Paid Workers Lose
text: THE median pay of American workers has stagnated in recent years, but that is not true for all workers. When adjusted for inflation, the wages of low-paid workers have declined. But the wages for better-paid workers have grown significantly more rapidly than inflation.

headline: Co-op Board Presidents Tell All
text: Intrigued by the dubious Zen of running a New York City co-op? You’d better be a fiscally prudent paragon of cooperation and as thick-skinned as a piece of Vuitton luggage, because the only entity New Yorkers seem to distrust and disparage more than co-op boards is the board president him or herself.

headline: Michael Shannon Cannot Understand Why He’s a Late-Night Reject
text: In “The Iceman,” you’re pretty scary as Richard Kuklinski, the contract killer who claimed to have killed more than 200 people. Ray Liotta and Robert Davi, who can be pretty scary too, are also in the film. Did you guys ever talk about being scary? Not really. Robert Davi talks a lot about his singing career. He was playing the Venetian, and he kept asking me if I was going to be in Vegas any time soon. Ray Liotta really didn’t say much, except every once in a while he would complain about something.

headline: Should I Report My Ex-Wife for Sleeping With Her Patient?
text: My ex-wife is a physician. We divorced when I found out she was having an affair with one of her H.I.V.-positive patients. I feel compelled to tell the state medical licensing board and the professional societies to which she belongs about her affair. My reasons for doing so are that I feel an intense urge to retaliate her breach of trust and that she potentially exposed me to H.I.V. (fortunately, I tested negative). I also know that, as a physician myself, I should report her to protect other patients, so that she may get increased supervision at her workplace and treatment if needed. Should I report her even though my main motivation is revenge? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Why Your Grandpa Is Cooler Than You
text: Most of us are aware that there are two types of old these days. There is baby-boomer old, an audacious, aspirational sort of old. Common depictions include couples sky-diving for their 40th anniversaries; Richard Branson doing all manner of macho rich-guy nonsense; and the woman of a certain age on a seashore holding a fluttering piece of voile toward the winds of freedom.

headline: The 4.14.13 Issue
text: Readers respond.

headline: The Unlikely Chef
text: My grandmother died when my mother was just 11 years old, and consequently my mother never learned how to cook particularly well. Certainly she had cousins and aunts who passed on bits of knowledge here and there, and she was taught to cook as part of her public education. Water, she could boil. Recipes, she could follow. But with a single father raising two young girls, my mother lost some skills along the way.

headline: His Life Was a Country Song
text: George Jones, the definitive country singer of the last half-century, whose songs about heartbreak and hard drinking echoed his own turbulent life, died on Friday in Nashville. He was 81.

headline: Smartphones Finally Surpass the Feature Phone
text: It’s finally time for the old-school clamshell cellphone to step aside and make way for the smartphone, which is now the most popular type of phone in the world.

headline: Quarterbacks Take a Hit in Round 1
text: If the three massive offensive tackles taken in the top four spots of Thursday night’s N.F.L. draft really wanted to display their quarterback-protecting skills, they should have gone back into the greenroom and blocked the television cameras from filming every heartbeat of Geno Smith’s angst-a-thon. Eric Fisher, Luke Joeckel and Lane Johnson should have teamed up midway through the round, when it became painfully clear that the N.F.L. was trying to go cold turkey on its quarterback addiction, leaving poor Smith writhing in a chair fighting an existential battle with his ego. Because by the time Buffalo stunned everyone by snagging Florida State’s E. J. Manuel as the only quarterback in the first round, even Smith’s biggest critics wanted to give him a hug.

headline: Starving the Beast
text: In the 1950s, government spending fell quickly after the Korean War ended. In the second quarter of 1956, the total government gross domestic product was $91.4 billion, at an annual rate. That was 0.4 percent lower than the $91.8 billion rate three years earlier, in the third quarter of 1953.

headline: The Gun Report: April 26, 2013
text: On April 8, in Toms River, N.J., a 4-year-old boy shot and killed his 6-year-old playmate “as their parents stood in the yard nearby,” the police later told CNN. We linked to this story in the Gun Report, and have been keeping an eye on it ever since. Two days later, Atlantic County Prosecutor James McClain announced that his office had taken over the investigation.

headline: Europe's Small Businesses Continue to Struggle
text: FRANKFURT — Smaller companies that provide most of the jobs in Europe face an ever more difficult struggle to win customers and get bank loans, according to a survey from the European Central Bank on Friday that contributed to a picture of spreading economic stagnation in the euro zone.

headline: Now Showing | Simone Shubuck
text: Though her filigree doodles of deceptively innocent-seeming flora and fauna were a fixture on the downtown gallery scene a decade ago, the artist Simone Shubuck has had only one solo show in the last six years — in 2009, at Corbett vs. Dempsey in Chicago. During that time, she married Adam Rapoport, the editor in chief of Bon Appetit magazine; became a mother; oversaw a protracted apartment renovation; and stepped away from her other career as a floral designer. Though she’s slowed her formerly frenetic output, she has continued to privately hone her technique, integrating abstract forms in pure, vibrant color. “My pace changed dramatically; I had to get to a new place in my life,” she says. “Having different identities brought me to a different place in my work.”

headline: For Altuzarra, a Ballet Debut
text: “It started in a really strange way,” said Joseph Altuzarra, recalling a day last summer on Fire Island when the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon invited him to design costumes for a new ballet that he was presenting at the New York City Ballet’s spring gala, on May 8. Although Mr. Altuzarra was friendly with the choreographer, he admitted that, out of courtesy, he had never asked too many questions and so didn’t fully know what Mr. Wheeldon did. “He said, ‘Oh, I’d love to do a ballet together,’ ” Mr. Altuzarra recalled, with a sheepish grin. “I was like, ‘Sure.’ ”

headline: Prize Winners Announced at Tribeca Film Festival
text: “The Rocket,” Kim Mordaunt’s feature about a 10-year-old Laotian boy who seeks refuge from his difficult life by participating in a rocket-building contest, won two top prizes at this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, claiming the festival’s Founders Award for best narrative feature and its best actor award for Sitthiphon Disamoe, who plays the film’s young protagonist.

headline: Estate Planning Remains a Moving Target Under the New Tax Law
text: WITH the federal tax on estates now kicking in at $5.25 million — or $10.5 million for a couple — it may seem that only the very wealthy need to worry about paying the tax. But that doesn’t mean that everyone else can forget about an estate plan.

headline: Image of the Day: April 26
text: A sports ground in Mumbai, Maharashtra, being watered as temperatures in the city soared.

headline: A Brooklyn Oasis
text: After an adventurous gut renovation that replicated its prim brick frontage but transformed its rear walls into a four-story curtain of glass and created a two-story-high internal wall composed entirely of plants, a former parking garage/office in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, has been reimagined as a single-family oasis and is about to enter the market at $8 million. And, yes, it offers the consummate amenity in this car-clogged, child-friendly borough: a one-car garage spacious enough to accommodate the owner’s S.U.V. and a battalion of scooters and bicycles.

headline: An $8 Million Cobble Hill Offering
text: Formerly a commercial building, the property has been reimagined as a single-family home after a nearly four-year gut renovation.

headline: See All Media News in One Place
text: Media Decoder’s regular features and other coverage can now be found on the Media & Advertising section front. This change in presentation will provide readers with a single destination for all important and timely media news.

headline: Netflix Looks Back on Its Near-Death Spiral
text: For Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, the worst part of the company’s 2011 self-inflicted Qwikster debacle, in which Netflix tried to both raise prices and spin off its DVD-by-mail business, wasn’t the parody by “Saturday Night Live,” the scathing media criticism or even the dizzying plunge in the company’s stock price from almost $299 in July 2011 to about $53 last September.

headline: Should Smaller Banks Really Have Less Capital Protection?
text: Richard E. Farley is a partner in the leveraged finance group of the law firm of Paul Hastings. He is writing a book titled “The Crisis Not Wasted – The Creation of Modern Financial Regulation During F.D.R.’s First Five Hundred Days.”

headline: Watchmakers Find Gold Rush in China Is Slowing Down
text: BASEL, SWITZERLAND — After opening hundreds of stores in China in recent years, some watch companies are facing an inventory glut and cutting back their retailing presence there.

headline: Space Camp — the Style, Not the Place
text: In “The Ghastly Love of Johnny X,” the extraterrestrial malcontent Johnny Xavier (Will Keenan) and his gang are banished to Earth until Johnny, holy terror and wielder of the “resurrection suit,” performs one selfless act. Amid vintage T-birds, soda fountains and cheesy special effects, “Ghastly Love” tries to work the same campy vibe as “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” but learns how hard that is to pull off. (Even “Shock Treatment,” the “Rocky Horror” follow-up, flopped.)

headline: Pope Francis Has a Few Words in Support of Leisure
text: On Tuesday, “Pope Francis: His Life in His Own Words,” a book of conversations with the man who was then Cardinal Jorge Bergoglio, will be published in English (Putnam; $24.95). These interviews from 2010 with two journalists in Argentina yield cute facts about the new boss of the church — a favorite movie? “Babette’s Feast” — but not much interesting theology.

headline: New Albums by Laura Mvula, Bassekou Kouyate and Savages
text: Jon Pareles, the chief pop critic for The Times, on the English singer and composer Laura Mvula; the Malian ngoni (West African lute) player Bassekou Kouyate; and Savages, an all-female London band of post-punk revivalists.

headline: Etching Boundaries, for Politics or God
text: Laura Mvula

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Tom Perrotta talks about the letters of Willa Cather; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Alexandra Starr discusses T. D. Allman’s “Finding Florida”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. John Williams is the host, filling in for Pamela Paul.

headline: George Jones, Country Legend, 1931-2013
text: Mr. Jones was the definitive country singer of the last half-century, and his songs about heartbreak and hard drinking echoed his own turbulent life.

headline: Shaking the Crowd in a Sicilian Town
text: We spotted her simultaneously. But it was my friend Jessie who bounded down the street after the young Sicilian woman whom we had just seen pull a golden arancino from a white paper bag.

headline: Perched on a Hilltop in Sicily
text: From arancini to a granita, seaside strolls to a nature preserve, you can find it in Taormina.

headline: G.O.P. Claims Victory as Bill to Curb Flight Delays Passes
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Congressional Democrats on Friday abandoned their once-firm stand that growing airport bottlenecks would be addressed only in a broader fix to across-the-board spending cuts, accepting bipartisan legislation that would bring the nation’s air traffic control system back up to full strength.

headline: Haute Hostels Put to the Test
text: With the wine tasting in the lobby bar approaching, I rinsed the green-tea shampoo from my hair, grabbed a towel from the queen bed and settled into a Philippe Starck chair, espresso in hand. A flat-screen TV flickered in the next room of my suite, but I was more captivated by the view that lay just beyond the glass doors of my balcony: the orange tile roofs of Lisbon, washed in the glow of a setting sun.

headline: You Call This a Hostel?
text: A wave of design hostels are flooding Europe. Take a look.

headline: A Bar Sprint in a Cocktail-Crazed City
text: As any boozehound worth his salt-rimmed glass will tell you, the City by the Bay is New York’s only real rival for American cocktail supremacy. Yet the last time I was in San Francisco was in 2006, which was also, coincidentally, the year I began covering the cocktail beat. And in the accelerated world of mixological invention, seven years might as well be a few generations. In February, I decided to head West to reacquaint myself. The trick: I had a lot of catching up to do, and only a few nights to do it in. A whirlwind bar crawl — sprint? — ensued. I encountered a cocktail scene that features distinct leanings (citrus, pisco, Chartreuse, mezcal), but like New York’s, one that is also impressively varied. Did I survive? You’ll have to read to the end.

headline: Creativity Flows Along a Rugged River in Zurich
text: Near the Sihl, a spirited mix of stores has popped up.

headline: Attack of the Curly Floor Mats: Subaru Issues Recall
text: Subaru says it will recall about 10,000 of its 2014 Foresters over defective floor mats, and a supplier of charging stations for electric vehicles announced a recall of some charging units that could overheat, according to reports posted recently on Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: The Motherlode Blogroll: Freshly Linked but Never Final
text: Weeks ago, I set out to update the Motherlode blogroll. I want to read blogs, I said — the kind of blogs I used to read, funny and honest and compelling.

headline: This Week’s Movies: ‘Pain & Gain,’ ‘Mud’ and ‘The Reluctant Fundamentalist’
text: In this week’s video, Times critics offer their thoughts on “Pain & Gain,” “Mud” and “The Reluctant Fundamentalist.” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: Hospital Wing Collapses in India
text: NEW DELHI — A wing of a public hospital in Bhopal, India, collapsed on Friday afternoon, seriously injuring at least four people and leaving more than a dozen trapped, according to Indian authorities.

headline: Inside the List
text: IRIS SHRUGGED: Iris Johansen’s new suspense novel, “Taking Eve,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 5. The book features her longtime heroine Eve Duncan, a forensic sculptor with a tragic past, and is the first in a trilogy scheduled for publication this year. “Writing a trilogy is always a difficult challenge,” Johansen told me via e-mail, “because I use an entire ensemble of characters that are familiar to fans but must be introduced to new readers.”

headline: Should Gun Restrictions Be Placed on Veterans With PTSD?
text: When Phillip Barker received the official report from the Department of Veterans Affairs in 2008, it said he suffered from homicidal ideations of a passive-aggressive nature. It also said that he had an alcohol dependency. That he experiences anxiety, sleeplessness, hypervigilance and nervous tics as part of his post-traumatic stress disorder, diagnosed in 2007 after his honorable discharge from the Marine Corps. And that he has flashbacks from his deployment to Falluja, Iraq, in 2004.

headline: George Jones, Country Singer
text: When you think of George Jones, you might think of country songs about heartache and regret. We think of his hit “White Lightning,” which was all about him and his pappy making moonshine and trying to outsmart revenoors looking for them. Mr. Jones died Friday after a career that spanned more than 50 years. Our colleague Jon Pareles writes that Mr. Jones was “universally respected and just as widely imitated,” and that his songs held “the echoes of a life in which success and excess battled for decades.” Here’s Mr. Jones on YouTube singing “White Lightning,” a No. 1 country hit in 1959.

headline: A Borough Seeks the Spotlight
text: The 19th-century buildings at the former lighthouse service depot on the North Shore of Staten Island are in such a state of decay that tree branches reach out of the dormer windows. But the city hopes this abandoned site, which dates to the French and Indian War, will soon re-emerge as a bustling urban center with shops, restaurants, a hotel and housing.

headline: Nomura’s Profit Gains Closely Tied to Japan’s Economic Success
text: Nomura has spent most of the last five years trying to break out of Japan. So it’s ironic that the investment bank’s best full-year results since 2007 were propelled by a revival at home. As with Japan’s economic renaissance, however, investors’ hopes are running ahead of reality.

headline: Paperback Row
text: A DISPOSITION TO BE RICH: Ferdinand Ward, the Greatest Swindler of the Gilded Age,  by Geoffrey C. Ward. (Vintage, $16.) In 1880, Ferdinand Ward persuaded Ulysses S. Grant to become a partner in a brokerage house that reported astonishing profits but was really a vast Ponzi scheme. (It blew up in 1884, causing panic on Wall Street and bankrupting Grant.) Geoffrey C. Ward scrupulously documents his great-grandfather’s rise to riches and fame, and his even more dizzying fall from grace.

headline: So Many Missions, All Tied to Music
text: “It’s your solo, take it away,” said the violist David Aaron Carpenter to the vibraphonist David Stevens during a recent rehearsal at a synagogue on Central Park West. Mr. Carpenter was directing the Salomé Chamber Orchestra in Lera Auerbach’s alluring “Sogno di Stabat Mater,” for violin, viola, vibraphone and orchestra, in preparation for a concert at the Metropolitan Museum.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Detroit, Vienna, Las Vegas
text: Movement Electronic, Music Festival, Detroit The city that the journalist Charlie LeDuff recently noted has fallen on such hard times that its dead are being moved to more desirable locations still maintains its status as an incubator of electronic music. Its signature event, the Movement Electronic Music Festival, May 25 to 27, features heavy hitters like John Digweed and Squarepusher (right) and an audience no doubt full of young bohemians.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Willa Cather’s Letters
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Tom Perrotta reviews “The Selected Letters of Willa Cather,” a look at correspondence that the great American writer wanted to keep private. Mr. Perrotta writes:

headline: The Loner Enjoys Company
text: PARIS — “I am fascinated by these dancers,” the performance artist Marina Abramovic whispered this month, sitting at the front of a huge, light-filled rehearsal studio at the top of the Bastille opera house. Before her, nine Paris Opera Ballet members moved dreamily around the room in an improvisation as the inexorable strains of Ravel’s “Bolero” resounded.

headline: Disgracing ‘the Quintessential System of Justice’
text: The state of Georgia may soon execute Warren Lee Hill, Jr., an intellectually disabled man with an I.Q of 70. Under a 2002 Supreme Court ruling it is unconstitutional to execute him or anyone in that category — but the Constitution, in this case, may not win out.

headline: The Sounds of a Mystery
text: PALO ALTO, CALIF. — The performance space of the Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics at Stanford University was filled to capacity on a recent Saturday morning, the blinds drawn against the optimistic California sunshine. Sets of loudspeakers positioned on either side of the room emitted a repetitive pattern of phonemes that were so short as to resemble brief electronic bleeps. After a few seconds, a voice with zero inflection but crisp diction seemed to emerge out of the bleeps, barking at me, “Wake up — wake up — wake up — wake up,” over and over, steady as a metronome. Then it changed tack: “Window — window — where’s the window — where’s the rainbow — where’s the rainbow.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE THIRD COAST: When Chicago Built the American Dream,  by Thomas Dyja. (Penguin Press, $29.95.) This robust cultural history weaves together the stories of the artists, styles and ideas that developed in Chicago before and after World War II.

headline: Nice Poem; I’ll Take It
text: If you read British newspapers, you might have heard of Christian Ward. In 2011, Ward won the Exmoor Society’s Hope Bourne prize for his poem “The Deer at Exmoor,” only to have his work revealed as a copy of “The Deer,” by Helen Mort, which won the Café Writers Open Poetry Competition in England in 2009. Ward defended himself by saying, “I had no intention of deliberately plagiarizing,” and suggested he had used Mort’s work as a model and had submitted a premature draft.

headline: Up Front
text: The novelist Tom Perrotta, who reviews Willa Cather’s letters this week, said in a recent e-mail that for all of Cather’s renown, he still considers her “one of the truly underrated” American writers. “She’s trapped in a regionalist pigeonhole,” he said. “She’s the bard of the prairie, Laura Ingalls Wilder for college kids, and doesn’t get the credit she deserves as a stylist and storyteller.”

headline: A Changed Man
text: It’s been almost 35 years since the publication of James Salter’s previous novel, “Solo Faces.” In the meantime, he’s written two volumes of stories and one of poetry, a memoir, a collection of travel essays and, with his wife, Kay Eldredge Salter, a book about food. He has not been idle. Still, any or all of those books, excellent as they are, might suggest a career in twilight, with grand gestures and major lifts all in the rearview mirror. And why not? Salter is 87, with a reputation so secure he has nothing left to prove. If there were a Mount Rushmore for writers, he’d be there already. He could have published nothing, and no one would have thought less of him.

headline: A Wrinkle in the Workplace
text: LONDON — There was a time not long ago when the image of pajamas evoked ideas like innovation, creativity, even freedom. Unshackled from the grind of the everyday workplace, employees or entrepreneurs could use a loose-fitting approach to unleash productivity.

headline: Sibling Rivals
text: Stories of marital relations — strained, destroyed or restored — surely take up a larger section of our fiction shelves than stories of brothers and sisters. Yet why should that be, given the deep imprint siblings can make? Staying intimate with one’s spouse is a challenge, certainly, but the problems posed by a difficult brother or sister can be just as painful.

headline: In the Heights
text: George Mallory, like Robert Falcon Scott, has departed the ranks of mere humanity and entered British consciousness as a Galahad of the snows, a titan who showed what a chap can do if he’s made of the right stuff. It’s fertile material for fictional recasting, and in her first novel Tanis Rideout adds a twist to the tale while making it entirely her own.

headline: Subject to Revision
text: “After the first death, there is no other,” Dylan Thomas wrote. How obvious, one might think. But the one-time-only nature of death is anything but self-evident in Kate Atkinson’s new novel, “Life After Life.”

headline: Revolutions Per Minute
text: In “The Flamethrowers,” her frequently dazzling second novel, Rachel Kushner thrusts us into the white-hot center of the 1970s conceptual art world, motorcycle racing, upper-class Italy and the rampant kidnappings and terrorism that plagued it. It’s an irresistible, high-octane mix — and a departure from the steamier pleasures of her critically acclaimed first novel, “Telex From Cuba.” The language is equally gorgeous, however, and Kushner’s insights into place, society and the complicated rules of belonging, and unbelonging, can be mordantly brilliant. None of the characters in “The Flamethrowers” are quite what they seem, fabricating pasts as nonchalantly as they throw together their art. Above all, they hunger to be seen, to distinguish themselves from the ordinary. One artist, responding to the question of why he invents, defends his florid lies as “a form of discretion.”

headline: Shadowlands
text: “When thinking about the fall of any dictatorship, one should have no illusions that the whole system comes to an end like a bad dream,” Ryszard Kapuscinski wrote 30 years ago. A Polish journalist, Kapuscinski was ostensibly reporting on the fall of the shah of Iran, but his devoted Polish readers knew that everything he said applied to their part of the world as well. “A dictatorship . . . leaves behind itself an empty, sour field on which the tree of thought won’t grow quickly. It is not always the best people who emerge from hiding.”

headline: Absence (40 Years’ Worth) Makes 2 Hearts Grow Fonder
text: João Crisóstomo, a butler to members of New York society, long ago mastered the art of decorum and the stiff upper lip. Yet in his private life he is as ebullient as they come, turning strangers into friends with a quicksilver smile and an ardent embrace. The result is a Christmas greetings list that has grown exponentially, even though instead of sending cards, he calls on the telephone.

headline: Out of the Oven . . .
text: On the second page of “Cooked,” his paean to home cooking, Michael Pollan makes a statement that may baffle his many fans (I am one). “I seldom made time for cooking or gave it much consideration,” he confesses. Later on, he tells us that before he wrote this book his regular method of preparing a meal was to “throw expensive fillets” of meat on the grill.

headline: Many Selves
text: A group of students at Cornell, born in Asia but raised in the United States by immigrant parents, were instructed to keep a diary. They struggled to recall the events of their own daily lives when they were later quizzed about them, remembering fewer details about their experiences than their Euro-American counterparts. Qi Wang, the Cornell scholar of “cross-cultural” cognition who conducted the experiment, speculated that Asians were not more forgetful but that they had, perhaps, filtered out the contents of their own stories, deeming them unworthy of being encoded as memories in the first place.

headline: . . . And Down the Gullet
text: An Italian saliva expert named Erika Silletti recently addressed a dental conference. History doesn’t record which aspects of saliva she extolled from the stage that day. Perhaps she described how art conservators are so enamored with its cleaning power they use it to dab fragile artworks. (Dishwashing detergent is a kind of simulated saliva, digesting the food you couldn’t stomach.) Or maybe she praised the people of Greece — who spit on everything as a sign of good luck — for their saliva-positive attitudes. What we do know is that her speech was a bit of a disaster. The assembled dentists regarded her blankly. She returned to her hotel room and burst into tears. “They think of it as lubricating, and that’s it!” she complained to her boyfriend.

headline: High Trees, Tall Poppies, Egalitarian Winds
text: It’s been nearly two years now that I’ve gone without quoting David Winner’s “Brilliant Orange: The Neurotic Genius of Dutch Soccer” in this space. I’m going to fix that now. Not on account of this week’s performances by two voetbal stars, Robin van Persie and Arjen Robben — but did you see those performances?! — but because an article in this weekend’s magazine includes a reference to “a Dutch proverb about high trees catching a lot of wind.” It’s the first defense Diederik Stapel, a prominent social psychologist in the Netherlands, employs to counter accusations of academic fraud. People envy a standout.

headline: Despot of Dogpatch
text: The cartoonist Al Capp, John Steinbeck wrote in 1952, “may very possibly be the best writer in the world today.” As Michael Schumacher and Denis Kitchen document in “Al Capp: A Life to the Contrary,” he could also be one of the most contentious. Capp (1909-79), whose comic strip “Li’l Abner” ran for 43 years and reached 90 million readers at its peak, was a celebrity: a radio personality, magazine essayist, talk-show regular and college speaker. Among his strip’s contributions to the cultural landscape were the expression “double whammy” and the invention of Sadie Hawkins Day, a mock holiday (and national craze in its time) that inspired Sadie Hawkins dances, to which women could invite men. Underlying Capp’s antic humor and prodigious productivity, however, was a toxic chip on his shoulder.

headline: Contested State
text: Anyone who has commuted to a Fort Lauderdale beach will be familiar with the journey T. D. Allman describes in “Finding Florida: The True History of the Sunshine State.”Because drawbridges that lead to the ocean’s edge are raised to allow large boats up the inland waterways, highway passengers are almost invariably subjected to long waits. This imposition — and the fact that the people behind steering wheels don’t protest — drives Allman to distraction. “Not one person demands to know: Why is it that the people with boats take precedence over us?” he writes.

headline: Transgenred
text: I’m going to go out on a limb here and tell you something I probably shouldn’t. Many of the stories in Kit Reed’s new collection were first published in science- fiction magazines. Are you still there? I know this kind of thing makes some “literary” readers itchy, so if you need to take a break and go read some Henry James, it’s O.K. But you don’t have to be afraid. There are no ray guns or Martians in “The Story Until Now.” (Not that there’s anything wrong with ray guns or Martians.) This isn’t “that kind” of science fiction.

headline: Fashion Fit for Executives, as Well as for Gatsby
text: When “The Great Gatsby” opens in United States movie theaters on May 10 and starts the Cannes Film Festival five days later, it could help revive some fashionable looks from the Roaring Twenties.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Following Breaking News
text: During momentous events like the Boston Marathon bombings, how do you get your news? David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss their media diet.

headline: In Speech to Planned Parenthood, Obama Criticizes New Abortion Laws
text: President Obama waded back into the nation’s volatile culture wars on Friday as he assailed conservatives who have sought to restrict access to abortion and contraception, and promised women’s activists he would stand with them “fighting every step of the way.”

headline: The Tale of the Tsarnaev Brothers’ Carjacking Victim
text: In an interview published in The Boston Globe, a 26-year-old Chinese man describes his harrowing 90 minutes with the Tsarnaev brothers after they commandeered his car on the night they were trying to flee the police.

headline: Popcast: New Albums by Laura Mvula, Bassekou Kouyate and Savages
text: This week, Jon Pareles, the chief pop critic for The Times, discusses albums he’s written about in this Sunday’s Playlist column,  including new recordings by these artists:

headline: A Filmmaker’s Rebellious Teenagers, Take 1
text: Hitchcock and “The Man Who Knew Too Much,” DeMille and “The Ten Commandments”: filmmakers sometimes take a second run at their own material. For the French director Olivier Assayas, “Something in the Air,” which opens in New York next Friday, is a double look back, revisiting his 1994 film “Cold Water” and, like that earlier film, incorporating elements of his own early 1970s adolescence.

headline: How Much Does Defense Matter in the N.B.A. Playoffs?
text: Defense wins championships, so they say. It’s such a cliche adage that it’s not really clear what sport it originally referred to. But when a sports commentator (or 40) uses that phrase to refer to the N.B.A., are they being accurate?

headline: Pint Sized | Edgy Duds for Kids
text: Sometimes the most buzz-worthy and best dressed on the red carpet are the miniature offspring of fashion-forward moms and dads (Suri Cruise, Harper Beckham) sporting the same labels as their parents are. Today Colleen and Roberto Crivello, the husband-and-wife partners behind the New York-based creative brand consultancy FDS Design Studio, are turning the tables with the debut of their edgy collection of kids’ wear that they’re touting as “Clothes for Kids That Moms Want Too.” Chalk NYC, the line made for and inspired by their two-and-a-half-year-old daughter, Alba, is for the discerning 2-10-year-olds who prefer their pants in stretch leather and their tees in Pima cotton.

headline: Ramp, Meet Egg
text: The spring ramp makes for a garlicky, delicious accompaniment to eggs.

headline: In the Ramp Debate, He’s a ‘Yea’
text: One camp of cooks really knows its ramps and is crazy about them. Another camp couldn’t care less, doesn’t know what all the fuss is about, thinks they represent a trend that is out of control, or just plain doesn’t like them.

headline: N.F.L. Draft-Day Fashion
text: Fashionable looks from Day 1 of the draft at Radio City Music Hall.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Gulf in Sales Numbers
text: There were not a lot of positives to take away from an analysis of the March 2013 sales numbers for DC Comics by Marc-Oliver Frisch over at The Beat, the news blog of comics culture: “Estimated sales of the average new DC Universe comic book fell to 31,000, the lowest since the big ‘New 52’ relaunch of September 2011.”

headline: Benazir Bhutto, 1953-2007
text: Photos from the life of the assassinated former prime minister.

headline: Why Do I Have Gout?
text: If one night you wake with the feeling that a big toe has suddenly become a battlefield, and a peek under the covers reveals not This Little Piggy but an angry red monstrosity from some old horror movie, your first thought may be to seek help. You need an M.D., you’ll think. Maybe a CT scan or even an M.R.I.

headline: Musharraf Under Arrest on Charges in Bhutto Assassination
text: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan — An antiterrorism court here placed Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s former military leader, under arrest on Friday on charges related to the death of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, adding to a tangle of legal woes that have hobbled Mr. Musharraf’s hopes for a political comeback.

headline: Wheelies: The F1 Golf Cart Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Pastas of Spring
text: To make a quick meal with spring vegetables, try one of these new pasta dishes from Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman. She writes:

headline: Exception to Miranda Rule Is Rooted in Queens Arrest
text: No straight line connects Benjamin Quarles and Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev, or stretches from Bayside, Queens, to Copley Square in Boston, or links a largely forgotten gun charge in 1980 to a terrorist bombing this month that inflicted mass casualties and left three people dead.

headline: Times Square, 8:32 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had breakfast with Emily Rafferty, the president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in a diner on Friday.

headline: April 28 — May 4
text: Nightmares, Recalled

headline: From Red Zone to Red Carpet
text: This is how football hooks you. You start the day uninitiated and feeling about the National Football League draft roughly the degree of enthusiasm you might if offered a chance to spend a quiet evening catching up on back issues of Cigar Aficionado.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Where Were You When …
text: During momentous events like the Boston Marathon bombings, how do you get your news? In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss their media diet.

headline: Focused on Scoring Threats, Bulls Play Nets 5 on 3
text: Propelled by Deron Williams’s dribble penetration and Brook Lopez’s touch inside, the Nets’ scoring flowed steadily in their Game 1 blowout of the Chicago Bulls. But since that game’s final buzzer, the Nets’ offense has been reduced to a trickle. The Bulls have constricted Brooklyn’s options and diverted the action to its least potent offensive players.

headline: Rejuvenation, Reflected on the Screen
text: Choices about the costumes and sets of Susanne Bier’s new film, “Love Is All You Need,” do much to reflect the character and her outlook on life.

headline: Homeowners in Flood Zones Opt to Rebuild, Not Move
text: A proposal to buy the damaged homes of New Yorkers who want to relocate after Hurricane Sandy is finding few takers, as most residents opt to rebuild, state officials said on Friday.

headline: City’s Highest Subway Station Reopens
text: The least “sub” station in the city subway system, Smith-Ninth Street in Brooklyn, which soars more than 80 feet above the scrapyards of Gowanus, surged back to life again Friday morning after a $32 million face-lift that left it shuttered for nearly two years.

headline: Move to Close Long Island College Hospital Is Halted
text: A plan to close Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn is being withdrawn, state officials said on Friday, in a startling victory for doctors, unions and community members who said the closing of the hospital would compromise health care for residents in the area.

headline: From an Office Romance to Home Cooking
text: Booming’s Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Galleon Group Co-Founder Surfaces on Horseback
text: It is a question asked by nearly everyone who has followed the insider trading investigation of the Galleon Group hedge fund: what ever happened to Gary Rosenbach?

headline: Weekend Fare
text: With its assortment of artisanal food vendors, craft makers and more, the Hester Street Fair, at the corner of Hester and Essex Streets on the Lower East Side, returns on Saturday for the season. The market is open from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Saturdays through Oct. 26.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Mud’
text: In Jeff Nichols’s latest film “Mud,” Matthew McConaughey plays the title character as a man who is always on the move. The character is discovered hiding out on an island in the Mississippi River by two Arkansas boys (Tye Sheridan and Jacob Lofland). To capture a constantly moving character, Mr. Nichols and his crew used a Steadicam camera to create sense of fluidity. In this video, Mr. Nichols narrates a scene where the boys bring food to Mud on the island. He discusses his camera choices and how they supplement his narrative.

headline: ‘Technical’ Problem Resolved, ‘Django’ to Open in China in May
text: LOS ANGELES — After being pulled from theaters this month over what Chinese officials described as a “technical” problem, Quentin Tarantino’s “Django Unchained” will return to movie screens in China on May 12.

headline: ‘Matilda’ Quartet Ruled Ineligible for Best Actress Tony
text: The four child actresses who rotate in the title role of the Broadway musical “Matilda” will not be eligible for a joint Tony Award nomination for best actress in a musical this spring, the Tony administrative committee ruled on Friday. The decision, the most newsworthy result of a busy committee meeting, sets aside a controversial precedent from 2009 when the three teenage boys sharing the lead role in “Billy Elliot” were deemed eligible for a joint best actor nomination — and went on to win that June.

headline: ‘Open’ Season in High Tech
text: Things must be getting really competitive in high technology. So many big competitive companies are striving to show how good they are at sharing.

headline: Obama Not Rushing to Act on Signs Syria Used Chemical Arms
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that he would respond “prudently” and “deliberately” to evidence that Syria had used chemical weapons, tamping down any expectations that he would take swift action after an American intelligence assessment that the Syrian government had used the chemical agent sarin on a small scale in the nation’s civil war.

headline: A Roll-Up-His-Sleeves Buyer
text: Stephen Sullivan was eager to buy a place that he could renovate himself.

headline: Obama Chooses Economist for Chief Regulatory Post
text: President Obama has nominated Howard Shelanski, the top economist at the Federal Trade Commission, to direct the White House office overseeing all federal regulations.

headline: The Dark Side of Innocence
text: Critics have a tendency to condescend to physical comedy, to brush off those masters of the sight gag and the pratfall, from Chaplin to Jim Carrey, by cooing over their “innocence,” their “joyfulness,” their “simplicity,” as if they were talking about slightly slow but adorable children.

headline: Chevrolet Announces 2014 Corvette Stingray Price
text: Corvette enthusiasts, the moment you’ve all been waiting for has finally arrived. Friday, Chevrolet announced the starting price for the 2014 Corvette Stingray: $51,995 for the coupe and $56,995 for the convertible. Of course, the other moment you’ve all been waiting for – when the Stingray shows up at dealerships – hasn’t been officially announced, though General Motors says to expect it in late 2013.

headline: A Sustainable Soap Box Racer
text: Teenagers from all over New York City will demonstrate soap-box derby cars they made from recycled materials at a “Street Games” festival in an East Harlem park on Saturday.

headline: Week in Pictures for April 26
text: Subjects include boxing’s return to Brooklyn, a pop-up poetry jam in the subway and life inside a castle in Amsterdam, N.Y.

headline: Wounded by Missing the Playoffs, the Devils Refuse to Blame Injuries
text: NEWARK — Martin Brodeur said he believed that the Devils, who missed the playoffs one year after their stunning run to the Stanley Cup finals, fell victim to the lockout-shortened, 48-game schedule.

headline: The Boston Bombing and Immigration
text: In the days since the Boston marathon attack, a number of Republican lawmakers have demanded a delay in immigration reform because the two bombers were fairly recent immigrants.

headline: Big Ticket | 25 Columbus Circle, Sold for $13 Million
text: Perched high in the south tower of the Time Warner Center at 25 Columbus Circle, a glassy corner condominium with unobstructed northern and eastern views of Central Park and the cityscape from every room sold for $13 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: The Largest Falcon Hospital in the World
text: It’s in Abu Dhabi, and it has operating rooms, an intensive-care unit and an ophthalmology department.

headline: It’s Vacation: Let’s Go on a Killing Spree!
text: It’s a hazard of just about any cross-country trip: irresponsible travelers who mar a beautiful view with litter or are insufferably loud or disrespect the rules of the road. It’s not the end of the world, but it can certainly put you off your tea.

headline: An Estate Plan for the Not-So-Wealthy
text: The high threshold for the estate tax — $5.25 million, or $10.5 million for a couple — makes it unlikely that most people will have to worry about the tax, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week. But that doesn’t mean that most people can forget about an estate plan, he says.

headline: Why ‘Community’s’ Low Ratings Don’t Necessarily Mean Cancellation
text: Could NBC’s “Community” be saved from cancellation once again?

headline: A Heavy Lift Onto the Screen
text: When Henry James’s novel “What Maisie Knew” was published in 1897, the movies were in their infancy — the brothers Lumière had exhibited their first motion pictures just two years earlier — and there’s no evidence that in the 19 years of life that remained to James he ever cared a jot for the new medium; it wouldn’t have met his standards. The movies have since avenged that slight in a way that seems at least arguably Jamesian: They have paid his work the ambiguous tribute of their attention. Dozens of adaptations of his difficult, delicate fictions have been produced since his death, all trying (and most failing) to capture something of his essence, the elusive beast in the verbal jungle.

headline: An Uncertain Lure for Samsung’s Digital Store
text: With the release of Samsung’s Galaxy S4 smartphone this weekend, the company will open a digital store that offers music, video, games and books.

headline: All the Dreaminess of Reality
text: MEXICO CITY — The foremost enfant terrible of Mexican cinema, Carlos Reygadas knows how to get a reaction. Whether serving up bloodshed and deeply unerotic sex in transgressive melodramas like “Japón” (2002) and “Battle in Heaven” (2005) or contemplating the enigmas of faith and love in the Mennonite adultery drama “Silent Light” (2007), his films are invariably primed to stir debate: the shock of the new or the emperor’s new clothes?

headline: Rebuilding, With an Eye on the Rafters
text: DETROIT — The end of the N.H.L. regular season is usually more break time than crunchtime for the Detroit Red Wings.

headline: Family, ‘Not Willing to Forget,’ Pursues Art It Lost to Nazis
text: Lt. Alexandre Rosenberg of the Free French forces pounded on the boxcars. Hold your fire, he told his men. There might be prisoners inside the train they had stopped outside Paris in August 1944. Slowly, a few of the heavy doors slid open, and a handful of worn German soldiers straggled out.

headline: Jack McInerney: The New New Thing in M.L.S.
text: The M.L.S season is still young but through the first seven weeks, no player is playing as well as Philadelphia Union forward Jack McInerney.

headline: Divorce Whisperer? Mediating With Parents Isn’t Easy
text: For some couples, deciding where to seat narcoleptic Uncle Reginald is the least of their wedding planning worries. Those with divorced parents are assured of having quite a few more hours of anxiety as they engage in additional negotiations with them.

headline: The Brain: Our Food-Traffic Controller
text: IMAGINE that, instead of this article, you were staring at a plate of freshly baked chocolate chip cookies. The mere sight and smell of them would likely make your mouth water. The first bite would be enough to wake up brain areas that control reward, pleasure and emotion — and perhaps trigger memories of when you tasted cookies like these as a child.

headline: Celtic Greens in Boston: A Guidebook in One Color
text: BOSTON — He holds the record for most games in a Boston Celtics uniform, for a player with the surname Green.

headline: Financial Opposites in a Life Together
text: Jennifer and Scott Bartone were married in October after a seven-year courtship. But they did not have a serious conversation about money until this week.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘Battleship’
text: Is there life after college? If the only horse race you watch is the Kentucky Derby, you might not think so.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom colonial in Harrington Park, N.J., and a five-bedroom stone and cedar contemporary on Long Island.

headline: Week in Review: High-Value Domestic Dispute
text: Millionaires clash over socialite’s child support claims. | Businesses take a wary approach to disclosures using social media. | Market delay in Chicago points again to technology. | Down payment rules are at heart of mortgage debate. | Hazy future for S.E.C.’s thriving whistle-blower effort. | Regulators to restrict payday lending. | Fed still owes Congress a blueprint on its emergency lending. | Co-directors for S.E.C. signal shift. | And Andrew Ross Sorkin says that in a tax fight, Amazon handed the baton to eBay.

headline: He’s a Mess, and That Makes It Funny
text: You never forget your first time, but the way you recall it changes.

headline: Cooking Squid at Home
text: Do you love ordering calamari in restaurants? Melissa Clark shows that it’s just as easy to prepare squid in your own kitchen.

headline: Searing Squid Is a Slippery Task
text: Squid is easy to cook but hard to sear. It releases so much moisture when it hits the pan that it tends to steam rather than brown. And since it cooks so quickly (two to three minutes will do it), it is usually done before much of the liquid evaporates.

headline: Their Rules, So They’ll Break Them
text: Fitz and the Tantrums, the kinetic Los Angeles sextet led by Michael Fitzpatrick, emerged in 2009 and was almost immediately lumped into a neo-soul scene with acts like Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bangladesh, Kashmir, Iraq and China.

headline: Grant’s Life
text: Charles Traub embarks on a photographic journey to capture the places made great by Ulysses S. Grant’s indomitable spirit.

headline: Fan of Marriage Makes a Commitment
text: Tracy McMillan is no stranger to drama. Until her reality-series debut on “Ready for Love,” the new NBC dating show, she was a television writer whose credits included critically lauded series like “Mad Men” and the “United States of Tara.” But perhaps the most compelling narrative she can take credit for her is her own life.

headline: Back From the Abyss
text: Few companies’ stocks have recovered from the kind of plunge Netflix experienced in 2011 after it tried to raise prices and spin off its DVD business. But this year it’s the best-performing stock in the S.& P. 500.

headline: Netflix Bounces Back
text: “House of Cards” was part of Netflix’s effort to overcome a bungled attempt to adapt to the digital landscape. James B. Stewart, a columnist for The New York Times, discusses the company’s turnaround.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Clinton co-op with two-bedrooms, an Upper West Side apartment with beamed ceilings and a Greenpoint condo with an office and playroom.

headline: An Appraisal: George Jones in Real Life and Real Time
text: Early in 1977, a couple of years after he and Tammy Wynette had divorced, the country music star George Jones played a show at the Stardust Inn in Waldorf, Md., his first in the Washington area in several years. I was then a young pop music critic at The Washington Post, so it fell to me to write a profile of the notoriously hard-drinking singer.

headline: Squid, or Scallops
text: The video above is a lesson in searing squid, a companion to the recipe in this week’s column: sauteed squid with chiles, mint and lime.

headline: Dutch Man Said to Be Held in Powerful Internet Attack
text: Dutch authorities say police officials in Spain have arrested a man believed to be connected to an online attack on a spam-fighting site that snarled the Internet last month.

headline: 11 Years Later, Debris From Plane Is Found Near Ground Zero
text: It was wedged in a narrow, inaccessible space between two buildings, about three blocks from the World Trade Center site. And there it remained, hidden from view, for more than 11 years. Ground zero slowly gave way to a new tower. Protesters gathered nearby, angry over a planned Islamic center.

headline: Goodbye, George Jones
text: To honor George Jones, who died today in Nashville, age 81, here is an unusual video. It is a real-life, pulled-from-the-headlines, celebrity-dysfunction, drunken-arrest, legal-mess, career-lowlight reel – that also happens to be a sweet, sweet duet with Dolly Parton:

headline: Sweet Deals as Strawberries Glut Market
text: Good news for berry lovers is not so good news for berry farmers.

headline: In Promoting His City for 2020 Games, Tokyo’s Bid Chairman Tweaks Others
text: With less than five months to go before the International Olympic Committee chooses a city to host the 2020 Summer Games, the three remaining bidders — Istanbul, Madrid and Tokyo — are increasing their efforts to win over delegates and the public.

headline: Man Sentenced in Plan to Bomb Manhattan Synagogue
text: The man who prosecutors said was the lesser participant in a foiled 2011 plot to blow up the largest synagogue in Manhattan in order to kill Jews and spread fear around the world was sentenced on Friday to five years in prison.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 26
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: Redistricting Likely to Hamper Democratic Efforts in 2014, Study Finds
text: Thanks largely to the way Congressional districts were drawn in the latest round of redistricting, even a dramatic wave election like the one in 2008 that swept President Obama into power and added to Democratic majorities in Congress would do little to alter the composition of the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, a new, nonpartisan study found.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 26
text: More photographs.

headline: Hula Hoop Marathon in the Buff, in Silence
text: On Wednesday, at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn, a man and a woman, both naked, hula-hooped in silence for 35 minutes. That may sound like a caricature of masturbatory performance art, but most of the work sustained interest, even fascination. To begin with, there was the suspense of whether the performers could keep their hoops going the whole time. They did.

headline: Sibling Rivalry
text: Based on the Ford Fusion, the 2013 MKZ reflects Lincoln’s ongoing attempt to distinguish itself from its Ford relatives.

headline: Artifacts | The Rocks at 30 Rock
text: In the age of the camera phone, it’s human nature to snap away at anything unusual. Those passing through Rockefeller Center over the next seven weeks will no doubt fall prey to that temptation when they encounter “Human Nature,” a constellation of nine towering bluestone figures that the artist Ugo Rondinone has set on the plaza in front of 30 Rock. No sooner were the giant evocations of fossilized humanity unveiled than they acquired a nickname. “It’s Ugohenge,” the painter Elizabeth Peyton said at a dinner at the Monkey Bar last Tuesday to celebrate the show’s opening. “Isn’t that what everyone’s calling them?”

headline: What Is Different About This Explosion?
text: Watch this very brief video clip of a Honda Civic hatchback being destroyed by an explosion from within. Does something seem odd about the blast? (No, the answer is not that the skin of the passenger-side door almost destroyed my camera.)

headline: Behind the Scenes in Covering Boston
text: The Times’s Richard L. Berke spoke with Katharine Q. Seelye, Boston bureau chief, and Brent McDonald, a video journalist, about the role of smartphones and social media in covering the Boston bombing.

headline: Mayoral Candidates Quizzed on Use of Drones
text: Public safety has been a major issue in the campaign for mayor of New York this year, and for weeks the candidates have talked at length about whether they would replace the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, whether they would continue to allow the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practice, and whether the department should be monitored by an inspector general. But on Friday, during a forum on technology, the candidates got a question that posed a new test of their views on police practices: Should the department be allowed to use unmanned drones?

headline: The Medium Term Is Not The Message
text: Ezra Klein tries to broker peace:

headline: George Jones’s New York
text: Hardly anybody would have looked for an “I ♥ NY” bumper sticker on George Jones’s tour bus. “The story of him and New York was he just didn’t want to come here,” said Jack Grace, a singer and songwriter who books performers for the Rodeo Bar in Manhattan.

headline: Your Agenda for ‘Fiscal Health Day’
text: A couple of week’s ago, I asked Bucks readers to nominate themselves for a financial tuneup, a day where I would come to their home and help them get through their long list of money-related tasks that have been neglected over the course of the past year.

headline: Where ‘Share the Road’ Is Taken Literally
text: “Woonerf” is what the Dutch call a special kind of street or group of streets that functions as shared public space — for pedestrians, cyclists, children and, in some cases, for slow-moving, cautiously driven cars as well.

headline: Italian Soul, Now Supersize
text: TESTED 2014 Moto Guzzi California 1400 Custom

headline: The Secret Ingredient Is Ford Fusion
text: I’d like to make a confession: I’m a Lincoln owner.

headline: Street Smarts: From Holland, Bright Ideas for Highways
text: If cars, traffic and navigation can be “smart,” is there any reason for roads to remain as dumb as bricks?

headline: LivingSocial Hack Exposes Data for 50 Million Customers
text: LivingSocial, the daily deals site, told its employees Friday that it had been breached, and said that data for 50 million users might have been compromised.

headline: This Week's Best-Seller Lists
text: The Times's John Williams and Gregory Cowles discuss traits of femininity in "The Athena Doctrine" and Ayn Rand's influence on Iris Johansen, author of "Taking Eve."

headline: Debt and Growth Data
text: I’ve had some requests for data sources on debt and growth; good point. So, it’s all in the public domain. The IMF public debt database  offers a downloadable spreadsheet of debt/GDP ratios going back in some cases to 1791. For GDP, the easy source for 1950 onwards is the Total Economy Database; you want the file on output, labor, and labor productivity. If you want to push further into the past, the Maddison Project has spreadsheets going back in some cases to the year 1000.

headline: Friday Night Music: More Luscious Lucius
text: Just enjoy.

headline: Twitter Shows Its Rude Side
text: What accounts for the galloping lushness of bad manners on Twitter? A recent incident may shed some light.

headline: Smuggling a Captive Audience Across a Border
text: Congress is preparing to consider a sweeping reform of the nation’s immigration system, but one shift in the terms of the public debate is already being signaled: News organizations have recently declared that they will find alternatives to the term “illegal immigrants.” The point is that although the immigrants may be in the country illegally, they themselves are not illegal.

headline: Staying Effervescent Against the Odds
text: The actress Heather Graham, 43, plays a small-town grain-elevator operator in the recently released film “At Any Price.” Born in Milwaukee, she lives in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: A Troubled Introduction for a Crucial New Model
text: DETROIT — The redesigned 2013 MKZ sedan was meant to herald a new era for Lincoln, the longtime luxury division of Ford that was recently rechristened the Lincoln Motor Company. The MKZ’s arrival, originally set for the late fall of 2012, was ballyhooed in an expensive advertising campaign and an insistent public relations blitz.

headline: The Year of the Cat
text: According to the Chinese lunar calendar, the Year of the Snake began on Feb. 10. But by most other standards, 2013 is shaping up to be the Year of the Cat. In the first week of February, Hasbro, makers of the Monopoly board game, announced they were replacing one of the traditional tokens, the flat iron, with a curvaceous silver pussycat. Ailurophobes howled, blaming the “all-powerful cat lobby” (so teased a reporter on NPR), but the evidence suggests that public taste alone explains the switch. There are 86 million cats in American households, and in a Facebook survey, the nimble cat instantly leapt ahead of the regular Monopoly retinue to become players’ piece of choice — nearly twice as popular as the Scottie Dog, and three times more popular than the Car and Battleship. Take that, cat detractors!

headline: Israel: Military to Stop Using Shells Containing Phosphorus
text: The Israeli military said on Friday that it planned to remove shells containing phosphorus from active use within about a year. The munitions, typically used to illuminate a battlefield or to create a smokescreen to mask troop movements, will be replaced with a new type of shell that uses gas, the military said. Israeli and international human rights organizations accused Israel of using white phosphorus munitions improperly during Israel’s three-week military offensive against Hamas and other militant groups in Gaza in the winter of 2008-9. Such munitions are not prohibited under international law, but they are not supposed to be used in civilian areas, because white phosphorus is highly flammable and, like napalm, it can burn flesh. Israel maintained that its use of shells containing phosphorus did not violate international law.

headline: A Den Mother for Art Spectacles
text: The children were too close to the stanchions, and Anne Pasternak wasn’t having it. “You can’t touch the ropes or the horses won’t come visit you,” she trilled.

headline: The Size of a Gumball, or Bigger Than Jumbo
text: WANTAGE, N.J. — Most mornings outside the gates of Tier Haus Farms here, several cars drive up to investigate the contents of an ordinary-looking cooler. Inside are eggs, freshly collected from beyond the gates by Carolyn Gerdes, an owner of the hilly, 70-acre property. Instead of having a traditional farm stand, Ms. Gerdes accepts orders by text, e-mail and phone for eggs, then leaves them for her regular customers to pick up when she is not available to hand them off directly.

headline: At Musical Buffet, the Entree Need Not Be Served First
text: “Life is uncertain. Eat dessert first.” At first glance, the program for Thursday evening’s concert at Alice Tully Hall by the Swedish Chamber Orchestra with the soprano Nina Stemme put me in mind of this much-quoted maxim by Ernestine Ulmer. The substantial fare appeared to have been reserved for the second half, which was given over to Brahms’s Symphony No. 1.

headline: Electrosoul, With a Heartfelt Sweetness
text: That Coco O could sing was not in question. For about a half-hour on Thursday night at Le Poisson Rouge, she’d been slithery, teasing, sensual, ecstatic. The carefree soul songs of Quadron, the duo for which she is the frontwoman, demand all of those things.

headline: The Growing Pains of Jonathan Krohn
text: It’s almost a job requirement for a 13-year-old to do things that will make him cringe as an 18-year-old. Some regret a death-metal phase, others a Bieber haircut. Jonathan Krohn says that his big embarrassment is his stint as a conservative pundit.

headline: Vows: Marci and Seth
text: An admitted “Hebrew school dropout,” Seth Lindenman never thought he’d marry a rabbi. When he proposed to Rabbi Marci Bellows, he got a whole congregation.

headline: A Dinner Menu Brimming With Bacon
text: Corey Wry, a native of Manchester, Conn., went off to culinary school and returned to open three hometown eateries, including a wildly popular burger joint, Corey’s Catsup and Mustard, that was featured on Guy Fieri’s Food Network show “Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives.” His newest restaurant, the awkwardly named CW’s Chops ’N’ Catch, offers comfort food at affordable prices.

headline: Jets, Picking Geno Smith, Are Talk of the Town Again
text: Minutes before the Jets drafted West Virginia quarterback Geno Smith on Friday night with the 39th pick, the NFL Network analyst Mike Mayock exclaimed that he didn’t believe Smith would land in New York because he’s perhaps not a franchise quarterback and it would create “a circus.”

headline: Sauvignon Blanc, Suited to the Season
text: Few vegetables are tougher to match with wine than green asparagus, which is synonymous with spring. My go-to white for the job is sauvignon blanc, because its characteristic aromas and flavors — commonly called green, herbal, herbaceous or vegetal — echo those of asparagus.

headline: Beach Boys Win Fight, and Lose It
text: The Beach Boys have won an eight-year legal battle over a collection of their memorabilia, including more than 50 handwritten scores for hits like “Good Vibrations” and “Surfin’ U.S.A.” But it is a partial victory, as binding arbitration has forced the band to agree to sell the memorabilia and split the money with other investors, lawyers and corporate entities who say they have a legal claim to it, court records show.

headline: An Outspoken Speaker, Seeking to Quell the Unruly
text: LONDON

headline: Netherlands Wins Yeh Brothers Cup
text: The Yeh Brothers Cup in Yokohama, Japan, was won on Friday by the Netherlands, represented by Bauke Muller, Simon de Wijs, Ricco van Prooijen and Louk Verhees, who are reigning Bermuda Bowl champions. In the 48-board final they defeated the team Italy Lavazza by 102 international match points to 78.5. The Italian players were Norberto Bocchi, Agustin Madala, Giorgio Duboin and Antonio Sementa. (Maria Teresa Lavazza and Guido Ferraro were part of the team but did not play in the final stages.) Third was Denmark, made up of Sabine Auken, Morten and Dennis Bilde (father and son) and Roy Welland of New York City, who won the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in St. Louis last month.

headline: Google Search Terms Can Predict Stock Market, Study Finds
text: The terms people search for on Google have been used to forecast how many Americans have the flu, travel plans and the price for which cars sell. Now a scientific study shows that Google search can be used to predict the stock market.

headline: Authentic, From the Name to the Tortillas
text: The restaurant Cinco de Mayo in Calverton would be a fitting place to celebrate the Mexican holiday of the same name next Sunday. The Mexican food served here is authentic, down to the house-made corn tortillas.

headline: It Came From Outer Space, Bearing Secrets
text: “Hamesima X” is a mystical tract seemingly reincarnated in the ultra-cheesy body of a 1980s straight-to-video thriller. Despite its outlandish premise, it’s a classic example of a feature-length foregone conclusion, in which a sulky skeptic is shown the light. In this Israeli film — directed by Yuval Ovadia, Or Yashar and Prosper Malka — a Mossad agent interrogates a mysterious visitor from outer space only to find religion himself.

headline: Youkilis Out Again
text: Infielder Kevin Youkilis, who has not played since April 20, was once again out of the lineup on Friday with back spasms.

headline: A Racial Divide Closes as Students Step Up
text: ABBEVILLE, Ga. — Mareshia Rucker watched in frustration last weekend as several dozen classmates in tuxedos and gowns walked into an Art Deco theater for her high school’s “white prom.”

headline: Bill Cunningham | Sketching in Pastels
text: The glories of spring are at a peak, and the tulips and hyacinths reflect the diversity of present-day fashion.

headline: Why Not Have City Opera Go Home to City Center?
text: Last spring, reflecting on the completion of New York City Opera’s first season as an itinerant company bringing productions to the people in theaters throughout the city, George Steel, its general and artistic director, defended his decision to abandon Lincoln Center and argued that things were going well.

headline: Philosophical Dialogues Made Physical
text: In his book “Le Danseur des Solitudes,” the French philosopher Georges Didi-Huberman focuses on the experimental flamenco dancer Israel Galván to explore the isolation of a solo. A solo is not necessarily a lonely act, he writes, but “a complex solitude populated by images, dreams, ghosts, memories.” Stillness is virtuosic; empty space is charged with energetic force.

headline: Colorful Serendipity for a School’s Sculpture
text: It may not be in quite the same league as finding the remains of Richard III under a parking lot in Leicester, or fragments of Chinese pottery dating back 20,000 years. But last week the discovery of a thousand or more shards of colorful Tiffany glass, stumbled on while clearing the site of a former Tiffany factory for a new school building in Corona, Queens, is expected to give a sculpture commissioned for the school more authenticity than originally hoped for by the agency that ordered it and the artist who is making it.

headline: Frenchman Will Return to China Prized Bronze Artifacts Looted in 19th Century
text: BEIJING — One of France’s wealthiest businessmen has agreed to return to China two bronze animal heads that were looted from the imperial Summer Palace near Beijing by invading French and British troops in the 19th century, according to a report on Friday by China Radio International, a state news organization. To China, the looting of the palace epitomizes the humiliation it suffered at the hands of imperial Western powers during the Second Opium War.

headline: A Couple’s Financial Tuneup
text: Tara Siegel Bernard, a reporter for The Times, helped Jennifer and Scott Bartone set aside a day to fine-tune finances and make headway on the money-related tasks that never seem to get done.

headline: A Look Into the Future of Midtown
Mormons Endorse Plan to Admit Gay Scouts
text: The Mormon Church has declared its support for the Boy Scouts of America’s proposal to end a longstanding ban on openly gay youths, while continuing to bar gay adult leaders.

headline: Nets Extend General Manager’s Contract
text: CHICAGO — The owner of the Nets, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, has been known for trying to make splashy moves and pursuing big names to lead his team, whether it be LeBron James, Dwight Howard or the former coach Phil Jackson.

headline: Israel Sees U.S. Response to Syria as Gauge on Iran
text: JERUSALEM — As President Obama wrestles with how to respond to new assessments that Syria appears to have used chemical weapons, leaders in Israel say they will be watching for clues about how he might handle the Iranian nuclear issue in the future.

text: No running backs and nine offensive linemen were taken in the first round. A look at the number of picks at each position in the first round since 1967, when the A.F.L. and N.F.L. first combined their drafts.
