text: To the Editor:

headline: Not Your Typical Subway Crooner
text: The Michael Bublé charm offensive hit the ground running this week. On Tuesday, the release date for his sixth studio album, “To Be Loved” (Reprise), Mr. Bublé put in a shift as guest co-host on “Today” and later taped an interview with “Nightline.” On Wednesday he was booked heavily with radio spots plugging the album and its insistently perky lead single, “It’s a Beautiful Day.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Attack Video and Bell’s Voice
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Knot Tied? Check. Vine-Covered Cottage? Check.
text: There were so many things to take in during Tuesday’s presentation of “A Marriage: 1 (Suburbia),” a performance and installation by Nick Vaughan and Jake Margolin that has taken over the upstairs and downstairs theaters, hallways, stairwells and other nooks and crannies of Here Art Center.

headline: For Zuckerberg, a Big Payout From Facebook Stock
text: Facebook shares may have been on a roller coaster ride in the year since they made their debut on Wall Street, but they haven’t been too shabby for its top executives. Mark Zuckerberg exercised stock options worth $2.3 billion, according to a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission late Friday — and sold about half, to cover his tax bill.

headline: The Season When Local Chefs Go Wild
text: In early April, a supermarket flier trumpeted: “Burst into spring!” Featured in the ad were imported blackberries, California strawberries and salad mixes in plastic clamshells from a corporate farm out West. That blackberries, strawberries and baby greens grown in distant climes had been available right through the winter here in Westchester County, for a price, seemed lost in all the enthusiasm.

headline: Europe Facing More Pressure to Reconsider Cuts as a Cure
text: BRUSSELS — Unemployment has surpassed Great Depression-era levels in Southern Europe. Recession is drifting to the once resilient economies of the north. Even some onetime hawks on government spending say they cannot cut any more.

headline: Internet Sales Tax Coming Too Late for Some Stores
text: Anita Demetropoulos, a Maine shopkeeper, figured she would never see the day when her most relentless competitor, Amazon, would be forced to collect sales tax.

headline: With Winters Gone, Can We Be Far Behind?
text: (This is part one of a two-part article.)

headline: Cano Carrying Injury-Riddled Yankees
text: Robinson Cano’s hot streak to begin the season has been especially important with so many starters out of the Yankees’ lineup due to injury.

headline: ‘The Great Gatsby’: What’s in a Cover Design?
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Filmmaker Held in Venezuela Sought to Show Political Divide, Friends Say
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Just a few weeks ago, Tim Tracy spoke of his time shooting a documentary in Venezuela as a rollicking adventure and a filmmaker’s dream. Now he is under arrest, accused by the Venezuelan government of a different kind of adventure: taking part in what officials here said was a plot to destabilize the country and incite a civil war.

headline: In Texas Blast, Horseman Died Trying to Save Creatures He Loved
text: WEST, Tex. — The emergency responders who rushed to the fire at a fertilizer plant here in the minutes before a deadly explosion gave their lives trying to protect the town’s people and property. Buck Uptmor gave his for its horses.

headline: A Libertarian Case for Expanding Gun Background Checks

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Japanese authorities approved Boeing’s fixes to its 787 Dreamliners, China’s factory output slows and recession threatens to spread in Europe.

headline: Enjoying a Well-Rounded Career in Music
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Cynthia Daniels, a Grammy-winning recording engineer and producer, has amassed a long list of famous clients: Beyoncé, Sarah Jessica Parker and Alec Baldwin, to name a few.

headline: A Blow to British Horse Racing
text: NEWMARKET, England — It is called the sport of kings and it has been in this haven of racecourses, stables and studs since the 17th century, when King Charles I and his courtiers made the 100-mile journey here by horse-drawn carriages.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: In Room 306 of the Lorraine Motel, the Last Night
text: We really do have a complicated relationship with the British, especially when it comes to stage and screen drama. Show Americans a grand English manor, some lords and ladies with upper-crust accents, period costumes and class-specific crises, and we practically declare a religion. Look at all the “Downton Abbey“ converts.

headline: Grading the Notable Second-Round Picks
text: The first night of the 2013 N.F.L. draft didn’t possess the star power many of us anticipated, but it set up an intriguing Day 2. With many prospects in both rounds projected to start immediately, we saw why this was considered such a deep draft. Let’s run through some of the interesting choices.

headline: The Death of a Countess in Exile
text: They knew her as the slender, straight-backed woman with an independent streak and a head for numbers. She told them she had immigrated from Hungary, and her colleagues at Merrill Lynch did not pry with more questions.

headline: After Attack, Suspects Returned to Routines, Raising No Suspicions
text: BOSTON — Just five hours after the bombs exploded at the Boston Marathon last week, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19, was back at his computer, doing what he did almost every day, posting a message on Twitter.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Yankees’ Cervelli Breaks Hand and Nova Leaves With Elbow Pain
text: The depleted Yankees could hardly afford to lose more players to injury, but in less than three innings on Friday, the Yankees lost their starting battery — possibly for a significant duration.

headline: The Magic That Storytelling Can Do
text: The imperceptible magic that pervades human existence and the power of myth to assuage sorrow are invoked by the playwright Stefanie Zadravec as she entwines the lives of strangers in “The Electric Baby,” a gently touching new drama at the Two River Theater Company in Red Bank.

headline: In Trek North, First Lure Is Mexico’s Other Line
text: CIUDAD HIDALGO, Mexico — With her leg snapped and folded excruciatingly over her shoulder, Elvira López Hernández lay flat on a railroad bed as the freight train hurtled above her, clinging tightly to two things: the railroad ties beneath her and the memory of the 4-year-old daughter she had left behind in Guatemala.

headline: Mexico’s Porous Southern Border
text: Seeking to enter the United States illegally, a growing number of Central Americans are entering Mexico, often under the gaze of Mexican authorities.

headline: A Song of Lament for Syria
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Apr. 27, 2013
text: "These are people I see in class every day. What’s wrong with dancing with me, just because I have more pigment?”

headline: Pushing the G.O.P. to Support Gay Rights
text: When the Rhode Island State Senate tallied up the votes against a same-sex marriage bill passed there on Wednesday, something was missing: Republicans.

headline: Instant Photographs, Lasting Images
text: Edwin Land, who founded Polaroid, the company famous for introducing and popularizing instant photography, in 1937, took inspiration for a famous model from home. An anecdote recounted on the company’s Web site says Mr. Land was moved to develop the Land Camera (which was introduced to the public in 1948 and produced instant black-and-white prints in about a minute) by his 3-year-old daughter, who wondered “why a camera could not instantly produce pictures after they were taken.”

headline: Father Gets Off L.I.R.R., Leaving Children Behind
text: Around 4 a.m. last Saturday, aboard a commuter train sidling through Long Island, a faint whimpering began to fill the sixth car somewhere east of Wyandanch.

headline: Corrections: April 27, 2013
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Holy Smoker
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — When I travel internationally, I like to immerse myself as much as possible into the local culture, which for me, is primarily about what local foods I can eat (I’m kidding. I’ve been known to skulk around museums too, mainly because they are known to have very clean restrooms.)

headline: Te’o Finally Comes Off the Board; Most Quarterbacks Don’t
text: It seemed fitting that Aaron Rodgers was rewarded with a lavish contract extension that could make him the highest-paid football player in history — for five years and $110 million, according to multiple reports — just minutes before the second round of the N.F.L. draft began Friday night.

headline: How to Build a Spoon
text: I have seen the future, and it is in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

headline: At 79, Still Keeping Brooklyn Bubbling
text: Eli Miller, who turns 80 in June, is the senior man among the few remaining seltzer deliverymen in New York City.

headline: As Old as the Bottles
text: Eli Miller, 79, New York City’s senior seltzer man, hoisted crate after crate of seltzer — weighing 70 pounds apiece — into his van and then draped himself over them.

headline: Statute Prevents Pursuit of Horace Mann Abuse
text: The Bronx district attorney’s office said Friday it could not pursue any cases of alleged sexual abuse at Horace Mann, an elite private school in the Bronx, because the statute of limitations had been exceeded.

headline: With Lineup Already Clicking, Mets Move Wright to the Cleanup Spot
text: Offense has not been a significant concern for the Mets this season, but in lieu of consistent pitching, Manager Terry Collins continues to search for more runs. He unveiled his latest experiment Friday night when the Mets faced the Philadelphia Phillies, moving David Wright from third in the order to the cleanup spot.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 26, 2013

headline: Thunder’s Championship Chances Take a Tumble With a Knee Injury to Westbrook
text: N.B.A. stars have been dropping like flies in the playoffs. David Lee of the Golden State Warriors was lost for the postseason. Steve Nash of the Los Angeles Lakers was seen being carted around in a wheelchair. Tony Parker of the San Antonio Spurs and Joakim Noah of the Chicago Bulls are playing through injuries.

headline: The Hugs Are Free, as Advertised, but Not Always Welcome
text: The sign is simple, eight big letters on a piece of cardboard, but when Jermaine Himmelstein takes it outside and holds it over his head and smiles, it acts like a strong magnet.

headline: E.P.A.’s Keystone Report Card
text: In the bland, formal language of interagency correspondence, the Environmental Protection Agency has written a trenchant review of the State Department’s most recent effort to assess the consequences of building the Keystone XL pipeline. The E.P.A’.s letter, issued Monday, at the end of the public comment period on the department’s latest draft environmental impact statement, is hardly a favorable report card.

headline: The Next Step in Drug Treatment
text: The mandatory-sentencing craze that drove up the prison population tenfold, pushing state corrections costs to bankrupting levels, was rooted in New York’s infamous Rockefeller drug laws. These laws, which mandated lengthy sentences for nonviolent, first-time offenders, were approved 40 years ago next month. They did little to curtail drug use in New York or in other states that mimicked them, while they filled prisons to bursting with nonviolent addicts who would have been more effectively and more cheaply dealt with through treatment programs.

headline: Congress Rushes to Aid the Powerful
text: Congress can’t pass a budget or control guns or confirm judges on time, but this week members of both parties found something they could agree on, and in a big hurry: avoiding blame for inconveniencing air travelers. The Senate and House rushed through a bill that would avert furloughs to air traffic controllers, which were mandated by Congress’s own sequester but proved embarrassing when flights began to back up around the country.

headline: Leaving Behind the Noise of the City
text: Rashid Perkins still remembers that first day. One summer morning, when he was 7, he left his home in Jamaica, Queens. At the Port Authority Bus Terminal, he said goodbye to his mother and boarded a bus that would take him to Needham, Mass., for a two-week stay with a host family, a trip sponsored by the Fresh Air Fund.

headline: The Morose Middle Class
text: The Middle Class is in a funk, its view of the future growing dim as fear rolls in like a storm.

headline: A General’s Life
text: Charles Traub embarks on a photographic journey to capture the places made great by Ulysses S. Grant’s indomitable spirit.

headline: A Party With Crunch
text: Salvation, Murray Hill style, means a party, at once visual, visceral, tangy and rowdy. The chef April Bloomfield’s newest venture with Ken Friedman strays far from their gastropubs, the Breslin and the Spotted Pig, and into Mexican, Asian and Middle Eastern territory.

headline: Man Charged in Killing of a Bronx 2-Year-Old Riding in a Van in 2006
text: For seven years, Joanne Sanabria has held candlelight vigils and mourned her 2 1/2-year-old son, David Pacheco Jr., who was killed in his car seat by a stray bullet near a busy Bronx intersection in 2006.

headline: Three-Hit Shutout Drops Mets Below .500 for First Time This Year
text: Just as David Wright was getting set to step inside the batter’s box in the bottom of the first inning, something went very wrong for the home plate umpire, Brian O’Nora. He sprinted off the field and into the Mets’ dugout.

headline: Democrats Said to Discuss Plan for Bronx District Attorney to Resign
text: With the prosecution record of the longtime Bronx district attorney, Robert T. Johnson, under fire, the borough’s Democratic leaders have been discussing a plan that would ease the way for him to step down within months, according to several people familiar with the idea.

headline: Grant in Pictures
text: The story of Ulysses S. Grant is an American epic practically without equal. Hollywood couldn’t dream it up. Even today, Grant’s complicated persona and unquenchable will to victory enthrall historians and fiction writers alike.

headline: A Bit of Writing, and Various States of Loll
text: In novels like “The Wife"and “The Ten-Year Nap,” Meg Wolitzer has explored themes of marriage, sex, gender politics and family. Her real domestic life is spent on the Upper East Side, where she lives with her husband, Richard Panek, 54, who is also a writer; their younger son, Charlie, who is 18; and the family’s dog, Jet, a 5-year-old Havanese. The couple’s older son, Gabriel, 22, is a senior at the University of Chicago. Ms. Wolitzer, 53, said she usually treated Sundays as a lighter writing day, carving out time for rest, Mexican food and an occasional cheap massage. Her newest book, “The Interestings,” was published this month by Riverhead Books.

headline: Giants’ Top Pick Blends Intellect, Intensity and Drive
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Justin Pugh, the Syracuse offensive tackle taken by the Giants in the first round, is a bruising, 6-foot-4, 305-pound all-American whom one of his college coaches on Friday called fiery, hard-nosed and eager to knock people down.

headline: Wang Is on the Yankees’ Radar
text: The former Yankee Chien-Ming Wang — whose 2008 foot injury derailed a promising young career — continued his strong start in the minors by allowing just one run in six and two-third innings for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre on Thursday. In 12 innings this season, Wang — who was signed to a minor league contract in the off-season — has a 0.75 earned run average.

headline: In Taking  a Quarterback, the Jets Give Up on Another
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.

headline: Kathryn Davis, Donor Who Made the Hudson Her Cause, Dies at 106
text: Kathryn Wasserman Davis, who contributed tens of millions of dollars to cleaning the Hudson River and promoting peace through an organization she founded when she was 100, died on Tuesday at her home in Hobe Sound, Fla. She was 106.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Q. Can you tell me about an enemy agent in Manhattan during World War II called the Doll Lady?

headline: Born, a Century Ago, to Be Wild
text: Members of the Queensboro Motorcycle Club in Queens, formed in 1910, show no sign of letting up.

headline: North Korea Expected to Indict American It Is Holding
text: SEOUL, South Korea — An American tour operator is facing indictment in North Korea on charges that he tried to overthrow the government there, the North’s official Korean Central News Agency said Saturday.

headline: The Bikes and the Fury
text: In a very short time, New Yorkers will have the opportunity to show the world that they are just as virtuous, well-intentioned and offended by sloth as people in Copenhagen or Geneva or any other of a number of cities where mindful living and wonderful yogurts reign. The city’s long-anticipated bike share program is scheduled to make its debut in May, allowing New Yorkers to pick up and deposit rental bikes at hundreds of locations, most of them, so far, in some of the wealthiest neighborhoods. Anyone waking up on a Sunday morning in TriBeCa, finding nothing in her refrigerator and hankering to go to Smorgasburg in Dumbo, Brooklyn, for instance, will now be able to do that with relative ease.

headline: Knicks, in a Stomping, Close In on a Sweep
text: BOSTON — The suspense had long since dissipated, along with the Boston Celtics’ spirit, but Carmelo Anthony was still on the parquet floor late Friday, dribbling, firing, skipping with a childlike glee and then, finally, making a slow, purposeful walk to the bench.

headline: Engines Revving, for 103 Years
text: Few clubs would want their headquarters in the Willets Point section of Queens, a massive, muddy cluster of auto repair shacks — but the Queensboro Motorcycle Club is perfectly happy wedged in there among the junkyards and salvage shops.

headline: Yanks Lose Cervelli and Nova to Injury but Salvage a Win
text: The 2013 Yankees, with a cast of has-beens and unknowns, have prided themselves on persevering, and Friday’s game was a case in point. In the first three innings, the Yankees lost their starting pitcher and catcher, possibly for a significant amount of time, but they ultimately prevailed against the Toronto Blue Jays, 6-4.

headline: He Left a Fortune, to No One
text: When Roman Blum died last year at age 97, his body lingered in the Staten Island University Hospital morgue for four days, until a rabbi at the hospital was able to track down his lawyer.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 10 P.M. (Sundance) A RIVER RUNS THROUGH IT (1992) Craig Sheffer portrays the writer Norman Maclean as a quiet, scholarly young man, and Brad Pitt (above right, with Mr. Sheffer) is Paul, his wilder, more magnetic brother, in this adaptation of Mr. Maclean’s 1976 autobiographical story about the sons of a Presbyterian minister (Tom Skerritt) coming of age in western Montana between Prohibition and the Great Depression — and finding expression for their emotions through fly-fishing. “These are men for whom the physical is inseparably entwined with the spiritual, men for whom both aspects of life are best appreciated knee-deep in a rushing river on a glorious day,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Between the novella’s well-known first sentence (‘In our family, there was no clear line between religion and fly-fishing’) and its elegiac last line (‘I am haunted by waters’), ‘A River Runs Through It’ circled gracefully among the landmarks of Mr. Maclean’s early years without violating the distant perfection of those memories.” She added: “It’s easy to recognize Robert Redford’s reverent film version of this beautifully spare novella as a labor of love. While the film is more lavish than Mr. Maclean’s story, and hence less commandingly precise, it radiates much the same seriousness of purpose. The same thoughts embraced by Mr. Maclean — of family and history, of the unbridgeable distances between men, of a wild natural landscape as a pathway to spiritual grace — are ably reflected on the screen.”

headline: Central Michigan Fan Celebrates No. 1 Pick
text: Usually after the first round of the N.F.L. draft, football fans in Michigan can proudly point to players selected who wore maize and blue or green and white during their high-profile Big Ten careers.

headline: With Crowd Behind Them, Celtics Go Nowhere Again
text: BOSTON — Doc Rivers said he felt his Boston Celtics team lost its spirit on Friday, an unimaginable concept given everything that appeared to be favoring them heading into Game 3 of their first-round playoff series against the Knicks.

headline: Game 3: Knicks vs. Celtics
text: The Knicks crushed the Celtics to take a 3-0 lead in the teams’ best-of-seven playoff series.

headline: After Plans to Build Titanic II, Australian Billionaire Forms a New Political Party
text: SYDNEY, Australia — An Australian billionaire who is perhaps best known for his efforts to build a seaworthy replica of the Titanic says he will use his vast fortune to form a new political party to compete in federal elections scheduled for September.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 27
text: NEWS After years of insisting that the primary cure for Europe’s malaise is to slash spending, the champions of austerity, most notably Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, find themselves under intensified pressure to back off from unpopular remedies and find some way to restore faltering growth to the world’s largest economic bloc. On Friday, Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain, who once promoted aggressive budget cuts, became the latest leader to reject European Union targets for reducing deficits. Andrew Higgins reports from Brussels.

headline: Hong Kong Retains Allure as Retail Mecca
text: HONG KONG — Amid bouquets, camera-wielding photographers and a bustling crowd of curious onlookers, Uniqlo opened a flagship store in the heart of one of Hong Kong’s busiest shopping districts on Friday – underlining the city’s unrelenting attraction for retailers seeking exposure to the giant mainland Chinese market.

headline: Off the Bottom but Not Yet in the Clear in La Coruña
text: Stability breeding consistency doesn’t seem to be an adage favored by La Liga clubs, although the facts should perhaps be given more thought by trigger-happy presidents. Last season’s three relegated clubs — Villarreal, Sporting Gijon and Racing Santander — all changed managers at least once during the season. One would be forgiven, then, for being unforgiving of Deportivo la Coruña’s Primera Division status when in February, languishing at bottom of the league, they appointed their third manager of the campaign.

headline: Obama and G.O.P. Spar Over Direction of Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama sparred with Congressional Republicans on Saturday over who was to blame for long flight delays this week, but neither side moved closer to a consensus on how to minimize the broader impact of federal spending cuts on the public.

headline: American Austerity, An Update
text: There is some tendency among economic commentators to think that austerity policies in a deeply depressed economy are mainly a European thing; you even find a fair number of people imagining that the United States is still engaged in fiscal stimulus. But the truth is that federal stimulus is years behind us, while state and local governments have cut back, so the overall story is one of fiscal contraction that’s smaller than in Europe, but not by that much.

headline: Justin Pugh, One Jolly Giant on Draft Day
text: The Giants seemed very pleased with their first-round draft selection: offensive lineman Justin Pugh of Syracuse, at No. 19 over all. The only concern might be his health after he was smothered by fans and family  in a raucous celebration following the Giants’ phone call on Thursday night. Luckily, he’s a big boy.

headline: The Ignoramus Strategy
text: A while back Noah Smith described one common strategy for arguing against Keynesian economics, and yours truly in particular: “Relentlessly pretend to be an ignorant simpleton.” Of course, as always, this strategy is most effective if you aren’t pretending, and really are an ignorant simpleton.

Storke Professor and vice chair in the Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences at Columbia University. headline: Boozer Increases His Scoring, Rebounding and Grinning
text: CHICAGO — Carlos Boozer strode to the United Center lectern after the Bulls’ Game 3 victory over the Nets on Thursday night. He was wearing a gray sports coat with a periwinkle and lavender windowpane pattern and a pair of baggy bluejeans, a clashing ensemble that could have been a metaphor for his three-year tenure with the team.

text: Part of an elite group, Syndie Molina is one of 104 rescue paramedics among the roughly 3,000 emergency medical technicians and paramedics employed by New York City. headline: Rebels From Darfur Stage Attack in Neighboring State
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Rebels from the Darfur region in Sudan on Saturday attacked a town in a neighboring state about 300 miles southwest of Khartoum, the capital, in one of their boldest offensives in years.

headline: Diagnosing the Wrong Deficit
text: IN the spring of 2010, a new patient came to see me to find out if he had attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. He had all the classic symptoms: procrastination, forgetfulness, a propensity to lose things and, of course, the inability to pay attention consistently. But one thing was unusual. His symptoms had started only two years earlier, when he was 31.

headline: Islamist Rebels Create Dilemma on Syria Policy
text: CAIRO — In Syria’s largest city, Aleppo, rebels aligned with Al Qaeda control the power plant, run the bakeries and head a court that applies Islamic law. Elsewhere, they have seized government oil fields, put employees back to work and now profit from the crude they produce.

headline: In the Season of Marriage, a Question. Why Bother?
text: IT’S surprising how many people still marry. As everyone knows, it’s a risky proposition; the divorce rate, though down from its peak of one in two marriages in the early 1980s, remains substantial. Besides, you can have a perfectly respectable life these days without marrying.

headline: I’ll Have Another’s Triumphs Put to Song
text: I was one of many horse racing fans that fell in love last year with I’ll Have Another as he partnered with jockey Mario Gutierrez to win the Robert B. Lewis Stakes, Santa Anita Derby, Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes. Bettors put the odds of this achievement at about 7,500 to 1. Gutierrez’s rides were masterful, and I’ll Have Another’s come from behind victories in the Derby and Preakness left the crowds screaming for more. Like all his fans, I was disappointed that an injury the week of the Belmont Stakes led to his retirement and sale to stud.

Illegal immigrants will be regularized, but most of them will have to wait at least a decade to gain citizenship. There will be more visas and new guest-worker programs, but also stiffer enforcement on the border and in workplaces.

When enough unsolicited huzzahs pile up, the Haggler likes to present them in a column.

headline: Rebalancing a Portfolio? Don’t Break the Seesaw
text: PORTFOLIO rebalancing — periodically resetting a mix of stocks and bonds by taking profits from outperforming investments and buying cheaper, underperforming ones — has always posed a challenge.

text: There is a 13-year-old in Tucson named Dallas Green. He loves swimming and is certified in scuba diving. His grandfather sends him antique coins every month for his collection. He plays baseball as best he can, the way his father, his grandfather and especially his sister would have wanted.

headline: Heading the Wrong Way

In reality, the economy is either stuck in low gear, or worse, slowing to a stop as budget cuts harm not only the users of overstretched government services but the overall economy. This precarious situation urgently calls for more federal spending, not less, though that message has been lost on Congress.

headline: Wikipedia’s Sexism
text: Early last week I noticed something strange on Wikipedia. It appeared that, gradually, over time, the volunteer editors who create the site had begun moving women, one by one, from the “American Novelists” category to the “American Women Novelists” subcategory. Female authors whose last names began with A or B had been most affected.

text: Most of my adult life, I have hated New York City.

headline: Another Alleged Drug Kickback Scheme
text: Two federal lawsuits charging a prominent drug company with making fraudulent kickbacks to promote sales of its drugs raise disturbing questions about how to control fraudulent behavior in the pharmaceutical industry, behavior that appears to be on the rise. The company is Novartis Pharmaceuticals, the American subsidiary of a Swiss-based multinational. Novartis denies any wrongdoing and vows to defend itself in court.

headline: Variations on a Gene, and Tools to Find Them
text: CANCERS were once named strictly for the tissue where they originated in the breast, prostate or other part of the body. Now, in the age of genetically informed medicine, cancers may also come with a more specific lexicon: the names of mutated genes deep within tumors that cause cells to become cancerous.

headline: The Lesson of Boston
text: IF only it were as simple as the drones coming home to roost. That would be comforting somehow. In giving us a tidy cause, it would give us a clear remedy: rain less death in distant lands, and worry less about death in our own.

headline: Food Aid Reform
text: Food aid is one of the most important tools of American foreign policy. Since the mid-1950s, the United States has spent nearly $2 billion annually to feed the world’s poor, saving millions of lives. But the process is so rigid and outdated that many more people who could be helped still go hungry. Reforms proposed by President Obama will go a long way toward fixing that problem and should be promptly enacted by Congress.

headline: Trying to Slam the Bailout Door
text: THERE’S a lot to like, if you’re a taxpayer, in the new bipartisan bill from two concerned senators hoping to end the peril of big bank bailouts. But if you’re a large and powerful financial institution that’s too big to fail, you won’t like this bill one bit.

headline: How Big Data Is Playing Recruiter for Specialized Workers
text: WHEN the e-mail came out of the blue last summer, offering a shot as a programmer at a San Francisco start-up, Jade Dominguez, 26, was living off credit card debt in a rental in South Pasadena, Calif., while he taught himself programming. He had been an average student in high school and hadn’t bothered with college, but someone, somewhere out there in the cloud, thought that he might be brilliant, or at least a diamond in the rough.

headline: Vanishing Southeast Division Has Had Much More Sunshine Than Success
text: WASHINGTON — After one final game Saturday night between the Florida Panthers and the Tampa Bay Lightning, the sun will set on the Southeast Division, a remarkably poor division by N.H.L. standards and across the four major North American professional sports leagues as well.

headline: Germans’ Dominance Is Peak of a Long Climb
text: BERLIN — The German soccer club Borussia Dortmund was at the edge of bankruptcy in 2003, unable to pay its players’ salaries. Rescue came from an unlikely source when rival Bayern Munich lent the club $2.6 million.

headline: A Realm of Their Own
text: At a studio in Montreal, the Ubisoft team pays close attention to detail while creating the video games into which millions of people escape.

headline: Where the Artists Are the Superheroes
text: When Tchae Measroch leaves work, his hands usually bear a fresh cut or bruise. He works, often on his knees, in a small room crowded with an odd mix of items: a dried-grass hula skirt, a car door, baseball bats, swords and knives of varying length, a camouflage net typically used to disguise military equipment from enemy eyes.

headline: The Great Degrader
text: I’ve been focused on economic policy lately, so I sort of missed the big push to rehabilitate Bush’s image; also, as a premature anti-Bushist who pointed out how terrible a president he was back when everyone else was praising him as a Great Leader, I’m kind of worn out on the subject.

headline: The Art of the Hunt
text: THE next time you visit an art museum, look around — not at the paintings, but at the people in the galleries. It’s a fair bet that women will outnumber men; even government statistics say so. More women than men study art, too, at both undergraduate and graduate levels. Art appreciation is a female predilection and so, you would think, is collecting. To buy art, you have to shop. Need I say anything about which sex has a proclivity for browsing — an essential element of buying, um, visual art?

headline: Whither Moral Courage?
text: WE find it easier, in these confused times, to admire physical bravery than moral courage — the courage of the life of the mind, or of public figures. A man in a cowboy hat vaults a fence to help Boston bomb victims while others flee the scene: we salute his bravery, as we do that of servicemen returning from the battlefront, or men and women struggling to overcome debilitating illnesses or injuries.

headline: The Dark Side of Energy Independence
text: JUST as the world was writing off America as a declining power, the country now finds itself on the cusp of realizing one of its longstanding goals: energy independence.

headline: Scouting Report on Ryan Nassib, Chosen by Giants in Round 4
text: The Giants grabbed another Syracuse player in the draft, trading up to take quarterback Ryan Nassib in the fourth round Saturday. Matt Waldman, a scouting expert who ranked the quarterbacks for the Fifth Down before the draft, rated him third, ahead of the new Jet Geno Smith (5th). He gives a fuller report:

headline: Discovery Near 9/11 Site Stirs Memories
text: For years, Lilia Tahlov tried to push it out of her thoughts. The “horrible day,” as she calls it, when the sky turned black and her teeth chattered incessantly.

headline: Sabathia Is Uneven Again, but Hafner Provides Enough for Win
text: Designated hitter Travis Hafner faced a great deal of uncertainty when he surveyed his options during the off-season. Hafner, a former Cleveland Indians star, had never been a free agent. The freedom to choose his next destination was exciting, but he was also nervous about finding the right spot. Hafner, 35, was headed toward the twilight of his career, if he had not already reached it, and a successful final chapter required the best fit.

headline: Italy Forms New Coalition Government to End Months of Political Stalemate
text: ROME — Ending a crushing two-month political stalemate that had spooked European leaders, Prime Minister-elect Enrico Letta formed a rare coalition government on Saturday uniting left and right — and including a record number of women and Italy’s first nonwhite minister — to steer Italy, with the euro zone’s third-largest economy, out of the doldrums.

headline: Giants Trade Up for Syracuse Quarterback
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Maneuvering to move up six spots early on the third day of the N.F.L. draft, the typically staid Giants chose Syracuse quarterback Ryan Nassib with a fourth-round pick Saturday, the highest the team has taken a quarterback since it chose Philip Rivers at No. 4 in 2004 and then traded him for the top pick, Eli Manning.

headline: F.A.A. Says Air Traffic Staffing Is Returning to Normal
text: After a week of air-traffic slowdowns, the Federal Aviation Administration said on Saturday that it had suspended its employee furloughs and was returning to normal staffing levels, while President Obama sparred with Congressional Republicans over who was to blame for the delays.

headline: In South Carolina Congressional Race, Drama Outpaces Discussion of Issues
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Mark Sanford has taken to debating a life-size poster of Nancy Pelosi on the streets. His Democratic opponent, Elizabeth Colbert Busch, issued a tribute to Margaret Thatcher, the conservative former British prime minister who died last month.

headline: Russians Go on TV to Say Sanctions Won’t Matter
text: MOSCOW — Just two weeks after the Obama administration imposed sanctions on about two dozen Russians accused of human rights violations, Russian officials organized a very public “so what?” on Saturday, gathering officials on the list and assuring them in televised meetings that condemnation by the United States government would not hurt their careers. The jocular tone of the meetings suggested, in fact, that it might help.

headline: Illegal Districts Dot New Delhi as City Swells
text: NEW DELHI — New Ashok Nagar is a typical crosscut of Indian urban chaos: Dust rises off battered, narrow lanes, tangles of telephone and electricity lines hang between poorly constructed, mismatched brick buildings. Sewage overflows from uncovered channels. And people are in the streets, in the doorways, everywhere.

headline: Departing French Envoy Has Frank Words on Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — It is always hard to gauge what diplomats really think unless one of their cables ends up on WikiLeaks, but every once in a while, the barriers fall and a bit of truth slips into public view.

headline: Immigrants Pay Lower Fees to Send Money Home, Helping to Ease Poverty
text: The first time Carmen Gonzalez sent money back to her family in Mexico, in 1991, Western Union charged her a $12 fee to wire $100. She earned that $12 working for six hours in a clothing factory in midtown Manhattan, which paid her $2 an hour.

headline: Marcum Keeps It Close; Bullpen Hands It Over
text: The Mets do not expect Shaun Marcum to be the second coming of Christy Mathewson. When they signed Marcum in the off-season to a one-year deal, the Mets were merely looking to stabilize their rotation in the wake of R. A. Dickey’s departure to the Toronto Blue Jays. They wanted a veteran who could eat some innings and win some games, a reliable arm for a staff in dire need of one.

headline: My Dark Times: A Survivor’s Story
text: Last October, Habibullah, a 22-year-old student from Quetta, Pakistan, joined 34 Hazara asylum seekers on a boat bound for Christmas Island, a small Australian territory about 240 miles off the Indonesian coast. Within 24 hours the boat had sunk in a storm. This is his account of his ordeal.

headline: Celebrity Guest Solver Elayne Boosler: Soft T’s
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve written a few times about the Extremely Spunky Border Terrier who lives with me as the brains behind the Wordplay organization, and it’s rare to find someone who loves dogs even more than I do. I think I’ve finally met my match in Elayne Boosler.

headline: Many Openings at State Agency Go to Those With Ties to Cuomo
text: ALBANY — New York State’s economic development agency created a new position last June, and then found a candidate to fill it: a young man named Willard Younger, who had just graduated from Colgate University with a degree in classics and religion. He became a special projects associate, at a salary of $45,000 a year, according to state personnel records.

headline: Rangers Will Face Capitals in Round 1
text: All systems are go entering the playoffs for the surging Rangers, who are looking a lot more like last season’s supremely competent team, and a lot less like the bumbling outfit they were for the first two-thirds of the season, as they prepare to face the Washington Capitals.

headline: 4 Young Brothers Die in Fire at Camp for Syria Refugees in Jordan
text: JERUSALEM — Four young brothers who had fled the civil war in Syria were killed in a fire that engulfed four tents in the Zaatari refugee camp near Jordan’s northern border, the aid worker who runs the camp said Saturday.

headline: No Rich Child Left Behind
text: Here’s a fact that may not surprise you: the children of the rich perform better in school, on average, than children from middle-class or poor families. Students growing up in richer families have better grades and higher standardized test scores, on average, than poorer students; they also have higher rates of participation in extracurricular activities and school leadership positions, higher graduation rates and higher rates of college enrollment and completion.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 28
text: National security and foreign affairs share the limelight on the Sunday political shows this week, featuring conversations about the investigation into the Boston Marathon bombings and the response to new developments in Syria’s civil war.

headline: Bulls Are the Ones Left Standing After Triple Overtime
text: CHICAGO — The locker-room floor was strewn with towels, torn bandages and ice. Eyes were red and gaits were stilted. After two games and two losses, after 63 minutes in a triple-overtime thriller on Saturday, this is how the Nets left Chicago.

headline: Ready (or Not?) for a Great Coming Shale Boom
text: SWEETWATER — About a year ago, talk began circulating in this West Texas town about a huge oil-producing formation called the Cline Shale, east of the traditional drilling areas around Midland.

headline: Reviving an Old Series the New Way: Fan-Financing
text: Around 10 p.m. on a recent Friday night, roughly 500 people at the Dog and Duck Pub in Austin gathered around a man holding an iPad. The man was Rob Thomas, the creator of the cult-hit television series “Veronica Mars,” and he was staring at the device, counting down the final seconds of a 30-day campaign on Kickstarter, the crowd-source-financing Web site, to raise money for a film adaptation of that “teen noir” series.

headline: Loans Borrowed Against Pensions Squeeze Retirees
text: To retirees, the offers can sound like the answer to every money worry: convert tomorrow’s pension checks into today’s hard cash.

headline: Rapid Growth Creates Cities Within Cities in India
text: India’s crowded urban centers are divided not only by class but also by the legal status of where people live.

headline: Lowering Standards to Earn a Diploma Could Raise Voters’ Ire
text: Of the three primary arguments about public schools under way in Austin, two are relatively easy for lawmakers to sell to the voters who put them in office.

headline: Valeant and Actavis Talks Fall Through, for Now
text: Merger talks between Valeant Pharmaceuticals and another drug maker, Actavis, have fallen through, a person briefed on the matter said on Saturday, potentially ending what would have been one of the biggest health care deals of the year.

headline: Lawmakers Take on Texas Truancy Laws
text: SAN ANTONIO — When she can focus on class, Rachel Hebert thrives as a student in the Northside Independent School District here. But Rachel, 17, has cerebral palsy, and medical complications often keep her from getting to school.

headline: Fleeing Pakistan Violence, Hazaras Brave Uncertain Journey
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — Stranded in a dingy hotel in the heart of this port city, waiting for the smuggler’s call, Hussain felt at once trapped and poised for freedom.

headline: Game 4: Bulls vs. Nets
text: The Bulls erased a 14-point deficit late in regulation and outlasted the Nets in triple overtime to take a 3-1 lead in the first-round playoff series.

headline: Barkley Learns That Bad Things Can Come to Those Who Wait
text: Matt Barkley finally heard his name called Saturday at the start of the fourth round of the N.F.L. draft, but after his precipitous descent, football players are going to hear Barkley’s name much more often. College football players.

headline: When One Man’s Game Is Also a Marauding Pest
text: EAST LANSING, Mich. — At first he thought it was a deer, perhaps the big-antlered buck he had seen before and hoped to bag someday.

headline: Feral Swine Spread to the North
text: State officials are scrambling to deal with an invasion of roaming behemoths that damage property and kill livestock.

headline: All Nippon Airways Takes Dreamliner With Improved Battery on Test Flight
text: HANEDA AIRPORT, Japan — All Nippon Airways, the largest operator of Boeing’s 787 Dreamliners, made its first test flight Sunday of a jet fitted with fortified batteries. The two-hour trip is expected to pave the way for a full resumption of flights three months after burning batteries on two planes grounded the entire 787 global fleet.

headline: Small in Stature Only, Robinson Scores 23 in the Fourth to Ignite the Bulls
text: CHICAGO — Early in the fourth quarter Saturday, Gerald Wallace set a hard screen on Nate Robinson in the Nets’ backcourt. Robinson weighs 35 pounds less and is 10 inches shorter than the 6-foot-7, 215-pound Wallace, and the collision had the feel of a puppy running into a Mack truck.

headline: With Flick of His Elbow, Knicks’ Smith Throws Celtics a Lifeline
text: BOSTON — J. R. Smith’s road to redemption was never going to be a simple, straight line. It was destined to be jagged, full of potholes and perilous hairpin turns. There were bound to be detours, even now, in the midst of his finest season.

headline: Smith’s Elbow Gives Angry Celtics Emotional Foothold in Series
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — Has J. R. Smith managed to do in one swoop what Doc Rivers couldn’t do in three games and a capacity crowd at TD Garden couldn’t do Friday night: awaken the catatonic Celtics with a much-needed jolt of energy?

headline: Tournament Seeks to Turn the Game Into an Art Form
text: The Alekhine Memorial tournament began last weekend as an unusual attempt to highlight chess as an art form.

headline: Jets Take Passer but Few Players to Surround Him
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — For a team desperate to find answers in the first draft orchestrated by its new general manager, John Idzik, the Jets completed a process critical to their rebuilding with an inordinate number of questions.

text: April 27, 2013

headline: Leo Branton Jr., Activists’ Lawyer, Dies at 91
text: Leo Branton Jr., a California lawyer whose moving closing argument in a racially and politically charged murder trial in 1972 helped persuade an all-white jury to acquit a black communist, the activist and academic Angela Davis, died on April 19 in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Shamshad Begum, Unseen Singer of Indian Film, Dies at 94
text: Shamshad Begum, a star singer in India during the early years of Hindi cinema, died on Tuesday at her home in Mumbai. She was 94.

headline: Phone Calls Discussing Jihad Prompted Russian Warning on Tsarnaev
text: The Russian warning to the United States government in 2011 about Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of two brothers accused in the Boston Marathon bombing on April 15, was based on two intercepted telephone calls discussing jihad, both involving his mother, a law enforcement official said on Saturday.

headline: Who Rules the Street in Cairo? The Residents Who Build It

headline: The Egyptian Revolution’s Transformation of Cairo, Block by Block
text: After decades of not being able to make decisions about their city, Cairenes are taking its development into their own hands.

text: A film that won over the Tribeca Film Festival’s jury has proven popular with the event’s audiences as well.

text: WASHINGTON — Accustomed to the role of target, President Obama exacted a light-hearted revenge on his tormentors in the news media and Congress on Saturday night with a joke-filled riff at the capital’s premier star-studded gala.

headline: Waves Are Different After Sandy, and Some Surfers Say Better
text: Walking down Beach 90th Street in Rockaway offers a glimpse of a neighborhood in the midst of an uphill battle: windows are shuttered, lawns are littered with debris and a beach is unprotected by its boardwalk. Yet as Rockaway slowly recovers, block by block, one crucial element is back, and, according to some, better: the wave.

headline: Confidence Issues Linger as the Dreamliner Soars Again
text: BEIJING — For nearly two hours on Sunday morning a Boeing Dreamliner 787 cruised the skies above Japan, with Boeing chief of commercial aircraft, Ray Conner, and the All Nippon Airways president, Shinichiro Ito, on board.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: “What explains this increasing perversion in society, where even children aren’t spared?” Debarshi Dasgupta and Prachi Pinglay-Plumber ask in Outlook magazine (print only). The authors survey the increasing number of reports of child sex abuse and ask what it is about Indian society that is causing this phenomenon. According to the National Crime Records Bureau between 2001 and 2011 there has been a three-fold increase in registered cases of child sex abuse, from 2,113 in 2001 to 7,112 a decade later. In speaking with experts in the field and those who deal with victims and perpetrators of child sex abuse, the authors find that it is not easy to determine a direct cause for the increase in sex abuse among minors. They find that offenders vary in behavior and psychology and therefore it is both hard to draw any generalizations and create effective means of prevention.

headline: Contrary to Reports, the Champions League Final Isn’t Set Yet
text: Will you be watching the second legs of the Champions League semifinals this week — Borussia Dortmund’s visit to Real Madrid on Tuesday, and Bayern Munich’s journey to Barcelona a day later? We ask because, if you haven’t heard, the outcome is a foregone conclusion, what with last week’s blowouts and the era of Spanish dominance being over and German soccer ascendant and plates shifting and all that.

headline: Monetarism Falls Short (Somewhat Wonkish)
text: The central debate over macroeconomic policy is, of course, between Keynesians and Austerians. And at this point the Keynesians have overwhelmingly won the debate everywhere except where it matters – the intellectual basis for austerity economics has collapsed, but actual austerity continues apace on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Knaves, Fools, and Me (Meta)
text: One criticism I face fairly often is the assertion that I must be dishonest — I must be cherry-picking my evidence, or something — because the way I describe it, I’m always right while the people who disagree with me are always wrong. And not just wrong, they’re often knaves or fools. How likely is that?

headline: 3 Shot Near Premier’s Office as Italy’s Cabinet Is Sworn In
text: ROME — Two military police officers and a passer-by were shot and wounded on Sunday in a crowded square outside the office of Prime Minister Enrico Letta and near the presidential palace, where his new government was being sworn in.

headline: At Least 8 Killed in Taliban Attacks on Candidates in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Taliban attacks on election candidates in northwestern Pakistan killed at least eight people and wounded dozens on Sunday, adding to a growing toll of militant violence before elections scheduled for May 11.

headline: Months After Newtown, Sorting Boxes of Grief
text: What do we do with the things people leave behind? What does it mean to move on, from the death of someone you love, or a divorce, which is a death of a different kind?

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: Cahill Saves the Day
text: Tim Cahill’s long (inter)national nightmare of answering questions about not scoring goals is over … at least for now.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘Never Say Die’
text: As the arrival of Derby Week brings horseracing fans’ simmering anticipation for the first Saturday in May to a full boil, it also provides an opportunity for some reflection on the sport’s rich history. Below, an excerpt from “Never Say Die: A Kentucky Colt, the Epsom Derby, and the Rise of the Modern Thoroughbred Industry.”

headline: Boeing Jet Returns to the Air, but It’s Only a Start
text: HANEDA AIRPORT, JAPAN — Katsuhiro Ogami, a top engineer at All Nippon Airways, could not sit still Sunday on the airline’s first test flight of a Boeing 787 Dreamliner jet fitted with fortified batteries. He peered, and peered again, at a monitor hooked to the plane’s batteries for any signs of overheating.

headline: Rushing to Replace Picnic Tables Lost to Storm
text: This spring has been no picnic for Chris Gruber and his staff of carpenters, who work for New York City and make much of the equipment used at its parks and beaches.

headline: Disruptions: Brain Computer Interfaces Inch Closer to Mainstream
text: Last week, engineers sniffing around the programming code for Google Glass found hidden examples of ways that people might interact with the wearable computers without having to say a word. Among them, a user could nod to turn the glasses on or off. A single wink might tell the glasses to take a picture.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE GOOD WIFE Season 4 concludes as Alicia (Julianna Margulies), Will (Josh Charles) and Diane (Christine Baranski) race through emergency court proceedings on the night of the election for governor. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, above with Chris Noth, left, appears as himself.

headline: Mary Thom, an Editor Who Shaped Feminist Voices, Dies at 68
text: Mary Thom, a chronicler of the feminist movement and former executive editor of Ms. magazine, died Friday in a motorcycle accident in Yonkers. She was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: A Writing Coach Becomes a Listener
text: The written word looms over William Zinsser. The many hundreds of books in his Upper East Side apartment stand at attention, as if awaiting instruction from this slight man in a baseball cap and sunglasses who, for a half-century, has coached others on how to write.

headline: Top Lieutenant of Dimon Is Departing JPMorgan
text: A senior executive in the inner circle of Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, is leaving, the latest departure after the bank reported a multibillion-dollar trading loss last year.

headline: An Italian Leader and a Political Acrobat
text: ROME — To select the cabinet that he presented Saturday to President Giorgio Napolitano of Italy, Prime Minister Enrico Letta, the new head of government, relied on what are widely acknowledged as his consummate skills: an ability to negotiate and a gift for building bridges, even between forces that barely speak to each other.

headline: ‘Pain & Gain’ Leads Sluggish Box Office
text: Two new movies, Michael Bay’s “Pain & Gain” and the star-studded romantic comedy “The Big Wedding,” left audiences underwhelmed — both pictures received a C-plus score in exit polls — as an overall North American box-office slump continued over the weekend.

headline: Lawmakers Call for Stronger U.S. Action in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans on Capitol Hill took President Obama to task Sunday for what they characterized as dangerous inaction in Syria, while Democrats urged the White House to step up its humanitarian response to the two-year-old civil war that has killed 70,000 people and displaced hundreds of thousands more.

headline: Wealth Gap      Among Races     Has Widened Since     Recession
text: WASHINGTON — Millions of Americans suffered a loss of wealth during the recession and the sluggish recovery that followed. But the last half-decade has proved far worse for black and Hispanic families than for white families, starkly widening the already large gulf in wealth between non-Hispanic white Americans and most minority groups, according to a new study from the Urban Institute.

headline: After 103 Years, Still Rolling in Queens
text: The Queensboro Motorcycle Club, founded in 1910, has had its clubhouse for 70 years wedged among the auto salvage shops in the Willets Point section of Queens.

headline: Figuring Out the Game’s Seasonal Rhythms
text: I feel sorry for people who never have to put their golf game in hibernation. Sure, they live where the weather is generally warm. They play golf whenever they feel like it. They can keep their swing thoughts fresh and their bodies limber.

headline: As Obama Faces Crises Abroad, His Foreign Policy Approval Is Down
text: Crises have flared abroad in the last several weeks, in North Korea and Syria, just as public opinion surveys have shown a dip in Americans’ approval of President Obama’s handling of foreign policy.

headline: Humanity Still Blooms in a Desert Bordering Mexico
text: Though relatively dispassionate bipartisanship has asserted itself in the immigration debate lately, it’s still not hard to find meanspiritedness in some quarters. A man at a recent town-hall meeting held by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, suggested that the best way to stop those who would enter the United States without authorization was with a gun.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Robbed at Gunpoint, Some Bronx Victims Resist
text: The first armed robbery attempt was in October, on a residential Bronx block near an elevated train stop. The victim fought back. He was shot in the leg.

headline: Bombings Trip Up Reddit in Its Turn in Spotlight
text: In the days after the Boston Marathon bombings, the social media and entertainment site Reddit had the breakout moment it had been waiting for — but not the one it expected.

headline: Iceland Ousts Government That Steered It Out of Crisis
text: LONDON — Voters in Iceland have ousted the center-left government that restored the country to solvency after the 2008 financial crisis, paving the way for the return to power of the center-right parties that many people blamed for causing the crisis.

headline: Overbay Helps Yankees Sweep Dickey and Blue Jays
text: The injured starting shortstop, third baseman and first baseman are not expected on the field soon, and the outfielder who had 43 home runs last season (Curtis Granderson) is in Florida rehabilitating after an injury. Sunday’s lineup had only one legitimate preseason All-Star candidate (Robinson Cano) and two players who were released during spring training this year. Even General Manager Brian Cashman, who broke his leg in a sky-diving accident, is still on the mend.

headline: The New Look of Public Relations
text: A GIANT in public relations is spinning in a new direction, reshaping itself in significant ways that underscore how agencies of all kinds are being made over to better serve marketer clients in the 21st century.

headline: Terry Jabs Knicks as Celtics Stay Alive
text: BOSTON — Jason Terry was upright again Sunday afternoon, his chin and his jump shot in working order, his conviction strong and his missions clear: Save the Boston Celtics’ season. Extend an era. If at all possible, irritate the Knicks just a little bit more.

headline: Researchers Put Sense of Touch in Reach for Robots
text: Finding and recognizing objects by touch in your pocket, in the dark or among items on a cluttered table top are distinctly human skills — ones that have been far beyond the ability of even the most dexterous robotic arms.

headline: Augie Boehm at the Honors Bridge Club in Manhattan
text: Augie Boehm of New York is almost as well known a pianist as he is a bridge expert. On May 13 he will give his 35th annual recital at the Weill Recital Hall in Carnegie Hall. Tickets are still available at the box office.

headline: Villainous Christmas and Biker Heroines
text: Joe Hill takes a cheery little Oedipal swipe at his father in the acknowledgment pages of his throat-grabbing new novel, “NOS4A2.” He describes the two of them riding back roads on motorcycles, Mr. Hill on his Triumph. His father, “a Harley snob,” admires the Triumph but says its engine reminds him of a sewing machine.

headline: Mets Tinker With Offense but Are Unable to Fix It
text: Before Sunday afternoon’s series finale against the Philadelphia Phillies, Terry Collins met with his coaching staff at Citi Field. The Mets had lost three straight games, their offensive slumbering and their relief pitching edging close to the realm of unmitigated disaster. Something needed to change.

headline: Ruminating on Love and Desire
text: Whenever the New York Philharmonic takes a break from Lincoln Center to play at Carnegie Hall there is usually a special program suited to the occasion. So it was on Friday night for a concert conducted by Alan Gilbert.

headline: Opinions and Feelings, Years in the Making, Play Out
text: In the 1960s, when she was in her 20s, Annette Peacock figured out how to write slow, spacious, long-form, highly original piano ballads as if the notes were falling naturally from her fingers, and that sounded, when ideally replayed, as if she were composing them all over again. She sang them with the full range of her voice, making them twice as good, with a kind of severe passion, only semi-sentimental, following their unsettling, unresolving melodic trajectories. They were somewhere between rudimentary and very achieved: new lieder, or some radically decelerated soul-jazz hybrid, or melted torch numbers.

headline: American Crossword Puzzle Tournament — Brooklyn or Stamford? A Special Message from Will Shortz
text: The 37th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament will be held March 7-9, 2014, at the Brooklyn Bridge Marriott, where the event has been for the past six years. Our contract with the hotel runs through then.

headline: An Artist Brushes Off the Constraints of Chart-Friendly Songs
text: “I think it’s fair to say that I’m probably not really known for my three-minute pop songs,” the English singer and multi-instrumentalist Steven Wilson said from the stage of the Best Buy Theater during his concert there on Friday night. “However, very occasionally, I can write something that clocks in at under 15 minutes that I think, you know what?, that’s not bad,” he continued as preface to “Postcard,” a four-and-a-half-minute ballad.

headline: ‘Rocky’ Musical Is Heading to Broadway
text: The new stage musical “Rocky,” an adaptation of the Oscar-winning film about a streetwise boxer from Philadelphia, is coming to Broadway next year, with preview performances set to begin in February at the Winter Garden Theater, the lead producers announced on Sunday.

headline: Self-Mockery in Movement, and Divination in Ritual
text: What connects the choreographers Souleymane Badolo and Cynthia Oliver? He was born and raised in Burkina Faso. She was born in the Bronx but raised in the Virgin Islands. Whatever African heritage they might have in common, it seems a thin pretext for their sharing a program. But so it was at New York Live Arts on Thursday.

headline: Here’s to the First 48, in Lessons of Word and Song
text: During one section of “Gabriel’s Guide to the 48 States,” which received its New York premiere at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra stood and sang a sacred harp hymn, a genre of a cappella choral music that evolved in the South. The excerpt came under the heading “Alabama,” one stop on a musical voyage from the young composer Gabriel Kahane that was commissioned by Orpheus to celebrate its 40th anniversary this year.

headline: Giving a Wide Berth to Artists of Cable TV
text: We used to turn on the television to see people who were happier, funnier, prettier versions of ourselves. But at the turn of the century, something fundamental changed and we began to see scarier, crazier, darker forms of the American way of life.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Attention, Audience; Attention, Shoppers
text: LOS ANGELES — Is “Scatter My Ashes at Bergdorf’s” a film or an ad?

headline: Stormy Relationship, Forgiving Followers
text: As Rihanna, one of the pop world’s most successful women, goes from arena to sold-out arena on her latest tour — which was to hit the Prudential Center in Newark on Sunday night and head to the Barclays Center in Brooklyn this weekend — the news media and her fans have been eager for updates on her relationship with the singer Chris Brown.

headline: Man Refusing to Testify Before Grand Jury in Times Square Bombing Case
text: A Brooklyn man has said that he will refuse to testify before a federal grand jury that is believed to be looking into the explosion of a homemade bomb in Times Square in 2008, setting the stage for a confrontation that could send him to jail for contempt of court.

headline: Once Upon a Landscape
text: When the artist Carol Bove was a girl, growing up in Berkeley, Calif., she once helped a friend of her father’s build a fish-shaped junk sculpture on the mud flats of nearby Emeryville, in a kind of guerrilla art park that free-spirited sculptors kept alive and weird for decades beginning in the 1960s.

headline: Admitted at the Door
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — C.W. Stewart has laid out a feast for us today, except that we’re going to have to pry it out of the fingers of some well-known movie stars. I’m up for it if you are.

headline: Kenneth I. Appel, Mathematician Who Harnessed Computer Power, Dies at 80
text: Kenneth I. Appel, who helped usher the venerable mathematical proof into the computer age, solving a longstanding problem concerning colors on a map with the help of an I.B.M. computer making billions of decisions, died on April 19 in Dover, N.H. He was 80.

headline: NBC Renews 5 Dramas
text: NBC really does have a batch of shows that are working, despite a rough patch this spring that even induced a presidential-level joke on Saturday night. Last week NBC announced it was renewing five drama series, including two, “Revolution” and “Chicago Fire,” that the network introduced this season. “Grimm,” arguably the network’s most reliable drama, was another show that was renewed; it holds up Friday night for the network and has experienced a ratings increase of 14 percent this season. The ratings for “Law & Order Special Victims Unit” have descended to just about survival level, but that show will return in a move that has been a ritual for the network for 15 years. “Parenthood,” the well-regarded family drama that performed well this year (up 8 percent), had been truncated to only 15 episodes, a sign that the network did not have the most faith in its endurance before this season started. That was also a sign that cost was a factor in considering its fate: “Parenthood” has a big budget and an enormous cast, with several star-name actors, including Lauren Graham, Peter Krause and Dax Shepard. A renewal order had been in some doubt until last week because of those budget concerns, but NBC announced that “Parenthood” would be back and with a full order of 22 episodes. The NBC announcement didn’t stop President Obama from taking a little shot at the network’s prime-time woes at the White House Correspondents’ Dinner on Saturday night. Joking about his recent performance at a basketball demonstration, the president said: “I took 22 shots and made 2 of them. That’s right, 2 hits and 20 misses. The executives at NBC asked, ‘What’s your secret?’ ”

headline: American Academy Announces Newest Class
text: The American Academy of Arts and Sciences announced on Wednesday that Bruce Springsteen, Pete Seeger and Herbie Hancock would be among the 198 newly elected members of its 2013 class. Among the other artists, writers, scientists and philanthropists who will be inducted in a ceremony scheduled for Oct. 12 in Cambridge, Mass., are Robert De Niro and Sally Field; the poets Annie Dillard and Natasha Trethewey; and the filmmaker Jonas Mekas, a co-founder of the Anthology Film Archives in Manhattan.

headline: With Bags of Cash, C.I.A. Seeks Influence in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — For more than a decade, wads of American dollars packed into suitcases, backpacks and, on occasion, plastic shopping bags have been dropped off every month or so at the offices of Afghanistan’s president — courtesy of the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Sudan Says It Took Back Town Struck by Rebels
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Sudan’s government said that its troops had regained control of a town attacked by members of a rebel alliance, but some of the town’s residents lashed out at local officials for failing to provide adequate security, state media and witnesses said Sunday.

headline: Court Ruling Takes a Stand on Essential High-Tech Patents
text: The high-tech patents wars are fed by the value of patents as weapons for extracting rich sums from companies and competitors.

headline: Beastie Boys Sign a Memoir Deal
text: If the Beastie Boys wrote a book, you might expect it to depart from standard memoir form. Rather than a strict narrative patiently winding its way from bygone days, such a book might — in keeping with the group’s hypereclectic style — be a pastiche of voices, images, irreverent humor and pop-culture reference points.

headline: On Borges, Particles and the Paradox of the Perceived
text: In 1927 a young German physicist published a paper that would turn the scientific world on its head. Until that time, classical physics had assumed that when a particle’s position and velocity were known, its future trajectory could be calculated. Werner Heisenberg demonstrated that this condition was actually impossible: we cannot know with precision both a particle’s location and its velocity, and the more precisely we know the one, the less we can know the other. Five years later he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for having laid the foundations of quantum physics.

headline: Iraq Revokes Licenses of Al Jazeera and 9 Other TV Channels
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s government on Sunday revoked the operating licenses of Al Jazeera and nine other television channels, saying that they were inciting sectarian conflict. All but one of the channels are aligned with Sunni financial backers, and the move was widely perceived as a crackdown on dissent by the Shiite-led government that is facing an increasingly violent Sunni uprising.

headline: During Jury Selection, Trying to Erase Politics From a Politicized Fraud Trial
text: As jury selection began two weeks ago in the fraud trial of two former associates of John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller who is now running for mayor, the judge sought to weed out potential bias or other disqualifying factors.

headline: Israel Says It Is Not Seeking U.S. Intervention in Syria

headline: Calling 911 Shouldn’t Lead to Jail
text: PARENTS of drug-addicted kids learn the hard way that when we think things can’t get worse, they do. As a teenager, my son, Nic, was addicted to methamphetamine, heroin and other drugs. At 20, he had used most of the illicit drugs known to man. But one night, partying with a couple of friends in his basement apartment in Brooklyn, the combination and volume caused him to overdose. One of his friends called 911.

headline: The Story of Our Time
text: Those of us who have spent years arguing against premature fiscal austerity have just had a good two weeks. Academic studies that supposedly justified austerity have lost credibility; hard-liners in the European Commission and elsewhere have softened their rhetoric. The tone of the conversation has definitely changed.

headline: A Haven for the Deaf Draws Federal Scrutiny Over Potential Discrimination
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — When the subsidized housing complex for senior citizens opened its doors here last year, it already had a waiting list. Designed by a deaf architect to fit the needs of the deaf, its units have video phones and lights that flash when the phone or the doorbell rings. Wiring in common areas pipes announcements made through loudspeakers into residents’ hearing aids.

headline: Predatory Lenders
text: Federal banking regulators are clamping down on the small but growing number of banks that emulate the predatory practices of storefront payday lenders. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency last week proposed solid new guidelines for the banks they oversee. The Federal Reserve, which oversees other banks that do this, needs to pick up this same theme and follow suit.

headline: Wins and Losses in the Fight Against Tobacco
text: Cigarette packages are unlikely to carry graphic warning labels anytime soon as a result of separate actions by the Supreme Court and the Food and Drug Administration. That is a setback, though perhaps temporary, for the federal government’s campaign to reduce the health damage caused by this highly lethal product. The silver lining is that the Supreme Court left intact most of the F.D.A.’s powers to regulate this industry.

headline: Erasing History
text: One of my favorite coffee-table books is an odd volume called “The Commissar Vanishes,” a portfolio of doctored photographs from Stalin’s Russia. When Stalin purged one of his fellow Bolsheviks, the comrade who fell from favor was duly cropped or airbrushed out of official photographs. “The Commissar Vanishes” juxtaposes the before and after. Here is the party stalwart grinning alongside Lenin in Red Square; and now — poof! — he’s gone. Person, un-person. History, un-history.

headline: Congressional Restraints on Gun Safety
text: One of the cynical arguments that Senate members recently invoked in ducking their responsibility to enact stronger gun controls was that the government first needed to enforce laws already on the books. The hollow, Catch-22 reality of this position has been underlined by a new inspector general’s report pointing out that a severely understaffed and underfinanced federal firearms agency failed to inspect nearly 60 percent of the nation’s 125,000 licensed gun dealers in the last five years.

headline: Next Steps on Military Sexual Assaults
text: In the last big health survey of active-duty American military personnel, conducted in 2011 and released last week, one in five female service members said they had been subjected to unwanted sexual contact since joining the military. That shocking statistic squares with other alarming indicators of the military’s pervasive culture of sexual misconduct. It also underscores the urgent need to change that culture.

headline: Donald Shirley, a Pianist With His Own Genre, Dies at 86
text: Donald Shirley, a pianist and composer who gathered classical music with jazz and other forms of popular music under a singular umbrella after being discouraged from pursuing a classical career because he was black, died on April 6 at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 9 P.M. (Bravo) THE QUEEN OF VERSAILLES (2012) The director Lauren Greenfield traces the lives of David Siegel, the billionaire founder of the Westgate Resorts time-share business, and his wife, Jackie, a former model 31 years his junior, as they embark on the construction of what is to be the largest home in America. The couple, above, plan to build a 90,000-square-foot mansion with 10 kitchens, a 6,000-square-foot master suite, a bowling alley, two tennis courts and a roller rink, modeled after the palace of Versailles in France and with room for their 8 children, 19 household employees and array of pets. But their blueprints don’t take into account the financial crisis. On the eve of the Sundance Film Festival in January 2012, Mr. Siegel sued Ms. Greenfield for defamation, alleging that “The Queen of Versailles” depicted Westgate Resorts “in an array of defamatory, derogatory and damaging ways.” Ms. Greenfield won the directing award at the festival, where this documentary was nominated for the grand jury prize.

headline: Van Gogh’s True Palette Revealed
text: AMSTERDAM — “The Bedroom,” Vincent van Gogh’s 1888 painting, with its honey-yellow bed pressed into the corner of a cozy sky-blue room, is instantly recognizable to art lovers, with his signature contrasting hues. But does our experience of this painting change upon learning that van Gogh had originally depicted those walls in violet, not blue, or that he was less a painter wrestling with his demons and more of a deliberate, goal-oriented artist?
