text: LONDON – Every spring, top financiers would mingle with royalty and guests like Madonna, Bill Clinton and Kevin Spacey for a gala to raise money for programs to improve literacy in India and fight AIDS in Africa.

headline: Guinness Record Holder Dies Performing Stunt Over Teesta River
text: Year after year, stunt after stunt, Indians have had their names imprinted in the Guinness Book of World Records, that official chronicler of human achievement that is often the gatekeeper of the eclectic and the bizarre. One Indian man has the world’s longest mustache, while another was once lauded for the world’s longest fingernails. Yet another struggled to retain his records in the book by attempting all sorts of titles: from writing on a grain of rice to stacking the tallest single column of coins.

headline: Noisy Courtship, Quiet Breakup
text: It was 13 months ago that the Jets welcomed Tim Tebow to the team, introducing him in their spacious field house at a news conference attended by more than 200 members of the news media that snarled traffic around the team’s facility in Florham Park, N.J.

headline: Scent Notes | Highland Breeze
text: Obsessed with W. B. Yeats’s epic poem “The Wanderings of Oisin,” the perfumer David Seth Moltz traveled to Ireland and Scotland to collect inspiration for HYLNDS, his latest collection for the Brooklyn-based D. S. & Durga. What emerged from his travels are three unisex scents that each evoke the lands in the Celtic myths Yeats drew upon: one is Isle Ryder, an accord of jasmine, gorse and poplar bud that conjures Finlaggan, ruins of a castle in the middle of a lake on the peaty island of Islay.

headline: Chrysler Reports a Profit Drop of 65%
text: DETROIT – Chrysler Group said Monday that its net income fell 65 percent in the first quarter, to $166 million, as the automaker spent heavily to prepare for new product introductions.

headline: Alibaba Buys a Stake in China’s Twitter
text: 5:32 p.m. | Updated

headline: Derby Dartboard: 2013 Race Preview
text: The Times’s horse racing experts, Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert, break down this year’s story lines and make their picks for the 2013 Kentucky Derby.

headline: Video: A Conversation With the ‘Traffic’ Screenwriter Stephen Gaghan
text: Life imitates art in a New York Times article that looks at the events that inspired Steven Soderbergh’s movie “Traffic.” The article focuses on a former Mexican police official who helped hunt down drug traffickers, much like the character Benicio Del Toro so memorably portrayed in the Oscar-winning movie.

headline: A Wire-to-Wire Ride on the America’s Best Racing Bus
text: The excitement of a horse race is legendary – the starting gate bursts open, hooves thunder, silks flash, legs claw frantically forward, the crowd roars, a horse’s nose crosses the finish line. In less than two minutes, a mini-drama is enacted. The stands are full of passionate fans, some who almost won and some who did and are on top of the world. Horse racing is a sport with a long and rich history as well as a colorful present. This kind of energy is a primal experience that most people only read about in books and watch in movies and television.

headline: The Protectionist Non-Surge
text: Update: The paper was by Eichengreen and Irwin, not O’Rourke — sorry, Doug.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Times: Eli Miller is closing in on 80 years old, and he’s still delivering seltzer to customers in Brooklyn. Why? In his words: “I don’t want them to have to drink that dreck you buy in the supermarket.” — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Weekend Gun Report: April 26-28, 2013
text: Jennifer and I made a decision a few weeks ago to stop writing a Saturday gun report and instead do a weekend roundup. One thing we’ve since discovered is that there are so many shootings on the weekends that it is hard to keep track of them all. It also makes for very discouraging reading, as you can see.

headline: Honda Recalls 44,000 Fit Sports Over Stability Control Issue
text: A switch in tire brand may be the cause of a recall of nearly 44,000 2012-13 Honda Fit Sport models. Tests conducted by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration uncovered a problem with the cars’ electronic stability control system.  Honda said in a report filed with the safety agency that the software would be updated on the electronic stability control, which it called Vehicle Stability Assist.

headline: When Chaos Is More Than a Theory
text: After a strange set of events, Monday became the day to pick through the rubble of the weekend.

headline: Immigration Reform and the Lessons of 2012
text: My Sunday column sounded some skeptical notes about the immigration reform being considered in the Senate, raising the question of whether an America whose native-born working class is facing a slow-burning socieconomic crisis is really in an ideal position to assimilate low-skilled immigrants at an increasing clip. What I didn’t say is that these intertwined issues — working class dysfunction and the hard path to assimilation — are part of why the Republican elite’s political theory of immigration reform looks so dubious.

headline: Billions of Cellphones Polluting the World
text: THE HAGUE — Once considered a status symbol, cellphones have become ubiquitous.There are  now 6.8 billion mobile subscriptions worldwide, 800 million more than at the end of 2011.

headline: Paid Sick Leave Has Some Business Owners Feeling Ill
text: When the advocates at Family Forward Oregon sought to muster support among businesses in Portland for a local paid sick leave ordinance, they found a sympathetic ear in Tony Fuentes. Mr. Fuentes and his wife operate Milagros Boutique, which sells cloth diapers and clothing for babies and children on Portland’s northeast side.

headline: The Economist Looks to Colleges for New Readers
text: The Economist magazine is headed to campuses around the country to encourage students, teachers, professors and others in the academic community to become readers.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: Was This the Worst Episode Yet?
text: Season 6, Episode 4

headline: For Jozy Altidore, 30 Goals and One Brand New Fan
text: There are certain moments in life where we feel truly humbled. Whether you’re a doctor, a teacher or a professional athlete, everyone has been in a situation where they are dealt a reality check and experience something seemingly bigger than life itself.

headline: Why Doctors Are Sued
text: What kind of medical error accounts for most malpractice payments: Surgical mistakes? Overdoses? Obstetric errors?

headline: Michele Davis to Join Morgan Stanley
text: Michele A. Davis, a prominent Washington insider, has been named to run the corporate communications department at Morgan Stanley.

headline: Justices Decline to Take Case on Alabama Immigration Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday declined to consider a case concerning a tough 2011 Alabama immigration law that makes it a crime to harbor or transport immigrants not authorized to be in the United States or to induce them to enter or live in the state. The move left in place an appeals court ruling blocking the law.

headline: What’s Important About Money to You?
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at The BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: ‘Clean: Overcoming Addiction and Ending America’s Greatest Tragedy’
text: The view that drug use is a moral choice is pervasive, pernicious, and wrong. So are the corresponding beliefs about the addicted — that they’re weak, selfish, and dissolute; if they weren’t, when their excessive drug taking and drinking began to harm them, they’d stop. The reality is far different. Using drugs or not isn’t about willpower or character. Most problematic drug use is related to stress, trauma, genetic predisposition, mild or serious mental illness, use at an early age, or some combination of those. Even in their relentless destruction and self-destruction, the addicted aren’t bad people. They’re gravely ill, afflicted with a chronic, progressive, and often terminal disease.

headline: Addict’s Father, Now Advocate
text: Addiction swallows lives whole, and not only with overdose, illness and concentric cycles of rehab and relapse. A less onerous but still tenacious kind of post-traumatic stress disorder may develop as well, with recovered addicts and their families compulsively reliving the past in private — or, like David Sheff and his son Nic, in public.

headline: A Life’s Work, Interwoven With Horse Racing
text: Shecky Greene. My family used to have a hat pool for the Kentucky Derby. Someone writes the horses’ names on slips of paper and puts the slips in a hat. Then you pay $5 and pull a name. That’s your horse. If he wins, you get the money.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Harvick Victorious at Richmond; Piquet Hits ‘Below the Belt’
text: Kevin Harvick found a hole in traffic ahead of him on a green-white-checker restart at the end of the 400-lap Nascar Sprint Cup event at Richmond International Raceway on Saturday night, rallying from seventh place to snatch the victory. Clint Bowyer finished second and Joey Logano third. Fourth place went to hard-luck Juan Pablo Montoya, who had appeared to be in the lead until a yellow flag came out with six laps to go; he was one position ahead of Harvick on the restart, but got tied up in slower traffic.

headline: Dukkah: Nut and Spice Mixes for Seasoning and Snacking
text: I think dukkah could be the next big thing.

headline: Stocks React to Social Media Mishaps
text: The Times’s Amy Chozick discusses the fallout of a hacked Twitter message that dropped stock prices last week and is now raising questions in the markets.

headline: Kodak Spinoffs Clear the Path for Emergence From Bankruptcy
text: Kodak said on Monday that it would spin off its document and personal imaging units to its British pension plan for $650 million in cash and noncash considerations, a move that paves the way for Kodak’s exit from bankruptcy protection.

headline: Made in Africa
text: From Ethiopia to Kenya, a flurry of local manufacturers and craftsmen have partnered with Western apparel brands to make stylish shoes produced and sourced entirely on the African continent. There are rubber-soled cotton canvas low-tops from Mombasa, suede tennis shoes from Addis Ababa and crepe-soled nubuck loafers that incorporate materials from Mauritius, Liberia and South Africa.

headline: Is 100 Years a Life Sentence? Opinions Are Divided
text: WASHINGTON — If people who are too young to vote commit crimes short of murder, the Supreme Court said in 2010, they should not be sentenced to die in prison.

headline: Second Thoughts About the S.E.C.’s Whistle-Blower Program
text: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: The 64 Mathematicians Puzzle
text: Physics professor Marco Moriconi has contributed a number of terrific puzzles to Numberplay including Gas Stations, Ant on a Rubber Band, Student Groups, the Five-Pirate Puzzle and Spaghetti Loops. This week we feature a slightly-altered version of another one of his favorites.

headline: Video: On the Street, Sketching in Pastels
text: The glories of spring are at a peak, and the tulips and hyacinths reflect the diversity of present-day fashion. The green of the trees is as fresh as the grass on a Swiss mountainside, forming a lacy canopy over all. Cherry blossoms are ready to bloom, and art students set up their easels in the parks. Women headed to a lecture on ecosystems at the American Museum of Natural History. On Earth Day, 100 young volunteers, all employees of Macy’s, spread mulch around the trees surrounding the museum and painted its fence. And what would spring be without balloons, their bright colors reflected in a red pleated shawl.

headline: Apple and the Debt Market
text: Apple may need to make its i.o.u.’s as desirable as iPhones.

headline: As East Midtown Girds for Taller Buildings, Squat Relics Endure
text: Barbara Connolly has rented an apartment in the same slender town house for 42 years. Her neighbors include three small brownstones, two well-worn stoops, a Halal Indian restaurant wedged into a narrow storefront, and an income-tax preparation company a flight up from the street. And also the Chrysler Building.

headline: Spicy Egyptian Dukkah With Chickpea Flour
text: Dukkah is very popular in Egypt, where it is made with chickpea flour, sesame seeds, sometimes dill seeds, and spices. I like to toast the chickpea flour. I use the mixture, which is adapted from a dukkah in “The Arab Table,” by May S. Bsisu, not only as a condiment for vegetables and bread, but also as a coating for fried fish or vegetables.

headline: Chinese Tourist Boat Heads Toward Disputed Islands
text: A cruise ship carrying Chinese tourists has embarked on a trip to the Paracels, a group of islands in the South China Sea that are claimed by both China and Vietnam. Vietnamese news reports said the ship left the coast of mainland China on Sunday despite protests against any such trip by the Vietnamese government in early April.

headline: As Jobs Lag, Fed Is Viewed as Unlikely to Do More
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is making modest progress in its push to reduce the unemployment rate. But that is not the jobs goal Congress actually established for the Fed. The central bank is supposed to be maximizing employment. And on that front, it is not making progress.

headline: ‘Curious Incident’ Dominates at Olivier Awards
text: The London stage adaptation of “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,” based on the best-selling novel from 2003, has won seven Olivier Awards – Britain’s equivalent of the Tony Awards – tying the record set last year by the musical “Matilda.”

headline: Jet Debris Near 9/11 Site Is Identified as Wing Part
text: Updated, 8:50 p.m. | Plane wreckage found last week behind a building in Lower Manhattan and apparently deposited there in the Sept. 11 attacks is part of a wing flap — not part of the landing gear — from a jumbo jet of the same model as those that crashed into the World Trade Center, the Police Department’s chief spokesman said on Monday.

headline: Triple Play: Week 4 Results
text: The Marlins’ Giancarlo Stanton found his power stroke just in time to affect two of our questions last week. He hit three homers over the weekend to become the answer to No. 1. And his two home runs on Sunday helped the Marlins avoid a sweep and score 13 runs in their series against the Cubs.

headline: With the Words ‘I’m Gay,’ an N.B.A. Center Breaks a Barrier
text: In 12 seasons as an N.B.A. player, Jason Collins has never been an All-Star or a scoring leader or even a full-time starter, but on Monday he shattered one of the last great barriers in professional sports.

headline: Cruz Breaks With Senate Tradition While Criticizing Colleagues
text: In his short time at the Capitol, Senator Ted Cruz, a freshman Republican from Texas, has shown little regard for long-standing rules of decorum. But on Friday, he publicly discussed the closed-door dealings of the Senate Republican Conference — and trashed his colleagues in the process.

headline: Next Big Challenge for Health Law: Carrying It Out
text: WASHINGTON — This month, a political organization aligned with House Republicans sent an e-mail to reporters attacking President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Hazelnut Dukkah With Fennel Seeds and Mint or Thyme
text: Some versions of dukkah, like this one, are herbal as well as spicy.

headline: Street Style: Neon
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of April 22.

headline: The Met and Israel Museum Buy Illuminated Jewish Manuscript Before It’s Auctioned
text: A 15th-century illustrated volume of the Mishneh Torah that was to be the star of a Sotheby’s auction on Monday was withdrawn from the sale and bought jointly by the Israel Museum in Jerusalem and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Widely considered one of the finest illuminated Hebrew manuscripts ever created, it was from the collection of the New York philanthropists Judy and Michael Steinhardt, who are selling their world-class collection of Judaica at Sotheby’s on Monday.

headline: Ralph Lauren Case Shows the Benefits of Cooperation
text: The Ralph Lauren Corporation’s settlement of an investigation into whether it made illegal payments and gifts to foreign officials shows once again just how much a company’s cooperation can provide it with the benefit of a slap on the wrist by the government rather than the trumpeting of embarrassing details.

headline: Emeli Sandé Bests a Beatles Chart Record
text: The Beatles fended off all contenders for half a century, but the Scottish singer-songwriter Emeli Sandé has toppled one of the band’s longest-standing chart records. Ms. Sandé’s debut album, “Our Version of Events,” has spent the last 63 weeks in the British top 10, surpassing the 62 consecutive weeks that the Beatles’ debut, “Please Please Me,” spent in the top 10 in 1963 and 1964.

headline: Freedom for California’s Indians
text: On April 27, 1863, nearly five months after President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, California abolished its system of forced apprenticeship for American Indians. Under the apprenticeship provisions of the state’s Act for the Government and Protection of Indians, several thousand California Indians, mostly children, had suffered kidnapping, sale and involuntary servitude for over a decade.

headline: The Play Date Gun Debate
text: Returning from a play date, my 6-year-old son tumbled through the door and announced, “Did you know so-and-so’s dad has guns?” The concept, in and of itself, wasn’t surprising. We’d recently moved to a bucolic town in northern Michigan where many families were recreational hunters. But the fact that I didn’t know any real details about the situation — whether the guns were locked away or who had access to them — suddenly made me nervous.

headline: For Nets, No Overtime and No Surrender
text: The Nets did not give the impression they were a team playing its last game of the season on Monday. They prepared as if Game 6 in Chicago was inevitable. There was no fire-and-brimstone pregame speech by a veteran teammate to rouse emotions.

headline: The Disappearing One-Handed Backhand
text: If you simply glance at the top tier of tennis, you might think the one-handed topspin backhand is alive and very well. Roger Federer’s is especially versatile. Richard Gasquet’s is downright electric. Grigor Dimitrov’s helped him nearly upset Rafael Nadal in Monte Carlo recently.

headline: Jason Collins Breaks a Barrier. But Will He Find Another N.B.A. Job?
text: Jason Collins, who played for the N.B.A.’s Boston Celtics and Washington Wizards last season, on Monday became the first active male athlete in a major American team sport to publicly announce that he is gay.

headline: After a College Decision, a Fear of Getting It Wrong
text: While everyone else was getting their acceptance letters, learning about their aid packages, and weighing their future college options, I spent the week doing something a little different: I visited Williams College, the school I’m committed to attend for the next four years, to try to get a taste of what my future is going to look like.

headline: Supreme Court Backs State Restrictions on Who Can Ask for Information
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that states were free to let only their own citizens make requests under their freedom of information laws. The court also dismissed a case concerning the right to a speedy trial for poor criminal defendants, after it had been briefed and argued. And the court declined to consider a case concerning part of a tough 2011 Alabama immigration law, leaving in place an appeals court ruling blocking the law.

text: Virgin Galactic's rocket-powered SpaceShipTwo breaks the speed of sound on April 29, 2013.

text: People waiting for Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to address a Congress Party campaign rally in Bangalore, Karnataka.

text: The television shows “All My Children” and “One Life to Live” begin their second life as Internet-only shows through the efforts of an ambitious production company.

headline: Teenage Years in the Stroke Belt
text: The Southeastern United States has a rate of stroke higher than that of the rest of the country, but it is only partly explained by known risk factors like high blood pressure and obesity. Now researchers have found a risk factor independent of the others: living in the Southeast as a teenager.

Chris Young, chief executive at DBG, becomes chief marketing officer at Alloy Digital. Joseph Gomes and Rick Kleczkowski, who founded DBG, are to also become senior executives at Alloy Digital.

headline: A Brain’s GPS, Eating Like a Local (Monkey), Weakness in AIDS’s Armor
text: Two Norwegian scientists on what a rat brain knows about location; new research into how some traveling primates take digestive cues from their hosts; demystifying talk of a cure for H.I.V./AIDS.

headline: A New Home for Health Questions
text: Thank you for visiting Consults. Because so many readers are eager to submit questions to health experts and reporters, The Times has launched a new online platform that replaces this blog: Ask Well, a feature of the Well blog. While older posts will remain available here in Consults, new health questions should be submitted to Ask Well.

headline: Dropping the Temperature to Heat Up the Crowd
text: NEWARK — There were so many moving parts onstage at the Prudential Center here on Sunday night: the dancers, sinuous and authoritative; the band, sturdy and loud; the large screens of various shapes and sizes that flashed images that changed with the mood; even the stage itself, which had a big rotating circle at the center.

headline: Why Burke Could Work in the N.B.A.
text: Listed at 6 feet, 190 pounds, Trey Burke will not be confused with point guards like Syracuse’s Michael Carter-Williams, who is 6-6 and 185, or Oklahoma State’s Marcus Smart, who is 6-4 and 225.

headline: A Sense of Where You Are
text: TRONDHEIM, Norway — In 1988, two determined psychology students sat in the office of an internationally renowned neuroscientist in Oslo and explained to him why they had to study with him.

headline: Massacre in Nigeria Spurs Outcry Over Military Tactics
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Days later, the survivors’ faces tensed at the memory of the grim evening: soldiers dousing thatched-roof homes with gasoline, setting them on fire and shooting residents when they tried to flee. As the village went up in smoke, one said, a soldier threw a child back into the flames.

headline: Lew Names Chief of Staff at Treasury

Patterson, who has served in the role managing the Treasury Department’s day-to-day operations since President Obama took office in 2009, plans to depart at the end of May.

headline: Charity Promotes a New York State of Mind
text: A charity devoted to helping the poor in New York City is playing up its roots in its first advertising campaign.

headline: Sarah Silverman Comedy Special, ‘We Are Miracles,’ Coming to HBO
text: At this point in her comedy career, there would seem to be few things that Sarah Silverman hasn’t done. Among the remaining items would be starring in her own HBO comedy special, but you can now cross that off: the cable network said on Monday that it had signed Ms. Silverman to record a comedy performance called “Sarah Silverman: We Are Miracles,” which it plans to show in the fall.

headline: The Exodus From JPMorgan’s Executive Suites
text: The departure of Frank J. Bisignano adds to an exodus of top executives from JPMorgan Chase in recent years.

headline: Afghan Leader Confirms Cash Deliveries by C.I.A.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai acknowledged Monday that the Central Intelligence Agency has been dropping off bags of cash at his office for a decade, saying the money was used for “various purposes” and expressing gratitude to the United States for making the payments.

headline: ‘Cured of AIDS’? Not Yet
text: What to make of all the recent “cured of AIDS” headlines? An American in Berlin, a baby in Mississippi and 14 patients in France are all alive without treatment.

headline: Both Sides Rest in Trial of a Philadelphia Abortion Doctor Charged With Murder
text: PHILADELPHIA — They are known as Baby Boy A, Baby C, Baby D and Baby E, all of whom prosecutors call murdered children and the defense calls aborted fetuses — the very difference in language encapsulating why anti-abortion advocates are so passionate about drawing attention to the trial of Dr. Kermit Gosnell, which wrapped up here on Monday with summations by both sides.

headline: Grid Cells: ‘Crystals of the Brain’
text: The  grid cells that Edvard I. Moser and May-Britt Moser found in the brains of rats generate such precise patterns that a review article the couple wrote was titled “Crystals of the Brain.”

text: Here’s a sweet little piece of animal news: a sickly beaver found three weeks ago along the East River was nursed back to health and released Sunday in the city by a animal-rescue group based on Long Island.

headline: A Rising Tide of Substance Abuse
text: America’s 78 million aging baby boomers are heading into retirement with more than their considerable wealth, health and education. They are also bringing into their golden years an epidemic of drug and alcohol abuse and mental illness that has yet to be recognized, according to a recent Institute of Medicine report.

headline: How a Fiat-Chrysler Merger Could Work
text: It took about a generation before Italian immigrants to the United States adopted the ways of their new home and shook off those of the old country. Italy’s premier industrial enterprise may do it in a matter of years. A spat over Fiat’s plans to fully acquire Chrysler, Detroit’s No. 3 car maker, could hasten the process.

headline: O’Connor Regrets Bush v. Gore
text: Now she tells us. More than 12 years after the fact, retired Justice Sandra Day O’Connor said it was probably a mistake for the Supreme Court to hear Bush v. Gore and anoint George W. Bush as president of the United States.

headline: N.B.A. Player Cites Representative Kennedy in Decision to Come Out
text: BOSTON — One bright June day last year, Joseph P. Kennedy III marched in Boston’s gay pride parade, waving energetically to the spirited crowd that had gathered along the route. At his side was Barney Frank, the gay congressman from the Fourth District of Massachusetts, whom Mr. Kennedy was campaigning to replace after he had announced his retirement.

headline: Credit Eased for Stay-at-Home Spouses and Partners
text: Stay-at-home spouses and partners may find it easier to get credit cards under a regulation revised by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Inflation Nation Not
text: Hey, does anyone remember the great inflation panic of 2011? All the usual suspects were issuing dire warnings about soaring inflation, and ridiculing the Fed for focusing on core inflation rather than headline changes. So, how’s it going?

headline: TimesTalks | ‘New Digital Age’: Preview
text: Google’s Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen speak with The Times’s David Carr about their book, which examines the impact of technology on society in the future.

headline: Electric Cars Rally on Connecticut’s Back Roads
text: WESTPORT, Conn. — “What a day, sparks all over the place,” said Leo Cirino, president of the Westport Electric Car Club, at the club’s EV Road Rally here, where on Saturday some 33 electric and plug-in hybrid cars took part in an approximately 40-mile drive.

headline: ‘The New Digital Age’: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces Google’s Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen.

headline: ‘I Thought I Was Bulletproof': William Friedkin Looks Back on the ’70s
text: No one had a decade of moviemaking quite like William Friedkin did in the 1970s. Starting with his 1970 film adaptation of Mart Crowley’s play “The Boys in the Band,” Mr. Friedkin, the Chicago-born and bred director, went on to make the 1971 crime drama “The French Connection,” which won the Academy Award for best picture and earned Mr. Friedkin the Oscar for best director; and the smash horror hit “The Exorcist,” which brought in nearly $200 million in its original 1973 release, and turned a generation of moviegoers off pea soup. But Mr. Friedkin finished out the decade with misfires and cinematic oddities, like “Sorcerer,” his 1977 remake of Clouzot’s “Wages of Fear”; his comic 1978 crime caper “The Brink’s Job”; and the thriller “Cruising,” released in 1980, which starred Al Pacino as an undercover police officer investigating murders in Manhattan’s gay S&M clubs.

headline: ‘The New Digital Age’: Five Billion
text: Part 2: Schmidt and Cohen explain their claim that five billion people will be joining the two billion currently online over the next five years.

headline: ‘The New Digital Age’: Permanent Change
text: Part 3: Schmidt and Cohen discuss fiber optic technology, and talk about the permanent societal changes that come with increased connectivity.

headline: First Active N.B.A. Player Says He’s Gay
text: The Times’s William C. Rhoden discusses the coming out of Jason Collins and how the N.B.A. player’s decision could ripple through the world of sports.

text: Part 4: Schmidt and Cohen reflect on recent advances in artificial intelligence, and explain how technology is transforming life in the developing world and in closed societies.

text: Part 5: Schmidt and Cohen talk about how Google’s “Don’t be evil” mantra has impacted the work they do.

headline: ‘The New Digital Age’: ‘Don’t Be Stupid’

headline: ‘The New Digital Age’: Terrorists

headline: ‘The New Digital Age’: Easy Activism

text: Part 10: Schmidt and Cohen talk about the role of established media in an increasingly connected and empowered world.

text: Part 11: Schmidt and Cohen discuss the core scarcity of attention on the web and the challenges content creators face in finding an audience.

headline: ‘The New Digital Age’: Vulnerable People
text: Part 12: Schmidt and Cohen explain what Google’s responsibility is to vulnerable people using their technology in repressed societies.

headline: ‘The New Digital Age’: Your Identity
text: Part 13: Schmidt and Cohen reflect on the future of personal identity and the problems that may come with increasingly visible aggregated identities.

headline: Charlotte Mayor Is Chosen as Transportation Chief
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama announced on Monday that he would nominate Anthony R. Foxx, a Democrat and the mayor of Charlotte, N.C., to be the next transportation secretary, saying Mr. Foxx’s local government experience would help him manage the nation’s roads, bridges and airports.

headline: Walkabout – 4/29: FAA Suspends Furloughs Despite Typos; Dreamliners Fly in Ethiopia
text: Furloughs Forestalled A typo kept President Barack Obama from signing legislation designed to end budget-related air traffic controller furloughs blamed for widespread flight delays. (CNN)

headline: Amazon’s Boom in Cloud Partners
text: You can tell when a technology is really taking hold. In addition to picking up customers, it generates other businesses that require their own care and feeding. And some of those businesses can illustrate how much more business is out there.

headline: New Doubts About Ginkgo Biloba
text: Millions of Americans take ginkgo biloba supplements to boost memory and prevent dementia. Studies have never found any solid evidence that ginkgo does any such thing, but it did not seem to be doing much harm.

headline: In France, White Trumps Green
text: Hunting for white asparagus in France, where the vegetable is a revered sign of spring.

headline: Seeking the Ardent Life, Finding It and Sharing It
text: Edna O’Brien’s fourth novel, “August Is a Wicked Month” (1965), displayed one of the best author photographs of the 20th century. It’s reprinted on the cover of “Country Girl,” Ms. O’Brien’s new memoir.

headline: Grim Economics Shape France’s Military Spending
text: PARIS — France will effectively freeze its military spending for the next several years, cutting nearly 10 percent of defense jobs while using more money for high-tech equipment, in a bid to maintain its ability to conduct overseas operations like the one in Mali, the government said Monday.

headline: Worthy of Versailles
text: MAGESCQ, France — I have come to regard it as the asparagus paradox.

headline: ‘The New Digital Age’: Give Kids Phones
text: Part 14: Schmidt and Cohen explore technology’s potential future impact on education and medicine.

headline: After Decades, Gillette and BBDO Ad Agency Part Ways
text: One of the longest lasting relationships on Madison Avenue, between the Gillette men’s grooming brand and the BBDO advertising agency, is coming to an end.

headline: When Killing Is No Longer for the Good
text: “Why, I can smile, and murder whiles I smile.”

headline: Is Talk of a ‘Cure’ for AIDS Premature?
text: Michael Mason and Donald G. McNeil, Jr. talk about new developments in the treatment of the virus.

headline: Two Clear Favorites and One Broken Jaw
text: The Pittsburgh Penguins and the Chicago Blackhawks were the class of the N.H.L. during the regular season, the runaway champions in the Eastern and Western Conferences. So there is no way they will meet in the Stanley Cup finals in June. The last time the top team in each conference advanced to the finals was 2001; before that, it was 1991. In hockey, poetic justice has nothing to do with the playoffs.

headline: Europe Bans Pesticides Thought Harmful to Bees
text: PARIS — The European Commission will enact a two-year ban on a class of pesticides thought to be harming global bee populations, the European Union’s health commissioner said Monday.

headline: Euro Zone Releases Next Set of Loans for Greece
text: ATHENS — Euro zone officials on Monday approved the release of 2.8 billion euros, or $3.7 billion, in loans to Greece, the country’s Finance Ministry said, paving the way for the approval of an additional 6-billion-euro installment at a meeting of the currency union’s finance ministers in mid-May.

headline: Ants Become Job-Hoppers as They Age
text: Ants change careers as they age, transitioning from caretakers to cleaners and then foragers, according to a new study that tracked more than 1,000 ants for 41 days.

headline: How Much Exercise to Work Off This Sandwich?
text: If calorie counts won’t deter people from overeating, maybe the threat of exercise will.

headline: Inside N.B.A. and Out, Words of Support (Mostly) for Collins’s Revelation
text: The public response Monday to Jason Collins’s announcement that he was gay was overwhelmingly supportive, at least among other professional athletes.

headline: Alabama’s Loss, Alabama’s Gain
text: Alabama’s attempt to enact its own foreign policy — a sweeping immigration law that criminalizes the undocumented and people who help them — has been knocked around in the federal courts, and has just been buffeted again. The Supreme Court on Monday declined to review a lower court’s decision blocking the part of the law that forbids transporting or harboring anybody who is in the country illegally.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Asian Festival

headline: Russian Bank Sells Shares in $3.3 Billion Offering
text: MOSCOW — VTB, Russia’s second-largest bank, announced on Monday that it had found buyers for all the shares it intended to place in a $3.3 billion secondary stock offering.

headline: Outside the Comfort Zone and Into Sketch Comedy
text: Amy Schumer, a breath of foul-mouthed fresh air as a stand-up comic, seems noticeably less revolutionary in her new series on Comedy Central, “Inside Amy Schumer,” which begins on Tuesday night. It’s primarily a sketch show, and what you get is the same sort of sketch-comedy roulette “Saturday Night Live” has been serving up for years: The good bits are hilarious; the others often kind of just lie there.

headline: Side by Side by Audience
text: The choreographer Anna Sperber is all about clean edges. She sets her new evening-length duet, “The Superseded Third,” seen Friday at the Chocolate Factory, on a long wooden platform. Shiny and gray, the horizontal structure is bracketed by two walls.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bangladesh, the Czech Republic, Syria and Gaza City.

headline: No Real AIDS Cure, but a Step Forward
text: The Times’s Donald G. McNeil Jr. explains the unusual cases in which H.I.V. has seemingly been killed with drugs, and what can be learned from them.

headline: Love, but That’s Only Part of His Story
text: When Paul Williams and Charles Fox were invited in the late 1970s to write the theme song for “The Love Boat,” Mr. Williams recalled during his opening night at the Café Carlyle last Tuesday, they took it to the singer Jack Jones expecting the television series to last for four episodes at most. Little did they know that it would continue for a decade and that the tune “The Love Boat” would become a staple — and running joke — of Mr. Jones’s shows.

headline: Where Foxes Are Wise and Humans Are Troubled
text: A majority of characters in Janacek’s enchanting “Cunning Little Vixen” are animals. In presenting this great Czech opera, first performed in Brno in 1924, most companies seize on the chance to create fanciful animal costumes and beguiling sets that evoke leafy forests.

headline: Jack Dorsey Talks Square and Wearable Devices
text: Many technology enthusiasts have had their eye on Glass, Google’s monocle that looks like something out of Star Trek. But the Internet-connected eyewear doesn’t really pique the interest of Jack Dorsey, chief executive of the mobile payment system Square and a co-founder of Twitter.

headline: Spending Cuts Threaten to Delay Research, Obama Tells Scientists
text: At a moment when scientists are on the brink of making breakthroughs that could significantly improve human lives, broad spending reductions that went into effect in March threaten to stall their progress for up to two years, President Obama told a gathering of scientists on Monday.

headline: A Reporter Eats and Drinks the News
text: Charlie Gasparino, a senior correspondent with the Fox Business Network and Fox News, is known (some might say notorious) for his dogged, determined pursuit of scoops on the titans of Wall Street. He is known, too, for his unusual habit of going on the air and chatting about what he had to eat (and drink) the night before. Mr. Gasparino, 51, met for a late lunch at San Pietro, one of his Midtown haunts.

headline: A Jazz Pianist Who Specializes in Disorientation
text: There were many possible points of entry to Vijay Iyer’s immersive three-part concert at Zankel Hall on Saturday night, but the most illuminating was also the most deceptively simple. “Maybe I’ll play a standard,” Mr. Iyer said casually, introducing a solo piano mini-set near the program’s midpoint. Then he began a murky, unsettled, slow-rumbling prelude, only gradually recognizable as the songbook ballad “Body and Soul.”

headline: New Generation Greets the Complexities of the Past
text: Charles Ives’s Symphony No. 4, performed recently by the New York Philharmonic, features music of such metrical complexity that two conductors are often used to keep order. Similarly, Elliott Carter suggested that two conductors should marshal the disparate elements of the coda of his “Double Concerto” (1961), which received an excellent performance on Wednesday evening at Zankel Hall by the American Soundscapes ensemble.

headline: A Blank Canvas to Create Smart Limbs
Level Global to Pay $21.5 Million to Settle S.E.C. Case
text: Level Global Investors, one of the largest hedge funds ensnared by the government’s insider-trading crackdown, has agreed to pay more than $21.5 million in fines and penalties to resolve its role in the investigation.

headline: Most Banks Could Still Profit Under Tough New Overhaul Proposal
text: Most banks would still make good money under a tough new piece of financial overhaul legislation introduced in the Senate last week.

headline: ‘Motown: The Musical’ Surges at Box Office Ahead of Tony Nominations
text: As Broadway producers and performers gird themselves for the 2013 Tony Award nominations on Tuesday morning, several shows are already fortified by strong ticket sales — so much so that Tony nominations may not make much of a difference.

headline: Occidental Petroleum Chief to Stay Until End of 2014
text: HOUSTON — Bowing to investor pressure, Occidental Petroleum on Monday announced that its chief executive, Stephen I. Chazen, would continue to serve in his position, but only through the end of 2014 to help find a successor.

headline: Obama Hails 150th Year of Academy of Sciences
text: President Obama helped the National Academy of Sciences celebrate its 150th year of service to the country by giving a speech at the group’s annual meeting today. There were some pretty nice laugh lines, including:

headline: Debating Age Limits on Tobacco
text: The New York City Council has taken up a proposal to raise the minimum age for tobacco purchases to 21 from 18, the strictest such limits in any major American city.

headline: $15 Million Gift and New Name for Community College
text: For prestigious private colleges, where donations that top $100 million are increasingly common, $15 million might buy naming rights to a new building or a laboratory. But for a community college, a donation of that size is both rare and transformative, and so New York’s newest community college is getting a new name: the Stella and Charles Guttman Community College.

headline: As Fliers Chase Low Fares, Fees for the Extras Add Up
text: YOU couldn’t hear the American Airlines gate agent mumbling into his tinny microphone about yet another delay at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport because he was being drowned out by the voice of the woman who makes those annoying security announcements.

headline: Table Talk | One Leicester Street
text: Unlike conventional hoteliers and restaurateurs, the Singapore-based Peng Loh, owner of Unlisted Collection — a growing family of hip, design-focused boutique hotels and restaurants in Singapore, London and Shanghai — opens properties based on one simple principle: opportunity. Rather than actively pursue new projects from the ground up, Loh waits for the right situation to present itself. And his newest hotel, One Leicester Street in London’s Chinatown, which opens May 1, is no exception.

headline: Your Brain on Computers: Readers Respond
text: My Disruptions column this weekend looked at a nascent technology through which you can control computers, smartphones and robotic arms with your mind.

headline: Privately Financed Spaceship Roars Closer to Space
text: For the more than 500 space tourists who have signed up for a trip on Richard Branson’s Virgin Galactic, Monday was a milestone: the day the spaceship that will be carrying them aloft made its first powered flight and broke the sound barrier for its first time.

headline: Are Doctors Nicer to Thinner Patients?
text: Are doctors nicer to patients who aren’t fat?

headline: New Albums From Iggy and the Stooges, Darcy James Argue and Kenny Chesney
text: IGGY AND THE STOOGES

headline: 100 Years Ago, Mayor Had a Ready Trigger Finger
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s campaign for stricter gun regulation might have been, well, gun shy about recruiting one of his predecessors, John Purroy Mitchel.

headline: As Election in Iran Nears, Ahmadinejad’s Critics Are Piling On
text: TEHRAN — Just six weeks before Iran’s presidential election, politicians and clerics have declared open season on President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and his government, in one instance calling him a “coward” and likening him to a “drunk driver.”

headline: No Comment Necessary: Spying on Muslims
text: Via The Daily Beast

headline: Tebow to Canada? Not So Fast
text: Tim Tebow, after being released by the Jets on Monday, is without a job, and his prospects of latching on with another N.F.L. team are uncertain. The Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League own Tebow’s negotiating rights. So, off to Canada he goes, right?

headline: It’s Monkey See, Do and Dance
text: Forty five minutes of monkey impersonations? Dressed only in undershirts and shorts, seven male dancers of the Cambodian Amrita Performing Arts institution held the audience’s attention on Sunday evening at the Guggenheim Museum with unfailing skill and charm. The dancers are all specialists in the role of the monkey from the Cambodian classical masked dance known as Lakhaon Kaol; but here only one of them ever donned a mask, and then only briefly. The production, choreographed by Emmanuèle Phuon, was called “Khmeropédies III: Source/Primate”; I’m sorry I missed the chance to see parts I and II.

headline: Philosophy That Stirs the Waters
text: BOSTON — On a recent sunny afternoon, Daniel Dennett showed up at the community boathouse on the Charles River ready for philosophical and nautical action.

headline: Diller Gives Bleak Assessment of Newsweek
text: Barry Diller, whose IAC/InterActiveCorp decided last year to turn Newsweek into a digital-only publication, on Monday gave a stark assessment of its chances to succeed.

headline: Alexander Graham Bell’s Voice, Animals in Space and More
text: “Hear my voice — Alexander Graham Bell,” the father of the telephone said on April 15, 1885, enunciating carefully, his voice recorded on a wax-and-cardboard disc at an experimental sound laboratory he ran in Washington. At the time, Bell was trying feverishly to develop audio technology that would best his archrival, Thomas Edison, who had recorded “Mary Had a Little Lamb” on embossed foil in 1877, according to the Smithsonian Institution, which owns a collection of Bell’s artifacts.

headline: Sacramento Kings Are Likely to Stay Put
text: The N.B.A.’s relocation committee on Monday unanimously recommended that the league’s owners reject a request to move the Sacramento Kings to Seattle, a decision that will probably keep the team in California and settle a contentious bidding war.

headline: Whose Art Is It Anyway?
text: The United States Second Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last week on a copyright dispute that pitted the photographer Patrick Cariou against the artist Richard Prince. The court decided in favor of Prince, reversing a 2011 federal ruling in which he was found to have used Cariou’s photographs illegally in a series called “Canal Zones.” The case might have broad implications for photographers and artists. As a photo editor, I can sympathize both with a photographer’s desire to protect his original work and with the concerns about limiting artistic freedom through the fair-use exception.

headline: A Too-Close View of Airport Security in Action
text: I’M a fashion designer and co-founder of Ankasa, a home furnishings company. I’m traveling all the time and really get a lot of inspiration on my trips to Asia. I’m there about every 45 days, and then travel domestically quite a bit, too. My wife thinks I’m on a plane all the time. I don’t think she’s wrong.

headline: Fewer, Bigger Travel Sites
text: The online travel search business is consolidating, as two of the biggest online travel agencies, Priceline.com and Expedia.com, buy smaller search engines.

headline: Video: TimesTalks With Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen
text: Bits live streamed a conversation with Eric A. Schmidt, executive chairman of Google, and Jared Cohen, director of Google Ideas, about how the Internet is reshaping people, places and things. Mr. Schmidt and Mr. Cohen are the authors of a new book, “The New Digital Age.” Click on the image above to watch the event, which was moderated by David Carr.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Hacking for Murder, and Talent Shortage Doubts
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: 50 Best Restaurants Awards Announced; Eleven Madison Park Is No. 5
text: Noma, a tiny rough-hewn restaurant in Copenhagen, has spent three years at the top of the World’s 50 Best Restaurants list, generated annually by the British trade publication Restaurant Magazine.

headline: The Warnings Behind the Numbers
text: On its face, Friday’s announcement that the nation’s gross domestic product expanded at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the first quarter was good news, following as it did an only marginally positive result for the previous three-month period.

headline: A Ban on Some Italian Cured Meat Is Ending
text: The United States Department of Agriculture will relax a decades-long ban on the importation of many cured-pork products from some regions of Italy starting May 28, greatly increasing the number and variety of salumi in markets and restaurants here.

headline: After Boston Bombing, American Ties With Russia Improve
text: MOSCOW — After President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke by telephone on Monday, a top Russian official said cooperation between the leaders’ intelligence services had “noticeably intensified in the past few days,” though he said Russia had not been able to provide valuable intelligence about the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing, Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

headline: Really? The Claim: Evening Primrose Oil Soothes Eczema
text: THE FACTS:

headline: Hoopla of TV, Wooing Ads to Digital Media
text: ANNOUNCEMENTS by giant media companies about new series and other programming ventures. Appearances by pop-culture personalities like the rappers Lupe Fiasco and MC Hammer. Performances by singers like the Lumineers, dancers and circus acts. Free breakfasts, lunches, hors d’oeuvres and drinks. Goody bags filled with giveaway items that include smartphone covers, computer monitor cleaning cloths and cookies.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,188 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Dreaming of Julia, a Top Filly, to Race in Kentucky Oaks
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The best 3-year-old in North America — based on any measure of past performance — will not enter the starting gate for the 139th Kentucky Derby on Saturday at Churchill Downs.

headline: Rangers Focus on Special Teams and Getting Healthy
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. – The Rangers practiced Monday for the first time since learning that the Capitals will be their first-round opponents in a series that starts Thursday in Washington.

headline: Fire on the Roof
text: A roof deck fire in Alphabet City was quickly contained Sunday. But firefighters fear that there will be more as New Yorkers look forward to warm weather, barbecues and holiday weekends.

headline: Bad Reviews for Patron at Restaurant in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — Andrea Benítez simply did what many rich, connected Mexicans have always done: she used her influence to step on the lower born. Witnesses said that when she was not given the table she wanted on Friday at Maximo Bistrot, a popular Mexico City restaurant, she called in inspectors who worked for her father at the country’s main consumer protection agency to shut it down.

headline: Blaming Europe’s Central Bank
text: FRANKFURT — There are certainly plenty of people who could be blamed for the economic crisis in Cyprus that caused worldwide anxiety last month. The potential culprits include Cypriot bankers who bet too heavily on Greece and a communist-led government that dithered as the losses piled up.

headline: How Sports Illustrated Broke the Jason Collins Story
text: The anticipation that a male in a major team sport would announce he was gay had been building for weeks, along with the frenzy among sportswriters trying to break the story.

headline: Steering France’s Economy, and Attacked From All Sides
text: PARIS — Pierre Moscovici protects his iPhone with a cover featuring a portrait of Léon Blum, a hero of France’s Socialist Party and three times prime minister, the last after emerging from Buchenwald and Dachau. Mr. Moscovici, France’s minister for finance and the economy, needs a good dose of Mr. Blum’s courage these days, under attack not just from the right but from within his own party.

headline: Housing Authority Is Sued Over Slow Pace of Repairs
text: To fix a water leak last month, workers cut out a piece of wall behind the stove in Pian Tam’s apartment at the Alfred E. Smith houses in Lower Manhattan. Then they covered the opening with plastic and told her that they would come back later to plaster the wall.

headline: Even VW Now Feels the Weight of Europe’s Economic Troubles
text: The troubled European car market is now dragging down even Volkswagen, the region’s leading automaker, as vehicle sales on the Continent have declined to their lowest levels in decades.

headline: Cervelli’s Positivity Faces Yet Another Test
text: The way Francisco Cervelli was calculating it Monday afternoon, he had five weeks and five days until he could return from a broken finger. But who’s counting?

headline: Janos Starker, Master of the Cello, Dies at 88
text: Janos Starker, one of the 20th century’s most renowned cellists, whose restrained onstage elegance was amply matched by the cyclone of Scotch, cigarettes and opinion that animated his offstage life, died on Sunday at a hospice in Bloomington, Ind. He was 88.

headline: Day of Firsts for a Spaceship
text: For the more than 500 space tourists who have signed up for a trip on Richard Branson’s Virgin Galactic, Monday was a milestone: the spaceship that will be carrying them aloft made its first powered flight and broke the sound barrier for its first time. In a telephone interview after the test flight over Mojave, Calif., Mr. Branson said the craft would go to space at the end of this year or in the first quarter of next year. He and his children are to be the first passengers. Over the past two and a half years, SpaceShipTwo has made a series of unpowered tests, gliding to a landing. On Monday, a carrier aircraft lofted SpaceShipTwo to 47,000 feet before letting it go. The engine fired for 16 seconds, accelerating SpaceShipTwo to Mach 1.2 — 1.2 times the speed of sound — and pushing it to an altitude of 55,000 feet, about 10.5 miles. More test flights will follow before the start of commercial operations.

headline: Roof-Deck Blaze on a Warm Day Presages Summer Barbecue Fires
text: One minute, sunshine and spring blossoms were the only things descending from the sky, the next moment it was ashes, soot and fire-hose water cascading from the first roof-deck fire of the year in Lower Manhattan on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Preschool Financing Has Dropped, Study Finds
text: State financing for preschool fell by more than $548 million, or close to 10 percent, in the 2011-12 school year, the largest annual drop in a decade, according to a report released Monday.

headline: 7 Killed in Plane Crash in  Afghanistan
text: Seven people were killed on Monday when a civilian cargo plane crashed shortly after taking off from Bagram Air Base, northeast of Kabul, according to an international military spokesman. The police chief of the surrounding area, Ezmarai Nasiri, said the plane “crashed soon after it took off and its tail caught on fire.” There was no information late on Monday about whether the plane was carrying cargo or its intended destination. It belonged to National Air Cargo, a military contractor based in Orchard Park, N.Y., outside Buffalo. Military officials said that the cause of the crash was being investigated, but that there had been no enemy activity in the area at the time.

headline: Stiff Neck and Spasms Send Wright to Bench
text: MIAMI — David Wright was held out of Monday’s game against the Marlins with what he described as spasms and stiffness in his neck. Wright said he was optimistic that he would return Tuesday, but he used the word “hopefully” at least a half-dozen times in a brief interview with reporters before the game.

headline: Lakers Move From What Happened to What Now
text: LOS ANGELES — The Lakers’ off-season began Monday after a season so grisly there is no certainty that any player in uniform for Sunday’s finale will be back.

headline: Flow of Tainted Water Is Latest Crisis at Japan Nuclear Plant
text: TOKYO — Two years after a triple meltdown that grew into the world’s second worst nuclear disaster, the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant is faced with a new crisis: a flood of highly radioactive wastewater that workers are struggling to contain.

headline: Publisher Is Backing Off a Book About Cuomo in Favor of One Written by Him
text: ALBANY — HarperCollins is backing away from plans to publish a biography of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo by one of New York’s best-known political journalists, and instead has agreed to publish a memoir by the governor.

headline: Debt and Growth: A Response to Reinhart and Rogoff
text: AMHERST, Mass.

headline: A City That Turns Garbage Into Energy Copes With a Shortage
text: OSLO — This is a city that imports garbage. Some comes from England, some from Ireland. Some is from neighboring Sweden. It even has designs on the American market.

headline: Studying the Dark Art of Leaking Deal Talks
text: Psst.

headline: The Power of ‘I Don’t Know’
text: My friend Alicia likes to mock me by mimicking the tone of online comments on my writing, affecting the snarky hauteur that is the Internet’s default: “Kreider makes the audacious claim that his cat is more attractive than all other living cats,” she’ll say. “According to Kreider, pie is a perfectly acceptable breakfast,” or “Kreider would have it that pants are purely optional.” She’s making mild fun of my sporadic blips of Internet celebrity, but I think she’s more heavily amused to hear commenters citing her feckless goofball friend as though I were some eminent authority, solemnly parsing my passing opinions as though they were official policy statements. Alicia’s an artist, too, and understands how audiences tend to ascribe magisterial intention and control to artists, when more often we’re just making it up as we go, doing the best we can by deadline.

headline: Bangladesh Needs Strong Unions, Not Outside Pressure
text: BANGLADESH, my country, is again in tears. Last week in Savar, a suburb of Dhaka, the capital, a poorly constructed building that housed garment factories and other businesses collapsed. More than 300 have been confirmed dead, and the final death toll could well exceed 700.

headline: Clothed in Misery
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: Italy’s New Premier Puts Stimulus First
text: ROME — Italy’s new prime minister, Enrico Letta, said Monday that he would move quickly to stimulate growth and jobs, while easing some of the unpopular austerity measures enacted to strengthen Italy’s public finances and ease its cumbersome debt.

headline: Basketball’s Gay Paragon
text: I heard a lot of talk Monday about how “perfect” Jason Collins, the basketball player who just came out, is. Perfect as in straight from central casting. (Or maybe I should say gay from central casting.)

headline: Investigators Obtain DNA From Widow of Bombing Suspect
text: Federal authorities are closely scrutinizing the activities of the wife of the dead Boston Marathon bombing suspect in the days before and after the attacks.

headline: Technology Start-Ups Take Root in Berlin
text: BERLIN — Near the Rosenthaler Platz subway station here, signs of the city’s high-tech future blend seamlessly with its communist past.

headline: Jim Thorpe’s Place in America
text: A bittersweet restlessness has long been tied to the legend of Jim Thorpe, the Olympic champion and American Indian whose gold medal feats mesmerized the nation a century ago.

headline: A State’s Duty to Indigent Defendants
text: On Monday, the Supreme Court should have said that every state has the duty to pay for counsel for indigent criminal defendants and ensure them a speedy trial. The court should also have ordered an appeals court in Louisiana to reconsider its decision to uphold a conviction for murder and armed robbery. The court did neither. Its five conservative justices simply refused to decide the case, leaving the conviction and a life sentence in place.

headline: The Mayor Rethinks Recycling
text: On recycling in New York City, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has come a long way. After taking office 11 years ago, Mr. Bloomberg eliminated a major chunk of the city’s recycling program to save money. Many New Yorkers were outraged. He was, they said, littering the earth as well as missing a chance to convert waste to energy.

headline: Ill-Considered Advice on Syria
text: To hear Senator John McCain of Arizona and Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina tell it, the way forward on Syria is clear. The United States should be doing more — directly arming the rebels seeking overthrow President Bashar al-Assad, establishing a no-fly zone. This is not a new line for these two legislators and others in Congress who share their views. But it has gathered force since the Obama administration disclosed last week that it believes Mr. Assad’s forces have used sarin gas against Syrians.

headline: 5 Are Convicted in Kosovo Organ Trafficking
text: PARIS — Five people were convicted Monday in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, in connection with an elaborate organ-trafficking network that lured poor people to the country to sell their kidneys and other organs to wealthy transplant recipients from Israel, the United States, Canada and Germany. Organs sold for as much as $130,000 each.

headline: Immigration Splits Senator From Mentor
text: WASHINGTON — Jim DeMint helped makeMarco Rubio a Senate star — and he could be forgiven for regretting it.

headline: Engaged or Detached?
text: Let’s say you are a young person beginning to write about politics and policy. You probably have some idea of what you believe, but have you thought about how you believe it? That is to say, have you thought about where you will sit on the continuum that stretches from writers who are engaged to those who are detached?

headline: Lost Every Day
text: Meet a Colorado woman with a rare neurological disorder who has no sense of direction, even in her own home.

headline: Tim Taylor, Yale and ’94 Olympic Coach, Dies at 71
text: Tim Taylor, who was the winningest coach in the history of Yale University hockey and coached the 1994 United States Olympic team and four national teams in the world championships, died on Saturday in Branford, Conn. He was 71.

headline: ‘Lost Every Day’
text: Many people, myself included, have a gnawing primeval fear of becoming hopelessly lost. This Op-Doc video examines that fear in a most extreme form. My subject is Sharon Roseman of Denver, who gets lost every day — in the streets she’s lived in for 20 years, even in her own house. When she wakes, her walls seem to have moved overnight. Her world can be transformed in the blink of an eye.

headline: Another Executive Leaves JPMorgan, Raising Questions as Vote Nears
text: 10:35 a.m. | Updated

headline: Once Again Standing In for the Mayor: Someone Who Wants His Job
text: As mayoral news conferences go, this one had all the usual Bloomberg trappings: a powerful commissioner, an Ivy League academic, an innovative pilot program and money from a private charity.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 29, 2013

headline: Fines for Agents Who Show Illegal Dwellings
text: The frenzied process of finding an apartment in New York City just got even more fraught — not for prospective tenants, however, but for real estate agents.

headline: Solutions for Syria's Refugees
text: The generosity of Syria’s neighbors is reaching its limit. What’s the best way to deal with the growing refugee crisis?

headline: The Detainees’ Dilemma
text: Fadhel Hussein Saleh Hentif is one of about 100 detainees on a hunger strike in the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. He was captured in 2001 by Pakistanis after crossing the border from Afghanistan, and, by 2002, he was in the American naval detention facility. He was 20 years old. He has been there since.

headline: Colleges Adapt Online Courses to Ease Burden
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Dazzled by the potential of free online college classes, educators are now turning to the gritty task of harnessing online materials to meet the toughest challenges in American higher education: giving more students access to college, and helping them graduate on time.

headline: Wells Shows He Still Has Bat Speed in a Fast Start for the Yankees
text: When the Yankees traded for Vernon Wells in late March, after a rash of injuries to their everyday lineup, it seemed as if they had put a price on their desperation: $13.9 million. That was the amount they agreed to pay Wells through 2014, an exorbitant sum for a player with a .258 on-base percentage the last two seasons.

headline: Adapting to Blended Courses, and Finding Early Benefits

But when a classmate was assigned to follow their instructions as literally as possible, it became clear that removing the bread from its bag was an important, forgotten step.

headline: All Puns Aside, Weiner Makes Lucrative Name in Consulting

headline: Former Governor Sanford and Rival Debate in House Race

headline: Mature From the Start, ‘Captain Serious’ of the Blackhawks Continues to Grow

He spoke in his familiar Western Canadian accent and with the same measured tones as always.

headline: Less Than Harvey’s Best Still Qualifies as Strong, if Futile

He reclined on a big leather chair, tapped his iPad and seemed not even remotely interested in making small talk with his Mets teammates.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) AMANDA KNOX IN HER OWN WORDS — A DIANE SAWYER EXCLUSIVE Ms. Knox is the American college student in Italy who was convicted in the 2007 murder of her roommate Meredith Kercher and served four years of a 26-year sentence before the conviction was overturned in October 2011. On Tuesday, Ms. Knox, above left, with Diane Sawyer, speaks in her first television interview since the acquittal. She also reacts to the recent ruling by the Italian Supreme Court that has extended her legal battle and put her freedom on the line again.

headline: A Conversation With: Director Feroz Abbas Khan
text: The 13th annual New York Indian Film Festival will open on Tuesday evening in Manhattan with the premiere of “Dekh Tamasha Dekh,” which was directed by Feroz Abbas Khan. The five-day festival is a showcase of more than 40 features, short films and documentaries, presented by the Indo-American Arts Council, a Manhattan-based nonprofit.

headline: Chinese Cruise to Disputed Paracel Islands Angers Vietnam
text: BEIJING — To many Chinese, the voyage of the Coconut Fragrance Princess, the first cruise ship touring the disputed Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, according to Chinese media reports, is about tourism: enjoying the azure water, sun and seafood of “China’s Maldives,” as the announcers on Liaoning Satellite TV put it.

headline: Groundbreaking Surgery for Girl Born Without Windpipe
text: PEORIA, Ill. — Using plastic fibers and human cells, doctors have built and implanted a windpipe in a 2 ½-year-old girl — the youngest person ever to receive a bioengineered organ.

headline: IHT Quick Read: April 30
text: NEWS Two years after a triple meltdown that grew into the world’s second worst nuclear disaster, the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant is faced with a new crisis: a flood of highly radioactive wastewater that workers are struggling to contain. Martin Fackler reports from Tokyo.

headline: DreamWorks to Take Its Characters to Macau Resort

headline: A King Takes the Throne, and a Nation Celebrates
text: AMSTERDAM — To the cheers of tens of thousands of people crammed shoulder to shoulder outside the royal palace here, Willem-Alexander of the House of Orange-Nassau became the Netherlands’ first king in 123 years on Tuesday as his mother, Queen Beatrix, ended a 33-year reign with the stroke of a pen, signing the act of abdication in an ornate chamber at the palace.

headline: 4-Year-Old Rape Victim Dies in India
text: NEW DELHI — A 4-year-old girl who was raped and dumped near a crematorium in central India died on Monday evening from cardiac arrest, hospital authorities said Tuesday.

headline: Is It Crazy to Think We Can Eradicate Poverty?

headline: Lesbian Daughter Tells Mother, ‘Address Wedding Invitations My Way’

headline: The Faces of Difference
text: TEL AVIV — I was impatiently waiting my turn to get on the Sunday morning radio show. The previous segment, involving two lawyers debating sexual harassment allegations against a well-known TV personality, went overtime after one of the lawyers asked, “Can I add something about the new currency bills?” “The bills?” the anchorman replied. “We will discuss the bills controversy at the second half of the show.” But the lawyer insisted: He just wanted to say that the notes’ design was an outrage. The other lawyer barged in: “We can agree on this.”

headline: Daily Report: Acquisitions Shrink the Number of Travel Search Sites

headline: Obama Considers Expanding Support for Syrian Rebels
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is once again considering supplying weapons to Syria’s armed opposition, senior officials said Tuesday. Such a decision would be a policy shift for the Obama administration, which has stepped up its nonlethal aid but stopped short of lethal weaponry and has expressed reluctance about greater military entanglements in the Syrian civil war.

headline: Unemployment in Euro Zone Continues to Rise
text: The euro zone jobless rate rose to a record 12.1 percent in March, a sharp reminder that unemployment remains among the region’s biggest problems.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’ Leads With 13 Tony Nominations; Tom Hanks Gets Nod for ‘Lucky Guy’
text: The new Broadway musical “Kinky Boots” led the pack with 13 nominations for the 67th annual Tony Awards, including for best musical, director, actor, score and choreographer, while its chief rival “Matilda” had 12 nominations in many of the same categories. The nominations were announced at 8:30 a.m. on Tuesday. The revival of “Golden Boy” had the most nominations of any play, eight, with the new Tom Hanks play “Lucky Guy” close behind with six nominations. Lead acting nods went to only a handful of the Hollywood stars performing on Broadway this season – Mr. Hanks, Laurie Metcalf, Holland Taylor and Cicely Tyson; among those snubbed were Bette Midler, Jessica Chastain, Katie Holmes, Scarlett Johansson and Al Pacino. Among the surprises were snubs of “Motown” for a best musical nomination and its star, Brandon Victor Dixon, for best actor. Fill out your ballot here. A slide show of the nominees is  here.

headline: Senior Congressman and Newcomer Win Senate Nods in Massachusetts

headline: Furniture That’s Simply Chic
text: This month, the interior decorator James Huniford unveils a brand-new Chelsea showroom and a sophisticated furniture collection, made up of the type of pieces the designer previously created only as one-offs for his high-profile clients. The designs, Huniford says, are meant to be “user-friendly” — scale and contemporary livability are paramount, and dimensions, as well as upholstery, are all customizable. This is furniture that inhabits that elegant territory somewhere between modern and classic. A tufted slope-armed sofa ($7,800) is refreshed with a casual low-slung profile; a campaign-style side table ($4,800) is cheekily updated with a not-remotely-portable stone slab and chains; and a two-tiered occasional table ($5,800) has a brass base with an industrial feel. “I like the tension between contrasting materials,” the designer says. “Metal and stone, wood and glass.”

headline: Jawbone Buys Sensor Start-Up for $110 Million
text: On Tuesday, Jawbone, which makes wireless headsets and music accessories, announced that it acquired BodyMedia, a company that sells wearable sensors, for about $110 million.

headline: Semiautonomous Cadillacs Hit the Road for Testing
text: It seems inevitable that there will be more and more cars with a computer rather than a human being behind the wheel in the years to come, and Cadillac has joined the race for auto autonomy. The company said Monday that it had begun testing a semiautonomous car, a vehicle that can handle driving functions without operator input in certain situations.

headline: Energy Agreement Hidden by Climate Disputes
text: This Twitter item leads to a Grist/Climate Desk piece on “Political ideology affects energy-efficiency attitudes and choices,” a fascinating new study in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences that, in part using light bulb choices, shows how polarization over the merits of cutting greenhouse gas emissions appears to torque the behavior of conservatives away from commonsense energy choices.

text: Young voters have become less idealistic and more partisan, according to a new poll conducted by Harvard University’s Institute of Politics.

headline: Tony Award Nominations: Who Got Snubbed?
text: Tony voters might want to lie low today if they don’t want to get devoured by Bette Midler, whose unrecognized turn as the superagent Sue Mengers in the one-woman show “I’ll Eat You Last” was perhaps the most glaring of snubs when the nominations were announced on Tuesday morning. Ms. Midler, an A-list star making her return to Broadway after an absence of some 40 years, was well-received for her performance as Ms. Mengers, a tough-as-nails Hollywood player, in “I’ll Eat You Last.” But neither she nor this original comedy, written by John Logan (a Tony Award-winner for “Red”), received a nomination. (Still, she’ll always have “Rochelle, Rochelle: the Musical.”)

On Tuesday, Netflix announced that it has scheduled its next original series, “Orange Is the New Black,” a comedy-drama set in a women’s prison, to have its premiere on July 11; and, as has become its custom, it will make all thirteen episodes of the series available for viewing at once.

headline: A Sudden Change That Took Years
text: It is a meaningful day in any world when you can stand back and watch progress happen. Thanks to Jason Collins, Monday was that day in sports. Here was an athlete in a men’s team sport willing to be the first to acknowledge he is gay. But the progress is what happened next. Applause. Almost universal, at least from all meaningful corners. A call from the president. N.B.A. teammates lauding his courage. It was like watching a generational change happen in five minutes.

headline: Not Too Much of a Good Thing
text: A reader sent me an e-mail expressing outrage that I should blithely sing the praises of ramps in my column without any mention of their imminent demise. Calling it an idiotic, irresponsible piece of journalism, he said I should be ashamed. Clearly, by urging cooks to savor ramps, I was simply another ignorant foodie who thinks wild-foraged food is there for the picking in vast unlimited quantities, and I had not done my research. How dare I suggest that the woods were full of ramps?

headline: Feeling For | Harry Winston Sunflower Collection
text: The late jeweler Harry Winston was quoted as saying (in a 1954 article in The New Yorker) that fine jewelry represents “what man has done to perfect nature.” In the jewelry house’s latest interpretation of the sunflower, which is being introduced this week, his words ring true. Drawing inspiration from the motif initially conceived in the 1950s as a one-of-a-kind high jewelry piece, the current iteration features a central diamond (the seeds) flanked by smaller diamonds (the petals), all of which is set in platinum. The collection includes a pendant necklace, drop earrings and studs. Also sprouting this spring are colorful versions of the sunflower earring, featuring a ruby, sapphire or emerald center stone.

text: Jennifer and I are both traveling today so we will dispense with the usual introduction. Here is our typically grim Gun Report, which, when you think about it, needs no introduction.

headline: Humbled by the Souvenirs of War
text: I usually forget about most dreams right after I wake, but I never forget the ones that involve combat. I collect those dreams and save them, locking them in a fortified mental safe I rarely open because the images may turn into nightmares. The war dreams are the pictures I never took. They are the souvenirs of war, the thoughts that continue to humble me. Some people might think that remembering such experiences would have destructive side effects. But for me, the dreams are a reminder of how valuable life is.

headline: A Compelling Gamay to Accompany an Omelet
text: Pairing decisions are part analytical and, importantly, part emotional. Almost nothing will go better with this creamy, pungent, savory ramp omelet by David Tanis than those two amplifiers of umami, fino sherry and Champagne. That’s the rational choice, yet what I want most is gamay, the grape of Beaujolais. Why? Back in the old days, when being able to prepare a perfect omelet was considered evidence of cooking ability, my custom for my first meal on any trip to France was to stop in at a cafe or bar à vin for an omelet, with a glass of the easygoing house Beaujolais. For me, this combination was comfort and beauty. Nowadays, I might choose a gamay from the Loire Valley, or one of the few American versions, like Edmunds St. John’s, which I think come closer to those lighthearted yet compelling wines. The rational choice? Maybe not, but it sure felt like a great one.
