headline: Opening Up Paraguay’s Landlocked Guairá Region
text: The priest faltered a bit as he climbed the stairs to the museum, housed in an attic above a church in Itapé, Paraguay, a town founded as a Franciscan mission in 1672. My guide and I had roused him from his siesta by clapping our hands repeatedly — the Paraguayan equivalent of a knock on the door. Fumbling with multiple locks and a ring of too many keys, he finally got the doors open and led us through the neatly displayed, modest treasures. I had to read the signs; his eyesight wasn’t up to the task: A 1752 wooden figure of St. Bonaventure, arms outstretched. Nineteenth-century baptismal documents. Metal meal containers from the Chaco War against Bolivia in the 1930s. Then he stopped before a simple black frock hanging from a wooden beam. “First cassock of Father Severiano Nelson Vega,” I read, “blessed by the Monsignor on March 19, 1958.”

headline: Maria Shriver Is Returning to NBC
text: Nearly a decade after she left NBC, Maria Shriver is returning to it as a “special anchor,” covering women’s issues for television and the Web.

headline: Q. and A. With Jason Collins
text: On the day after Jason Collins made history by becoming the first active athlete in any of America’s four major sports leagues to acknowledge that he’s gay (see my column here), he hopped on the phone from Los Angeles to talk briefly with me about the reaction to his announcement, and the road he traveled to this juncture.

headline: Combing the Backside in Search of the Next Big Horse
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — As the sun rose above the iconic Twin Spires on Tuesday, the backside at Churchill Downs began to come alive. Owners and trainers made small talk with reporters, and fans lined the rail to catch a glimpse and snap a picture of their favorite Derby and Oaks horses.

headline: Video: The Art of the Leak
text: The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Lattman discuss the strategic use of leaked information in deal-making.

headline: Newspapers Post Gains in Digital Circulation
text: The nation’s newspapers suffered a slight decline in total circulation over the last six months compared with the same period the year before, but they benefited from an increase in digital subscriptions, which now make up nearly 20 percent of all daily circulation.

headline: Living in Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn
text: Tucked in the south-western corner of Brooklyn along the Verrazano Narrows, the community has retained its population and home values.

headline: A NORC, Up Close and Personal
text: Fort Hamilton, the square-mile-size southern half of Bay Ridge, which takes its name from the local Army garrison, is not a place that people tend to leave. Judging from the numbers, this magnetism has effectively turned it into a “NORC,” or naturally occurring retirement community.

headline: Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival to Celebrate Kronos Quartet
text: As part of its 40th anniversary, the Kronos Quartet will present Kronos at 40, a five-day program that will include 28 free performances on Lincoln Center’s plazas during the opening week of this year’s Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival, which runs from July 24 through Aug. 11. The ensemble’s programs will include 11 premieres (including four newly commissioned works), and collaborations with dancers, pop musicians and indie classical performers. They are also the group’s first New York performances with its new cellist, Sunny Jungin Yang.

headline: Cannes Adds Jim Jarmusch’s Vampire Film
text: “Only Lovers Left Alive,” a vampire film by Jim Jarmusch, has been added to the lineup in competition at the Cannes Film Festival, its organizers said.

headline: Routledge to Publish Porn Studies Journal
text: Pornography has made increasing nonclandestine appearances on college campuses, thanks to events like Sex Week, which has drawn criticism for spicing up educational offerings workshops with sex-toy raffles and lectures by porn stars. Soon, campus types will also be able ponder the mysteries of sexuality through a less obviously titillating medium: a full-fledged scholarly journal dedicated to pornography.

headline: Looking for Answers: Making Sense of the Boston Marathon Bombing
text: Overview | What prompts two brothers to kill and maim innocent people? Were Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev foreign-backed terrorists, embittered immigrants or just plain crazy? And can the United States government do a better job of preventing these events from happening again?

headline: Rolston, an American Hockey Stalwart, Announces Retirement
text: Brian Rolston, a veteran of 17 N.H.L. seasons and the last active member of the 1996 United States team that won the World Cup of Hockey, announced his retirement Tuesday.

headline: Bulls’ Defense Bears Brunt of Mounting Injuries
text: Few teams soldier through injuries with the pride and confidence of the Chicago Bulls, but even they were not be able to handle the mounting body count in Game 5. The Nets overwhelmed the Bulls’ depleted defense and raided the lane in a 110-91 victory, staving off elimination and sending the series back to Chicago for Game 6 on Thursday.

headline: Finding Gay-Friendly Tour Operators and Places
text: As more countries propose legislation to legalize same-sex marriage, destinations and travel companies are increasingly marketing themselves to gay travelers. But John Tanzella, president of the International Gay and Lesbian Travel Association, warned that not all those who talk the talk necessarily walk the walk.

headline: Report Cites Large Release of Sewage From Hurricane Sandy
text: Over 10 billion gallons of raw and partly treated sewage gushed into waterways and bubbled up onto streets and into homes as a result of Hurricane Sandy — enough to cover Central Park in a 41-foot-high pile of sludge, a nonprofit research group said in a report released on Tuesday.

headline: In This War, the Enemies Are on All Sides
text: “A Delicate Truth,” John le Carré’s new thriller, is anything but delicate: it’s ponderous, heavy-handed and obvious — everything that his wonderful early Smiley novels, which traded in moral ambiguity and psychological nuance, were not.

headline: Le Petit Paris
text: A wave of change is coursing through the French city of Nantes, bringing cool new eateries, hotels and culture.

headline: Health Care Law Is ‘Working Fine,’ Obama Says in Addressing Criticism
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Tuesday that his health care law was “working fine,” and he played down concerns that the law could disrupt coverage or lead to higher premiums for people who already had health insurance.

headline: On an Unhappy Anniversary for Seles, Wondering What Might Have Been
text: Twenty years to the day after Gunter Parche, a deranged Steffi Graf fan from Germany, plunged a knife into the upper back of then-world No. 1 Monica Seles at a clay court event in Hamburg, the footage of the attack is still hard to watch.

headline: A Brain's GPS
text: May-Britt Moser and Edvard I. Moser of the Kavli Institute for Systems Neuroscience talk about what a rat brain knows about location.

headline: Transcript of Obama’s News Conference
text: Following is a transcript of a news conference by President Obama at the White House on Tuesday, provided by Federal News Service. Click on a topic below to navigate to that section of the conference.

headline: Mexico’s Curbs on U.S. Role in Drug Fight Spark Friction
text: MEXICO CITY — In their joint fight against drug traffickers, the United States and Mexico have forged an unusually close relationship in recent years, with the Americans regularly conducting polygraph tests on elite Mexican security officials to root out anyone who had been corrupted.

headline: Carbone’s Take on Potatoes Anna
text: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tweaked for home cooks.

headline: How Are You Celebrating Queen Beatrix’s Abdication?
text: Subjects of the Dutch colony of Nieuw-Amsterdam, arise! After 33 years as your benevolent overseer, your queen has forsaken you.

headline: The Mediterranean Diet’s Brain Benefits
text: A large new study confirms that sticking to the Mediterranean diet — fish, poultry, vegetables and fruit, with minimal dairy foods and meat — may be good for the brain.

headline: Gotham Chamber Opera Announces New Season
text: Gotham Chamber Opera, a small, feisty company that has become known for its thoughtful productions, particularly of Baroque and contemporary works, and for casting promising young singers in principal roles, will undertake collaborations with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New York Philharmonic and Trinity Wall Street during its 12th season, which opens on Oct. 23.

headline: Larry David’s Comedy Piece Missed the Mark
text: About three weeks after 9/11, Clyde Haberman and his editors took a chance. He wrote and they published an “NYC” column in The Times that employed a light and humorous touch on the subject of the attack on the World Trade Center.

headline: Élysée Palace to Put Wine Up for Bid
text: PARIS — The dreaded phantasm of economic austerity has finally knocked its bony fingers on the door of the Élysée Palace, which announced on Tuesday that it would auction off 1,200 bottles of its finest wines, renew its cellar with “more modest” vintages and return the surplus to the state budget.

headline: To Satisfy Its Investors, Cash-Rich Apple Borrows Money
text: 9:00 p.m. | Updated

headline: How Immigration Reform and Demographics Could Change Presidential Math
text: We’ve designed an interactive graphic that allows you to make different sets of assumptions about immigration reform, population growth and racial voting patterns to see how the electoral math might change in the future.

headline: Saison
text: Inside the San Francisco restaurant where awaiting the next thrill is part of the fun.

headline: SoftBank’s Chief Talks Up Takeover Bid for Sprint
text: 7:50 a.m. | Updated

headline: Parental Quest Bears Fruit in a Kidney Disease Treatment
text: Reluctant to say it aloud, Natalie Stack wrote her 12th birthday wish on a restaurant napkin: “To have my disease go away forever.”

headline: The Republican Health Policy Trainwreck
text: A few weeks ago, Ezra Klein and Ben Domenech had a fairly detailed back-and-forth — culminating in this mano-a-mano exchange — about whether a Republican or conservative alternative to Obamacare actually exists. You can read or watch them go at it and form your own judgment, but I think the answer is pretty straightforward: A conservative alternative or alternatives, yes; an alternative that Republican lawmakers are ready to vote for, no.

headline: Reunited Neutral Milk Hotel Announces Limited Tour Dates
text: Neutral Milk Hotel, the 1990s indie-rock band known for its experimental sound, obscure lyrics and cult following, is reuniting for the first time in over a decade for a series of shows next fall, the band announced on its Web site.

headline: The Long Wait for Wage Protections
text: More than three million home health aides — a lifeline for the elderly who are neither in institutions nor able to manage life’s mundane tasks on their own — are learning exactly how sclerotic the nation’s regulatory processes can be.

headline: Critics of Police Would Make New Yorkers Less Safe, Bloomberg Says
text: With criticism of the police infusing the Democratic race to succeed him, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday offered a staunch defense of the New York Police Department, as well as a spirited attack against its critics.

headline: The Restaurant Critic Hits the Road
text: My restaurant review this week tackles Saison, a tasting-menu restaurant in San Francisco that makes extraordinary demands on diners and rewards them with cooking that is at least as extraordinary. I had mixed feelings about the place a year ago, but my second meal there, early this spring, was one of the most compelling I’ve had on the job.

headline: Before Rewards, Demands
text: SAN FRANCISCO — One of the most compelling meals I’ve had on the job was served to me early this spring by a restaurant here called Saison. About a year ago, I had one of the most maddening meals in my career, also at Saison.

headline: In a Newsy Month, CNN Gets a Big Bounce, Fox News a Little Bounce and MSNBC a Drop
text: Breaking news is always good news for CNN, and April’s ratings are the latest example.

headline: Missing the Big Picture
text: President Obama used the better part of a rare news conference this morning to explain why Congress bears much of the responsibility for three of his most prominent failures: the pain of the sequester, the inability to close Guantánamo, and the problems implementing health-care reform. There’s no doubt that he’s right, particularly on the first two, but the questions and answers this morning missed the big picture: By tying up the White House with short-term matters like these, Republicans and many Democrats in Congress are making it impossible to even discuss the overriding issues that will determine the country’s economic prospects.

headline: An Evening with Salter, Ford — and Bascombe
text: The acclaimed novelists Richard Ford and James Salter shared the stage at the 92nd Street Y on Monday night, accompanied by a surprise guest —Frank Bascombe.

headline: In Misdemeanor Cases, Long Waits for Elusive Trials
text: Francisco Zapata keeps a copy of the Constitution on his cellphone. So when the police stopped, frisked and charged him with misdemeanor marijuana possession, he wanted what that cellphone document promised.

headline: Next Concert Season at the Met Will Include Music in Galleries
text: The major shift of emphasis that the Metropolitan Museum made in its concert series this season, the first programmed entirely by Limor Tomer, as general manager of concerts and lectures, will carry at least through another season and seemingly far into the future, Ms. Tomer announced on Tuesday. She has largely abandoned the traditional series of classical recitals and chamber concerts in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in favor of nontraditional events related to Met exhibitions and, in many cases next season, actually taking place in the galleries.

headline: Stravinsky Inspires a Festival to Get It Together, Fast
text: The Trinity Choir, the resident professional ensemble at Trinity Church on Wall Street in Lower Manhattan, is not unfamiliar with the notion of big undertakings. In recent years this superb chorus has released a reference-quality set of Haydn’s masses on the Naxos label, made a Grammy-nominated recording of Handel’s oratorio “Israel in Egypt” for Musica Omnia, and sung with the Rolling Stones in Brooklyn.

headline: Before the Hot Flashes Come the Flashbacks
text: When asked why she wrote “Scrambled Eggs,” Robin Amos Kahn, in a Q. and A. provided with that play’s press materials, replied, “I went to a career coach who encouraged me to write ‘my story’ because he thought I was funny.”

headline: Union Chief Recommends Delay in Use of Test Scores
text: Warning that a new set of academic standards was on the verge of falling into the “dustbin of history,” the leader of a national teachers’ union called on Tuesday for school systems to postpone using new tests to evaluate teachers and promote students.

headline: A Sisterhood Against Terror
text: The former C.I.A. analysts Cindy Storer and Barbara Sude don’t have the cheekbones or flame-red hair of Jessica Chastain, who played an analyst in the Oscar-nominated drama “Zero Dark Thirty.” They look like the women next door, a reality emphasized in the HBO documentary “Manhunt” (on Wednesday night) by an early scene of Ms. Storer driving out of her suburban cul-de-sac in a station wagon with an American flag mounted in a rear window.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: May 1
text: Art is in the air, and on your dress; Piamita bikinis, inspired by a cat; Elder Statesman designer creates a J. Crew line and other shopping news.

headline: The Knick Fan Blues
text: After 40 years without a championship, Knicks fans expect things to go wrong. But William C. Rhoden says they should relax and enjoy this postseason run.

headline: Video: The Knicks Fan Blues
text: After 40 years without a championship, Knicks fans expect things to go wrong. But right now they should relax and enjoy this postseason run.

headline: Finding John Kerry’s Senate Replacement
text: Two weeks after the Boston Marathon bombings, Massachusetts voters will choose the candidates hoping to fill John Kerry’s vacated Senate seat.

headline: 3 Years After Bruins’ Collapse, Goalie Stands Tall
text: BOSTON — Tuukka Rask saw firsthand what a hot goalie can do in the playoffs: he can win the Stanley Cup. Tim Thomas did it for the Boston Bruins two years ago. Rask, a spectator in 2011, sees no reason it cannot happen again.

headline: Now Showing | ‘The Source Family’
text: There is a particular feeling that is both satisfying and unsettling when the reality of a legend fails to deviate from the fantasy. “The Source Family,” the subject of a documentary by Maria Demopoulos and Jodi Wille opening tomorrow at the IFC Center, is such a pure expression of an archetypal 1970s psychedelic subculture that it feels like an ornate and elaborate invention. More than 100 young men and women belonged to this utopian commune, which was led by a self-made spiritual leader who called himself Father Yod. By the time of his death he had 13 wives and was believed, by his followers, to be God.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Headliner

headline: This Season, a More Measured Tortorella
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. – You know it’s getting close to crunch time when John Tortorella starts feeling aggrieved. After practice here on Tuesday the Rangers coach was answering a routine question about team chemistry entering the playoffs when he embarked on an R-rated tangent that accused reporters of misrepresenting his relationship with Marian Gaborik, who was dealt to Columbus at the April 3 trade deadline.

headline: In Venture Capital Deals, Not Every Founder Will Be a Zuckerberg
text: It’s the dream of entrepreneurs to sell their company for millions of dollars. But the dirty secret of venture capital is that the dream can be dashed as the venture capitalists make millions in a sale, leaving the founders with nothing.

headline: In Central Park, Hunt for an Intruder, the Snakehead Fish, Is On
text: The Harlem Meer, in the northeastern corner of Central Park, has long been a refuge for city people looking to indulge their inner Huck Finns, whiling away a lazy summer afternoon fishing for bass, yellow perch and black crappies.

headline: Consumer Spending Without Consumer Confidence
text: Consumer spending is usually a sign of consumer confidence.  But that’s not the case in today’s fraught economy.

headline: Stormy Weather Can Set the Stage for Sounds Both Old and New
text: The Miller Theater at Columbia University has long been a hot spot for adventurous programming. But in promoting “The Baroque Vanguard,” the second of three concerts in the theater’s “Bach, Revisited” series, which took place on Saturday night, the presenters may have overstated its novelty.

headline: Navigating the Supermarket Aisles
text: Michael Moss, left, and Michael Pollan visit a typical supermarket and talk about cooking and the food industry.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Bangladesh, Syria, the West Bank and New York.

headline: Grandma Looked Good in It, and So Does Dad
text: It’s an ordinary day at the beach. Big Sis is primping in sunglasses. Grandpa is doing push-ups. Little Sis is pretending to be a ballerina and turning cartwheels. But wait — why is Dad slipping on a woman’s bathing suit?

headline: Pots and Pans, but Little Pain
text: By the time most Americans reach adulthood, the supermarket ceases to hold surprises. But Michael Pollan, one of the most prominent voices on food today, a man who knows the nuances of the grocery store inside and out, was struck by the sight of the cheese aisle.

headline: Credit Reports More Accurately Reflect Debts Discharged in Bankruptcy
text: When you file for personal bankruptcy protection and have debts discharged by the court, your credit report is supposed to be updated to reflect that you no longer have to pay those bills.

headline: Revisiting a Rossellini Classic to Find Resonances of Today
text: The 1950s are full of movies that were initially greeted, by critics and audiences, with indifference or derision, only to be hailed as masterpieces in hindsight. “Vertigo,” “The Searchers” and “The Sweet Smell of Success” are among the best-known examples of this kind of revisionism. Another, only slightly less famous, is Roberto Rossellini’s “Viaggio in Italia,” a film so maligned and neglected in 1955, the year of its American release, that it did not receive a review in The New York Times.

headline: In Performance: Deborah Cox
text: Deborah Cox, accompanied by Nick DiFabbio on guitar, sings “Someone Like You” from the Broadway revival of the musical “Jekyll & Hyde,” at the Marquis Theater.

headline: How Commune Became Cult
text: For anyone looking to teach a master class in brainwashing techniques, “The Source Family” might be an excellent place to start. Documenting the hippy-dippy lifestyle and hedonistic principles of Hollywood’s favorite 1970s cult — led by the self-professed guru and suspected bank robber Jim Baker, a k a Father Yod — Maria Demopoulos and Jodi Wille’s disturbing film is an object lesson in psychological manipulation.

headline: Juggling Primal Conflicts of Innocence and Sin
text: Mesmerizing, mysterious, willfully perverse, the Mexican movie “Post Tenebras Lux” opens with two scenes, one realistic, the other fantastical. In the first a toddler roams across a muddy country field at dusk as thunder booms and dogs chase cows, horses and donkeys.

headline: Rejection Is a Process
text: Beth Kissileff has taught at Carleton, Smith and Mount Holyoke Colleges, and the Universities of Minnesota and Pittsburgh. She is the editor of a forthcoming anthology: “Reading Genesis” (Continuum Books, 2013).

headline: Scene City: Politicos and the Stars Who Portray Them
text: After the White House Correspondents’ Dinner, a party hosted by Bloomberg and Vanity Fair.

headline: A Visual Way to Navigate Among Comments
text: When it comes to comments on the Internet, there are often two distinct buckets. One, a sludge of vitriol and anger toward the author of a post or story. The second, too many comments to navigate where the good input from readers is often lost in Bucket No. 1.

headline: The TV Teaser That Depresses
text: It’s only Tuesday, but we can already declare a winner in the competition for the Most Attention-Getting Press Release Teaser of the Week. It’s Animal Planet, which on Tuesday morning sent around an e-mail with this in the subject field: “The Search Is on for the Best Hooker in America.”

headline: Front Burner
text: To Taste: Aiding Animals, Veterans and That Sweet Tooth

headline: No Judging About Gay Players on Basketball Courts
text: The West Fourth Street basketball courts in Greenwich Village, known far and wide as the Cage, draw some of the toughest and best streetball players from across the city. And on Tuesday, as the sporting world absorbed the news that the journeymen N.B.A. center Jason Collins had come out as gay, the denizens of the Cage said, by and large, that it made no difference to them.

headline: In Defense of Education, Books as Armor
text: 4:31 p.m. | Update:  According to the organizers of the book-shield project, members of the New York City Police Department confiscated the book shields that were to be used for the May Day events at Cooper Union today.

headline: The Last Days of ‘The Office’
text: The sitcom, which paved the way for a new style of filmed comedy, will show its series finale on NBC on May 16.

headline: Ben Folds’s 24-Hour Musical
text: The indie-rock songwriter composed and developed a short work in one night as part of “The 24 Hour Musicals.”

headline: Four Musicals, Coming Right Up
text: Ben Folds, the indie-rock songwriter, spent most of Sunday watching people on the streets of New York and thinking about what might make them burst into song.

headline: President Obama on Guántanamo
text: Speaking at the White House on Tuesday, President Barack Obama said he would try to close the Guántanamo Bay prison. (NBC)

headline: Gray Matter in Moments of Triumph and Defeat
text: A new competition show on the Discovery Channel is searching among 10 people with very good brains to find the one with the best brain of all. But over on the National Geographic Channel a peppy little audience-participation series has been demonstrating that the brain is easily fooled and not to be trusted. How are our brains supposed to process these conflicting signals about our brains?

headline: It’s ‘Kinky Boots’ vs. ‘Matilda’ in Tony Nominations
text: Traditional song-and-dance shows about scrappy underdogs dominated the Tony Award nominations on Tuesday, with four — “Kinky Boots,” “Matilda,” “Bring It On” and “A Christmas Story” — taking every slot in the race for best Broadway musical. Serious fare suffered, with the gritty “Hands on a Hardbody” edged out for best musical and “The Testament of Mary” — a monologue by the mother of Jesus — quickly announcing a closing date after its lead actress, Fiona Shaw, did not receive a Tony nomination.

headline: Americans on Terror Threats
text: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News of Americans’ views on security issues after the Boston Marathon Bombings.

headline: A Field That Once Looked Bleak Attracts Young Careerists
text: THE allure of the travel industry as a career, recently seen as dated as a Pan Am stewardess pillbox, is surging as more people take jobs in a sector bolstered by renewed spending.

headline: For Healthier Flying, Pack a Pair of Walking Shoes
text: CHRISTOPHER BERGER, 42, an exercise physiologist and professor at the University of Indianapolis, has an uncommon view of airports and business travel.

headline: Plan to Do Work in Coach? You’d Better Not Count on It
text: WHEN you travel for business, do you have every intention of getting work done on the plane? If you’re in business class, you could be good to go. If you’re in coach, good luck with that.

headline: A Corporate Retreat for Team-Building, With a Taste of Wine
text: IT seems counterintuitive for companies to take their employees somewhere where the alcohol begins to flow even before lunch is served. But wineries around the world are increasingly accommodating businesses asking for meeting space, catering and even wine-making lessons for their workers.

headline: Dispatches From the Foxholes of Business Travel
text: FREQUENT business travelers are called road warriors for a reason — most of them have a collection of war stories, ranging from minor annoyances to full-combat nightmares.

headline: Craving Wi-Fi, Preferably Free and Really Fast
text: TRAVELERS hitting the road with their mobile electronic devices have three questions about staying connected away from home: will there be Wi-Fi, how much will it cost and how well will it work?

headline: Airports and Hotels in Emerging Markets Outpace the West
text: FROM Asia to Africa to the Middle East and the Americas, the business of business travel is booming in emerging countries. And it shows.

headline: Frustrated Air Travelers, the T.S.A. Chief Shares Your Pain
text: JOHN S. PISTOLE was named administrator of the Transportation Security Administration in July 2010 after 26 years at the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He recently answered questions about the agency’s policies. The interview was edited and condensed.

headline: In-Room Entertainment Turns Away From TV
text: LEN MARKIDAN, a 26-year-old marketing consultant based in San Francisco, is the type of business traveler who forced LodgeNet, the hotel guest-room entertainment provider, to file recently for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

headline: Premium-Class Service, Long Before Fliers Board
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Measuring the Benefits of Tech Tools
text: When I was a young reporter we could not afford cellphones. I remember waiting in line for a pay phone in downtown Mexico City one afternoon to call in the news about the auction to privatize the phone company Telmex, driving those behind me crazy while a copy editor on the other end patiently typed it into those glowing green letters of an earlier information age.

headline: Ethics Panel, Upset by Delay, Vows to Release Report on Lopez
text: New York State ethics regulators, frustrated that their report examining allegations of sexual harassment by Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez has not been released to the public, say they will disclose it themselves if the Legislature and prosecutors fail to do so shortly.

headline: The Art of Orly Genger
text: Images of the artist’s work.

headline: Poll Finds Strong Acceptance for Public Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — Americans overwhelmingly favor installing video surveillance cameras in public places, judging the infringement on their privacy as an acceptable trade-off for greater security from terrorist attacks, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Results of Poll of Americans on Terror Threats
text: The results of a poll by The New York Times and CBS News of Americans’ views on security issues after the Boston Marathon Bombings.

headline: Obama Ally Likely Pick for F.C.C.
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama is expected on Wednesday to nominate Tom Wheeler, a venture capital investor and fund-raiser in Mr. Obama’s presidential campaigns, as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, two administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Plane Carrying Mexican Officials Crashes, Killing 6
text: An airplane belonging to the attorney general’s office crashed on Tuesday in central Mexico, killing all six people on board, the authorities said. The dead included the crew, two federal agents and a prosecutor who were returning to Mexico City from Zacatecas State after helping with the arrest of people suspected of being members of the Zetas, one of the country’s most violent gangs. The cause of the crash is under investigation. The plane, a Beechcraft King Air 300 built in 1985, had unspecified mechanical trouble Monday night, forcing it to return to Zacatecas and delaying the return of the group, the attorney general’s office said in a statement.

headline: Times-Picayune Plans a New Print Tabloid
text: Nearly one year after The Times-Picayune of New Orleans announced that it would print only three days a week, the paper said it planned to roll out a three-day-a-week tabloid edition.

headline: Jailed Official in Ukraine Gets Decision in Her Favor
text: MOSCOW — Before she went to jail a year and eight months ago, Yulia V. Tymoshenko joked that she carried a toothbrush and a bottle of water in her purse in case of arrest.

headline: After Catching 15 Innings, a Day of Rest for Buck
text: MIAMI — John Buck arrived Tuesday afternoon in the visitors’ clubhouse at Marlins Park and declared himself rested and ready to play. Manager Terry Collins quickly scuttled those plans. There was no way Buck was starting for the Mets on Tuesday, not after he caught all 15 innings of their loss to the Marlins on Monday night, a marathon that extended into early Tuesday morning.

headline: Douglas R. Lebda
text: Mr. Lebda, 43, is the chairman and chief executive of Tree.com, a public company based in Charlotte, N.C., and the parent of LendingTree.com, an online marketplace that matches mortgage borrowers with lenders.

headline: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
text: The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that it would make the most widely known morning-after pill available without a prescription to girls and women ages 15 and older, and also make the pill available on drugstore shelves, instead of keeping it locked up behind pharmacy counters.
